reviews.review: beautufulll cusco. All my life I wanted to travel to Peru and see these beautiful places, and suspuesto Sacsayhuaman was one of those, 100% recommended, is a beautiful place in Cuzco

Recommended tours. I also recommend doing the tour sacsayhuman or sexy woman, as we usually say, since pronounce the right way is almost impossible, lol ... can also make the tour of the Sacred Valley, two very recommended tours when they have the day off, and if the agency tourbulencia much better.
Mysterious and exciting. How did they move those huge stones into position with joints that are perfect with no metal tools and no system of writing?

Endless views. Our group did not try to walk up to the top of this amazing place as we were nearing the end of our amazing travels throughout Peru and some of our group were having issues with the altitude. But just viewing the amazing architecture from the center of Sacsayhuaman was incredible. This is a trip to be cherished.

Really cool site. Really cool site with great views of the city. Huge stone walls. Could explore all day here. Recommend bringing a coat as it seemed to get windy and chillier when we got above the city.

Amazing work from the Incas!. This is a perfect half day activity to do staying in Cusco. The site is about 20 minutes from Cusco city center and many transportation can bring you there. It's really worthed to go with a guide so you get the information about the Inca's work, which is amazing by the way!

A top wonder. We had information about this historic place, but not doubts, it is one of the tops in the world. Easy to walk from Cuzco, you need at least two or more hours to enjoy this wonder of the incas.

Worth the visit!. We walked from the center of Cusco up to Sacsayhuaman - take care if you're going to do that, since it's quite an uphill hike and at a high altitude. But well worth the visit, even if the entry ticket is quite expensive (I forget how much we paid now). It's not very crowded, you get to walk along all the stones and see plenty of llamas!

Get there early. We got a taxi up from Cusco for 10 Soles and took ourselves around with our guidebook and additional information we'd picked up. Well worth the trip, but it started filling up from 8am so get there at 7am as it opens. Afterwards, just go to the road and flag down a bus to get back down to Cusco (or walk up to other attractions up the valley) - it's 1 Sole, then ask to get off at Recoleta to walk for 10 mins back into the centre. Alternatively ask to be dropped in the centre of Cusco and you'll be shown where to change bus and pay 2 Soles.
Amazing!. We had a guided tour of this amazing Inca temple. The architecture is just amazing. I could have spent much longer just wandering around and absorbing the atmosphere.

Very Busy Attraction. This is a very busy tourist attraction. I would recommend going with a guide or doing your research before going so that you understand the significance of what you are seeing. Also, dress in layers and keep rain gear handy as the weather changes pretty quickly.

Astounding !. The most amazing thing I've ever seen in my life ! Huge rocks cut into different shapes and sizes and then somehow they were able to fit them all together like a jigsaw puzzle and done with milimetrical precision. All done manually and there's no way to be any more precise even with the most advanced technologies ! Hats off to the engineers who built it !

Take a guided tour. This is an amazing site and it is quite large. A guided tour gives you more of in insight into its construction and how it may have looked before the invaders. How this was constructed without help of modern day technology is mind boggling. Also great views of Cusco from here.
An introduction to Incan architecture. This huge meadow with enormous blocks of stone created by ancient architects, seen against a vivid blue sky. Amazing!

Amazing place to visit above Cusco.. This is more than just walking around another Inca site. There are many hidden areas in Saqsayhuaman that you will get impressed. If you are not on a tour, try to find a local that can show you all the hidden areas of this place like the tunnel under the rock, the slide rock and more.

Nice day out while you get ready to climb a mountain or do a proper treking. Its is a very beautiful site just outside Cusco and you can get there with a taxi. Usually a tour guide will take 4h to go around but it can be done in 2h if you are in a rush.

A view and altitude to leave you breathless!. Well worth scaling the seemingly endless steps and hills to find yourself in an amazing Incan site with awesome views across Cusco. We climbed on our second day and definitely felt the altitude but once there you'll be amazed by the sheer scale and the skill of the Inca people. Loved it.

Mindblowing site. How the hell did they do it. That question kept on being on our mind when we visited this site. How did they carve, pollish and fit together these huge blockd of stone xith such precision. What a sitebthis must have been before this was being used as a quarry. A MUST SEE.

The Amazing Incas. This was an unbelievable site. I can't imagine how they were able to haul those gigantic rocks from miles away to this site. The rocks fit together like pieces of a jigsaw puzzle. After all these years it is still intact. Remarkable.
Peru Trip. Amazing ruins in Peru. We had a guided tour, and then time on our own to explore. The history and how these were built is very interesting.
Beautiful. I enjoyed this more than Machu Picchu, it was far less crowded and allowed for absorbing of the atmosphere and imagining what might have been had it not been dismantled by invaders
bucket list item. This was my favorite place to visit in Cuzco because it is a marvel to see how the place was constructed.

A must visit in Cuzco. We climbed the hill to visit the remains of Sacsayhuaman, and I had to stop several times to catch my breath. I thought that since we had hiked to the Sun Gate at MP, this little climb would be a cinch. I think the altitude of Cuzco had something to do with my breathlessness as well as my age (71). Anyway, once we were up at the ruins, we were amazed at the immense rocks the Incas had transported. A guide would have been helpful since so little of the fortification remains and there's almost no signage to help the visitors imagine the dramatic events that took place there. Still, I wouldn't miss Sacsayhuaman.

The Great Palace. This place was a very nice surprise. It was part of an excursion and you can see the enormous palace that was built for the great Inca to live. Huge stones that were carved and brough there, perfect shapes and incredible architecture, plus amazing views!

One of my highlights in Cusco . Only a short walk from Plaza de Armas you will find the gigantic archeological site of Sacsaywaman. It's covered by the bileto turístico but you may want to do a guided visit to truly take in the site. I didn't (because on a budget) but I read about it beforehand and the views only are worth your time. I spent a good 3h30 walking around, listening to music and taking in the views. It's hard to believe that only 20% of the site remains today.

Its a must!!!!. Beautiful landscape! Wonderful for walking and pictures! Its better if you goWith a local person or a guide because the history is interesting and amazing! Its included in the city tour! Its really closed to cusco city
Interesting Site, but..... After Machu Picchu, it was a bit ho-hum. Too far to walk for older adults so you'll need to get a taxi or go on a tour. Important site in Cusco and Inca history.

Impressive Incan stonework. There are many ruins to see.They all tell a different story. A guide or prior searcher is a must. We did not spend much time here, but worth the visit to contrast with the other ruins we have seen. The tightly fitted huge stones are amazing.

Lovely Energy Here. This is one of the most interesting sites in the Cusco area. Our guide shared a lot about the history and culture of this site. I enjoyed it a lot and will return, if I ever come back to Peru. Don't miss the cave! Scary!
Ruins on the hills of cusco. These are ruins close to cusco that are worth seeing very interesting and great views of cusco. Interesting to see the cravings up here
Spellbound . The scale of this place is mind blowing, well worth a visit with a guide or someone with knowledge of the place to point out characteristics. My words wouldn't do it justice

Great sight near Cusco!. I was impresses by the the sacsayhuaman temple, event though I visited the temple after going to machu pichu. The temple is a few minutes from cusco, and impresses by its size and constructions. Huge rocks perfectly combined to form huge walls. A must go when you are in cusco.

It spoke to us. Because the site is so large, we didn't feel overwhelmed by hordes of tourists.
We were able to wander around and emote with the place.
Well worth the visit.

sprawling site. This is a very interesting but its at quite an altitude and the climbs can be punishing. It is important to understand the nature of the place - we had a guide who gave us the background.
Underrated and worth the visit. This Incan ceremonial ground is gorgeous and powerful. Definitely take the time prior to Machu Picchu as it helps build an understanding of the amazing culture.

Don't miss this one !. I would recommend taking a taxi up to the top where you enter the grounds and then walk back down into the main part of the village. Stop for a cold drink along the way. Amazing views.This very sacred place is not to be missed, you can imagine the workings of this place from the ruins that remain. This was a "waring" spot, one where they defended against intruders of all kinds. More of a fortress rather than a Royal Sanctuary. Just lovely and so very close. For those of you with Great legs, walking up and back can certainly be done. It's really worth the 2-3 hours it would take. You can also hire an English or any other language guide right there as you enter so no need to read up on this to go and experience it. Great guides, very very reasonably priced.

Sacred valley site close to Cusco . We visited while staying in Cusco before the inca trail. We took a taxi from Cusco to Tombomachay and walked the 8km backdown to Cusco via 2 other sacred valley sites and Sacsayhuaman. Whilst there definitely worth the 10minwalk up the hill to Christo Blanco for great views of the whole city.

Average. To be honest, this site isn't that bad. It's just that I saw this after spending time in Machu Picchu and in comparison is not that exciting.It is a quite large and it is a nice drive to get there because it does overlook the valley.Other than than that, that is all that I can really say about it
At The Top. "SexyWoman". Great way to remember "Sac... " , our guide did a phenomenal job sharing with us the history of this ancient ruin.
eye opening. We had a great guide who opened our eyes to several possibilities and theories about this site. So fascinating.

Huge stones. This was our first exposure to Inka building techniques. Amazing how they moved and cut huge (multi ton) stones and fit them together so precisely. Easy to get to if staying in Cusco. Well worth the trip.

Impressive. Worth a side trip out of the city center to see the ruins here. Mostly left is the layout and foundations of the original site, the building stones having been taken to Cusco for use by the Spanish in constructing the cathedral. Fun to wonder about what construction must have been like with minimal tools. Great views of Cusco as well.

Impressive, google info first. When you're there, just try to imagine how absolutely amazing this place would have been when it stood tall! I had a look at information about Sacsayhuaman on a website called roughguides before going and it gave a good brief context for the stuctures you can see there. If you like old ruins and great scenery, check it out.

Very large and interesting!. This was a stop on our city tour of Cusco. We booked it through Inca Trail Reservations. We walked to their office and told them what we wanted and they made it happen. The tour bus was clean and had plenty of room, our tour guide spoke excellent English. This was such an interesting place, it was a little crowded but worth being patient for!

Impressive structures. Like seeing the large pillars of rock (steles) at Stonehenge, it is easy to marvel at how the Incas brought these huge stones to the mountaintop to make this facility (you are only seeing what remains, as much was quarried to make the other structures in Cusco). The archeologists are learning more about the site every day, so your trip will have more information available.

A must see in Cusco. The was an amazing place to visit. You learn so much about the history and culture of the Peruvian people. The structures are really quite beyond what you can imagine. The photos definitely do not do justice to the architectural beauty of this place.

Massive ruin, sort of the "coloseum" of Cusco. Located above the city, Sacsayhuaman offers views of the city, and a huge field bordered by Inca walls, featuring massive stones to the more common smaller terraces. Must have been a meeting place, and the day we visited the ruin was hosting a tournament. Was fun to see all the smartly dressed competitors. The scale provides an idea of how large and complex the Inca civilization really was - This is worth the walk -

Walking around the ruins. The weather wasn't great, but it was quite pleasant to walk around the interesting ruins of Sacsayhuaman. With the explanation of a guide it is possible to imagine how would life be back then and enjoy this trip to a different culture.
Amazing. This place is amazing!But when you buy the ticket is better to take the one that is for 4 days!Because you need more than one day to see it all!!!
good. Wonderful place, stunning work of architecture and engineering. It is a place where perfection of Inca culture note, every piece is unique.

Very different style ruins with massive rocks . The Sacsywawan ruins should be top of your list for Cusco. The massive stone walls of the temple in concentric rings sprawls across the area. Be sure to walk over and up on the stone quarry side to get the full view of the walls.

Amazing place well worth visiting. Short visit as part of a longer tour, but well worth it to see the overall , the massive boulders and to get an insight into the important part that ceremonies played in Inca life.

Fascinating place. Sacsayhuaman is a large, impressive site of Incan fortress and temple just above Cusco, with great views of the town as well. The size of the stones used to build the fortress is incredible. Plan to spend an hour or so wandering around, but bear in mind there isn't an awful lot of explanation as to what you're seeing.I did this at the end of a morning seeing all four ruins near Cusco; a bus to Pisac or Calca from Tullumayo (just south of Av Garcilazo) will drop you at Tambomachay; it cost me S/. 2. It's then easy to walk down along the road to the other ruins; about an hour's brisk walk to Sacsayhuaman. I then walked back to Cusco down the pedestrian path which can be found near the steps up to Cristo Blanco.

Great!. Really impressive Inca site close to Cusco. The walls of the fortress are made of very huge stones all fitted neatly next to one another. Take a taxi up and walk in 20 minutes back to the city.

agood way to fill half a day near Cusco. a bit out of town but a cheap taxi ride from the town centre.Don't forget sunglasses , hat and suncream as you are mercilessly exposed to the sun.A spectacular ancient inca site.We didnt ave a guide which in hindsight would have been much better.We were upset at the high cost of PEN 70 each ( peruvian new soles)
Interesting with good view over Cusco. Worth a visit, would recommend a guide to give you full history and importance of site. Good view of Christa Blanca and city of Cusco below
Stunning site. Sacsayhuaman is a huge site - make sure you have a guide or guidebook to explain the place. Not too hard to walk around if you are not up for a strenuous hike.

Half daily trip, visited archeological sites near Cusco. Perfect day in Cusco:Morning time used to visit museums in city center, lunch in nice restaurant and afternoon trip to visit places in the near.Very important thing: Do not mix city tour (churches and temple of the sun) with out of city sites in half day tour. Not enough time for visit all - just to run through.Try to find good guide, check on tourist comments.Had bad experience on amazing locations because of bad organization and poor knowledge guide.Just run through Inca temples and ruins without any relevant information. At the end of the tour, we spent more time in alpaca wool factory than on historical locations.Luckily, I prepared myself for tour, read about places and know more information than guide.

Sacsayhuaman. This is a spectacular example of Incan construction using huge stones cut precisely to fit against one another. I highly recommend some reading about the series of battles that occurred here between the Spanish and the Incan. It is a fascinating place.

Awesome "unexplained" masterwork Stone Fortress. Sacsayhuaman is the fortress where Cusco (Inca) made its last stand against Francisco Pizzaro and the Spanish conquistadores. Pizzaro defeated Manco Inca Yupanqui (the 9th Sapa Inca) in the year 1536 at Sacsayhuaman . The incredible STONES vary in size from 20 to 122 tons all in solid granite that supposedly the bronze age INCA constructed with 20,000 men to fit with varying angles so perfectly so as not even a piece of paper could fit in between (uh, okay, I guess so). I still cannot figure how they (whomever) cut granite (hardness 8) with that much precision, with bronze tools (hardness level 2) and rock hammers. This is why I came to see it for myself. Anyway, in my humble view, Sacsayhuaman is in the top 3 places to see in and around this part of Peru. It is a must see, a 2nd tier wonder of the world.
Interesting Tourist sight. Enjoyed seeing the site but very important to have guide to explain the setting! Very interesting Incan remains...

Interesting place. We walked up here from Cusco town. It is cool to see and walk around. You can get a guide but we opted against it, unsure of how much one would cost. It would be useful to read up on the history of Sacsayhuaman yourself before going so as to get a bit more out of being there. Well worth a visit. Great views also of Cusco.
Worth Seeing. There is not much left of the original ruins but the stone terraces are quite impressive and definitely worth a visit while in Cusco.
Don't miss this. Worth the money. Be sure to walk back into town along the path, not the main road. Visit the Vegetation of Peru Museum.
Sacsayhuaman. Our tour guide new a lot about Sacsayhuaman and pointed out the more unusual things about the site,like the biggest carved stone and how the walls don't all stand up right.
Exceptional history. An easy trip out of town to see one of the last strongholds of the Incas. Amazing stonework and views of the surrounding area. Well worth the trip.

Guided tour with Lima Tours. This was our first experience of the archeological sites around Cuzco. A big thumbs up to our tour guide Percy, who not only was knowledgeable about the science and history of the ruins but wasn't afraid to have an opinion about what could have happened around the time of the Incas as well. The entry to sites are well organized and there is little delay in getting your ticket clipped. Situated on the mountain overlooking Cuzco, this ruin is amazing for the scale of its original construction and now the remains. The Inca empire was a strong military power, so many structures were built to protect the people in them, store water and food and situated high up mountains to view possible threats. What remains are massive stone blocks carved to precision and stacked against each other, no cement between. This site is beautiful for its flow and peacefulness. It also provides a spectacular view of Cuzco from the top. Cuzco is believed the centre of the Incan empire. If like me, you are still learning about the history, a guide and a group is a must. You get so much more information this way. This was a very good outing.
don't miss. Inca site and fortress above Cusco. Huge rocks fitted together in a defensive position. Usually included in city tour.
Worth the trip. This was a very interesting place and worth the trip out. Beautiful views of the city from the top. Get there before sunset.

Sacsayhuaman is a fantastic place to see the massive rock work the Incas did.. Very interesting ruins. Not as big a Machu Picchu but impressive none the less when you see the size of the large stones that they were shaping and moving into place.

Amazing!. This place is actually a sanctuary. You learn how the Incas managed to bring huge 8 ton rocks from far away places and put them together in such a way that to this day we can't explain how the buildings are still standing. It used to be covered in gold! One advise... You will want to take pictures under its doors because of the scenery and the way the sun shines on them. Please be courteous and stay out of the way when others take pictures. I was a hustle to wait for people to pass by and then take the pictures. It's like they don't get that you don't want some stranger face in your album. Stay out of way and get someone to prevent people from just walking pass you while you take your pictures.

Fun Inca Site Near Cusco - Don't Miss the Rock Slide!. My first full day in Cusco, a friend who'd already been there a few days convinced me to go on a hike from Tambomachay to Sacsayhuaman. It was a beautiful route that took us through the countryside, but the only Inca site along the route that was really worth the money spent on the Boleto Turistico (the ticket you have to buy to visit certain sites) was Sacayhuaman. It's a large site the you can really explore. There are cave passages, llamas, beautiful stone work, and great views over Cusco. There is also a natural rock slide that everyone should definitely let the kid in them experience. :) Definitely recommended, especially since it's so close to Cusco and there's so much to see.
Could be Inca's Best Work. Large complex demonstrating some of the Inca's most ambitious works. Rock work on par or better than Machu Picchu. Take an experienced guide as the history is fantastic.

Really fascinating if you have the time and energy else save for more impressive ruins. I've been here twice before and its fascinating - it is an Inca walled complex high above the city of Cusco. The walls have different levels with lime stones of enormous sizes. If you have the time to explore it you'll certainly find it worthwhile however I feel that with the limited time (and energy) that its best to rather explore the more impressive ruins in Pisac, Moray, Ollayantambo, Winay Waynay and Machu Picchu, the most beautiful and impressive ancient Inca ruins.

Test of high altitude tolerance. We climbed from Plaza de las Armas to Sacsayhuaman on our first full day in Cusco as a test of our acclimatization to the high altitude. (We were going on a 4 day Inca Trail trek later.) We were also rewarded with good views of Cusco and a very interesting Inca site! We highly recommend visiting this site, whether you hike up or not!

Impressive stonework, stunning views! (~1-2hours). A moderate 30 minutes walk in the nice San Blas district get you to this impressive site. Do not expect buildings but the ruins of the fortifications gives an idea of the strength of this civilization. The view of Cusco and it's surroundings makes the visit extremely enjoyable!

It is fun to say. Saqsaywaman was a very worthwhile stop just outside of Cusco. This Temple site was the center of Incan culture in Cusco. The perfectly fitted stones are from a quarry more than three miles away. The stones weigh as much as 160 tons. This is also the same stones that the Spaniards used to build the Cathedral de Cusco. Visit early to avoid any crowds and wear a jacket since it can be quite windy at the site. Most of all enjoy saying Saqsaywaman. By the way that is the way it is spelled on the signage at the site.

Handy to Cusco. Historical Inca site close to Cusco, easy walking around site. Not a lot to see except stone walls. Good to see how they fit together. Close to Statue of white christ so see them both together.
Beautiful and peaceful. Not so overrun with tourists. Peaceful place to sit and soak in the scenery. We used a private guide, but easily done on your own.

Great site - don't miss it.. While we saw many Inca ruin sites on our trip to Peru, this one was (in my opinion) one of the most impressive. The size of the stones is incredible, and on a sunny day it's a great place to just hang out and take in the views.

Get there early and miss the crowds - opens at 07:00. This is one of 4 Inca sites, and the best, just outside of central Cusco either a 30 min walk or 5 mins in a taxi. (The other sites being Tambomachay, Q'enqo and Puka Pukara which can all easily be visited together in half a day). Get there early as it opens at 07.00 so you miss the tour buses, or later in the day after they have gone. We got there just after 8 and it was still quiet but started to fill up by mid morning. This was originally an Inca temple and then later used as a fortress by the armies of Manco Inca and ultimately the of a site bloody battle with the Spanish. It's a huge site, but the most impressive aspect is its 360 Metre long Zigzag wall, consisting of some enormous stones which makes it even more incredible as to how the 15th century Inca were able to construct it without mortar and for it to still be standing. The size of some of the stones are so large (one apparently estimated at 360 tonnes) that legend has it that 3000 men died just moving one of them! You can also walk to the statue of Christ that you will see lit up in the evening from the Plaza de Armas.  In summary this is a must do site when in Cusco and easily ranks up with Ollantaytambo and Pisac. I highly recommend.

Truly amazing!. We walked up here from our hotel in San Blas. It is an amazing place - quite large & takes a while to walk around. We didn't get a guide - just walked around on our own. The rock walls are so huge & so amazing! How they were able to build it is insane! Definitely a must see!
Big stones, amazing!. I was liked too much visited this Amazing place, I went in the morning at 8:00 am. It was a very nice day with my friends.
Staggering. Well worth a visit. Astonishing yo think people could build this even with today's technology let alone way back then. Incredible let.

Sacsayhuaman is a must-see in Cusco!. Sacsayhuaman is a wonderful example of Incan architecture just outside of the downtown in Cusco. After visiting many Incan sites in the Sacred Valley and Machu Picchu itself, I recommend seeing Sacsayhuaman while you are in Cusco. It rivals many of the sites we visited, and is very close. Worth your time!
How did they move those rocks?. A 15 minute trip from our hotel. Recommend a tour guide -- we used a book. Interesting when you consider what the Catholic Spanish Conquistadors did to the Inca's.

Again, Inca's meet Spanish. A lot of rocks and very big rocks. How did they all get there to build this fort? The people of Cusco are very proud of this outdoor, uphill park. Great views of the city from the top and also where all the "squatters" have settled.

Aliens did it. Spectacular ruins very close to the city of Cusco.We walked up the hill to these ruins and enjoyed going through the tunnel, seeing the roaming alpaca, and the large stones that were perfectly placed together without mortar.

Incredible construction. This is the most amazing attraction to visit in Cusco! Even though it doesn't stay in downtown, it is worth the visit.This is the head of the Puma. It is the best Inca ruins you will find after Machu Picchu. I recommend taking a guide because it is too open and difficult to understand the importance if you are all by yourself, but beware with the guide, I joined a group and my guide was incomprehensible.

Inspiring area. Sacsayhuaman is a highly interesting area above Cuzco with the ruins of an old Inca Temple. The walls are constructed like a snake with huge blocks of stone. From the top you'll get a great view on the red roofs of Cuzco and the surrounding mountains. We went up by taxi and walked down through an interesting area in one of Cuzco's neighbourhoods.

#2 ruins behind Machupicchu. Sacsayhuaman is one of 4 ruins just outside of Cusco, and by far the most interesting and largest of the bunch. If you have time for only one, do this! From the Incan rock slides to the fabulous views of the city of Cusco below it's well worth a 2-hour visit.

Amazing. I was tired and almost opted to skip this attraction. So happy I didn't. It is very different from the ruins in the sacred valley. These rocks are huge and the sound carries so well. The area is much bigger than I thought. I was there about an hour but could have stayed much longer.
So amazing!. We had only a quick visit to these ruins. I wish we had had more time. It is a fascinating area to explore.

Larger than you think. . This inca site is quite massive and highlights the quality of Incan stonework. We had a guide who took us through the gate to the underworld into a large area like an arena. The strong buttressed walls are iconic with sweeping views over Cusco and upwards to the Christo Blanco. Not to be missed.

A most interesting temple. Need a guide to fully appreciate this visit. Once again one can appreciate the fantastic architectural skills if the Incas. Make sure you go to the adjacent Jesus Christ statue to capture the best overhead view of Cusco

Have a local guide help you enjoy Sacsayhuaman. This is an incredible Incan site just outside of Cusco. It's basically pronounced "Sexy Woman" which makes it easy to remember! This place was home to the Incan Emperor and so is the most exquisite type of Incan construction. It is a must see. But, be sure to go with a guide (we used Condor Travel) so that you are educated about what you're seeing.

Great Views of the City. This was a great place with so much history and an amazing view of Cusco. It is right next to Cristo Blanco and you could spend hours walking around, highly recommended at sunset.

Very interesting site. We visited this place as a part of Valencia Travel tour to Peru. Cusco is a very charming city and from this place you can see the entire city. The history behind this place is extraordinary.

Hire a private guide to do this site justice!. This is a fascinating site. Its stonework is incredible... even more impressive than Korikancha or Machu Picchu. It forms the head of the puma that was ancient Cusco's aerial shape. There are conflicting theories on what it was and why it existed (from temple ruins to military garrison). It is a huge location with tremendous views of the city. It's incorporation of civil engineering details is fascinating. The only unfortunate thing is that not a whole lot of it remains, having been raided for masonry supplies by the Spanish for their construction projects and demolished by the Spanish to subjugate the Incan population.My advice to you is this: hire a private guide to do a tour of this site. We went there first as part of the City Tour... a very disappointing whirlwind 7-sites-in-one-afternoon tour spent in intensely crowded conditions, long line-ups, and not much info imparted (especially about this site). The second time, we returned with Carlos Mendivil and did a private tour and he was outstanding (his phone number: 941 448 867... I'm trying to add him to Trip Advisor now as he's not on here yet). The site came to life under his stories and explanations.I would definitely try to see this before going to Machu Picchu.And by the way, it's pronunciation is virtually, "sexy woman" ("sax-say-WA-man") making many tourists giggle.

Impressive site in Cusco. An impressive archaeological site just north of Cusco, with incredible views over the city. Although it is not particularly far from the city centre, the uphill walk would be tiring at Cusco’s altitude, so many people seem to take a taxi up then walk back down. Consider joining the Highlands Free Walking Tour instead – this leaves from Plaza Regocijo & include a free bus ride up to Sacsayhuaman, leaving you in the perfect location to explore.

A great site overlooking the city.. Sacsayhuaman is up on the hill overlooking Cusco. The stone work is nothing short of amazing. The views of the city are stunning and the rock slide is fun! The guides are very knowledgable.TIP: Although it looks close to the city center, it is not walkable. Negotiate with a cab driver to take you up. He will offer to wait for you saying that there will be no cabs to take you down after you're done with your visit...don't listen. You can easily get a cab to take you down afterwards.MORE TIPS: Get a guide. Wear sunscreen. Be prepared for windy conditions.

Amazing historical site with superb examples of Inca construction skills. This site is perched in the hills above Cusco and is well worth a guided visit to understand more about the Incas' clever construction skills. look at how the huge blocks fix together exactly without the need for mortar.
Incredible Place to be. I enjoyed every second in this place and the view of cusco is mesmerizing. The city tour is only 30 soles plus your ticket to enter the sites. A must see

Amazing architecture. This impressed me more than Machu pichu. I think only reason it was not a world wonder was the fact that it's easily acceible and not as photogenic as Machu pichu. This was built with single stones weighing up to 7 tons from 60 km away. Machu pichu was built but quarrying the bed rock of Machu pichu mountain itself so not so impressive.

Interesting structures and history. We stopped here as part of a Cusco tour. Our guide walked us through the structures. it was fascinating to see the detail in shaping these stones and forming them into solid walls with such precision. It's not a difficult walk to explore, but may be a a challenge if you do this without acclimatizing to the high elevation.

Inca Site Part Of Cusco Historical Tour. Sacsayhuaman is one of four sites you will visit if you travel to upper Cusco. This site is best known for the amazing ten ton rocks the inca's moved and made into walls. Large plaza for events and nice to walk around. Note: There are restrooms here. Just bring your own TP.

Ruins in Cusco. Sacsayhuaman is really amazing. It is about a ten minute drive outside the city ($5 dollars US or an unremarkable forty minute uphill walk; I recommend taking a taxi up and doing the walk back down) and a really interesting set of ruins. The largest rocks were carted away up through the 1930s so what you have left is far different than the ruins in Pisac, etc. There is also a super cool natural rock "slide" that visitors are encouraged to climb up and slide down. It can be overlooked if you do a super quick trip of the site but is so worth the extra minutes to slide down. Two thumbs up!

More ancient structures, but still pretty cool. This is an immense structure! Amazing what some determined people can do. Our guide was great and had lot to tell about the people and reason for building this temple. The day we went is was very empty, and we got to go on the paths anywhere without waiting. It was impressive to hear that this predates the Inca by 1500 years.

Kind of a waste of time.. I love history and ruins aspect of Peru. However, there was not enough to see or learn here to make it worth the stop. It might have been our guide's lack of explanation. But of all the archaeological stops on this trip, this was the only one that had me shrugging my shoulders.

Catch the Sacred valley tour and come back here later!. This sight was the highlight for us on the Sacred valley tour. A little crowded when we arrived, but wide open spaces and a little spring in your step put you into some nice photo opportunities. Just amazing!!

Interesting but expensive. Took the walk up from plaza, not too exhausting! s/70 for entrance, we were told by our hostel to take passports, but no-one asked for them. Some lovely views and nice to wander around although expensive. Bring toilet paper for the loos!

Amazing. Amazing place to visit. It is an archeological site very near the center of Cuzco. It is well preserved and really interesting. It is very worth it to Hire a tour guide there, makes a huge difference to have some one who can explain all the purposes in the architeture and struture of the place. Great view of Cuzco there as well.

Amazing views!!!. This used to be a sacred place that now overlooks the Cusco area. It was covered by the Spanish when they invaded this area to douse the enthusiasm for the local Inca traditions but later uncovered and is truly magnificent! Visit here before Machu Picchu, it will give you a fuller appreciation for the masonry of the Incas.
Nice historic place. We had a guide from Lima tours - Jose' - who had so much knowledge. Amazing place with a lot of history!

Spectacular Inca ruins. I visited this as part of an afternoon city tour. It is also accessible by taxi from Cusco central as it is not far from the city. It is one of the attractions on the Cusco tourist sites and hence you either have to by a ticket for a single entry, or buy a multiple-site ticket (better value at 130 soles) which gets you in to about ten sites. You would need at least an hour there to do it justice

Fascinating site overlooking Cusco. I've been to Sacsayhuaman twice, in 2012 and 2016 and both times, I've been awed by the architecture and technology that remains to be seen at the historic site. And, you cannot beat the view of Cusco and the Valley laid out at below the Inka Fort and ceremonial site. Worth a visit.

Worth the climb above Cusco!. Sacsayhuaman (if you say "Sexy Woman" people will know what you mean) is quite a climb above Cusco, but very much worth the climb. Some choose to go by bus or car, but the walk up the hill is part of the enjoyment. Once you arrive at the gates, there will be guides to show you around. Our guide was Wilbur, and he was very knowledgeable. This is a wonderful starting place to learn about the Incas and to see some of the amazing Inca craftmanship.

Part of a 1/2 day tour. We visited this site as part of a 1/2 day tour. It was worth it. You can sse the quarry right next to the ruins. There is plenty of land around to get a feel for the size of events that used to take place there. The stone work was was very impressive and show how talented the Incas were even if know one knows exactly how they cut the stones.

Expensive. Me and my partner are travelling on a budget so we did not want to pay the 70sol each (dont get conned by the "tour guides" waiting at the gates for u, go to the actual ticket office). Instead we walked up the road which was actually not too steep or difficult. Got some fab views of cusco and still got close to the ruins even tho fenced out.

Unforgettable experience - the ruins are simply amazing. This is a site not miss, though so close to Cusco, many people tend to miss it, the ancient fortress is more than a fortress, it was a self sufficient small city that could accommodate the whole population from Cusco, the stones are huge and the zig zag walls are unique, take your time to walk around the top of the fortress for a breathtaking view of the city, make sure you go to the water reservoir (no more water nowadays), from where you can take the best pictures of the walls, while at the ancient water pool, you will be able to see strange rocks cut to perfection and wonder how they did it with the tools of the time. A must to go while in Cusco.
Have to go!. There's 2 ways to get in. Take a bus or taxi or hike up the back streets of Cusco like we did to the other enterance. It's a little hard but the views are amazing and the site is huge.

Beware of horseriding deals. Went to sacsayhuaman by feet and was offered a horse back ride for 60 soles - this would save the entrance fee of 70 soles or the tourist Ticket for different places for 130 soles. After a nice slow ride and visit of an inka place thea acompanying guy took the horses and told me to just walk down the road and go to the sacsayhuaman entrance, no extra fee. Endec up having to pay the etrance fee with a had nodding guy at the entrance. So - be aware. The horsebackride is nice butdoes NOT include the entrance to the site. The site itsself is impreesive.

Beautiful, expansive ruins!. I walked here from the plaza, and it was not nearly as horrible a hike as I had anticipated. Once at the top, make sure to take your time exploring the ruins--they are widespread and interesting. I spent the entire afternoon here and loved it!
good for a day out. this is ok but its a bit samey in the end once you have seen machu pichu. the masonry is very good but half complete

Expensive for the little that remains. First this : Sacsayhuaman is still very impressive, despite the fact that the Spaniards used it as a cheap quarry to build the city of Cusco, and by doing so destroyed it more or less completely.The price of 70 Soles, if not purchased with a combi ticket (130 Soles) is too high for what is remaining! There is NO explanation and if you want to understand what you are seeing you have to hire a guide, who will tour you around (another 50 Soles).If you are visiting other sites, like Machu Picchu, and do not have Sacsayhuaman in your combi ticket, I would recommend not to visit it, as you will see better in the other sites (like the temple in Ollantaytambo)
very interesting. Just outside of Cusco on the way to macho Picchu. An old Inca settlement.We had an Inca do a ritual ceremony for us, very interesting.
Great cite, minutes away from Cusco,. Great place to visit and walk around. Panoramic views of old town Cusco. You can hike down from ther to central Cusco
Incredible Architectural Site. Amazing structure located outside of Cusco. Provides incredibly views of the city and also very close too the Christo statue (much smaller version of the one in Rio)

Inca's Temple. Sachsayuaman should be visited with a tour guide so that you can learn the history of the Inca ruins. It is located at the top of the mountain, which was a strategic vantage point for the Inca to view his people down below. Cusco has a lot of historical Inca sites and this one should not be skipped. My son, who was four years old, had a blast here. Children love to run through the open grounds so it is a favorable tour for small children.
amazing. its a very well preserved inka temple, could be better cared and signaled but it is an overall great place to go

Beautiful and Fun. Light day trip in the beautiful ruins. Recommended to walk the way down to Pisac too.It appears pricey but it includes entrance to other parts of the Sacred Valley as well. We managed to visit only this but we had a really great time and it was still worth it.Don't miss it.If you have an international student card- bring it.

Ancient Inca site. We didn't know what to expect but we had a great guide (Boris) which brought history to life. Incredible how the Incas placed HUGE rocks to form massive structures and man made lake

Monumental. This was an ancient Inca citadel, and the scale of what remains is impressive. Some of the rocks are enormous, and the structure has stood up well to several earthquakes that leveled the nearby town of Cusco

Great Ruin Not Far From Cusco City Center. We rented a taxi and saw several sites this day. This gave us the luxury of planning our visit and how long we wanted to stay at each site. Our itinerary included Pisac ruins and marketplace, Q'enqo, Sacayhuaman and one other that I cannot remember but it was a hunting lodge. Sacayhuaman (pronounced "Sexy woman") was our favorite. I guess it is supposed to represent the head of the puma. Apparently all the sites represent some part of the puma's body. Anyways, it is impressive and the curvature of the walls makes one wonder how on earth did the Incas cut these huge stones. From here one can also see the White Christ statue and can also get a great view of the city. In front is a wide flat grassy area and across the way is more to see. What fascinated me was the rock formations on the left. The striations in the rock are impressive. There is also a "rock slide" that you can slide on. Our guide also showed us what they said was like a funeral area and beyond that was a dark cave you can walk through. I thought it was really a good introductions to large Inca architecture. This is included in the Boleto Turistico. Always bring water with you as you may get thirsty from all the exercise. As with everywhere in Peru, wear good shoes and sunblock.

Great day trip in Cusco. If you're relatively fit, I suggest walking up to the site; it is part of the adventure and only takes around 25min from the main square. But wait a couple days to acclimatize so you don't lose your breath. We also walked between sacsayhuaman and Qenqo. That was one of the best parts - we say lots of locals flying kits in parks and local places. It was good to get away from the super tourist centric main areas.I think the 70 sol entrance fee is a bit steep. Although we are definitely glad we went.

Best Inca Ruins near Cusco. Hands down the most impressive Inca ruins in the Cusco area. I recommend skipping the cab ride and taking the 30 to 40 minute hike up to Sacsayhuaman from the historic plaza of Cusco. Amazing views of the city and structures that are impossible to comprehend. If you do one activity in Cusco, this is the one!
Sacsayhuaman. A great place for a view of the city and the ruins are amazing. An easy hike compared to everywhere else we went.

inegmatic place. One of the things that most surprised us Cusco is Sacsayhuaman, giant rocks that you can not explain how they were to stop there, given the technology of the time, and others are included in more places in Kenko, Tambomachay and Puka Pukara, which you can visit in half a day, either in the afternoon or in the morning, a highly recommended place to visit, when they go to Cusco.

Awesome remains of the Citadel!. Be sure to read up on this place before going. It will all look the same unless you know what you're looking at. This is amazing as far as stone construction and masonry techniques of an ancient civilization! Buy tickets at the gate of the park. As long as you read up a little, you won't need a guide. You will need at least 3 hours and you will need to take a taxi to and from this location. I would;t recommend walking that road with all of the busses and cars running that road. It is quite a foot hike anyway. You can ask your taxi driver to return or wait. The total cost of a taxi from Plaza De Armas and back was about 20 Sol ($6.30 USD).

INCA CONSTRUCTION. This was a good preview to Machu Picchu. A good place to visit but not without a knowledgeable Tour Guide. Ours gave us lots to think about on how this was possibly made and why. Truly amazing on how the stones were moved and placed and that they are still in place as tight as ever!

Do not miss this!. This site may not be as famous as Machu Picchu, but, as the nerve center or "brain" of the Inca Empire, it's just as impressive as MP, and with far fewer crowds (not to mention the expense and difficulty getting to MP). This location was the political and religious center for the Inca Empire, and it has lots of structures still in good condition. It also has nice views of Cusco town. I would give this site a very high priority for visit. Along with Pisac, it should not be missed.

Amazing. We went with a guided tour (Condor Travel) and it was really interesting to see how skilled and clever the Incas were as we toured the foundations of this Inca temple. You have to take a bus ride up but it's well worth it.

Visiting Sacsayhuaman. The site was incredible. If you are in Cusco for just a short while, I would put this site on the top of the priority next to Maccu Picchu. It was incredible what the ancient Peruvians engineers built.

The wonders of the Incas. This is a must visit when you get to Cusco.How this site was assembled with Inca's travelling miles and miles with huge stones (well before trains and cars were invented) to create a site that was assembled without the use of cement/ mortar is just mind-boggling.The view of Cusco from high up here are worth the visit alone then you just get this great feeling of the history. Amazing!

Worth the taxi ride to view Cuzco down below. I was looking forward to visiting Sacsayhuaman because of its history. And man, those rocks are HUGE. It's hard to imagine that the ancient Incas were able to carve and move such massive stones. The massive rock walls are a sight to see. I recommend for travellers to visit it. Btw, if you want to see the real city, don't bother taking a bus or taxi back down the mountain. Just walk down and through their neighbourhoods. I met two American girls while walking around and the three of us walked down together. It was a great walk.
Amazing views and history!!. If you do any of the tours, this has to be included!!! You'll love it!!! The view of the city, the history, the craziness of how it was built!! You just have to see it!

Good for photos with Alpacas. You will get a good view of the city of Cusco here along with views of some ancient ruins. I did not find the actual ruins super impressive. However, there were many alpacas roaming around the area and it was a great place to get up close to them for photo opportunities. I would recommend a visit to this spot if you have time, since its only a 10-15 min cab ride (10 soles) away from central Cusco.Tickets are required to enter. It was 70 soles for a limited ticket and 140 soles for a full ticket (which includes other access to other sites around Cusco).

Interesting and not too big a site. This is an interesting and thought provoking site. A guide will enhance your experience by explaining the significance and Inca history. Many large stones are all around and one wonders? Worth a visit
Interesting visit. This was our first ruin visit but not the most impressive. It is worth the trip however. The view of Cusco is pretty awesome. Bring a jacket, it gets chilly up there.
A must if in Cusco. The view of Cusco is breathtaking as is marveling at the construction of this magnificent ancient structure.
marvel of masonnery engineering. try to understand how they made this possible without any gap! Not to far from central Cuzco, a short pleasant walk uphill.
Easy to get to from Cusco by taxi. Nice examples of Inca architecture close to Cusco. Easy to walk around for anyone. Great view of Cusco from the top.
Interesting ruins sight. Definitely need a car or bus to get up here. Interesting huge stores, none of the same size. Good view of Cusco below.

Worth a visit. We had a guide, which I think was probably important since I didn't see too many signs, but the place was worth a visit. Nice overlook of the city as well. A little "breath-taking" to walk the stairs at 12K feet ;)

Really impresive. When I arrive to Cuzco i was really specting something awsome but in Machu Pichu. I was totally wrong.25 minutes from Cusco is located this place and is amazing specially the huge amount of ruins and the impresive quality of the architecture.Huge rocks are fit one inyo another like legosa nice place to visit if you like Archaeology

Amazing ruins spread out over a large area. These ruins are not tall but cover an astonishing breadth of land. Very impressive and definitely worth the climb (or taxi ride) up the hill to get there. Acclimate to the altitude for at least a day before walking to this site.

Worth visit for the view of Cusco. We walked up the steep hill on 2 separate days. This park closes at 5:30 pm and we arrived the first time at 5 pm so wet turned the next day. The walk did provide us sights of all the people along the way almighty with the small shops. So worth it for that.The next day we arrived at about 2 and the area was pretty quiet so we visited the viewpoints which were great. The ruins them selves were pretty basis, reminded me a bit of the Ronan Forum with no explanatory signs. Want more? There are guides at hand to hire.As we were walking around about 60 tour buses arrived so things got a bit busy. We left 4:30.
interesting Inca Ruins. THese ruins are pretty inspiring, with nice vistas and great photo ops. the walls in some places are made of huge stones, joined together near perfectly.

the most beutiful places in cusco. we can recomend it to make just you have to walk 25 minutes for Cusco centerespaciality in the morning, because in teh afternoon is too many peoplealso you cna visit the sites around SACSAYHUAMAN

Historic Incan site. wonderful construction, very interesting historic importance in the Incan vs. Spanish empire. It is best to go with a guide only because they can tell you the details and explain the significance.

Awesome place. There is a price for entry but it's well worth it. Elevation can be a challenge but if you pace yourself and breathe deeply one should be fine. My method, which worked well, while climbing was to take 5 steps, stop and breathe then take 5 more, etc., etc.

A little bit of the same. Full disclosure we hiked Macchu Picchu and up to the Sunfate first and then got to Cusco, but for us it wasn't anything spectacular. If you arrive in Cusco first, I could see how this could be fascinating. The views of Cusco up there are impressive. We might have ruins burn out. After the Macchu Picchu hike the previous day we opted for the cab and it was awesome and super cheap.

Don't want to miss. Amazing site, make sure you do not miss. Wonders to see the stone work and arches and the scale of such a magnificent landmark. Went in the late afternoon and there was not a lot of people walking around so makes for great photo opportunities. Weather can change suddenly so make sure to bring a sweater and rain poncho in the winter.

Awesome. Excellent option. A must for all visitors to Cuzco. Better tan any other site in the city. Giant stone walls that look impossible to move, matching in perfect combination. Everyone around wonder how was it posible to build by people that let the Europeans conquer them! A wonder without any doubt.
interesting Inca site. Large site of archaeological and historical interest near Cusco generally included on the multi site city tour.
Amazing. What's to say, when in Cusco go to "Sexy Woman". Part of the package. How many more characters? ....

Very Cool with the Kids. This ancient Incan site was a huge hit for the entire family. The natural rock slide and the llamas were fun for the kids. The expansive historical site was fascinating and beautiful. It is located only a few minutes outside of Cusco and could be visited for as little as an hour, or as long as a full day. Loved it!

Utterly incredible site.. The site of the Inca's strongest resistance against Spanish Invaders boasts incredible architecture. Unfortunately, it was damaged badly as it was used for building materials for the churches and other needs of the new rulers, but what remains is still breathtaking.

Worth the visit. We caught a cab up, 15 soles from town. You can buy a pass for 1 day which gets you into 4 tourist attractions or a longer pass which cost 120 sole. It cost 70 sole for 1 day. Once in there it is amazing, the view of the city and the inca ruins are amazing. You can spend around 1-2 hours just looking and climbing around the ruins. A must see.

Nice introduction to Inca history. We did the four ruin excursion on a single day and it was worth it. Sacsayhuaman was by far the best one if you are willing to pay for a guide. Local guides are very good, I have to say. They all carry the guide credentials and are well versed in the history of the places that they are working at.

Impressive and Enormous. You can't appreciate the skill of the Incans unless you see this up close. Many structures, all put together without mortar or iron tools that have withstood earthquakes. Quite a incredible sight.

Brilliant. A great site with so much to see and understand. I have waited years to see inca stone work and try to understand how they did it - this was the perfect place to start.
Our guide also helped us to understand the sites importance in the area and wider inca empire.

Urban Ruins!. An easy hike from Plaza de Armas in Cuzco, Sacsayhuaman is a must visit site when in the city. Just keep walking up the hill, then walk up another hill, and you're there. You can opt for a bus tour, but then you have someone calling after you constantly and can't truly enjoy yourself. Like other ruins, this is covered by the tourist ticket and a guide is easily contracted once you arrive. My favorite time is around sunset, when the golden light of the setting sun makes the place truly magical.
Beautiful Inca ruins. Beautiful ruins overlooking the city of Cusco. Easy to access via taxi. On the Cusco city tour. A must see.
amazing and worthwhile. This place is huge, can easily spend a good hour or more here, the tours only allow about 40 minutes. A great view overlooking Cusco

Powerful . This huge site, is just a short trip from Cuzco. There are many bus tours that give you a good amount of time to walk around. The Inka rock walls are just simply amazing. Very impressive the size and precision of the master builders. best stop near the City of Cuzco. Nice place to take photos. So glad we had rain jackets.

Impressive stonework but very pricey!. If you have time in cusco it's worth a visit and easily walkable from cusco centre. The massive stones are astounding and offer something different to see compared to machu picchu. However the ticket price is high and there is little information available so do some reading beforehand!

Worth the money!. We weren't sure if we wanted to spend the money, because we weren't going to any other sites but we are so glad we went. It was beautiful walking around the ruins and we saw several llamas on the grass. We made our way over to the natural slides and it was one of the biggest highlights on our trip!

Good start to explore the inka civilizations. A stiff 30-40 minute walk uphill (remember the altitude) from Cusco city centre, the complex shows remarkable Inka engineering and stone work. There are also great views over the city. It's not essential to hire a guide, but if you're new to Inka history and Cusco you may want to take one of the official guides at the entrance. The boleto turistico is about sol 120 and covers about a dozen sites so hang on to it.

Well worth a visit.. Ask your hotel to find you a taxi driver to take you to all four locations of the Sacsayhuaman ruins (or just find a taxi in the Plaza.) This was originally one large complex, but now the four sites have separate entrances. You will need the boleto turistico to enter, but can purchase it there. All of the taxi drivers in Cusco are very familiar with Sacsayhuaman. There are also guides that you can hire once you get there, and the taxi driver will wait for you. The taxi price was very reasonable - about 30 soles for about two hours. It's another of Peru's wonders. Get out of the city and see this marvel. It's only about 15 minutes away.

Best combined with a day trip. We visited here as party of a day trip while getting acclimated to the altitude before hiking to Machu Pichu. It's a really amazing site but not very realistic to do in a cost effective manner unless you visit as part of a tour group. The site is well maintained but without a guide you won't get much out of the visit.

Incredible Ruins just outside Cusco. Visited this place as part of a day trip when I had half a day to spend in Cusco before setting out to Machu Picchu. This place offered a good preview of what is to come in Machu Picchu. Some of these ruins pre-date the work of the Incas. The place offered wide vistas with stone structured built with different levels of finishing. You also get a nice overlook of the city of Cusco as a bonus.
Nice Archaeological Site. Very nice site - smaller than some - an easy walk with nice views. Very close to the Blanco Christo staue that looks over the city.

Good for an hour or so, combine with other nearby ruins. Enjoyed this place. Great setting, quite a few things to see and makes for good walking. Place is not overrun so one can take one's time and enjoy walking around and taking it in. We noted how the Inca architecture was so focused on fitting stones together perfectly, rather than using mortar. Hard to fathom how this was built - the enormous physical effort and craftsmanship are astounding.
Cusco from a bird's eye view. It is about 40 minutes walk from Cusco, an impressive citadel built of huge stones around 1100 ad, allow about 60-90 minutes for visiting the inside of the complex
A must-see in Cusco. We had a wonderful trip to Sacsayhuaman. The site itself is very interesting and the views are wonderful. Definitely a must-see while in Cusco.
Stopped on the way . This was a quick stop on our way to the Inca Trail. Great location to see Cuzco, it's up high. It's a good historical site but seemed anti climatic in comparison to other sites.
Ruins in Cuzco. Enjoyed this place a lot. We had been in Machu Picchu for two days prior and seen the Inca ruins there but we loved this as well. Very awesome view of the city from the top as well.
Simply incredible. The architecture is impressive. Perfection in fitting stone.Very important to hire a city tour or a guide to explain the history of the site.

Cool site, but low info.. I was traveling with my dad and he wasn't feeling well, so I walked up here on my own from Choqechaka. From there you pass a nice (if, like so many places in Peru ) chock full o litter waterfall and a parish church that was having a picnic (Cusqueno & roasted cuy galore!) and exuberant Saint's parade when I was there. Note to solo travelers: walking this way or from the Plaza de Armas, you will move through several sets of steps where you can easily become isolated. There were the usual, not particularly threatening creepers lurking around corners and being annoying. I made sure to keep me wits about me!Ok, so, the ruins at last. The views are great (though as a native of Scranton PA, USA, I had some de ja bye). You will wonder how they moved and arranged these enormous stones. I continued to wonder throughout my visit, in fact, because there was no print info available in any language, and for once, no one was trying to sell me guide services (or a massage, or a "100% baby alpaca made by my grandmother" or shaman services or whatever on the streets of Cusco. So I would recommend this site for some freaking peace and quiet.To me, the best parts were:1. Random brazen llama herd at top of site providing photo oops, tourist mayhem and hilarity2. A natural stone slide that seemingly local children were enjoying (did they make them pay 70 soles?)3. An abuela with photo-ready alpaca who came springing out of a cave. She was so cute, I gave her a pocketful of soles for a photo after steadfastly refusing to fall for that one for like 2 weeks.To sum up: research it before you go so you know what you are looking at, be open to enjoying current Peru at least as much can as ancient Peru

The guide advised us to call it "Sexy Woman". Large well-developed archeological site that was mostly a fortress. It's huge, and seems even grander when one considers it was mostly constructed with human labor with boulders transported a reasonably impressive distance.

A must see. What a wonderful place to explore, from the rock formations that are slides, to the massive rock formations that to this day no one can figure out how it was done without modern technology.

surprisingly close to Cusco and impressive. We visited this prior to our Salkantay trek. It is very close to Cusco and very impressive. Well worth a visit. If you have kids dont miss the slides down the stone formations on the backside of the site.

Very worthwhile - get a guide!. We walked up to Sacsayhuaman (think: 'sexy woman' in terms of how to pronounce the name of this place) -- which was fine but nothing really to see on the way. So I'd recommend taking a cab. We were not going to hire a guide, but after about 5 minutes of starting to walk around, we realized that having a guide would make it so much more meaningful, and it did! Our guide was Guido - and I'd highly recommend him. He was very knowledgable & passionate about Sacsayhuaman and Incan history; he has worked in some of the archeology digs in the area. There are guides waiting to be hired, right inside the entrance, and that is where we found Guido.  Before you go to Cusco, read the book 'The Last Days of the Incas' by Kim MacQuarrie. It describes the spanish vs Incan wars and interactions, many of which occurred in Cusco. Sacsayhuaman was the location of a major battle described in the book. It was really neat to see the walls and location of this battle. Guido showed us part of the site that had been excavated in the last 6-9 months. Originally they thought Sacsayhuaman was a fortress, but now they believe it was a spiritual place for the Incas. The stone work here was every bit as good as at Machu Picchu. In some ways it was more impressive - the main 3 walls (quite long) at Sacsayhuaman were all the highest quality Incan cut stones which were only used for religious sites and places the royalty/emperors lived.

Connectivity and WOW factor!. Such a Scared space here....lots of tourists and a fine walk up from Cusco if the mood hits you. Again make sure to buy the 10 day tourist ticket as you never know when the man/lady will pop out and demand payment. The structure is awesome...so perfectly constructed at a time when..well...tools were rather primitive. The results here are mind-boggling. You have to ask how? Why? Where did it all come from?? I suggest just ponder life..lay back and connect with the energies of the stones and let the Universe answer those questions. A MUST see.....
An Inkan Treasure. Will see along with several other stops on the All Day Group Sacred Valley Tour. Well worth the $35 US/person.
Amazing. What an amazing feat of human engineering...the size of the walls and rocks, the history, the whole Inca background...worth a visit with a guide
Awesome. An amazing slice of culture and history, not to mention impressive construction techniques... Well worth the time :)

Interesting and fun site near Cusco. Fun for the whole family: history, tunnel, slides, and great photo opportunities. While still being an archeological site, this place is as interactive as it can be, so it is fun for the whole family.

Awe inspiring stonework. An amazing example of Inca stone work with massive stones fitted so precisely together that a piece of paper cannot be inserted in between the stones. Be prepared to spend some time there climbing and taking photos.
Incredible place. Knees to know you'll be 10,309 feet high so drink your cocoa tea or choo on the leaf cause chances are you'll get a bit dizzy if you don't.. Wonderful place so much culture here.

Amazing Ruin just outside Cusco. An impressive and incredible ruin just outside of Cusco. Although it is uphill, you can walk there and back from Cusco. We actually started at Tombochay and Puka Pukara, other Incan sites, about 8 Km away and walked to Sacsayhuaman. It was a nice walk but there is no real trail other than by the roadside. The formation of the boulders and how tightly the construction was made were extremely impressive.
Fascinating!. After having seen a lot of ruins, you still want to see this. The stones are huge. There are caves. It's different and fascinating. Not to be missed!

July 2016. Really cool arsenal that is built above the city. You get a great sense of Incan building and a wonderful view of the city. Only negative is that they don't really label what everything is. I assume a tour guide could provide the information but a self walking tour leaves you a little vague of specifics.

Our First View of Inca Architecture. Sacsayhuman (or Sexy Human) is an incredible piece of Inca architecture located 15 minutes outside of Cuzco ... We saw it as part of a one-half day tour of the city and immediate environs. Cuzco was the capital of the Inca Empire and was where the Spanish (Pizarro) first met with the Incas. Sacsayhuman are a series of walls and terraces with built, like most Inca buildings without mortar, but perfectly fitted stones, many weighing several dozen tones ...

A must visit with children. The perfect antidote for museum-weary kids. It's a 30-45 minute urban hike from the Plaza de Armas to the top of Sacsayhuaman. Entry is included in the Boletos de Turistico, but we had already gone once with our guide so we had to pay again. The second time was just for fun and well worth it. The back hill has "slides" that have been carved by the bottoms of previous sliders over the course of hundreds of years. Our boys spent at least an hour just running up and sliding down the various boulders. Afterwards, we marvelled again at the huge carved boulders of Sacsayhuaman -- from the back hill you get a view of the entire structure and an appreciation for the enormous scale that you cannot get from the ground. Finally, we explored magnificent architecture up-close and climbed to the top for a gorgeous view of Cusco. Though it is fun for the kids, knowing that each boulder was rolled from a far away hill, meticulously carved and perfectly put into place, and then so callously destroyed by the conquistadors, you cannot help but feel awe and anger at what humans can make possible.
Beautiful view overlooking Cusco!. Be sure to take time to see this view! You can also see the Christ figure overlooking the city too! You will not be dissappointed.

DO your research before visiting. We didn't understand how it works, you buy one ticket which entitles you to entrance to 4 ruins around town. They are spread out so you need quite a few hours and transportation to visit them all. If you want to see just Sacsayhuaman you still pay for 4. Hire a guide at the entrance or you won't understand what you are viewing.
Peru Vacation. A must see to appreciate the historical and religious significance of Cusco during the time of the Incas.

Very impression and nice view of Cusco. We spent an hour exploring the rocks and walked the stairs to see the view of Cusco. It is a good amount of walking and needed to talk it slow because of the attitude.

Capital of the Incan Empire. You can feel the importance of this place as you walk through. It is absolutely stunning. When you arrive at the top of the ruins, the views of Cusco cannot be beat. What a fantastic experience!
Wonderful site and great view of the city.. In a temple site where you an visit at your leisure and enjoy the history and be in awe how they shaped and moved the stones to built this temple area.

Giant ruins close to the city of cusco . I went with friends and we were amazed with the size of the stones. It's not so much walking compared to other sites but you get to have the idea of how amazing were the Inca culture. It's also recommended for people who can't handle much altitud or are scared of height since it is not as steep as many other ruins
Very interesting. Interesting visit: you can see the temples, the huge stones and the panoramic view of Cuzco. It is preferable to go with a guide that can explain the several temples/ structures.

GIANT walls mark the end of the Incan Empire. Sacsayhuaman is where the Spanish broke Manco Inca's siege of Cusco, their last chance to remove the conquistadores. Here, you can see the MASSIVE remains to the Incan defensive walls enclosing the royal and ritual buildings of the Muyuq Marka, where the 1500 Incans defenders died. Nearby is the prominent Cristo Blanco marking the hill from which the Spanish mounted their attacks. Also, there are excellent overlooks over Cusco, and a natural "sliding rock" around the far side of the Rodadero, which is fun for families. While you can walk here from Cusco, it is uphill to above 12,000ft/4,000m. Guides (and toilets) are available, and plan of at least 90 minutes for your visit.

Big Rocks. The biggest rock is 128 tonnes and they don't just come from the field that the wall is in. A great place to get up close to the walls where you can see how the huge rocks were fitted together without mortar and are still standing even though the area is prone to earthquakes.

The zigzagged walls of the fort are very impressive. On a beautiful sunny day its a glorious place to go to admire the puma's teeth walls of old Inca fort, as well as the sun temple on the top of the hill and the glorious views of Cusco from the top. We skipped the guides and found some useful posters at the far end of the site, which helped us navigate back via a more interesting route. Also taking the rough road out of the car park straight into the plaza meant that this trip had a more limited amount of climb than some of the inca sites we visited (whew!)
Day Trip. Sacsayhuaman is an unbelievable place. The rocks are huge!! It is hard to believe that people moved them into place. It is walking distance from Cusco which was a nice surprise.
Amazing Sight. But avoid the guides at the gate they are not good. Make sure you allow 2 hours for the visit. I also recommend taking a taxi up to see it.

Tips for your visit to this educational, enriching experience and a great guide. This is a great place to get the feel for Incan civilization. It's a beautiful site and also offers great views of the city. Recommend getting a car to drop you at the top and meet you at the bottom, so you can walk downhill through the ruins. Also, for time, I also recommend late in the day. We arrived just a few minutes before the entrance closed at 5pm, and it was a lovely time to be there: quiet, not too crowded, no scorching sun. Highly recommend our tour guide Maria: perfect English, detailed explanations, and plentiful offers to photograph you and your companions. Her cell is: +51 984 348 530

Incredible site!. If you have kids, they must slide down the natural rocks! Make sure you get a good guide...We had one that was rushing us to finish and who knows what he said....His English was not so good...
Huge Rocks. A good preview to what we were going to see. The rocks here are huge!!! Its like a bog sporting field surrounded by rocks. We had perfect sunny weather, August is part of the dry season.

mystical heights. The ruins were captivating in addition to the spectacular views. You receive a good sense of the history and people of the region. We marveled at the engineering expertise of this ancient culture as well as their reverence for all of nature

Too bad they don't propose a daily ticket. To visit the sites around Cusco, you have a limited choice of tickets to buy. Ones are for four sites and one or two days (70 Soles) and one is for 16 sites, for 10 days (130 Soles). A friend came for a daily visit and was not able to enter the Sacsayhuaman site without paying the four sites ticket ! It is only to make more money on the back of tourists. I don't like that.
Amazing ruin.. You can see this from cusco centre on top of the hill next to the white Christ statue. We went up as part of a tour, could have done with another hour to take it all in.

You need to buy a ticket for all ruins and sites. Magnificent boulders placed scientifically one upon the other ..Good to have a good guide who can explain inka traditions and calendar.This place is packed in June so plan ahead.A hike but you can walk it slowly from he city.Visit the horses for riding there too!

Fun Day Hike ro Ruins!. We hiked up from the city center (LOTS of stairs/uphill) but the views, trails and ruins were totally worth it! There is an overlook area for good panos of the city and then you can walk all around the ruins. There is also a rock formation you can play on and literally slide down. You can also get to the Cristo Blanco from here.

Wonderful introduction to majestic Incan sites. Visited Sacsayhuaman as part of a small group tour and this site is magnificent. It was getting late in the afternoon (July 2016) and it is an open site so got quite chilly and windswept but there are enough Incan walls to satisfy that thirst for photos. Even with the high number of visitors - enough space to get some great photos and particularly across Cusco from near the entry point. Well worth a visit and so close to Cusco. Wear comfortable walking shoes!

Sacsayhuaman - the ruins above Cusco. This is a short trip from the city centre of Cusco. The best way to see it is to hire a taxi for the steep but short trip uphill then walk back down at your own pace. Great views of Cusco and some really neat ruins to see as well.

Hidden jem. If you are staying in cusco, then simply don't miss this place. Worth the walk up the hill and you'll spend a morning or afternoon exploring the ruins. Fantastic views of Cusco and very impressive ruins.
Beautiful. Must go! We were there walking from our hotel and it is an amazing walking! I would recommend rather go by bus or taxi. It is close by the plaza das armas and the views are amazing

Must Visit Sacred Space of Incas. We arrived at the top of the mtn to be greeted by a tour guide (recommend finding a tour guide to learn about the site)... There are people wearing a lavender/light purple jacket with an official tour guide emblem on the jacket... charged 50 soles... for private tour... Our guide was a young woman trained as a tour guide. The park rangers discourage anyone from selling their goods within the site. A very sacred site with an amazing history behind it. Do not miss visiting this destination if you're in Cusco.

Best archeological site in Cusco and Sacred Valley region. If you want to be amazed by Inka architecture and lost masonry skill there is no better site. For stonework it's better than Machu Picchu. We picked up a guide at the gate for 50 Soles. He was average.

Large stones make this place unique. After Machu Picchu and the ruins of the sacred valley we thought that we weren't going to be impressed by more Inca stonework. We were wrong, the grandure of the site coupled with the immense size of the individual stones make this site well worth the visit.

A must see from Cusco!. Impressive and quite different to other ruins such as Machu Picchu due to the size of the stones used in the construction. Easy hike from Cusco centre and a great view of the city!
How they have done this. And I can add, for what? But it is impressive and worthwhile a visit to see the big rocks, the doors and the views.
Amazing site to visit. You'll be amazed by the craftsmanship of ancient Peruvians. They were able to build this without the mastery of metal
impressive. first site to visit arriving in Cusco . For me after Machu Picchu the most interesting Incasite . Advice , start the visit at the back entrance .

Unimaginable Sight. Sacsayhuaman or " sexy woman" as some locals call it, has such a beautiful view overseeing the city of Cuzco. The technological construction is absolutely astonishing. The size of the boulders and how well they fit together is incredible. It truly is a lost art. If you are visiting Cuzco, definitely check it out.
