Beautiful historical sight! Much less visitors than Machu Picchu. A beautiful well preserved sight on top of a hill overlooking Cuzco. Take a taxi up the hill and walk back down after your visit.Mainly visited by Peruvians and far less international visitors than at Machu Picchu whilst this site is not that much less attractive.
Peruvian Stonehenge. No crowds here, great experience. Highly recommend it. While there we were lucky enough to hear and see a Falcon, and a large group of Llamas and Alpacas. Relaxed atmosphere.
Nice walk.... ...up from the main plaza area of Cusco. Great views, fun to be among ruins so close to town. Little informational signage.

Great half day visit. . In Cuzco so decided to go to sacsayhuamam. Caught a taxi Ann's was told not to pay more than 10 Sola. Dropped off at the top gate and decided to walk on a self guided tour. An amazing experience. Went to the top where the tower had been and looked over Cuzco and the site. Did not appreciate how big it is. Walked to the opposite hill and walked around those sites. Great view of the fortifications from here. Walked to the lower gate and then back to the Hotel. Great half day tour. Could have a guide however we pre read on the site. Highly recommended

Worth seeing in Cusco. My friends and I visited these ruins on one of our days acclimating to the altitude before hiking the Inca Trail. We hired a guide at the site (I can't remember what we paid, but we forgot to bargain and it still was really cheap). You don't need a guide, but I think we would have missed a lot without him. The tour was about 2 hours long and our guide knew a lot about Inca history. The ruins were amazing and covered a pretty large area. We learned a lot of things we hadn't known before about Inca Ruins, like that some stones form the shapes of different animals. If you have a free day in Cusco, I think this is definitely worth touring. Also, make sure to check out the natural rock slides at the ruins!

Temple with a view. The temple, also known as 'sexy woman' (makes it easy to remember its name and pronunciation), is a short walk from the city center. It is quite big and has a great view of Cusco from above. There you can see the great work of the Inkas, fitting the stones nicely without cement or anything to keep it together. It also has a 'zig zag' wall representing the teeth of the puma, which is interesting and different from the other temples around. Good to get there early before the crowds.

Interesting site with lots of history. Walked up the hill from the centre of Cusco. The walk is enjoyable because you get views along the track. At the top are large, interesting and extensive ruins, alpacas and local sellers. Possibly a better option than Cristo Blanco because there are less people.
Nice walk, good view of cusco. Nice steep walk up to these ruins in a lovely setting. Great view of Cusco from the top. We didn't hire a guide but would be a good idea.

Must see!. Impressive Inca Fortress!The stone size only makes the visit much worth it!Another good point is that it is very close to Cusco (we went there walking from the hotel).It's also a very nice mirador point to Cusco!You would need around 2h to visit it without too much haste as there is more than just the fortress (there is an arena behind, and also a stone area with natural toboggans and another one with small tunnels where you can pass through... Actually quite fun to do).Go in the afternoon to take the most advantage of the sun orientation.If you take written explanations from a guide book, I would say a guided group visit is definitely not needed, as this place is much better to walk on your own freely.I suggest to buy the /s 130 ticket that includes other places like Murray, Ollantaytambo, ... If you plan to stay more days in Cusco (which is highly suggested)!Enjoy!
Take a tour here!. We enjoyed these ruins, and it helped to have a tour guide! Extensive and interesting. Lots of ups and downs if you choose to take them!
Very cool. This is a cool site to visit. It is very large. Our favorite spot was the natural rock slides. The kids loved it.

Huge rocks, huge site, huge views, cool place. This place exceeded our expectations. Easy cab ride from town and worth 1-2 hours walking around. The mirador of the city is fantastic. There's a cool natural slide that the kids loved too, its really fast! Don't miss this in Cusco!

Great ruin walking distance from central Cusco. I visited all four of the ruins outside Cusco in a half day (Sacsaywaman, Q'enqo, Tombomachay, and Pukapukara). I took a bus to Tambomachay from downtown Cusco and then walked back to Cusco, visiting all four sites along the way. I am glad that I saved Sacsaywaman for last because it was the coolest and the biggest! It also offers great views of the city of Cusco when you get to the top. I read information about it before I got there so I didn't hire a guide, but if you would like to hire a guide then there are some waiting at the gate where you enter. You need a boleto turistico to enter this site.

Inca heritage inside Cusco. I don't know what I was expecting, so I believe I got so much more! We hired a guide at the entrance and it made the visit so much more worthwhile, explaining a lot about inca culture. It was a nice prelude to Ollantaytambo and Machu Picchu.

Nice place . Great place to start knowing some of the history of the Inka people. These ruins are one of the most impressive ones. There is a short tunnel inside one of the areas... Not too far away from Cusco

Wonderful with good guide. We were on a tour so our guide described what we were seeing and told us of the reality versus the legends. This place was a gathering point for Quechuans to store their products. It is a lot of walking so wear good shoes.

Magnificent. Its like the Pompeii of Latin America! Fascinating structures - do take the underground tunnel, its fun. Don't believe the stories of human sacrifices, there's no convincing evidence of actual sacrifice but I guess the guides like a story.

Great place . Wow, Firstly, this place is 70 soles, but if your visiting a few places pay 130 soles and gives you access to about 12 sites, but this is the best.I got myself a guide paid 60 soles for 1 hour, but sure you can haggle it down, lots of interesting things to see on the stone work, helps if you have read up on some of it prior to visit.My tip is to walk here from town, very slowly uphill, then from main access following your tour, you can take one of the small public busses Moroles? For 1 sol and visit 2 nearby places that is on the group ticket and then the statue of JC
You cannot get enough of Ica marvels. You can only just soak up the marvel of building these monuments to the sun and their other gods without modern equipment. Well run with toilets.

out of the town but worth seeing. this takes a tour or taxi cab ride out of the city. It is worth seeing if you have a tour guide so you know the history and what you are seeing. Build by the Inca's and the Spanish destroyed to rebuild Cusco. Worthwhile

Do not miss this site. The Inca site of Sacsayhuaman is located above the city of Cuzco. Indeed, you could walk right up to it, if you have the endurance to climb the steep trail - the Christ statueon the mountainside that is visible from Cuzco is standing right next to Sacsayhuaman. We did not hike up, instead we had a guide and driver from Alpaca Expeditions drive us up to the site. Having a guide explain the significance of Sacsayhuaman to us was a wise decision, there are no signs at the site to explain what you are looking at. We learned that theSpanish forced the natives to bury the entire site under dirt, so that they would forget the glories of their former Inca empire. Our guide also told us that the zigzag shape of the walls was meant to represent a bolt of lightning, or else the zigzags represented the teeth of a Puma, an animal sacred to the Inca. The best reason to visit Sacsayhuaman (which apparently is a Quecha word for "satisfied falcon") is to see the enormous stones that were used to build the walls. Some of the stones weigh over 200 tons, and were transported here from quarries over 30 km away. The masonry really is amazing, especially for a stone age culture.It is well worth your time to walk through this site.

Great views, interesting site - so close to the city.. I recommend taking a guide. We paid 40 soles for 45 minutes so not cheap, but without a guide you don't learn much - while with the guide, it becomes very interesting, as well as great to walk around. views of Cusco are superb.

Epic. Even though we didn't have a guided tour we thoroughly enjoyed exploring the ruins. We had the most comprehensive ticket which allowed us plenty of freedom to visit what we wanted when we chose. Really close to Cusco so don't miss it even if you only have a little time.

Impressive complex with pre-Inkan origins, great city views. We enjoyed an unguided tour of Saqsayhuaman on our last day in Cusco. If you are touring various sites in the Sacred Valley, buy the multi-site pass at any location. We bought ours at the Koriqancha museum. Take a taxi up... It cost us S/15 (about $5) and it's easy to get a ride back to town usually for less than the ride up. Ask the fare before getting into the taxi as there are no meters. Follow the arrows and visit all the 4 major ruins including stones weighing over 50 tons that lore says predates the Inkas and were built by giants. There are smooth hill of stones that you can slide down. Challenge yourself to enter the caves and pass all the way through in total darkness if you dare. See the huge circular plaza, or visit the throne of the Inka. There are also Ltd of guides who will explain the various complexes. We opted to explore on our own.

Great archaeological site close to Cusco. Sacsayhuamán, ancient Inca ceremonial site, is well worth the visit ––if nothing else, for the amazing views of Cusco. Take your camera. Even if you don't climb to the top, the view of the gigantic cut stones from ground level is impressive. Worth the visit ––but make sure you take at least a few hours to rest and acclimate before attempting it.

Beautiful views, nice visit, overpriced. Sacsayhuaman is a beautiful ruins to visit with an interesting story, with great importance in Quechuan (Incan) history. The views from up there over Cusco are awesome as well. Would highly recommend a guided tour (no more than 20-30 soles per person) of the site, as it will add a whole other dimension to your visit. We do believe that the 70 soles for a day pass to this site as well as the 3 other sites nearby, is too expensive. We'd visited the Convento de Santo Domingo church (another important Quechuan site) before and felt that gave us a similar feel for the history, so if on a budget I'd recommend the church + a walk to blanco cristo.

From a distance. We took a city tour and Sacsayhuaman was one of the stops we made. We were not able to enter the historic site, just view it from a far. It looked pretty amazing even from far away. I would recommend seeing the site close up.
Enjoyable Day Trip. Went there with Family. Love the Stone structures. Breathtaking views of the city. Worth visiting don't miss this when in Cuzco.

Interesting trip. Definitely worth going here with a guide (ideally with either a city tour or a sacred valley tour). It's a little preview of what to look for in Machu Picchu, but in itself is an impressive fortification.
Awesome. More than I could ever expect. Absolutely amazing. Get a guide and use him or her. What a story and what about a civilization that could produce such an amazing place.

Unmissable. Don't miss this superbsite overlooking the city. Breathtaking views and an incredible archaeological complex. No explanations of course, despite the steep entrance fees and pretty useless guides that roam the premises.
An amazing view . A must see when visiting Cusco! Strong recommended to have a guide to tell you the Inca history. Perfect spot for jumping pictures ;)

Its Famous Nickname, Sexy Woman. Many spelling versions that include Sacsayhuamán, or Saxahuaman is a citadel just outside Cusco proper. Our guide has pointed out the intricate structures, how they built the doors, the non-stop pouring water that was built on slanted walls (for a reason), the trapezoid shaped spaces on the columns for earthquake defenses, etc. The water flow was actually built on a six kms underground hundreds of years ago and is still perfectly flowing today. The water has hidden for protection both hygienically and to hide from enemies. These Inkans were so smart, always protecting their existence. The walls were constructed of huge stones carefully fitted together tightly without mortar. Some had interlocking pieces. These thinking was also implemented in the Burobodor Temple, the famous 8 layer Buddhist temple in Java Indonesia. In 1983, Saksaywaman became a UNESCO World Heritage Site. For more history, come see for yourself.

Very beautiful. This area is very close to Cusco but almost 1000m more in elevation. The ruins are spectacular. The magnitude and magnificence of the rocks. How they were carried and interlocked to withstand thousands of years. The views were spectacular. Making it to the top of these ruins were truly something to be proud of and the views are the perfect reward. We had a guided tour with a group, which didn't allow us enough time to visit both sides of the ruins. Get as much time as you can and take lots of water. Remember to breathe through your nose and not your mouth. It preserves more oxygen. Have fun!
Sexy Woman. Major historical site on the edge of Cusco. Impressive remains and plenty of space so doesn't fee too crowded.
Worth the trip. Great place to visit and right there in Cuzco! No long train ride and right up there in the list of Inca places to visit. Not far from there is the Christo Blanco.

Amazing Ruins of a Never Finished Inca Complex. No one seems to know with certainty what the intention was in building these monumental structures on the hilltop overlooking the Cusco valley. But they are spectacular--and, in places, are comprised of colossal stones. The one you see in many photos is estimated to weigh 14-tons. Have you noticed how many pre-history sites--like this relatively modern one--are shrouded in mystery? How did the transport the colossal stones? How did they shape them without iron tools? What was the purpose of the structures? Whatever the answer, the site and stonework is impressive and the view of Cusco is unrivaled. Enjoy!
sexy woman. The Incan idea of a stadium, this place is huge in the hills above Cusco. with the amazing fit stone blocks that withstand earthquakes

Spectacular ruins, go on your own!. Sacsayhuaman has been heavily reviewed as one of the most amazing ruins in South America.On top of the general reviews I would recommend going on your own allowing you to explore the back of the ruins, where there is an amazing natural rock sllde and a few tunnels.
Nice view. You have to walk a lot to get there, but it is very nice. The histoty of this place is awesome, a must-go at Cuzco.

Amazingr ruins that will leave you guessing. These ruins were positively incredible. Our entire group came up with several theories as to how this place came to be. The sheer enormity of it is mind boggling!

Worth the trip. It takes a bus drive to get ther (unless you rent a car)
If you visit on a sunny day you'll get to see the amazing views.
Otherwise it's just great to walk around and marvel at the amazing walls and shapes. Hard to believe the history behind this place. It's definetelly worth visiting
Amazing. So beautiful, so interesting -so high, the air is really thin. It is the "head of the puma", there are great views from up there of the rest of the body- the city...
Wonderful. We are so glad to have visited Sacsayhuamn. Would advise anyone going to go with a tour guide. Viajes Pacifico are great.
Expensive. Is not to big for the price. The ticket is too high for what you get. I will say buy a bus ticket with your own guide and see the site on your bus and save money and time.

Inca history. On the outskirts of Cusco city are the various Inca temple ruins, this being the most famous and largest in the area. Get to hear all the history and how this period in history happened this will give you a better perspective if visiting other Inca sites.

Amazing Inka structure. If you are staying in Cusco you really need to take the time to walk up to the Inka ruins (although you can take a bus or taxi if you are lazy). It's all uphil so can be a little tiring but worth it. We visited the day before our 5 day trek as preparation.

Well preserved ruins. Close to Cusco, this area of ruins is well preserved. If you only have time to visit one area of ruins in the Cusco area, choose this one. We picked up a local guide when we arrived that that was very helpful understanding the area. (You should pay the equivalent of about $10 if you do this) If you have kids, don't miss the slides and the tunnels!

Nice walk from town. We entered the name of Sacsayhuaman in google maps and even without cell connection could follow our route right to the entry. Not much sidewalk in places, but safe and a good amount of uphill climbing to shake off the traveling/airplane blues.
Inca remains. Impressive masonry and great views over the city of Cuzco. You will pass local housing and people on you way to and from the ruins

Unique, impressive and beautiful views over Cuzco. An extraordinary site with some of the largest building stones anywhere in the world and the unique jig-saw masonry is mysterious and fascinating. Thin air at this altitude, but not too taxing. Spectacular views over Cuzco.

Inca ruins just outside of Cusco. . We walked up the hill from town to the Blanca Crusta and the Sacsayhuaman ruins It was a beautiful sunny day and the views into Cusco were amazing. It's quite pricey to get in but becomes better value if you're seeing a few things in the area. If you're worried about the walk up, take a taxi but the walk back into Cusco was pretty quick and easy.

Beautiful view of Cusco. Lots of history, but for me the best part was the view of Cusco and seeing how the city has grown. We enjoyed the area so much, we missed our tour bus and had to walk to meet them at the next stop!
IMpressive. Impressive what you see. After Machu Pichu, it may be a little bit less magical, but it is definitely worth the stop!!!

MUST See in Cusco! Incredible!. Saqsayhuaman was definitely one of our top 5 ancient sites in Peru! Of all the ones in Cusco, if you can only do one site, then this is it! (If you can venture further out of Cusco, Tipon is another must see!) This site is massive and very well maintained and although a guide would be a good idea, you can visit without one if you’ve read up on it quite a bit. Especially if you’ve been to other ruins where you did have a guide and were able to learn the history of pre-Inkan stonework. It is more the history and the story about this particular site, which is very interesting. The stonework here is absolutely immaculate – you can’t even fit a piece of paper between those stones! Some of the stones are incredibly large – the heaviest stone weighing 300 tons, apparently! It’s hard to imagine anyone moving these massive stones with no modern equipment, let alone making them fit so precisely together - truly remarkable! If you go to the upper part of the walls, there are several other paths leading to less touristy parts of the site. Views from here over Cusco city and the walls below is really something! Same goes for the stairs up the other side at the limestone outcrops. The altitude often puts people off from climbing those extra steps to a place which seems to be of no real significance, but you can often miss out on something quite incredible. Tip: We entered the site from the far end (no queues to get in…) No toilets at this end, but at the main entrance (we didn’t use the toilets here, so can’t comment on them). If you have a driver, ask him to drop you to the far entrance and pick you up at the main entrance, That way you not only avoid the queues, but you also only need to walk through the site once, saving you from walking all the way back. Entry is on the Boleto Turistico.Wear sunscreen and a hat and take enough water and some snacks. It is a huge site and you’re exposed to the sun the entire time. Definitely definitely a MUST see in Cusco!

Steep. Second time visiting this location but this time I was able to cover more good walk wear proper shoes a lot of dust at the top blowing hold your cap or hat as you may lose same with the wind about 227 steps could be more. Only disadvantage is that they take you to this location after you had a all you can eat lunch.Otherwise great walk.
Amazing. Makes you think, how did they do that. Did the bus tour. Not walkable from town. Something to check out.
Great inca site. Really worth a visit - in great condition and quite awe inspiring. Unique layout based on lightening. Alpacas roaming freely and wonderful views of Cusco.

Fascinating! . Of all the inca sites this one really made me want to understand more about how they knew how to build such incredible places. Their ability to construct this site using such large sized stones truly gives you something to think about.
lnspiring. The sheer scale and size of these ruins is inspiring.How they built these structures is beyond me.This is close Cusco and you get a great view of the city.Worth a visit.

Excellent, slow paced tour for first day in Cuzco. We took it easy our first day, rested for a few hours in the hotel and then took a taxi (~S12) from the Plaza de Armas to Sacsayhuaman. We gave in and hired a guide which actually made the exploration more interesting and fun as he pointed out details we certainly would not have noticed on our own. It was chilly the afternoon we went. Glad I had a jacket. Bring water. There are bathrooms near the entrance/exit. Got a taxi at the exit at the end of the day for ~S10 to our hotel in the historic district of Cuzco.

Interesting . It was amazing to see these huge stones that were placed there without modern technology. It is nice to know they are still excavating the sight. Leaving the site it was a little frustrating passing through all of the people trying to sell trinkets.

Massively impressive. It's not Machu Picchu, but it's a massive site with amazing sites (the largest stone weighs 128 tons, and was brought there from 15km away- how???), the tour guides are very informative, also has a natural rock slide built in that is fun
OMG!. It's just too hard to describe how beautiful this place is. The imposing stone walls against the mountainous background is an awesome sight. I find it the most beautiful in the Cusco region.

Beautiful views of Cusco . My title says it all. It was also the only place we saw alpacas!!
Beautiful site, and good little stroll that's not too winding as you acclimatize!
FYI: costs no more than 10 soles to get there or come back from plaza de armas.

Worth the visit for the historians. Being completely honest, a lot of people might not like the place, however the ones that have passion for history and culture should really visit Sacsayhuaman. It is amazingly vibrant ruins of hundred years that allows you to have a glimpse of the history of Peru.

Phenomenal Incan Ruin. Saqsayhuaman left me in awe. Be sure to visit the tunnels on the Water Temple side. There is a trail leading back down to the central plaza of Cusco which is safe and an easy hike.
Worth the climb. You can just drive up in a bus... but it is well worth the climb through the city. Along the way we stopped at a wood carvers shop: excellent craftsmanship!

Incredible constructions, less crowded then Machu Picchu and more impressive. This place is actually by far larger than Machu Picchu and more accessible. It is also much more impressive in that the stones were moved from elsewhere and some of them way many tones (10000 kg or more). Another great advantage is that there are no queues!

Great archeological site!. Excellent archeological site!
Worth visiting!
The site will provide great photo opportunities and you will be able to admire amazing inka ruins!

Very, Very Impressive .... I consider this a must see if you are in the Cusco area. These ruins are more about its visual effect - the vastness of the space and the sheer size of the stones/stonework. Not as rebuilt as Ollantaytambo or the Machu Picchu sites. Get a taxi up and enjoy the all downhill walk back to the historic center. Also recommend hiring a guide at the site, or joining an organized tour from Cusco.

No Need to Book a Tour!. I grabbed a cab in Cusco with 3 other friends for 70 soles (roughly $22, less than $10/pp) TOTAL and he took us to Sacsayhuaman, Tambomachay, Qenqo and Pukapukara. I originally prebooked Sacsayhuaman and paid $70 for a tour of the only this site, but quickly realized that I could do it on my own for significantly cheaper and on my own time.Sacsayhuaman is a short 20 min drive from Plaza de Armas. We saw Cristo Blanco first and walked down to Sacsayhuaman. Of course, without paying for the tour, you do not get access into the grounds, but we still got to see everything we wanted to see from the outside. You'll still see the stones and be able to take pictures, but you miss out on the history lesson without a proper guide. If you're short on time/traveling on a budget, you don't need to book a tour to see Sacsayhuaman. Grab a taxi and negotiate a deal where you'd get taken around to all the sites. Again, you don't get access into the grounds unless you pay for entrance, but you still see everything and can still get up close (most of the sites just had a simple rope blocking it off, so you can do as you please as long as you don't cross the rope). Plenty of people chose to just grab a taxi instead of the tour, so you won't be alone!

Amazing. What an incredible place. In some ways better than Ankor Wat. Amazing location and fascinating history . Worth having a proper guide to explain the site and what you are seeing. Great views over Cusco

There is more than Machu Picchu. Is there anything that can beat Machu Picchu? This site was so different you can not compare them, and it is definately worth a visit. The massive boulders form a zig zag shape across the fields overlooking Cusco, representing a strong indigenous contrast to the huge Christ figure on the neighbouring hill.

Worth the hike!. We walked up from the center of Cusco to see the ruins. Decided to do it without a guide- there's plenty to see and read about. Might have been nice to have someone to explain everything in detail, but we liked being able to move at our own pace. Popped over to the Cristo Blanco as well. Definitely worth hiking up and seeing the great views and awesome ruins!

Great way to spend a couple of hours. Although it isn't in the same ballpark as Machu Pichu, the site offers a great opening look to Incan history. It overlooks the city, which will give great views and there were few people on the day we went. Glad we went and can be done in a short time.
Mindblowing experience. This site is conveniently very close to the centre of Cusco and it is just beautiful. It also has an interesting history and is part of the big tourist attraction ticket.

Large rock perfectly stacked. One can see many walls made by Inka people. It is amazing to see how they carved these huge rocks and made them line up perfectly one on top of the other. Also, you can have nice view of the Cusco city in the valley.

A Great Stop Among Many. There are so many Incan ruins to see in Peru. This is one of the better ones with incredible ancient architecture. There were numerous alpacas running around the property. Also, one of the few places where the public bathrooms are acceptable. Still, I'd recommend you carry your own toilet tissue just in the as it's clear that the Peruvian government cares nothing about tourist hygene or comfort.

Large ruins with secret meanings. This is quite a large area with the rocks revealing secret meanings. It's worth hiring a guide so you can be shown the various symbols in the rocks.It's also worth hiring a taxi and getting them to take you to all three ruins, starting at the top and working your way down to these ones. It's a full day out if you do that and pretty cheap.

Great archeological site. A fascinating place to go and see just how advanced the Incan culture was. A spa celebrating water. You need a ticket to get in. Along the route to the site you will find various wares being sold. Beware, they tend to be synthetic colours. Putting that to one side, the site is well looked after and very interesting.
Cusco City tour. Very interesting history.We had a great knowledged guide.Towering high above Cusco 12.00ft.the ruins of Sacsayhuaman.

Descending capstones in size order. Must hire a guide on site to understand the layout. Kids can slide down the stone slides. No signs and no explanation on site. There are at least 3 nearby other related archeological sights. This is a great archeological park and worth visiting. Admittance by park pass also good at other sites.
Amazing stonework . The stonework at Sacsayhuaman is amazing in its high quality. Our guide was great & kept the kids intrigued with his stories about the history of the site. Well worth a visit

Spectacular place!. Sacsayhuaman is a very impressive Inca Temple, if you are coming to visit Cusco, you should not miss this amzing Inca site, just 30minutes outsite of the main square of Cusco. I highly recommend to anyone this wonderful site.

excellent trip. it was a great day not alot of people and you could spend time just enjoying the history and sights, drink alot of water the air is thin but not to bad easy walk around at your speed, enjoy we did
Don't miss it!. And make sure to WALK up and down from Cusco. A spectacular Inca site and a perfect introduction to Inca architecture before visiting Machu Picchu.

Great archeological site. Sacsayhuaman a great archilogical site to visit while staying in Cusco. It is recommended you visit around the time of the Winter Solstice festival as it is one of the biggest festivals of the year. Also, take time to explore and pay for a guide so you understand what the meaning behind of the huge stones is.

Spectacular Site. This place is definitely worth a visit. I visited this place as part of a tour group. The site was much larger than I had expected. There is a fair bit of walking and going up and down stairs involved.The first section of the site has an altar and a short but very dark tunnel that you can walk through. The massive stone walls in another section of the site were very impressive. The masonry is very similar to those at Machu Picchu.There is also an observation spot where you get a very scenic view of Cusco. The statue of Jesus Christ overlooking Cusco is also nearby.Expect to see vendors near the entrance and around the parking lot. I wish people would be more respectful to these vendors since they are only trying to make a living.

Inca stonework here is mind blowing. We very much enjoyed walking amongst the ruins of Sacsauyhuaman. The sheer scale of some of the stone walls here is mind blowing. An excellent example of Inca skill in stone masonry.

Another amazing Incan site. A site that is well worth a visit that is close to Cusco town centre. Jump in a taxi and head on up. I would say one thing, pay for a local guide. These sites are 'brought to life' and you have a far better understanding if you use the local guides whom are well educated and informative on the history of the area. It would not be anywhere near as enjoyable if just going for a look without a guide to inform.

Magic place . We enjoyed our visit. We hired a tour guide inside the place. It's a very impressive place were you feel an incredible sense of peace and quiet. Very interesting from the historic point of view

Historical stone area on the Upper hills of Cusco. It's an Inca complex surrounded by walls that were made by fitting stones tightly together without mortar, that is located north of Plaza de Armas at walking distance.
More important than Machu Picho. I was stunned by the quality of construction work made almost 700 years ago but unfortunately destroyed by the Spanish.

Fascinating Inca Site. We visited this as part of a city tour and we thoroughly enjoyed it. The walk around the site is very interesting and there was so much to see. The actual scale of the whole place was massive and the size of the stones was impressive. The surrounding views are amazing also, well worth a visit

Wow . A truly amazing place even before you consider its importance in the history of Peru. Well worth getting a guide to show you the largest stone built into a structure anywhere, the reflecting pool and to provide insights on construction techniques. Go in early morning or even better late afternoon light to truly capture the magnificence of the stonework. Apparently you can organise a horse ride up from Cusco which would be a terrific way to understand the task faces by the conquistadors when attempting to take this stronghold. And the kids loved the ancient slides in the rocks!
Big play castle. One of the stops of our city tour. Looked like a giant playmobil castle. Interesting to get some information about it.
A Good Walk. Sacsayhuman is a beautiful historical place.There you can see Alpacas and the Inca buildings.You need to buy the tickets for the tour.
Best value. First tour booked through trip advisor and well worth it! Our guide not only had a 5 yr tourism degree, but a 5 yr anthropology degree. Great information and great tour. 4 sites, 1/2 day.

Amazing engineering!. This is one of the Inca sacred ruins surrounding Cusco. It is awesome! The size of the stones and the technology they used to move them will remind you that many regions were more advanced than Europe at the time. Definitely see this!
Inti Raymi. Amazing to come back and see inti Raymi Festival take place on the scared grounds. Could easily walk down (not up) to our hotel in town. JW Marriott.

Cool rocks. I caught a cab from cusco to tambo machay then hiked it back in to town via puca pucara and sacsayhuaman. Well worth the effort and not rushed by tour guides/groups and can do your own thing. The rocks at sacsayhuaman are amazing, not to mention the views over cuzco and surrounds. Spend half a day and check it out
Don't miss. One of the most sacred Incan sites, go with a guide! It's an awe inspiring location with really incredible energy. Check out the stone slides!

Worth a visit. Definitely worth a visit if you have time! Probably the best ruins in Peru after Machu Picchu. I would suggest having a guide to take you around as there are no signs to explain the significance and architecture of the ruins. - Awesome view of the city of Cusco from on top!

Unforgettable experience! . I visited this site with a travel group and was amazed at the precision of how each structure was built. It was interesting to learn about the rich history of the grounds as well as the symbols incorporated in the architecture.
Great way to spend an afternoon. Have an afternoon free in Cusco? Go to Sacsayhuaman. It is very scenic, with fantastic views of Cusco.

Great introduction to Inka culture . We went there with our guide Ms Christina. She was full of interesting stories, some tales and some historical facts. It is an awesome start for your Inka experience. I would suggest going there with a guide so the stones would get some meaning. Walking is easy so no need for any sophisticated outfit. Please enjoy
Cool place. Good place to go see more of the Inca's handy work. You could easily spend a couple of hours just wandering around here and has a great viewpoint to see Cusco
Wonderment. Take the time and hire a spiritual guide to take you through this place. Some of the rocks date back 3000 years and a proper guide will make you question the reality you thought you knew.

School trip!. Amazing views and history! We had just arrived in cusco and we were dealing with the altitude change as we were visiting the ancient ruins. The history and the views did not go unnoticed!
A place to see. Inca's build temples in 15th century here and the architecture is amazing. One of the tourist attraction in Cusco

Nice ruin site, pricy entry may stop some. Nice walk up behind the Plaza de Armas is the Sacsayhuman ruins. Once a fort only a little bit remains. There is also a section of very large rocks which transform into little tunnels every now and again. At 70 sols this is not a cheap afternoon activity.

Best example of inca stonework in Peru.. Sacsayhuaman is one of the top highlights of Cuzco and Peru. The inca ruins here are unique and in some ways better than Machu Picchu. Get a guide to explain the history and end your visit with a wonderful walk back down to Cuzco.
Amazing Incan stone work. A good tour guide is essential. Luxury Peru Travel was excellent.. Take the Diamox medication. Climbing in the altitude is tough. Well work the time and energy to explore.
Get a guide. Sacsayhuaman is a vast temple. You would be wise to get a guide because the history is impressive. Without one, it would be "just another ruin".
Great view of Cusco. You can hike up or take transport. View of Cusco is worth it. Not much else to do though. But if you have the time...
inca ruin. Good to see once but there are better ruins in the sacred valley and also macho picchu. Would enjoy the city more if going to other ruins in the sacred valley

Nice walk to the top. I got up early and walked up from my apartment as they were opening. I was one of the first people there. I felt like I had the ruins to myself. I spent two hours walking around and enjoyed the energy of the place before tourists began flooding in. Definitely worth a walk up in the morning before it gets too hot. Beautiful treasure of a the Cuzco area.

Great start to Cusco. Our guide picked us up at the airport, and started the 4 day tour with Sacsayhuaman. We walked the grounds slowly, trying to acclimate to the altitude. The site is quite large, and very well preserved.
Impressive stone ruins. We hiked up the hill to this site and enjoyed walking around and seeing the amazing stone work that the Incas did so long ago. Nice views of the city below too.
Unbelievable!. We took the half day trip around Cusco and this was the highlight of the day. Just how they managed to haul these stones to this spot is unbelievable.

Super Cool Ruin. The architecture of this ruin was probably my favorite, the scope and size of the stones at this site were incredible, and we had a really good guide who told us many stories about the building of this temple and the purpose of it.
Impressive. Although the stone work is not as finely done as some in Machu Picho, one can easily imagine the pomp and ceremony that took place in this ancient field surrounded by stone work

Wow what a find. This site is a good 30 to 45 min walk from Cusco centre, or take a taxi. The site is huge and an excellent example of the skillful stonemasons the incas were. These huge boulders were put together and cut by hand the precision is amazing. The whole site is so impressive, there is a moon and sun temple, numerous living quarters, it's pretty well preserved considering the age of the site. Walk to the top and you have an stunning view of the whole city. Definitely worth a visit.

Really nice place to visit but not on a tour. We took a Cusco city tour our first day in town and we were rushed through the ruins. We went back on our own the next weekend. We walked up the hill from our hotel and it was much more fun to wander around for an hour or two.

Amazing. Put this on your 'Must See' list! Taxi ride is inexpensive or you can walk there. We started walking but got lost so we took a taxi the rest of the way (it's a 45 min walk uphill from the centre of town) and we walked back. It's an enormous place so if you are on a budget you could bring a sandwich and eat your lunch there. Many people were relaxing on the grass. It's a huge place so don't be turned off by the tour buses, you probably won't even notice all the people because there are many things to see. A great 1/2 day excursion. No guide books/pamphlets are provided however guides offer to give you a tour for a fee. We just walked around ourselves and read about it before we went. All signs are only in Spanish so Google Translate would be helpful. Great views of Cusco. Take a sweater and t-shirt because it gets cool and then warm.

A very relaxing place. Sacsay = to be sated, Huaman = falcon. This archeological site was built by the Incas as a resting place/a place where they came to relax. Its huge, with stones of various shapes and heights. The story behind how these stones were brought up to the site is incredible!!! I recommend buying the Boleto Turistico/tourist ticket which is 130 soles as Sacsayhuaman is one of the many places you can visit with the ticket. The views of Cusco city are incredible, and the entire place is very relaxing and peaceful. I also recommend visiting this site as part of the Cusco city tour, because the tour takes you to the nearby sites of: Qenqo, Pukapukara, and Tambomachay.

Interesting, even after visiting Machu Picchu. Take a guided tour of Sacsayhuaman to learn about this interesting architectural site near Cusco. It is often part of a combined city'/architectural site tour. Worth seeing when in Cusco.

Largest Inca stonework!. The Incas placed stone upon stone without the use of mortar. The rocks are so finely cut that not even a knife blade could be slid in between the stonework! Sacsahuaman presents ruins a distance from Cusco, Peru. Pageants and ceremonies are conducted in native apparel. A wide variety of touristy goods ad well as food from the region can be purchased at the site, though I would caution restraint when it comes to native cooking.
Gotta go. One of the many historical spots in Cusco. An absolute must see. Steeped in history. Easy to get too, if you can score a tour that would be the best way to absorb it.

Impressive at sunset. We visited at sunset... The temperature was getting fresher but the light was perfect for the pictures..Visiting with a guide is essential, I think, unless you document yourself well before going... The guide option is the easier way since you get the information while visiting and are pointed the details "on the spot"So we saw the huge rocks making up the site, individually carved, similar to the Egyptian pyramids, the sacrificial stone and the crypt where possibly the bodies were exposed after the sacrifice...Seeing these places while the sun was down gave a it a spooky twist...All in all, the site is well maintained, the people very friendly and a private visit with one's own guide gave it a definite plus!!The phonetic way to remember the name is "sexywoman"
fascinating Inca site. Don't miss it on your visit to Cusco but best appreciated with the assistance of a knowledgeable guide
Inca ruin. Well worth time. Visit was toward end of day near sunset. Great pictures of this immense structure. Guide proved excellent overview of history of place.

History Survives. This location is another historic site showing the engineering accomplishments of the people during Inca times. These walls of stones are amazing interlocked with no mortar. The annual ceremony of the Inca people was being held the next day.

Archeological site. After enjoying Machu Picchu, we had the best luck in the world to find our taxi driver "Angel" he took his time to explain things to us and mention several sights we should see, this one was one of the recommendations! Amazing place, they were making preparations for Inty Raimy their celebration of June 24th.
Breath taking. Incredible Inka ceremonial place. Stones are massive and perfectly fitted that there is absolutely no space between them.

Fun!. Since we were in town and not too far away from the area we did a tour of the different ruins. This was the best out of all of them (besides Machu Picchu). Buy the tourist ticket (130 soles to visit all ruins). If you just buy the ticket for that 1 ruin it is 70 soles but the 130 soles tickets one lasts for 10 days and gets you into more than 4 of the ruins. It is worth the price. loved that they had the alpacas right there and they don't run from you, also there is a natural rock slide! Awesome view of Cusco too.

Nice afternoon. Sitting at about 12000 ft is Sacsayhuaman, a citadel on the northern outskirts of Cusco. Sections were first built by the Killke culture about 1100. The complex was expanded and added to by the Incas from the 13th century. They built dry stones walls constructed of huge stones. Workers carefully cut the could era to fit them tightly together without mortar. It was truly a sight to visit. We enjoyed our time here exploring around. We hired a private taxi from our Cusco hotel for the day and he drove us around to other sites as well. He waited while we explored around and we never felt rushed. I would recommend getting g a private driver for the day as well and not try to go on the public bus. We paid 250 soles for his time and had him from 0900-1730.

Beautiful Views of Cusco. A challenging early morning walk up hill was so worthwhile after we saw the ruins at Sacsayhuaman and the amazing views from far above Cusco. Definitely a recommended spot to visit and see when in Cusco. We spent more time at the lookout enjoying the views than we did at the ruins. Guides were available for hire (about $20 USD), but we declined as this was our final day in Peru and just wanted some free time to wander on our own.

The site is great but the tickets expensive.... Being interested in everything archeaeological of course wanted to visit Sacsayhuaman. The site is huge and very impressive. The only issue was that we found the entrance tickets on the expensive side (130 soles per person) and decided not to visit the park. We turend around, took the normal road up the hill and were rewarded with great views!

Better to go without a Tour. Beautiful old ruins with great views of the city. We went with a tour and didn't have as much time as I would have liked. There were more sites around it that are worth exploring (like the Jesus statue nearby) so I would have liked to have more time there. Definitely very touristy. Lots of people and vendors.
Very Impressive. I would say that you should visit this place to understand how was developed the Inca Empire and its construction as well.

Amazing!. Situated outside Cusco, an amazing structure comprising thousands of 100 tonne-plus boulders fitted together like a giant 3-D jigsaw puzzle. Take your time to admire it all including the views of the city in the distance.
Unbelievable!!. Beautiful and amazing. Hard to believe that this was built when tools were unavailable...maybe aliens really did build it!!

Blown away by the workmanship. A must see near the outskirts of Cusco. Incredible sized stone jigsaw puzzle using incredible ancient workmanship temples that would be hard to replicate in today's world. Greta to see such old ruins accessible to the travelling public.
Take the tour guide. Very cool! Amazing they moved 180 ton boulders around 600 years ago like that! Its a pretty quick visit, not a lot at the site. But worth the trip to see. Start your tour here.

Gorgeous and amazing. This sight is incredible. Anyone interested in history will love this. A gathering spot/political area for the Inca, it is beautifully made and vast. Not crowded and absolutely gorgeous at sunset. We saw some "wild" llamas and had a good time just relaxing in the historic beauty.
Fantastic Place. Amazing what is left of this site, A fantastic trip of 2.5 hours. Well maintained area and a great view.

An Inca religious site visited by Pope on his visit to Cusco. The stonework craftsmanship makes this worth the visit and a great kickoff to your trip to the Sacred Valley. Incredible how,the stones where shaped to fit so tightly. The craftsmanship is indicative of it being a very holy site.
'Inti Raymi'. Exceptional recreation of Inca rituals for this annual celebration. A must see for anyone visiting Cusco. A bit high up, so make sure to acclimate to the altitude prior to visiting.
Last battle grounds . We bought ticket to the ruins and payed a tour guide. The sun beaming on us yet it was cool. Sunblock is a most at that elevation. It will take two hours 😊
Very different Inca walls. Really nice place. Nice view of the city. The walls are really impressive. Huge stones, placed in zig zags.

Don't Skip!!!. These are great, huge ruins right in Cuzco! We had had enough of cathedrals and museums and wanted a hike. These ruins ended up being just up the road from our hotel. We spent a couple of hours walking the ruins. Great pics of Cuzco from the top and interesting history surrounding these ruins! Great afternoon activity!

The intricacy of the arrangements of rocks is amazing. We visited this site as part of a city tour, and were amazed by the size and arrangement of the rocks. Our guide was very knowledgeable pointing out the large stones at the end and middle of the wall. He told us the weights of various rocks, which were very large, and made us wonder how they moved them into position. Well worth a visit.
really interesting. I recomend this place to visit, it's wide and green and has super interesting ruins. You can go speacily to watch the Inti raime.

The original Cuzco. This has been largely rebuilt, and is very neat to see. If you have a few hours to spare, definitely worth the visit!Tip: From Centro Historico De Cusco a taxi should only be about S/.10 or less. The first charged us S/.40! The second only S/.6!
Definitely worth seeing. It is amazing to think about the amount of work involved with constructing this site high above Cuzco. Enjoy the panoramic view of the city as well
Classic Peru . Stone fortress of Sacsayhusman is worth a visit. The ultimate example of Inca military strength. Fascinating walk around the sites with interesting insight on how the Incas lived
fascinating. Visited as part of a group city tour, and this was the highlight. The scale of the place as well as the size of the rocks used to build it is just incredible.
Historic site. This is a peaceful place and also a sad place as it is where the Incas made their last stand against the Spanish Conquistadors.

Wow blown away. A must see when in Cusco, well worth the trip up the hill. Amazing what is left of this site. So much history and words can't describe the beauty. Well maintained area and a great view of the city below.

Easy sight-seeing; great photos . You have to pay 170 soles for the tourist ticket around the sacred valley. If you plan to see more than one of their options, it is worth it. We loved "sexy woman." It was a beautiful hike and yielded some fantastic photos. The engineering with enormous rocks was astounding.

must see. If you decide to go to Sacsayhuman be prepare and drink Te de Coca, because the hight is around 4,000 meters, remember be prepare, very interesting place to visit close to Cuzco 3500 meters hight need to drink Te de Coca or Coca te, is better is you take a tour.

Enormous carved stones. This site is strategically built on a hill overlooking Cusco. Some of the stones are over 30 feet high and weigh over 350 tons. The area covered by the remains of this Fortress is huge. Very impressive!

Really impressive site . Walked up a lot of very steep steps from our hostel in San Blas. Took about 20 minutes to get to the Cristo Blanco and then five minutes to the Inca site. We had already done a sacred valley tour and the 4 day machu picchu trek at this stage so we had seen a lot of ruins but this was still very impressive and worth the walk.

Less people!. This location was nice because there seems to be less people here than the other sites we visited. It was raining on and off the day we were there which probably kept the tourists away too. It was nice not to have so many people around! We did this on a city tour and our guide was knowledgable and kept it interesting!

Breathtaking!. Take a guide to truly understand the history and intricacies of these stones that once formed a fortress or temple, you decide. This was our first stop straight from the airport and the hike up literally takes your breath away so walk very very slowly no matter what age you are.

An interesting ruin...would make a great amphitheatre!!. Sitting well above Cusco this ruin has much history to share. We were there late in the day, so the shadows were deep, but still great views of the city and surrounding area.

Mysterious Inka ruins so close to Cusco. An impressive display of Inka site construction using enormous random size stones perfectly fit together without cutting them to perfect rectangles. You can't fit a sheet of tissue paper between the rocks anywhere. The stones were hauled from a distant quarry, and apparently they decided it was smarter to interface the stones at the construction site rather than cut them to shape before transport. The "temple" buildings were constructed by lifting the assembled structure and supporting them with timbers while sliding the new stones underneath after the interfacing fit was determined and the tops and sides of the new lower stones were shaped by a rubbing and "sanding" process. The largest stones were about 100 metric tons. No engineer today would attempt to building anything from the top floor down by lifting the upper structure. It was a center for a variety of religious and astronomical practices.

Sexy woman. Well that how the locals find a bit of humour saying the name of this great and historical site. The size as it is is staggering, understanding how big it was prior to the Spanish demolition is mind boggling. I really enjoyed all the sites around the Cusco area...
Ruins close to Cusco City. Very nice ruins. Make sure you have plenty of time to visit. Also helpful to have the Boleto Turistico before you arrive.

A must-see destination!. Very impressive Incan ruins high above Cusco. Weather was clear but breezy during our mid-afternoon visit this time of year so having a light jacket/windbreaker is highly recommended.

Nice ruins close to Cusco. Pronounced sexy woman, it's a place where more questions are raised than answered. Takes about an hour to explore. We had less than that due to being part of a tour group. Do this one before Pisac, Ollantaytambo or Machu Picchu so it's not a big letdown. A very interesting ruin to visit.

Worthwhile visit. It is a very interesting site to see. The area is very large and one can spend hours just walking around. Unfortunately the tours don't allow that much time but you get a feel for the place.

Impressive and mystical.. How did they do this!?! High on the hillside overlooking Cusco - make sure if you walk here that you are acclimatised to the altitude. Otherwise take a cab. Very impressive and well preserved ruins. Amazing view over the city below.
Visit. Called here on bus trip, interesting with excellent photographic views of Cuzco. How did they manage to cut the stones so precisely?

For the photos. Great vista point from which you can see all of Cusco. Unfortunately not much left in terms of Inca and pre-Inca ruins up here. With more time, I'd probably do a tour to hear more stories about what the site used to be. If on your own, you can easily do it in an hour.

While less famous than Machu Picchu it is as impressive. When you look at the sheer size of this place coupled with the many tons of boulders used to construct it you are left in awe of how this culture was able to construct this. It is truly amazing

Hire a local guide!. I signed onto a local tour to Sacsayhuaman and do not regret it on bit. We visited five sites with Sacsayhuaman being the first and the largest. The other four were each interesting to incredible, and had I been DIY touring, I would have missed out on a lot.Our local tour guide was knowledgable and willing to be flexible. We extended our stay at Sacsayhuaman as we found it to incredible. Our tour thus ran over time a bit, but we made it up to him by upping our tips to him (a bit!).There remains an argument as to whether Sacsayhuaman was a fortress or was temple grounds. Our Peruvian historian is of the temple opinion, and gave compelling arguments in the structures themselves. Both the design and the use of the structures bolstered his temple center argument. Look into the question before you go. You will see more of what you are looking at if you have the two arguments in mind when you arrive.My time estimate is for seeing several sites, not just Sacsayhuaman alone.

Fascinating Incan ruins in a gorgeous park-like setting. You can't visit Cusco without visiting this place, which was thought to be a citadel in the capital city of the Incan empire. It's located on a steep hill that overlooks Cusco and contains fascinating ruins, which show the Incan's ability to build without mortar (i.e., by fitting massive stones together). It also contains beautiful parkland so Peruvians use this site for athletic activities and picnics. Going on a short tour is worthwhile and there are a number of licensed tour guides who are always available.

amazing stones. Just outside of Cusco, this site provides a great view of the city and is an example of the amazing Inca construction skill. One stone weighs 128 tons! While the site is not as impressive as some of the others, the history of the site is quite interesting.

overlooked attraction. Everyone who heads to Cusco head out to Machu Picchu and Sacred Valley. But most have to fly in to Cusco and in the hills of Cusco, are some beautiful ruins called Sacsayhuaman. Very peaceful and majestice. Should not be missed

Excellent site to visit before going on the Incan Trail.. This place is truly amazing. It's hard to believe that there's so much more buried underneath the soil. You get to see the best examples of the Incan building methods that use no mortar.
"Incredible". It is amazing to think how the Incas were able to build sacsayhuaman . You have to see it for yourself. It is something you can not describe in words.
Very nice views . Amazing photo opportunities in this place but there isn't a terrible lot to see. It's mostly decayed ruins, but a good guide is able to make this considerably more interesting.

A must-see place in my country.. I am Peruvian and I feel really proud of my history, especially when it comes to the Incas and Cusco City. It is my second time in Sacsayhuaman and I continue being amazed by this breathtaking construction. You feel the energy, the power, the passion of the incas. If you visit Perú, you HAVE TO go to Cusco, Machu Picchu and Sacsayhuaman fortress.
interesting to see. it is a great side trip just outside of cusco but not as spectacular as other sites within the country

Impressive Inca ruins!. This place used to be a sacred Inca place, not a fortress, that is, the Incas would come here to pray, perform rituals etc. The place is really beautiful, and it is worthwhile to spend 1-2 hours there. If you live in Cusco, you can just walk there, but a taxi is about 10 soles. There are locals at the entrance that will try to offer you a 30-40 minute guided tour. I was a bit suspicious about it, but we ended up having a very nice guide! She even taught usa few words in Quechua!
Interesting place. We really enjoyed this place. Amazing how the large rocks were brought to this place and then carved to fit. A must see when in cusco
Another Inca Site to Illuminate History. This was a very walkable and interesting site to continue to learn about the Incan culture. Spacious and quiet.

Great 1st Day Visit in Cusco. We met our 3 young adult children in Cusco to do a 4 day Inca Tail hike. On the first day in Cusco, we went to Sacsayhuaman. We were all very travel weary, but we were energized by this amazing stonewalled complex. We took a taxi up and walked down since we were staying out of the city center, but it's walk-able from the historic center. Make sure you get the tourist ticket that covers many of the sights in the area, Boletto Touristico, if you plan on visiting more than 1 place.

Great view of Cusco. Very close to Cusco and offers amazing views of the whole city. Of course, the ruins themselves are awe-inspiring. Apparently, the largest stone was something like 120 tons and the joints truly are crazy tight.

History and beautiful view. The most impressive archeological site around Cusco, proving the high construction abilities of the inca people.
There is a great view on the town as the site is situated on a high hill close to it.
Horse ride. We rented a horse and road to the temple of the moon and temple of the monkey for 1/4 of the price. We were able to see Sacsayhuaman for free on our walk back to cusco
like other ruins but has a natural stone slide. The stone slide was the highlight. We got some good laughs from it. The ruins are much like many of the others. I would pick the others over this site.

Must see with a guide. We took a city tour that included this beautiful site above Cusco. A guided tour makes the site more interesting and gives insight that you will not pick up by walking around on your own. Juan was our guide (arranged by Amaru Hotel staff).

Walk around history . Essential spot to visit. And I certainly recommend walking up to this spot! There is a free way to walk up to the right of the Christo Blanco.
I would recommend getting a good guide or reading up a lot!

Another incredible Inca attraction. Amazing architecture display. The stones are huge - about 2-3 times the height of an average person. I would recommend going earlier in the day before it get's into the peak heat of the day, as there is no shelter from the sun. Also, bring cash to either pay admission on purchase the attraction 'stamp' - no credit cards, etc are accepted.

Walking tour from city. It is really close to Cuzco. So it is possible to go walking, only going up by the streets that go upstairs from main square.Ticket is S/.130 for all the major archeological sites.Impressive huge stones building this area. Not really necessary to go with a tourist tour.

Great Intro to Inca Ruins. We did this tour a day before leaving for the Inca Trail. It's a nice uphill push to get your legs stretched out for the trail. I would recommend a guided tour, there are some locals hanging out at the gate when you enter who offer tours. They will take you to highlights you wouldn't otherwise know about. Great views of the city and close to the large statue of Jesus. This is a great half day activity in Cusco!
Sacsayhuaman. The tour price is pretty fair but you have to pay a mandatory entrance fee of at least 70 soles to see the ruins

Very cool ruins but too expensive . It's like 130 Sols to get in, luckily the person at the desk gave me a student ticket for 70 Sols but even then that's an expensive ticket to get in. I realized after I got in its easier to just sneak in by hiking from Cristo Blanco. The ruins are really cool though especially at sundown the way the sun shines on the rocks.

A little overrated . There are so many great sites in the area but this one is a little less so. You have to use your imagination as it's just rock walls. If your guide isn't good at explaining then it can be a boring site.

Inca hostory right in the heart of Cusco . A 30min walk from plaza de Armas is sacsayhuaman sitting a top the hill overlook the entire city of Cusco.It's an easy 30 minute walk, or you can take the sight seeing hop on/off bus to the top. I walked and felt very safe by myself. You must buy the boléto turistico from the municipal office in town and show them when you arrive. The sight is huge. I exploded by myself and did a lot of research on the area so I was able to understand the history and significance of the site, however if you do go by yourself, you may find yourself getting bored just walking around looking at enormous rocks.You can hire a local tour guide which is also a good idea and they can take you to the other parts of the site that the books don't tell you about. From here you can easily walk over to blanco cristo (the white Christ) and take more photos of Cusco and even do some plane spotting from atop the hill as the airlines make their approach in to Cusco Airport. A beautiful afternoon. All up including the walking it took about 1.5hrs for a round trip. Definitely recommend making the effort to see this site while you're in Cusco.

Marvelous ruins. Overlooking Cusco, these are a marvelous set of ruins to visit if you don't have time to travel to Machu Picchu. I am still unable to grasp the fitting of the stone blocks using only stone tools.

Inca ruins so close to Cusco. Our tour of Cusco took us with our guide to Sacsayhuaman - not far from Cusco, you have an elevated view of the city and amazing Inca ruins at the same time. Once through the entrance you walk across the open grassed area and stand in wonderment at the sheer size of the remains of the rocks of the ruins, of the original Inca fortress.The massive walls are of stone, which have been each individually carved to fit together with the next one - they just fit together, perfectly and you can only marvel at the precision and expertise in which this must have been crafted so many years ago. We walked through the site and our mini bus picked us up at the other end where there is a car park.
Nice views of city. Worth a visit. Views of the city are great. Site itself is not really that interesting after seeing Machu Picchu. There were llamas.
Be sure to have a tour guide to really understand. Fascinating structure very close to Cusco with incredible stonework and history. easy to get to. A must see.
How Did the Incans Place Those Rock?. This site is another Incan archeological treasure. The enormous rock structure is in a zigzag formation with unfathomable precision.

Better ruins than Machu Pichu. This site has less crowds and better ruins than Machu Picchu. What it lacks in comparison to Machu Picchu is the incredible mountain views but hiking in the nearby area is still quite beautiful.

Fascinating site. A really interesting local Inca site. You can hire a local guide outside (Pay up to $20) or just wander. It's a very step climb up here which will take you some time if you're suffering from altitude sickness as we were. Fascinating site that gives one a great introduction to Inca sites and architecture.

Huge stones which surround this fortification are a great tribute to Incans' abilities.. We were greatly impressed with Incan's building strategy and workmanship. This ruin is very close to Cusco and easily reached.

spectacular massive ruins at a short distance from Cuzco.. They show the amazing building skills of Inca. Only the main massive basis remains, which adds pain for what was removed by the Spanish conquistadores. However, some of the ancient magic still remains

Less famous than Machu Pichu but an important Inca site. Sacsayhuaman is just on the outskirts of Cusco, up a mountain side and so affords wonderful views back overlooking the city. The site itself is full of Inca walls. Mostly these walls are of the closely interlocking "Imperial" Incan style, which are reserved for religious buildings. It actually has more of these "Imperial" walls than Machu Pichu. However, Machu Pichu is more famous because the ruins are more complete and because the site is in an even more impressive location. The walls at Sacsayhuaman also clearly show the "zigzag" pattern that represents lightning, which would have been a familiar and frightening sight for the Incas.
Almost as interesting as Machu Pichu. Stunning and impressive sites rendering testimony of the time when Cuzco was the capital of the Inca kingdom. Great view overlooking the city.
Don't miss it. Just outside of town, another fascinating Incan ruin. Well worth having a guide or a detailed book, as there is not much signage. Incredible views of Cusco.
amazing. one of the first place to explore in Cusco. it's impressive to see those rocks so organized. I've been wondering how amazing must to be the the sun festival (inti raimi) realized there.

Must-see ruins in Cusco. Worth visiting while staying in Cusco - easy to get to, spectacular ruins. You can bargain with the guides: there are people wandering around offering to guide. It's worth getting a guide to understand what you're looking at (and they're well prepared, with detailed pictures on hand etc.).

Cool views and awesome history. We took a taxi up here which was very affordable and definitely worth it. A guide was at the front and offered to show us around, I would recommend going wth this option. You may have to discuss the price a little bit but the information he was able to give was amazing. I would recommend taking a tour around first then wondering around afterward on your own. The views of the city were spectacular and it was definitely a must do while in Cusco.

Amazing Inca ruins with breathtaking views. Prepare yourself for an impressive view from about 12000 feet. These ruins were constructed of huge stones put together like a puzzle. Some weighing 300 tons. There is so much fantastic history here I recommend a guided tour. A tour bus can take you to a drop off point. A lot of walking once you get there some pretty flat. Of course you can climb the paths up through the massive rocks. The site is said to be a military fortress. The Inca fought the Spanish there in 1536. There is a huge open space where they hold a festival in June. Beautiful place.

Amazing Incan History and Architecture . A fun and beautiful site to learn about the history of Cusco and the temple. I grabbed a guide for 30 soles (around $10), who explained the structure, and it is more intricate than meets the eye. Very close to the main square, we grabbed a taxi on the way up the hill and took a stroll back on the way down.

Great walk, great preparation for a trek!. At a higher altitude than Cuzco, we used this trip as a means of testing our ability to cope at higher altitude. As such, we weren't expecting the beautiful views and interesting sights that came with it. It's a hike, but it's definitely worth it. Advise walking up as it only took us about 30 minutes from the centre of town.

Incredible ruin right in Cusco. Sacsayhuaman was *almost* as interesting as Machu Picchu, for me. We went with a guide who showed us the ruins as well as a slide on the rocks and a tunnel through them; amazing views of the city are here too.

A very special site. We really enjoyed this site. The shapes (and size!) of the stones are interesting and awesome. The views of Cuzco from the top and back are beautiful. One of my favourite archeological sites in Peru.

How did the Incas move and cut those rocks?. Upon arriving at Sacsayhuaman, my first thought was that I could have seen as much in pictures. But no photos could convey the massive size of the stones and how well they were cut to fit together. And how were they moved to the location? And stacked? Impressive.

Amazing architectural feat. It's amazing how the Incans manage to build this temple, and on a hill at such high elevations. The rocks were so well put together and constructed robustly. The various symbologies and meanings from specific constructs indicates a society that has excellent architectural and construction skills. There are guide books that shows where to look for specific constructs and their meanings - or go with a guide or hire one at the gate. Be aware though - some guides will talk about the history and the factual state of the site - we ended up with a guide that was a "shaman", apparently. It was interesting to hear his perspective on each of the symbols interpreted according to numerology, healing power of the chakra, etc. He lost me when he asserted the Incans built the site some 40000 years ago.... and that the Incans used the symbols "+" and "-" on the rocks to depict the positive and negative forces. Still, it was an interesting tour of the site from a unique perspective. Be that as it may, the site is beautiful, a temple on top of a hill with a beautiful "meadow" in between the 2 parts of the temple. The peaceful setting is tinged though with the realization that it was also the site where the Spaniards defeated the Incans and many died there.Climbing to the top of the temple allows a beautiful view of the city and on a clear day, one can see the snow capped mountains in the distance. We were there late afternoon, so the light cast a glow around the temple - it must be magical at daybreak when the sunrises, especially during the winter/summer solstice.FYI: there are 2 entrances to the park - a lower entrance and the upper second one where the buses park. If you are catching a cab from the city (cost about 12 to 15 Soles), make sure you get the cab to drop you off at the 2nd (upper) entrance (where you can see the temple itself). It is a bit of an uphill climb (at high altitude) from the first entrance - not worth the effort if you can get to the 2nd entrance. You can also catch the cab back from the 2nd entrance - the first lower entrance seems not to have easy transportation - I see a few visitors waiting and one was so happy to grab the cab when I alighted.

Some Amazing Stonework. We visited the site as part of the Cusco City tour. The tour includes this and 5 other sites.In regards to Saqsaywaman the stonework is amazing and the size of some of the rocks makes it difficult to imagine how they moved them into place. Definitely worth a look. As part of the tour you get a 10 to 15 min explanation of the site and it's history and the get 25min or so to explore the site yourself.We booked the Cusco City tour at Liz's Explorer for 25 Sol each but you'll need the Boleto Touristic del Cusco to get into most of the sites except the 2 churches w by where you'll have to pay extra. Still worth it.

Huge Site Of Incan Centre. This is way up above the city and is worth the visit.It is believed to be one of the centre of Incan culture in its time.The huge stones and their intricate carvings to fit with each other is pretty impressive.Useless without a guide or a good guide book.Young kids can run free here in this wide open area until you get up on the gallery structure.It is a long park to visit so be prepared to walk a fair distance. The exhibit is mostly flat unless you decide to climb up a level.The sheer size of the site is impressive and worth a visit with a good description of its history.
Jaw dropping. We got a complete tour of Sacsayhuaman and you just have to look in awe as to how that was possible. You were also to get some great views of the city below.

A great day trip. The Incan stonework here is marvelous and it's so close to the city! Definite add to your trip. We went with Sunagate Tours and had a wonderful tour of the city then this amazing site afterwards followed by a local textile shop.

Inca ruins. This site impressed me with the size of the rock blocks and how the incas succeeded to put them together to build such a place... the central part of the site is a good place for meditation and rest on the grass in the sun.Respect for the builders!!
Amazing ruins!. Dominating a hill above Cusco, this is the very impressive site of a major battle between the Incas and the Spanish. Great views of the city and surrounding mountains.
Great place, nice view of Cusco. The site itself is very impressive but I think the best part is the stunning view you have over the whole of Cusco.

Beautiful view of Cusco. Just a short drive out of Cusco and well worth it. There is a beautiful view of Cusco and one can only imagine how majestic the site must have been. Evidence of the amazing stone work is still there including the heaviest rock which is estimated at over one hundred tons.

Close to Cusco and plenty to see!. You can either walk up or take a taxi to the entrance of the park. I recommend getting a general Cusco/Inca guide book since there isnt much information at the top. There are llamas, tunnels, an amphitheater, and ancient Incan structures! So much to see so close to Cusco!

Amazing ruins! Worth visiting while in Cusco!. I love the jagged walls made of huge boulders. What an amazing site. Read about it before your visit or take a private tour in order to learn more and appreciate the history behind the ruins. It truly deserves an investment of time for learning.

Picture perfect! . This is the best place to get a birds eye view of Cusco. If you want a good panorama of the city, go here. Every photo you take will be beautiful, no filter needed! I took a private taxi roundtrip from my hotel in San Blas for 30 soles, it took about an hour to explore the site. I also hired a private guide at the doors, for 40 soles he gave me solid background information, was my personal photographer and showed me secrets to the site, like how to climb and slide down the hills or how to feel your way through a pitch black cave! These are experiences I would've never had with a tour group. There is also have a giant 11 sided, a good picture spot, said to have good juju. Well worth a visit, I knocked it out early in the morning before leaving for Machu Picchu and am glad I did!

In awe of the workmanship.... Here is a place where you stand in awe of the workmanship. Stones are individually carved to make this temple/gathering place. They fit together like jigsaw pieces, having been brought from over 9 miles away. No concrete - no mortar and earthquake proof! Need to just stand and take in the the splendor of the area and be amazed at the workmanship. Great place to visit.

How did they do this?. When we visited the ruins the first comments from my wife and daughter were that this was a fake. There could be no possible way that this could have been constructed hundreds of years ago by people who didn't have neither pack animals not the wheel. It has to be see to be believed. The setting takes you back in time to the Inka Kings. Well worth the time to visit.
cyclops forteress. Mytical place with walls made of rocks a haevy as a full jumbo jet. The central place was the scene of a battle between Pizzaro and the Inca's.
impressive. I would not walk to Sacsayhuaman - it up a very sizeable hill. Take a taxi or tour. Definitely worth seeing.
Nice view. Probably the least impressive Inka site that we visited though it is large with a spectacular bird's eye view of cusco
History and awe. I was struck with awe when I walked through this intriguing and mysterious and beautiful place. It reveals the amazing engineering capabilities of the Inca.

Nice Inca ruins and great view of Cusco. When in Cusco, this is a must-see for the Inca ruins. Our guide was very informative, but a good guide book might work. You do need to understand the history of it, though. Go on through the snake archway and walk the path to the large cross overlooking Cusco. It is a GREAT view!!!

Loved it.. I only wish I had more time, the tour was too rushed to fully enjoy this site and I would love to see this site again but really be able to enjoy it. The architecture design is amazing. I would highly recommend this place as a place to make sure you fully enjoy your time there.

$5 taxi ride from Cusco, worth a day trip there!. Great ruins to walk around and take it! you don't need a guide, just head there are wander around. The ticket is $70peruvian soles for 1 day to see all the sites around that area - you can buy the ticket at the gate to Sacsayhuaman.
