Breath-taking views and construction. Sacsayhuaman was wonderful. We had some difficulty securing a tour in English because we came later in the day, but our guide was able to communicate with us well. The construction is incredible, and there's so much to see. You will need at least a couple of hours to fully experience this site.

Beautiful ruins close to Cusco. We were able to walk up to Sacsayhuaman from our hotel (Palacio Manco Capac) but otherwise, it would be a short cab ride from the center of Cusco. We did the Sacred Valley tour the day before visiting this site and learned a lot about Incan architecture so we opted to just explore the site without a guide. I would recommend going in the morning to avoid crowds. The view overlooking Cusco is spectacular from this site and you can also walk up to the large Jesus statue overlooks the city as well. We spent approximately 2 hours at the site.

Inca ruin right at the steps of Cusco. Much of our knowledge going to Peru was concentrated on Machu Picchu. It was a delight that the tours we booked introduced us to different archeological sites such as Sacsahuayman. The colossal stones fit perfectly like legos! Really a site to behold. Best to view from afar and up. An extra for the kids was that we had llamas roaming around.
Part of your Historoical Visit to Peru. A large area with quite a few remaining walls and some steep steps. You are probably in Peru to visit Historic sites so dont miss this one.
Interesting. Interesting and beautiful views. You can easily walk down to Cusco town from here, but walking up to it is a steep hill, if you are not quite fitt, take a taxi.

HUGE STONES at Sacasyhuaman! Make sure you have a guide otherwise they're meaningless. Sacasyhuaman is a really cool place, just a 20 minute walk from downtown Cusco (up a heck of a lot of stairs, but still, walkable). My husband and I went there and quickly realized how expensive it is for tourists to visit - 70 soles per person! Blech. But since it's a "must see" of Cusco, we went for it. Didn't have time to see the other sites included in the ticket price, unfortunately. Once through the entrance gate and up to the top of the hill, we were approached by a tour guide offering us a tour. We paid 50 soles (bartered down from 60 soles) for a 1.5 hour tour of the main level of the ruins. If we hadn't had gotten a tour guide, we wouldn't have been able to recognize anything significant! Make sure to either arrive with a tour guide, or secure a random one at the site. There's a lot of history and symbolism at the site and it's pretty epic. Enjoy! The blanco christo (white jesus) is walkable from Sacasayhuaman as well, and while it's a steep hike, it's pretty neat to see it close up too.

Amazing historic place!. Bring a guide when exploring Sacsayhuaman, it will truly enrich your experience. The history of the ruins is outstanding and some facts, almost unbelievable. Always a good idea to pack a rain poncho/jacket. It rained and hailed while we were there, but that didn't stop us. At the end of the rainfall, a huge rainbow cast upon the ruins, it was beautiful. Our tour ended with a beautiful hike to a viewpoint overlooking all of Cusco.

Amazing view and interesting place . If you walk to the place, make sure your body is acclimatized as the walk is about 30 minutes and is quite steep. You can also get there by bus or taxi but I think the best way is to walk so you can enjoy the view of the city.The place itself is stunning, it's quite big and you can also walk around or chill out on the grass. Amazing view of the city from the top of the ruins. From here you can walk 10 minutes more to reach the Cristo Blanco.

Don't miss this!. Recommend not missing this site. Take a taxi up. We would recommend hiring one of the guides that are there just inside the gate. Ours cost 40 Soles (About $12) and was well worth it as she pointed out things that we would have missed. Her English was perfect and she took her time. Then, take some time to wander about this peaceful location.
Worth Visiting!!. Great area to visit and walk around, amazing ruins, terraces and fortresses, precision of carved stones is amazing.

Amazing inca site! . During our visit to Cusco we visited this ancient inca fortress. This site has tons history to it and is located in the gorgeaus mountains on Cusco. Make sure you take Sorochi pills when going its 3800 high!!

Awesome experience. Inca-build on a grand scale. This was our first site visit in Peru and we really had little idea of what this particular visit would entail. It was awesome! Fortunately, our guide had assessed our fitness levels correctly and immediately took us to the highest levels of the site. The stone-work is amazing in both scale (150 tonne stones!) and quality - even after 500 years. The oft-repeated adage about gaps and razorblades is true.We were to continue to other sites, Machu Piichu, included but as the first, this left a lasting impression of the skill and resolution of these so-called 'ancients'. Just a pity they had some less-desirable habits such as sacrificing wee girls.
Stunning precision. The precision of carved stones is amazing. Panoramic view of Cusco can take your breath away. It's better to go there with Boleto Touristico - much cheaper.

Sacsayhuaman. One of the historical sits you can visit during the city tour, which I recommend you to do before visiting Machu Picchu. This will take you approximately half a day, including other ruins nearby.It's mandatory to have the Boleto Turistico and you can buy it either at Plaza de Armas or when you get to any belonging site. Worth visiting!

Another impressive construction feat. We were on a group tour. Our guide gave us background of site. Different than Machu Pichu, but still impressive. You also get a great view of the city from the top of the structure.

Spectacular site just outside Cusco. This is a former Inca citadel, of which only the largest stone fortifications survive. The rest of the stones were taken away by the Spanish to rebuilt Cusco for themselves. A tour guide may help, but isn't essential. Consider spending a quiet afternoon among the ruins and ponder how the megaliths ended up in their current form atop this hill.

Surprising close to the town square. A good example of Inca architecture close to Cusco. The site has plenty of space to sit and admire the construction or have a picnic. There is little by way of storyboards to provide background on the site, so a guide or some pre-reading is advisable. However if you have neither, the scale of the construction is still impressive and you have a good view over Cusco from the top of the site. When you have finished there is a path down to the central square of Cusco, a 15 minute stroll.Tip:If your female the sign at the entrance makes a great photo, but you have to say the name quickly.
Impressive Site. Great area to visit and walk around to take in the Engineering feats of the Inca civilization. This site is in the city and accessible by taxi, bus or even walking

Worth the visit! . Amazing ruins, terraces and fortresses. It took about 20,000 people to build over 2-3 generations so about 60-70years, Amazon & only 15 mins out of the city, worth the visit. Great views of Cusco city too!

Fascinating place. Husband and I often found ourselves standing there, jaws agape, wondering how the heck they built this place. The stones are so precisely cut and many are absolutely massive. It's awe-inspiring to think they built those huge, sturdy walls with none of the machinery we have today.We took a taxi here, for 10 soles. And a taxi back for the same amount. So, about USD$3 each way, which is cheap. Even though we love walking and walk miles every day during our travels, this is at high altitude and all uphill. There's no way I'd attempt to walk there from Cusco, despite it being so close. Expect to spend about 3 hours here or more. We took it slow and easy because of the altitude.Well worth it.

Great views of Cusco . Having taken a few days to acclimatise to altitude my son and I needed to stretch our legs and see if we could manage this thin air.Turning right from our hotel the Belmond monasteries hotel, the lane goes straight to one of the entrances to the park. Approximately 300m above Cusco, it was a bit of a blow however we wanted the excel isle so walked along the road to the higher entrance70 soles entrance, and there are many guides to educate you, as they say, otherwise you just see rocks!Plenty of rest rooms, souvenir sellers and wide open spaces.I am certain there are a number of tours up the hill but if you want a short hike then this is very doable with a bit of effort.

Make sure you have a good guide. I went with a tour as it was easier and figured I'd get some background on it. I was the only English speaker on the tour so yet again I got a very brief translation on what was going on. It's a very impressive place to visit and as the crowds show, it's also a very popular place. On a tour, good or bad, you follow a procession of buses throughout the afternoon. So you're never alone.

How Did They Do That?!?. We visted Saqsahuaman in the last day of our visit to Peru and right after two days at Machu Picchu. Even after seeing the marvels of the complex at MP, this is an amazing site. The boulders that make up the retaining walls are immense - much larger than those that make up the pyramids at Giza! And each was cut to fit perfectly with the surrounding stones. The view of the site from the hill behind the main site is exceptional, with the glacier-topped peaks in the background and the city of Cusco below. Definitely worth a visit.
Fascinating. Visited with a local guide. Interesting and impressive site. No shade though, so sun cream and hat a necessity.
Worth the stop. Amazing display of the Incan stone work and building process. Easy walking, pretty area. Llamas for cutting the grass.

The soul of Inka. A gigantic ruins of inka. Very interesting place, especially for history lover! Many city tours will include this place so do not worry about missing it. Your tourist ticket also include this place so if you have it no need to pay extra. Also it is very close to city center you can visit here by your own.

Beautiful!. The biggest and most well-conserved ruins around Cuzco. It's worth the visit if you didn't see Machu Picchu first. Take a bus in direction of Pisac and ask the driver to drop you next to the ruins. It costs 1,50 soles. It's included in the partial boleto turistico (70soles) with Tambomachay, Pukapukara and Q'enqo. If you want to see all of them, ask the driver to drop you to Tambomachay and then walk back to Cusco stopping at the different sites. It takes approximately half a day, a bit more if you take your time.
Megalithic Ruins. Impressive, extremely interesting, must see while in Peru next to Machu Pichu, overlooking City of Cusco

Worth Exploring. This site is definitely worth exploring, however I would suggest a knowledgeable guide. Very interesting, awesome views of Cusco and don't miss the rock slide, rock tunnel and sacrificing stone. The person who didn't find it interesting must not have explored the entire site and probably did not hire a guide. There are many surprises beyond the entrance gate if you take the time to explore it.

Impressive astronomical and religious complex. I found the zigzag walls at the bottom to be very unique, along with the massive stone blocks (some weighing more than 100 tons) that had to be moved into place by many men over a 70-year period. Be sure to have a guide who can explain the significance of what you see.
Different landscape. We hired a taxi from hotel for a day n visited couple of sites including this one. Ruins are impressive but one can only appreciate if you have not already been to Macchu Picchu.
Lovely, relaxing site. This is an interesting historical site which showcases old military architecture. From the top there is a lovely view of Cusco.

Impressive. This Inca ruin just top of the hill from Cusco is very impressive and the view of the city is worth the visit. It is always better to have a guided tour to learn about the history of this famous temple.

Typical Inca site, Good view of Cusco. +Short taxi ride from main squareCan appreciate typical Incan building technique-Really need a guide to appreciate it (freelance were 50USD)No written information Expensive entry ticket (does include other sites)No food closebyNo shaded areas 1 bathroom available, outside the siteNot gated, so if you enter without a ticket from the back

Amazing site!. We took a city tour which unfortunately spent way too much time in the city and didn't allow enough time for the ruins like Sacsayhuaman so one recommendation is either don't take a tour that combines city stops and the ruins or carefully clarify how much time will be spent where. I would have enjoyed at least an hour to poke around Sacsayhuaman to fully take in not only the ruins but also the whole area to the side of the ruins where there are slides, an arena, a tunnel going into the arena some people conjecture was used by the spiritual leaders to prepare for their ceremonies, and many of the megalithic straight cut rocks. Hope you learn by our error to allow yourself more time at this site. It deserves it.
Mesmerizing and very intriguing. Mesmerizing, sacred and very intriguing. Must see when in Cusco. It is usually included with any bus city tours.
Good if you have the time. Cool site but not a must see. Great views of Cusco and neat archeological site. If you have to choose between this and Tambomachay and others, this is the one to see

Very interesting ruins!. We visited in May, 2016, and went with little prior knowledge about Sacsayhuaman. WE were easily able to buy a ticket right at the gate....in spite of warnings that we could not. But this was the off-peak season, so it was not busy. We hired a guide at the gate to help us with the history, and he was fluent in a couple of languages, including English. I highly recommend a guide. Keep in mind that you may hear the guide's opinion, not necessarily facts about the ruins. Seems that everyone has differing opinions about the Incas and how this ruins was built.

Not to be missed. Just 10 minutes by taxi above Cusco, this is a megalithic fortress/temple not to be missed. It is included in the bolleto completo. The size of the stones are just amazing and the view of Cusco is breathtaking. Even a day after a visit to Machu Picchu we were impressed.
Great place. Super place to visit with great views over Cusco. It's a really large site and very interesting. You would be best to have a guide to explain the details to you.

GREAT PRACTICE FOR MACHU PICCHU. When you're in Cusco, a visit to this ancient well built Inca fortress, at 12,000 feet is a must. Best appreciated when you have a guide although one can still do this after researching the place. If you have a private guide, one can spend as much time as possible, however with a group tour, time is limited. Very interesting massive stones from ages ago. This is a good prelude for the trip to Machu Picchu. Weather was unpredictable when we went to this site and there's no nearby shelter to run in case of a downpour. Best to bring an umbrella when there's possibility of rain.

Stunning!. This Inca sight is magnificent! The sheer size of it is super impressive. Not to mention there are fantastic views of Cusco city from this sight. We went with a guide which really enhanced the experience and painted a picture of what it would've been like at this important Inca sight at the time it was built and used. Highly recommend!

Impressive place. Amazing to learn the history of this site, amazing the stone work of the incas, you can take very good pisctures close to the Wall made of hughe stones all very finely fitting with each other. Very recommendable

best place to visit around Cusco. This is the best historical site around Cusco. We visited it with City Tour and didn't have a lot of time to explore it. I recommend to spare at least a couple of hours for it. The view over Cusco from this place is breathtaking.

Spent 3 hours 1 day on our own and 1 hour another day with a guide. I recommend you go it alone on one day. Take a taxi up to the location for 20 soles, do not have them wait, and take your time walking the area. You are at 12,000 feet so take your time! It is as massive as the pictures lead you to believe. Again, it's obvious that there was some older megalithic civilization which the Inca's found and added on based on the size of the older stones and craftsmanship vs. that added by the Inca. Who built it and how is a mystery. All the guide can tell you is about the Inca additions.
Incredible history. Unfortunately, one needs a hired guide to learn anything about significance and appreciate local and Peruvian history

Is better to hire a guide.. Be aware that some people will tell you that is not possible to buy the entrance ticket at the entrance so they can sell you tours but like any other park you are able to buy it at the entrance.You can either have a Cusco travel pass for 130 PEN which includes 13 of the main attractions entrance fees or the partial for 70 PEN, which includes the entrance to the 4 archeological sites.If I wouldn't have hired a guide I would only have seen a bunch of impressive size rocks one put after another.However, since I found some local to explain me (for a reasonable price of 40 PEN) for 50 minutes I understood many things about ancient civilization in Cusco.I like this kind of things because my beat friend love alien theories and this is one of the perfect places for those geeks.Besides if you hire a guide you have better fits than selfies if you travel solo.

Meh. You'll likely to this if in Cusco, but frankly, it's eminently missable...it's neat, I guess, but depending on where you are in your trip, evntually Inca walls blur together and there isn't anything here distinct enough to be really interesting.

Took me by surprise. I started at Tambomachay and walked down the road (safe to do alone, lots of cars passing and no aggressive dogs) visiting Puka Pukara and Q'engo on the way. They were all interesting but I'd really saved the best to last. I had no expectations but was blown away by the site. It's big with lots of varied parts to it - I particularly liked the lava slides! The main plaza is very impressive. I hired a guide at Q'engo and he stayed with my for Sacsayhuaman/Sacsaywamàn, which I would recommend. I am not convinced there is proof for all their descriptions, but it's still interesting to have a theory(s) about how the site was used. Really enjoyed it, and there are great views to the Christ statue and a view over the city. A short (albeit uphill) walk from the plaza de armas.

Walking to Sacsayhuaman.. If you want a little bit of a challenge, one can walk from the Plaza to Sacsayhuaman. You will enter from the back and it is a great work out as you slowly ascend up the mountain. Don't be discourage as I just saw some of the kids whose parents work in the National Park running up and down the stairs

Easy accessible Incan site close to Cusco. We walked to Sacsayhuaman from our hotel in Cusco. Great acclimation hike before trekking to MP. No tour guide needed. Explore on your own and take in the stellar views of the city.
Beautiful Inca Ruins in Cusco. Besides enjoying the ruins, the walk up and around the ruins was a great training for our upcoming trek to Machu Picchu.

Good Incas Ruins that are close to Cusco. These ruins are close to Cusco and have plenty to of history. I would recommend seeing them but see Machu Picchu first. Look at doing a city tour to see these.

Amazing Incan Ruins. No wonder these ruins are called the "Stonehenge of Andes!" You will be in awe at how such enormous stones were cut to fit in making walls, temples and living structures in the 13th century, without modern tools or machinery, and without using any compound to hold the stones together! The construction is amazing!

Could Spend All Day Here. We came here with a tour so didn't stay more than 30 minutes, but heard if you came on your own, you could spend all day here. It's very close to the main square, 10-20 minutes at most. The giant rocks are fascinating and magnificent! Loved learning about the history here from our tour guide - Sacsayhuaman (not pronounced "sexy woman", but close!) used to be called Inti illapa wasi = House of the Sun & Thunder during Inka empire. Highly recommend visiting while in Cuzco!

First real look at Inca civilisation. Sacsayhuaman was our first real look of a civilisation that existed over 500 years ago. We took a 1/2 day tour of Cusco and its surrounds with Inca Tours, and Sacsayhuaman was one of the sites visited. It whets your appetite for greater sites such as Pisac, Ollantaytambo and of course the great Machu Picchu. The wonderful tour or local guides explain the history of the site; having a guide is a must, you will get more out of your visit. The size of the site is amazing as is the quality of the craftsmanship.Your guide can explain many of the intricacies considered when the Incas were building this citadel.Be careful, for you are now over 3,700 metres. It is much higher than Cusco which is 3,400 metres.From the top of the site, there are the most wonderful views over Cusco and the valley below.If you are going to make the effort to get to Cusco, make sure that you take the time to visit Sacsayhuaman, you will not be disappointed.To visit this site and others, we purchased "vouchers" that provided us with tickets to most of the sights around Cusco, and the Sacred Valley. These also outlined what sites and points of interest we should see. Most invaluable!

So much history!. We went in the afternoon and were surprised to find it pretty empty. We took a cab from plaza del armas (only 15 sol) and declined getting a guide. We just wondered around for about an hour and a half taking it all in. You can also walk to the huge statue of Jesus which offers an amazing view of all of Cusco.
Visit. Nice ruin, Inca nice temple, close to visit in a day.Walk slow, drink water, take if you can a Tour with a guide to understand more of the site

Love the ruins!. AMAZING ruins! I was blown away at the first look of these ruins. Amazing craftsmanship and skill. Please take time to marvel at the corners and angles and really think about what kind of skill and the amount of time that must have gone into carving these stones. We went with a private guide which was good because she made sure we kept moving. My boyfriend and I love ruins and we easily could have spent hours and hours here and not done anything else.
Tidy and Informative . This historic site offers a clear insight into the Inca era and the effect of the Spanish colonization, well worth a visit

Great for a Cusco Afternoon. After landing in Cusco and checking into our hotel, we grabbed a quick lunch then a taxi up to Sacsahuaman. We spent the entire afternoon exploring the ruins and appreciating the grand views of Cusco. Then we hiked back down to our hotel. The stonework at this site is perhaps the best in the region - bordering on or surpassing some of the work at Machu Picchu. The stones are certainly some of the largest, and the Templo del Sol offers great 360 views of Cusco. Plan for an afternoon!

Hot but Interesting. Amazing, perfectly carved stones which weigh over 130 tons! How did the Incas ever move them! A truly amazing feat! Get a guide or a good book to explain the area. It was super hot when we visited, with no shade around. Plan accordingly.
Amazing. I was impressed about this place, I encourage everyone to visit, there's more than pictures showing , it's history, energy, we have to be proud for such a great "INCA" history...

Ruins very local to Cucso. This visit was part of our city tour and it was very beautiful. As part of the tour you only stop for a short while. I would have liked to hang out longer and explore. There is some walking an climbing so jumping off the plane and starting to hike is a risk at this altitude. If you do, breath in deeply through the nose and out through the mouth to try and limit the headache.

Impressive Incan site. Sacsayhuaman is an easy Incan site to visit just north of the main part of Cusco. You can take either a quick 10 minute taxi ride there, or walk about 20 minutes (although up a steep hill so better to walk back) depending on how you feel. Once you arrive, you will need to pay a 70 Peruvian Soles fee to visit the site (which covers a few other Incan sites nearby). It is worth it to support the upkeep of this beautiful place. The stones are impressive in terms of size and how they were sculpted and set up as a foundation for this Incan site. You also have an amazing view of Cusco from this location, probably why the Incans chose it in the first place. Definitely not to be missed!

Fantastic guide named Julio!!. Sacsayhuaman (aka Sexy Women for Quechua challenged gringos) is spectacular. One climbs up a hill with a beautiful vista of Cusco and upon reaching the top sees Incan ruins that are awe inspiring (including a 130 ton stone). However, I would not have made a Trip Advisor account just to write this review had it not been for our guide, Julio. He is well spoken (in English and presumably Quechua and Spanish), knowledgeable and, above all, passionate about archeology and his nation's history. He was extremely patient and took us on a path that my group would never have been able to replicate on our own. Julio gave is new nuggets of information at every turn and made the experience fantastic. Also he only charged 10 Soles per person. I highly recommend finding Julio when you visit!!

Worth a visit!. We visited Sacsayhuaman during our time in Cusco and really enjoyed the visit. Some tour companies include this visit as part of a city tour but there is no need to get on such a tour if you only want to visit this site as it is walking distance from the Plaza de Armas. If you decide to walk, remember that you need to buy a ticket either at the Touris information kiosk or I believe they sell tickets at the entrance. The size of the rocks there is impressive and you have a very nice view of Cusco too!
Easy to get to. This is one of the great archeological sites in the Cusco area. This site is a great example of the stone work in the building and is much easier to get around than Machu Picchu.

Beautiful . This was lovelyBeautiful to seeBut after seeing so many inca ruins is it really worth the long hike and pricey 70 soles to get in? I didn't pay this I went horseriding and we passed this and went in the back way for the same price.Enjoyed this much more than the walk up :) Talk to the locals outside the ticket office to get a good deal on horse riding

One of the Trifecta. Perhaps the easiest of the Inca Ruins Trifecta (Machu Picchu, Pisaq, Sascayhuaman) to get to, it is impressive in it's engineering, scope, influence and history. Sweeping views of Cusco, easy walking to most of the impressive stone walls and structures. A guide really helps understanding the history and significance of this site. Highly recommended

BIG Rocks. This area is a archaeological sight on one of the many hills overlooking Cusco. The rocks the Incas moved to build this sight were enormous. Great place to check out and hike around. Nice scenery and llamas

Interesting and historical. It's not far from Cusco so I would recommend making sure this is one of your stops if you're in Cusco for a couple of days. It's helpful to understand the history of this site before going as it was pivotal in the Spanish defeat of the Inca.

Easy to walk to from our hotel. Expensive entry but you can get the combination pass if you want to see other ruins. As ruins go, this was interesting and not crowded (I would rate Angkor Wat or any of the ruins of Egypt as far more spectacular, plus SO MUCH CHEAPER!)We enjoyed walking around here, the views to the city are beautiful and the ruins are interesting. It made it nice that there were no so many people there.
Amazing Engineering. Surely worth the stop! The grounds are absolutely beautiful and there are wonderful views of the city from up high. Pretty easy walking, bring water.
Amazing! Huge gigantic stones much like Stonehenge!. Amazing fortress! Walking poles are helpful though the climbing steps aren't as difficult as Machu Picchu.
Amazing!. Great history tour at Sacsayhuaman. This was a nice way to start out our trip in Cusco. Cusco Punco tours helps to understand the history of the area prior to seeing Machu Pechu.
A step back in time. Scenic ride to the site. Not as impressive as Machu Picchu or the site at Ollentaytambo. You can take a great picture of Cusco from the statue of Jesus.

A little confused.... I thought I had done enough research to have some idea what we were doing...however I didn't know much about these tourist tickets! My husband and I hiked up to the site and about halfway up you come to the parks entrance where u will have to buy the entrance ticket - 70soles for 1 day (4sites) or 130soles for 10 days (all sites including sacred valley) as we had already hike that far we didn't really want to go away and think about it so we just purchased the 1 day ticket.The lady told us it was easy to get to the other 4 sites, you can walk and there is a bus...so we set off. Sacsayhuaman was easy to get to and great to look around. Q'enqo was next, a little confusing about which path to take but it's simply just along the main road and easy to walk. We enquired at Q'enqo about how to get to the 3rd park (it was 4.5km away) and he said that there is no bus but we might be able to get a cab on the road...we didn't want to risk it so we walked back to Sacsayhuaman where there were a number of available taxis. It cost us 30soles for a ride to the 2 remaining parks and to get back to Cuzco. The other 2 parks are a nice change from Sacsayhuaman and Q'enqo as the have a more relaxed vibe and beautiful mountain views.However, now we are looking at a sacred valley tour I'm kinda wishing we went for the 130soles 10 day ticket!!

Awe Inspiring. Our guide helped us to remember this name by saying "Sexywoman" - but this was an ancient site where one can really learn and understand the Incan Culture. The zig-zaggynexx and lightening shape of the structure gave it incredible depth for spectacular picture taking.

Our first Inca Ruin. Don't even try to pronounce it, everyone calls it sexy woman. It is amazing. If you go with a guide have him or her take you thru the tunnel in the rock, pitch black and a tight squeeze. And don't forget the alter where there were actually human sacrifices.

Not just a pile of rocks. No, this is a pile of HUGE rocks expertly cut and placed. How did they do it with no machinery? I suppose the Incas had a lot of time on their hands. You simply can"t visit Cusco without seeing this. You 'll only need an hour.

Very intriguing structures. We visited Sacsayhuaman today. Sacsayhuaman is an Inka ruin just above the Cusco city. We took a taxi from our hotel (historic Cusco) to the site. The taxi fare was S15 (appx US$4.55 in my exchange rate). The Boleto Turitico, which I purchased earlier in the day, includes this site. The site requires reasonable amount of walking and climbing (and at 12,142 feet elevation it not an easy task). But it is easily doable if you don't hurry. The stone structures are defies logic. How a civilization that did not have wheels, metal tools can build such stone structures is unexplainable. Some of the stones are big, really big. They are cut in such precision and fit together that there is absolutely no gaps between the stone. You have to see to believe it. It takes two to three hours to see all the sites within the site. By the way, when we were about done visiting the site, we called the taxi driver and he picked us up from the gate without any extra charge (S15).
Nice site. Nice site close to cusco. We took a cab uphill to qenko and walked downhill to cusco via Sacsayhuaman. We asked for a tour guide, Julio showed us al interesting places in this site!

WOW!. The stone work here is some of the most impressive of all the Inca sites. Huge stones on top of each other that just make you wonder how did they do this. A must see and give yourself plenty of time.

Lots Of Walking...Be Prepared...It Is Worth It!!. This Inca site contains so much history about the Inca Empire. Knowing a little history prior to my trip to Cusco, Peru - I knew that Cusco was the Capital of the Inca Empire and there are still many new archeological sites being discovered nearby and that is fascinating to me. What is also something to remember is the altitude adjustment - Cusco is actually higher in altitude than Machu Picchu - this location is over 12,000 feet above sea level - that is just crazy - so be prepared for possible headaches and nausea. There is much ground to cover and you might run into a Llama during your tour.

Better than expected. The guidebook I had didn't tout this very highly, and I can't figure out why. I went on a gorgeous day and saw beautiful soaring views of the city and the mountains, in addition to the ruins themselves. No, there is not a lot left of the buildings themselves left, but there's plenty to see of what's remaining of the elaborate defense fortress. The walk up can be a little steep, but the walk back was pretty and relaxing.

Excellent trip to enjoy with group or family. What an amazing site with so much history and just 30 minutes outside of Cusco. It's part of what is believed to be an ancient solar calendar, and is intriguing way to gain insight to the Inca culture, ingenuity and technical skills. It is so amazing how the Incas were able to move such large boulders to create this structure. The view of Cusco City is also pretty awesome from the up there. Definitely worth a visit while in Cusco.

An absolute must!. If you're up for a steep step climb, it's a great walk through the neighborhoods. If exercise isn't your thing, a cab or tour will do. A magnificent fortress representing Inca ingenuity and engineering.

Awe inspiring. This Inca archaeological site is truly impressive. It's hard to imagine how the Inca's moved stone from more than 3 miles away to this site, or how they pulled water off the mountains to supply the city. We visited as part of a OAT tour, and were dropped off at the entrance, versus hiking up from the town of Cusco. While there is plenty of walking involved, it's nothing compared to the large uneven steps of Machu Picchu. Don't miss this amazing site. You can't take a bad picture.

Amazing ruins near Cusco. These are beautiful archaeological ruins, a short hike (25-30 mins) or a bus/cab ride from Cusco. Must visit. Beautiful panoramic view of Cusco. I was lucky to have beautiful weather when I was here.Can also visit Cristo Blanco , just 10 mins away from here.

Nice view and interesting site. This is a site that overlooks Cusco and is one of the many archaeological sites in the area. It is not real easy to get to, but it is enjoyable. We had rain, which was a bummer.

Impressive Inca remains. The site dates from the Inca empire and large part of it remains despite the terrible destruction caused by the Spanish invaders in the XVI century. It is located on a hill just outside the beautiful city of Cusco. The huge size of the stones used by the Incas and their perfect ensemble are unique and make this historic site a must see place.
NICE!. Dont go with new trainers. I remember that i went with my new trainers... BIG MISTAKE!!!! You will walk alot on BIG STONES! Its a cool placee! :)
relaxing. Nice views and trekking roads, its an ancient place, definitely a place to visit in Peru, ask for vulca store
Sexy woman !. Very good scenery! We visited the site when we took a horseback riding tour. Did not go on the inside but was close enough to see the outside ruins and take pics

Wonderful Incan ruins atop an accessible hill. If you visit Cusco and have any level of fitness then make sure you take a walk to Sacsayhuaman, which is just outside town. He outlook is incredible and in the Kate afternoon light it takes a great photo. If you want to make a day of it you can take a taxi even further afield to Tambomachay. From here you walk back down through several sites of historical interest. You need a tourist ticket to access most of these places, but I'd be tempted to just get a partial - the museums and galleries aren't that well curated.

Impressive architectural site . Temple if the sun and lightning, 15 minutes from Cusco.Impressive assemblage if boulders and carved Rick's to create this temple. Just to think about how boulders were move is worthwhile.

Great ancient must see. On my trip to Cusco, went twice once from each entrance. One of which is within a 20 minute hike from city center up hill. It is one of the must see sites in the area. The farther entrance requires a cab ride and has other sites just a little farther out and a wonderful small alpaca wool processing factory with a great short explanation tour and the best negotiable prices and quality around Cusco. PS. They expect you to haggle.
Sexy woman. The size of these boulders is impressive and hard to imagine how the Incas moved them . An encore to Machu Picchu.

One of our favorites!. We really enjoyed walking up from our AirBnB place at the end of Tandapata to the Sacsayhuaman site, then across to Cristo Blanca and down the steep stairs into town. We saw about 20 Inca sites counting those along the Inca Trail and the stonework at this site really stands out.

Sexy woman! Impressive Incan battle site. That is how our guide said to remember this place...sexy woman is much easier to remember than Sacsayhuaman! A truly stunning piece of engineering, that has stones weighing hundreds of tons forming a wall of zig zag shape. The site of the last Incan battle, with beautiful views is definitely a "must see" in Cuzco

Must-See. We had a few days in cusco and decided to have a taxi take us to the historical sites in the area for a few hours. This was by far the most impressive site in the area. We were lucky enough to find a guide who was available to take us around the site. I would highly recommend hiring a guide for this site since it is so large and so historically important. We were there for an hour, I only wish that I had more time but I had a massage booked in cusco we had to get too.
Huge in Scope. When you stand next to the huge boulders that make up this site you are dwarfed but them. the site has little else but a climb up will give you a great view over Cusco.
Beautiful . This is beautiful site and is good for people of all levels of fitness to explore. It is much larger than i expected and offers an amazing view of Cusco, which it sits just above.

Must see if you have time in Cusco. We went here for an hour during a private tour of Cusco. The ruins are impressive and it is nice to see the apparent battlefield of the the ancient Spaniards versus the Inca. The walk also includes a nice vista of Cusco. It is a nice afternoon or morning outing if you have time while staying in Cusco.

Beautiful place to spend a few hours!. Sacsayhuaman (easy to remember because it rhymes with "Sexy Woman") is about a 5-10 soles taxi ride up the hill from the Plaza de Armas and well worth your time if you are in the area and have 2-3 hours to kill. It's a beautiful place rich with history. There are great views of the city, a slide worn out of the rocks, and some tunnels and a cave to crawl through as well if you like exploring a bit.

Beautiful archeological site!. It is about a 20 minute drive from Cusco and it is definitely worth visiting. There is a great view of the city of Cusco. It is amazing how the Incas built this fortress aligning these huge stones with perfect accuracy!

Nice historic complex . I think it's the best historic site we have seen in cusco. The sunny day helped. I mean, it's not like there's soooooooooooo much to see, lots of stones but if you are in cusco you have to go!

Definitely worth a visit. An amazing place full of history and culture. There are several different theories as to how it was built and what it was used for but the one I liked most was that it is the temple of energy with the main walls built to represent lightening. It is a nice walk down to Cusco from there as well.

Just one of the amazing sites we visited. This was only one of the many Inca sites we visited on our tour. It was astonishing to see and try to comprehend how the ancient Quechen civilization was able to build such precise and astronomically aligned structures. Well worth getting the Cusco Tourist Ticket (Boleto Turistico del Cusco) which gives you access to at least a dozen different sites in the Sacred Valley. The price is Soles $120 which is only $43 US.

Interesting - I like the jagged teeth!. This is different to most of the many Inca ruins you will be pointed to (and will eventually get bored of) due to the jagged teeth structure of the walls. Well worth seeing but you need the tourist ticket and need to see quite a few other sights with it to get your money worth.You can also wander across to see the jesus on the hill once you're done!

What a site!. Beautifully crafted, towering over Cusco, Sacsayhuaman is an impressive site. Unbelievable evidence of past glory, built with incomprehensive precision, this former temple site makes you ponder how was it erected with little to none technology.Entry with a Cusco Tourist ticket that can be purchased in advance or at the site for the equivalent of $43. Cusco Tourist ticket is also valid for other Sacred Valley sites such as Qenko, Punca Pucara, Tambo Mackay, Pisac, Ollantaytambo and Chinchero.

Sexy woman or too hard to say.... Unbelievable Inca. Ruins with walls made of huge boulders (how did they do it?). Well preserved, clean and easy access, many llamas walking around. Very short drive from Cuzco. Not to be missed!

Fascinating!. I went with a group of people and this was one of the locations that I really wanted to see and it did not disappoint for me. Before going I had done my research and knew what I was looking at, but we still had a guide, which I highly recommend! It was nice to even sit in the field and appreciate what went into the building of this amazing structure! The Incas were genius engineers! I recommend taking a taxi here as we made an attempt at walking there and it is 2 miles or more straight up hill and if your in Cuzco to acclimatize this may not be the best start. It's was like 6 soles, which is $2.00, totally worth it!
Awesome. Can you believe they moved these rocks weighing tons and tons to top of this mountain. Absolutely Incredible. Would have liked overview map with descriptions.
Great visit. This is a place you can't miss.It's really amazing! If you can read about it, before visiting, it will be of great help. The huge sotones and the views are stunning.
Sacsayhuaman. Very interesting. Well preserved ruins. Amazing how the Inca's cut and moved the stones to build Sacsayhuaman. Well worth a visit.

Another wonder to explore. This architectural wonder sits high above the city, with views of the surrounding area. The grounds are expansive and well maintained. It is any easy place to navigate if you are unsteady on your feet, but there is quite a lot of walking to see the entire site.
Stunnig. A truly unique site, Astonishing workmanship. easily accessible from Cusco. Great views.Not to be missed.

Best ruins local to Cuzco. There are a lot of ruins to see in the area. I'm guessing this is because of the relative age of the Inca empire. (Oxford and Cambridge had both been founded before the rise of the Inca's) It's easy to get Inca ruin fatigue but I have to say that this place was the best of them, for size and impressive stonework.

A must see site. If you are in Cuzco you must see this site. The sheer magnitude of the site, the 350 ton stones, the human effort and skill to build the walls is simply awe inspiring. I still find it hard to understand how ancient man did this. The site itself is very large so it never seems busy. It is very quiet and peaceful up there away from town. We arranged a cab with our hotel to take us to four sites, wait while we visited each site then return us to the hotel. The total cost was 80 sols. Well worth it as it was totally trouble free and we went at our own pace. I don't recall seeing a cafeteria so you may want to bring some snacks. The washrooms were clean and functional. There are personal guides at the gate for a few sols if you want more in depth info. It can get windy and cool up there, as you are up on the mountainside. Good shoes are best but I saw lots of people wearing flip flops so it is proof that it is a nice leisurely place to stroll. Go see it.

Expansive display of Inca masonry. This location features Inca stonework of a massive scale. It further prompts the question: How did the Incas move, place, and fit such massive boulders? Grand view of Cusco from the top of the top.

Very good introduction to Inca building techniques.. With a breathtaking view, the huge stone terraces offered a great introduction to Inca building. A bit crowded when we visited, but not uncomfortably so. And what did we expect? The trip also included other stops, including a weaving cooperative, with a demonstration of the creation of natural dyes.
Remarkable place. In a country filled with ruins I didn't expect to be impressed, as this one of my last visits. Easy hikes. Great views. Would recommend to anyone in Peru.

Interesting bit of history. This was on a tour I took. Lots of old granite walls and green space at about 12,000 ft altitude. Our guide was definitely up on his history. It had llama's roaming freely on the grounds.

Breathtaking. Wear good walking shoes, a hat, sunscreen and pack a light rain poncho. It was sunny, with little clouds, so we chuckled when a man came by selling ponchos. We were at the end of rainy season. About 5 minutes later cold, slushy hail came down for about 15 minutes. Needless to say our party of 28 bought all the ponchos the man had. We were amazed by the skill of the rock cuts and how they all fit together. Truly amazing. A must do!

Lots of hidden gems!. My wife and I recently spend 10 days in Cusco and this was one of our day trips. Some people might think I'm crazy calling this site a "Day Trip" but we spent about 5 hours here and loved it. There are hidden caves, hidden ruins, an Inka bath tub, rock slides and so much more. If you really want to see the hidden gems you cannot do a tour. They'll rush you through the main site in 20min and you'll miss everything else. I'd suggest walking around the perimeter of the site. You'll find trails and you can follows these. Unfortunately I can't give much more description about the hidden caves. They're quite hard to find and we chanced upon them because we meticulous explored the whole site.If you're interested in doing a huge explorations of the ruins bring food and water! If you leave they'll charge you for re entry.

Nice and close to cuzco . Nice counpound of ruins very close to cuzco. The obit thing is the price of the boleto quite prohibitive although you can see two other less interesting place with it. 70soles

Disappointing. The ruins here were the most underwhelming of the sites we visited.There wasn't much here compared to other sites in the sacred valley. A good place to stop on the way back to cuzco but not worth the individual trip

Great big rocks! . Biggest among the 4 ruins close by. The one day 70 soles boletos pass can get you in here plus the other 3 sites. We hired a taxi to just drive us here plus the 4 other close by ruins.
A must see!. Amazing! We had a private tour guide and it was worth every penny to learn the history of this place and how the Inka's moved these huge stones with pure manpower.

Don't miss this place!. This is located about a mile outside of Cusco. Its a cab ride from the center of town, about 10 soles ($3). Built by the Incas many centuries ago it sits above Cusco and give you a great view of the city and the river that runs through it. Great place to bring lunch and picnic on the grass.

Absolutely incredible. This is just a short drive out of town and the work there is just fantastic. One of many Inka sites visited, but it left a wonderful impression. Unfortunately, I was in a tour group, and did not have the opportunity to really visit as much as I would have like....

Impressive and Majestic with Astonishing Views of Cusco. One of my favourite sites in Cusco, Sacsayhuamán is an impressive Inca fortress overlooking the city. Every time I visit, I'm impressed by the size of the boulders used to construct the walls of this fortified complex. Both the site and the views it offers over Cusco are amazing. Pro tip: on one side of the site there is an area of rocks that have been worn smooth, which you can use as a slide.

Amazing but need at least 2 hours.... We visited Sacsayhuaman as part of a half day city tour and would have liked to spend a bit longer here. Very interesting but you probably need a guide to get the most out of the visit.
Pretty large ruins. There are so many ruins in the Cusco area, it's hard to compare them. However, Sacsayhuaman is beautiful, but takes a long time to walk. It's huge!

Don't miss this fabulous ruin!. The "lightning" or "zig zag" walls in this important Inca site are one of the most amazing things we saw in Peru, especially considering that they were made without stone tools! Don't miss this if you are in Cusco. Climb the stairs up from town if you are getting ready to do the Inca Trail in the next few days, or take a taxi. It is worthwhile to hire a guide but not necessary.

A trek up but worth it . This place has a lot of history and allows you to have a good view over cusco. I would recommend getting a guide as there are a lot of little details which you will otherwise miss. Wr got a guide at the entrance and paid 30 soles for 1h. Negotiate the price as they will ask you for a lor more.
Good warmup. These ruins are a nice warm up for the Sacred Valley and is close to Cusco. If you are looking for a place to begin your understanding of Incan culture and history this a good place.
takes about two hours. but any of the city tours will give you a view from outside and that maybe all you really need. You can walk in from Cusco city
Amazing building achievement. Great place to spend 1-2 hours exploring. Amazing how the Incas were able to pull this off with no modern tools... nice scenic view over Cusco

Interesting visit. We were in Cusco on our way to Machu Picchu and Sacsayhuaman was part of our tour. I think a visit here is a great way to acclimate and prepare for the walk i through Machu Picchu. We walked around this ruin for about 1 1/2 hours and saw many large rock formations that were spectacular. A great place to visit.

Huge site with a view. Very impressive ruins high above Cusco. We struggled a bit with the altitude as it was on our first day in Cusco. The scale and size of the site and the amazing stonework is a must see.
First attraction in Cusco. Very close to the city - an easy taxi ride. Amazing architecture and story. We visited when there were not too many people there and it was very peaceful.

A MUST See when in Cusco!. We arrived early and beat the crowds. Best to wear your hiking boots with ankle support as you are climbing up and down uneven stairs. The site was immaculate and you can see as much or as little as you wish. Beautiful views of Cusco and Cristo Blanco. We encountered llamas just lazing the morning away chomping on grass - definitely got selfies of that encounter!
An Amazing Visit. We had a personal guide through this area. The sites were amazing and this is a must when you are in Cuzco.

Machu Picchu a must see. Our guide had us hike up to a high point and told us not to look right (toward the ancient city) but to look down or to the left...he said that was so we can experience the "Magic of Machu Picchu. We did as he said, then all together turned to see the whole place in one complete view .....gasp! ..incredible! Make sure you take time to be alone in some of the spaces and feel the energy (if you are into that sort of thing). in some places it is very strong. Make sure you look down below and find the little farm house where the boy lived who showed Hiram Bingham the lost and jungle covered city of Machu Picchu.

Huge stones on a historical significant place. We visited this important site for the Inca's as part of a full day tour with our guide Edgar from Tikariy tours. You really (always) need a guide to learn more in depth about the background, hypothesis, different interpretations etc of a place. And Edgar was very knowledgeable! And you can enjoy a wonderful view over Cusco valley from up there.

Must Visit in Cusco. This is a must visit archaeological site in Cusco. It can be combined with Q'enko, Tambomachay, and Pukapukara for the 4 ruins tour of Cusco.If you go on a Sunday with good weather, the surrounding area will be lively with locals enjoying their day with picnics, family, and games. It's a great way to spend a day in Cusco.

Photos don't capture this place.. Even if the ruins weren't there, the views alone are surreal. Photos do not do this pace justice.Some tips:There are no restrooms at Machu Picchu once you get inside. I would recommend you eat light before you go and visit the facilities before entrance just to make sure you are on empty. You don't want to have to hike all the way back to the entrance.We got up a 4am to be there for sunrise (This was in May). The sun was already up by the time they opened the gates. If I had it to do over again. I would have slept until 6am and taken my time.Go in the morning. It is nice and cool. In the afternoon, the sun is pretty intense.Take the train at least one way. It is a beautiful ride and comfortable with clean restrooms.We did not get a guide. There are so many guides that you almost can't help but over hear them anyway. Save the money.I saw some people with small kids there. I would not do that. Some of the ledges are no joke. I would only take teenagers. That is just me.If you feel the need to be there first, have your whole party at the bus line no later than five. The line will start to form between 4 and 4:15, but you will still get on one of the first three buses if you are there by 5. That will get you there in time for the opening. If you try to save someone's place i the bus line, it won't work. They come through the line and stamp your ticket around 5 or so. If stragglers show up later to join their group, they won't get on the bus without the stamp.The llamas up there are tame. You can approach them with no worries.The hike to the Inca bridge is not for people who have a fear of heights.Hope some that helps.

Impressive, sprawling site. This is a huge site, more horizontal than vertical, but once you start to walk through (best bet is to have a guide) you can get an overview and appreciate what was the majesty of this location. Make sure you check out the huge, 3000 lb stone as partt of the zig-zag wall.

Everything you expected and more. As many times as one has seen the famous photos of Machu Picchu one is never prepared to see it for the first time, the magnificence of the location and the extent of the ruins are an awing experience. There is a lot of climbing and a lot of corners to explore, we were there for about four hours and could have stayed longer. Getting a guide is a good idea.We arrived around noon time and the morning had been very rainy but in about an hour the sky cleared. I think this is typical, so maybe going in the afternoon is your best bet, also a lot of tourist come from Cusco directly and they are gone by mid day so it is less crowded in the afternoon.Be ware of the bus ride from Aguas Calientes, it is a hair raising experience, the drivers seem to take pride in seeing how close they can get to the precipice, and the road is so narrow that can only accommodate one vehicle so sometimes the buses had to back up in this narrow, steep, slippery roar. You are better off not looking out of the window.

A must for Peru traveller. Great historic and archeological site with modern accommodation and service nearby. Good scenic bus ride and climbing around. Better to take an earlier tour or visit as part of the Inca Trail. A full day and a lot of water recommended. You need to be fit to cope with the altitude Nd steep climbing. Very picturesque setting and mountains around.

You just HAVE to see sexy woman!. The ruins here are quite impressive.......of course, not nearly as impressive as if the Spanish had not stolen many of the stones from here to build the Church in Cusco, but these ruins are far different than anything else that we saw on our trip.The largest of all the stones that the Incas used in their foundations is located here, both the tallest as well as the heaviest ones. The stonework here is as good as that in MP or in Ollantaytambo. An hour or two here should suffice, not too much to take photos of, as we have found that photos do not do this place any justice any way.
Great Place to visit.. I can not believe we were there, what a great experience . Trian trip to there was super, if you go, book a vista dome train.

A wonder of the world. Machu Picchu is an impressive and utterly unique Inca Citadel, situated atop a mountain above the Urubamba river valley. It was the ancient Incan gateway to the Amazon rainforest, and believed top have been a powerful fortress, holy site, and university in Incan times.The place is utterly awe-inspiring, and almost every word that the guides grant you is fascinating. We visited Machu Piccu after four days of hard trekking on the Inca Trail, and happened to arrive just as a downpour was beginning.I have to say that the rain, quite apart from dampening our spirits, actually made Machu Picchu come alive - with ancient, carved rain gulleys and gutters roaring into life as they carried water from the mountain into the valley below.Most definitely a bucket list activity. Go and book your flights to Peru to see this place. Go on. Do it. Now! I will remember this place for the rest of my life.

Perfect half day activity. This was a great way to get our feet wet on Incan construction and history. We hired a private driver for 80 S and bought the half tourist ticket for 70 S that allowed us to go also to the ruins of Puca Pucara, Q'enko and Tamomachay. When we got there we were aproached by a guide and boy, were we glad we agreed to have her show us around! She explained the way and meaning this giant boulders where placed. Also took plenty of pictures and pointed at several important details that otherwise had come amiss. Perfect half day activity since we had to go back to town for our cooking class. The other sites had no guides available at that time, but Q'enko was noteworthy with it's labyrinths and underground altar

Awesome Ruins. The ruins you will see at Saqsaywaman are incredible. How they ever moved rocks of that size and fit them together so perfectly will just astound you. The building rocks here are much larger than those at Macchu Piccu. There are beautiful views from these ruins including views of the Christ statue. One of my favorite things here was the herd of llamas that live up on the hill. They will let you walk right up to them for pictures but they absolutely did not like to be touched. I would highly recommend this stop.

Trip-Peru. I traveled to Peru last September 2015 so I'm late in writing this but I booked with Milena Fernandez and she worked with me for months on developing just the right itinerary. Milena included places that were not on my radar had I been the sole planner. It was delightful. I highly recommend this tour company. If in Ica, a must is the sand dunes and sandboarding. Trip-Peru contracts out to local guides who were exceptional. I will be going back to Peru to visit the Jungle and Lake Titicaca and when I go, I will go through Trip-Peru on any future trips,
A nice place. If you like Inka ruins, then you will like this place too. It's close to Cusco, so mainly it's easy to go. But it's not that impressive like other ruins the have around.

Sacred Valley. A whirlwind day tour of Chincherro for textile experience Ina community based place, the spectacular green Inca terraces at Moras, lunch at Yukay organized by Condor Tours and finally working off all that buffet calories climbing the 14 terraces of Ollaytatambo was just fabulous. Would have liked to take pics of the salt fields at Maras.
increíble. a beautiful sight to behold within the mountain range and cascading fog, truly a spiritual experience

Sacsayhuaman. This fortress on the outskirts of town is definitely worth a visit. You will not believe the huge rocks that were put into formation, and the architectural placement of those huge stones is unbelievable! This is a must see! Easy walking.

Not worth it!. With the high altitude; we only wanted to do this one site. It was 70 soles ($23) each. We explained we only wanted to see this one site, but that was the price. It was not worth it at all. IMO the city is gouging the tourist by not having a ticket to only see this fortress. See Machu Pichu; but no need to pay the high price to see this.....maybe if you plan to see all on the multi ticket; but you need transportation to get to the other sites.We noticed a guard with binoculars watching for people sneaking in from the back. There are ticket booths at 3 entrances.

Machu Picchu and Galapagos trip with Andean Discovery. A long time dream of being in Machu Picchu was finally realized. Andean Discovery Tours created the PERFECT adventure for us. There are many moving pieces to this trip..planes, boats, buses, trains.. we did not have to worry about a thing other than my camera and enough storage on my card. Loads of amazing photos.Every accommodation was more spectacular then the other. With the attention to detail and off the path discoveries, I truly felt the full experience of the Peruvianculture. Our guide Manu was the perfect blend of knowledgeable and fun. Even my last minute request to hike Wanapicchu was no problem for them to get a limited pass for me. When there is so much expectation, I am pleased to say with Andean Discovery, there was not disappointment.
Sacsayhuaman. A great half a day trip within easy walking distance from Cusco centre. Worth a visit! Good preparation for the Inca Trail.

It's a once in a lifetime experience. I personally did the hiking trail. But upon reaching the site of the ruins I never realised how much more there is to explore there. You need some level of fitness to be able to explore all the bits in one day. Remember to use the bathroom before entering since there are no way to use the loo inside.

Apus-Peru provided the best experience!. We did a one day trek on the in a trail, getting off the train at mile marker 104, hiking 10 miles to arrive at Machu Picchu. Hector, of Apus Peru, was our guide and he was wonderful, knowledgeable, and a joy to be with during our tour.

Imagine those boulders. Once you get there, you will marvel even at a far distance (esp. at a distance!) as to how intricately the Incas built this fortress. I could only imagine such force to align all those huge boulders on top of another. It's absolutely a must-see. I'd advise you to wear your most comfortable shoes and warm clothes if you're doing your trip from January to April. Weather is perfect during this time but chilly.

Great site. Well restored site worth visiting with a guide. Take the bus up unless you enjoy pain and then you can hike up to the site. Time the visit in the early morning before the major crowds start, and you'll only have to spend one night in the town. The local restaurants like to play scams - 'free' pisco sours, reduced rate, etc, and then add on a service charge. Some restaurants are fine but verify charges first and the ones that play the games, be sure not to leave any tip.

The wonder of the world. Well arranged tour with America Expeditions agency in Cusco.Hotel pick up, bus to Ollantaytambo, then the train to Aguascalientes, the bus and the tour in Machu Picchu, and all the way back.

Interesting. We visited Sacayhuaman as part of our tour and we didn't know what to expect after visiting Machu Picchu 2 days before. It cannot compare, but it is very interesting. It was a fortress with massive walls of hewn stone. Our guide explained lots of things about why and how. The walls are 5 meters underground as well. The top stones have been stolen and used for a lot of buildings in downtown Cusco. But is still very impressive.
Sexy Woman!. This place is amazing. The huge boulders are impressive - as they must have been to those visiting the Incas. Beautiful site, restrooms available. Free and easily walkable.

Historic Ruins. With alpacas roaming the spacious grounds these Incan walls and architecture are a site to see. The precision in which the rock are cut to fit is pretty amazing. With all the green grassy fields surrounding the ruins you do not feel crowded at all. A nice leisurely stroll.

Sexy Woman. This site sounds just like the title above and involves a walk up a fairly gentle slope, but I was still puffed out due to the high altitude. I had to explain to the guide the only way to get that high in Oz is in a plane! We visited this site and others from Cusco in a tour group of about 12. We stayed in an excellent hotel called Maytaq Wasin, which is a 5 minute walk to Cusco's main square. Lots of alpaca stuff for sale, but beware of acrylic stuff from those walking the street.ABC or 3 again, if you like that sort of thing. I had a funny haggle with a stall holder about 2/3s of the way up Sacsayhuaman for a tablecloth. I liked it but it was too much (120 sols) but she caught me again on the way down. I only had 40 sols on me and after she followed me down the path for a few hundred metres coming down in price as we descended she finally took the 40 sols, although with an unhappy face. The main reason for this post is to recommend the Maytaq Wasin. Very friendly staff, good breakfast and evening restaurant also good, but watch the servings! We found them very large, so think about sharing 1 dish if you're not too hungry.
Interesting Ruins. Worth a trip when visiting Cusco and the surrounding area. Very beautiful scenery and different ruins.

Very interesting!. But aren't all Sacsayhuamans? This is a great place to get close and marvel at the intricate block fitting the Incas used. You can see curved joints fitted so closely that a playing card won't fit between. Well worth the visit and close to Cusco, so a morning or afternoon trip.
Inca temple . Amazing Inca Temple showing the wonderful creations of the Inca empire n South America. This place is high above Cuzco with beautiful view

Entry not cheap for foreigners but nice walk!. Nice walk to do in a group, not very difficult and the views of Cusco are great. We did this the day before starting on a full trek... in a way it was a good easy introduction to the days of walking that lay ahead.

A must visit area. You will be stunned by the precision cuts to fit these huge heavy rocks into one another. This site is just outside Cusco and I would highly recommend you join a tour with a guide to get the best from it. It is a fairly open area, some gentle slopes and no water or toilets available.

Amazing ruins. We had already visited Machu Picchu, Pisac, and Ollantaytambo, so we were tempted to skip this one--you can only see so many stone walls. Very glad we decided to go anyways. We got there at 8AM to avoid crowds and heat and were all alone for a few minutes. A random guide came up to us (Julio Romero, email Jcesar_198658@hotmail.com) offering his services and we took him up on it. The sheer size of the stones was magnificent, and the location overlooking Cusco, while not as mystical as Machu Picchu, is still pretty grand. Julio showed us some things that we wouldn't have picked up on ourselves, like the symbolism of aspects of the construction, the natural stone slide, the Incan tunnel (which we all went through in the dark), and even the acoustical qualities of the site--you can hear an amazing echo if you stand in the right place. Even if you've seen all the other ruins, don't miss this one. It has unique qualities to offer. We liked Julio's tour, so we told him we'd put his name in our review.
Lovely stop. Not a large site but a bit of historical interest. This was an enjoyable easy walk for whole family. Llamas grazing in the field. Flowers growing from rocks.

Beautiful and historic!. It's so wonderful to see history like this. The grounds are beautiful and the walk refreshing. It's amazing to see how this walls have stood the test of time. If your in Cusco, this is a must see!
Must see when in Cusco. This is like an intro to Machu Pichu if you visit Cusco first. Easily accessible and worth the day trip. The rock formations are pretty similar to Machu Pichu.

Great but, you would see many more on the inca trail. Not far away from Cusco, this ruins can be a spot to see if you are not expecting to do the inca trail. When I went there, there were not a huge bunch of tourists, and also was great walking around it, but now that I did the inca trail, I wouldn´t have done it because I saw many more on my way to Machu Picchu and the entrance for this site is still s/70. Nonetheless, a great place to see.

Worth a visit!. More like sexy human.... I can't help but make fun of the name. Sorry to digress haha. It's amazing to see these big walls of boulders!We didn't want to pay an unreasonable amount of money for a tour, so we rented a cab for the day and had the driver wait for us outside for 1.5 hours. We got our tickets and walked in. By the way, the ticket includes a few other attractions but we didn't have time. Not long after we entered, there was a lady approaching us saying she offers tours on site. We were skeptical at first, but the price was cheap and she sounded knowledgable. I'm glad we did that!The total price came out to be less than if we were to join a tour, on top of that we got to spend as much time as we wanted and had a private guide to tell us stories and take pics of us. Don't forget to go on the rock slides! And don't hurt your bum coming down. A girl from our group couldn't walk the next two days because she fell hard on her bum coming down from the slick slides.

Vacation with friends. This was a beautiful park and archeology site. We had the luxury of a guide to get the most of the history and significance. There is a small cave, roaming llama's and huge stones and formations. A must see.

Impressive Mountaintop Fortress. These ruins are a difficult but exhilarating walk from the Plaza de Armas in Cusco Peru. If you are weary of the walk, then it is a short taxi ride from the town center. When you walk through these ruins you can feel the history all around you, and you can better understand the battle that took place here. This site is not as visited as other Incan Ruins, but it behooves you to go and see for yourself.

Intriguing. Sacsayhuaman is an old temple area above Cusco with panoramic views of the City!We saw this site as part of a small package tour of Cusco and Machu Pichu. I must recommend "Lima Tours" for our hurried visit to these sacred places, as we had limited time for touring. Thanks Lima Tours....well done, a great service.This temple site is large and has wide areas of grass which will impress you with what was once here.
Photo ops galore. This is a great spot close to Cusco for seeing iconic Incan stonework along with seeing a small herd of llamas.

Prequel to Machu Picchu **March 2013**. On our first full day in Cusco, we took the nice long walk up the steady incline to Sacsayhuaman. It was a great way to get use to the altitude and a warm up for our visit to Machu Picchu a couple days later. Spectacular views of Cusco and a very lovely day out.
Worth a visit!. Sacsayhuaman is definetly worth a visit while in cusco! Be sure that you don't miss it! It is amaizing

Self-guided tour. No real information - unless you want to pay for a guide. Easy to walk around and just enjoy - the cost is a bit steep though, 70sol for foreigners, but you can buy the 130sol ticket for all of the sights (valid for 10 days).
Worth seeing. I was here in June 2015. Nice weather and many things to see. This place is worth seeing if you are close by. I would not make a special trip for it.
Go early. This was a very interesting stop. The panoramic view at the top is well worth the climb. Opposite of that is a nice place to see some of Perus many lama.

Amazing site. This site will leave you astounded. You leave with more questions than answers.There are many archeological sites to see. My advise is to buy a Boleto Turistico Del Cusco.This will give you access to 16 sites for $130 Peruvian Soles. You have 10 days to use your ticket. The alternative is paying $70 Peruvian Soles per site.For sites close to Cusco the local bus or taxi is cheap enough. 10 soles to Sacsayhauman. Ask price before committing. Transport to other sites can be fun and cheap by taking the normal buses service for local people. Very safe.

Stunning Ruins above Cusco. I did the hike up to the Incan Ruins. Most people bus up but it is a good walk, though with the altitude it felt more like walking with 100 lbs on my chest. I also took in the large Statue of Christ. The views are amazing as are the ruins itself.

GIANT STONES! Must visit if in Cusco. This is an extraordinary site. If you are in Cusco you have to visit it. Majestic stones. Especially beautiful in Spring with the wildflowers in bloom. Breathtaking views of Cusco from here. Don't miss it.

Beautiful Place. Our Very 1st Tourist Attraction on our Trip to Peru.Absolutely Beautiful Place, so much history and the people are so knowledgeable. This is a MUST VISIT Location if you are in Peru. Lamas running free through the site while we were touring was so exciting. I must have taken over a hundred photos.
Amazing. This place is magical. And that because of the history behind it. Guide is almost a must if you want to understand the geniality of the incas

A great set of ruins to get you in the right mindset for Machu Pichu. Great place to explore! I suggest getting there early in the morning or later in the Afternoon as this place tends to pack out with large tour groups. I flew my drone (with permission) and was able to get some really amazing shots. Buy the week pass, it gets you into a lot of sites in and around Cuzco.

this site was beautiful. You could walk and explore as much as you like. While many in our group just meandered through the ruins, I would encourage anyone who is able to climb the stairs and look around. Gorgeous!
Lovely alpacas!. The place itself is good but not as great as Macchu Pichu but the alpacas there are so cute! We never saw such cute alpacas anywhere around Cusco
Great Bus Trip Up. Wonderful walking in the area. Very interesting archaeology and history. We were there on a day when there were few tourists, which was a bonus!
Gorgeous site. Well laid out. Huge stoneworks and it was quite extensive (although not nearly the size of Machu Picchu). Plus there was a fabulous view of Cusco. Well worth the trip.

Amazing sight. The massive plan that the Incas were unable to complete has been partially destroyed (the stones were used for the churches in town) ...but still helps you to see the engineering skills the Incas possessed before being subjugated by the Spanish.

Buy the site packet and Make this your FIRST STOP!. Do a city walk... take the path to the ruins, they're safe and 15-20 min walk at leisure pace (not stressing your lungs), enjoy the panoramic. If you're history and wonder how the heck did they get those rock up there take the tour! (you can get a tour guide right at the site, no need to spend extra $$$ getting it from an agency, besides you'll be helping them, as most of them are College Students!!) You can see the city from outside and take decent pictures. HOWEVER, if you buy the pass to see 4-5 Sacred Valley sites, this is one of them, take the tour... You'll learn a lot, enjoy and be amazed by the walls.

Almost better than Machu Picchu . I spent an entire day driving as walking all around this incredible site. Pictures do it absolutely no justice. The energy here is just insane and very positive. Be sure to hang out with the perfectly crafted, mysteriously placed rocks. Get a guide at the entrance for 20 soles, they know a lot! The views of Cusco are breathtaking.

Nice ruins near Cusco. This was a nice place, outside of the hubbub of Cusco. The ruins are lovely. Some very good Inca stonework, and a nice view of the city. It would be a great place to have a picnic. One thing to note is that it's located above the city, at over 12,000 feet, and there's some walking and stair climbing involved. If you haven't already spent a day or two acclimatizing to the altitude, this might not be the most fun you could have.

Sounds like sexy woman!. We were touring on a rainy day at Sacsayhuaman, It was a light rain being that we are active seniors we did climb on as many of the big rocks as we could. It would be such fun for kids to be able to run around and touch the gigantic rocks.

Awesome Inca Ruins. The ruins and the location were excellent. Views of Cusco and a short walk up to Blanco Christo for wider views. The ruins were special in that the stone blocks used were huge. It covers a wide area and the ticket includes three other smaller ruins up the hill, easy to get to by public bus.

Good - but a little underwhelming.. I went here at the recommendation of my hotel's concierge. It was good, but underwhelming. Nice to see ruins and you can walk around for a while. You can also get a nice view of Lima. But there are so many other better ruins in Peru.

A Must See in Cusco!. These ruins are close to Cusco and well worth the visit. Stop here before Machu Picchu. Climb the ruins for an excellent view of the city. The mystery of the site is....how did the Inka's move such large bolder from the quay to this site and carve the stones. Was this a defensive position or a religious site?
Fascinating Ruins - Amazing Views of Cusco. Very interesting Inca ruins and some fabulous views overlooking Cusco and the Plaza de arms square. Well worth the visit
Great escape 20 minutes from the city. Came here with family for a brief excursion. Brought kites to fly beside the llamas. Great views of Cusco.

A nice site but only ruins left now. I visited this site as part of a tour but I was a little disappointed because there is no much to see at present. The guide explained how difficult it was at the time for the Inkas to carve the large stones and build the walls but thousands of years earlier the Egyptians & the Greeks build even freater temples so I was not so impressed.

In a ruins close to city. We had guided tour of ruins which were really interesting. You need to be able to climb to top to get a good perspective of the ruins and you also get great views of Cusco. There is also apocalypse craft shop at top

Thought provoking Impressive Inca Ruins. Sacsayhuaman is the first Inca Ruins we visited in Cusco. The huge stone boulders and columns are truly amazing. How did they do that?
