What tools did they use? How many years did it take them? We are lucky that a good percentage of the ruins still in place. The Spanish must be getting tired of moving the stones. Thank goodness! The view of the city on the right side closed to the entrance is spectular. Do take time to enjoy the site and don't rush.

Loved this place!. We visited the Sacsayhuaman ruins as part of a four-site tourist pass. We only had a limited time there, but we really enjoyed walking around the ruins - they are spectacular. This location has a great view of the city of Cusco and the site is close by. We took a cab there and it was inexpensive. I highly recommend it.

Great inca ruins right in Cusco.. Great inca ruins just minutes from downtown Cusco. It is amazing they figure they only have 20% of the stones still remaing. Destroyed by the spanish and then used as a rock quarry.
Best view of Cusco. You should see this view of the city. The ruins are nice, but get a tour so you can have it explained!

Great site with great views. This site is definitely worth checking out. The craftsmanship is amazing, and there are great photo opportunities. There are multiple levels that you can walk on, and you can get quite close to the stones. Its best to have a guide to tell you about it, and the reason for the shape in relation to the underground rivers in Cusco. This site is easy to navigate around, and it is very close to the historic district. There are a lot of stairs to walk up to get there if you don't take a bus or taxi so I would definitely recommend being driven there.
Interesting and massive archaeological feature.. Enjoy a walk through history. Very unique and large in scale. Take a guide to explain. Take time to enjoy exploring this place.

To our surprise. "Sexy woman" was a really peaceful experience. There are hidden ruins throughout the grounds and it was fun to stroll and explore each corner of the site. We had not orignally planned on visiting this site but had some down time so decided to go. We ended up spending half the day here, meeting new friends, running for cover during a hail storm and getting up close and personal to grazing alpaca. Leisure fun.
Great Archeological site. Old remains of Peru, well maintained. Very near to city in nearby hill top. Great view of the city from the place

Best Incan Ruin in Peru!. This was our favorite incan ruin site in Peru, better than Machu Picchu! Enormous 16 ft stones, all surrounding a large center court are extraordinarily impressive. "Sexy Woman" as the locals 'translate' it into english is reachable from a 20-30 minute strenuous walk from the Plaza De Armas. Beautiful views over the city of cuzco, and amazing sized multi-ton stones make up the walls. Make sure to visit the cool walk-through tunnel which is a bit dark and creepy, but worth the adventure! There are guides in the park which will find you as you approach looking like a gringo, but it is possible to tour without a guide. They won't have any maps on site, due to either being out of them or trying to get the guides money...Accessible via the tourist pass! We paid piece meal for each ruin site but probably would have been better off with the tourist pass...

Impressive. This historical site gives you a close up look at the construction methods used by the Inca. Some lovely flowers growing between the rocks.The entrance ticket actually gives you entry to several historical sites on the outskirts of Cusco.
Incredible Ruins. Don't miss seeing Sacsayhuaman outside of Cusco. It is very close to the city and almost as spectacular as Machu Picchu. Large stonework and a great view of Cusco.

Cool ruins. These ruins were really interesting - my only regret is that we did not spend very much time there. We saw the incredible construction of the walls and how the Inca placed stones in the shapes of animals in the wall. Definitely worth the trip.

Muddy mess. I was disappointed by this. Expect a muddy trail to the ruins and to the Cristo statue and view overlooking Cusco. The trail was treacherous and I fell twice on this slippery dirt and mud "path". I hiked 4 hours the day before at Machu Picchu up steep steps without a problem. Don't waste your time.

More enjoyable than originally thought. This exhibit is actually four different sites. Gives great insight into how the Inca residents of Cusco lived. Massive rocks give thought on how these boulders were moved

Machu Picchu isn't the only Incan site near Cusco. Cusco is choc full of Incan ruins and remnants, and Sacsayhuama is one. In addition to its historical value, the site offers spectacular views of Cusco and the surrounding mountains. It's advisable to visit Sacsayhuama as part of a Tour because there are other nearby locations worthy of a visit, and it would be much easier to have them all coordinated on your behalf. The bottom line is don't consider Cusco as only a way station to Machu Picchu, and don't restrict your exploration to the city streets. Head up into the closer mountains and enjoy all that the Inca left behind.

Fascinating!. This is a must see. Make sure you have enough time to explore the entire site. We were short on time so I don't think we saw the entire thing. There is a really cool slide made from stone. Try it if you can, but be careful. The local kids play there all of the time.
Hiding Inka spot. Old inca ruins not only a historical view but one of beauty as well. It is without a doubt a must see

Amazing. Amazing megalithic stones, you must add this site to your Cuzco visit. Ollantaytambo is another must see if in the Cuzco area.We were with a tour group when we visited. Wish I would have taken a taxi and spent more time at this site.

Masterpiece. The so called fortress stands over the city of Cusco at an altitude of 3700 meters.A walk in this complex is mindblowing and a must-do for the inca valley visitors but walking over 3500 meters is not a game, specially if you are not an experienced trekker, so I suggest to save energies for the visit reaching them with a taxi from the city: it costed me 7 soles after a fast bargaining. You will be assaulted by the local guides: a fast reading of the wiki page will save you money and confusion.To go back to Cusco there are several paths in the green, with the city always in sight so it's almost impossible to get lost.

MUST SEE!!!. Everyone of course comes to Peru to see Machu Pichu. However the stonework at this site is OVERWHELMING!! You must see this site! It is always more impressive to me that even Machu Pichu.

Amazing, enormous, and close to the city. I recommend buying a Tourist Ticket (Boleto Touristico), it will allow you in here as well as other sites around the city (Qenko, Puca Pucara, Cusco Cathedral, Ollantaytambo Temple...), it's a great deal. Sacsayhuaman is amazing for its sheer magnitude, some of the rocks weight dozens of tons, and they're arranged in a tremendous fort. You can easily hike from Cusco to Sacsayhuaman and back in a morning's trip, and even catch the view from the Cristo Blanco statue on the way

Sacsayhuaman will Blow Your Mind. Sacsayhuaman, just outside of Cusco, is the place where the Incan's had their one major victory over the Conquistadors They used engineering and flooded them. Is it a temple or is it a fortress? That depends on your guide. But Nevermind, it is serene and monumental. The rocks which were finished without the benefit of metal tools slide together like giant teeth. While Colonial Cusco crumbles, these rocks stand their ground. Definitely worth an afternoon trip.

not a lot of context on site. We got the 1 day boleto turistico. Left our hotel around 8am and walked here, stopped at all the other sites (Q'enko, Tambomachay, Puka Pukara), and got back to our hotel around 2pm. We weren't rushing, so you could probably do it in less time. We did take the bus, el huerto, to and from the upper 2 sites. From Sacsayhuaman you can walk to Q'enko, and from Puka Pukara you can walk to Tambomachay. There's a lot of variety in these sites, and great views. I recommend if you have a day to spare outside of the city. There's not a lot of info on the significance or history of the sites, so get a guide or google it when you get home.
Wonderful ruin sight!. We went to this sight as part of our city tour. It was amazing. It made us realize just how many wonderful ancient sights have been preserved in this wonderful country!

A preview near Cusco. A small site on top of the hill in Cusco that you could potentially walk up on feet and visit without being charged. The free walking tour also take u near here as well. Its only very small though so if u just got into Cusco and want to explore the town a little before getting to your major sites then its worth a stop

Worth walking in the rain !. The only day of rain we had - but we put on our rain slickers to go atop this Incan fortress, and view the "Temple of the Sun" from atop the walls. I can believe it took over 70 years to build, since, like most Incan structures, the boulders used are from another area and cut onsite to fit the existing bedrock. Like a lot of our stops, the guides from Gate 1 Travel split up to accommodate the members of our group who didn't want to go to the higher altitude. A GREAT sight !

Sacsaywaman the best place in the world. i ve been in sacsaywaman last november. it was gorgeous place to visit. there are animals in the place such as llamas and alpacas. i really recommend tourist to visit the place once they are in cusco.

Why pay?. 130 soles? Really? We walked up to the Cristo Blanco statue and lookout instead, where you also get a (free) view of the ruins only 150m away. Sure it's not the same as walking around, and the large boulders did look impressive, but certainly not impressive enough for the steep entry fee. Enjoy Machu Picchu instead and do this one for free.Note: people offer you horse rides around nearby attractions as you walk to the entry of the site.

Amazing by the Incas.. Amazing by the Incas.The size of these rocks asks the question.Gow did they manage it.
This is a must see part of your visit to Cusco.
Cusco. Amazing structures forming this ancient Inca city. This size of some of the rocks is staggering, how did they move them and fit them together so closely ? Well worth visiting
Nice place to be visited.. To have the most of this place we recommend you get a well prepared tour guide like we had, Edwin Masco made our tour the most incredible one. He's a PHD in Inka culture.

Majestic Inca Ruins. This is a stunning spot, both for beauty and history. A guide is very helpful in pointing out things that are magical. It is a huge site, but just a quick taxi ride from downtown Cuzco. The Touristika Bolleto (tourist ticket) is a great buy and gets you into many museums and ruins for 10 days. Beware of purse snatchers.
Great historic site. The second site on our tour and, like almost all of them, most impressive. Be sure you are prepared for any weather regardless of the predictions.

Stunning example of masonry. The site shows how Incans were masters of dry masonry with high walls and terraces. The site is not a wow factor like other areas but still has an interesting history.** there are a few steep steps but the rest of the area is fairly flat but may not be accessible with a chair. Ask your guide to take the downhill route to avoid the climb.

Wonderful Views over Cusco. AN interesting site, but make sue that you have a guide to explain the site to you. Visit here before Machu Picchu, so that you have an idea of the wonderful stonework done by the Incas. From here you will also have some wonderful views over the Cusco valley. Be aware that you are much higher that Cusco, so if you are suffering from Altitude Sickness at Cusco, this site is much higher., so just be aware.This is an easy site to walk around, but there is section which you should climb up to get a great vista of the site and Cusco.
an enormous place to serve as fortress. it was made from supermen, its huge stones could not be carried by any man, it has to be a tech of some kind.

A great historical sight with beautiful views. This was a interesting sight which offered beautiful views of Cusco down below. It was neat to see that back then they could create these places without the technology we have now. Its a bit of a hike to the top but it is worth it. They also have dogs wandering who will follow you on the way up.

this is an imposing fortress i visited many times. woooow, thanks to my agency that i didnt leave out of my tour the visit of such a huge place, thinking about the weight of those rocks i fell down admiring it.

Amazing!. These pre Incan ruins are absolutely amazing. There is a fair amount of walking involved but it is certainly worth it to see these wondrous ruins. Our guide was very informative. It is important to have a guide or at least some literature about the significance of this site. Otherwise one might not grasp the site's true meaning and wonder.
Nice walk towards sacsayhuaman. Especially the trip towards Sacsayhueman is very nice. It is a lot of climbing but it is a beautiful road leading to it. There are streams and nice vegetation.

top of Cuzco. Beautiful open place in the top of Cuzco. You could climb the stairs of the ruins and have an extraordinary view of the place and Cuzco as well.You need the Cuzco Pass (130 soles) that you could use in quenco, pukapucara, tambomachay and saksaywaman. You only could pay in soles, no credit cards or dollars accepted.When you enter there are guides that you could hire.There are other three ruins very closed, like 15 minutes in car so you couldstart with Saksaywaman, then Quenco, then pucapukara and tambomachay.

Amazing and Relaxing. Massive stones placed together to form a city/walls. The creation is the wow factor because it is crazy to think this was done without 'modern technology'. I remember thinking - I wonder who is really modern - back then or us? The views are beautiful and relaxing. Well worth the visit.
Interesting. This was an interesting site, but we visited this after Machu Picchu so not as impressive. Might be better to see this first. Be sure to bring rain gear in rainy season!

Inca Legos. Wow. This place is a true mystery. We never give the ancestors credit for having assembled these enormous walled cities. Get a guide that can explain the origins of this place and you will get the benefit of the visit. Without that, there is no interpretation along the way to self-learn.

Read before hand . This is a place where not having documented yourself before Isnt gonna impress you. In reality the history is quite reach if you either have a guide or read in advance. Think about the way the Incas moved incredible sized stones with rudimentary technologies. And how the greenfield of today turned into a banquet for the Hawks after a massacre between Incas and Spanish.

Completely mind blowing.... This was one of the best, slightly off the beaten tourist track, landmarks that we found... me and my partner thought it was an incredible place to be and we were left to wonder at how, for the time it was built and the tools they were meant to have used to build it, it could ever have been possible...

Stunningly interesting. It's impossible to believe the story that the incas only existed for 200 years prior to the Spanish. Go here and enlighten yourself. It's beautiful and interesting to see the science behind this inca fortress.

I like the way it's pronunced in Quecha!. In Quecha it sounds like Sexy woman! We spent the weekend in Cusco for our second wedding anniversary and totally enjoyed this site. We would highly recommend it to any others, it's close to Cusco and very interesting.

Best Ruin Closest to Cusco. It took as about an hour to wander up and through. Beautiful sights of Cusco from the site. We did not get a guide, but probably would have benefited from knowing more about the great history we were experiencing. We went on our second day in Cusco and only got a little bit winded climbing the steps. It is not an intense hike. It's absolutely worth the trip if you're staying in Cusco.
Amazing site!. Amazing site. Unbelievable how they moved, shaped and fit such large boulders. Definitely a must-visit spot.

Totaling unexpected. When we first arrived at this location, I saw a local older lady holding a IIama, been so up close with this animal that produces such beautiful and warm wool. The huge stones reminded of the stones from the pyramids of Egypt due to the size of each one of them. Can get very cold and Windy, so layer well.

Beautiful rambling ruin. Our family had a wonderful time exploring the Sacsayhuaman ruins. The grounds were quite extensive so it made for a great place to wander. The huge stones were impressively carved but even better was the chance to enjoy the Andean countryside.
Interesting!. Incan ruins made from rock quarried at another location. Massive stones in an interesting formation. Lamas wanting on the grounds.

Impressive Incan fortification. This is outside of Cusco, so you'll need a car. The site is a great introduction to the Incas, who reportedly retired to this location during the struggle against the Spanish conquerors. The scale is massive, and to fully appreciate their construction strategy, walk across the field and climb the hill overlooking the fort.

Imposing and stunning Inka construction. This place show us the advanced techniques of this people who had the largest empire in America, watching this big stones carved and placed here from distant areas you simply love it and the view from the city spectacular

An interesting site if you're into inca history. This is one of the main inca sites around Cusco. To walk around the actual site you have to pay with a tourist ticket, but you can walk next to it for free, it just means you can't get inside but it doesn't make much difference! If you're not going to see any other ancient sites, this is probably worth seeing

History in Life. We started at Sacsayhuaman in the morning. It was a longer tour than I anticipated. Fortunately the sun wasn't at full force yet. If you like history, this is the place to start. Our guide was very knowledgeable about the historical significance of the area. It introduced us to the magnitude of the Inca power over the land and the people. A definite must see.
Sacsayhuaman day trip. Day trip including famous sacsayhuaman.what a sight the stones are huge. Also did horse riding up to the edge of the sight.

Unbelievably breathtaking.....honoured by this site.. Coming from North America and being born in the late 60's.....I am used to cranes and bull dozers and backhoes to move items like rock and soil. It was a humbling experience and an experience filled with awe and honour to be at sacsayhuaman. To bear witness to such human strength and fortitude and foresight......at a time when manpower was the means to use.......well that is an experience like no other. Sitting and staring in awe....that is ow I spent my time. I would recommend this site to everyone,

Excellent Inca site. One of the most interesting sites near Cusco. It's really huge and quite beautiful. The scenery around it is equally stunning. You have views of mountains as well as the city of Cusco. The ancient Inca building skills were just amazing. One also wonders how did they manage to bring granite pieces over a ton in weight to places as high as 3400 meters above sea level. Just marvelous.

Boggling rock formations of an ancient fortress. And wild llamas!. Here is an easily accessible historic site, not on the usual tourist map, but well worth a walk-through. Not crowded. If you have a guide like our wonderful Carlos, you will learn boggling facts about how this amazing place was formed. How DID they do it?!

Hard to imagine moving these blocks!. Sacsayhuaman was an amazing site built by the Incas for the upper class accountants and bureaucrats of the Quechan empire. It had some defensive purposes, but also served as a visible reminder of the power and advanced civilization of the Quechuan people. It also served as a ceremonial site, with a large field located between the defensive walls and the natural cliffs that provided the raw stones for much of Sacsayhuaman fortifications. The history is fascinating and the puzzle of how these people moved such massive stones without the aid of machinery, hydraulics and other tech advancements, is spellbinding. I so enjoyed the visit here but I was a bit sad to learn we had missed (by just a couple of days) a large annual reenactment of the Inti Raymi (Festival of the Sun) which occurs in late June around the time of the southern hemisphere's winter solstice. If I'd known, we might have altered our schedule a bit to be there for the show!On the bright side, there were a lot of dancing and musical groups marching in the Cusco city center in the days leading up to the solstice, so we saw a good deal of native culture you don't always encounter while visiting. Timing is so important.

Worth a visit. This site is out of town and was part of our city tour. This Secret site is just fantastic and if you have enough time climb the opposite hill and you get a superb view. It is just amazing how they build these places at what precision and how these very large granite stones where fitted so perfect. Just amazing. I certainly would go again.
Great historic site. Important to visit to understand more about the incas. The stones are impressive. The view from the top is looking over Cusco is awesome.

Amazing Ruins! Gorgeous view of Cusco!. Yes, I realize it is expensive, but my friend and I thought the small 70 soles tourist ticket for Tambomachay, Pukapukara, Q'enco, and Sacsaywaman was worth it! Each sites was amazing but Sacsaywaman was really huge and impressive and we enjoyes having a picnic lunch overlooking the ruins and Cusco. We took a taxi to Tambomachay and then we walked between the archeological sites and down to Cusco from Sacsaywaman and it was an easy downhill walk the whole way.

Great Inca site. Out first Inca site en route to Secret Valley.Fabulous walls created using some 300 ton boulders.Amazing to see the anti earth quake joints and extent of project that was undertaken.Well worth the visit

If you can't get to Machu Picchu or Ollantaytambo, check this out. Built by the Inka people in the same way as Machu Picchu. Some of the stones are larger than those used at Machu Picchu or Ollantaytambo; however, some stones at these other two places started out larger than the ones here.

Wonderful historic side in the heart of Cuzco. I was very lucky, being there early in the morning before the tourist buses arrived. Local Peruvian women around with their cure Llamas (or Alpacas?), and great atmosphere. Really worth the trip.

Fascinating portrait of Inca architecture and life. Sacsayhuaman is one of the largest Inca ruins that depicts how the Incas lived, worked and learned. Learned about their astrononomical prowess that enabled them to predict weather for crop production (using the natural stone in the shape of a Puma). Also, saw a cave showing the original stone table where they experimented with surgical operations and prepared bodies for mummification.
very interesting. I wanted to know more about the Inka history. Advise you to get a guide so you know what you are looking at.

Cusco must see. Sacsayhuaman is a definite must see while in Cusco. It's near enough that you can walk there. Just use your GPS or walk in the general direction with a map and you'll find it. The ruins are awe inspiring. How they could have moved such huge stones and then fashioned them to join so closely is still unknown. It's not a big site to navigate and there are nice areas around there to explore. Walk yourself back to Cusco for dinner.

Hike to sexywoman. We had a great time walking in the area of sexywoman. It was good to see many peruvians play football and also enjoy the nice whether. The attraction as such is nice but not extremely interesting. For kids it is very nice

Awesome. This was the major Inca city at the time of the Spanish. It is hard to imagine how stone this size could have been moved from their quarry and so perfectly place in a manner that would allow a sharp blade to penetrate. Definitely a must see.
i was surprised to go up alone. being a woman i thought i was going to faal down to the floor of being tired, but i could finish this 1 hour 30 minute wander by this giant fortress, i loved it.

Inca Fortress. Sacsayhuaman is an amazing example on Inca construction using very large rocks, some estimated up to 100 tons built upon a substructure in some places over 12 feet deep and engineered with seismic consideration to maintain the fort through the numerous tremors that frequently shake Peru.
Interesting ruins. Visited as part of tour. These ruins are where the Pope held mass when he visited Cusco. Great pace to visit.

Awesome but with a "rip off" factor. Again, entry charge seems high, 70 sol is expensive for Peru. Seems like gov' is determined to kill,the goose that lays the golden egg... Despite this a great site, but zero explanation or official support for your entrance fee. Not a single word of explanation in any language. Local unofficial guides but who knows what's they know and after paying a high fee who wants to get ripped off by a guide as well.

Pronounced "SexyWoman". This archeological site is truly magnificent and an excellent example of Incan civilization. This Incan fortress is built with stones precisely carved out of the mountain and tell the story of Incan religion, military and daily life. Just up the hill from Cusco.

Steeped in history and architecture. No visit to Cusco for those enroute to Machu Picchu is complete without a visit. If you do this on your own, find a guide. The history and architectural marvels cannot be appreciated otherwise. Finish the tour walking down into the valley and Cusco. It isn't steep or hard, and may take less time than the bus trip, with all the traffic. You'll be descending, so altitude sickness will lessen.

Amazing Example of Incan Construction. Interesting walk from one end of this interesting exhibit to the other. The size of the rocks used in this construction is unbelievable. Sure adds to the mystery of how they were built!

Ancient Ruins plus the Cristo Blanco. Book the City Tour, available from local travel agencies, which will include Sacsayhuaman. It is the scene of an ancient Inca fortress, where the Incas fought a battle against the Spanish invaders. It is well worth the visit - the City Tour includes the services of a guide. One thing to mention is that it is well above Cusco in altitude and requires a lot of walking, so if you are already having difficulty with altitude, you might want to take this into consideration. Another caution is that if you are there in summer (North American winter,) you should bring along an umbrella. Showers can come up suddenly, and there is no shelter. We brought ours, and those who did not had to madly scramble for the bus or buy ponchos from the locals who are on the scene. Part of the Sacsayhuaman tour takes you to the nearby Cristo Blanco, the 'White Christ' statue which is visible all the way to the Plaza de Armas in Cusco. Families with really small kids might find the going a little rough. It's not dangerous, just that if you have to carry a little one, it may be strenuous at the altitude.

Inka ruins and overlook of Cusco. We visited Sacayhuaman near the end of the day. The huge stone work is impressive (one rock was over 10 tons). This was also a battle site with the Spanish. We had a native guide, who took great pride in his culture, that made the tour more interesting. We also had great views of the "White Christ" and Cusco at night. I recommend visiting in the afternoon and coming by at dusk.

Some Really Big Rocks.. This is a fair sized and interesting site, with the most notable thing being the zigzag wall and theenormous size of the stones on the lower wall. According to our guide some of these larger stones havebeen estimated to weigh as much as 200 tons or even more. If you have time when visiting be sure tocross the field, climb the stairs and go around to the back side of the hill, here you might see peoplesliding down a natural slide formation on the rock, additionally there is a large round area that used tobe a reflecting pool for star gazing.
Beautiful Views. Very interesting stop. Beautiful views of the city of Cusco and the mountains surrounding it. Christ the Redeemer is located nearby as well in a short walk.

A must see. Definitely grab a guide for your sighting of Sacsayhuaman unfortunately I can't recommend any because ours wasn't that great but they point out pieces of knowledge you won't want to miss about this place. The trek up to the panoramic view points are also a must. I was lucky it was quiet and peaceful so I just got to breathe in the view and not worry about other tourist.

Impresive!!. Sacsayhuaman is one of the best places to visit around Cusco, its located n top of the city were you have an impressive view. The huge granite stones have wondered explores for hundreds of years making the myth of the aliens seem reasonable the truth is that how it was constructed remains unclear still now in days. Around the area there is many other sites definitely worthwhile to explore.

Sacsayhuaman. Amazing views. The only bad thing is that our guide wasnt very experienced and we had to wait for an hour for the bus to pick us up. Tip: Take a taxi and hire a guide when you get there!
it was very challenging for me to go up. i tried to do it in 15 minutes, running, but i failed, i was with no air and had a very sore feet, but the vistas i got were worthy the excercise.

How did the huge boulders get on top of this plateau?. What makes this area so special is the sheer size of these rocks and how these rocks are so evenly stacked above this plateau to have fortified the area. When you arrive you will not be as amazed until after you walk around and take in the sheer size of these ruins and the preciseness in building the walls.

Superb view for a reasonable price!. We went here with a group and guide, he was lovely and very informative. We bought a pass that was valid for several sights in the Cusco area, this was 130 soles, which is a reasonable price because there is a LOT to see!There were no toilets, but this is normal as you are on the top of the hill, lots to see and explore and the views are out of this world! I'd recommend hats and suncream to take with you.Worth the visit, great fun for both kids and grownups!
Excellent views. Excellent views of Cuzco city. If you're planning on hiking the Inca trail, I recommend hitting these sites before the Inca Trail.

Impressive stone wall construction. Great view of Cusco city below.. "Sexy Woman" is not as spectacular a Machu Picchu or Ollantaytambo, so I think it becomes under-appreciated sometimes. That's a shame because I think the beauty of its architecture is subtle. Of all the Incan ruins I visted during my Peru trip, I think the stone walls at Sacsayhuaman may have been the most impressive, in terms of their size and the precise way in which the larger stones were cut to fit so intricately well.It's a shame that the original rooms and plaza were destroyed by the Spanish conquerors; I would have loved to see a little bit of them. The remnants are sparse and there has only been a little reconstruction.The other thing many people like about this site is that it provides great overviews of Cusco city below. We visited this site as part of a full-afternoon guided tour of several places in the Cusco region. I don't know how much of the tour fee went towards the admission fee here, so therefore I can't really comment on the value of the admission fee, since many have commented here that they felt the fee is very expensive.

"worth a visit". This is an interesting site to explore. positioned high above Cusco appears at first sight to be from a Flintstones set. Worth seeing the white christ statue which lights up at night just 400 yards away to really appreciate the views over Cusco.

Stunning archeological site 2km from Cusco. Sacsayhuaman (pronounced 'sexywoman') is the first of the 4 archeological sites (Saqsaywaman > Q'enqo > Pukapukara > Tambomachay) positioned along the first 8km of the road that runs towards Pisac. Located only 2km from Cusco, near Q'enqo it is easily the best of the four peripheral sites and not to be missed.GETTING HEREI would recommend doing this as part of a trip incorporating all four peripheral sites. If you don't have enough time to go to all four I would still recommend making the effort to come to this site alone as it's spectacular. Two options - tour vs independent travel.TOUR - The four archeological sites are included as part of the popular Cusco city tours. Costing around 50Sol these begin in the afternoon by visiting several city sites (Plaza de armas, Cathedral, Qurikancha temple) before extending out into the peripheral sites. Because this runs over half a day and crams in the city sites as well as these four I found it to be quite rushed and I wasn't afforded the amount of time I would've liked at the archeological sites - which was really the only reason we did the tour. I wouldn't recommend it.INDEPENDENTLY - Biggest question is going to be your choice of transportation. You are climbing uphill at elevation from Cusco to get to these sites and because of this most seek transport to the most peripheral site of Tambomachay before walking the 8km downhill back to the town. Buses traveling to Pisac can drop you off at the most peripheral site of Tambomachay for 3Sol (although you need 8Sol to get a taxi to the bus station usually). From Tambomachay you trace back to Pukapukara > Q'enqo > Saqsaywaman, a distance of 6km, before the 2km downhill descent to Cusco. Tambomachay & Pukapukara are 200m from each other and it's similar for Q'enqo/Saqsaywaman so you could get an interconnecting taxi although I saw none when I was there. Instead of a bus you can pay 25 Sol one way on a taxi to Tambomachay. Finally you can get a private taxi for the entire trip for 50Sol (they wait while you visit and take you between sites). This is probably the best option but you'll need good negotiating skills. There are well documented reports of muggings of people walking between the ruins so solo travel is ill advised. I noticed a reassuring police presence between the sites when I passed through so I speculate the authorities are clamping down on this as to not discourage tourists. Entry to the sites is via the Boleta Turistico ticket - these cost 130Sol and covers numerous attractions in and around Cusco over the space of 10 days.If you wanted to visit Saqsaywaman in isolation from the others you can walk here from the Plaza De Armas (see below picture). This is around 1km but up quite a steep incline at an elevation of over 3000m and will take you over half an hour easily. From Saqsaywaman there is a path leading to the statue of Christ the Redeemer (Cusco version).THE SITESacsayhuaman is easily the best of the 4 archeological sites. It's an old citadel built from huge boulders cut so well that mortar was not required to hold them together. The stone work for me was a real highlight. It towers over cusco and offers excellent views for those who walk through to the viewpoint. Historically this was one of the sites of one of the most bloodiest conflicts between the spanish and the Inca during the 1500's in which thousands were slaughtered. Following this a lot of the stone from the site was pilfered for buildings in the colonial city but enough remains for it to be a worth wild visit.Please take the time to rate my review.

Sacsayhuaman. What a site it was!!!! The most amzing thing beside the architecture in stones so well positioned it is hard to believe that people actually did it with bare hands, the $ million picture is at the top, the fact that you see the whole city if Cuzco. the view is amazing.
Zig zag footings. Situated high above the city of Cusco are these wonderful old ruins, well worth the visit. Allow atleast 3/4 of an hour to takeit all in.

Awesome ruin site in Cuzco!. This place is seriously legit! There are incredible areas that seem sort of "hidden" here. Find the caves and the natural slides (yes, slide down them, it's a blast) and this place will be a highlight of your trip :)
Excellent! Fascinating!. Get a guide at the gate. Different from Ollantaytambo and Machu Picchu in terms of the site with caves and tunnels with carved niches used for rituals.

Great walking around to see the ruins. This is easily done in an hour or 2. There are some great views. It is one of the better sites in all the sites nearby. It is easy to walk if yo don't mind some steps. What a rich culture!

Wonder of it All. How did they build this? How incredible that this still stands today? The precision is remarkable. For me, this was one of the highlights of our Cusco tour. I was really impressed with this park and the history around it. Great history and views.

Amazing. You can stay for hours and will not see everything. I went with a guided tour and had little time to explore and intend to come back some other trip. You can buy your ticket at the entrance or in the city paying the boleto turistico (that includes other sites too). Take a hat, sunblock, coat, rain coat if possible. The weather changes very quickly.

Inca Temple ruins above Cusco. This is one of the compelling Inca ruins to see as it is one of the largest single Inca structures adjacent to Cusco - co-located here by the Cristo Rey statue both overlooking Cusco below. This is made of giant limestone rocks cut and fitted together, serpentine walls withstanding earthquakes

amazing!. Our tour guide told us that Cusco is hot and sunny and cold and rainy...all in the same day!! He was right. When we arrived, we got lots of great photos, but within an hour, it was cold, and the rain was icy!! The blocks of stone are unbelievably large and it's hard to imagine that people actually put them into place.

Go with a guide!. We decided not to go to Machu Picchu, due to the time cost and number of tourists already going there. Sacsayhuaman was wonderful and I barely missed going to MP. Like MP, the setting is very dramatic. We went on a city tour with SAS tours, and we were very glad to go with a guide. He told stories and explained lots about the history of the ruins. He really helped us appreciate the site more then we would have.

Interesting but you really need a guide. This is an impressive structure with lots of historical significance but I think you really need a guide to fully appreciate what you are seeing. We had a guide take us around the site and found her to be invaluable in understanding the history of the place.

not your average ruins. Stones are absolutely amazing....huge. Recommend going with a guide who can tell you the history "sexy woman" including that the name means: Falcon satisfied from eating human remains. Great trip of the hill from Cusco if you are trying to acclimate for hike to Machu picchu later.
You must be there. 20 minutes walk from down town. Impressive stone inca military palace. Must be seen to better understand inca powerness.
Peru . Fantastic day trip, ran smoothly and got a lot covered. Amazing time! Great agency to use for booking tours in Peru.

Worth Seeing. Sacsayhuaman is definitely worth seeing. Great views of the city of Cusco along with a large complex which sits between the time line of Tiwanaku, Bolivia and Machu Picchu.I enjoyed exploring the site, (10 soles by taxi from Cusco or you can easily walk up the hill to it), questioning my understanding of Inca culture and society and bouncing questions of a fellow traveller I met there, (Shaun, San Fran).Yes I'd agree with some reviewers, Sacsayhuaman isn't on a par with Machu Picchu, or even Tiwanaku for that matter, but for a few hours out of your life after making the effort to get to Cusco it's definitely worth a visit.
1st trip to Peru. Hard to tell what has been reassembled but still an amassing historical site. fairly easy walking through ruins and back to our Hostal. Take taxi to top and walk back

Go before Machu Picchu. We went after spending 4 days on the Incan trail, and while Sacsayhuaman was cool-ish, it didn't compare to what we had seen on the trail and felt a bit disappointing, especially for the price you have to pay. If we had gone before we had done our Incan Trail hike, I imagine we would have thought it was better.
Must see when visiting Cusco. What an amazing place for visiting archeology sites, great views looking down at the city of Cusco and visiting the weaving cooperative.

A very interesting site that provides greater understanding of the history of the area.. A guide is necessary to gain the greatest perspective to this site. The construction (without mortar) is astonishing.

Fantastic ruins just outside of Cusco!. These ruins are really a must see. I would highly recommend either hiring a guide or buying information on this site so you have an idea what you are looking at. My daughter an I took a cab up the hill a few miles out and did all the other ruins along the way. It was a great way to spend the afternoon and you can buy one ticket that will allow you to see them all. Highly recommend.
incan ruins. This is a quick way to introduce oneself to incan ruins, as it's a quick cab or bus ride from cusco. it provides a fantastic view of cusco from high above the town.
Spectacular. Our guide described the meaning of the shape of Sacsayhuaman and pointed out the large stone with 11 corners. My traveling companions also were crazy enough to try the sliding rock.

One of Cusco's best sights. It’s not to be compared with Machu Picchu, but while you’re in Cusco, Saqsayhuaman is a must! The sheer enormity of the stones, and the precision with which they are carved, is truly extraordinary. The climb can be a bit difficult, given the altitude, but it’s an experience and a view you won’t forget.
Fascinating. We were only able to spend a limited amount of time here, but it was very interesting, and I would return to explore further.
Amazing. It was a cold, windy, misty day but still worth seeing Sacsayhuaman. It is a bit of a walk over uneven terrain but worth the trip.

Beautiful site. My wife and I visited on our Honeymoon. It's a large ceremonial area with some of the largest stones used in pre-incan structures. You can take your time here, very leisurely; there are locals at the entrance offering tours (we did not use one). It's about a 10 minute taxi ride (walking is possible but it's all uphill on a narrow and busy street). Entrance is 70 Soles, which includes entrance to multiple sites.

Fantastic and majestic. We did literally no research before coming and so didn't know what to expect. We stopped at Sacsayhuaman on our way to Machu Picchu based on a recommendation by a tour guide in Cusco. Wow, were we impressed! We arrived VERY early in the day, so there were no tourists yet except for us. The ruins were astounding. It was honestly one of the most impressive sights we saw in Peru. The slide carved into stone was a fun diversion, but the best part was that one of the alpacas that are allowed to roam around for the benefits of tourists gave birth while we were there! It was just walking around and then the baby started poking out! We watched for 20 minutes or so until it was done. What a memorable experience!

Fascinating architecture . This historic site is a must-see for visitors to Cusco. Sacsayhuaman is fascinating and you may want to allow more time to explore it than allowed on the multi-site City tour. We only had ~20 minutes to explore in our City Tour group, but the rock masonry is more impressive than anywhere else we visited in the Sacred Valley and Machu Picchu. To re-enter the site, we would have needed to buy an additional Boleto Turistico (S/130 each). I'd recommend finding a private tour so you can spend longer here. It is also next to the Cristo Blanco (White Jesus) monument, which you can walk to from Sacsayhuaman. It is an easy walk down winding staircases to downtown Cusco from there.

Magnificent Inca ruins outside Cusco. The impressive site of Sacsayhuamen is a half-hour walk uphill, a little north of Cusco. Many of the stones are of huge size. Although the site is in ruins, there is plenty of evidence to suggest where a large amphitheatre once stood, as well as towers and a sort of throne. There are some great views over Cusco and surrounding countryside.

Great place to visit. Amazing ruins - there is a short, but very dark (pitch black) tunnel, beautiful view of the ruins, amazing stone work. We were there with a guide who told us about the life and spirituality of the indigenous people. Worth a visit.

Big Pile of Rocks, Descent View of Cusco. Nothing really incredible, the only reason I believe this attraction is so well rated is that a lot of people travel through Cusco on their way to MAchu Picchu and it is fairly easy to access...However, sites like Pissaq, Maras, Moray and Ollantaytambo are much more interesting to visit.

The best thing to see in Cusco. This is by far the best ruins in Cusco. Its huge! The rocks they used are giant and all fit tightly together. It demonstrates the knowledge and ingenuity of the Incas. Go with a guide so they can explain the history to you. There is also a great spot to take pictures of the city. Wear sun screen, bring water and good walking shoes!
I hiked up ..... in a swift time. I really was impressed by the enormous rocks...it was out of this world how to transport them and how they did build without present technology

Built on a solid foundation. I found that reading books by author Kim MacQuarrie followed by the walk uphill from Cusco town square gave me an excellent flavor for what it would've been like for the Incas defending this fort and the Spanish trying to conquer it on horseback. The massive stone portals make for incredible photos. It is also a wonderful panoramic view back into Cusco. I would not miss this site on a trip to Cusco.

Mistical place, the crown of the inca impire. Very worth going to this site! The stones are the biggest of all the sites in the sacred valley. I travelled around and for sure the most impressive construction was at sacsayhuaman. Worth going up walking. It is very quick from San Blas !
Great view from cusco!!!

Interesting ruins close to Cusco. These ruins are fairly close to Cusco, above the city with great views. It would be a bit of a hike from the city, up hill. They are very interesting and fun to explore. If you have transportation of some kind there are other Incan sites close by to explore as well. This is a must see if you aren't going to Machu Picchu just to see the complexity of the Inca structures. The elevation is higher than Cusco. Was also cooler than Cusco. You don't need hiking shoes, it's a gentle slope throughout. Not absolutely necessary to be with a tour. Worthwhile seeing even if it's just on your own, just take a guidebook and go. From Cusco you can see a huge white Statue of Christ at Sacsahuaman way up on the hill.

Worth the visit. We had taken Cusco city tour (Viator/Vijes Pacifico). The tour covered the Cathedral & Qorikancha which are both near Plaza de Armas and Sacsayhuaman ruins which are in the city suburbs. All the 3 places are worth the visit.

this was the looking point above the city. When you go up, you will discover why they call this capital city the Puma City, its shape from the old part is a shape of a mountain lion...a Puma resting on the ground.I liked it a lot to know all the secrets of this ancient Peruvian city

Inca fortress. Sacsayhuaman is a must see if you are around Cusco, not as impressive as Machu Picchu but definitely something to behold. You can enter the place with a ticket for s./130 and also access other 10 sites in the Inca Valley so I would say it worth it. You got to appreciate the inca constructions in the place

A fascinating fortress. Replete with an ancient manmade reservoir, massive stones and dark, hidden tunnels, this place stirs the imagination and inspires with its incredible engineering. Worth the drive from town for sure.

Ancient mans legacy, modern mans quandrum. This site is one of several major sacred sites in Peru and should be held in respect when visiting. There are some very incredible constructions that one cannot just put off to Modern mans evolution of building. This site is way beyond anything we Modern humans could accomplish or even comprehend. Be respectful.

Impressed. Gald I didn't miss this.. The prancing llamas entertained us as we explored the expansive Inca ruins of the Sacsayhuamán. They have free range of the grassy grounds. Good to read up on the history of the military fortress before going, or go with a tour guide - you will really appreciate it more. The wall (or rampart) is most impressive, built in angled sections of enormous limestone boulders. Beautiful views of Cusco from up there.
fantastic place. its better is you are up to do a hike, i have been there many times but this time we decided to hike from Cusco..about 25 minutes and back and the experience was wonderful
Unexpectedly amazing!. I had no idea that such a massive, impressive site was so close to the center of town. Don't miss it.

Impressive site. Impressive Incan (and pre-Incan) site with much to see and explore. We took a guided tour - we turned up at the gate and were approached by a lady offering a 1.5 tour for 50 soles for our group of 3. We accepted and are glad we did. Foolishly, we didn't get her name to recommend her.She showed us through a whole bunch of places that I'm sure most casual visitors don't see and explained a lot of the history and interesting features. The tour was in Spanish, but she claimed to be able to do it in English as well.The massive stonework is impressive, but for me the highlight was the area around the circular water storage facility.We walked back to Cusco, which was a nice way to finish our day - only 15 minutes or so to the Plaza.

You can see all the city down. it was amazing to go up and then take pics on the town, there is people from around the world...I never got bored because you can go to the woods and have a picnic. Hope I will come next year.

Great stop when in Cusco!. We had a blast walking here from Cusco. The views were gorgeous- great panoramas of Cusco. There were also not a ton of people here, so we felt like we had a lot of it to ourselves.

Absolutely amazing. Today Sacsayhuaman is the place for Into Raymi, that was held originally in the Qoriqancha. The massive stones are impressive and tell the story about the magnificent technology and engineering of the Incas. Try to visit by yourself instead of the hurry of the local tours. The place deserves a little contemplation.

Impressive site, but no written information. Sacsayhuaman is a very impressive site, built with huge stones worked to fit together perfectly like a puzzle, as was pre-incan style for their religious buildings. It is in walking distance from the centre of Cusco. If you buy the boleto touristico (130 soles pro persona) at Sacsayhuaman, note that they only accept cash, no credit cards, so be sure to bring enough cash. There is no written information on site, but there are guides at the entrance that are very eager to give you a tour, for a fee of course. We preferred to walk around by ourselves, which is also highly recommended, in spite of the lack of written information.

Incredible!. Be sure to visit all four: Sacsayhuaman, Q'enqo, Tambomachy, and Puka Pukara. They are all so different from each other and incredible in different ways. We paid 50 soles for a taxi driver to take us round trip from Cusco to all the sites and wait for us while we explored -- a worthwhile expense! Sacsayhuaman is the largest of the four sites, so make sure to leave enough time (and energy!) to explore it.You'll need a Boleto Turistico to access the site.

Amazing. Worth going just to see how incredible the architectural skills were so long ago -- these gigantic boulders were built without any mortar. It's fascinating to see. It was a little exhausting on the first day here -- when you're trying to acclimate to the altitude - if you're feeling good, do it, if not, wait one day -- but don't miss it!
Another amazing site. Don't miss this site it is also an amazing site and covers a huge area. You will find the usual knick knacks on sale at the exit.

Very impressive ruins! Inca engineering at its best!. If you're in Cusco, be sure to visit Sacsayhuaman! A taxi ride to the ruins is very inexpensive and there seems to be no shortage of guides at the site offering their services. We should have held out for one who spoke better English - she was still able to make our walking tour in the rain very interesting. You will stand in awe of the Inca engineers that built the walls of this ancient fortress. It's mind-blowing to see gigantic stones that were cut precisely to fit together without mortar. Don't miss this!
Amazing. Went there in the afternoon. Its quite a long walk if you want from the old town in Cuzco but it is a truly magical place. Really recommend it!

WOW!. I truly loved coming to Sacsayhuaman. It's just so amazing to see what people were able to build a very long time ago without the tools we have now.. This was one of the highlights of my trip to Cusco! DON'T MISS!!!

Fantastic place!. The place is out of this world... literally. After seeing this walls I no longer have any doubts they were build by much more advanced civilization than ours. Must see in Cusco. Highly recommended.

for those who have no time or are tired. this was a short walk up to a nearby place who stunned me so much...to think how the inkas managed to move these huge boulders without the modern hi-tech we have today is totally crazy and out of this world...simply unbelievable.
I highly recommend this site.

An architectual treat and an engineering feat. Outside the main city of Cusco, this is a site which will amaze you. What people can do without modern engineering devices and equipment AND it's still standing hundreds of years later!
Amazing. Cannot imagine how the Inca people could do this years ago. That was amazing. Worth visiting. Also you van see the Cuzco city from the very top.

Very cool, Awesome Views. What an incredible site to see! Really amazing what people were able to accomplish - almost unbelievable. Be sure to head around the site to get the most spectacular views of Cusco.

GO!. We were feeling so lousy because of the altitude and had heard Cusco's ruins were nothing compared to the Machu Pichu that we had just seen. However, a cab driver took us there and I am glad we went. In fact, he said, walk around and I'll meet you back here in an hour. We thought (yeah, we need 5 minutes with feeling this bad). An hour passed and I didn't want to leave! I was hot and windy so dress appropriately. There is no shade so wear sunscreen and take a hat. There is lots of walking too.

Inca Mastery. I wasn't sure why my Peruvian hosts wanted to visit Sacsayhuaman. We had been discussing the accomplishments of the Inca's and they put me in a vehicle and took me to the hills above Cusco. There I found walls of massive scale with each boulder precisely arranged so that a hair couldn't pass between the adjoining stones. Some of these were ten or more feet in height weighing 100,000 pounds or more. How were the stones transported to the hills and how were they joined...it makes Stonehenge seem simple. Prepare to be amazed.

Sacsayhuaman Is Ok.. Sacsayhuaman is something you should definitely visit if you are spending time in Cusco; however, it would not be my first choice of things to do. It is fun to climb on the ruins.

Huge!. I didn't realize the size of Sacsayhuaman when I walked up to the ruins - or the size of the stones in the in the walls - but I enjoyed walking around the place. I think it would be better served with a guide but even so, a lot of the rock has been hauled away so it's difficult to figure out what the structures were.
Off the normal tourist route, a hidden treasure. Hidden away at the top of the hills above Cusco this is worth the extra short trip to the top. Great history here.
Extraordinary Site. Close in, and overlooking Cusco, this large site is great example of Inca construction. They were master builders.
Stretch our imagination. Where there is a will there is a way to move tons of rock to build a temple exactly where you want it!! An amazing engineering feat and a great view of Cusco.

Worth the time. While it is 'just a bit green space with stones' it is definitely worth 2 hours of your time. To 'get it' you need to climb one side of the complex then sit and look. The enormity of what was and the ruins now fronting you slow sink in. Note it is an exposed space so be prepared for sun, rain and in our case snow (yes it snowed in Dec - apparently very rather so maybe dont both preparing for snow).

Fantasic Ruins near Cusco. We loved our brief tour of these ruins. On the outskirts of Cusco "Sexy Woman" is a fantastic, sprawling sight to see. Very green and open, with fantastic views of Cusco. Worth a visit.
Ancient mystery. U can't miss it. Colosal thousand tons stones, a holy place of mysterious origin. How its was built is way beyond the common stories you'll get. U gotta see it for yourself.

if you love hard way walking going up, this is it. fir all the hill walking lovers, I advice you to go to ¨Sexy Woman¨ if you like to sweat a lot hiking and exploring this massive complex, plenty of hills to go up and a lot o rocky plain to walk, again I recommend it
Inca ruins. What it is believed to have been a temple to the Lightning Deity. Biggest rocks in any Cusco Inca compound. Very interesting.

Inka construction at it's best!. The last of the Inka cities we saw, it is an amazing piece of construction. Stone blocks the size of semi's fitted together so tight you can't get a piece of paper in between. I've seen it on television and it exceeds it's billing. Also, much easier to negotiate than many of the Inka sites at much lower altitudes.

Amazing. It's huge, and green and the ruins are so interesting! I recommend u going on your on, and not as part of a city tour (because u won't have time to see all of the park). And u should have at least 2 hours inside to explore everything!!
Great ruins and not to be missed. Most trips offer this as optional but make sure to visit this. Amazing Inca site just 20 mins from Cusco center.

Seeing the HUGE stones the Inca moved into place was awesome!. It is amazing to me to see what ancient civilizations were capable of with regard to the Inca ruins in Peru. Some of the stones moved into place and fitted together to form terrace walls and/or fortifications at Sacsayhuaman exceed 100 tons! The scope of the site and the skill of the builders is worth having a look.

Good hike at Cuzco. Great way to acclimatise to altitude is to take a short walk up the hill to the Fortress. Like it so much, i have been there 3 times. Did tours with two different guides and both had different interesting things to pint out. Take some biscuits for the friendly dogs at the fort.
Sexy-woman. Remember to have some soles ready for the entrance fee. Went on a rainy day. It was a nice place to visit. I recommend having a guide to bring you around.
Great Inca historic site. A great introduction on Inca's civilization and their amazing accomplishments before a visit to remarkable Machu Picchu.

Beautiful site and nice views. Sacsayhuaman or 'sexy woman' as our guide jokingly called it, was simplyAmazing. It's two huge inca / Andean stone constructions but full of history. It's important that you go there with a guide as well so that you understand what the whole site is about. There's also a beautiful view over Cusco. We spent about 30-40 minutes there at quite a slow pace.

Very cool, big place, interesting history . Big place, very cool architecture and a very interesting history. Walkable distance, but in my opinion you should rather visit it (along with three other sites) on a day tour from Cusco, which are quite cheap. Not including the boleta turistico, of course. Possible to buy a small pass only for those for sites, but if you've got enough time I'd advise you to buy the general one (the full one). Very much to see.

Interesting ruins outside of city but go for Ollantaytambo for more history . Essentially a ruins for you to visit but would not take more than 45 minutes to visit . Not many notable features for this ruins other than it was used in the wars against the Spaniards. The ruins are not so well preserved and not many notable places to visit. If you gave more time, visit Ollantaytambo and Machu Picchu for a more interesting visit. I suggest that after visiting this ruins, go and walk to the Christ the redeemer statue 5 minutes away for a city view.

So close to the city so utterly fascinating. There is so much to amaze you here, the Inka walls, the views, the very large open plaza where you can imagine an ancient gathering to worship, commune, celebrate. The alpacas were grazing, the sun was shining, you may become transfixed.

Gorgeous!. The only reason I rated this below five "stars" is that the local vendors were getting extremely insistent, crowding up around us like vultures and shouting about their wears. The ruin itself was absolutely gorgeous, and an easy climb compared to other areas we visited. It had many levels and look out points without having all the steps clumped together!

so cool! don't miss it. we almost skipped this site after having just gone to Macchu Picchu but it is astonishing in it's own way - the stones are GIGANTIC and perfectly placed. It's awe inspiring! Plus the view of Cusco is not to be missed!

Interesting site right in Cusco. Definitely worth a visit. Very historical and a good precursor to doing the inca trail or visiting Machu Picchu. You won't be wowed if you visit it after MP. Be prepared to walk uphill a lot, and it can get hot/rain in quick succession so apply common sense as regards attire. Note it's not exactly cheap at approx 70s per person which seems steep given it doesn't include any sort of guide, map, information, etc. Toilet facility available at the ticket booth but that's it for facilities.

Mysterious and Fascinating Stonework. After spending almost a week traveling around Peru, this was one of the last archaeological stops that we made on our trip. If we would have done this right when we arrived in Cusco, it would have set a precedent for the trip, and the sites that we visited would have gotten more and more impressive.Seeing this at the end of the trip definitely diminished from the amazing engineering feat, but it was still extremely appreciable. With a natural rock "slide" and small tunnel systems, it was a really enjoyable stop.I would definitely recommend making this stop before going to other Inca sites in Cusco and The Sacred Valley!

Impressive, but you will need a guide. If you will not have a guide, you must do some good research beforehand, or it will not hold meaning for you. It is impressive to think that hundreds of people worked for fifty years to construct this area, which was primarily a military installation and home of the Royal Family in the 15th century. It also served as an important astrological center for the Incans of that time. Unfortunately, when the Spanish came, they moved a lot of the stones into Cuzco for construction of other buildings. It is a lovely sight, nonetheless, and there are llamas grazing on the property who sometimes take off running at high speeds for no apparent reason. If you are going to Cuzco, you have to see it.

A large open site with impressive Incan architecture. Set in the hills above Cusco, these ruins are easy to access, without strenuous climbing--although a great panoramic view is possible from the top of the glacial-scarred hill across from the site. The site was a fortress, and the most impressive feature is a series of three long terraced walls. As elsewhere, the precision fit of the granite blocks used in the construction, some of which are immense, even by Incan standards, is amazing. Besides the view of the site itself, there are fine views of the city below and of the nearby White Jesus.

Awesome quick tour. I've done sacsaywaman before. It's a fun and quick tour for families or adults.Great ancient architecture and the sundial is an awesome piece of engineering from so long ago.Definitely a must see part of any tour of cusco.

Excellent site. This is a great starting point. From here you will appreciate the craftsmanship and precision of their building practices. You will see the clear difference between how they built this sacred site and normal buildings
Don't miss it. Get a guide for sure....to tell you what you are looking at and the history of the location. Amazing. Lots of walking but easy/level walking.

Worth Seeing. As others have commented, there are other Incan sites that are more mind-boggling, but this is still impressive. If nothing else, the size of the stones that were used to build this structure is amazing and the views of Cusco make it more than worthwhile.In addition, there were a number of Llamas on the grounds, including a very young one, that were engaging to watch.

Large Incan ruin site on mountains above Cusco. Interesting Incan ruin site. Beside the Blanco Jesus on hills above Cusco. Great views . The size of the stones used to construct this site are amazing.

Nice panoramic view of Cusco. In Sacsayhuaman, there are many spots to take panoramic photos of Cusco (see attached example). I find this to be an interesting Inca site with symbolic meaning (ie one theory saying it is the 'head of the puma' whilst Cusco is the body), and visitors can learn about how the Inca people meticulously built stones without gaps etc. On a purely objective standpoint, however, sights such as Pisac, Ollantaytambo and of course Machu Picchu are more impressive. Still well worth a visit.
28 Ton Stone. I was winded by the altitude but could still marvel at the Inca imperial building stones. Views down to Cusco were amazing.

My visit to Sacsayhuaman. Very interesting place and its history up in the mountains of Cusco. Beautiful very wide open area and nearby hills with beautiful view, tranquil place. The rock walls are interesting history. The breeze feels fresh away from the city of Cusco. It's a beautiful mountain top.

Ruins. Sacsayhuaman is another wonderful site in the Cusco region. It is amazing how the area was built with those massive rocks without mortar. If you love ruins, history and architecture, this is a must see.

Incredible Impressions. Identifying some smaller ruins you sudddenly are faced with an incredible large Inka - fortress, huge dimensions, leading automatically to the question, how human beings could create such walls, using stones up to a mass of 125 tons, carved and arranged with mm - precision without technical means. Unbelievable ...

Incan Jigsaw. This place is a must-see if you are in the Cusco area. The view of the city and the Andes is stunning, and the stonework is incredible. It is an impressive intro to the Incas' work before bopping off to Machu Picchu.

Impressive Site & Wonderful Views of Cusco. Sacsayhuaman is one of the great Incan mysteries in the Cusco area. The best way to get there is with one of the many day-tour groups that start in central Cusco and bus you to Sacsayhuaman and other nearby sites. Go with a guide (or a guidebook) that can orient you to the most impressive stones (120+ tons) and stonework. Wonderful views of Cusco, as well.

A must see!. Think "sexy woman" to say this name. An awesome Inka structure with stones many tons in weight. Some 10+ feet tall. How on earth did they get there? This was home to 20,000+ people all dedicated to communal living while building this amazing structure. The ancient building techniques include rounded stones, fitted together like a jigsaw puzzle, which has allowed many Inka structures to survive the myriad earthquakes that have taken out so many of the more modern buildings.

You want a hike?. We had a free day and went in an adventure to Sacsayhuaman, from the main square in Cuzco took us about 30 minutes to get there, is higher than Cuzco but since we didn't have problems with altitude any more, we could enjoy the hike. We had an spectacular view of Cuzco and can give us an idea why the incas choose this place for their capital. A 100% recommended.
Immense Stones..incredible place!. Worth checking out ...even if some of these ruins were not on the radar before we left we were glad we visited them and can read about them from home.

So interesting . Well worth the time. Very close to the city. Really interesting to see what the incas were able to accomplish without any modern tools. Take a tour. It is worthwhile to have someone knowledgeable explain it all.

Massive Incan ruins!. Amazing to be similar to the Egyptian how in fact the Incans moved these massive bolders some weighing upwards of 125 tons. This is another fascinating place to visit while in Cusco high above the city. Walk aboe these rock formations and enjoy the views of the city below, lots of history surrounding this place.

Perfect Example of Inca Buildings. This place was very interesting and was a good example of the way the Inca built their buildings. They used no mortar but cut the huge blocks of rock to fit into each other. You can walk around and explore and it is very interesting.
Waooo. Never been there before and really blown me away so incredibly see with my eyes a magnificent construction. ..a must see...

Amazing!. It's still amazes us what the Incas and pre-Incas were able to build. Tall rock structures. Be ready to walk, listen to history of what and when all was built. We also climbed the Suchuna Chincana. Be ready to climb lots of steps.

great place to start. This location is a few minutes from cusco by taxi, easy to find and walk around, no matter if crowded or not, great place to take panoramic pictures of cusco, I recommend to do it before you go to machupichu and on weekdays or early on weekends, takes an hour to complete two if you want to have a picnic there. more flat areas to walk than up and down steps as other locations.

Nice to see if you have some free time. This are some neat ruins in which you can get up close and see how well the big stone were connected and carved. You can also get a wonderful view of the complete city of Cusco from the top. You will see some alpacas around and they seemed to be very use to people. Overall I wished that there were some signs explaining what certain things were.
Don't miss this great site so close to Cusco. Walk up from main square is a bit of a hike but well worth the walk. Incredible Incan ruins, if you go without a guide read up to get full impact.

Sexywoman! Definitely must see while in Cusco. There are 4 other sites that you should consider seeing when going out to Sacsayhuaman. These sites are Tambomachay, Puca Pucara, Qenqo, and Cristo Blanco. Here is how we did it. First of all, don't for get your tourist ticket (Boleto turistico). We took a taxi from Plaza Regocijo to Tambomachay (20 Soles) then we walked to Puca Pucara. From Puca Pucara you can either walk or take a bus (1-2 Soles) to Qenqo. We walked and it took us about 50 minutes. It's about 30 minutes walk from Qengo to Cristo Blanco or you can take a bus for (1-2 Soles). It's an easy 5-10 minutes walk down hill from Cristo Blanco to Sacsayhuaman. You can do it the other way around, too. However, I like the way we did because you started out from a small site and end up at the bigger site. It's more rewarded that way an less for me anyway.Go check it out, you can't compare Sacsayhuaman with Machu Picchu. Personally, I think Sacsayhuaman has more Megalithic structures than Machu Picchu. The wall around Sacsayhuman alone is very impressive! Don't forget to slide down on one of the natural sliders on the Rodadero of the site.

You really should have a look.. A main feature of the 130 soles tourist ticket Sacsayhuaman and the other 3 local Inca sites a well worth a look and pretry spectacular. Consider getting a taxi to bring you to the other local sites as they are a bit spread out. Pity that the Spanish besides to wreck most of it.

Great site - GET A GUIDE. I made the mistake of not getting a guide. Do yourself a favor and get one. It may help than just walking around and wondering. Site is quite big and some walking involved. Plan to spend 1.5-2 hours minimum.

Historical. The Locals call it "Sexywoman". This is a most interesting place. To view the stone structure.and try to imagine how these stones of such tonnage could be brought and placed on each other is a wonderment. Worth seeing.
Sacsayhuaman A must see!. This is a great day adventure while in Cusco! You can walk there if you are staying near the Plaza De Armas and the entrance fee is 70 soles but well worth it.
Enjoyed this! Nice walking tour.. These were cool ruins just outside of cuzco. You can walk over much of the ruins. Neat history and a good introduction to the inca infrastructure.

A must visit in Cusco. We were in Cusco unfortunately during a two day strike, so all taxis and public transportation were out of commission. Stil, we decided to brave the hill up to this attraction. Sure we may have huffed and puffed out way up the hill, stopping many times for a breather, as young Peruvian children ran past us playing soccer in the streets, up hill! But boy oh boy was it worth the hike. Guides at the gates were offering tours for 60 soles, but we decided to pass and explore the grounds on our own. In retrospect, I wish we had hired the guides, but we still enjoyed exploring the grounds on our own non-the-less. There are lamas on the grounds as well, in the large open middle grounds to come and take pictures of, though they don't seem to be as use to people as the ones at Machu Picchu are, so you likely won't get an up close picture with them, but you can get close enough to still get some nice ones with the ruins in the background.
Easy to walk there. This monument is not far from the main square and most of the tour guides said that this was the most important historic construction near Cuzco and really it is, do not miss.
Astounding Inca stone work very close to Cusco. Just a few minute taxi ride to splendid ruins. Not to miss. Available as a package with other sites, well worth the cost.

Amazing. It is amazing what the Inca's built by hand. It is above the city of Cusco. The stones fit perfectly. The view of the valley at breathtaking. The site is huge. It has last at least 800 years.
GORGEOUS. One of the best archaeological sites in the Cusco region! The stone structures are fascinating, and the history even more so.

Amazing site. The tour guide called it “Sexy woman” that is how it pronounced. It is a very tide and clean place and a beautiful spot. The ruins are magnificent and a must to go and see, walking up to the upper levels may be a little difficult for some, but worth it.There were a heard of Alpacas/Lamas (still can’t work it out) on the flats so we were able to get reasonably close.

Very Cool Ruins Just Outside Cusco. It was a quick 30 min hike from our hotel to the ruins just outside of town. Once you are there the views down to Cusco are amazing. We found a guide at the gates and he did an hour tour for us for 40 soles (we paid 50 bc he had no change, which seems to be a thing) It was worth it for the tour, we went through some crazy pitch black "secret" tunnel to get to the amphitheater section and then walked back to the main ruins. Very cool, ruins. There are sections that look like a puma paw, llama and guinea pig. The rocks a huge! We left from the Plaza de Armas around 8am and were back in town by 1130am.

Okay, but I guess it had to do with our tour guide! . I left the ruins closeby to Cusco city for my last week, maybe after visiting so many ruins this one didn't impress me. That being said, it is still pretty impressive how the stones were stacked on each other. Again, I had a terrible tour guide and it was also raining ☔ that day.
Ruins. Another site visited that was very clean, safe and friendly people. The walk around the site can be a little difficult for the older person but walking around the lower area can be done.

Beautiful, must go. A lot of people go there. It's very beautiful though.If you don't really know about history, a guide is required. Otherwise, you won't understand what you're looking at.Shouldn't be more than 60 Soles for 2 people. You'll get a better deal if you get a group.
Unbelievable stone work. Beautiful historic location with incredible views of the city. Our tour group was so impressed with the workmanship of the stone walls.

inca fortress. on the high side of the city, stuning view from the city and the valley below. You can rent a horse and ride about the wholle complex wich includes, the inca labitinth , Kenko and fuente del inca.
Awsome. Avoid the guides, each one has a different lie. The Invaders only interested in gold and silver did bother to take records of what this was.
Natural beauty. In the heart of a beautiful nature reserve this Inca remains offers fabulous views not to be missed.
Large grounds. I'm not sure what to make of this large area containing Incan ruins. Apparently it was used for festivals or sports.

An expansive complex that stood like menhirs created by Asterix & Obelix. I visited Sacsayhuaman this November and found the place to be magnificent. The original structure was an expansive complex that are still used today for Inti Raymi festival. You can spend an hour or so to explore the entire area, though it is barren of any artefacts on its own. My taxi driver doubled as a tour guide and I found the explanation he provided gave the place more meanings. It was part of a guided tour that included three other sites: Tambomachay, Puka Pukara and Qenqo. Worth going to visit Sacsayhuaman alone if you happen to spend at least two days in Cusco. I personally think it was better to take transport to these places rather than hiking up/down the winding roads. Save your energy and spend more time at the sites.

go with a guide. This is an interesting Inca construction, with a great view of Cusco. However, there is not much on site for information, so if you want to understand the significance of the site, get a local guide to show you around.
Love the name. It was an interesting site, wasn't crowded, with nice view's. Our guide provided lots of historical background which made it worth the trip.

Impressive Inca site just outside Cusco. These ruins are located just above Cusco. They're quite something. You can easily walk from Cusco (20-30 minutes. Alternatively you can grab a bus for 1-2 soles each way or taxi up for 8-15 soles each way - depends upon how good your bargaining skills are.The site is included in the tourist tickets you can buy for either 70 or 130 soles (depends upon how many sites and museums you wish to check out).
Amazing!!!!!!!!!. Unreal site. Cannot get over the shear size & magnitude of this place. A MUST if visiting Cuzco, fantastic photo opportunity at the top overlooking the entire city.
Amazing ruins close to Cusco. A 20 minute bus ride into the hills brings you to this huge Inca settlement. Very impressive and well worth the visit. Superb views of the city of Cusco
