Fascinating ruins - a must see when you're in Cusco!. We had the benefit of an amazing tour guide who understands clearly the history of this interesting site. Beautiful view of the city, plus fascinating history. Don't miss this when you visit Cusco --

Beautiful!. Definitely worth seeing! You see the amazing Incan architecture with huge stones moved here.Perfect for people who don't want to exert much.For this who want to climb a bit etc can climb up to the top of the place, for a big panoramic view! Pray for a day without rain!

Surprising and spectacular site with amazing huge stones. This is an amazing and massive site that I knew nothing about before we went. The massive stones are just astounding and ultimately mysterious because really no one knows how they got there. It's mind boggling and something worth seeing.

A Great Historical Inca Site. This area requires a some walking and some climbing. It is all about how great the Incas were as precise builders. There is also a small area where you can have your picture taken with a llama or buy the local Peruvian trinkets.

Great view. Really cool inca ruins. A real tranquill place with a Great view of cusco. The admittans fee might seem a bit steep but the ticket also includes entrance to most of the ruins in Sacred valley and some museums in cusco.

The question is still not answered,"How did they move those massive rocks"? Lots of theories exist. . Very interesting place to visit and actually see and learn more about the Incas. Until you actually stand beside those 110-180 ton rocks with multi corners and realize they were placed there like a tightly fitted puzzle with a lot of forethought to lasting many generations and with standing unknown numbers of earth quakes do you realize the engineering knowledge that civilization must have had! What a shame to have had all that knowledge lost forever. We're would we be to day if it wasn't destroyed?

Great 2-3 hours trip from Cusco. We took a taxi to visit the Inca ruins. It takes circa 15 min to get there. It's great for a little excursion while still having time to stroll around in Cusco on the same day. The view over Cusco is also super pretty :)
Worth a trip. Not the most impressive of the ruins you'll see - especially if you're going to the Sacred Valley, but with a guide it's worth the trip.
Must see ruins. Even after visiting Machu Picchu, these ruins were worth the trip. The amazing large stones used in building made this ruin different than any others we saw.
Great stuff . Massive rocks, perfectly played game of Tetris. Nice to just wander around wondering how they did it.

a inca-ruin near Cusco City. A inca-ruin near Cusco,you have to climb a long escalier and get to entrance of sacsayhuaman,it's more beatiful in the evening and you could overview cusco. There are some llamas,so cute,so shy.

Nice Ruins. If you have the Bolleto Turistico its definitly worth a visit you can even catch a bus up there for 0.70 Centamos so dont pay any Tours or anything like that Its really big so be prepared to walk abit take Water with you on hot days
Incredible!. It was incredible! The size of everything and knowing this was built with out modern machines! I want to go back and see more.

A Good Primer For Your Trip To Machu Picchu. Our guide suggested we stop at this location in preparation for our trip to Machu Picchu and we are glad he did. Besides being a less crowded way to be introduced to Inca building techniques it gives great views of the city of Cusco. Very interesting.
ruins close to cusco, cheap and easy. You can walk to these ruins and the entrance fee is cheap. You can do 1hr horseback riding for $10 nearby

Incredible!. My family visited these ruins in July 2015 and were amazed and in awe. How did they move those massive stones and carve them and place them so intricately. It's a really really beautiful site and there are great views looking down to Cusco. My kids really enjoyed walking these ruins.

Interesting and close to the city. There's not much left but walls but they are huge and impressive. A guide definitely helps to understand the significance of the place. Going there is easy too with local buses and walking down after to the city is a breeze.

Amazing Inca Fortress. We visited this at the end of the day after an extensive tour of Cusco.
It's stunning, our guide didn't give enough of the history, we had read up on it before luckily.
Go to the top to take a great look over Cusco below.

Great views. Interesting site to explore. Offers great photos and views of the city. Some small vendors at the exit, and lady and alpaca to take your picture with for a tip. Give yourself an hour or so here.
Beautiful ruins. This was a small but beautiful attraction and there are great views of the city. A wonderful experience.

Wonderful. We did not take a guide but we should have. The site is really not far from the city (45min) and clearly worth it. The ruins are beautiful and you will have the BEST point of view over the city
Tour is good.. Tour is very informative. Guides will even translate to non spanish speakers.The sites are alot smaller but worth the time and effort.

Very interesting Incan site. This is one of the many interesting Incan sites to visit in Peru. It's right on the outskirts of Cusco and provides great views of the city. If you are visiting Cusco, this site is worth a visit.
Intriuging place. This is a very interesting site. Don't know how they got the stones in place way back then. Lots of good photo shots

A fascinating view of Inca ruins. This is a great stop on your journey through Peru and takes about one hour. A very interesting view of the Inca construction and mystery of how they built their temples with such precision. There are even free-roaming alpacas in the area.
Fun for Kids.. Had a great day exploring accessible ruins. Don't miss the natural slides at the north end. My kids loved the "caves."

Cusco "above". Beautiful location overlooking Cusco and built with precision cut stones weighing more than 350 tons. To bad the Spanish tore much of it apart to build their cathedrals and homes with. In it's original state it would rival any castle built in Europe or the pyramids of Egypt.
awesome . cool old archaeology site. having a good guide makes all the difference here, so make sure your area on a good tour and spend a few hours exploring.

How did they build this!!. Like a lot of the things in Peru you keep wondering how did the the Incas achieve all these structures when they didn't have the modern equipment that is available today. Amazing.

Beautiful site and history!!. My girlfriend and I took a tour of this spiritual site with a local guide. She gave us a wonderful history lesson of the site. Standing back and looking at the wall, you can't help but appreciate the dedication and perseverance of the Incas people! How were they able to move solid stones that weigh in excess of 100 tons is just amazing!! Additionally, take your time and walk around, and you can feel some of the peaceful spirits still wandering the area. Take in the past, then look down the valley to see the present, beautiful Cusco!!
Amazing. Seriously how did they move the huge rocks. This place has some of the largest rocks used in the structures of all the Incan sites. Amazing. Not far from Cusco

Close to Cusco. Really close to Cusco, make sure you buy the Inca Pass, we paid around $50 dollars but you can get to many attractions. Some of these locations are about 2 hrs away from Cusco but you can hire a cab for about $40 dollar a day. You will not regret going to these places since you are going back in history.

One of the greatest civilization ever. After visiting the legacy that the Inca left the world one wonders what a great civilization they were! Full of knowledge of their surrounding and respect for the Pacha Mamma (mother earth) Try to go with a guide as there is so much information

forget the altitude and walk up to Sacsayhuaman. Don't be like most others who visit Sacsayhuaman by driving up to the ruins as part of a large guided tour group, but head out on foot from the Plaza de Armas and explore the ruins with one of the local guides you will meet at the gates to Sacsayhuaman. It's well worth the effort

Must see historical site. Never realized what impressive builders the Incas were. We saw this site prior to macchu Picchu. A good introduction to inca sites. Helps to have a knowledgeable guide. Ladies, be sure to carry your own toilet paper and hand sanitizer.
Must see. You can easily walk here from Plaza de Armas. The incredible rock formations will keep you in awe. Small fee to enter.
A must see when visiting Cusco.. Our guide gave us the wonderful history of this site and the huge rocks were amazing which left all of us in awe of how they were once put in place.

Located high over Cusco, stunning views, and unbelievable. Sacsayhuaman is one of the best known historical sites near Cusco. It is located above Cusco and has amazing views of the city below. We spent a few hours walking around the site and were blown away with the details and size of the rocks that make up the structure of Sacsayhuaman. There were tourists around but it didn't feel extremely busy or crowded. Also, there was a herd of alpacas that casually strolled through the site while we were there.

A steep but short walk from Plaza de Armas. It took around 20 mins to walk up the hill behind the Plaza de Armas. We bought our Boleta de Turistico currently costing Sol 130 per person at the entrance which will provide entry to many of the other sites we shall visit over the next few days. We spent 2 hours wondering around this impressive site. It was very peaceful (at least it was when we were there) and has wonderful views of the valley below. We also crossed over to the neighbouring Cristo Blanco - more of a tick box exercise I felt.

Worth the Hike. You can easily get a bus, taxi or horse up to Sacsayhuaman. We walked up - although it is quite steep in places, it doesn´t take very long and seeing the streets/views on the way up is worth it. The site itself is pretty incredible, with fantastic views of Cusco, and shouldn´t be missed!
Incredible Inca Archaeological Site . It's hard to imagine the engineering feat that it took the Inca's to build this place. A wonderful hike up to it from Cusco. A must see when visiting Cusco.

Huge Inka fort a short uphill walk from the centre of Cusco. Walk up the hill to this Inka and pre-Inka fort! You'll need a tourist ticket and don't go early in the morning or late at night, as this can be dangerous.

No guide, still impressive. We walked up the long hill and chose to see the ruins without a guide, though a few offered. The standing remains were so impressive, and the architctural abilities obvious. We didn't know what the significance was until later - that cusco itself was shaped as a puma, and sacsayhuaman was the head - the jagged walls being the teeth. Beautiful views, neat geology, and warm/exposed at the top - bring sunscreen and rain jacket.
Very interesting place. I enjoy my visit to all the ruins in Cusco. If you can you should take a private tour. You will learn a lot!

How they did?. This place is amazing! It is huge, lots of ruins, lots of history and I always keep wondering how they did it?It is not far from Cusco and you can have a basic visit in 45 minutes.I recommend it!

WOW!!!. it is amazing what the Inkas did around here, huge rocks to build a huge fortress it is wonderfull, from here you also have a great view of the city, our guide Chino told us that this was the main fortress in Cusco.

Sexy Woman???. It took me a few minutes, but I finally understood that the name of this beautiful place was NOT "Sexy Woman".... it is an ancient temple that exudes an air of reverence. Our guide led us to a somewhat private area where he created a beautiful challa ritual for us. Along with the beautiful energy of the temple complex, It touched me deeply. I will never forget this day.

A Main Atraction!. This is a marvelous historical site. Although there can be lots of visitors, the site is large and sprawling and you can feel like you are not surrounded by people. We had a great guide who explained the significance of the site, but any good guidebook, might do the same. This site is as important as any Inca site for learning about the expert stone work and architectural prowess of the Inca. This is a bit out of the way, but worth the ride!

Wonderful Side trip. Get a guide. Due to the strike, we were not able to hike the Sacred Valley, so we went here instead. We met two other couples and shared a guide. Get a guide. He pointed out things that you never would have seen without. It was about $5 USD per head for 90 minutes.

Big stones. Outside of Cusco you will find 4 Places of interest - among them "sexywoman".Take a taxi to Tambomachay - about 20 soles from downtown Cusco and start the day here. Remember your "tourist ticket" - and from here you can walk safe to Puca Pacara. Small places which only will take half an hour to visit.From Puca take a collectivo Down hill to Q' enqo -another interesting place - and from here you can walk to Sacsayhuaman - the most intersting place of the day.Take a collectivo from here back to Cusco centro. Its great fun and only cost you 2 soles. Remember to visit Christo Blanco.
Amazing . Great sites, good guides. Lots to do, one on the list for anyone travelling in Peru, definitely worth it.

Read on for transportation tips!. How to get to Sacsayhuaman from the south:- Walk uphill from town: very hard, especially if you're still acclimating to the altitude.- Hire private taxi from wherever you can find one (such as Plaza de Armas): expensive, around 15-20 soles, but reliable.- Ride a colectivo whose final destination is Pisac. These leave from Calle Puputi, and will cost you around 2-5 soles. Unless you are within walking distance of Puputi, I highly recommend taxiing to Calle Puputi--taxi drivers will immediately know what you mean when you say Calle Puputi. Added advantage of colectivo: you can ride on the colectivo up to Tambomachay/Puka Pukara instead of just to Sacsayhuaman.- Take a senor del huerto bus from the same Calle Puputi. 1 sol. Wasn't obvious to us where these buses originated, so we went with a colectivo.How to get to Sacsayhuaman once you're done visiting Tambomachay/Puka Pukara:- Cheapest: hike down. this can take hours if you're slow. Sounds like the trail is poorly marked, and you walk across private property. We didn't attempt it.- Also free: walk down along the road. Probably a bit dangerous and definitely very slow (the sites are miles apart).- Next cheapest: flag down a southbound Senor del Huerto bus and tell the driver you want to be dropped off at Qenqo/Qenko or Sacsayhuaman. 1 sol.- Flag down a passing colectivo and tell them the same thing. A few soles.- Pray for a southbound taxi (probably one that's just completed a dropoff at Tambomachay) and pay a higher price. Again, highly recommend combining Sacsayhuaman DEFINITELY with Qenqo/Qenko as well as--if you can make it up there--Tambomachay and Puka Pukara.

Close to Cusco, only spent and hour here. We visited this place after a morning of horse riding (which is only 5 minutes away). Forgive us for not knowing too much of the history of this place and we didn't find much info whilst we were here. The sun was shining and we got loads of tourist photos. I can't remember what the entry fee was but it was expensive for what was a few people sitting in a hut at the entrance. I think this is the sort of place you have so see if you're staying for a few days at Cusco. I imagine i will see it on TV in a few years and think 'i went there' other than that, they are essentially some large (extremely well cut) rocks.

Surprisingly intact considering local attitudes as recently as 1980. We spent a couple of hours wandering around here. The Inca stonework is awesome to study. Our guide told us that this has only relatively recently become protected, within the last 40 years. Prior to that locals used to come to use it as a quarry. A must visit if in Cusco

Inca Holy Site That Is Also An Engineering Marvel. The stone wall base to the site is interlocking 10-15 ton stone blocks engineered to withstand earthquakes. How the stones were moved from the quarry to how they were fitted and lifted is a mystery. Make sure you get the history from a good guide as the story of the site is compelling.

Well worth a taxi ride or walk up the hill from the town. Worth spending an hour or so wandering round the site. Grab a guide from near payment desk for around 50 Soles (could probably knock this down but I couldn't be bothered). Our guide was full of information and spoke good English. Not far from the town so could pop up in a taxi in 10 minutes

Amazing!. This site is the resting place of some of the most impressive Inca stonework. Our guide explained that the largest stone is about 20ft tall and is estimated to weigh about 112 tons. It was dragged about 4 miles by about 2000 men!

Impressive sites, but best expereinced with a guide. The overall site is the size of many football pitches (and as flat!) so be prepared to do some medium intensity wandering. It is impressive as it is, but to really get some sense of the history and its significance I strongly recommend you go with a guide (ideally in as small a group as possible)Each separate area has different stories to reveal and you will be rewarded by taking your time, so try to avoid the standard dash thru that many tour companies can offer.You can walk it up from Cusco if you wish but perhaps easier to pay @ $3 for the taxi to take you up and then wander down at your leisure.

Wonderful. When staying in Cusco, this site is a must! It is just above Cusco and can be accessed either by walking, bus or taxi. We took a taxi to the entrance and arranged for our driver to meet us at the other side. We took our time walking across the site and marvelled at the workmanship. Entrance had to be paid in cash, they would not accept US dollars.
Great ruins in the city. We walked up from Plaza de Armas (take water!) and spent a couple of hours walking around the ruins. Make sure you go down the rock slides - fast and fun!
Great Ruin right outside Cusco. This is a great ruin within the city limits of Cusco. Great views of the city from the ruin and nice grounds to stroll around

Sacsayhuaman is Mind Boggling. FYI - I am a megalithic maniac - so that may color my review. I just love the stone places in the world - especially where huge stones are set in very precise ways. Sacsayhuaman is full of precision stone settings. There are some HUGE blocks and some very intriguing joints between them. I was with a tour and only got to spend about 90 minutes here; but I could have stayed for hours. If you are intrigued by the abilities of the old ones to manipulate stone, this is one place that will boggle your mind and warm your heart.
Amazing!. we really enjoyed visiting this site and marveling at the obvious ability and skills of the people who had built it. The sheer size of some of the stones was quite awe-inspiring.
Amazing. Definitely take a walk around, the size of the stones will leave you in awe of the Inca's. We ended our trip with a great horse ride.

Stunning ruins!. This one is definitely the most different of all the Inca ruins we visited. Definitely worth it on a sunny day! Make sure to take a hat, wear some sun screen and carry lots of water (the sun can get REALLY strong up there!). Also, after you are done walking around make sure to take the little path down to Cusco city. It's a wonderful walk and there are great views of the city

How did they do this?. We went to Sacsayhuaman at the end of our tour time in Peru. By this time we had seen many Inca ruins. Still, we were very impressed with seeing this site. We went on our own without a guide so we weren't able to learn that much about the site. It was very interesting to see what the Incas were able to accomplish...I still find it incredible.I would see this site if you have the time. Definitely take a taxi from the plaza..only $3 and walk down afterwards
Great History. We had a personal guide and he was very knowledgeable about the ruins. It's nice to see that these ruins have been preserved very well.
Amazing history. I recommend paying for a guide. A woman from the park approached us and ask if we would like a tour. Incredibly educational.

Vast Fascinating Inca Ruins close to Cusco. Although it is a steep walk (or a short drive) the visit is definitely worth the effort. This is a vast Inca fortification used in one of the last stands by the Incas. It comprises huge boulders that have been sculptured to perfection - don't miss it if your are visiting Cusco.
Worth a visit. Most interesting - so much to be learnt from visiting the site. The views are brilliant and one is in awe of how it was constructed.
Inca fortress. Beautiful view of the city of Cusco from the top of this Inca fortress. This was an excellent stop on the tour of Cusco to see this vast Inca ruin.
Absolutely amazing. You're not going to believe that regular people cut and fit these giant stones. They are perfectly fitted together and HUGE! This is a must visit not too far from Cusco.

very enjoyable. On our first full day in Cusco, we were feeling pretty good and decided to walk up the hill to Sacsayhuaman, then over to Cristo Blanco and Q'engo. It was an enjoyable walk and a nice test for altitude readiness prior to inca trail (although I wish I'd worn hiking boots, I was in boat-type shoes and my feet were quite tired by the end). We hired a guide just outside the gate, and both of us were thoroughly glad we did (this theme runs throughout everywhere we visited in Cusco - not much signage at the ruins, which is nice in that they aren't "cluttered" ... but really does make a guide a necessity). I would think if you spent time in Cusco and didn't go to this important site, you'd be short changing yourself. I think we spent about 90 minutes there.

Fantastic example of Inca ruins.. The site is vast and well worth a look. We did notice that some of the restoration work was a little poor compared to the original but it did not detract from the overall effect.

Awesome. Saqsayhuamán- yes, I copied and pasted that- is so great to visit. Make sure you get the tourist pass so you can see all of the smaller ruins in the Sacred Valley. It over looks the city of Cusco which was cool to see. You can walk over to the Christo Blanco statue, as well. I actually walked back to town after visiting here. Easy to access.
Memorizing.. Its hard to believe that I planned on skipping this location due to time. My husband really wanted to go, and I am so glad we did. The ruins are truly breathtaking.

inka temple very close to cusco downtown. very interesting to get to know the 2nd most important sun temple to the inka people. it is also very close to downtown, hire a guide at the entrance and spend ~2 hours on it.

Need to See it to Believe it. 160-ton boulders put in place with nothing more than ropes, logs and labour? This is an amazing place of Incan history; one can only stare in wonder at the achievement and wonder what it must have looked like when undisturbed.

Impressive Inca site. This site was brought alive by a great guide who explained the different types of stonework and how they are earthquake proof as well as the history behind the building- much better than wandering around on your own

Amazing ruins in Cusco. Worth a visit. Some of the pieces make Stonehenge look like an amateur pebble sight. Wild llamas hanging out and plenty of lovely views. You will spend about 1-2 hours there depending on how interested you are in the background.

Unreal--just a tremendous feat!. This site will take your breath away when you see the size of the stones and realize how far away they came from! Then it will break your heart to know they were pilfered to build the cathedral. Great site, worth a stop AND a guide.
Spectacular ruins.. Great experience of walking around the site of this Inca fortress. Made us admire once again the fantastic stonework.
Sexy woman. Definitely a place to visit while in cuzco. It is also a good training in case you want to do some trekking

Great attraction. Visited this historic place with a group of friends on a trip to Peru. Took a taxi from Cusco. Did not hire a guide ahead of time, but was able to find one right there, at the site. The guide was very knowledgeable and spent an hour telling us about the history of this place and showing us around. Recommend to take kids here. Ancient stone architecture is amazing!

Great views of Cusco. These are wonderful ruins located up on the hills of Cusco. Fascinating history and they have an amazing view of Cusco.I walked up from San Blas (three times). It is also walkable from the main square (about 40 minutes).The best deal is to buy the Cusco Tourist Card. You get into a number of sites for 130 soles.

A must. On any visit to Cusco ,is one of the most imposing Inca monuments called Sacsayhuaman .Its only a short drive out of the city the site is extensive and an impressive example of Inca military architecture.Its made up of three large terraces which overlap in a zig zag fashion.

Unbelievable Inca Craftsmanship. This is a perfect complement to Machu Picchu because the rock formations are better. You can easily spend 2 hours at this site. Challenging trek to ruins but well worth it.

Cusco Ruins. Having been to the Sacred Valley and Macchu Picchu we weren't sure what to expect. We took a taxi (10S) from downtown. We did not hire a guide as there were several clearly labeled routes and quite frankly we were more in the mood to wander. What we enjoyed the most was how unique each part of the ruins were, on one side was a series of zig zig pattern walls. On the other large rock faces as grazing sheep. Having done our homework we managed to find the sides in the back of the ruins (they were very fast - consider yourselves warned) and enjoyed the amazing views of the city. As there are two entrances we went in one side and out the other. This was very convenient. There is no shade here so I would recommend planning accordingly. Over these are great ruins and very easy to access.

Fantastic fort. After a steady 30 minute climb up an Inca stone trail, you reach this amazing fort. The climb can be quite tough due to the elevation so take it easy. The stonework at Sacsayhuaman is impressive. As are the views of the city. You can easily spend a good hour exploring this ancient site. We didn't opt for a tour guide, referencing a book we already had. Although you can explore alone, I would imagine a guide could add some real Inca flavour, bringing the place alive. There are a couple of other Inca sites you can explore by foot from here, including Q'enko and Cristo Blanco. We recommend you ask for directions from the rangers so you head off in the right direction as it is not well sign posted.
Amazing sight. It is hard to imagine how the Incas constructed this place hundreds of years ago. It is a truly stunning sight overlooking the city of Cusco.
Must see. Very atmospheric place awesome building wasn't quite ready for the scale of the amount of work and ingenuity the incas used to build this marvel

Beautiful at Sunset. I hired a private taxi to take me up here -- do it, it's so worth it! The site itself is impressive, beautiful, and full of sacred energy if you quiet yourself enough to allow it to flow in. It's accessible :) Gorgeous, beautiful, stunning at sunset! I'd suggest you plan at least a couple of hours here at minimum.

We had a flash hail storm. After having a very hot day we arrived at Sacsayhuaman and as soon as we started across the field a sudden hail storm hit and the temperature plummeted. Such a great spot to wander around and marvel at the stone masonry work.
large. Went as part of city tour so our visit was short and missed the slides that I wanted to see. Nice stone work.

Absolutely Astonishing Structure!. It's more than amazing to witness how big stones this structure has. Some of the rocks are longer than 25 feet and weigh about 125 tons. It's definitely worth visiting it.

Amazing, must visit, one of the top highlights of our trip to Peru. Our trip to Peru and specially Cusco and its surrounding areas included several short stops at key locations but Sacsayhuaman was easily one of the best.I didn't expect much from this place but as soon as we arrived and began to walk around the giant boulders we were mesmerized by the imposing structures and history behind it.Must visit place and a sight you'll never forget.

Amazing. Don't miss this local attraction and be sure to hire a guide. I recommend that you take you poles as well. This site has far more significance that most of the guidebooks indicate, and we were stunned by the beauty of the place as well as its scale. Our guide was a bit creative including telling as the the Incans created tunnels from Cusco to Machu Picchu (what?) along with other questionable facts. She was an able tour director overall during our hour which given the very direct sun and attendant heat was plenty for our party. Don't miss this important part of the Incas' history. It will solidify their genius even more for you.

Worth every step up to it!. Sacsayhuaman is worth the hike. Definitely hike from the 'Plaza Mayor' of Cusco and see the beautiful side streets, great views hiking up and feel the rewarding sense of how high you can climb even above 2,000 meters! Take your time, stroll, discover and definitely find the corners and ledges nobody else visits!

Amazing Inca large stones with view of Cusco. Well worth the trip, was filled with tourists however great view down to Cusco and the thought of 4000 men trying to place these stones and carve to at one time have one roll back down the hill and kill 1000 men, you just have to be in awe
Really impressive place. Amazing example of Inca buildings and well worth a visit. It does get cold though as the wind blows across the site so do take a sweater!

Wonderful Inca Ruins 10 min from Cusco. On our 2nd day in Cusco we went to Sacsayhuaman for a few hours late in the day. It wasn't crowded at all. It was our first time to see the Inca Ruins. It also has sweeping views over Cusco and the Jesus Statue overlooking the city of Cusco perched high on the hill. We had a private guide which I think one must have to really understand what you are looking at. We used the services of Cusco Local Friend (review of them separate on their page). We loved the services we received from Cusco Local Friend it was outstanding. I would definitely seed these ruins while in Cusco.
Impressive. Must see! It is really impressive place. It is closer to the city center than it looks so you can walk there.

Pronounced "saxywoman". This is a must while visiting the great city of Cusco. Sccording to our guide the city was originally designed in the shape of a Jaguar. At the top of the hill there used to be a tower plated in gold which represented the eye of the jaguar. This is where they believed the Inca could view the entire city. The ruins are quite interesting and its history fascinating. Its an incredible site with huge stone walls strategically placed and in some placed you can see shapes of animals in the stone. Be sure to arrange travel up and down but the walk down is not at all difficult and actually quite pleasant.
Amazing. Could not believe the sheer structure of this, lots of history behind it, go with a guide who can tell you everything

Impressive stones!. How those massive stones were put together is amazing and a sight to see. The place is over-hyped by some people but it is best suited for a quiet visit. Go early in the day, before noon, otherwise the crowds in the afternoon can get large.

Never seen before. What you can appreciate there is enigmatic and wonderful. You will be in awe as you explore the structure. The tour guide can make the difference for a good or a excellent visit. Ours was just good.
GREAT PLACE. Great place, but the goverment need invest to remodelate and will be similar Machu Pichu constructions. Near cuzco, great to visit but need time and work.

Genius Rock engineers.. The awesomeness of this sight cannot be over emphasized. It is a marvel of of the stone age people and their high technology in agriculture that surpassed anything in the west or east. A short trip from Cuzco and we wandered around for several hours just trying to take it all in.

The size of the stones carved and moved is amazing. The sheer size of the stones moved and the field between the two sections is impressive. The use of the field as water drainage storage is a feat of engineering as well. Definitely worth the trip to see.

Underrated but pretty amazing. These ruins are certainly underrated but they are spectacular. The size of the rocks you see here are larger than any other ruin in the Machu Pichu /Cusco region. You will be able to experience from close up how the Incas built giant instalations. Two added bonuses - 1) not many tourists since they concentrate on Sacred Valley and Machu Pichu and 2) only a 5 minute taxi ride from Cusco.
Awesome sight!. Next to Machu Picchu, this was the most spectacular site we visited. The sight of those giant rocks so perfectly chiseled and formed to fit in sync was truly amazing! Don't miss it!
An amazing experience. A fantastic experience especially with our guide who had a wealth of knowledge. well worth seeing during a stay in Cusco. It is classed as the start of the Inca trail..
Senic. A very big site with great views of the surrounding area, really gives an insight to the size of the city and what the Inca's were capable of.

primer for inca trail. Do yourself a favor and try out the hike up to Sacsayhuaman while in Cusco--it's a good primer for what the Inca Trail is like, and will provide some awesome views of Cusco. It takes about 2-3 hours to view in total.
Quite interesting, visit if you have time. No comparison with Machu Picchu, but interesting all the same. Quite a feat to carve and move all those boulders.
Amazing Place. Go with a guide, to really get the history and to see some things that you would miss walking around by yourself.

One of my favorites. Sacsayhuaman is my favorite archaeological site besides Huayna Picchu and Machu Picchu. The place is very big and I was able to take lots of pictures with llamas and vicunas. Strongly recommend.

Sacsayhuaman not to be missed.. This site is about 20 minutes outside of Cuzco. We saw this after seeing Machu Pichu and the Sacred Valley sites. Although we were prepared to be underwhelmed due to the magnificence of Machu Pichu we were not disappointed. The site was beautiful and it was not crowded. The size of the stones was mind boggling This site allowed us to be more contemplative that we could with the crowds at Machu Picchu Not to be missed.

Sacsayhuaman. This was a fantastic place to visit. Definatly the best of the 4 on the hill just outside of Cuzco. i decided to walk down to this site, from the other ones up the top of the hill. On reflection, its probably easier to just get a combi, as it was very hot and a bit further than i expected. You can definitely go and see this independently and you dont need to be on a tour. I got a brochure in spanish, as there were none left in english, so might be a good idea to read up a bit of info beforehand :)

Incredible Incan Stonework. The size of the stones and the exactness of the masonry here was amazing. We visited as part of a private tour and got to see some Incan slides up above the main ruin area. So cool! One of the highlights of our trip in the Cusco area.

Incredible History. Something to put on your bucketlist. I have read so much about ancient histories and Sacsayahuaman was one of those things on my bucket-list. It did not disappoint. Obviously there are a lot of tourists there so I'm sure there's someone complaining on these reviews about that. But if you're a history buff and you want to get a glimpse at one of the wonders of the world, then this is a must. I recommend reading a little about Incan history before you go or have a tour guide with you that can explain everything to you. I also recommend hiking your way up from Cusco but remember, it's high altitude so you'll get puffed out but worth it when you make the very top :) Enjoy

"Sexy woman" was definitely an experience not to be missed. We lucked out and went to "Sexy woman" on the day the local schools were rehearsing for the annual reenactment of Inti Raymi in this awe inspiring coliseum type structure made of gigantic stones. Our guide from Condor Travel - Washington- did a wonderful job explaining the tradition of young men competing in various events as they attempted to reach warrior status. The spiritual significance of the site is also fascinating. I say it was great despite a vehicle breakdown on the way to the site. Kudos to Condor Travel for the quick response they made in finding alternate transportation and keeping us informed during the process.

don't skip. don't miss this- we were there after Manchu Picchu and were as thrilled with the wonders of Incan engineering here as we were at the more reknown MP. We did take a taxi from San Blas neighborhood and had him stop at the Blanco Christo statue as well.

Amazing Inca Terraces. Considerable walking needed to access the terrace and store houses building high up on terraces on the site.Well worth the visit. Expect to be harassed by souvenier sellers along the roadside where the coaches park.

Evidence of Near-superhuman Achievement in the Outskirts of Cusco. How the ancient Incas cut & laid the massive stoneworks here is beyond belief. Although, the quarry at which these stones were mined was evidently located at the nearby cliffs (as opposed to the Stonehenge monoliths which were mined & carted over hundreds of miles), the ingenuity underlying their cutting into fitting shapes like in a child's jigsaw puzzle is astounding. As someone pointed out, the pronunciation of this attraction's name comes close to "sexy woman".

Mystical, magical, spiritual.... If you go to cusco, don't miss "sexy woman". It's a steep, yet short walk up to the site. This place is very mysterious and awe-inspiring when you see the craftsmanship it took to move, shape, and fit such enormous boulders into the current structure. We went twice. The first time we walked the area by ourselves and then the second we happened to run into Mario Salomon Caceres Vara to be our groups guide. He was incredible! If you are open to hear about the native people of Peru's version of history and spirituality then he's your guy. If you are not an open minded person then you'll probably not like him. We had 1 person out of our group of 8 leave b/c his spill conflicted with her religious beliefs. The rest of us loved it, and I personally took some life-lessons and insight away from the experience He said he'd spend 1-2 hours with us and he ended up spending 3-4 hours for around $20 (we probably ended up giving him at least $50-60 from our group). Sacsayhuaman is a must see place for any traveler who appreciates ancient culture.

Impressive relic of Incan Civilization. This is an historic site in the hills above Cusco (it is not in or near Plaza de Armas in Cusco as the address in this entry seems to suggest) and it is impressive. It consists of some massive stones hauled from a jaw-dropping distance, polished, and expertly arranged (without mortar) to create a coliseum / arena type gathering place for major events such as the Inti Raymi (a sort of Olympic games for Incan teenage boys). TIP 1: Climb up one or both of the optional sides to get a beautiful panoramic view. TIP 2: It's important to have some sort of guidance visiting this site. If you just wander around yourself or without background information, you won't fully understand or appreciate the significance of the place or the human accomplishment it reprents. Instead, it will just look like semi-interesting ruins.

A short but steep walk up hill from Cusco. Very good Inca ruins and a reasonable entrance fee. You need 1-2 hours to walk around the site but it is well worth the visit. Spectacular views over Cusco - a must do!
Extraordinary. Amazing look into the temple of the sun and understanding the power of the Incan culture. Created without machinery this a wonder of the old world.
Cuzco in august. Perfect whether nice and sunny, clear sky ,very pleased with the altitudes. Is a waking trip around the andes.

Great View of Cusco!. We took a taxi to Sacsayhuaman and we already had purchased the tourist ticket. You can get the ticket here as well if you did not get it in Cusco. We took a guide (which we rarely do) in an attempt to get more details than I could out of the printed guides. Guide was OK, provided 'back story' and answered our questions. It is best to do some reading on Incan history and the Spanish colonization before visiting these sites. It will help put the sites into perspective. Otherwise....it can be just a lot of stones neatly fitted together.

Good Sight. It was alright to head up here. It was good to look down over Cusco. The Inka sight is nice as well but I may have been Inka'ed out as it was just alright. But if you were just taking in this and one or two more it would likely be amazing.... but...

Amazing place. Amazing place. the stone walls are massive, some blocks are over 100 tonnes. The city tour doesn't spend long enough at the sight so I recommend going up on your own. Fantastic viewpoint over the city too

Sacsayhuaman. It was very beautiful at Sacsayhuaman. The view of Cusco was breath taking from the cross and the statue of Jesus. The ruins were also very nice. The walls were very high, and have been kept in shape.

Impressive site that will surprise you with its scale and design. There's more to this site than meets the eye when you arrive. It's an impressive piece of history. Be sure to stop and look at the diagram of the entire site at the entrance to get a feel of just how large the structures are. When we visited, there were students performing in a marching band, and young men practicing military drills. It all added to the ambience and scale.

Amazing historical place. It's amazing to see the huge stones the Incas used, and the design they used. Take the time to walk all over, and make sure to find the tunnels in the rocks. It's a very neat site.
Great views. Came by taxi but walked back - a good start to our Cusco adventure, had to take it slowly because of the altitude but wonderful vows all over Cusco and an early introduction to the Incas

Massive stones. You really should come here if you are in Cusco. The scale of the stones was so large and impressive. We did not take a guided tour but they do have free maps (in Spanish) with the highlights you should see. You have to ask for them so pick one up from the main booth inside because the arrows weren't great around the site. We followed the red route on the map. There is a great view of the city of Cusco below. Also make sure to find your way to the slippery rocks. They are in the area called Suchunao Rodadero on the map. They are like a slide. There are also some small tunnel caves past the slippery rocks. No shady areas, bring hat and water.
Interesting. Full of history, from the top good views. Make sure you have sun-block and of course walking shoes. It was a nice day when I went so it was thoroughly enjoyable

A must to see attraction at Cusco. Sacsayhuaman was the head of the puma head when Cusco was an Inca city with the shape of a puma. It was an espiritual place were most of the religious celebrations took place. Today is a wonderful place, almost as a park, with huge stones and walls, that remind us the greatfulness of Inca empire. It is still a place for espiritual celebrations and events. You can go there as part of a city tour or you can go solo by taxi

2 Days in Cusco. We finished our trip here and stopped on the way to the airport....don't skip it!We spent about an hour here with a guide. Get a guide worth the money but you don't really need more than an hour here.
Impressive. It's really big and impressive site. Lots to see. But unfortunately if you don't have a guide you won't learn much about it because Peru doesn't really have explanation boards anywhere.

Not the most interesting Inca ruin but the easiest to get to. Sacsayhuaman, pronounced "sexy-woman", yes that is how it is pronounced, is just above Cusco by the Christ Cross and a 15 Sol cab ride or 40 minute walk up the hill. It is interesting to visit and the Eucalyptus trees give off a great smell, but you should consider this a warm up for the better sites like Ollantaytambo, Pisac, and Machu Picchu. However the view of Cusco from up here is fantastic and you can see the entire city spread out below you.This is a part of the full tourist ticket so if you are visiting museums in Cusco this should also be a stop in town.

Important site. This Incan ruin is best visited with a tour guide in order to understand what you are seeing. The setting itself is well worth the visit. Set high above the city of Cusco, the views are beautiful. Impressive plaza area where ceremonies were held, as well as the ever amazing examples of Incan stone on stone construction. Some of the stones at this ruin are just huge. Hard to imagine how many hundreds of men must have been used to cart each of these stones to the site and then put them in place. The countryside just beyond the ruins is great to explore on foot. You can hike in this area all afternoon! We even hiked back to town.
Enormous, Amazing Inca site. You are first struck by the enormous size of this site, then by the intricacy of the many walls made with enormous stones. It's amazing.
impressive structure. This is a large and impressive ruin to explore, as well as having great views of the city below. Even the hawkers on the approach are a fun part of the attraction

The world above, and all around. Being from Trinidad, West Indies, Peru in general and Cusco in particular was extraordinary. Sacsayhuaman is awesome. The sheer size and workmanship take the breath away ( as well as the altitude and the cool, cold wind). Our guide, Alejandro Vargas Dias, described the history and the features of the site. Pictures convey the colour and something of the size. They don't tell you of the perfection of the stonework and its overall impact. You are in the presence of something ancient and enduring.

City tour of Cusco. We a tour by Condor to take in the sights of Cusco. This was a most interesting stop. We were there just before sundown and got gorgeous photos of the site bathed in golden light. Very informative tour!

Good Example of Inca Culture and Construction . My wife and I visited this site as part of a half day Cusco tour run by Condor Travel. Our female guide was very informative and knowledgeable.Saqsaywaman is a very large archeological site which includes the three tiered temple, a large "square" and the quarry from which the Incas obtained the large rocks which they carved into massive stones that fit perfectly with on another, to construct their temple.It is a very impressive structure showing the original amazing stone work of the Incas and it is certainly a very worthwhile visit.

Amazing construction. This is an amazing place high above Cusco. It was constructed by the early Incans as a fortress to their city. What is astonishing about this place is the massive boulders that had to be cut (chiseled) and moved to this remote location. The boulders all fit perfectly with each other and are huge. It's unbelievable how they were able to carry off this feat of construction. It's worth the drive to see this impressive place!

Amazing view of the city. My friend and I decided to hike up to Sacsayhuaman (many Americans call it "sexy woman") from Plaza de Armas. Although most people will take a cab or bus to the summit, walking up from the city center is very doable. You'll get slightly winded but it makes it all the more worthwhile when you reach the top. Once at the top you can take pictures with natives dressed in traditional garb and their baby alpacas. Following the trail will bring you along a few areas where you can rest and take pictures with a breathtaking view. Highly recommend!

Great starting point for exploring the Inca sites in Peru. Sacsayhuaman sits right above Cusco and offers a great view of the Cusco valley and Cusco itself. It's a great introduction to Inca kingdoms history. Getting there from Cusco is easy; you can trek or hire a car to get there. Do take a guide.

One of the most amazing things I have ever seen. I first saw this site almost 15 years ago, but could not wait to return. I spent two morning at Sacsayhuaman this past summer and it seemed even more astounding. Please try and go in the early morning. There will be fewer people and the light will be perfect. It is walkable from Cusco's main square (although it all uphill!). 1-2 hours is the minimum. Take your time. Soak it up. Enjoy!

Worth a visit.... Cool fortress worth visiting. Be sure to bring rain gear as the skies opened up out of nowhere when we were there. May be best experienced with a guide to share the local perspectives on the fortress and some of the key things to look for.
Sacsayhuaman was the place to see in Cusco. We really enjoyed this place... it is really worth a visit. It is breathtaking to see these, well preserved, facts about Inca civilisation.

A smaller scale site than Machu Pichu with its own story to tell.. If you see one, you've seen em all! If you feel like that, get a good guide because each site has its own story to tell. This site has all the hallmarks of Inca construction and is being looked after sensitively. It's not as big as Machu Pichu and far less crowded.

Incredible marvel of Incan engineering. Above Cusco is Sacsayhuaman. (just go up from the main plaza and you can't miss it.). It is quite a breathtaking climb to get there, but the burn in your legs and lungs is worth it. The stone work by the Incans is stunning and perfect. This is a great place to visit while in Cusco, and gives you a great preview of what to expect when you visit Machu Pichu.

a Place that must be visited. A sacred place of the Incas, it is a little like visiting the pyramids in Egypt. Built before Machu Pichu, the stones used are huge and you are left wondering how they were moved.This is definitely a must place to visit.
Amazing place . Amazing place... You can feel the vibes around you , a quiet place and a must in your trip... You have to book it with a city tour.

first ruins outside of the cusco. get a guide or you won't find the stones that you need to see. there are a lot to see. you buy the tickets for 4 ruins and without the guide, it only takes 2 hours. if you have a guide, it can take 4 hours at least. Enjoy.
Breath Taking. Beautiful smell of eucalypti's trees on the way. The Vendors selling their wares. Panoramic vistas Just gorgeous. A world treasure.

Sacsayhuaman. We saved this for our last day in Cusco, having already been to Machu Picchu and Choquiqueraro. I was almost reluctant to go, but the 35 minute walk up hill was invigorating, and the site so different from what we had already experienced. It was the last stronghold of the Incas and a major site. I was unhappy that the $21 entrance fee didn't include any literature in English or Spanish. But we did find at the end one large sign station, which was good.

A once in a life time Day. We got the rare opportunity of being there during the Inca festival with everybody decked up in traditional clothes and Inca dances, the processions etc. Great Day! The archeological remains and Inca constructions were quite amazing to see.

Very Interesting Place. Hundreds have people have already written about this place. A must see place when you are visiting Cusco. It is a interesting place to visit to understand the ancient Mayan culture.

Highlight of my Machu Picchu trip! Start your day here. They open at 7AM.. To prep for Machu Picchu, I read the Last Days of the Incas by Kim McQuarrie (great book!), and I was hoping I could figure out how to visit this site, Saqsaywaman, when I go to Cusco. To my surprise, it’s very close to the Plaza De Armas. I started at 6:30AM and took Amargura street (up a long set of steps) to Don Bosco street and followed that street all the way to the entrance. Sure, this is the same road that cars take, but since I started so early there were hardly any cars and actually a couple of people were going for their morning walk. I want to say it took me around 40 minutes to get up the road to the entrance from Amargura /Saphi streets intersection (but I was jogging parts of it – and it was a tough jog). It opens at 7AM.It costs 70 Sol to get in and you could take multiple marked trails. I took the 45 minute trail. There are folks asking if you want a guide, but I didn’t get one. I just wanted to be there and think that this is the same spot where the Incas battled the Spaniards. It’s a little hard to think about that at the Plaza de Armas (another location where they fought) when there is a KFC and McDonalds there, but at Saqsaywaman, it’s just the land and what’s leftover. And a great view of the city. I also ran into either Lamas or Alpacas grazing.

Worth the stop. Great site lose to cusco. A perfect entry into the inca culture.
If going to the sacred valley, it is the first stop leaving cusco

Interesting site, amazing views. A great site and a great way to get a sense of history. Take a trip with a guide unless you have a really good sense of history/culture, or you will miss out. The sites were incredible. Bring a jacket - it gets cold up there.

Worth the short (sometimes steep) hike. Instead of taking one of the many city tours on offer, we opted to hike up to Sacsayhuaman. The walk took less than the advertised 45 minutes and was a great way to see more of the city. You buy tickets at a booth about half the way there and hike up the rest of the way to the archaeological site. We were easily able to find a guide to provide a tour when we reached the site. The site itself was fascinating – the immense stones are quite the contrast to the construction at sites like Machu Picchu.

An extraordinary Inka site. This is an amazing place with so much history. Our guide, Danny, did a really good job explaining the site's finer points and there was a serene atmosphere about the place.
Worth the climb, gorgeous views of Cuzco. Worth the climb, spent all day there but I am a mad history buff and had a personal guide. you can cover it in 2-3 hours if you want a quick look

Very Cool. We didn't get to spend too much time here, but the hour wed did was well worth the visit. The ruins are awesome and the site was definitely one of the best we saw. It was huge and had some great photo ops. We purchased a city pass and this was one of the attraction it covered.

A true enigma. Unfortunately, we were only able to see Sacsayhuaman from the comfort of our tour bus. However, we were still able to see from afar how tremendous this place is. The massive and huge boulders here has a history all by itself. Worth a visit next time around

Good local stop. Get a taxi from Cusco and end your ruins tour here. It is the biggest and has the best views. One taxi driver will stay with you for the 4 sites for 100 soles. Do not miss the catacombs in the front of the site and the amazing views of Cusco at the lookout point.
Great Ruins. Besides being greeted by numerous Llamas, this is an impressive ruin site. Definitely worth the visit. You can't help but be in awe of what the Incas built.

Spread over a large area.. This was part of our introduction tour to Cuzco. It is worth a visit. Set high above Cuzco, this park covers a vast area. It is not overly commercilaised. As the first visiting point at high altitude, getting up and down the mounds in the area can be hard work. If we were at home this would not be a problem.An amazing introduction to Inca construction although most has been removed. Most of the retaining walls are huge boulders beautifuly made to fit. Llamas roam the grounds and make an interesting feature in the park. A path leads all the way back to the city quite a distance below.

Great walls & amazing view to Cusco. Great place to visit and very close to Cusco. This is the most strategic Incas building where you can see a panoramic view of Cusco city. It was built with zigzag walls, representing lightnings.

Accessible and Impressive. This is an expansive area in the hills above Cusco where you can wander throuh the Aztec ruins. They are quite impressive, even though the Spanish dismantled a lot of of the buildings to construction in town below. The main limitation is that there is no guidebook or interpretative signs to explain anything. We were willing to pay a guide, but there were none available.
dizzy views; dizzy altitude. excellent location to wander round, although altitude can make it very hard work. great warm up for machhu pichhu

Sexy Woman. This place is awesome, it is as if you are on the top of the World, you can see the city of Cusco and it is beautiful.Magical place indeed,those Inca people are genius,how did they manage to build this boulders of rocks is unimaginable.

Altitude makes every step a little more challenging. Relatively easy to get to from Cusco, take a taxi up and then walk downfrom Saqsaywaman. It's a beautiful, serene place. Interesting to see how the rocks held together despite not using any mortar or clay, etc. Amazing feat. Didn't quite like that there were locals in traditional costume with their babies and llama trying to charge you for a photo. Other than that, enjoyable walk. Do take a slow walk - lots of water and pauses to take photos.

Just how did they build it?. Impressive site with huge rock walls and terraces right outside of Cusco. Massive rocks over 130 tons tightly fitted to make sections of walls in this ceremonial center. You will appreciate just how clever this ancient civilization was. At one side on top of site is a great viewpoint of the city of Cusco.

Monkey Fist!. We loved our visit to Sacsayhuaman! It's a fun side-trip with wide-open spaces and not a lot of tourist density-- a nice change of pace. Doesn't require a long visit, but definitely worth a stop!

Worth a walk from cusco.... We were there just before rain, and it was a sight to see the dark clouds just above the green ruins... And we walked our way back to cusco, and it was a pretty sight to see the city from top...

Worth a visit.. not much hiking, but there's a spot when you can look over Cusco and take some very good pictures, also a nice breeze was moving fresh mountain air. Impressive Incan architecture, with the traditional massive boulders.

Inca Stonehenge on a massive scale. Breath-taking remains of a huge Inca construction on the outskirts of Cusco. Huge stones have been transported long distances to build the site and were carefully and skillfully inter-locked.

Great location for a day trip. Very much worth the 70 soles to enter the site. If you don't have time to go to the sacred valley, this is a good alternative. The ruins were beautiful. Suggestion to folks planning a trip here - might be a good idea to hire a local tour guide. I think we missed a lot of the details without a guide.

Impressive historic site!. Built on a hill overlooking Cusco, Sacsayhuaman is famous for its huge carved stones. some are over 30 feet high.Lots of walking and very windy. Go with a guide or on a tour to maximize the experience.

Part of City Tour. This was one of four Inca temples we visited with our City Tour. Unfortunately we visited this site after Machu Picchu and I would recommend seeing Machu Picchu last as it makes all others seem rather plain. It is, however, a great complement to better understanding the workings of the Inca when combined with all the other temple/city tours.
Good to know the inca history. It's wonderful, but you should do it with a local guide. Otherwise, it's just a bunch of old ruins. No bathrooms inside.
Amazing Inca Ruins. You'll marvel at the size of the stones the Incas used to build this place, some as heavy as 30 tons.

An amazing Inka site close to Cusco.. This site is enormous and one wonders how humans have ever been able to put those enormous stones in place, so that the walls look absolutely perfect and no earthquake can move them!

Amazing views and architecture. My husband and I had planned to visit Saqsayhuaman because it was close to our hotel, and it exceeded our expectations. The size of the grounds and the size of the rocks that compose the site are astounding, and the views of Cusco from Saqsayhuaman are amazing. You can take a self-guided tour, and you'll likely spend 1-2 hours there depending on how much ground you cover. I highly recommend exploring this historical site.

Impressive Size, Impressive Views. This is an impressive sight, but among so many impressive sights in Peru, it can't take first place. However, I would highly recommend a visit to this site. It is impressive in its scope, with terraced areas surrounding a huge, flat plains area that is at least large enough to contain 6 football fields. It is also a site where some of the largest stones known to be moved by humans are part of the structure. The largest one is estimated to be over 400 tons. The view from its highest point provides a vast panorama of Cusco.

Must See in Cusco. This is one of the closer attraction from Cusco. We traveled by car that was arranged by the hotel. Our driver introduced us to a tour guide when we arrived. It's a big attraction with large grass fields and buildings. It's up in the hills over looking Cusco. There are a few large Inca structures there built with large stones. Like most Peru attractions, the place is keep clean and organize. It's a must see attraction if you're in Cusco.

Make sure you go with a guide. Really enjoyed the day, I went with the walking tour, it cost 60 soles and lasted 5 hours. We were in Sacsayhuaman for probably a hour. Our guide was really informative and the site is incredible. It was really easy to imagine it in its former glory.

Beautiful and amazing site. It's right by the city center and super easy to get to. If you're doing the Inca hike, i highly recommend you spend a day or do doing easy hikes/ day tours like this to get used to the air.
Once you're there the view is breath taking.

Impressive. This ruin is only 20% of the original builing complex but it is still quite stunning what the Inkas were able to do. The view on Cusco is great and when u walk to the other side there are stone slides.

Great day trip from Cusco. Slightly hard to get to but well worth the effort. I suggest hiring a taxi for the afternoon and take in all four ruins that encompass the Sacsayhuaman site. Start at the top of the mountain and work your way down. I suppose it is possible to walk down once you arrive at the top but i do not suggest it. The taxi is not expensive and most of the drivers will know exactly what you want to do. Your hotel can arrange it.

Highlight of Cusco. Jokingly referred to as Sexy Woman (the closest phonetic was to pronounce Sacsayhuaman with a dash of fun thrown in) this is an absolutely stunning and definite must-see destination while in Cusco. Best to go with a guide to show you some of the more 'secretive' areas to visit at the site and to provide you with amazing stories that will blow your mind (using only stone to cut stone and without the use of modern transport and measuring tools, the Inca moved 2000-tonne boulders more than ten kilometres and cut these rocks so precisely you cannot slip a dollar bill between the rocks -- that do not have mortar between them -- hundreds of years later). Don't forget your camera: best views of Cusco there is and very tame (and photogenic) llamas!

Great place!. We did a self guided tour here and had a lovely afternoon! We took a taxi from Cusco as it was our first full day at that altitude and did not want to over do it. Totally worth the small fee for the taxi. A great first day activity while we were getting used to the altitude! Only complaint was that we could not pay for just this attraction but had to buy a pass getting us into 4 attractions, some of which we were not planning to use. So it turned out to be expensive for a single afternoon.
Sacsayhuaman - a must. An absolute must while in Cusco. Make sure you have a guide, they are inexpensive and make all the difference.

Take a tour!. Wonder place to visit. Highly recommend a bus tour to get the history. Never did that before, but was pleasantly surprised with the quality of the Peruvian woman's English and sense of humor. Great sunny day when we went.
several thousand feet above sea level.. Strange name ( Sassy woman). High altitude, lovely surrounding Andes Mountains. Interesting history related by guides.
A must see when your in Cusco region. Great venue. Allow yourself a minimum of 2-3 hours here. There is lots to see and lots of climbing stairs.
Amazing view. Beautiful ruins with an interesting history. It's a long and heavy walk though but it was well worth it to see the amazing view of Cusco.

Worthwhile trip, but spring for a guide. Certainly a must see for any Cusco/ Sacred Valley trip. The stone works are impressive. Strongly recommend spending $40-50USD for a guide. There is very limited signage and nothing in English and our guidebook only summarized the site. Having a local guide dramatically increased our appreciation of the site and history.

There is a lot more to Sacsayhuaman than the inexperienced eye can see.... An enormous Inca Ruin which overlooks Cuzco and the Sacred Valley. A good guide can describe how the huge stones were placed together (without mortar). There are reasons for specific surfaces and zig-zag walls. You can also see the Cristo Blanco (White Christ) in the distance. This site is fascinating, educational and beautiful.

Worth a visit.. Our first look at these huge limestones which you can't imagine them being moved and placed. Built in the 1500 's and watched the Alpacas and Lamas wondering around as though it was untouched.

good sight seeing. As with most sights of Incas, the real purpose of this attraction is known .Different versions from a incomplete fort to a fort destroyed by Spaniard's. The huge rocks are absolutely magnificent , and to imagine them being rolled down the point and the put tighter is mind boggling.

Interesting architectural example of Inca skill. Enjoyed our trip here. Beautiful panoramic vista and interesting examples of how clever the Inca's were. Incredible stonework. Also went to an Alpaca factory. Beautiful handmade baby alpaca sweaters.
Great views. We visited this spot after being in Machu Picchu, so it didn't appear that impressive to us. You get a great view of Cusco from the site.

Feel the energy!. visit the moon temple in the back of the ruins and meditate for 10 mins......I was able to feel the energy there...it was very peaceful and relaxing. the interesting thing I learned from the local is that when you whistle form one end of the temple it echos on the other end and this was used for communication during Inca days ;)

Most important Inca ruins, only comparable to Machupichu. This is the most important and fantastic Inca ruin. Only Machupichu can match with this ruin. Considering the size of stone and the quality of stone work, I am sure that it was more important site to Inca people than the Machupichu. It is shame, spanish conquerors had destroyed most of it, and had used stones from this site to build their own buildings. When you visit this ruins, you should take at least two hours and you should also climb small hills in the opposite side of huge stone architecture.
Lovely but crowded. Sacsayhuaman is lovely but like many of the better known sites, too crowded. Much of it is current roped off for excavation/restoration.

Impressive site. One of the most stunning Inca sites. This was a ceremonial site used as a fortress by Manco Inca during the siege of Cusco and the site of a decisive battle. The massive stones used in its construction are truly amazing; moved here without the use of wheels and cut to perfection using stone and bronze tools. Amazing!

A 'must see' when in Cusco. Did lots of touristy things when in Cusco, this is at the top of my must see list. It has amazing architecture and left me wondering yet again, just how did they construct this? We had a guide which was worth it, to get an understanding of how it was believed to have been built.It has amazing views of Cusco city

Impressive!. This is one of the must see sites while in Cusco. The place is quite impressive, massive rock formations and its place in Incan history . Its location provides a good view of the city of Cusco below.

Missing some descriptions. Nice place however lacking any comments or description. Just a number of huge stone blocks if you are not prepared theoretically or not having a guide. Nevertheless making a big impression.

Cusco's Archaeological Treasure. Cusco's Archaeological Treasure is found at Sacsayhuaman. These were ruins of a fortress/hideout that was built by the ancient tribes as defences against Spanish before the town of Cusco was built. You will see many ruins and stones that were used as part of the "cementless" structure. The view of Cusco from high above is super spectacular! So beautiful that I spend almost an hour taking photographs! There is usually a few locals with one or two condors - so there is a minor degree of wildlife on display. Definitely for me, this was the highlight of Cusco!

Impressive place in Cusco. We had one full day of visit in Cusco and started with this amazing place! You overlook the city and can clearly understand why the incas picked this place for their celebrations. You feel so small and in awe before what they built many centuries ago. To think that they moved these granite rocks of several tons without any of our modern tools... Truly an amazing place and an amazing civilisation.

A must for anyone visiting Cusco!. I am glad I decided to go here in the limited time I had in Cusco. Me and my friends just took a taxi from Plaza de Armas and were excited to find a free english speaking guide who was trying to brush up his english. He was great and explained us all the amazing history of this place. Pictures turned out great, you get few great views of the entire city so make sure you go on a clear sunny day to get some nice pictures. This place takes few hours if you want to walk around the whole thing so wear comfy shoes and stay hydrated. You will also be greeted by a couple of alpacas!
Don't use bus tour. I took a bus tour booked on the street and it was very quick - no real history was given - left to roam around with no explanations of the site.

Good view over Cusco. I wasn't particularly impressed with Sacsayhuaman, the statue wasn't as impressive as some of the statues of Christ that I've seen in South America and it was a bit dirty up there (rubbish and what I think was dog dirt!). The best bit of this place is the view over the city which is pretty good,
Amazing enginering!. A great place to see the amazing engineering feats of ancients. Get there early for less people (though there's plenty of room). Great views of the valley...

Favorite excursion in Cusco. This was our favorite and most interesting attraction in Cucso. We hired a guide (which you can bargain with at entrance) and it was worth every penny. Guide provided interesting history and points of interest. This was an amazing place. This should be put on the top of your list for Cusco!
Perfect example of Incan architecture. Terrific example of Incan ingenuity. Close to the city, and easy walking. If you only get to see one Incan ruin in Cusco, see this one.

Top attraction in Cusco. This was our favorite attraction in Cusco. While the churches in the plazas were pretty, the fact that they were built by the Spanish over previous Inca sites detracted from them. This is the best place to see Inca remains in the city. It is very mysterious how they got all those giant rocks up the hill and had them fit so tightly together. The views of the city are spectacular. The hike up was pretty steep but definitely worth it to see the ruins and city views.

Sacsayhuaman - A good example of Incan Architecture. The nearest translation to this is Sexy Woman :-) We did this as part of a morning trip before going to Pisac market. The Inca stones are amazing, and a testament to their architectural/engineering skills - a little more time there would have been great. Amazing view of Cusco from here too.

Visit in the morning to avoid the crowds. We took a taxi to the ruins mid-afternoon and found the ruins to be extremely busy with tourists. We were mobbed by ladies at the entrance trying to sell us scarves, jewellery, etc. English speaking Guides were available but we did not use one.It was difficult to move through some sections of the ruins due to the crowds. The ruins themselves are worth visiting and like the many other ruins we visited in Peru they were unique in many ways.We were at the ruins for about 90 minutes and managed to get around the entire site.It's an easy down hill walk (with plenty of steps) back to Cusco centre. It took us about 20 minutes to walk from the ruins to the Plaza de Arms.
Must Go. Must Go - the stone work is incredible and history is fascinating. We bought the pass for all of the locations around Cusco and did most of them.

Interesting site. Sacsayhuaman consists of three terraces made of huge blocks of granite; it's an interesting ruin and a good example of Inca military architecture. None of the stones have any fixing cement; yet there are no visible gaps between them. Just to stand in front of the massive stones gives you a real insight in to just how difficult and how much intensive man power must have had to be used to make this construction. There is a doorway in the structure and the steps aren't too steep and it's easy to climb up to each level. It's well worth a visit; relatively close to the centre of Cusco and whilst there you have an opportunity to see the statue of the White Christ which is very close by.

How did they build it?!. Absolutely beautiful Inca, or pre Inca, as some believe, site. Using a guide is great (if a guide is good, ours was brilliant) as otherwise you won't know where and what you are looking at, even if you are a history nerd like me. Makes you wonder:) One of the most interesting sites I've seen in Peru.Very nice views of Cusco as well.

More Inca ruins and beautiful view of the city. This was the last of our Inca ruins since we had been to Machu Picchu and Ollantaytambo already (we left Cusco for last.) The guide we hired at the site was pretty mediocre and her english was extremely hard to understand. I would recommend hiring a guide ahead of time at any Inca ruin site - and I especially wish we had done so for this one. The one special thing about this site is the magnificent view you get looking down at the city of Cusco and it is worth going here just for that alone (even if you are Inca ruin jaded as we were a bit.) Also you can walk from the top of Sacsayhuaman over to the "Cristo Blanco" (White Christ statue) and that is also a must see. These ruins are definitely magnificent and impressive and somewhat unusual in their zigzag formation. Try to go on a clear day for the best views of the city below.
Very interesting!. If you're in Cusco don't miss this place. Here are so many Inca ruins around and this one is excellent.

Use the guides. Great afternoon: Take a 10 soles (approx $3) taxi ride to Sacsayhuaman. Entrance costs 70 soles. The English speaking guides walk up and ask if you want a tour for appox 1 hour for 50 soles. Its worth it, they are super knowledgable and help you understand what you are seeing because otherwise it just looks like a bunch of big rocks. After the tour, take the walk down to center city. The views are beautiful, its free and you walk on mostly a pedestrian only street. Only takes 25min to walk at a slow pace back to the Plaza de Armas. Then grab lunch on one of the terraces overlooking the Plaza. Perfect afternoon.

beautiful inca wall but do not visit in afternoon in high season... We made this mistake, and had a guided tour, but there where so many (mainly peruvian who get discount) people that it was like a circus attraction.It was not possible to take in the right atmosphere.Everywhere people where posing against the walls.Nice inca architecture though, but next time we visit in the morning.We got a 2 day boleteo touristico which was not good for this site (only for the cusco city tour...) so we had to pay the extra 70 soles a person for a day visit, a ripp off.

Historical Drought. Apparently this is an interesting Incan ruin. I don't know how people find out anything about it because no information leaflet is given to you at the site. Perhaps it is a way of forcing you to get a guide but when you're on a tight budget and have already paid for a 10 day bolletico touristico there's very little money left over for guided tours. The site offered beautiful views of Cusco and the architecture of the site was amazing but its relevance or importance was completely lost on my friends and I as we blundered through the site without any idea of what we were looking at. Definitely room for improvement in order to make this an interesting attraction worth visiting.

Must do!. You wouldn't visit Cusco unless you're interested in exploring Inca history/ ruins... and this is a great place to begin. It would be pointless to go without a guide who can actually explain what you're looking at. Really close to Cusco town, with great views over the city.

Incredible Inca ruins with amazing history!. If you are following the Inca ruins through Peru you can't miss this one. Make sure you get a guide we had Elvis Chahuara from Gate 1. To hear where the name and reference to the "fat eagle" were amazing. Whether you are an admirer of complicated construction with simple technology student of Incan history or an Ancient aliens fan you have to see these precision built structure of immense stones and picture the battle that ensued there resulting in the fat Eagles

A must if in Cusco. This site should be part of any trio to Cusco. Although there remains considerable debate as to who and when actually constructed this site, and what its true purpose was, its magnificence can't be appreciated in pictures. STRONGLY recommend it be seen with a knowledgeable tour guide. We used David Tours with Fernando as our guide - he was simply superb!

Warm up to Machu Picchu. Strongly recommend visiting this site with a guide to learn about Inca construction and symbols. It is a great way to prepare for the much larger sites of Ollantaytambo and Machu Picchu.

Jaw Dropping. this place is amazing, how did the Incas with so little by way of tools get this massive boulders and shapes so tightly together. A testament to ingenuity, spend time with the family spotting the various animal forms.
peru trip. impressive ruins from inca period,smaller scale than Machu Pichu close to city,easy access.,beutiful view

Good ruins near Cusco. Fascinating historic site with huge stones and interesting lightning bolt shape. Important to go with a guide who can explain the significance of what you are seeing. Only 15 minutes from town.
