Most impressive of the 4 ruins close to Cusco. To be honest, I was going to skip all the ruins close to Cusco as we were going to do all the ruins in Pisac, Ollanta and MP anyway, but after finally deciding to get the Boleto Touristico (which, might i add, is a huge tourist rip off), we decided to do it as a day tour for 40 soles per person. 6 euros for a half day tour...cannot really complain. This site was definitely the most impressive and we enjoyed the views from up top and getting a brief history lesson on how the Incas put the place together.
Interesting Inca site. Wonderful example of Inca architecture in one of their important palaces. Not as impressive as Machu Picchu or Olantaytambo but worth a visit.

Incan marvel. Had a private tour with Richard Ccahua of Sungate Tours. He is a local and really knows a lot about this amazing site. How the Inca fit the giant stones together is a mystery. But it is totally worthwhile visiting.
Great pre-cursor to Machu Picchu. A must see in Cusco! Had a great guide from Sungate Tours as well which really made for a special afternoon!

Incan ruins that are well worth the visit.. The site is filled with giant examples of how precise the Incans built their important and sacred structures.Huge stones fit together with barely a crack between them.
Going up to the top of Sacsayhuaman gave you a brilliant view of Cusco.

Cusco's main Inca place - must see!. A must see. Stunningly large Inca fortress, right above Cusco. Take a taxi up (maybe to the QenQo, which is only a few hundred yards further uphill) and walk back, through San Blas, to Cusco. Great views, road in good condition. Do not try to walk the other way (UP) unless you are very fit. Hard to imagine how 10.000 Inca's lost this fortress against 1000 Spanish..... No steel swords and armour must be the answer, but still.
Awesome . What a great place !! Just a nice walk from Cuzco to admire this amazing example of powerful of the past.

Great way to spend an afternoon. This is a great place to spend a sunny afternoon. It offers great views of Cusco, the mountains and the former Inca fortress. It can be reached from Plaza de Armas by taxi 10 soles, or by foot (20 minutes).

Lovely afternoon in Cuzco. My first ruins on this trip. Commanding view over the city. A lovely afternoon. Wasn't too busy when I went. There were guides if you wanted them but if you wanted to wander on your own you were free to do so. I walked up from Plaza de Armas but a taxi would have been a sensible idea
Amazing complement to Machu Picchu . Well worth the visit, if recommend taking a cab to the furthest ruin and walking to the others, ending with this one. Made for a fantastic afternoon.

Great Inca Introduction. Well worth the short taxi ride (or hike up for the more adventurous) to get oriented to the wonders of the Inka/Inca. Hired a certified, official guide at the beginning (Carmen) who was excellent. Great explanations that she supplemented with explanations and illustrations in reference books.
Another incredible Inca structure. Amazing structure and well worth the visit up another 300 metres or so. Brilliant view of the city and surrounds.
Simply amazing. A place to go if you are in Cuzco. Worth to have a guide to explain the place and the possible uses of it.

Special site near Cusco. Visited as part of a tour from Cusco, wow! a very interesting sited with ruins. Part of a series of sites, buy your ticket for the local cusco area or an expanded one . Really enjoyed our visit!

Worth a trip but expensive entrance fee.. If you're staying in the city, trying walking to Sacsyhuaman instead of taking a bus/taxi/car or a tour. The exercise will help you acclimate to Cusco's elevation and it's great exercise. We went up a series of steps and then walked up a winding road to find a church where we met a guide that took us horseback riding. He took us behind Sacsayhuaman into the valley and advised us we could go in the back entrance for free. This isn't true - if you want to see the ruins, you'll have to get a tourist ticket for 70 soles ( $23) to go in and explore the ruins. There is an attendant stationed by the entrance checking tickets. There are some llamas grazing and the ruins are impressive. You can hike up and see the Cristo Blanco for free, but otherwise you can pay or walk back down the road leading to Cusco.

Miracle stone masonry?. This is a must see sight. The unbelievable precise huge walls makes you thin, how possibly anybody carved those 100's of tonnes rocks and matched them to each other. By ancient chisels???...

Great ruin to visit in a couple of hours. This is a nice, interesting ruin on the outskirts of Cusco. You can spend a couple of leisurely hours walking around. I highly recommend getting a guide at the entrance -- they are not expensive and give you a much better idea of what used to be there.

Amazing architecture. We traveled with REI adventures. We spent a couple of ours just walking around. I was amazed at the architecture and the way the stones meshed together so tight you couldn't even get a blade of grass between them. I was in awe of what the people centuries ago were able to accomplish. Wish I had brought my hiking stick. It would have made the stairs easier.

A Cusco MUST-SEE!. This is an amazing structure, that must be seen in person to believe and appreciate! Don't miss it when in the Cusco area. We and our kids loved climbing and wandering around in amazement. The view of Cusco from up top is beautiful.

worth visiting.. I didn't actually pay for the entry price, but my car drivers stopped and I walked along the road. Lovely views of the city. The ruins looked great also. I would recommended doing drive/walk if you don't have much time or don't care about selfie's..:)
Sacsayhuaman. Our tour was very well done. The guide had prepared charts to illustrate points of interest and explain the ancient culture. The sites were amazing!

By far my #1 spot at Cusco. Such a beautiful site, so close to the city! Situated on the top of a hill, about a kilometre from the Plaza de Armas, Sacsayhuaman is a must-visit place, to admire the inca sense of scale and architecture. The reward for hiking up the hill is the gorgeous views of the city, and the mountains beyond. This site is a good prep before going to Machu Picchu, especially because it has a fraction of the visitors and you can linger longer. There are more alpacas to get up close and personal with. Though there are only walls left in the ruins, what walls they are! At the lowest level, the stone boulders are enormous, and you wonder how they pushed them up and placed them exactly so. The tourist agencies advertise this place as "sexy woman" to make it easier to pronounce.

Awesome way to spend time in Cusco. Really great place to see, you may want to get a guide, we just took a cheap taxi up there and walked back down to the main square which was very cool! Incredible ruins!

Unbelievable place!. I was so amazed on the grandeur of this place that I will never forget it! I was surprised by the huge stones and the precision of the building. How was this possible without technology? It is well worth spending many hours walking around it!
don't miss this ruin close to cusco. It's so impressive to see this massive ruin so close to Cusco's centre. llamas run free here and the photo opportunities are endless
Definitely worth a visit to the ruins.. These ruins are amazing. To see the size of the rocks and the architecture was truly a very special experience.
Fascinating. As it's easy to get to and very different from other ruins, I recommend it. Despite the guide saying the main area would take an hour, we were done in 35 minutes.

Fantastic historical site. Very cool site. It was PACKED solidly during Inti Raymi, but the rest of the time, it's pretty easy to access. Would very highly recommend visiting during your time in Cusco

Impressive.. I actually visited the ruins twice. The first time I got to see the ruins proper, the huge stones and natural rock slides made for impressive viewing. The top of the ruins also provides great panoramic views of Cusco. Entry is via Boletto touristico only which is something of a pain. The ticket is 120 sole and covers a bunch of attractions around Cusco and is valid for a couple of weeks; or you can get a partial ticket for 70 soles covering a specific four attractions for one day only. If you only wish to see one or two attractions this proves needlessly expensive. I purchased a day ticket to see the four ruins close to Cusco, Sacsayhuaman being one, and it turned out it was actually possible for me to gain access to all four sites without my ticket being checked... somewhat frustrating. That being said the site is remarkable and the second time I saw it was for the Inti Raymi celebrations; crowds of people, and largely local too flocking to see the dances and re-enactments. Set against the stony backdrop of the ruins. If you can visit during the festival do it, it's also free, don't let the tourist offices trick you into believing you need a ticket to see Inti Raymi.
Don't Forget!. Super hot during the day and frightening cold at night. Bring even amount of summer and winter clothing. A lot of walking!!

Well worth a morning. These are some terribly interesting ruins. They give you a sense for the history of Cusco as the capital of the Inca empire. To see the whole circuit, just take the public buses. Each ride is a single Sol. Guides can be hit or miss. Best practice is to catch one that is finishing up with a small group and make sure they were satisfied. Also, not to be sexist, but the women guides seem to be more interested in making sure you enjoy the tour.

No reason not to go if you are in Cusco!. It is no Machu Picchu but Sacsayhuaman is a really cool place that is easy to get to in Cusco. The more I walked around the ruins the more it grew on me. You can buy a pass for multiple ruins for 130 soles I believe or the day pass is 70 soles.

Very interesting site--if you have a way to get the distance from town. This is an Inca fortress or temple (not certain) with interesting features. It is on fairly flat ground and so easy for those with knee or hip issues to see.

Awesome natural stone slides and fantastic stone work. I almost gave Sacsayhuaman 4 stars because it just isn't as spectactular as Machu Picchu, but is still amazing for what it is. We were fascinated/shocked by how GIANT stones were brought to this site to build Sacsayhuaman. We were with Peruvian friends who told us about the site, and they turned down the people who offered to be our guides. Our friends question the accuracy of the guides. There are the coolest natural stone formation slides. It was fun to slide down them and watch others go down the slides.

best of 4 Inca ruinas close by Cusco. If in Cusco visit this ruinas close by. There are three other ruinas on which we spoiled time and enerlgy which were relatively useless. This one was good! If you have more time go to Pisac, Some 45 -60 minutes drive for a great Inca town

Ancient ruin. Was probably the most impressive Inca construction until destroyed by the Spanish with many of the stones used in building the cathedral. Worth a visit to get an idea of the scale of construction in Pre-Columbian Peru. The views over Cusco are excellent.

Walk up early morning. A good introduction to Inca sites and just a 15-20 minute (uphill) walk from the main square. Helps with acclimatising. 70 soles entrance fee is well worth it. The interpretation boards are at the far end of the site where the bus stop entrance is.The tiers of jagged terraces (representing a puma's teeth) are impressive and accessible
Worth the walk up the hill from Cusco.. My son, husband and I also hiked the Inca Trail and as other reviewers have said, Sacsayhuaman was impressive and worth the visit.

Spend a day exploring the stonework!. I recommend hiking up to the top (instead of taking a bus) of Sacsayhuaman and exploring the stonework. Leave yourself time to take the side trail near the huge Jesus statue past the Llama pasture. We were there for Inti Raymi and went up a few days before to check out the place before the festival began. Despite all the people, it still felt intimate and awe inspiring. There are bathrooms at the top, but be sure to bring water. If you plan to visit several attractions in the area and around the sacred valley buy the general ticket touristico at the visitors center in Cousco and it will be less expansive than buying from shops, hostels, or the attractions themselves.

Such a surprise, make time to visit. We took a taxi there and walked back still buzzing with the place.The size of the blocks and arrangement is awesome, but look for the ariel view it shows how intricate the layout is, one can only be impressed with this construction.As a bonus it provides one of the best views of the city.

Expensive. When I lived in Cuzco 13 years ago Sacsayhuaman used to be free on a Sunday. It's now s/70 and since I'm over 25, I can't get the reduced student rate of s/40. I can't imagine anywhere else in the world where it would be possible to charge so much money to access a heritage site, especially given the cost relative to local wages.
Impressive stonework. Not as impressive as Ollantaytambo, but still - Incan stonework at a glance. A pleasant half-day walk.

Worth the Visit....Take a Guide if Possible.. Sacsayhuaman was well worth the visit... stone walls are amazing and the history of the place is even better. I do believe that you get more out of it if you take a guide so you they can explain all of the history to you.
Wear good shoes... We wore hiking boots

Nice place to visit. Big Inca complex, nice to visit, even if you also visit Machu Picchu, Ollantaytambo and/or Pisac. Great view over Cusco with good view of the Plaza de Armas.
Entrance is only possible with the 'Boleto', which is rather expensive for foreigners (125 soles), but will also give access to other sites, mainly in the sacred valley.
Beautiful. Beautiful and I dare day more spiritual than Machu Picchu. Absolutely amazing how they moved those stones. Did I mention the free roaming llamas?

Spectacular Place!. As an archaeologist, I can say that the preservation of the Inca architecture is simply beyond amazing. The megalithic architecture is simply magnificent. You will really appreciate this one! It is an absolute must see. A trip of a lifetime! Highly recommend!

The structures used to be 3 meters higher.... First trip had no guide. Second trip, we ended up on a tour...learned a lot! Appreciated even more. Spaniards tore down much of what had been there to build their churches. Sacred site, amazing...
Just make sure that the tour doesn't leave you at the last stop...walking down in the dark is dangerous.

How did they do it?. A mystery, extraordinary place, where you have a hundreds of tons big rocks put together making a some kind of fortress. Inca´s unbelievable technique by only putting the polished rocks on each other is fabulous. For me the second best and the second landscape to go in traces of incas right after Machu Picchu.

Great place to spend an afternoon. Machu Picchu is good, but I like this place even better. The walls are so intricate for being made from gigantic stones. Bring a book or a D about the history of the Incas and spend the afternoon here learning about their unique legends and history.
A Good Hike. The hike up to Sacsayhuaman is well worth the effort. It only takes about 25 minutes from the center of Cusco and is a very interesting place.

Learning about the Incas. Lots of walking. Make sure you wear comfortable shoes. Bring water. Depending on when you go bring clothes that can be layered. I had a sweater that morning but all the walking got me warm and I ended up just leaving a short sleeve on. It's a beautiful place.
Impressive site. The ability to move large rocks long distances is beyond belief. This site is important to visit, and expensive compared to other sites.

Slides and Jumps over Cusco at Sacsayhuaman. We hiked up and wandered around the area and had a blast going down the Inca slides as well as climbing through the cave area to the open stadium. We also used the stumps that overlooked Cusco to get some jumping pictures over Cusco

Not in the league of Machu Picchu. We visited Sacsayhuaman after visiting Qorikancha and Machu Picchu and hence may be didn't find it extraordinary. The structure is grand with some huge rocks which really make you wonder how they did it back then. Some rocks weigh several tons. The most interesting part about all Inca construction is the technique they employed to construct these structures without using mortar and ensuring that the buildings withstood multiple earthquakes.PS: PLS SELECT AN ACCREDITED GUIDE AS THERE ARE MANY PEOPLE STANDING AT THE ENTRANCE OFFERING THEIR SERVICES BUT AREN'T UP TO STANDARDS.We got tricked into selecting one with little knowledge and that too may have been a reason we didn't find Sacsayhuaman outstanding.
Worth the walk. This is a ,just see place, you can take a taxi there and walk back to town, beautiful place, your visit would not be complete if you don't go the Sacsayhuaman!

Visit to Sacsayhuaman. Impressive Inka fortress/temple built out of gigantic rocks , overlooking the city of Cuzco , Peru. The rock are fit perfectly like a jigsaw puzzle and one can't imagine how they were put together. It looks supernatural.

A great historical tour as well as viewpoint for Cuzco. This was an interesting excavation, with an excellent view overlooking Cuzco. Since Cuzco was built in the shape of a puma, "Sexy Human" was its head.
beautiful. Helpful to have a tour guide, but this place is phenomenal. Don't forget to check out the natural stone slides on the backside of the mountain.

First things to do when you arrive to Cusco. Just the day after you arrive to cusco, you should visit Sacsayhuaman, it's only 30min walk from the main square. Is really safe going there walking during the day.
Impressive ruins. Impressive Inka's ruins closed to Cusco. Definitely, you need a guide to learn about the details. It offers a great panoramic view of Cusco

An Inca fortress, easily accessible.. A fairly easy walk to see the brilliance of the structures with stone so strategically placed and expertly built by the Incas. Amazing to see one stone weighing 155,000 tons!

Sacsayhuaman: Locals pronounce it "sexy woman!". As we learned from our tour guide, Cuzco was the center of the Inca Empire. (Machu Picchu was a religious and scientific outpost.) And Sacsayhuaman was the cultural center of Cuzco. That makes Sacsayhuaman the #1 most important tourist site in Cuzco, at least in my mind! It is located on the edge of the city and requires a taxi, bus, or tour to get there. I strongly recommend getting a tour guide, as there is only one interpretive sign on the entire site, located at the ticket office. Without a tour guide, you will just be wandering around a pile of rocks without understanding their importance. We hired a driver through our hotel's front desk, who drove us to Sacsayhuaman, where we purchased a "partial ticket" that gave us access to four adjacent Inca sites north of town. (A "full ticket" gives you access to 16 historical sites across the region, which is too much for most tourists.) The hotel promised us that we could easily pick up an English-speaking tour guide at Sacsayhuaman who could then guide us through all four sites. Not so easy! We waited more than one hour for an English-speaking guide to show up. The guide was quite good, but he charged us double the amount the hotel said it should cost.

The most astonishing place I been. The Nature and the construction on the mountain hill, is super good, how Sacsayhuaman is made, above Cuzco, walking and touching the stones is like returning to old times, this place is part of the city tour of Cusco.

Amazing first taste of the Inca Empire grandeur. This place just North of Cusco (walking distance but uphill-mind the altitude) humbles you. The mere size of the rocks! Nobody knows how they were transported to the site since the Incas had no horses and didn't use the wheel. It's perfect a vertical puzzle, an amazing example of human will, faith and hard work but also of human greed... the Spanish Conquest wrecked the citadel and the walls, stairs and rock slides remain because they just couldn't move them. A must in your Cuzco/ Machu-Picchu trip. Just a taste of what's to come in this breathtaking part of the World.
Good Example of The Temples. This is a great space to simply see the complexity of the stone work and the vastness of the work. It is amazing. It is an easier walk than some of the ruins.
Worth a visit. Neat, but don't go out of your way to see it. The view from the top of the city below is very cool and the climb isn't bad at all. But if you skip it you won't regret it either.

Very beautiful and impressive. A must see next to Cusco - we took a taxi up to the site. The size of the stones and their arrangements were impressive. Please note - bring water and snacks as there are no places to buy it up there!

overwhelming. Only about 20% of this amazing Inca temple is still visible. Nearly all the movable stones were used by the Spanish conquerors (and the Peruvians after independence) to build Cusco. What remains is massive and a wonderful introduction to the skill of Incan stonemasons.

Vacations at Cusco. Excellent and beautiful place to learn about the history of the Inca and the Spaniards interaction since the early dates. The state of preservation is excellent although what we see today is what the Spaniards left standing....

A truly incredible and magical place. The size of the stones and the sheer magnitude of the place is breathtaking. You stand in awe of the intelligence of the incas for being able to build such a place. Definitely worth a visit when in Cusco.

An Inca fortress located on a steep hill 3700m over the sea level. This incredible place is included in the UNESCO World Heritage List. It is easy to imagine how magnificent this place was in the times of the Inca Empire. All covered with gold. Built with a technology that we don't understand even in these modern days. Some stones are so big and so heavy that only big modern cranes could handle. That's why the theory that Inca people mastered the levitation doesn't sound so crazy at all. In this special place you will feel the energy, peace and mystery that this fortress contains.
dont miss this. Great place to get you ready for Machu Picchu. Not as famous, but still worth seeing. Plus they have alpacas.

Great - if you go before Machu Picchu!. It's an impressive site, the craftsmanship of the stone walls is seriously impressive. If you come after visiting the Sacred Valley (Ollantaytambo) / Machu Picchu it may seem a little less impressive, however we visited before this which worked in our favour! We had an excellent guide from our tour agency, however you arguably don't need one here. Part of the Boleto Turistico ticket - which also covers nearby ruins as well as various sites in the city centre.
Macchu Peru tour. Very fascinating history and archeological site. The drive to the site is also very scenic. There is Llamas and Alpacas crazing in the fields there as well.
Sacsayhuaman. Has an amazing view!! Dont need a guide...just get a good brocure or book and do the Hike yourself. Bring lots of water and a few good snacks :)

Earthen ovens to cook potatoes. While the large stone walls are truly magnificent, we had seen many other stone terracing features during our trip to Peru so were somewhat tainted when we visited this feature at the end of our trip. During the Inti Raymi festival, however, the park service peels up the sod and allows the people to come in and dig up the soil to make earthen ovens to cook potatoes. This is clearly a full family affair where each person in the family has an assigned task. Try to time your visit to take in this local cultural tradition as well.

Seeing the sites of Cusco. We went there twice before the Inti Raymi festival and during the festival. Definitely would recommend the same to visitors who want to get an appreciation of Inca culture and accomplishments and the festival is spectacular to see. If going to Cusco go for the festival in June it is worth it.

How did they do it?. The size and scale of what the Inca's achieved - and how they used their learning from previous cultures in their buildings - is truly amazing. Such a shame that much has been lost. How did they move those stones?

Great way to acclimatize in Cusco!. On our first night in Cusco, our Machu Picchu tour guide gave us a pre-trek briefing and told us to walk up to the Sacsayhuaman ruins to get a taste of what our trek would be like. We were so glad we followed his recommendation. After ascending for quite some time, you feel incredibly accomplished when you reach the top. The views of Cusco and the Andes were insane and great for good photo ops. Additionally, the ruins themselves were super cool. We also spotted a herd of llamas/alpacas grazing and hung out with them for awhile. Definitely worth visiting!

Shame there is so little left. but you can still sense the magical of the place. Take your time to imagine what it was like and how it was used, don't rush, and you're likely to be awed by it. We had the guide Rodney from Alpaca Expeditions, passionate about his local Inca culture.

Lovely site above the city. Easy ten sol taxi ride to the main entrance from plaza de armas. Have a nice long wander around then walk back down to the centre from the opposite end of the site. Lovely way to spend a morning.

Amazing!. Unexpectedly good. Make sure you take a guide to tell you what as there is no signage. This whole construction is extraordinary and at the size of some of the stones is beyond belief. A beautiful setting make this a really interesting half day option from Cusco. you can walk from Cusco if you are game through perhaps better down hill than up. We found this the most interesting and extensive of the ruins close to Cusco (combined with Tambo Machay, Q'enko and Puka Pukara)

Impressive ruins!. The rocks forming these ruins are colossal! You can visit the ruins on your own- I recommend buying the "Boleto Turistico" (Tourist ticket) that allows you to enter to multiple sites within Cusco and Sacred Valley - but going with a guided tour is much better as they will explain the significance of this religious complex. don't forget to visit the other ruins around: Qenqo ( with the underground sacrifice chamber), Tambomachay (the Inca baths), and PucaPucara (a military checkpoint)

Memorable trip. This trip was one for the books. Marvel at the engineering prowess of the Incas while sipping coca tea to prevent altitude sickness. Take some picturesque photos at the stone formed door. Walk through mounds of history that has been witness to the early struggles of man...

You should take the tour with the horses! It's amazing;. This trip was booked with View Peru & Signatures; When we arrived, the day before we spoke with Marco Antonio about the attractions we can visit and he recommended to see the ruins near Cusco; We took a private tour with the horses and a guide and i was very happy because i always wanted to ride with horses (and by the way the horses are very calm and are nice with tourists). The guide was young and he spoke English very good; we enjoyed this trip the most and was a big surprise because we didn't expect to be so diverse. We took the horses on the hills and the view was overwhelming. I have great memories about it.

two weeks in Peru. Amazing stone work on a massive scale. We were very lucky to visit during a rehearsal of the yearly remembrance of the Inka nation. The entrance of the King carried on a wooden platform down the multiple levels from the Temple site to the arena(the size of 4 football fields). The music, voices and dancers were quite a presentation, then the King (professional tenor) could be heard singing his role very clearly, without an audio system. We spent 2 hours at the site, even without the rehearsal, a must see in Cusco!
gorgeous ruins. this was a very beautiful historical site. I highly recommend it. wear good shoes, take lots of water and be in relatively good shape to explore it.

Fortress of Giant Stones Built by Human Hands Alone. This fortress sits on top of a hill and took over 7 decades to complete for the protection of Cusco. It is built of masonry walls of stones that are so large and thick that it seems impossible that humans could have moved and placed them there. The stones are so well fitted, that the point of a pin could not be inserted in between them. The fortress was originally built with terraces and flat spaces and with a trench dug in the front. Unfortunately, the Spaniards eventually seized Cusco and the fort was dismantled and much of the complex destroyed. The stones were used to build new Spanish government and religious buildings and also wealthy Spaniards’ homes. This saved the conquerors time, expense and the effort of bringing in new stones for their construction. Today the only stones that are left are those that were too heavy to move from the site. Be sure to wear sturdy walking shoes, layered clothing for warmth and pack an umbrella or rain parka in your travel bag.

Monolithic zig-zag walls. You can walk to and from the ruins from Cusco, and have great views of the city along the way. The sheer size of the stones in the walls, is amazing!! It is hard to believe the the Inka people could erect such huge, perfectly constructed walls.
Breathtaking. We spent a lot of time being shown around the ruins here, absolutely amazing, make sure you visit you won't be disappointed, this was a great follow on to Machu Picchu

It is one of the best. Similar to Stonehenge. An incredible and amazing site. The stones are gigantic (tallest one is about 7 meters?) and the view is fantastic! There is so much history behind the place, and it's very mysterious about how the Incans built such a place. The Incan stone slides are special bonus.

It is one of the best. Similar to Stonehenge. An incredible and amazing site. The stones are gigantic (tallest one is about 7 meters?) and the view is fantastic! There is so much history behind the place, and it's very mysterious about how the Incans built such a place. The Incan stone slides are special bonus.

Impressive ancient fortress!. I went with South Adventure Peru Tours on a tour of Cusco's cultural sites after hiking the Inca Trail to Machu Picchu—Sacsayhuaman was impressive in it's own right because of how the Inca *still* used their mortar-less joining techniques even though they were using *incredibly* massive stones here. Definitely a great place for a view over Cusco, and I look forward to seeing what the ongoing archaeological work here continues to dig up!

Sacsayhuaman Fortress Ruins. This is a 'must see' Inca site if you are passing through or staying in Cusco. This extensive ruin covers a mountaintop at an elevation of over 12,000 feet. The site is said to have been occupied since 900AD. The Inca greatly expanded the fortress from the 13th century and used it as a military outpost and storage facility. It containes some of the largest cut stones found in the Inca Empire, precisely cut and fit together without mortor. Most of the smaller stones have been removed by the Spaniards and used to build the colonial city below. This site is often featured on the TV series Ancient Aliens as an example of Inca stone masonry. You can't help but wonder how they did it! Your guide will most likely tell you that people refer to the site as 'sexy woman'. There are awesome views of the mountins and the city of Cusco below and would be a great place for a picnic. The locals use the large open spaces for special events and festivals. On a nearby hilltop is the Christo Blanco, the White Christ, a gift to the city in 1945 from Christian Palestinians. It is a smaller version of the Christ the Redeemer statue above Rio de Janiero. You can see a video of these sites on my youtube channel: youtube.com/c/donstailey

Feel the Energy. This was amazing. You could really feel the energy here. The only regret I have is that the tour I was on did not give you enough time to soak it in. You need at least 1.5 hours there.

It's a Wonderful Ancient Site. I'm always curious when people compare every ancient Inca site in Peru to Machu Picchu. Why would someone do that? Each place is uniquely amazing, and this is no exception. It's close proximity to Cusco makes it a must-do, in my book. We took a taxi up the hill (at something like $8 per hour, they will drop you to see what you want, when you want, and will be waiting when you're done). We hired a guide on-site, and she was wonderful. We spent about an hour combing through the ruins, which are spectacular, and spent another moment with the resident Alpaca on the way out. I highly recommend.

Interesting Inca site, worth a short visit if you have extra time. My wife and I enjoyed touring Sacsayhuaman with a local guide. The stone workmanship is truly amazing and you can get some great views of Cusco from a nearby vantage point. We enjoyed climbing the three levels of the ruins to get a better view of the entire site.

A must do when in Cusco.. Sexy Woman is awesome because it is a mere 20-30 min walk from Cusco. The ruins are very impressive and the whole site is pretty darn big. You can also walk to the christ statue as well. If you like ruins I highly recommend Sexy Woman. The stone work is beyond impressive.

Historical significance. This spot is of great historical and cultural significance and is worth visiting with a guide to understand its significance. It must have been an amazing structure as only a small portion of it remains. It also allows for wonderful views over the city of Cusco.Entry was part of a ticket that allowed entry to a number of different sites.

Excellent time,great adventure. Took a private tour on horse back. This was the highlight of our trip. What an amazing way to see these ruins. There is less supervision that allows one to really get up close and clinb around in a way that is just not possible in other ruins. We purchased some carved stone pieces from a guy who's house was next to the ruins. Be bought (for 2 soles / .66 cents) Chacanas (Andean crosses ) which we placed on the altar of the temple of the moon. We went up to the rock labarith and our guide showed us how to offer coca to the mountain and introduced us to punya an herb that grows wild and when you smell it it opens your lungs...no lie , amazing and incredible. I will never forget this amazing experience with my family. This Is what it's all about.

Ancient Ruins Minutes from Downtown Cusco. These incredible pre-Incan and Incan ruins are just minutes from downtown Cusco. Some of the stones are so large it is hard to imagine how they cut, moved and set them in place without the kind of equipment that we have today. The builders of this place were truly extraordinary.

Easily Accessed Inca ruins.. Probably not as spectacular as some other Inca ruins but well worth a visit. It certainly looks unreal but not so. Parts have been restored but much is original. It is close to the main city and can be reached by bus or taxi for minimal cost. I suspect it looks better at night as I noticed good lighting around the area. This would be a fantastic amphitheatre for an outdoor concert.

Saqsaywaman, The Head of the Puma. Huge Stones! You can find several over 25-foot long, 100-ton stones along the ruins which are in a considerable large area. It's very near Cusco city, so you can visit this and other ruins in a five-hour tour.

Don't Miss "Sexy-Woman!". Not to be missed, a very exciting stop in cusco, about 45 acres of natural proteted lands, with many sites, 200,000 lb. pre-Inca stones, incredibly carved into fortresses, see thrones, tunnels, natural rock slides, Inca reservoirs. Do hire one of the guides, they can show you what you won't know is these, it's fun, there are llamas wandering around, too.

Maybe we were a little ruined out. After seeing Machu Picchu, this place does not live up. But it is worth going to, especially if you can get a good guide. It is close to Cusco, the scenery is beautiful, and the views from the top of Cusco are beautiful

Worth the visit, not sure if a guide is worth it.... My husband and I visited Sacsayhuaman toward the end of our trip to Peru, and as we were limited on time, we opted not to get a guide. We were BLOWN AWAY by the magnitude of what we were seeing and the fact that humans moved those massive stones into place without modern machinery. As we walked around the site, we'd eavesdrop on the guides giving tours and found that each guide had his own explanation for what we were seeing. Shelves cut into rocks were seats for royalty according to one guide, and offering platforms according to another. Sadly, a lot of what we "know" about the ancient cultures of Peru are just speculation. There simply aren't reliable records left to help us make sense of it all. My suggestion, read up on the site before you go, and just take it at your own pace, or if you hire a guide, take it as A theory of what you might be seeing. Definitely worth a visit, though.

Nice historical spot. This place is heavy with history, and people of this culture try to maintain it nowadays. The option we did was to visit the 4 incas sites around Cusco with a small trip by horse. This was very good, instead of following the road we travelled through the fields...

One of the many wonders to see around Cuzco. Please get a guide - you'll learn about the construction, use, history and significance of this amazing stone fortress. There's a cavern/tunnel you can pass through where it's completely dark - you'll have to hold on to the person in front of you with one hand and cover your head (to not bump it on the rocks) with the other - but a cool experience as you enter from the "natural" side of the fortress - as opposed to the side where it is all hand carved rock. On this side you'll also find several large natural slides that the kids (or maybe you) will enjoy sliding down.Once your guide is done, you can take your time exploring, admiring the stone work and taking lots of pictures.Don't waste your guide's time with this - there's so much to learn, if you're into that sort of thing. You'll likely want to take a cab there, but can easily walk down - maybe a 15-20 minute walk to the plaza.

Ruin near the city. I liked that this Ruin was so close to the city. I was able to walk here from my hostel near the main plaza in Cusco. I would recommend riding horses around this ruin - the horse ride takes you into the country side of Peru. Very nice
Go to the top. Most definitely make this part of your trip. And definitely go to the top. If I did it at 74 so can you. Just can't believe how thet did it.

Beautiful place. This is one of the highlights of the Cusco area. Not only is it a nice drive up to the location, but it's terribly interesting. Go with a guide, so that you can learn about the location and what it's all about.

Overlooking Cusco. Consider for a moment that Cusco was the capital if the Inca Empire. It is like Rome to the Roman Empire: there are interesting sites everywhere. Or at least the ones that the Spanish didn't destroy. This place overlooks the city and was built to be the head of a puma. Also, don't work your tongue too hard trying to pronounce the name: it's Sexy Woman. This is a very large, beautiful preserved site. Lots of walking, spectacular view

Shop around for best city tour price. Visiting Sacsayhuaman is likely on of the first ruins you'll visit on your trip to Cusco/region. And so worth the visit. On arrival there are tour options pushing to get you to choose them. Or you can do it on your own with a walk uphill from town. Shop around for the best tour price. It seems many of the shops sell the same tour and you are all grouped together on large buses. Glad I paid significantly less than others on my bus with me. It was an excellent tour to see several local city sights in the afternoon, but shopping around was best.
Amazing . This place is truly amazing. The size of the stone blocks is enormous and it's really difficult to imagine how they managed to building this just by the force of men.

MUST not miss if in Peru. Whether you are an alien theorist or just plain amazed by ancient Peruvian works, this place is a must see. How they cut the lines so perfectly and fit them in place is a true wonder. Stand in amazement at the work of the ancients. The cuts are perfect, no flaws. Breathtaking at the very least. As an aside, a farmer does keep a small herd of friendly alpacas in the field. If you are lucky there may be a baby to see. He had no problem with us approaching the small herd

Stonework to marvel at. This is the closest Inca ruin to Cusco, Look up and find the statue of Jesus, Sacsayhuaman is just beyond it. We hired a driver and spent the day seeing 4 of the ruins closest to Cusco and started here.It was a beautiful sunny day and there was some type of ceremony going on celebrating spring. It was an interesting mix of an Inca shaman, Catholic priest, an oriental religious person and several locals all together welcoming in the new season. Sacsayhuaman is a large complex made up of 3 huge serpentine walls of hand cut boulders that fit together perfectly with no mortar, just precision cutting. Some of the stones are as big as a car and fit together so tightly you can't slide a playing card between them. A true wonder of Inca engineering! You can spend up to 1/2 a day here of you so choose as the site is quite large. We spent about 2 hours wandering around and then headed for our next site.If you only have a short time in Cusco this is an Inca ruin that is exceptional in size and engineering and is just a 10 minute cab ride from the main square and well worth your time.

Amazing work. This was the first Inca site we visited. it was amazing to see how it was all put together. Our guide told us all about the history. I suggest that you use guides for the sites. You get so much more out of what you are seeing.

spend at least 1/2 day here. if you combine this with too many other things you're better off not even wasting your time. i say that because that's what i did & it was very frustrating. i like to hike, explore, stop and enjoy the moment. this is not possible here in less than a 1/2 day tour here. i suggest no more than 1 other place the day you visit here. definitely worth spending some time here

Absolute must. Perhaps one of the most fastinating and intriguing of all the inca sites besides that of Machu picchu. Both my wife and I loved the serenity and history of this beautiful location. Really awe inspiring construction.

Awe-Inspiring. While most visit Cusco as a stepping stone to the amazing Machu Picchu, it's important to remember that Cusco and the surrounding areas have equally fascinating sites like Sacsayhuaman. The giant, multi-faceted stonework blows the mind, and the site is huge and fun to explore. Our girls especially loved seeing the llamas and alpacas around the site. Truly a fascinating way to spend a day near Cusco.
Worth a stop!. We visited 5 places on the circuit - definitely worth a stop! With the full ticket you are paying for it either way.

A true wonder!. We stopped at Q'enko a site of worship and mummification on the way to Sacsayhuaman. Sacsayhuaman is a magical, mysterious and beautiful site with wonderfully built walls of stone. The Incas were true masters of architecture and construction; makes our modern structures look like the work of amateurs. It is a beautiful and peaceful site despite all the tourists. There is a section where one can "slide" down as the Incas did which is very cool. Definitely worth the visit. You need at least an hour here to appreciate the beauty and architecture of the site. Also, there are "stairs" a little away from the main site where you can visit the cross placed on the top of a cliff when John Paul II visited Peru and there are stunning views of Cusco from there. You can also appreciate the layout of Cusco from here - the city was laid out in the shape of a Puma by the Incas.

A must see!. This site is huge and simply stunning... While walking around you can theorize about how on earth they moved those MASSIVE boulders.... rollers and man power, witch doctors, aliens? ;) But seriously, a really great place to visit! Make sure you go either on your own time or with a tour that will give you time to explore. Our tour guide talked a TON and we didn't get near as much time as we would have likedto just look around. It's a realatively short ride from Cusco via taxi/tour bus (maybe 20min) so you can go back if your tourguide is the same:) DEFINITELY a must see!
Worth visiting. If you like to admire Inca building skills or if you just want a spectacular view of Cusco, go up there, have a glass of wine and enjoy it.

Take Time to Explore. This was our first visit to Incan ruins after arriving in Cusco and it was impressive. Our guide spent way too long lecturing us on the merits of the Andean religion and his interpretation of the site (there is plenty of disagreement as to which civilization was responsible for which stones) that the didn't give us time to really just explore. We took off eventually and found grand views of the town along the extensive trails. Be sure to go with a guide or a guidebook so you can understand the relevance of the numbers 13 and 52 and get an idea of how much science and technology went into building this site by both Incans and pre-Incas.

A bit crowded and worth it. I went with a small tour even though I read up on the history. Next time, I'll go alone and linger a bit longer. It is amazing to be up close and see the amazing stone work.

Second to Machu Picchu. I got the multi-day pass which was well worth it as I planned on visiting multiple ruins including this one. Next to Macchu Picchu I found Sacsayhuaman to be the second best ruins to visit. The ruins is huge and I spent a large amount of time exploring.A tip for the ruin hunters we caught a bus up to Tambomachay for a few soles and walked our way back visiting all of the ruins on our way back to Cusco, we even met a few people doing the same.

Half Day Tour. This was well worth our time. Tour guide moved a bit to fast for our taste... and we hated being swamped with folks hawking wares on the bus.. but greatly enjoyed touring this fascinating historic site. We plan to go again with friends in a few years. This time, we will hire a private guide.

Interesting but best to do with a guide. We went with a guide and found the area to be very interesting. I can imagine that without guide it might lose a bit. If you've already been to Machu Picchu and some ruins around the sacred valley this may seem a little repetitive but as with many there's always some stuff that's just a little different from the rest.

BIg rocks!. If you think your office job is hard, think of the people who put this place together. Incredibly large stones hand cut and moved into a vast temple-fortress complex with outstanding views of Cusco. A must-see in the Cusco area. Don't forget your selfie stick!
Wow. Great place to visit, very interesting recommend you get a guide and be prepare to be there at least 3 hours!
Great Day trip. Great day trip to this beautiful area. The rock structures are amazing as in all of Peru. Would not spend more than a couple of hours. Restrooms available.

Beautiful ruins and challenging hike from town!. Went to Sacsayhuaman twice, with an organized tour and on my own. The ruins and views of Cusco from the hilltop vantage point are both terrific. And the climb from town is a great way to challenge yourself if you're acclimating prior to trekking!

Interesting and impressive. I agree with one of the recent reviews which mentioned the fact that it loses some of its impact if you have been to Machu Picchu first. Nothing really can compete with Machu Picchu, nevertheless this is worth a visit.

Spectacular Fort. I recommend heading to Cusco and spending the first 3 days there until you can feel tingling on your face from your altitude sickness prevention pills. Then take a hike to Sacsayhuaman to practice getting used to the climb. If you decide to do the Salkantay trek rather than Inca Trail, it will be a higher climb. This fort is phenomenal. I loved every bit of it and you can hit this and the Christ on one trip. I met some terrific kids who wanted to take pictures with me and they were absolutely adorable. The fort has tremendous history which you can download from app store. Look up Cusco. Don't be a wimp and take a bus or taxi. Do the thousand step hike up. It's good practice for your longer hike to Macchu Picchu.
Don't go on afternoon city tour. $18 and see all the sights. That is the problem- too many sites and too little time except for an I was here picture

Better in its Original glory. Amazing display of architecture and stonework, however the spaniards destroyed the majority of the site to use its stone for their own cathedral so there isnt much remaining.

Sacsay Indeed. Well worth a visit, BUT: - If you are planning to go to MachunPicchu, go here first. It loses its splendour after the magnificence of MP! - take plenty of water and snacks. It's quite far out of Vusco, and there are only extortionately priced shops nearby.
Better to catch a Sunset. You might be getting into closing time but is worth seeing the colors in the sky and the lighting when the Sun goes down
Great ruins!. We went after Machu Picchu but it was still very cool. Very different type of structure! Definitely worth seeing.

Amazing Site. This site was very interesting. The stones were huge and were places together where not even a razor blade could get in between them. Our guide said this was his favorite site. I wouldn't go that far, but I did enjoy it very much. And it wasn't very crowded! I'm not sure how much the charge for this site was as we bought a ticket that covered all of the major sites.

A must see. Sacsayhuaman is a must see when visiting Cusco. The sheer size of this Inca fortress is amazing. Its especially lovely as the sun begins to set and the golden light highlights the stonework.

A Great Start. This is one of the first ruins we saw, in the e. It is just outside Cusco and is easily accessible by van. Likewise it is relatively flat, again making it readily accessible. As viewing this ruin is easier than many, one can begin to appreciate the innovative nature of the civilization. Large stones, pieced together with perfection was a harbinger of what we would later see. If a person has the inability to manage the physical requirements of some of the other ruins, Sacsayhuaman is an excellent choice on your itinerary.

Sacsayhuaman is a testament and achievemetn of the Inca Empire!. The wall of Sacsayhuaman is an historical site well worth visiting - it demonstrates the amazing archeological, archietectural and engineering capabilities of pre-Inkan and inkan civilization. The stonework quality was truly impressive!

Inti Raymi Spectacle. We were there for Inti Raymi ,and it was amazing. Pay for the seat, and the ride up and down. There must have been 200,000 people there easy. Up and down all the hills. The seats are NOT comfortable, you have no option. If you have a portable back support, bring it.

Expensive. This was a very expensive site (S/. 140 per person, or about $46 US) and not that interesting. Because the site is located so far above Cusco, it offers some great views of the city, but you can get those same views just by going to the neighboring site. Jesus Blanco, which is free. I kept hearing from everyone that this place is a must-see, but I wish I had kept my money instead.

Main event. Each year the celebration of the Incan sun god, Inti Raymi, takes place in the center of Sacsayhuaman. The ancient Incan ruin, still under excavation, is a beautiful site where you can feel the presence of the ancient civilization. Be sure to stop at the entrance and read the large description posters to understand how the site is laid out and what significance you find in the positioning of the 'walls'. Make sure you seek out what is believed to be the largest stone used in the Incan empire. Speculate on how each of these stones was put in place.
Inti Raymi festival. Was lucky enough to visit during the Festival of the Sun God & saw the celebration of Inti Raymi at the site
Temple of the Sun shines. Aclimitize by walking up to this large site above the city. Or rent horses from a local grey market vendor and ride, like we did

History of Cuzco not to miss. This was included in the city tour and the guide provided a very good commentary on the history. This is not to be done without a guide as you would be looking at a bunch of rocks as there is no information posted about this in the reserve.

Shouldn't be missed. We did this as part of an excursion with National Geographic however I just wished we would have had more time. The size of the stones here is mind-boggling to think of how they moved them into place and aligned them. Some restoration work going on but I suspect that is happening all the time. Don't miss this place.

Must see Inca historical site in Cuzco!. We arranged a 3 hour city tour of Cuzco and Sacsayhuaman was part of the experience and well worthwhile. However, it is helpful to have an expert guide to explain the significance and history of the site. The site underlines the genius and building skills of the Incas - simply incredible!If you are in Cuzco for a few days this is a must see visit!

Get out your hiking boots. This monument is considered the first of the new seven wonders of the world. This zig-zag fortress made of several platforms stacked on top of one another. The size of some of the boulders are enormous!!!!! It's a marvel that you'll want to capture on film.
Tourism . Excellent views. The tour guide was excellent too. I took a lot of pictures of this beautiful place.

Can't miss this site while visiting Cusco. If you are interested in Incan history, culture and architecture, which I assume most people are if they are visiting Cusco, you must visit this site. It is easy to get to from Cusco; you can even walk- albeit uphill. Or, you can take a taxi to the ruins, then walk back to town, which is what we did. The ruins are exquisite and have a very colorful history, including a famous battle between the Inca and the Spanish conquistadors. The stones are enormous and are some of the largest stones ever found in any pre-Hispanic settlement in the Americas. The setting is also quite spectacular, sitting high above Cusco.

Amazing Incan ruins walking distance from Cusco. We hired a guide just inside the gate who gave us a great appreciation for what we were seeing. There were so many things we wouldn't have noticed without her.
Inti Rymi. Cusco's largest annual festival Inti Rymi is held on June 24 every year. It's not cheap but worth it!

Marvelous Sacsayhuaman...and a side visit to Q'Enqo. Excellent site to visit, especially since it's just a 15 minute drive from Cusco. The rock walls are impressive, the engineering marvelous in terms of how the stones fit, and the site is very well maintained. Can easily combine it with a stop at the nearby Q'Enqo (both are included in the full Boleto Turistico). We took a taxi from Plaza de Armas and kept the driver waiting while we visited both sites.

Practice for sun god festival. Our group happened to tour here during practice for sun god festival later in the week of June 20TH. If that was cool enough the things the Inca did with stone was incredible as were the panoramic views!

Magical and Massive Fortress.. This the most impressive and grandest Inca site in the Cusco area. It is either a fortress or a religious temple. In any case, it is massive even after being partially dismantled by the Spaniards. It stretches several hundred feet and is comprised of least three tiers of massive stones, all fitted together with surgical precision without the use of mortar. In fact it is so huge that I, from the adjoining hilltop, could not fit the entire fortress in a single picture frame even using a wide angle lens. It is almost magical in its massive stones which had to be moved miles and miles to this site. You have to spend some time here!! The site is easily reachable from Plaza/Armas by a 30-45 min uphill walk. Once on top, you have a very nice view of the Cusco and the surroundings. Also nearby, is the statue of Christo Blanco overlooking the city. Admission is via the Boleto.

Nice Ruins So Close To Cusco!. These ruins are fantastic in their own right even though you'll probably do them before or after going to Machu Picchu. They are so close to Cusco though and you can get a tourist ticket that lets you roam through a bunch of different ruins for a great price.
Majestic and Meaningful. Both the structures and the nearby mountains had a majestic presence. Our guide provided valuable historic and spiritual details that enhanced appreciation.

Best Inca site near Cusco. Visited this Inca site right outside of Cusco during our Ultimate Inca Trail tour with Amazonas Explorers. We were fortunate enough to be there during the Winter Solstice - when we got to see the site along the preparation for the big festival that happens on June 24th. Really neat to experience. The site is well preserved, and helps you learn more about the Inca culture. A must see.
Great view of Cusco and good ruins. The ruins were good, whats even better is the view of Cusco. We went around dusk and the view was incredible. You can see the region's highest mountain.
Local Ruins. One of the many spectacular ruins in the Cusco area which is usually included in the city tour. Great place for an afternoon visit.

Ancient Inca ruins just on the edge of Cusco. This site (pronounced similar to "sexy woman") is an ancient Inca fortification and ritual space. Here you get a really good sense of the Inca culture's architectural building skills. Note that it does take some imagination to 'see" what it was like when it was originally built.

Inca battle site . My family and I visited this Inca ruin the day before seeing Machu Pichu. And it was a valuable precursor. This was a site where a battle between the Incas and the invading Spanish ensued. You can visit on your own or hire a guide. I would recommend hiring a guide for about 40 soles or approximately $13. Knowing what you're looking at makes it so much more interesting. But a good guide is very important. Try to find someone who not only has knowledge of the place but is also happily willing to share it without you having to pull the information out of them. We had a great guide. And as a side note, because this place sounds phonetically like " Sexy Woman ", that's how the locals refer to it.

Must visit. There is a bit of a walk but it takes you back in time to see how the Incas consolidated an empire in those days. It is cool and vast expanse and be sure to have a good walking stick if you have joint problems.

Massive stones!. When you look at the overall design of Sacsayhuaman it is quite impressive than the Incas were able to come up with and execute the design (spoiler alert: it is shaped like a lightning bolt). The use of massive stones is very impressive and once again highlights the stonemasonry skills of these early builders.

An outdoor Inca experience. Sacsayhuaman is an outdoor visit of an old Inca temple/town/fortress. High up on the city of Cuzco overlooking the town. It is well preserved and you can spend a couple of hours wondering around the ruins and terraces. Look out for the hidden animals in the stonework,Make sure you wonder over to Christ overlooking the town for an excellent view of CuzcoIt would have been much more interesting if there had been some notices with explanations in English. We had a guide with us, who explained everything.Be careful of all of the sellers offering you everything that a tourist doesn't need! they are quite pushy at this site. This is one of the places that the bus trip comes to if you pick up a tour from the town centre
Dramatic site. This is a very powerful site which enormous walls built with gigantic stones. It is very open and affords beautiful views of Cusco.
interesting site. This was our first stop after we arrived in Cusco enroute to the Sacred Valley. It was a good introduction to the Inka's use of stone and how the designed their sacred sites.
Historic Ruins. Unlike other tourist clogged ruins, this was quiet historic with wide open spaces. Knowing the history of the place does make it a better visit.
historical site. one of the best inca stone works. there are several sites to see around cuszco, this one is a must. most tourists call it sexy woman.

Impressive Incan ruins. We kind of stumbled on the ruins on our way to see the Cristo Blanco statue. I'm so glad we came! The Sacsayhuaman ruins have some of the best examples of the Inca's stone cutting skills, and you can see some massive (like the size of an SUV) rocks held together with no mortar or anything. It was so impressive! Plus, the views of Cusco are also amazing.
Sacsayhuaman. This place will remain in our memory as the most astounding Inca ruin that we saw. There is no way to describe the intricate and precise nature of the rock formation.

Interesting and excellent view point. Possibly the most easily accessible site, Sacsayhuaman is interesting and also disappointing. The view is great. You can walk up to the site from downtown Cusco via stairways near the San Blas area. The view over the Cusco valley is excellent.The original Quechua stone work is amazing. Regrettably, the site has been "repaired" using materials and techniques which are stunningly inferior to the original. The site would have been better left alone rather than butchered with the poor restorations.

Impressive Site. A great site to learn about the amazing Inca stone construction. A commanding view of the city of Cusco and surroundings. Take some time and walk around. The stone used here is much larger in scale compared to MP. Though most of the structures were destroyed by Spanish, it is a MUST for visitor to Cusco.

Interesting but not a highlight for me. This is another Cusco treasure which highlights the stonework, but you will want a guide to explain things. Cusco has so many wonderful attractions, but this one was just average for me. We did so many tours with history lessons that all sounded the same, so this site was just so-so on my list.

Strongly recommended. While in Cusco acclimatizing, I strongly recommend a visit to Sacsayhuaman a.k.a. "Sexy Woman".It's a mountain that overlooks the city of Cusco, providing a great view. It contains substantial historical significance and amazing ruins. It's beautiful and worth the time to visit. While there we were approached by a freelance guide who turned out to be pretty great. He gave an excellent and informative tour, rich with (probably) accurate historical information and also took us to various interesting places in the mountain.

Walk around this site if you have time. We saw this site via a bus tour, and unfortunately only drove by the site. I would have loved to stop, and take the time to explore - but we had limited time in Cusco. If you don't have time, take a bus tour and drive by the site. if you have time - explore it!

Crazy cool!. Not as cool as Machu Picchu but comparable! It was defiantly a highlight of our trip to Cusco!! Probably would be more interesting with a guide but could do alone and still be flawed. The view of Cusco from top of site was incredible!

Interesting short visit, combine it with other nearby sites. Easy to do on a short journey by taxi from the city centre. We had a car and driver to go here combined with Pukapukara and Tambomachay for a half day for about 80 Soles. Larger than expected site with excellent examples of the stonework Inca walls.

Amazing. I am big fun of ancient civilizations, this ruin is amazing.
Lucky me, I will be here on the big celebration of Inti! Unfortunatelly the ruin is damaged to much, but the remains are well preserved.
Only one, but big con: 130S entry free is over priced!
Great views of Cusco. Definitely worth the trip up! We went late in the day and it was very quiet and peaceful. Great views of Cusco and the Andes Mountains.

Incan History Lesson. The citadel of Sacsayhuaman, just outside Cuzco, was our first exposure to the Incan civilization . This World Heritage site was their former capital. The walls are made of huge stones that were sculpted to fit together without using mortar. We used a guide to learn the history of the site.

A visit to Sacsayhuaman - Cusco.. A beautiful historical Inca ruins. A great site to spend a couple of hours wandering about at your own pace. There are guides if you are so inclined. This site shows off the incredible workmanship of the Incas in shaping massive stones to fit together. There are also quite a few Llamas wandering about the site.

Big and Beautiful. I wasn't quite sure what to expect when going here, as I'd see a few things here and there in guidebooks and from friends, but I didn't see it featured too much. That being said, I found this site to be wonderful and fun to explore. The history of Sacsayhuaman and seeing it in person does not do the photos justice. I tried explaining the vastness and grand scale as I was showing others photos, but it just doesn't translate. I'd highly recommend this site to others and would add it to your must-do list when visiting Peru and the Cusco area.

Llamas!. Sacsayhuaman was nice for us because we had an extra day to kill, but if your time in Cusco is limited I wouldn't bother. We did appreciate the small llama herd with the most adorable babies.
Go Before Machu Picchu. Cool sight with some great vistas of Cusco, but if you've already spent time in Machu Picchu it'll seem a little quaint. Check it out for yourself.

Good but skip if you don't have much money/time. You can visit here by yourself, which is recommended because there's a lot to explore. The entrance is expensive, but you can use the ticket to visit many of the places in the Sacred Valley, so it may be worth it depending on whether you will go to those places or not. The ticket costs 70 soles for students and about double for non-students but you can get into about 10 attractions. Sacsayhuaman is located on top of a very large hill, and is hard to get there by walking due to the altitude, but it is doable from the Plaza de Armas. Set aside at least 30-45 minutes, or more if you're in bad shape. Once you get in, you have to walk more to get to the ruins. The ruins, though, are beautiful. Not as impressive after you've seen Machu Picchu, but they make for great pictures and you can have an awesome view of Cusco from it. From here you can also easily get to the White Christ on the other side of the hill, so visit these two together!

Marvel at the expertise of the Quechuan builders - an interesting visit. We visited Sacsayhuaman as part of a private tour. I would highly recommend a guide as ours was able to provide information and stories about the site that enriched our visit. Sacsayhuaman is an amazing Incan construction, a walled fortress which apparently forms the head of Cusco’s “puma”. It is located on a hill overlooking the city of Cusco, providing great views of the city and surrounding valley. We marvelled at the architectural expertise of the early Quechuans who built the walls of this fortress temple by cutting enormous rocks and joining them with such precision, without any cement or mortar, that you are unable to place anything between them. Apparently the biggest stone weighs 126 tons. There were also Alpacas wandering around the area, providing photo opportunities. An interesting tour - definitely worth a visit.

Unique archeological site. Although much of the site has been destroyed over the centuries, the remains are still impressive. The size of the stones and precision of the construction are amazing. The site is an inexpensive taxi ride from the Plaza de Armas. I would not recommend walking there unless you have unlimited time and energy. The site is quite spread out. Allow at least one and a half hours and hire a guide at the site. You really need to do this in order to understand the significance of the place to the Quechua people today. The people still make traditional offerings of coca leaves on the ancient altars. The guide will show you the stone depictions of the llama and guinea pig.
Good for a shortvisit. The place is nice to stroll around. Often tourist tours do not give enought time to do it though. I would recommend taking a taxi there and ask it to wait for the return.

Tiring but great to visit. We took a walk here from the city center. It's quite a climb in a full sun... Didn't look difficult, but required many stops along the way. Before the main get, we were hassled by locals offering horse rides .. Note that no horses are allowed on the site. DONT DO IT! Past the gate, you get to walk up some more... Tiring, but once you reach the site, it's worth it... Also, you can just lie down on a carpet soft grass and rest a bit while taking it all in before continuing the exploration... It's a beautiful site with very interesting history - read up on it.

Saxy woman. Our guide suggested the pronunciation on our tour. A name you will never forget. We visited this attraction after Machu Picchu and several other ruins. I enjoyed this as much as any of he others. Not because of its beaut but because of its history and the many friendly llamas that came to say Hello. I was kind of tired so I didn't tour the entire ruin. It is flat in many places with sandy/grassy areas. There were several berms to use as your back rest and I sat in The warm sun just relaxed and enjoyed. I thought it was truly lovely...and the natives (llamas) were friendly.

To short time to explore everything. On arrival find a board of all Kings which reigned in the area. It is sheer amazing how did this guys brought the stones from two kilometers away down here and put them together the way they are now! Still pity didn't get time to explore more.

I don't get it.. I don't understand Sacsayhuaman. Only 30% of the ruins remain, after the gold, and then the rocks themselves were pilfered by the spanish to build their churches in Cusco. The site was one of a great massacre. The destruction of an advanced culture. Visit, and there is little mention of the waste and atrocity that took place here. To me, it felt like someone promoting Auschwitz purely as a historical attraction.

Curious. While Machu Picchu may be the most breathtakingly beautiful Inca site, Sacsayhuaman is perhaps the most intriguing. When you see the size of these stones it will blow your mind! How on earth did they cut them and move them? I found the site very intriguing. I did not hire a guide but read about the site in advance. I plan to read more about the site when I return home. I Would recommend visiting this site. The cheapest was is to get a 1 day partial tourism ticket. It must be used on that day and costs 70 soles. You may also get into 3 other sites including Quenqo which is about 15 min up the road. The hike is tough but worth it!

Great Place to Explore. We walked to Sacsayhuaman from downtown Cusco - about a 1.5 miles. Nice walk, but pace yourself since it's all uphill. We did not get a guide, but instead just roamed around the ruins on our own. There are white arrows directing you, but no other signage. Be sure to check out the cave like tunnel(s) on the north side of the site (have your flashlight on your phone handy) Lots of places to have a little picnic, bring snacks and enjoy the view. We also hiked up to the Christo Blanco - impressive up close. We spent around 3 hours walking there and back and exploring. You could spend a lot longer if you wanted.
Phenomenal!. What a tremendous place to start your tour of the Inca and Quechu civilizations! I could have stayed there for days exploring and feeling the power there. Fantastic!

Incredible ancient fort. What a tremendous place. Almost unbelievable that Inca were able to create a fort that was suited with an ingenious watersystem so they could hold it against the Spanish for several wees until they found out hoe to stop the water supply.

Worth the visit, but go with a guide. Not quite as impressive as the sacred valley ruins, but worth a visit to get to know a bit about the importance of these ruins and the history of Cusco. Go with a guide to get the background story.

Must see if you go to Cusco. Another set of ancient construction that show the fantastic engineering feats of the Incas. Get up close to the stone walls and passage ways. Walk up to the top to see one of the best views of the entire city of Cusco you'll ever get. A definite must do if you want to complete your tour of the Cusco region.
Great Incan Site. Great site for viewing & understanding the size of Incan monumnets. Views of Cusco are amazing from the site. Well run & well maintained.

Awesome intro to the Incas. I'd seen all the pictures, but actually seeing this archolgical site up close was amazing. It's a large site, constructed with incredible precision. Only 2.1km uphill from the Plaza De Armas. The view from the lookout over Cuzco is breathtaking and as a bonus there is also the Christo Blanko statue.

Good place to see historical side of Cuzco and great views of town. This is really worth taking the time to visit while in Cuzco. It's got amazing views and the place is quite serene and just fascinating historically. There are lots of little nooks and crannies so give yourself a few hours to explore. Don't be fooled by all the people offering to give you a tour or horseradish. It's a hike but it's a good hike. And on the way back, stop for the warm corn and cheese at the entrance. Sooooo good. It's a good workout so make sure you are up for the walking.

An Amazing Inka Ruin. This is another amazing Inka Ruin, just outside Cusco, with a lot of history. It boggles the mind when you wonder how they could get these huge rocks positioned like this hundreds of years ago. And the scale of it is massive! The only reason that I didn't rate it as Excellent, was because Machu Picchu is the benchmark I am comparing it to.

Historic place, awesome!. Incas were incredible architects. All their stone projects and works are still there...incredible.This place is very nice, a guided tour will really help you to better appreciate all these incredible constructions and its history!

Impressive Inca Ruins Near Cuzco. We visited Sacsayhuaman after our magical time at Machu Picchu. While Sacsayhuaman lacks the misty mountain magic of the more famous site, we marveled at its scale, at the engineering effort to haul, shape and place these massive stones, and at its commanding view of Cuzco and areas nearby. Wear comfortable walking shoes and take a wind jacket -- it gets breezy.

Incredible sight and nice short hike to get acclimated. How did the Incas build this incredible site. Amazing. Go visit caves and tombs as well. Once you are done touring Sacsayhuaman, its a short hike over to the Blanco Christo. a great 1/2 day adventure. I would encourage you to hire a guide to enjoy the site and learn more about the culture of this magnificent place.

nice view of the city from the hill!. you get a really pretty view of the whole of cusco from the top of the hill. the jesus statue is worth taking a picture with and if you look very closely you can almost make out the puma that cusco is supposedly shaped like.
Craftsmanship. Amazing craftsmanship and good views over Cusco, more relaxed than some of the other historic sites.

Amazing Place. An amazing place. Hard to imagine the effort to build this. The large carved stones were placed with such precision.
While we didn't feel the sacred forces ourselves, there were many people who did. This is a must see place in Peru.
city bus tour from main square cusco. glad we took this bus tour from the old town, through the new town and suburbs to the ancient site, would recommend. some people opt to walk there

Excellent view of the City from the top of the hill. This is an amazing site, it is bult with huge grey stones which would be very havey and difficult to transport it. The edges are rounded so water does not go through and there is hardly any space between stones!! They also had doors. There is fair bit of walking and climbing but it is worth it.

Expensive. We arrived to find the entry fee was 130 S for one to visit . As a result we didn't honing but we did walk around the area which was extremely interesting and worthwhile . Shame they asked so much . Nothing could compare to Machu Picchu.

not to be missed!!. These ruins are overlooking Cusco, you could even walk to them if you don't mind a challenging uphill climb. They are amazing and beautiful, and gargantuan in scale. Quite different from others in the region. It is worth it to hire a guide to explain the purpose and history, and to tell you about the ceremony held there each year. Another example of the Inca stonework but on a mammoth scale.

Very impressive. After 3 days of seeing piles of rocks, I wasn't sure if I needed to see more. But this was worthwhile stop. You see the skill of the stone cutters here as well as at other places, but the size of some of the stones here were very impressive. You can't help but wonder how they moved that stuff around.
Stairway to heavens!. Walking from town to Sacsayhuaman is worth the climb. You will be rewarded with a fascinating piece of history.

Great ruins. We came here as part of a city tour and were not disappointed. We had already seen many ruins but these stones were huge and it is amazing how they managed to fit them all together over such a vast area. We had a tourist ticket so the price of entry was already covered. I would recommend a visit here.

Not to be missed. Everyone has heard of Machu Picchu but many have not heard of Sacsayhuaman. It is amazing. It does not have the dramatic scenery of MP but it is easy to get to and the architecture is amazing...quite different than MP. You stand in awe at the size of the stones and the jigsaw fit of each one...no mortar.it's fantastic and not to be missed!

Sacsayhuaman. Very nice piece of history in Peru, did not like it the guide referred to it as sexy woman, and not Sacsayhuaman, culturally incorrect on his native culture, as I am fro Hawaii and would rather learn ethnic place names as they are not as foreigners are able to pronounce. All in all, very rich culture.
Incredible!!. We took a private tour to Sacsayhuaman during our stay in Cusco. And we wonder how the Incas build that spectacular side.Great view of the city.
Close Ruins. Great ruins just on the outskirts of Cusco. The Pre Inca and Inca engineering, building, customs and beliefs are second to none.Loved this
A must see in Cusco. A perfect place to start learning about the Incas. The rock terraces are made from stones that size of a bus. How did the Incas move them about?

Fortress remnants....... Heck of a hike up to Sacsayhuaman. Entry is pricy for what you get. Over time, much of the stonework has been re-used for local homes. We skirted the entry and walked down the paved edge.
