Gorgeous ruins!!. It is just a wonder looking at these ruins built so long ago. I could never do that type of work so it leaves me in awe. It was a gorgeous place and had lots of great places to take pictures. It is very close to the statue of christ.

This Wonder is truly worth a visit. Having visited many times over my history of 30 years in Peru, I can honestly speak from personal experience as well as the comments our travelers that visiting Sacsayhuaman is a must do when you are in Cusco. I strongly suggest having a very knowledgeable guide who knows the more out of the way and special areas here and take your time to enjoy this site and some of its connecting sites. I also recommend that Cusco and the surrounding areas should be visited on the back end of your time. It is higher than the Sacred Valley and Machu Picchu so we feel that in order to get the most enjoyment (less chance of soroche) have your Cusco tours on the way back and before you move on to your next destination or head back to Lima to go home.
It's a stop on the day trip. The day tours stop here. There are some Llama and Alpaca, but the site pales in comparison to the nearby sites in the Sacred Valley, Inca Trail, and Machu Piccu

Spectacular. It's a great hike up to this place from Cusco. A little practice run if you are doing the inca trail. It's worth the visit. It's very different to what we saw on the trail. Superb strucures out of massive stone and the best view of Cusco. Highly recommend

Worth the wait. When we first arrived at the gate there was an unexpected downpour which did not look like ceasing forcing us to turn away. We then returned the next morning to a bright sunny beautiful day and boy was it worth it. Keep time on hand to explore the various small sites, walk around and simply bask in the marvel of the engineering and thoughts of the era gone by. Huge stones had been moved without the help of modern day earth movers to create this marvellous structure.

Best place to appreciate Inca stone carving in Cusco. We toured Sacsayhuaman (our guide told us that it is pronounced sexy woman) on an overcast afternoon and we were nearly alone in this amazing space. It's huge - you will get a good walk in and may be tired from the altitude but it is simply the best place to see the incredible ancient stone walls of the Incas.These huge stones fit together perfectly with no mortar and seemingly no space between them. And they are huge...Stonehenge sized...and beautifully crafted. It is mind-boggling to think of how the Incas could build these temples but they did and Sacsayhuaman is testament to the Inca craftsmanship. We loved the llamas that keep the grass mowed.
Worth the visit.. Take around 2 hours for a visit. If you want you can take a guide ("waiting" at the entrance). Enjoy the great building - and watch (live or in youtube) the intiraymi....

Excellent ruin overlooking Cusco. Sacsayhuaman was a very interesting ruin, unlike any of the others I saw while in Peru. The stone work is remarkable and the sheer size of the stones in the walls is unbelievable! The Incas were brilliant with stonework and water management. (among other things) This site is not to be missed if you like the stone work of the Incas, the unique zig-zag fortress is beautiful, and though a good hike up from central Cusco, I great place to look out over the city as well!
Fascinating. Fascinating Incan ruins in Cusco, apparently a central government facility. How on earth did they move and cut these stones? This is worth a 30 minute visit.

tour guide is key. Tour guide gives more context and appreciation to the site. Fun to get up the ruins and explore. Certainly easier early in day, with fewer people. Does get crowded on the climb up/down.

Well worth the visit!. Better construction than Machu Picchu, but heavily mind to construct Cusco. There is plenty still here to appreciate the craftsmanship of the Incas. Great view of Cusco. 10 soles taxi ride from a hotel at the foot of the "hill". I strongly recommend hiring a guide (inside the entrance) for 50 soles to better appreciate what you are looking at.

Amazing Inca site not to be missed.. Second time seeing Saqsaywaman and it is no less impressive. Amazing engineering feat by the Inca builders. Give yourself at least 1-2 hours as it is worthwhile seeing the site from the top to see the zig-zag walls as well as from the lawn at the base to see the huge stone blocks. A must see when in Cusco!

As interesting as Machu Picchu. We had a 1/2 day city tour with Condor Travel and this made the visit memorable. Sacsayhuaman runis are definitely worth a visit if you are in Cusco. Great views of the city below, herd of alpaca in the meadow so we got some great animal shots. Of course, learning the history was fascinating.

amazing place. Huge archaeological area with easy trails, caves and stunning views. By the entrance huge displays allow you to learn a lot about the Inca dynasty and the Inca masonry. But just walking around you can admire these ruins and the surrounding nature.

steep walk up. We were staying in Plaza de Armas which is about a 20 minute walk up if you know the correct route through town. Lucky for us, we found a taxi driver that found a short cut and got us there for cheap. we walked around the beautiful ruins and some lots of alpaca roaming. worth the visit here.

Amazing & Bad service. We arrived at the early morning, good wether, not so many people.
A perfect day to explore this place, and it was!
It so interesting and medical!
The ruins expressive, the rocks, the walls, WoW!!
Bet when you talk about service, here it's the problem of this place.
Not enough information, map, and the restroom.. There no T.P.

Just walk! (or jog). Sacsayhuamen is awesome! I actually saw a few falcons. It is an easy walk, or jog if you are good with the altitude, from most joints in Cusco. Do as the locals do, and pack a light book/ snack. See it squirrely early in the morning, to beat the crowds. I visited several times while staying in Cusco. It was a beautiful, inspiring, morning hang.

Inca ruin. Very impressive though went here after Machu Picchu, so there is no comparison. From higher road in taxi, it was even more impressive. Had a little altitude sickness that day despite 3 days in Sacred Valley and 2 at Macchu Picchu and hiking Huaynupicchu; so might have enjoyed it more if feeling a little better.

Very impressive, a must see. We visited Sacsayhuaman during a day excursion from Cusco. We travelled by mini-van with a very knowledgable guide who explained the history and background of the area and I would recommend the use of a guide to make the most of a visit. Sacsayhuaman was the historical capital of the Inca Empire. The stone work is perfect and it is difficult to see how such perfection could be achieved even if modern techniques were used. The dry stone walls are made of huge stones by workers who carefully cut the boulders to fit together without mortar. Sections of the walls were built about 1100. The site was added to UNESCO's World Heritage List in the 1980's. Well worth a visit, particularly if a guide is with you.

Inca ruin just outside Cusco. Worth a cab ride or local tour. Not overwhelming, but engaging ruin and nice place to relax, read and soak it all in. Also, walkable to the White Christ and the scenic overlook of Cusco.
Beautiful ruins just above Cusco. The road up there has a wonderful view of the city. And we loved wandering around the ruins and learning more about the ancient civilization that lived there.

Walk up and down and stay until dusk. We took a taxi ride from downtown, but the walk uphill from San Cristobal church was easy enough and you get views of Cusco as an extra. The walk down was very rewarding, on the same path, even with low light.The views where you get the best idea of its size are in the hill north of the big grass terrace. It's not very high but you get enough perspective. If you extend the visit until late afternoon most people will leave and you may be left alone with a herd of llamas.

An absolute mus. I guess this is included in mosttours but if not you really must go here. Apart from the spectacular views across the city you get a jaw-dropping realisation of how clever the Incas were.

Worth a visit if you have lots of time. We passed Sacsayhuaman on the city bus tour. It looked very interesting and certainly worth further investigation if you have the time. The bus tour gives a great overall expiation of the place and you see it from several sides.

walk to it! Also, beware of horse ride scams. It's about 15 minute walk , very safe, beautiful views. No need to take a taxi or ( much worse) be bused in.At the entrance, there are different gusy at different tiems of the day. They speak English and show you very professional looking brochures about seeing all the ruins including Sachsayhuman on horse tour. They're scammers. I wasn't interested in horses, so I said no. And then the guy who checks tickets and heard all the conversation pointed me to a sign on Boleto turistico "No horses" - no horses are allowed at any of those sites.As to the ruins - absolutely amazing and highly recommended.

Not Just Another Pile of Stones. Well, it is a pile of stones, but an impressive one. Check out the zigzag pattern of some of the walls. Also note the beautiful landscape surrounding the site. Supposedly you can walk from the Plaza de Armas in Cusco to this site, but unless you have been in the area awhile, I would not attempt it - the altitude is very high and even the shortest journey can be exhausting.
Sacsayhuaman. A great site to visit before going to Macchu Picchu. You are able to see different Inka building styles.

Great warm-up hike and view of Cusco. This was a great warm-up hike for those doing a multi-day hike to Machu Picchu. It has a great ariel view of Cusco and it's fun to see the ruins and there's a "Inca slide" near the back that can be fun to slide down. Make sure to hike to the Christo statue too!

A Must See. This is an impressive place to simply visit, but a knowledgeable guide who can explain the history and background will greatly increase your appreciation of the visit. There is also a nice panoramic view of Cusco from here.
Inca Treasure. This is a great site to visit if you have a few days in Cusco. Get a guide for this one. Amazing stone work that differs from the other sites.

A must, specially since its so close to the city.. You just HAVE to visit Sacsayhuaman. It was an important Citadel built during the Inca Empire. It is a huge place, where a series of complex structures were built using gigantic stones. It really takes your breath away. Sacsayhuaman is also the place where modern peruvians celebrate the Inti Raymi now, which is a spectacle to behold (it is held on 24 June every year). You also can go there during the third sunday of September if you want to behold the "Warachikuy", another important festival.All in all, a place you just cannot miss on your visit to Cusco.
Amazing place!. The huge stones at Sacsayhuman makes you wonder how the Incas managed to get them here. Your imagination runs wild at the events that were held here. A must see if you go to Cusco
Inca site worth visiting. Good to get a guide and will spend at least an hour at this place. The history is great. Be prepared to climb steps. One of the must visit sites when you go to Cusco
Amazing!. So amazing to see the ruins of the Incan people! And there is an awesome view overlooking Cuzco. I would highly recommend this to anyone!

Impressive! Good hike!. Very impressed with the ruins. It was also good training to acclimate before our hike to Salkantay. Start at Plaza de Armas and walk up the hill to Sacsayhuaman. Just don't forget your money like we did because the nearest ATM is back down in the plaza!

Larger than expected. This Inca site contains large carved stones comparable in size to those found at Stonehenge in England. It is a massive wall. The area is near a large statue of Christ and one can have a panoramic view of Cuzco from this overlook. Outside the ruins are native locals waiting to have you take their picture while they hold small lambs or stand with alpacas or llamas - they like some soles but are very accomodating .

saw a lot of al pacco. It was very good.. It was a nice hike back to Cusco overlooking the city. Right outside of the hike there was an interesting church and they were selling boiled corn with cheese. It was delicious.
Worth a visit. The ruins are worth a visit, because of the view of the city of Cusco from the top and the big rocks with which the Incas built the place.

Amazing. It is being part of this rich culture of Inca when you visit Sacsayhuaman. While visiting make sure you have an able guide with you to tell you the amazing stories behind these complex structures and as my guide and many reviews have pointed out, Stonehenge has got nothing over theses beautiful and articulate structures. If you are well versed with the history then the fun is double fold

Stunning stone work, but pace yourself at altitude. Sacsayhuaman showcases the stunning quality of Incan stonework. The blocks of stone are huge yet the spaces between the stones are straight and tight. Truly one of the marvels of Incan civilization. The structure is in the shape of the jaws of a jaguar which can really only be appreciated after climbing some steps. At almost 12,000 feet above sea level (the top of Vail, Colorado is 11,000 feet), those 100+ steps will take the wind out of you unless you take the time to acclimate first. So, see Sacsayhuaman after spending at least one night in Cusco. (They sell tiny bottles of oxygen at the Cusco Airport for a reason.)

Beautiful place with a fascinating history. This was one of my favorite days in Cusco. This archeological site is truly impressive, though the experience is significantly augmented by hiring a guide. When my group arrived, we were about unsure when approached by a woman asking if we wanted a tour, but ultimately we decided to go for it and I can't even imagine how much we would have missed without her informative guidance. I actually learned more from her about Incan society, religion, and history than from the guide we had at Machu Picchu! The site also offers breathtaking views of Cusco from above.

Good if you are planning to visit other nearby sites. I have nothing bad to say about Sacsayhuaman specifically; it is an interesting archaeological site that also provides excellent views of Cusco city. However, the price of admission is really only worth it if you plan on visiting the other Incan sites in the area.

Lots to see but it is at high altitude so take things slowly. This park area is situated above Cusco so it is very high. The views are great from the Christ the Redeemer statue. Ancient inca walls dot the area and there are plenty of walking opportunities for those fit enough.

complex and elegant masterpiece. if you know what you are looking at then you will be able appreciate this marvelous craftsmanship that was created even before the discovery of modern tools. The guide with us was really helpful in explaining everything to us and gave us an impressive tour of the place. One should not miss out on this adventure while in Cusco

Wow!. My husband and I hiked from the center of the city of Cusco to visit this archeological site. What an amazing place! If you are visiting Cusco, you have to visit this site. If you don't feel up to walking, there are buses or cabs that can get you to the entrance. Don't miss it!!

Beautiful views. Definitely worth a visit. The town below is cosy and relaxing, we are now in Cuzco and we are glad we spent 3 days in the village away from literally crowds. Go for a walk to villages nearby often this and don't forget to climb the TOP! Yes! Those ruins on top.

Worth It!. This is a must when you visit Cusco. Climb the road from town up, up, up the hill towards "Christo Blanco" and you'll find an amazing set of Incan ruins. The entrance fee to these ruins (and all the ruins in Peru) are expensive but that's what you're there for so whip out your wad of soles (Peruvian money) and pay the toll. Note that, if you are going to go to other ruins (Olytytambo etc.) make sure you get the multi-location pass. You'll save money for sure. Anyway, back to the "Sexy Human" (what the guides call it for fun) ruins. They are really beautiful. Set in a large flat plateau above the city, they offer wonderful views of Cusco and a great taste of the amzaing ruins in all of Peru. When you leave, continue walking on the same road over the mountain (don't retrace your steps down the hill again) and then cut down the steep staircase into town. You cannto get lost and although it looks sketchy, it's very safe. When you get down past some ramshackle houses, you'll come out into a warren of shops and cafes that are really cute with some great arts and crafts. Enjoy! Peru is the bomb!

Must See!. This is one of the key Incan sites. I didn't appreciate it as much as I should have due to the altitude sickness but after visiting Machu Picchu I realized that the rock structures here are some of the most impressive.
Wonderful ruins. I was very impressed by the site and how well kept it is. The view is also gorgeous!!! We didn't have any money for a guide but I'm sure it would have been worth it.
Incredible. This place is incredible. Everything is made by stone and its very close to the city. It´s highly recommended.

Really cool sight. Sacsayhuaman is a cool pre curser to Machu Picchu. The stones are interesting and touring the site is easy and wont exhaust you. The site is just outside of Cusco so it's a quick drive.
Good for a Walk Through. An interesting archaeological location, but it is worth just a walk through. You need a taxi to reach this from the downtown area.

Quite impressive and more accessible than Maccu Picchu. It is a cyclopian style ancient construction near Cusco. We had a beautiful day on this trip and enjoyed it greatly. The guide remarked that Erich Von Daniken visited this site in confirmation of his theory of alien visitors involved in Earth's history, but was obviously skeptical about it. You may become a believer when standing near 125 tons boulders neatly placed among smaller but still considerably heavy rocks into long walls. Mind bugling! Some smaller sites nearby were also interesting. There is apparently a combo ticket that includes about a dozen of sites around Cusco and Urubamba valley, so if you explore on your own or get a couple of tours you may get this ticket.
Incredible big rocks and nice views. Went on a tour, everything good, far away bathrooms but nice open place and arqueological incredible.

Another impressive Inca site. You can access Sacsayhuaman either via foot (hiking up there) or by bus, which will drop you off right at the site. I believe there is a small nominal fee to enter. The huge incredible stone work shouts Inca! The lush green grass and terraces is also very impressive. Take your time when you do arrive because it is higher altitude than Cusco, so don't pus it. Once you work your way to the highest point of Sacsayhuaman you will be treated to an amazing view of the historical Cusco city center! Please Enjoy!
Amazing HUGE stones. You can walk here from the center of Cusco (OK, hike up here), but it's well worth a visit. The massive stones alone are awe-inspiring and the city view is terrific.

An Inca site worth visiting. We toured Sacsayhuaman during our stay in Cusco before starting the Choquequirao trek. The ruins are large and very interesting. However, it is best to visit before visiting Machu Pichu or Choquequirao as they are much larger and more interesting. There are several other interesting Inca sites near Cusco that are included in most of the offered City Tours.

Impressive!. According to my tour guide, British tourists have told him that Stonehenge is "kindergarten" compared to Sacsayhuaman. Boulders up to 30tons are quarried and brought here. Block by block they were carved and chiseled to fit each other perfectly like Legos with interlocking systems. The space between each boulder is so tight rainwater doesn't even seep through. All this amazing construction is done with only stone tools. It has been theorized that Sacsayhuaman might have been used as a fort, or a monument to attest to the greatness of the Incan empire. The shape of it is supposed to be an outline of a puma's head from aerial view.This area is just huge and there are ruins on the opposite side of the walls too. On the hills you may find an alpaca/llama herd grazing. We took pictures with them and they were friendly. You can walk amongst them too but as with all livestock don't get too close. A different tour guide told us that behind the walls there are underground tunnels suspected to lead to other Sun temples or buried treasures. Nobody has anything definitive because the tunnels are so complex many explorers have perished.
Impressive. One of the many stops with my group. Another example of the past Inca culture. Enjoyed the vista above the complex, but you get a better understanding when walking through it.

Amazing Inca Masonry. Wandering lamas and alpacas. Great views of Cusco. Worth a wander with a guide. The one we hired for 40 soles was nice enough, but her English was useless and her explanations in Spanish were not to impressive either. I should have vetted her a little more carefully before hiring her at entrance to site.

Warm up for Machupicchu. Was part of a tour and well worth the visit. The site & size of building rocks were amazing. Nearby is another short walk which takes you through caves. Include this as well while there.

Stonehenge meets the pyramids. Visited here with tour guide and Sacsayhuaman is colossal. You have to wonder at the achievement, with many monster rocks, perfectly fitting into the rocks around them. If you think Stonehenge is amazing, Sacsayhuaman is stonehenge x 1000.Not to be missed. Take your wide-angle camera.Some maps & guide books suggest this can be walked to, and easily, from Cusco town centre. Don't believe it, you'll need transport to get there & back; tour bus, or rent a minivan.

Spiritual Ruins. The Spiritual Ruins and large stone walls are impressive. I centered myself and walked in the caves with an open heart willing to feel the energy of the Ruins. Science informs us that we are made of energy. Faith tells us that our souls (energy) are felt by othersI enjoy visiting places with a historical energy.

Amazing Incan Ruins. The magnitude of this site was almost unfathomable. The alpacas that inhabit it were fun to see. Some of the stones you wondered how they got them on top of each other and they fit perfectly. Amazing views down to the City of Cuzco.

Very worthwhile. This is a great way to spend your 1-2 days of altitude acclimatization in Cuzco. The park gives you top-down perspective of the city and valley. It is also a way to get up-close to Inca ruins in a way that you could never do in the US. Go during Inti Raymi, and get another experience altogether with a cultural festival to blow your mind.

Very impressive. Visiting this Inca ruin was not part of our plan but we wanted to do a city tour and this was included. Partly glad that we stumbled upon this because the ruin was impressive! On how they were able to fit the rocks together without mortars and how these huge rocks were transported and moved was impressive!Tip: I would have been hugely interested in this tour if I was not dealing with altitude acclimatization issues the entire time. We just arrived that morning and immediately did this tour. Be warned! Rest when you arrive to acclimatize and then do this tour. Even when you feel you are ok since you are taking altitude pills, you will find out how "not ok" you are at the altitude once you climb the steps to see this ruin! How I wish that I did this the next day so I could have asked a lot of questions since I am hugely interested in archaeology and engineering.

If you like an old ruin you'll love this. It's easy to get used to the scale and engineering skill of the Incas when doing the sights around Cusco. Sacsayhuaman is another example of the immensity of a project which our guide says took 50,000 people 50 years to complete. Certainly makes you wonder......how, and why...

Breathtaking Vistas and Confounding Mysteries. This "citadel" was the last tour at the end of a what you might call a mind-numbing week of visiting one world wonder after another, beginning with the ruins and terraces at Pisaq, and on to the majesty of Ollantaytambo, followed by circular terraced agricultural testing grounds at Moray, then to Machu Picchu, then to the miracle of Coricancha, finally to the enigma that is Saqsaywaman- whose meaning is uncertain- "marbled falcon" or "marbled head," being two of the more likely meanings. Indeed the site appears to have been intended to represent the head of the puma whose body was represented by the layout of the city Cusco itself. From an open plaza that was painstakingly cleared to make room for important rituals set in between mounts that were shored up by zigazagging walls of stone transported from 3 kilometers away, whose largest stones weigh more than 60 tons (how did they move them?) to the foundations of twin towers overlooking the city of Cusco itself, there is more to take in than can be comprehended in one sitting.
Wow. Taxi up to the park and the walk down was so much fun, not only the parks but the people going about their daily lives as we passed.
Sacsayhuamn tour. It was a great tour and would recommend it if in Cuzco, lady was there with her Alpaca and for a small tip you can get ur picture, they stink but are cute!
Worth a visit. This site is well worth a visit.Impressive construction, finest building technique using monster rocks.Excellent view of the city from the hill, easily climbed.As always, carry water.

the fun thing about this is its pronounced "Sexy Woman". Which I can totally identify with :). There is not a lot there so getting literature about the location is crucial to understanding why this is important. We had a guide so that was helpful - also got to see the "lawnmowers" (alpaca) in action with their shepard. Cool.

Incredible stonework. A great Inka site not far from Cusco. The stonework here is absolutely incredible, with monoliths the size of those at Stonehenge. Well laid out park-like setting, a real pleasure to visit. .

Ruins in a big open space - with llamas!!. I liked that these ruins weren't squashed into an urban area but spread out so that we could experience them more naturally. Also liked the juxtaposition of a huge Jesus in the background of my photos of the site. As with other Incan sites, a draw is the incredible engineering.

Awesome Ruin!. This is an impressive site high above Cusco. Unfortunately only a part of this fortress still stands as much of the original was destroyed by the Spanish and parts hauled away to build other structures. Some of the rocks weigh up to 360 tons and are precisely fitted together to form walls that extended over 300 yards. The rocks were moved into place using log sleds, levers and lots of manual labor. Hard to imagine the size and magnitude of the original.

Amazing site, one of the must see's when visiting Cuzco. This is a beautiful site but even higher than Cuszo's 11,500 feet - here you are at 12,500 feet. so you may want to have altitude pills handy and drink a lot of water before doing this tour. We arrived in Cuzco and headed out to here the first day. we were huffing and puffing on all of the climbing. We are flat landers from Florida. The ruins are very impressive and well maintained. No facilities inside!
Great historical place. Although it was smaller than expected, the archaeological place is great, well kept and is worth the time.

A great introduction into the Inca Ruins. Sacsayhuaman is pronounced "Sexy Woman." I kid you not...lol... It's a great spot to see some of the Inca ruins. I was introduced to it by the Free Walking Tour.

Impressive for the 60-100 ton stones. A site ... temple or fortress? (as with most Inca'n artifacts, no one really knows) ... impressive for the 60-100 ton stones used to build it. 40 minutes for a walk around will suffice.

Amazing site, one the must see in a visit to the Cusco region. The site is near Cusco and is part of any half day tour of the Cusco Surroundings, or the full day tour, it is a must see place, and just admire the engineering of the location.Try to climb to see the water reservoirs.

impressive. This is a beautiful site but even higher than Cusco so you may want to acclimate before doing this tour. We did it our first day assuming the city tour would be on a bus and we were huffing and puffing on all of the climbing but we are from Florida. The ruins are very impressive and well restored. I highly recommend this.
Great Experience . This was a great adventure. Awesome to see how the Incas built the temple. Definitely breathtaking and great views of the city!

Construction marvel. Awed by construction and beauty of site. We hiked up from Plaza de Armas which is very doable and gets you used to altitude. Only negative I is cost of tourist bolleto. Used to getting an interpretive brochure. Non so you will pay for tour guide who are standing at gates for you. That is the only negative I had of Cusco was the constant haranguing to,purchase something but I know they are just trying to make a living.
Breathtaking. Beautiful place, with huge rocks that take your breath away. You have to go there, try to walk there, it has another view...
Just Do It. So much to see here. The rock walls and ruins are something to behold. Make sure you get there early before the crowds and to get the most of this site make sure you have a guide.

Excellent. I might need to remind some basic facts... Inca sure is an old civilization very interesting to study and to discover. Yes in Peru we can see inca ruins (or even ruins of an older civilization : nazcas) but the Incas built a lot of their foundations on older ruins that people have no idea where they come from, we just know they had been there before incas. We don't even know how those foundations were built because some rocks weight something around 20 tons.In Sacsayhuaman we can totally see the difference between the inca's foundations and the "older/mysterious/not-human?" foundations. Those latter are just too huge and too perfectly cut and put together to have been built by humans ages ago.This is what makes this place special, we can't stop wondering how (and by who) those foundations (that were used by the incas, but they had been there before) were built.AWESOME place.
great historic site. the work that the incas did with stone blocks is amazing and everywhere around the andes. this site was located just above cusco. worth visiting.
Yes. do visit. either walking all the way from downtown. far but good excercise or by taking one of the tours from the town..
Handicapped. It is fairly accessible in wheelchair.The area has grass.To be expected certain areas are not accessible .

Beautiful and impressive site with panoramic views of Cusco. A great introduction to the Incan ruins around Cusco and for helping to orientate oneself with regard to the city, using the panoramic views from the top.Marvel at the intricate construction and use of massive stonesThen enjoy the panoramic views of the city and the Cristo Blanco (White Jesus) statue situated on the next hill.

What it must have been...... If you are at all interested in history and architecture then you must go here while in the Cusco area. As with other Inca sites, the stonework will amaze you. HUGE stones that still fit together like a glove after hundreds of years and major earthquakes, can only imagine what it looked like before the Spanish destroyed it.As with any major archeological site, best explored with a guide who can give insights that you would not get on your own.

Hire a Guide!. These ruins are excellent and were made even more interesting because of our guides. I think not having a guide would be be very limiting. Make sure you devote at least 3-4 hours to this experience.

Beautiful Site. This was the first ruin I saw on my Peru trip. It was truly amazing! The tour guide showed a picture of how the ruins would look like before it was destroyed. Use your imagination and you will discover how beautiful it once was (although it still is today).

Howdid they do this?. The remains of this Inca fortress are astounding. Composed of massive stones that were brought there by human power, you only have to use your imagination to consider how this was built and used. Take a knowledgeable guide with you.

Stupendous building. The skill of the Incas in stone masonry and building was astonishing. It puts Stonehenge in the shade, including how they transported stones up to 250 tones in weight the 35km from the quarry.

Ancient Inca Wonder. This is an amazing site. To think of the battle that took place here between the Spanish and Incas five hundred years ago. What a magnificent empire the Incas had. One can easily imagine the events that took place here. The incas were a proud people and their ancestors should be proud. This site is easy to remember - it is pronounced sexy human!!

A must if you are in Cusco. The ruins are very close to Cusco and transportation is readily available. They provide an interesting insight into Inca culture and skills - obviously not to the extent of Machu Pichu - but nevertheless impressive. As with other such spots in Peru, there are souvenir sellers in abundance, but none of the aggressive salesmanship you fiind in so many other countries. The visit was truly a memorable experience.

Sacsayhuaman is a very amazing site with huge stones in the walls of the structures.. It's an amazing sight to see! The stone walls go on and on and the size of the pieces of stone in these walls raises the same questions that arise while looking at Machu Picchu. How did the Incas do this and did it work?The Spanish Conquistadors did attach the Incas here and finally defeated them. The history told here is another chapter in the eventual downfall of the Incas. You will find this site of interest and another part of the puzzle of the Incas.

Do not miss this!. Some people had written this was outside the city, it is not. We walked here from our hotel which was next to Qurikancha. The walk up is strap, but don't worry, it's not too long. We currently live in the mountains of Medellin and are a semiprofessional athlete and an equally fit individual. If you are coming from a low altitude or consider yourself out of shape, give yourself a day to acclimate to the altitude of possible. You will enjoy it more. The vendors at the bottom sell sodas and coca snacks, you may need these. You have to buy a pass to multiple attractions in the city, there is no option for just Sacsayhuaman. However, it is well worth it, even if it's the only one of the attractions you are able to make it to. Bring you ur camera, the skies are breathtaking and the ruins are incredible. Paired together-increadible beauty you'll remember for the rest of your life.There are wild dogs all around that pop up out of nowhere-but they're friendly and mostly leave you alone, don't worry about them. There are women with llamas at the top you can take your picture with. They have baby llamas in tiny hats too. If you're into that kind of thing.

Sacsayhuaman. We were impressed with the size and weight of the boulders used to construct this site. The boulders were taken from a quarry about 2 kilometers away and transported to the top of the hill overlooking Cusco. The boulders were either dragged by workers or rolled using tree logs as rollers under the stones. A couple of the largest boulders were estimated at 180 tons and 80 tons. Like all the ruins, it is a lot of up and down walking, but worthwhile.
very interesting things rip with excellently t guide. Time to ask questions, guides all spoke English, enjoyed all. Llamas wandering about, few sights taken in on trip

Brilliant bit of history in the heart of Cusco. A great way to spend the afternoon -- after a good and beautiful walk from the center of Cusco, we reached an amazing site which included historical ruins, alpacas/llamas, close-up view of the statue of Christ and great views overlooking Cusco and the nearby mtns - perfect spot for taking photos. I definitely recommend including a visit to Sacsayhuaman during any Cusco stay.

The "Sexy-Woman" Experience. I had to title my review this way, as that is what I thought our guide was saying the ENTIRE time we were there. This place is a great way to learn about the Inka ways of architecture. The landscape and the explanation behind the great stone walls is fantastic. If you're into History, architecture and lore, this is the place for you.There may even be opportunities for llama photos out here. And if you want to take your photo with a "traditionally dressed woman" and her animals, be prepared to tip them however much you can in soles. They DO expect it.

Sacsayhuaman. Sacsayhuaman is an incredible introduction to may other marvels of the Incas. The stones are massive and the walking is very easy. It is in all the Spanish textbooks, but much more impressive in person!
Beautiful views wonderful history. love the ancient artefacts, rolling green landscape. The terrain was easy to manoeuvre and the tour guide was very knowledgeable and attentive

awesome ruins. spectacular! Great introduction to any Machu Picchu trip. amazing Inka architecture and rock work. Easily accessible to Cusco and hiking back to town. Take a taxi up and walk back via an inka trail into San Blas

Amazing stone work, beautiful grasses, funds slides!. Visit Sacsayhuaman for sure, it is very easy to access from anywhere in Cusco and has the best stonework of any of the other Incan ruins we saw in the sacred valley!
Very nice and not far from the city. I took a taxi to the place and walked down to the city. It has some impressive architecture and a nice view of the Cuzco.

Impressive Inca fortress. A great place to visit while staying in Cusco. An impressive construction plus a great view of the city from the top.
I was "lucky" enough to stumble upon another attraction - a big spider (see the photo) just roaming the sandy paths of the site. Nice!
Awesome bigass stones. I love the megaliths! So amazing how they have stood the test of time and earthquake. The Cristo Blanco statue is a little weird but the archeology is worth the trip.

make a stop. I was told by a friend to make sure I visited "sexy woman" [easier to say]. So glad I did. Discovered only n 1986, this is an amazing site. Naturally they are still working on excavating--will be very exciting to see what else they discover.

Self-guided tour of Cusco's Incan ruins. We did a self-guided tour of Sacsayhuaman, Qenqo, Tambomachay and Puka Pukara and found it to be easy and affordable. 1) Took taxi to Sacsayhuaman. 2) Hired English-speaking guide at ruins for an excellent private tour. 3) Walked to Qenqo (15 minute stroll). 4) Took local Senor del Huerto bus to Tambomachay (usually a blue van that says Senor del Huerto on the front). 5) Walked around Tambomachay and Puka Pukara. 6) Took Senor del Huerto back to Cusco. The bus was 1 sol each way, taxi was 10 soles I think, guide was perhaps 40 soles for the tour. Definitely got local color on the bus, with standing room only, sick dog on the way to the vet and wide range of ages. We had decent Spanish skills in our group to ask people where to wait for the bus.
Excellent site, a must see when in Cusco. We went up to this site around sunset. No people, it was amazing. the ruins are in great shape and I enjoyed our tour of the various sites
Beautiful setting and view. We visited here at sunset and it was lovely. The ruins are interesting too, but do not compare to Machu Picchu.

Great Views & Pleasant Walk. The lush grounds provide a great place to walk, take in excellent views of the city & the hills and its an overall pleasant place to be. I enjoyed my time here greatly. There were llamas just roaming and the greenery is just very beautiful. The walk up here from Cusco is very charming with brick layed streets and local shops you pass along the way. The views were very nice and it is an iconic place to visit. This would be a great place to spend an afternoon. There are also local women who set up little booths by the statue to sell locally made goods.

A great cusco stop. We went directly from our flight to see. It was well worth the stop. It takes about an hour to walk the sight. An easy walk for most people. There was a scenic view of the city of cusco below

Must see whilst in Cusco. Go hear early to avoid the crowds and for spectacular views over the city of Cusco. The Inca fortress is impressive - although we went without a guide so had use our imagination. We were struggling a little with the altitude but managed OK. There are also some tame alpaca roaming around which was fun for photographs. Recommend taking a local taxi both ways. There were several 'taxis' waiting outside when we left and its with it for the steep descent down a narrow cobbled street in a clapped out Fiat!

Worth a trip. Worth the 10 min drive/30 ish minute walk from the old section of Cusco. Great ruins, wonderful examples of Incan engineering and structural planning with great attention to detail and movements of the sun.

Do not miss out on this! . Breathtaking ruins - we went early and beat the crowds. You can really see the craftsmanship of the Incas at this site. Magnificent views of the Christ statue and Cusco. Tip for all of Cusco - get the Boleto Turistico - it's a city pass to most of the major sites. You can get online (if you can read Spanish) or at one of the sites. It is a great value.
Must visit!. 15 mins taxi drive from Cusco, will cost only $5 but make sure you have the Boleto Truistic.Place is amazing...open space... good rike, best go after you get use to the altitude...

Llamas amid ancient ruins. An ancient Inka site perfect for strolling and marvelling at the incredible stone workmanship of the Inkas while inrteracting with friendly llamas in an attractive park like setting

Amazing work. The most impressive thing about Sacsayhuaman is the amount of work that must have gone into the shaping and laying of the huge stonewalls. The large boulders had been shaped to fit into each other with amazing precision. Doing it with extremely large wooden chunks would have been very difficult but how they did it with such stone pieces is mind boggling. We had the services of a guide who was provided by Condor Travel and his knowledge greatly enhanced the tour of this site.

unbelievable stonework. We had only a short time here, but it was amazing to see the huge rocks and how they fit so perfectly together. The views from either viewpoint were also amazing. It is interesting to think of how they got those huge stones in place there!
impressive. How did they move those big rocks?? But Machu Picchu was life changing, spiritual, I wouldn't put this in that league. View of Cusco was great--Iove that city.
Huge Rocks in Little City. Great place to visit and see huge rocks that are Pre-Inca era. The shape of the little city is similar to a lightening bolt and fun to walk around.

Best as part of a tour. It was fantastic to see inca ruins so close and admire the audacity of the builders. I would recommend having a private tour, it will most likely be included, but they offer a lot of local insight, inca history, and flavor to the ruins.
A nice warm up to Macchu Picchu!. If you have a few days in Cusco I would highly recommend this trek as a start. It still has very cool architecture and lots of alpacas!

A great way to escape from Cuzco. Just a short walk from San Blas, this site is well worth a visit. The Inka walls are stunning, and it can be quite quiet if you get there early. It is worth seeing alongside other sites to get context.

Excellent examples of Inca stonework. This is an amazing place. First, it is one of the few Inca ruins where we can definitively say, "this event happened there on this date," since it was the scene of a major battle in one of the Inca rebellions. This is quite a rarity, since the Incas didn't leave a lot of written records (for example, millions of people visit Machu Picchu but we don't even know why it was built or have any record of a single event that occurred there). Second, it's architecturally very impressive. Finally, it's a nice place to walk around. It definitely helps to have read something about the Incas, their architecture, and the struggle against the conquistadors. Or you could take a guide. The one downside to ALL of the Inca ruins around Cusco and the Valle Sagrado is that there is virtually no interpretive material on the sites. If you go expecting a sign at each structure speculating on what it was used for, or talking about design principles and techniques, you will be disappointed. There is nothing, anywhere. That having been said, if you do some reading in advance, or hire one of the guides, all of the ruins are an amazing experience. Also, it's cheap. I saw a lot of reviews in which reviewers were complaining about the price (130 soles is too much to pay, etc.). But the 130 soles isn't just for Sacsayhuaman - it's for the boleto turistico, which gets you into ten sets of ruins and three or four museums. That works out to about three dollars per site. I don't think this is expensive at all.

Awe inspiring. It is hard to imagine how in the world this magnificent structure was built so many hundreds of years ago with none of the tools we have nowadays and to see the sheer size of those perfectly cut rocks and boulders, tightly fitted with no mortar or cement to hold them in place, withstanding the various earthquakes that have occurred though the centuries.

Best city overlook spot!. Best city overlook spot! The view is absolutely amazing! This is walking distance from the Plaza de Armas, though it is uphill in high altitude, if you take your time its really not that bad of a hike (20-30 minutes). You don’t need to buy a tour you can visit the ruins for free but tours are available.

Pride of Cusco!. This huge ruin is close to central Cusco, and offers a glimpse of the incredible talent of the ancient people who inhabited this region. To view the well constructed fort, along with understanding the symbolism of the buildings, was a true education.

Blown away. Amazing place - we visited prior to going to Machu Pichu and were struck by the enormity of the site and the preciseness of the Inca structures. Peru is a wonderful country to visit, the people are friendly and proud, and the environment is very different to anything we have seen before.

Great Ruins Just outside of Cusco. This place is massive and it's 10-20 minute drive from the center of Cusco. It hosts the inka raymi Sun Festival. The place is massive and there is plenty of places to explore and look at the city.

Impressive. A site for which little is said in UK and the two guide books I read before travel . An impressive site which gives real ambience to the size of the task facing those early developers . the quarry aspects and considerable mounds give an impression of the huge development task which must have gone here .
Must visit when in Cuzco. Interesting place overlooking Cuzco. The story behind the place is as interesting as the scenery. Apply a lot of sunblock before going as it's open space.

sacsayhuaman visit. The ruins were awesome! The stonework was so impressive and the preservation is really good. Our guide did a great job. His name is Victor Torres and he is excellent. I was thoroughly impressed. Be ready for a gauntlet of hawkers at the end when you leave. They are aggressive in trying to sell you trinkets.

Ruins do not impress but the view of the city does. After seeing Machu pichu this site is not very impressive. However there are a few highlights such as the natural slides and the nice view of cusco city. Worth doing if having an extra half day, it's walkable from plaza de areas (20-30 min)'

More Fabulous Ruins. This is a very approachable archaeological site. Unlike Machu Picchu, there is not a tremendous amount of climbing and strenuous exercise with this, but you certainly get a good idea of day to day living. You are at considerable elevation so it's wise to take it slowly.

Nice construction. This is built like a fortress, the complex cover a huge area. What remains today are the astounding outer walls constructed in a zigzag formation on three levels. Like many Inca constructions, the walls are made of massive, irregularly shaped boulders that fit together like a jigsaw puzzle without the aid of mortar. The stones are so closely spaced that even a piece of paper cannot be inserted between the stones.

Land of the giants.. This is a place built with stones the size of trucks. I remember seeing an old black and white photo of them as a child in an enclycopedia. When you are there the size will bowl you over. The idea that humans moved and and fitted these stones in such a way that thousands of years latter you cannot fit a toothpick between them ! Look closely you maybe able to find the figures of animals in the shapes of the rocks fitted together, they are there! An amazing place a must see in the wonders of the world.

Ruins close to Cusco!. This site is included in your tourist boleto ticket to see the ruins around Cusco and the Sacred Valley.I would definitely say "go to Sacsayhuaman becuase you will be amazed at how the Inca's built this place". Sacsayhuaman definitely has the largest rocks of all the ruins in the Sacred Valley and Machu Picchu. Really unbelievable.Also going to Sacsayhuaman provides amazing views of Cusco from a higher elevation level. You will get amazing pictures of the city.A visit to Sacsayhuaman is provided in most Cusco city tours. The free walking tour provides a free bus to Sacsayhuaman,

Marvelous giant place. This place I think it is unique, all the blocks of rocks are giants, never I saw such a tremendous work to put together all those stones, we decided to take this tour with Kondor Path to get the acclimatization on the height Andes before our main hike, I think was a great decisions because a was not felling that if was difficult, one day exploring the area it is the best.

Feel the energy. Sacsayhuaman is a inca building full of magic and energy. The site is really interesting and located close to the city, you can go there just walking.Go to Sacsayhuaman and feel the positive energy, this is just a magical experience.
Amazing stone work. Excellent example of Inca stonework. Beautiful location above the red roofs of Cusco. A good preliminary to visiting Machu Picchu.

Neat visit. This is included if you buy the tourist card. We enjoyed this (and the entire Sacred Valley tour). This is a remarkable location and you stand in amazement at their ability to build something like this so long ago. Certainly do not want to leave this off of your Cusco trip!
History. Walk among the ruins and it is fascinating to see how these structures could have assembled entries ago, Great view of the countryside

Impressive ruins but not like Machu Picchu. We enjoyed our short tour of these Inca ruins. Since we had already seen many ruins in the Urumbamba Valley and at Machu Picchu, these did not appear as impressive, largely because there is little restoration. Unfortunately it took many years before the site was actually recognized for its historical significance and preserved so during the years stones were removed from the site. It's close to Cusco downtown so you should definitely stop by if you are in the area, however!

A must do in Cusco. This is the place where you can see the biggest and nicest real Inca walls. The place is impressive, as it is quite big. You can go there by foot from Cusco (via the old Inca trail), and if you want to have nice shots be sure to be there at the opening (7:00 am); large crowds of people may ruin your shots.Also, on the upper side of the site, there is a natural waterslide (no water, just rocks, but slides quite well); there is also a big "auditorium", that can be reached via a tunnel (very dark scary tunnel).After the visit you can come back to Cusco with lots of stairs via San Blas neighborhood.

Important Part Of Cusco Experience. Take the trouble to get up the hill to Sacsayhuaman, an impressive Inca structure not "contaminated" by Spanish colonial building around the ruins. It is here that you get a feel for the colossal dimension of the structures Inca engineers were able to design and construct with primitive tools.
Nice Incan ruins. Need to see this place while you are staying in Cusco. Take any city tour and this is included. You can see here the famous incan stones, perfectly cut. I recommend this place!

Quite interesting site. I had a very knowledgeable guide, Fabrizo to guide me through the site. The ruins were interesting and wonderful view of Cusco below. My guide showed me a cave that we walked through. However it was a bit creepy because as soon as you enter you can't see anything. It is completely dark until exiting the cave.
Nice view.. Lovely place but very similar to many other in peru. We didn't have much time to walk it all as the guide rushed us.

This lesser-known Incan ruin is amazing. I had not heard of this ruin before arriving in Cusco, and I was amazed at the scope and scale of the Incan vision for this site. The stones are enormous, and there were a lot of interesting features to explore. We spent about 2 hours here, which gave us an opportunity to explore at a relaxed pace. Great views of Cusco.

Worth it. Incredible site. Huge, many interesting aspects, lots of places to explore. Beautiful views. Great day trip. One of the coolest archaeological sites I visited in the Sacred Valley. Do not leave Cusco without visiting here. It is very easy to get to: we made a nice little trip by hiking up past the San Blas neighborhood to Cristo Blanco (big White Jesus statue), then hopping on over down the highway to the site of Sacsayhuaman. A neat little excursion, many good photo ops.

Visited with guide. Walked up from town (30mins) and took services of guide at the entrance for s60. He was very informative, was actually a shaman and gave some really interesting insights into Inka's. Without guide would be very hard to get much out of it apart from a great viewpoint.

One of many attractions on an awesome 9 days. The Inca and Pre-Inca history . We seen many places where Incan people lived and the restoration that is now taking place to unclover and make clear how the civilization lived. I like the fact that people in these areas are still using parts of some of the buildings from centuries past and they are still standing.

Extraordinary Inca citadel on Northern Outskirts of Cusco, Peru. This archeological site dates back to approx. 1100, with the Inca expanding the complex in the 13th century. The massive stones were hand cut and are precisely fitted without mortar as in all Inca sites. As in Machu Pichu, depending upon the relevance and importance of the specific area of the site determines how precisely the stones are carved and fitted together. Walk around this area and absorb the history. Our National Geographic guide, Diego, was amazing and a wealth of information about the Inca, their culture and building techniques.
Another amazing Inca ruin. This is a HUGE inca ruin. Although not as impressive as Machu Picchu, it helped to visit Sacsayhuaman first and learn of the history of the Inca Empire.

Must see on the outskirts of city. Impressive ruins of an Inca fortress. Generally alpacas grazing. The stone work is unbelievable. Every year in late June there is an impressive Inti Rimi Inca ceremony here with a cast of a thousand in traditional ceremony garb
Interesting Ruins. If you get a good guide very interesting INCA ruins, dont miss caves through rocks, extensive site. Basic facilities for visitors. Well signposted.

Impressive Inca ruins overlooking Cuzco. This place offers great examples of Inca stonework and pretty views of Cuzco. It's not to be missed if you're in that city. Make sure you're prepared for cold and rain, even if the earlier part of the day has been clear and sunny.

Great Site to Visit. Don't Miss It. The architecture of this fortress/temple is absolutely beautiful. The walk is an easy on and the scenery is really breath taking. The masonry of the structure is really impressive considering they had no wheels and primitive tools to build the structure

Amazing and tragic fortress.. The fortress makes up the "teeth" of the original Puma shape of Cusco city(Kaasko in Qetchua) Being up close to these massive, perfectly fitted stones was awesome. Great views of the city and sacred mountains. Sadly this site was not appreciated until the 1960's when they stopped contractors from using the ruins as a quarry, hauling these amazing boulders to Cusco to build hotels!

A Great View and Impressive Ruin. Similar to my reviews of the other sites in this area, if you have time to leave Cusco city and see these sites and you have not seen MACCHU PICHU yet then go have a visit. Of all the sites in this area this one is the best. Be sure to climb to the top and enjoy the wonderful view.

impressive Inca construction. When visiting the place really impressed me and see how the Incas managed to move these huge blocks of stone to make this wonderful place its totally different to see in pictures tan being in the area made me admire more the incas
great landmark to see. Amazing and on the hill. I cant wait to return there. If you go to Cusco, you must check out this landmark. You also must ask about the the statue of Jesus Christ
Great View. Really cool, unfortunately we went on a rainy day but the view down upon Cuzco is really cool, and the history is fantastic

One of my favorite Incan sites. I was lucky enough to get there in between tour busses so it was very peaceful. Tourists or not though, it's well worth the visit. Tours are usually combined with Puka Pukara and Tambomachay, which are ok, but this is spectacular.

Very big, don't leave it to the end of the day. Don't do what I did and start the trek up to the hill around noon. That way you'll have more time to take it all in. I'd recommend buying the ticket for all the attractions.
Brilliant. Brilliant on a sunny day. Huge site and lots of space and peace. Fantastic walls. And llamas to greet you.
Amazing. I love the stone work. It is amazing structure. You get a great view of Cuzco from this place. One should not miss this place when in Cuzco
Beautiful, historical place. The Sacsayhuaman is the highest point in Cuzco. It's a beautiful, historical place but can be a problem if you have altitude sickness.

GoToPeru provided us with this in our package. Our English speaking tour guide made this attraction a great experience. We highly recommend everyone to take this tour. The size of the Incan fortress and history surrounding this area was incredible. We loved walking over the grounds and taking pictures.
interesting history. very cool to see this stuff before machu picchu. lots of history. The stones must be touched! I have been here twice.

Huge!. Huge! A fun a relaxing way to get out and get a feel for Incan Stone Architecture.
Its amazing to think that the metropolitan city of Cusco is just a short distance away from such a massive structure.
Spectacular. Visited Sacsayhuaman while in Cusco on a tour. The views are awesome. Absolutely breath taking. A must see.

Do it first. Go here before you see Machu Picchu. Some people just walk here, but I visited during a "City Tour". It was fun just wandering around here and imagining how much work it would have been to pull all of these giant rocks into perfect alignment. It was a little rainy and cold when I visited in December. Have a poncho handy or buy one from the people selling them everywhere!

Highly recommended. Whether you explore Sacsayhuaman on your own or with a guide, make sure you give yourself enough time to truly experience them. I recommend at least half a day There is an entrance fee and as with many other places they only take cash. They also sell a multi-grounds pass that gives you entrance to other significant ruins.I did this without a guide, walked up from Cusco; I was swearing at the steps by the end but it was worth it. They're not treacherous or overly steep, there are just a lot of them. :) The view of Cusco alone makes this worthwhile, but bring water. And then the ruins themselves, even if you know nothing of the Incans and their architecture it's fascinating. The history, the achievements, the grandeur. If you do nothing else in Cusco, do Sacsayhuaman!

Well worth the hike! . Great views over Cusco and some interesting ruins to explore. The hike up the hill is quite steep and is likely to be more difficult if you are still adjusting to the altitude, but well worth the effort. You can also walk across from the top of the hill and view Christo Blanco - Cusco's answer to Christ the Redeemer in Rio! There are locals selling souvenirs and water etc at the top as well as the usual poses with Lamas and guided tours. There is a toilet at the base of the hill but this was closed when we closed due to sewage issues! So make sure you go before starting to walk up would be my advice. In terms of paying to see this attraction, I would recommend buying the tourist card that gives access to a number of different attractions at a reduced rate.

The Head of the Puma. Of the many narratives that the local guide told about Saqsayhuaman, was that the Incas built Cusco in the shape of a Puma and Saqsayhuaman forms the head, A likable story as the remains on site are three different levels of zig-zagging walls, that could represent the teeth of the Puma. Another narrative states that 3 different levels represents the Inca religious symbolism of the Underworld (Snake), the Earth (Puma) and the Heavens (Condor). The first level of walls are the most impressive as they comprise massive boulders, the corner stones are more than 25 ft high and supposedly weighs more than 120 tons. Besides the megalithic size of the boulders, the different shaped stones are fitted precisely, without the use of mortar and "no blade of glass, paper or steel can slide between them". At the top level there are remnants of what appears to be a circular tower and other buildings.The main negative about visiting this site like many archaeological sites in Peru is the lack of comprehensive on-site documentation. Therefore you would first need to read up on the site before your visit so as to understand the significance and to develop a checklist of significant things to look-out for. Second you need to have a good local guide to tell you the stories and to point out the significant points on site. So do your homework first in order to enjoy the visit later.

A must if you're in Cusco area. You need to stop and take the tour to the sacsayhuaman ruins. It's pretty close to the cusco center and there are plenty of tours operators that can take you there or you can get a taxi to take you there too. It's an impressive site conformed of several floors and at the top there sacred plaza. It's worth the time but get a tour guide to give you the explanation of how they made the ruins from the cantera rock found in the mountains

great place. Nice place to first visit of Inca site. Impressive. And you can walk from the centre of Cuzco. Nice walk as it goes through streets, houses, buildings, church... Love the walk from Cuzco to Sacsayhuaman, with nice view of the Cuzco and the valley below. It takes only more than an hour to walk with pleasant :)

Absolutely fascinating. Unbelievable that such a fantastic architecture was achieved by manually hauling gigantic pieces of stone to form this terraced structure. We walked up from the town following a very basic map......a little steep at times but managable. Loveky to walk around the area once in the grounds. Lots of alpacas and birds which provide added interest. You are able to climb up to the statue of Christ which we decided not to do.

Good place to visit if you do not do Machu Pichu. We were here today. It takes approx 15 mins travelling from the centre of town up on the top a beautiful hill. Now, this is an amazing place when you look at the architecture, the stone mason work, the geometry and calculations that went into building these terraced structures, some stones are 9 metres long weighing approx. 350 tons. The thought of intelligent processes put in place to move these granite stones is mind boggling. Incorporating into this is the Inca traditions of Serpents, Puma and the utilization of seasonal Equinox sundial properties. It is no doubt brilliant. The nearby gift by Brazilian Government of the statue of Jesus Christ- similar to the one in Rio, also offers some breathtaking views of the city.There are also friendly brown and white Alpaca roaming these areas and for some, that alone could be worth it. The Alpaca factory store on site also sells garments and Jewelry- I thought it was very steep but you can bargain them down 10-15%If you have visited Machu Pichu, it is a much smaller structure and you would not miss a lot, from that point alone.I hope, this is helpful

Incredible Incan Ruins!. These ruins are amazing! The sheer size of the stones used is astounding.Such a short walk from Cusco, you have to check it out!For more reviews and information on places we've been and things that we've done check out our blog!www.looktheworldintheeye.comfacebook.com/looktheworldintheeyeinstagram.com/looktheworldintheeye
don't forget to visit. you may reach the ruins on foot rising up from the plaza de arms along pedestrian street, maybe a little heavy but the view of this ruins is gorgeous.

Peaceful with a great view of the city. This site is impressive with its massive boulders, amazing stonework, and the detail you find at every Inca site. From the top of Sacsayhuaman you have a great view of Cusco. We visited in the late afternoon on a week day and heard music coming from somewhere in the city below. We spent 1 1/2 hours there, but wish we had more time to explore. It is a place well worth visiting.

Special and sacred. Vast area to walk through and get immersed in the incan/ pre incan culture.fantastic area for photos in front of uninterupted Basalt stone walls. Some weighing 1 ton. Views overlook Cusco. Tranquil setting. Enjoy
Impressive. This is a must see, the stone work is beautiful and the history is also impressive. It’s a bit out of Cusco but if you have the time definitely go see it.
Sacsayhuaman. Mesmerising. The applied mathematics that went into the design of this "puma head" is quite astonishing.
Inca stonework at its finest. The sheer size of the stones and the precision of the joining facets have to be seen to be believed. I still can't understand how the Incas did it.

Massive and Beautiful. Sacsayhuaman (our guide said some remember it as 'sexy woman') it's a little out of the way but you should make the effort to see it. High above Cusco, the massive architecture and stone work will impress even the most jaded observer. And from the top of the site, you can look down on modern Cusco. If you have a good guide or guide book, you can identify the triangle that is the area of the original Inca capital city below. The site was decimated by the Spanish conquistadors and most of the stone structures were recycled into housing for the rich Spanish occupiers.
Enjoy the view!. Interesting site with amazing view of Cusco City. Bring good walking shoes. The weather started off fine, but the rain soon came in... bring your poncho.
What a great place. Visiting this and other Inca ruins around Cusco was a good foretaste of what is to come at Machu Picchu. The location overlooking the downtown was perfect.
not to miss. Did not go there this time, but this place is so massive you have to see it. Walking distance from center if you are over soroche or chewing coca leaves.

Powerful Display of Inca Ingenuity. We visited this National Park as part of a tour and I was astounded by the huge boulders all placed in exacting locations for buildings etc. The weather was gorgeous and the views of Cusco superb. The park also includes a huge statue of Christ similar to Rio's overlooking Cusco with outstretched arms. Definitely this is a not to be missed attraction in South America. Choose a sunny day for ultimate experience.

Go to the top for great panaramic shots of Cusco. the site itself isn't that good or extensive compared to those in the Sacred Valley or at Machu Picchu but it does provide a great overlook of the city. Most tours don't give you enough time to climb up to the overlook, they just walk you through the center of the ruins.
Incredible Site. This is an incredible historic site. The precision of the placement of the enormous stones is amazing. It is also a nice walk to and from the Plaza de Armas.

Incredible!. How the Incas and possibly previous races built this is a miracle and should be the 8th wonder of the world. The way they could maneuver rocks to fit just right with numerous cuts, angles, possibly interior joint holdings, etc and then lift hundreds of pounds of rock in place is amazing! Words can not e plain this place! Awesome views of Cusco too! Free bathrooms!

Good example of Incan stonework. Relatively easy walk through this park, which was included in a multi park pass we had. You can climb up, we didn't, but it seemed relatively easy (guess that term is relative when it comes to Incan sites). Nice example of Incan stonework and good view of Cusco.
interesting. not far from cuzco and very easy to reach it even by bus, this old inka fortress, whose name means "satisfied hawk" is one of the so called 4 ruinas.worth a fast visit

Archeologically very interesting. We had a great guide who was very informed. If you like the archeological sites, this is a don't-miss-it. It's part of most city-tours, so it's not hard to get to see. As long as the altitude breathlessness is tolerable, take time to walk around to see it all.

Stunning site. Visited here on a tour but we really wished we had made our own way here, it is a stunning place, well worth an afternoon to itself. It is a huge site with excellent Inca stone work on show and a vast area to explore.

Interesting Ruins as you arrive to Cusco. Located just 5-10 minutes outside of downtown Cusco, Sacsayhuaman is a cool place to visit before seeing the more well known Inca ruins- Sacred Valley, Machu Picchu. I suggest taking a cab up there- a long winding road, and walking down. Also- if you are planning to visit other ruins, buy the all inclusive ticket for 130 Soles (Sacred Valley). Great views of Cusco from up top!
Great Inca site. A wonderful site that really beings home the building prowess of the Incas with its huge blocks of stone all so intricately locked together. Close to the Town

City tour with Danny' Tours. I took a tour on a double decker bus for about 2 hours. Most of the tour was just driving by tourist sights. They only stopped for 1 minute at the Sacsayhuaman to take pictures from the bus. They did stop for 25 minutes at some place where they were selling alpaca wool products. The tour only cost about $7 so I got what I paid for.
Impressive!!. Inkayni Peru tours- Edgar made this experience something special. The history and meaning of the place was amazing to learn!! Thanks Edgar!
Remarkable archeological site. Incredible Inca and pre-Inca stonework set over a wide site just outside of Cuzco. All the guides will tell you to remember the name as "sexywoman"!
Walls and history. Just try and imagine how those Incas moved those massive stones for the walls over many miles and then fitted them together like a jigsaw.

WOW!. So, our stop at Sacsayhuaman was a really unexpected treat. We knew that we were going to be taking a tour to some local sites, but what we didn't expect was the grandiosity of these sites. We were expecting something minor, but instead were treated to something really incredible. Well worth the stop. I only wish we had more time to explore this!

a pleasant walk with great views. take a taxi to here and then walk back down to the center of Cusco. We spent a lovely few hours walking around soaking up the history and enjoying the views over the city. Locals dress up and bring their llamas for you to take pictures with.Make sure to have a small flashlight(or phone) with you to walk through the tunnel.

Inca ruins atop Cusco. Even if you've gone to too many Inca ruins, the view of Cusco and surroundings from up here was beautiful. Go with a guide to get the best experience or buy a book so you know what you are looking at.
Must See in Cusco. you can admire the rock formations. There is a place you can have birds eye view of the city of Cusco. and there is the white Christ statue which looks over the entire city.

Great Ruins. These are very close to town. In the Plaza De Armas if you look up for the Christo Blanco statue on the hillside, the ruins are right next to it. It is free to go to Christo Blanco, it will cost you between 70 and 140 soles to see Sasayhuaman (pronounced sexah-woman). The ticket is not just for the ruins over the city, but depending on your ticket 3 to 12 more. There are many ruins very close to Cusco and if you can make a trip of it you should see them all. The Ruins over the city are amazing. Some of the largest rock walls I've seen in my 8 weeks in Peru. Larger rocks than even Machu Pichu. A must see if you are in the area. It will take about 3-4hours to tour the ruins at a moderate pace.

Great photos and views. I took some great pictures looking out over Cusco with its beautiful red terracotta roofs and surrounding mountains. The ruins themselves offered some nice perspectives for photographing.But, I didn't see any placards explaining anything, nor did I see anyone explaining the ruins or their history. Had we not had an introduction at a museum earlier, it would have simply been a park to walk through.Easy walking to a couple of other sites like the Cristo Blanco and Qenqo. You don't need to book a tour group to see them if you have decent Spanish skills. Take another cab onto Tambomachay and Pukapukara after too.Lastly, wear sturdy walking shoes or hiking shoes, some areas had slick mud in March

Great ruins so close to town!. We had great weather and climbed up to the ruins from our hotel on Resbalosa. Very enjoyable to visit and wonderful views of the city. Wasn't too crowded on a Weds. morning. Helps to have a map with some info about the site to help inform your visit (we bought one from a vendor at the entrance for 9 soles).
beautiful. Went through a small cave with a large group. Still a very beautiful and impressive Inca site. Has a beautiful view of Cuzco City.

Nice appetizer to Macchu Piccu. a good place to spend some time while acclimating in Cusco. Amazing views of the city and the ruins are impressive until you see Macchu Piccu. If you're especially savvy you will avoid the taxis and take the $1 nueva sol bus ride to and from the sites.

Amazing what the Incas built.. The tour was through Perutourism and the guide was knowledgeable and informative. The tour consisted of 4 parts and included a tour of an authentic alpaca product factory.

Stunning!. This archeological site forms part of the city tour, which you can book for 20 soles (£5) per person. Make sure you book the tour that lasts the whole afternoon and not the one and a half hour tour, they are the same price but you get much longer at each location. Sacsayhuaman is the second stop on this tour, and it is just amazing, especially if you're lucky enough to see it in a thunderstorm as we did! (There's a thunderstorm most afternoons in the wet season). Fabulous Incan stonework and a great view of Cusco.
Amazing piece of Peru's history. Everywhere you look, you see the remains of a vast civilization. The stone work is so perfect, each time I wonder how they did it. Well worth the visit.
Amazing. How did they do it - I still wonder! Walk around and just get puzzled by the technique they used. A walk to the top also give you a perfect view of Cusco city.
Well worth a visit. We visited Sacsayhuaman as part of the half day Cuzco city tour which I highly recommend. Well worth the visit to experience the surrounds of Cuzco and marvel at the ruins.

Pretty Spectacular. It's really cold, bring your best jacket.
It takes like an hour and a half if you have local tour guidance.

Large area. the area was interesting because of the large "rocks" or boulders that had been moved here by the Incas for construction. There is a 90 ton and a 60 ton boulder.....can't imagine how they were brought here. you need a guide to explain the area to you

Sacsayhuaman - Cusco. Another stunning site showing the breadth of architectural expertise of the ancient Incas. Pay close attention to the carvings in the mammoth stones comprising the zig-zag walls and you can see snakes as well as concave intentions that may have used in the placement of the stones.The uppermost structure may have been utilized as a type of calendar to aid in plotting when to plant crops. Also, stunning views of the city of Cusco from the vantage point of this site as well as a close-up look at the huge statue of Jesus which was given to the city as a gift.

short drive to spectacular ruins and views Sacsayhuaman. We did this one afternoon with Condor travel in Cusco.Great guides and very informative.Great views too.Wonderful experience.When in Cusco take some time out to see.

Great Stop on the Bus Tour of Cusco. This is a site worth seeing near Cusco and is part of the bus tour that leads from the square. The historic significance and beauty of this area are worth a longer visit than the 10 minutes we got on the tour.
Take your time in Cuzco. People rush to Machu Pichu but there are many other places with a lot to offer like Sacsayhuaman. Very interesting.
Interesting and worth seeing!. Very cool facts and sites about the Incas. Highly recommend this tour! Loved the rock structures, and llamas.
Amazing. Wear comfy shoes! It would be easy to spend all day but possible to hit the highlights in a few hours

Beyond Belief. Another one of the fantastic ruins seen while in Cusco. To get so close and to inspect these ruins, is amazing. We had a perfect day and a real great guide telling us the story of how it was built, then again, maybe the Aliens did lend a hand. A site not to be missed while part of anyones Peruvian adventure.

Sexy woman. I visited a few years ago but will remain the same. Sexy woman is just another pile of rocks, however, it's a wonder how it was made, great views of cusco and a nice walk to get there. Carry your walk on to christo blanko and around the otherside of the hill, You will come down the airport side of cusco, a good afternoons walk and as I was stoping in the main square getting back to it through the narrow roads, after coming to the city level again, you will come across some nice little hidden gems, local cafés and the like. Get used to the altitude before taking to the hills as every breath is a killer but cusco is one of my favourite cities to explore.
Inca site. The expanse of the site and seeing the walls built with huge boulders. There is a good view of the large statue of Jesus that overlooks Cusco.
