Big green field with rock. Because we were there by the tourist guy, and we can not spend a lot of time there, without the explanation and longer stay, it seems like a lot of rock to us. The best part is from there that you could see the whole city of Cusco.

Inca fortress near Cusco. A great place to explore while you are in Cusco. Amazing how the Incas could built this fortress in the Andes Mountain.......These boulders weight ...Tons....the complex is made of large polished dry stone walls, with boulders carefully cut to fit together tightly without mortar.The longest of three walls is about 400 meters. They are about 6 meters tall. We are a group of 12 from Canada, had a local tour guide explaining the history and took us through the site for about 1 hour. We enjoyed this visit during our stay in Cusco
Sexy woman. Beautiful first spot to learn about the Inca, the ruins and to have space to explore. Loved the stones slides, fun!
Impressive site. Sacsaywamaan overlooks cscuo offering great views of the city as well as being an impressive megalithic site.

Amazing Site. Just seeing the ruins and the size of the stones is amazing. Questions, popped into our head, why and how? Luckily, we had a knowledgeable guide, who explained the history of the ruins and the thoughts of meaning of the site and how the large stones came to be there. If you're taking in Machu Picchu, these ruins are a nice teaser to prepare you for the wondrous sites and ruins to come. We highly recommend Sacsayhuaman.
Nice place.. The place is not far from Cusco. And the ruins are very nice. The view from there is also nice. A stop ypu should do if touring the countryside of Cusco.

Just outside Cusco city.. You can gget a cab to take you up to Sacsayhuaman for 20 SOL's (about $7) and the cabdriver will return at a set time to take you back down to the city if you wish. The views of the ruins are impressive as are the size of some of the stone used in construction. A great view also oof the city of Cusco below. The fee to get into Sacsayhuaman is 70 SOL's ($23) and may be a bit high for what you actually see.

Amazing site. It's on a plateau above Cusco, it is an impressive example of Inca military architecture, It is made up of three enormous teraces which overlap in a zigzag fashion, it uses enormous boulders...amazing
interesting ruins. yes, you should plan to visit here on a tour with a tour guide....just a short distance outside of Cusco
Excellent local food. Food and service were superb. If you really want to taste local food; this is the place to go. The owners are there to help and serve you all the time.

ruins with a view. very beautiful ruins, with amazing building with giant rocks.
Lots of stairs to go up but it's worth it

spiritual spectacle. What an amazing spot to behold. I came up here on my first day in Cusco and am so glad I did. The views of the valley are incredible and the ruins are unbelievable. So many "pinch me moments".

Sexy Woman. We went in January and left our warm clothes in the hotel room. Mistake as it was warm and sunny upon our drparture, but hailed two hours later. We huddled together for warmth, but learned a valuable lesson about the weather in Cusco.

Definitely put this on the list. Our interpreter told us this was place was pronounced like "sexy woman" in English. I'm not sure he was correct. But regardless, it was absolutely breathtaking! This site is located just above Cusco and requires lots of walking. It's best to use a guide to explain what you are seeing. The enormous granite rocks that were hewn and drug over mountains to be placed in their current configuration are fantastic; imagining the labor it took is incomprehensible. It's also worth seeing/touch the drag marks in the granite -- drag marks that were formed during the melting of glaciers where have long since disappeared. Be sure to look for the stones that are arranged in the shape of the puma's paw.

Take a guide, negotiate, don't accept first price. Although we had hailstones the day of our visit, having a guide made a difference, he told us things we had not read in guidebooks, and brought us through a cave system (bring a torch)!

Amazing experience!. It was a great start to my journey through Inka constructions! Keep watch for the llamas in the walls and be sure to have a trusty guide to tell you about the story of this place!
Preparation for visit to Machu Picchu. This site helps to explain the Incan culture and building techniques. It is good to visit before heading to Machu Picchu.

Very well worth visiting. I walked up from Cuzco. It's not too far and is a great way to get to and arrive at the site.I had a wonder around first then took a guide before looking around by myself for the last time. I would recommend having a guide because they bring the site to life, I think it is definitely worth doing. For example my guide pointed out the condor in one of the walls which I had seen and actually taken a photo of but, I didn't realise at the time what the stones I had photographed were.All in all, Sacsayhuaman is very interesting and quite an amazing place, It is just outside Cusco and is easily walkable; in fact its a good training walk if you are going on a trek.
giant stones. this inca ruins is maybe the biggest one i have to see, really amazing , and unbelievebeble how was built, and it is really nice, also to learn more of the incas
Sacred place. I heard the correct name is Sacsa Uma or "Forehead" what match with the speculation about Cusco city with the Puma shape. Amazing place

Nice but bit overrated. This is considered as THE ruin in sacred valley area but in my opinion this is bit overrated as they dont have unique landscapes like most other ruins have. It is a large open space wih Incan walls on one side looking like a fortress and did not found it breath taking as it was claimed. One thing which i liked is the view to a distant redeemer kind of large Christ statue from this ruins.

Very interesting place to visit.. I had no idea what to expect, but the guide made it an interesting visit. Some fantastic views whilst driving to/from the place and I enjoyed it all. My only downfall was not doing some homework on the topic before departing for Sth America.

Awe inspiring. Our guide took us in the back way missing the crowds. How interesting to see how with minimal equipment, the Incan's were able to create such a masterpiece. Definitely get a tour guide. You will get the most information and a great insight as to the way this area was built.

Must See. This is a beautiful place complete with lots of roaming sheep. It's a fortress just outside Cusco. It's believed that the city of Cusco was laid out in the form of a puma whose head was the hill of Sacsayhuaman.
Very interesting. Thoroughly enjoyed our first "taste" of Inca history in this beautiful location. Very good guides who explained everything in such detail.

Don't miss this!. If you are in Peru to see Inca stonework then don't miss Saksaywaman (spelling varies). The Incas surpass all the masonry work you have ever seen...ever. and they did it with bronze chisels, now power tools, no wheeled devices and no beast of burden. Noe imagine a precisely (!) made stone of more than 100 tons 28 kilometers from its install point. Now go to Saksaywaman and see if you can figure out how they did it. Do not miss this site!

A must.. While Machu Picchu is the ultimate destination for most foreign travelers to the region, Sacsayhuaman (pr. sexy woman) is a must for a walk around. Understanding the Inca history and significance of this site make it a place to ponder and contemplate life there before the colonials lent a hand to its demise. Make some time to read a bit of Inca history before you arrive. Visiting Sacsayhuaman before or after Machu Picchu will lend to your overall experience. If you have able legs, the 30-60 minute walk to the site is worth while. Great neighborhoods and charming streets.

Sacsayhuaman. This particular site was used as a temple &/or fortress. What is amazing are the walls. As in other Inca sites, the stones are carved to fit exactly with the next boulder. Two of the boulders in this long wall however weigh 115 and 120 tons respectively. They were somehow transported 17 km (10 miles) to this site. It's amazing that they were able to accomplish this without any heavy machinery as we know of today.

try to have the shaman guide!. best visit these ruins alone, take your time, and if possible, have a guide telling you the spiritual secrets hidden in the stones. I checked afterwards and most was correct ;-) It makes the visit a little magic, so much better then the 30 min rush with a tour!

Them be big rocks. Seeing these giant rocks stacked at incredible heights is a sight to see. I still can't fathom how the Inca were able to put this together but it's definitely a marvel. Not as breathtaking as Machu Pichu but still worth the trip.

Must see . Amazing and amazing! We visited with our Gate 1 tour group on February 9. Inca construction at it's best.How did they? Stones 28' tall with an estimated weight of 40 tons moved 5 miles. Primary stones with 14 surfaces caved smooth to fit with other adjacent stones. Why the lighting shaped corners? Stone footing simular to other locations in the world such as Stonehenge.  A beatiful and engineering exhibition

Not much worth it compared with all other Inca Sites. We had planned for 1 day in Cuzco then 5 days in Sacred Valley and Inca Trail. In my perspective we wasted 2-3 hours better used walking around very charming Cuzco coming and walking around Sacsayhuaman.

The rocks are huge!. This place is unbelievable! I first heard of this place in a book called "the Chariots of the gods" or something like that by Erick VonDanicken. It is insane the way the carved the rocks and even more insane is to imagine how they hauled these rocks. this place is a must see in Cusco area. Of all the places we visited around Cusco, this was the most impressive one. once again UNBELIEVABLE!

...Made by the hands of giants?. Sacsayhuaman is not far from Cuzco so it is an easy trip to get there. We took a "city tour" with Reliable tours and it was a wonderful experience. Our guide, Fredy Palacios Paiva, is an Official Guide who works for Reliable Tours and also an an individual guide. His English was fantastic and he knew so much about the history and the culture of Peru. He brought the site alive for us.The massive stones that make up its construction are perfectly aligned. We couldn't imagine how they could move stones so huge...Some are larger and heavier than a tank. It is so worth the trip. In the summer they hold a huge festival there.
marvelous. marvelous and unique, it is amazing to see those stones and their size, you really feel impressed of how they fit one with another

Incan treasure. Only a 30-minute walk from our hotel in Cusco, Sacsayhuaman (pronounced "sexy woman"; yet another reason you won't quickly forget this jewel) is one of the many unheard-of Inca sites that will capture your attention. With no plans to do so, we hired a gentleman (Marcos) who was simply standing outside the entrance and offering his guiding services. He was knowledgeable and spoke pretty good English, and we felt very fortunate to have accepted his offer to show us the site. Like other less-renowned ruins (Moray, Ollantaytambo, Pisaq, etc.), Sacsayhuaman is a fascinating location, and you can't help but be in awe of the engineering feats of the Incas. Only a 4-star rating simply because you have to save the 5s for places like Machu Picchu (and Pisaq, which is more impressive IMO).

Amazing Andean Architecture of Precision-Carved Stones. Saqsaywaman / Sacsayhuamán / Sacsahuaman is a "Fortress" like walled complex - an example of pre-hispanic Andean architecture. The site is located at an altitude of 3,701 mt /12,000 ft, on the northern outskirts of the city of Cusco. There is a 'great' plaza and massive terrace walls made of huge-size precision-carved stones of interlocking shapes. Possibly, the plaza area and the elevated structures were used for large gatherings of people for ceremonial activities. The site is an amazing Andean architecture of precision-carved stones.
Great Place. So interesting and beautiful. How they managed to move the stones is amazing. The countryside was just beautiful. Great place before going to Machui Picci

A great historical Inca site to visit. Don't miss this one.. it is located in easy driving distance from Cusco, though you would be wise to hire a private guide to take you there as well as other archaeological sites like Machu Picchu

Place to go near Cusco. This is a place to go near Cusco.We got a cab from downtown cusco, we spent U$6 in a 20 minutes ride.The entrande fee is expensive 70 soles (U$23). You can use this ticket to visit three others sites.If you go alone you do not know what are all the stone. I prefered to hire a local guide for 30 soles (U$10). They asked 40 but we agreed with 30 after five minutes negotiation.Edwin, the guide, show us the whole in 75 minutes. It is worth.We walk down to the city. It is an easy walk down hill.

Expensive. My husband and I hiked up to the Ruins to prepare at elevation for the Inca Trail. The entrance fee was very high and when we had to pay partially in ISD, the women at the gate quoted us a different exchange rate for the day. So we actually paid more than quoted price to get in. We didn't do the full tourist package ticket, because we only had a few days and the other sites didn't interest us as much.Once inside there are no plaques or leaflets to guide you through the site. There are a few signs at one of the two entrances in Spanish, but they don't offer much insight. You could, of course, hire a guide for 50 soles, but we had spent all of our money just to get in.I would only go if you get a guide, because otherwise they are just big rocks.
Sacsayhuaman. GO! Every bit as stunning as Machu Picchu - and it is so near to Cusco. Taxis go there all the time.

Who build it? So much unknown. This is an amazing place I could have spent the whole day at. It is huge and the boulders are gigantic, who put them there and how did they get there. So much......so little known....
Really interesting. First Incan site we visited and a good introduction to the sacred valley and Machu Picchu. We went with a very knowledgeable guide, which definitely made a difference.
Impressive. If you read or listened to "The Last Days of the Incas" by Kim MacQuarrie, you will really get some perspective visiting here. Regardless, one is blown away this most impressive structure

Amazing place but crowded.. It was a interesting place. Amazing to see how those huge rocks were shaped and stacked with such precision. It was very cool but got a few 4's because it was also very crowded.
Something to do..... I liked it, but I mostly liked the view of the city from here. It's easy to walk to....a bit of stars, but nothing too bad. Coming down you can catch the bus for a sole.
Breathtaking. Anyone who visited Sacsayhuaman will say the same thing. Its pretty impressive . I recomend going with a tour guide.

Incredible!. This ancient Inca ruin was by far exceeded any of my expectation - it was truly a wonder. Dated back to thousands of years, I wonder how could the Inca people do all of the planning and building? All of these rocks were so precisely cut !

An Inca Wonder. This site is not to be missed in Cusco. You must go with a guide who can explain the history of the site and the Inca heritage. What an amazing feat to build and what an engineering genius! The enormous rocks are put together like a puzzle and are earthquake proof. This must be seen!

Worth it. This is an archaeological wonder. The intricacy in which the stones were cut and the amazing feat that it must have been to haul these boulders into the hills.. Simply amazing. Visit on your own- without a tour- spend the day and favor the area...
Very interesting. The old Inca Ruins were very interesting. The whole planning and layout of the area, so long ago is incredible. Certainly a very interesting experience not to be missed,

Good initial spot for introduction into the Inca way of life. We were on a guided tour with Scenic Tours (Australia) and our guide (Elliot) talked us and walk us through it all. Having a guide is the only way to get full benefit out of this site otherwise you don't get the history of the place. Maybe Lonely Planet could help but our guide was great. Scenic tours bought us the ticket so not sure of the price. It is mainly rocks and sizes to look at, there a better ruins within Sacred valley, but this place is worth a look.

Great Surprise!. Upon our arrival in Cusco, we headed out with our guide tand explored these architectural ruins. We hiked a bit, a good way to get acclimated to the altitude , and get accustomed to the amazing history of the brilliant. Inca people. We were able to ride horses among the countryside above the ruins, a wonderful perspective high above the city of Cusco. A most interesting afternoon.

Need a guide. We spent a day in Sacsayhuman (Sexy Woman) and overall a very beautiful, impressive site. The shortcomings... this was not cheap - the cab ride was (12 soles) but it was 70 soles a person just to get into the park. I would have had an easier time with that if it included anything.. i mean a freakin map would have been amazing. There is no literature or anything that helps you really appreciate what you are looking at/for. I would come back... but with a person who could help me appreciate everything.

Impressive place!. We got our tour to Sacsayhuamán organized by our travel agency Fairtravel4u and we enjoyed it very much. It was worth having our own guide who spoke excelent English and who knew somethin interesting about almost each of the huge stones from Sacsayhuamán. It's unbelievable how the Inca's could move and carve these huge rocks! You have to see it to believe it.

Getting a whole picture. Enjoyed this example of Terraced structure. Parts are still being restored. We did not spend a lot of time here but it was a great introduction to the Incan locations we would be seeing in the following days. We basically walked from one side to the other where our transportation met us. Our guide helped us remember how to pronounce the name by sexy woman!

Sexy Woman. Just Amazing - that is it , make sure you a lot enough time. we ran out, as we only booked two hours there and needed a lot longer to really take it all in. To really understand the destruction the Spanish laid on the land in Peru is something else.

3rd days of ruins, not as impressive as the rest. This is a nice spot and some of the rocks that make up the ruins weigh more than 600 Tons! But if you've already done 2 or 3 days of ruins and hiking Macchu Picchu with tour guides, it may be redundant. this spot is focused on the Puma and is supposed to be shaped like the Puma head. There are also a lot of cute locals that use this as a playground with kids sliding down the natural slides and playing in the rock tunnels.

Ancient City, Close To Modernity. Coupled with a few other destinations, a visit to this walled complex can be part of a great, historical and fascinating half- or whole-day trip while staying in Cusco. Just two miles northwest of the city, it overlooks beautiful, red-roofed Cusco in the valley below. The HUGE foundation boulders of the zig-zagged walls that fit in so precisely with each other, with no mortar in between, will make you marvel at the engineering skills of the ancient Incas, and you should take the time to wander up and around the ceremonial plaza, the hilltop sections and take a gander at the resident alpacas munching under the watchful eye of their alpaca-herder in the field just past the main entrance. I recently read that, if you arrive by 7 AM, there is no admission charge. Security guards arrive at 8. Unless you are carrying a travel guide, you might want to pay to join a tour group so get a full appreciation for the "Sexy Woman"

Nice view. I have been there for 2 times and always nice place for historical and for nice view for the city. I went there by one day trip and before I went there by myself both are ok. I walked up hill to the village behind to rent houses from local people in the village.

Sacsayhuaman (Sexy Woman). The mighty Inca hilltop fortress of Sacsayhuaman is incredible. We walked through the ruins, up the stairs, over the balconies...it’s huge and took a few hours to walk around. Only a small fraction of it, the foundations, remains today. Three massive terraced walls used to exist rising above 60 feet in a zig-zag fashion – some say to break up attacking opposition forces. A trip here is really worth it if you are in the area and have time!!

The famous "Sexy Woman". This is one of the famous ruins close to Cusco. It is know by English speakers as "Sexy Woman", cause is easier to pronounce. It is great for pictures. Make sure you allow enough time on this place due to the large amount of tourists. There are a lot of steps but I did not see ramps, which means that is not that "friendly" if you need an elevator but from the ground you can take great pictures too. Also, I didn't see any restrooms.
love ruin viewin. Very impressive scale and cool location over the city with great historical significance. Having a guide will make difference

Go the back way to avoid paying entrance fees. Seeing these ruins were cool, but not worth the entrance fee. Go around the back way and up the hill behind Sacsayhuaman and Cristo Blanco to get into the area for free!

One of my favorite place. A trip to Sacsayhuaman is worth it if you have limited time in Cusco. The construction is amazing and the views are excellent.I really love Sacsayhuaman.We walked from our hotel up to Sacsayhuaman, obtained a guide at the top and thoroughly enjoyed our tour of this beautiful area. Enchanting¡¡¡¡

Amazing inka ruins you can walk to. An uphill 45 minute walk from our hotel in Cusco (Rumi Punko) led us to this amazing ruin. Stones carved to fit exactly with the next and at least 10 feet high forming zig zag walls. Llamas roamed among the ruins, some led by locals anxious to have us take their pictures.... worth the small tip. This is a national park, be prepared to pay the entrance fee.

A not miss site of Cusco. An old Inca site that overlooks all of Cusco and is well over 11,500 feet of elevation. This site doesn't have to be a challenging hike if you don't want it to be. However if you are willing and able to climb to the top you will be rewarded with an amazing view.
Can feel the good spirits. It's a very special place that does give a good feel for the Inca culture. Amasing constructions! xxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

Incan Splendor. It is a wonder to see the kind of advanced structures the Incans had managed to create, and the years of climatic changes and earthquake menace it has endured to stand testimony to their brilliance.
A must visit

beautiful but steep entrance fee. at 70 soles, the entrance fee to sacsayhuaman is a little too expensive. but the stone works are really amazing. all those giant rocks that fit each other perfectly would leave you in awe. it's location is on top of a hill towering over cuzco and it gives an incredible view of the city.you can easily walk to sacsayhuaman but it gets steeper once you get near. spend about 1-2 hours exploring the place. i wish a had hired a guide because there weren't any information available.
Amazing. Just amazing, you cannot miss this place even if you stay in Cuzco just few minutes, one of the best sites to visit here if you love the incas!
Around Cusco. Well worth visiting, an historic site of the Inkas that is nearly as incredible as Machu Picchu. Fine stone-masonry and informative guides.
Incredible site.... So much to see here! The ruins are amazing as are the caves, but you have to try the natural rock slides as well.

Expansive Ancient Spaces. Sacsayhuamán in the Quechua language means flacon or hawk. This huge expansive walled complex is so large it is difficult to capture in photos or video. The large stones placed here without any mortar, are so well placed that not even a sliver of paper will fit between them. This was the former capital of the Inca Empire.

If you see only one Cusco Ruin make it this one. Large area of ruins, principally walls, but lots of them . Couple of thousand feet above Cusco so the oxygen is getting thin. You can walk up on the area above the walls for great views.Gives you amore tangible idea of the labor that went into this civilization.

Huge stonework walls - very imposing structures. Good view of Cuzco from the top. We were very impressed by the sheer size and complexity of the stonework. Incredible workmanship & engineering feats. Our lack of time spent at this altitude made climbing the very high, irregular steps challenging.
Nearby Ruin. It's a really amazing place, the big stones and construction are magic! and its really close to Cusco city. I enjoyed my visit in the afternoon.
Very interesting. If you can only go to one ruin at Cusco go to this one. Lots of original walls to see. Large enough to spend an hour.

Wished I had hired a guide. My boyfriend and I decided to hike up as a way to increase our endurance day 1 in Cusco. We didn't realize it would cost 70S to enter or that it included other sites (duh...). The site is beautiful, however we didn't grasp the historical importance until afterwards. As boring as some of the day trips are, at least they would provide the information you'd need to understand what happened there. ALSO: don't forget to take a walk to see Jesus so you can pet the Llamas!

Best ruins in Cusco - but see it before Machu Picchu!. I'm very glad I visited Saqsayhuaman. I took a taxi 10 Soles each way (equivalent of a little more than $3 USD) so getting there was easy. Taxis were right outside when I left. Lovely Incan ruins with VERY large rocks. I also loved the view of the White Christ and the roaming llamas and alpacas. I have more selfies with alpacas then ruins! I went in January, so wear good hiking shoes (slippery when wet) and bring a poncho! Despite the rain and cold, I was glad I went.Fee was included in the Boleto Turistico (which was 130 Soles -- roughly $44 USD).
Amazing pre-Incan stone work. More climbing, but worth it to view the stone work, the glacial effects, and the wonderful scenery. Recommend climbing to the top to get the full effect.
great. amazing stone work...love to envision what it was like when completed. Incas were an amazing culture....

Well Wort the trip. Sacsayhuaman is a modest drive from Cusco center, but an amazing Inka and pre-Inka sacred site with very well preserved ruins displaying the classic Inka knack for putting amazingly cut tons-heavy stones together in amazing precision. The site and surrounding nature is awe inspiring and well worth the trip. Are there more amazing sites in Peru? - well Dooh! MachuPichu- but this is an amazing site to visit for your day in Cusco before MachuPichu

Another excellent excursion. The ruins of Sacsayhuaman were again brought to life by the brilliant Condor Travel guide Alex Medina. His knowledge and passion for his subject shone through and made this a really enjoyable experience.

"Sexy woman". Is what our guide said about these ruins - and it stuck! We were here the day we arrived in Cusco and many of us were a bit light headed/dizzy from the altitude. Notwithstanding, it was great to walk around and see the alpacas running around and see the old Incan workmanship (and the view of the city)
A must!. I had the fortune to go to this site on a private tour and learned a lot of the archaeology and formations in it! A must if you are visiting Cusco.
A good first stop when adjusting to the altitude. Not a whole lot here to see but there are alpaca which make for some fun photo opportunities. The structure is amazingly constructed.

Definitely worth it. It's an old fortress area.... long views... big site. I loved the look out point, and some people did a traditional ceremony there for a recent loss... we also tried out slingshots there.

Take a tour!. This site is pretty big, there are tons of places to look around. At the top there is a little look out point where you can see the whole city. It's amazing! I would say take a tour because there is so much history and sadly a lot of the sites have been so destroyed by the Spaniards that without someone to tell you what's what it seems like just rocks in weird formations.

Needed more time. I visited Sacsayhuaman as part of the Cusco city tour. I really enjoyed this site though and wished we would have had more time to explore it. I would recommend going on your own instead of as part of the tour because the site is huge with tons of great views. On the city tour we only had maybe 30 minutes of free time to explore and we hardly saw any of it. Plus its pretty close to the city so it's not that hard to get to. Make sure you find the natural rock slides if you visit :)

scenic historic site. we hired a taxi from inkatravels through our hotel -- full day for cochahuasi and pisaq and 1/2 day for the other ruins. this was our 2nd day trip. This is a walled complex on the northern outskirts of the city, on top of a hill, so probably a fortress. The size and precision of fitting of stones is awesome. Some stones weigh 50 tons. Precision of fitting, combined with the rounded corners of the blocks, the variety of their interlocking shapes, and the way the walls lean inward, is thought to have helped the ruins survive devastating earthquakes.Cuzco was designed to mimic the shape of a reclining puma, with Sacsayhuamán as the head. The zigzag design of the large wall of this site is believed to represent lightning, creation, and the teeth of the puma. god to know some background, but one can enjoy the site for aesthetic value also... the cute alpacas that graze there add to the experience...

Un Miss Able. Sadly the site was desecrated and crushed by the spanish, but on top it was pillaged for generations by local people for building supplies. thankfully that stopped last century, and is now World Heritage. Amazing and inspiring, this was first large scale site we went to in Peru and totally breathtaking. Do Not MIss!
Very nice. excelent, bigger stones, beautiful landscapes, I like this place, I enjoyed the city a lot, not like lot of people

From Blanco Cristo, do this.... From Blanco Cristo (got up there by taxi), we walked toward Sacsayhuaman. Down a slick hill. A woman whistled at us to go to the entrance instead of cutting across a little stream. At the entrance she asked for our Sacsayhuaman tickets. We asked how much they are. 70 soles! No. So we said we're going to walk down the rocky road that points in the direction of the town (Cusco). So we did that! On the way down, we stopped at a church with a belltower. The walk down was safe -- the walk up would not have been as that road goes through what looks to be a rougher part of Cusco.

My favorite place in the city. only 10 minutes away from the main square, this place is awesome. Great for seeing inka structures, for only 10 soles (per person) you can hire a guide in the place, the history of the place is interesting and it is a great place to just sit and relax, looking down at the city (as it's located at the top of a mountain)

Amazing!. Sacsayhuaman or 'sexy woman' (kkk) is the best site near Cuzco. Your guide will make all the difference but you shouldn't miss it. We had only one day and a half planned for Cuzco and We did not regret to go to Sacsayhuaman.

Fun just to learn how to say. The drill is, logistically almost everyone spends time in Cuzco before or after the real purpose of their trip, Machu Picchu. The Inca sites in Cusco don't quite compete with MP, but they are interesting and pleasant. The scale of this site is quite impressive, and charming Inca "peasant" will pose with llamas for you ...
Great place, walking distance to Cusco. Up a big hill, or take a bus or cab. This is a beautiful, amazing, historical area right outside of Cusco. Magical.

An important Inca ruin outside Machu Picchu. I'm not a big history buff but I did appreciate seeing these ruins that played such a big part in the ultimate defeat of the Manco Inca and fall of the Inca empire. While it lacks the detail of Machu Picchu, the sheer size of the rocks and the intricate way they were fitted together gives yet even more depth of appreciation for the skills and fortitude of the Inca nation. Another highlight of this attraction is that one can overlook the entire city of Cuzco and again appreciate its historical role.
Amazing place. Dramatic, interesting and a must see place to visit.Another Inca temple that makes you realise the skills of the Incas
After Machu Picchu everything else is a bit less but.... Nice to be able to walk there from our hotel. I should have read a bit more about it first or hired a guide.

Expensive. My boyfriend and I went to Sacsayhuaman by taking a city bus up to the top. We spent some time at Cristo Blanco, a Peruvian favorite, and took pictures of the city and surrounding mountains. When we went to go into Sacsayhuaman, we realized we would have to buy the 130 soles (40 USD) pass that's good for seven days that allows you to visit all the ruins in the Sacred Valley. There is no option to only pay to visit one location. We didn't have time to visit more than one, so we didn't actually go in. However, we had a good view of most of the ruins, and we noticed that there weren't any signs or labels to tell you about the rock structures. So you'd also need to pay for a guide. This was something we noticed with many tourist places actually, an expensive entrance fee and an even more expensive guide fee. Where the entrance fee money goes, we do not know, because there is no infrastructure around the ruins, no informational signs, dirt paths and very few employees outside the guides. This made us hesitant to pay because we want the money we spend to go to maintaining the ruins and to the employees who maintain it. We aren't sure this is happening in many of the Sacred Valley ruins.

ok but nothing special. Went there with my girlfriend. It's a small site which we did not find especially nice or great. Wouldn't go there again. Maybe just go to the Christ to have the view over Cusco. For the walk to the Christ you don't have to pay anything.

SACSAYHUAMAN (or sexy woman as our guide called it). A visit to this Incan historical site is a must. It is a lovely open grassed area with the Incan ruins in the distance. Our group virtually had the place to ourselves. We marvelled at how the Incan community were able to construct this walled fortress and took plenty of photos. The alpacas grazing in the background completed a most interesting visit. Lovely views from up high of Cusco in the valley made for excellent photographic memories.

So much history. I came here with the City Tour. Our guide walked through the entire area to explain to us the history of this former capital of the Inca Empire. I suggest going here with a city guide so that things can be explained during the walk through. Or else it might seem only like impressive rock structures. It was raining on the day I visited Sacsayhuaman, if it was sunny, it would have been more gorgeous.

Easy access from Cuzco. This impressive ruin is not far from Cuzco and although most of the visitors arrive on organized tours this place can be reached either walking (good level of fitness required) or by hiring a taxi in Cuzco, we paid 10 soles but beat the crowds and explore the place at our own leisure.
Sacsayhuaman day trip. Its a nice place but we reached there quite late in the evening and were exhausted to enjoy the place at leisure

Very impressive!. Wow - I wasn't prepared for how impressive this Inca site was. The zigzag constructed walls were so amazing. Too bad there so many people here - made it a bit hard to appreciate but oh well. People were clamoring to climb up this walled fortress (which we did, too) but really what you want to do is climb up the hill on the other side of the grassy bit so you can actually get a view of this massive structure from a close distance. Make sure you allow yourself enough time up here - it's very impressive. There were even alpacas grazing on the lawn. The views to Cusco in the valley below are also very impressive - we came around 5pm and the light was good over the valley. Sachsyhuanan is a must see site when visiting Cusco. We accessed this site independently with a car & driver hired for transportation between Ollantaytambo and Cusco, and extended the day to include sightseeing. We purchased the 130 sol / person Boleta Turistica del Cusco ticket which is good for 10 days and includes this site as well as 15 other sites or museums in the Sacred Valley and Cusco.

Amazing ruins. Another Inca ruin that is a UNESCO world heritage site. What is striking here are the sizes of the huge boulders used for this walled complex. It must have been a challenge to get one stone on top of the other to make their buildings then. Really impressive.
You also get a good view of city of Cuzco from here.

Part of sacred valley tour. We took a tour with a guide we hired at the airport. I'd recommend doing a little research before hiring a guide. In fact, a book is probably fine! Our guide either didn't completely understand our questions or was not 100% informed. But, we loved Sacsayhuaman and the other Sacred Valley sites we visited and felt they were good preparation for Machu Picchu.
interesting site. brilliant views over Cuzco, interesting building techniques, very large site, A good guide or guide book would help in understanding the significance of the site

It's worth a visit. It's a short hike throughout, but and interesting stop in Cusco. Amazing to think how they moved such large stones for building 100s of years ago. It can be a little breezy at this location, so I'd recommend bringing layers to keep warm. I recommend going to the Cristo Blanco (white Christ) statue right next to Sacsayhuaman as well. From there, you can see fantastic views of Cusco!

Interesting and vast open spaces. I walked from Cusco Centre to Sacsayhuaman, through San Blas - its steep, so make sure you are acclimatised. It took about 40 minutes. Don't miss this historically fascinating attraction, the forte is said to be in the shape of puma claws. I loved the openness, the mountain surrounds and views over Cusco. I also walked onto Blance Christo (white Christ) and a ouple of other sites including the temple of the moon. Take rain gar and a warm jumper even if its hot and sunny when you leave. Its the mountains and the weather is unpredictable.

Nice experience. We had first decided to visit only Sacsayhuaman, but later got a cab to visit the other 3 sites. Although Sacsayhuaman is the largest one of the complex, Tambomachay is worth the ride.

Really close to Cusco. A short drive from Cusco tour the 4 sites at Sacsayhuama. Easily reached inexpensively by cab. We toured there prearranged by regular cab for 70 Soles and then paid 70 Soles each for entry to the 4 Incan sites.

Beautiful Views of Cusco. This historic Incan site offers a nice vantage point above Cusco to see the city and surrounding mountains. We had a very informative tour guide who educated us on the history of Sacsayhuaman and the debate over whether it was a temple or fortress (I vote temple!). Not a MUST SEE while in Cusco but an interesting visit if you have an hour or so of free time in the area.
worth it. Cusco is wonderful and the views around the city are definitely worth it. You can buy a pass for tourists that allows entrance to multiple sites.
Impressive and mysterious. Smooth stone-slides among rough boulders.Enormous stone blocks so thoroughly fitted to each other.Great view on Cusco

Amazing and mysterious. Walked up from our hotel near Plaza d'Armas (huffing and puffing), and spent at least 1/2 day wandering around. The 3 stone walls are just awesome and mysterious; loved the herd of llamas in the field, and the beautiful natural huge rock mound. Worth lots of time to just contemplate and enjoy.

Great ruins and views. These fantastic ruins overlooking Cusco form a nice mini-hiking excursion. They are easily walkable from the city and the hike is an easy test to see how well you've acclimatised to the altitude. Read about the fortress and its history before you go there though, it was the site of a pulsating battle whose outcome was balanced on a knife edge and history could've turned out much different had the chips fallen the other way.The ruins are an excellent example of Inca architecture and masonry, among many to be seen in and around Cusco and the Sacred Valley. The Christ Redeemer copy is another curiosity worth checking out.

One of the lesser Incan ruins. I found Sacsayhuaman to just be ok. There are so many amazing Incan ruins in this area that I wouldn't devote time to this one unless you are an absolute archaeological buff. However, the stone work is still amazing and you get some very nice city views of Cusco.

A wonder. If you start your visit to Peru here you'll get a sense of what to expect at other sites later on. It's amazing to see these huge blocks of stone that were pushed and shaped and placed to create this massive complex. Testament to human perseverance. You can't even began to imagine the scope as most of it was torn down and used by the colonialist to build Cusco. Take your time and crawl over it all!
fascinating ruins!. Don't miss this spot! Even though it is a bit out of town, it is well worth the trouble to get there. Quite interesting history.

Inca Ruins abound. The question we all have around the Inca ruins is how did they get these rocks here. The same question goes for this site. Some of the rocks are incredibly huge, carved perfectly and fitting together perfectly. Apparently this was an area for outdoor venues or parades for the masses. Interesting!

If in Cusco, you cannot miss this ruins. This is part of history of the Incas. Part of the ruins that remain in Cusco where you will find the biggenst stones put together misteriously. Need to have your picture taken next to one of these.

Nice visit with a guide. We went to this location with a guide who knew how to stay away from the crowds. We would not get as much from the visit had we not had the guide. It is pretty well maintained and has wonderful views of the city below. It is easy to walk the entire area (it is a large area) without feeling like you are hiking up and down hills.

The Inca's "Pentagon" and "West Point". In the Inca's grand city plan for Cusco, this site was the "head of the Puma." It was also the place where military strategy was shaped and officers were trained. Vandalized by the Spanish conquerors we can now only marvel at the remnants of the impressive stonework. Huge boulders of limestone were fitted neatly together with simple tools.While everyone can enjoy the view of the city below, the site lacks interpretation, and you will get much more out of a visit with a knowledgeable guide or a detailed description in a guide book.

A great place to wander for a day. My husband and I did this as a day hike from Cusco. You don't have to join any of the tour groups, though most of them try to tell you that you will save money by going with them. The upside of having a tour is having people explain the ruins to you though. But, you can walk up the steps to the left of the cathedral in the square and continue up towards the left until you reach the gate where you pay your entrance fee. Hold onto your ticket as people will ask to see it. It's a beautiful area to explore, and you can access the Christo Blanco from there as well.
awesome architecture. To see how they created this place is dumb founding. One must have great mobility to climb those big steps.
An easy trip from Cusco. This site is impressive and has an interesting history. I would have liked it better if it was less crowded, but it certainly is worth visiting from Cusco.

Pure histrory. In this places you can "live" the Inca's history... For better understanding of the place and their history, is higly recommended to hire a guide, or go well informed.. Beautiful please, and a "must go" place if you're staying in Cusco.

A lot of ground to cover. There is a lot to see surrounding the old fortification. A guide offered us his services and without him we wouldn't have seen half the things we saw including some caves and the hidden artwork featuring the snake, the puma, and the condor. We spent about 3 hours hiking around the site

big stature. famous architecturally and historically, with reason. colossal public works project, the scale of which is mind-blowing. we wasted too much money on a local guide, would have done much better to buy a local guidebook in the bookstore near the plaza de armas as self-guide this one.
Sacsayhuamen. Great place to visit, close to Plaza de Armas, about 20 minutes by car and gives one a view of life of the incas
Worth the tour. I did this apart of wider tour day. I enjoyed the site. Worth doing as apart of a tour, as the walk to to the top of mountain from plaza de armas would be long and uphill.
How did they do this?. This place will blow your mind. It is so Beautiful, and this sacred place rivals many wonders of the world!

Beautiful and peaceful. So these are considerably close to the city of Cusco though be warned if you are planning to walk as we did its a good 45 minute hike all up hill and not for the faint of heart, You go through some interesting neighborhoods of Cusco that you may not see otherwise, all safe. There are tours offered for it so if you have limited time and don't really want a work out than go for that. There are some horse back tours as well. The architecture is beautiful it is a large site so plan on spending some time there.

Must-see. This is a must-see Inca ruin. There is no signage, so it is best to read up on the history before you go or find yourself a guide. We visited as part of the Cusco city tour which I would not recommend. The group was huge, we were given only a short amount of time to walk around, and the guide gave very little history or detail about the site. I definitely wish i could go back and spend more time looking around this massive and impressive site!

Real Inca Art. Place where you can see the real Inca art where huge walls built with huge limestone blocks as perfect as possible ... such that spanish people suggested human cannot do it ; its evils work so all inca people are evils ..... you cannot see this art in Macchu Picchu.... a good guide makes it perfect ; I may suggest responsible tour in cusco ...
So close to Cusco. Great views of Cusco, but very little signage. Best to visit with a guide but don't Miss these ruins or the view.

Eye-catching introduction to colonial Cusco. The ruins of Sacsayhuaman are only 1 mile north of Cusco and are towering high above the city. This is the place to see the masterful masonry of the Incas even though the conquering Spanish tore down and ransacked the fortress city. One fifth of the original complex is still there for us to admire. The great view of Cusco is worth the trip too.
Ruins. amazing to try to divine how they were built. Though conquerors tried to destroy & bury it , they did not succeed.

Interesting. This was part of my tour so I am not sure how much the ticket was, but it is definitely interesting. The views are nice and the ancient architecture is interesting. Be aware of llamas and alpacas running around I had one nearly run over me (scary!)

Amazing. Great way to spend a few hours. When you get there, there will be a ton of guides that you can pay to take you around and explain the history. Totally worth it otherwise we would not have any clue on what the structures meant, nor would we have found the cave to walk through. Great view of all of Cusco from the top as well.

Fantastic views. The views from this perch in Cusco where the statue of Christ is are fantastic. It's well worth taking a taxi up or better yet take the city tour from the Plaza de Armas, which includes a stop here.
Close to town. Very nice Inca site and very close to Cusco. Some of the better stonework and a good place for pictures. The natural "slides" were a hit with our group.

Incredible site- not to be missed. Like many other ruins, most of the structure is missing ,Either because the Spaniards have destructed the site, or the stones have been used to built cathedrals. This is the case here. But the site is still magnificent with stones weighing up to 65 tons. It is a vast area and you could walk hours before seeing everything. However it is surprising how those blocks were transported (assumed by rolling them on logs) and assembled like a puzzle. From the highest point you have a complete view of Cusco. It is amazing. You are at 3400 meters; walk slowly and take pauses. And protect yourself with sunblock. It is a must see place. Do not miss it.

Must do WITH a guide. Our guide was Alberto, he was arranged through our hotel, Rumi Punko and he was excellent. We spoke wtih others who went without a guide and did not have nearly the same expeirence. I would combine these ruins with Tambomachu, Temple of the Moon and Qenco. Alberto also works/owns Qucharitas (ice cream shop just off of Plaza de Armas). Another great place.
Incredible Inca treasure. The restoration is well done. How didi the Inca get these huge stones cut and placed in the wall? I was in awe.
Wonderful area. This is a must see area when in Cusco. The land, the people and the views of Cusco are all wonderful. There is the white Jesus and three crosses also as well as inka ruins.

Spectacular. I am a bit of a philistine when it comes to history and archaeology and anything that happened a long time ago. However, Sacsayhuman takes me out of that and ignites my sense of awe: those stones are massive and so perfectly worked! Plus the view from the site is great too. If you feel energetic and aren't too tired from the altitude, it's worth the little hike up there . From the Plaza, it's less than 1 mile, but don't be fooled...unless you're very fit or well-acclimatizzed, it'll take you longer than you think! :)
All we heard - and more. Beautiful sight! Of course, the name is often pronounced "Sexy woman" but our local guide spilled the "true beans" about its origin!

a must-see. After spending sometime visiting ruins in Cusco and Macchu Picchu, you'd think enough is enough. However Sacsayhuaman is a place not to be missed. It is located just up the hill near Cusco and you can go there by taxi.The site is very impressive, huge and we can see Cusco from above. Would be helpful if there is a map provided so anyone could visit it without a tour guide.

A sight not to be missed. Tour guides can make it or brake a tour... Thankfully we had a so so and not that terrible guide. Many guides in peru act very been there done that attitude and it can be a bit dissapointed so a guide book can come in handy...

Close to the center and a beautiful view. Great view to the city, amazing ruins, really worth to see. It's part of the City Tour, which is not a typical city tour. The City Tour in Cusco is a half day trip where you get to know the most important ruins around the city of Cusco, including the Inca temple that was hidden below the construction of a Christian Church.

Not really worth it. The entry ticket is not cheap for what it offers and if, like us, you are nearing the end of your trip in the area, then the ruins are not very impressive. You get a nice view of the city though but still not worth paying for.

Very Impressive. This is an amazing site. The intricacies of the architecture and the amazing views make it a must see in Cusco. A large part of the complex was destroyed long ago but many of the walls and stairs remain. The stones weigh up to 120 tonnes and are perfectly in place which is quite amazing to see. We just explored the site ourselves because we didn't have a ton of time but it might be good to have a guide to get more of the historical significance out of the place. We walked up to the site from the San Blas area and while it was steep it wasn't an unmanageable walk. You might not want to if it's your first day at altitude though.

Long walk uphill to this site. We decided to walk from the Coca Museum to this site. It was quite a long walk uphill. The area seemed safe. It cost 70 soles to get into the site. There really wasn't much to see. I understand a lot of the stones were taken to build the cathedral. There is a very good view of the city from the site. The best view of the site walls is from the rocks across the grass area where the llamas usually feed.
Amazing ruins. Just amazing! still wondering how this was built centuries ago. This was an optional tour on our trip but is worth a visit. Some walking is required so beware.
must see. Be ready for a lot of walking when you come to Cusco. The ruins are magical, don't miss out on this one in particular

Impressive. Unbelieveable to see the huge boulders and precise masonry. Also, sad to learn that what is there is only about 20% of the original. We were fortunate to have a very good guide who made it come to life.
Nice Inca Site. It's worth going up there from Cusco. You can also take a bus to pisaq and jump of at the 4th arqueological site and walk back to cusco. On the way you can see 4 inca sites.
A very interersting holy site. You need a guide to fully benefit from the visit there and some background of Inca and Pre-Inca history

Very Large Stones. Access to Sacsayhuaman requires the tourist boleto which you purchase in Cusco at one of the Ministry of Tourism's offices. It costs 130 soles and gets you entrance to 16 historic sites around Cusco. There are 4 ruins north of Cusco's plaza de Armas with Sacsayhuaman being the closest. It is very easy to take a city bus for around 2.50 soles to the farthest ruin called Tambomachay and then walk back using farmers trails to the city center. Along the way you get to visit the ruins of Pukapukara and Quenco finally ending at Sacsayhuaman. The walk takes about 4 hours and will bring you to ruins that are smaller and not on the tourist boleto. If you want to visit Sacsayhuaman without paying, go at 6 am and enter from the back farthest side from the city.
a quick tour. amazing view and wall structure....go high up to see the wall...interesting.....easily spend an hour here
Unique. Very powerful.It's amazing how they could have built all this, some of the stones weight 150 tonnes

Archaeological Site not to be missed. The whole site is massive and presents fine examples of Pre-Inca architecture. Huge stones were placed in diagonal rows by hand to form the existing platforms. Remarkable achievement.

Splendid. This old Inca fortress was, in a word, amazing. Some of the stones forming parts of the walls weigh as much as 300 tons and mesh perfectly with other large stones. All without machinery or computers
Very Interesting. This area was very interesting to learn about. We did have a guide to give us historic information and that is a big help in order to appreciate the area.
Not to be missed. A visit to the site is important to understand Cuzco and its Inca design. It is close and very easy to visit.

Inka complex near Cusco. Really great complex even some Llames & Alpacas roaming the grounds. At this site you can explore some very large stone walls of the Inka's. It's really amazing how well these stones fit together.
Historic site. Easy access and very interesting, especially with a guide. Very user friendly as you can easily walk among the ruins and get up close and personal

An ancient civilisation. Very well preserved this ancient ruins of a lost Inca civilisation is a wonder to see.How perfectly huge blocks of stone are laid on each other shows the architectural talents of the Incas,

great ruins, short uphill walk from cusco, beautiful views. Visited late one afternoon in September. We hiked up from our hostel near the Plaza de Armas, took us about 20-30 minutes. Uphill walk but not overly strenuous (we're pretty fit). Need the Boleto Turistico for entrance - sold at the site (Peruvian soles only, but vendors nearby will exchange for high rates). Beautiful site with lots of history. Impressive Incan construction. Great views of city. We walked up mid-afternoon & stayed til sunset - were lucky to have a rainbow pop up over the city. Felt safe there but the street we walked up from Cusco looked like it could get a little seedy after dark, so once the sun set we headed back pretty quickly.

Worth the Uphill Hike. These ruins are located up the hill from "downtown" Cuzco. Expect to take about 30-45 minutes climbing up the backhills to reach this site. But once at the top of the hill, you will be near the Christ statue, and will be able to see all of Cuzco. Defintely worth the walk.The ruins are not quite as spectacular as many other sites visited during our recent trip to PERU. We were told by our guide that this was a triple-walled fortress, which appears as the head of a Puma (from an airplane). Of course, you cannot see any of this on ground level, and cannot appreciate the complexity of the ruins.What you CAN see however, are the huge stones (thousands of pounds in weight) which were somehow transported down the hill form the quarry to the site. That in itself is a miracle. The stones are not as smooth as at some other Incan archaeological sites. But they are still assembled tightly together without the aid of mortar. And our guide informed us that the structure was at least another 6 feet higher originally, so you can see how this would have been some type of fortress.The stonework here is what is really amazing. In some respect, this stonework might be considered more complex, and certainly more serpentine, than say at Machu Picchu. Anyway, this site is close to Cuzco, and a nice way to spend a sunny afternoon. There is an open area around the ruins, so lots of dog-walkers, kite-fliers, and picnickers await you at the top of the mount.

What a Unique Experience!. It is nice to hear the stories about this site from a tourist guide. There is so much history in all the mountain ranges around Cusco. Make sure you stop at this location and support the locals with a small purchase. I got a wonderful picture with a local and I tipped her for her trouble. This is well-worth a stop.

Short visit but worth it. This place has great ruins. It doesn't take long to get there and it won't take you long to see the ruins, but they are worth the trip. The way they were able to move and place the huge boulders is amazing. In some ways the stone work here is much better than Machu Picchu.
Amazing ruins. Great views of Cusco and fascinating ruins, well worth a trip, but wear hiking shoes. I would recommend hiring the guides that work there, as they enhance the experience.
Big open area ,with Alpacas roaming freely. Big open area ,where they also hold festivals ,the ruins were very interesting.Alpacas roaming freely and good view of the city

Impressive site. This Inca site was ammasing in size and view. Our tour guide was great and its knowledge of the site was impressive. It is amazing to see who the Incas were able to build such big sites and their knowledge of engineering and stone masonry was comparable to other cultures of their times.

Perfect in the early morning. I arrived at site in the early morning (7am) and there were no people. It was extremely beauiful and the views were stunning. Well worth arriving early to beat the crowds.

Nice ruin when in Cusco. Nice but heavy walk up from Cusco centre makes it a good preparation if you're planning a hike at this altitude. 5 minute walk to Cristo Blanco for an amazing view of the city.
Gorgeous views of Cusco. Inca walls were so impressive. Views were breathtaking. It's a must see place if you're in Peru. It helped that we had a great tour guide to explain the history.

Very interesting!. We were quite impressed with these ruins. Our guide, Edwin, was able to show us the amazing parts of Sacsayhuaman and explain the history and special plants in the area. Plan to spend a couple of hours to see it.

Great site to visit.... We visited this site during a tour of the Sacred Valley. It is truly amazing what the Incas were able to build and this site is in pretty good condition considering most of the stones were removed to build the city of Cusco.

Great ruins to visit. We visited this site on a tour of the Sacred Valley. Very informative and close to Cusco. It is amazing how well preserved these ruins are and how the Incas were able to build these structures.

Impressive. Impressive constructions,megalithic stones,everything destroyed by the Spanish. Don't miss this place and enjoy it visiting just walking inside,contemplating it and trying to imagine how sumptuous should it be.

Important ruins that need to be explained. These ruins are a spectacular example of the traditions and beliefs of the Inca peoples. These ruins need to be explained to visitors to give the depth. These ruins need to be accessed using a tour pass, which is purchased at nearly all tourist venues in Cusco. The Inca culture is still alive in Cusco. With these ruins being a focal part.

not to be missed. one of the most important places to see around the town,fine inca architecture , get a private guide o a small group company ,group services are very cheap but you will might be very dissapointed
How did they do that?. These stones are beyond gigantic and fit together like puzzle pieces. We were in total awe of these ruins. You cannot visit Cusco without spending several hours here!

Simple but interesting. "The Sexy Woman" as our tour guide from Condor Travel said that we do not forget the name of the place. And we will not. The place is located the outside of the town of Cusco, the top of the big hill. Place is large and contains some of the very huge stones in three layers. The first layer is amazing with some 30 m high stones. The second layer is more like Inca style and symmetry. The third layer is like natural stones - round and manageable. The square between the walls is big and festive - I could see all the fest and worship going on that square. There I saw me my first lamas - and I was exciting to take pictures of them. When we arrived to the gate in the morning, there was no queues, but as we were in the park I noticed that there was huge lining going on in the gate. Reason for that was that you have to buy a ticket, mark your name in it and show the passport in the gate. And they stamp the ticket and perforated it - and it will take time ... Some bureaucracy at the gate takes time - but it is probably safe then?The place is its best with guide so you hear the stories. The place itself is beautiful and interesting, but you need the stories to make it lively. So take a trip with group/guide.When you are leaving out the area to the other end, you come a cross with women and children with baby sheep ages only few days. They give you an opportunity to take pictures with sheep and them - for some sol. I didn't have sol coins, but I give just some small change that I had, but the girl I gave them was so disappointed that I couldn't pay for real, that I feld bad and did not take the picture. Otherwise the place was worth of seeing.

Taxi up, walk down. Easiest way to get here from town is by taxi and then walk back down.The site itself is quite large and again I think we would have benefited from having a proper guide rather than relying upon a book. Having said that you can still get a sense of the scale of achievement of the Incas when you look at the size of the stones used in the construction. Mind you, having visited Chinchero the previous day (with a guide) this was a little bit of a let down but still woth the visit.

Historical Place. It's amazing how the authorities keep the remains clean and tidy.Lots of history and architecture here. There is a statue similar to Christ the Redeemer (Brazil) overlooking the city.
Awesome. Brilliant Inca site, worth a visit, again Condor Travel supplied the most knowledgeable guides. The views and areas are outstanding
Worth a look. This was part of a day trip but don't expect to see Muchupichu, we found it interesting to learn about the local history and walk up close to the walls.
Worth the trip. Really impressive ruins just outside of Cusco. You can take the public bus here for almost no money. We took the Cristo Blanco bus from Avenida del Sol and Sto. Domingo.

Introduction to the great Inca sites. This will probably be one of the first Inca sites you visit after settling into Cusco, and is a fine example of such early engineering and architecture. Not too many steps in this one, unlike other such sites.

Impressive. Don't miss this historic site. There is an amazing atmosphere here: you can almost feel the way the Incas worked, building with the huge stones, designing and measuring the the walls. Well worth the fee. Our guide was extremely knowledgeable. I wished I could have stayed longer to absorb the details of the construction and the the lives the Incas must have led. The site is huge so leave plenty of time to walk round it. There is very little shade so bring your hats and umbrellas to shield you from the sun. It wasn't too crowded when we went in the morning.

More stones. After a while when you visit the Peruvian mountain range you see lots of rocks ...what's interesting here are the size of the rocks used in building. However when the locals try to reconstruct they do a poor job
Worth the visit. We went here prior to Machu Picchu and it was a great way to get some history before the trek to Machu Picchu. Very nice with some interesting information.

Bring your sunscreen. Bought tickets in town for 70 sol from the tourist info centre for the tourist circuit just outside of Cusco. Well worth every penny. We hopped on and off the local bus, which cost about 1 sol each time, to save walking up and down the hill to the different locations, the locals on the bus will help you along with the small boy who will sometimes be working on the bus collecting money. We worked our way from top to bottom early in the morning and we had each of the places to ourselves pretty much until we went to Sacsayhuaman, which was pretty crowded but still able to walk about a fair bit. Find the slides at Sacsayhuaman to have a go on, make sure you have sturdy shoes as you can go quite fast! They are on top of the hill opposite the main Sacsayhuaman building and to the right.

Impressive Inca site just a short walk from Cusco town centre. Well worth a visit to this Inca site on one of the hills which overlooks Cusco. Admission is 70 soles. Huge Inca stone structures at this site. After your visit, there is a lovely walk back down to the town centre.

How did they build this?. Just on the outskirts of Cusco - a massive site. How on earth did they build this? Easily accessible by taxi, electric bus or on one of the organised trips from your travel company. Well worth a visit.

Amazing example of engineering prowess. A huge site with a long, zigzag wall of beautifully cut and placed stone. Has the remains of a round center - be sure to review the photo at the gate as it is impossible to get near the center.
Amazing ruins, not far from Cusco. Nice way to spend time "acclimatizing" to the altitude in Cusco. We saw a few alpacas too, which was fun!
Amazing. A must see while staying in Cusco. The architecture is as fascinating as Machu Picchu but within the Cusco city limits. Take a taxi or tour guide up to see it. You will not regret it.

Great, a must if you are in Cusco. Right there!! Is around the corner of Cusco, if you go on a tour, you normally visit 3 or 4 other place, but this one is the best one, I went with a tour guide in a group (which I regret), is so close to Cusco, that I'm sure i would have enjoy it better on my own
5 site tour. Above Cusco, did the 70 Soles tour of 5 sites. It was alright for an afternoon excursion. The best was sacsayhuaman. Great views of the city.

Glad we went. Amazing history! Got a guide at the gate and certainly enjoyed all the history and commentary. Schools were practicing for a big event the following w/e so it was very colourful as well as historic. Walked from there to the big hillside statue and then down to the Plaza de Armas but took a taxi up.

Get a guide. A great site to explore, but get a guide and you'll be shown little nooks and crannies most will miss. The official's on the gate were a bit grumpy, refusing to give us a map. Just insist on the way in.

A must see place to visit!. It's worth taking a taxi to Sacayhuaman! Don't try to walk to this area - it's all up hill, roads are narrow and bad and sidewalks are non-existent. It cost us $34 for 5 people and the taxi took us there, waited for us, gave us mini-tour of the city and dropped us off at our hotel. Well worth the money! There were lots of tour groups here but it was so vast that it was quite easy to get away from the crowd. Amazing place and worth going too!Tip- they do charge an admission fee so make sure you have enough cash with you.

A must see - minutes from Cusco. Excellent ruins - unfortunately much of the stonework removed in Colonial times for building the cathedral and other buildings in Cusco. Large blocks that are fit together so perfectly.You will probably get a glimpse of a herd of alpacas roaming across the site.No info availble so have a guide or guidebook.Great view of Cusco.If you are a geologist - some interesting bedrock.

Intriguing!. Fascinating remnants of history and one could almost imagine the local life and festivities taking place here. Architectural and engineering marvel of its time! The Alpacas roaming around added to the experience.. One is very dependent on the guide and the internet for details though.. a local museum / office with some illustrations would have been great I guess.

the head of puma. you wil see the remaining stones from this head (the town of cusco had the shape of a puma body and this hill was the head) until the spanish destroyed for build the cathedral and other buildings..its really amazing the quality of the sharp granite stones that fit perfect between them.and the panoramic view of town is in front to your eyes

Amazing!. Walk across fields populated with llamas, where battles were fought. Explore the "fortress" and learn about the magical ways Incas built with massive stones, using no mortar. Interact with the natives who will pose for pictures or sell you handcrafted souvenirs. Fun afternoon!
Seems like a good spot. such a stellar example of inca might as they constructed this place from stones so big you can't image them ever being moved. must see. must explore. I got engaged there!
The views are great!. Head up there to see a more complete picture of Incan history! It's worth it to have a guide to explain the significance of things.

An Amazing Site. It's mind boggling how multiple-tonne stones were transported there to build this expansive site of worship. The area harbors incredible energy and natives still go there on the solstice in the after-hours to worship.

Hard to say but just remember "sexy woman".... Our tour guide said that if you remembered "sexy woman" you'd never forget how to say Sacsayhuaman. This place is unbelievable and the people who built it were amazing. Every stone fits perfectly and you'll be amazed by this engineering feat!
Spectacular site. Very big setting. You get a great feeling when you stand in the open field and look at the big walls. The view of Cusco is spectacular!

Inca Peru settlement close to Cusco. Jumped on Red bus tour for a whirlwind tour of local sites....
A little like a amusement park ride due to heights of mountains and sharp corners but hey when in Rome! Called sexywoman by our guide who humourously gave a brief overview.
Essential visit for Sacred Valley. This is an essential visit for anyone touring the sacred valley. Complete with impressive Incan ruins. Interesting history. Easily accessible.
incredible ruins. It's difficult to believe that the Incas nearly 900 years ago were able to transport and carve these huge pieces of granite with out any metal tools or modern technology.

Worth seeing. Four of us took a cab up here from Cusco. It cost us $25 US total round trip. At the entrance gate we purchased the Boleto Turistico--Tourist Ticket. It was about $45 US each and good fir 15 different places for 10 days. You need to pay in Soles. At the ruins we hired a guide for $25 Soles and she explained everything in much detail and showed us around for an hour or so. The place is interesting and worth seeing. There are excellent views of Cusco city from the top! It was our first day here and we could feel the elevation. If you feel energetic you can hike to the white Christ from here too. Our taxi was waiting for us, so we didn't.
One of my favorites. A trip to Sacsayhuaman is worth it if you have limited time in Cusco. The construction is amazing and the views are excellent.

Puma!. Along with the other reviewers, I, too, would have liked to have seen it before the Spanish quarried it during the Colonial Period. I was feeling a little short of breath at that point due to the altitude and there was a bench to sit down on and rest for a bit. Our City Tour guide did not necessarily speak an English that I particularly understood, but he certainly did so with gusto! I was able to get the over all effect. The rocks are huge and the Puma shape must have been beautiful.

Interesting Site- Worth A Visit. This is a large Incan site that sits on a hill overlooking Cusco. The views themselves make the visit worthwhile without going into the history of the site. Be sure to slide down the stone slides!
Head of the Puma. This amazing setting above Cusco gives a idea of how stunning the Inca empire must have been in the 14th century. Best with a guide.

Worth taking time to see. This is easily accessable by foot above Cusco. I would suggest getting a guide to give some history, we were impressed with the space but pretty clueless about what we were seeing. Very impressive though, the stones used to build are HUGE! Amazing to think how they moved these things. A good way to spend a few hours in the morning and get away from the hustle and exhaust fumes of Cusco
Amazing construction!. Its incredible how advanced the quechuan were...they built enormous buildings that were able to resist the devastating effects of earthquakes.

Great Ruins. Was there for a short afternoon tour. Walked around some and loved the area. You can see the statue of the white Christ from here. Got some great pictures! Kinda wish I had more time there to enjoy it a bit more.

Beautiful and worth the slight climb. We walked from our hotel, which was up a slightly steep street in a less known part of town that I would recommend only be walked during the day. The cost of the pass that you purchase to enter seems steep until you realize that it includes a 10 day pass to several other sites, so be sure to get this same pass elsewhere before visiting museums or come here first so you save on admissions to other places you may want to visit. The sites extend to the Sacred Valley and the pass covered nearly everything we wanted to see- happy we discovered by chance before we had paid for other entries!
A very spiritual indoctrination. This is one of the major battlefields where the Conquistators slaughtered the Inca people. Believe it or not you can feel their presence and the sorrow.

An incredible sight. We walked here from Cusco. Even after seeing Macchu Picchu, it was still fabulous to see the fortress built to protect Cusco. The stones are enormous and had to be carried from many miles away. The views of Cusco are great.
Fun Hike. Its a 30 min walk from Plaza de Armas. Its a bit of a hike up there but well worth the views. Go there for some spectacular shots of the city and the roaming llamas.
Wonderful city view. We hiked from on high to see this majestic site. Wonderful examples of Incan stone work, their altars, their play (slides- I kid you not!).
Awesome. You have to wonder how the Incas built this fortress with the tool they had. Every stone was so precisely placed that you could not still a needle in between.
Loved Sacsayhuaman. We walked from our hotel up to Sacsayhuaman, obtained a guide at the top and thoroughly enjoyed our tour of this beautiful area. Enchanting!

Oh to see it prior to the Spanish invasion...... What a spectacular place............in some ways it outshone{with some imagination} all else. This is a huge spectacular monument to a short lived civilisation. It should be 60% larger,now that would have been quite something Huh?.
Visit to Sacsayhuaman June 2014. Visited with a group of travellers on Sacred Valley tour. Tremendous views over Cusco - recommend use of a guide to hear the full history

perched above cusco. What an amazing site to see. A must!
If you're feeling up to it, take the stairs all the way up from center city and keep looking around. You'll see majestic views of Cusco as you ascend up.
Worth the visit. Impressive Inca ruins well worth the visit. It is easy to get blasé about sites around Cusco, but with the tourist ticket it is possible to pick and mx where you go.

Great if you are with a tour / have a guide. The views are stunning of the surrounding area and overlooking cusco. If you have a guide then it is really interesting to hear the significance of each area. It is also a great place to have your picture taken with some alpacas.
It was part of the cusco city tour and the tickets were included in the price.
Lovely walk up and interesting ruins. Lovely walk up, if you have acclimatised of course. interesting ruins with plenty of history. The cristo blanco is just next to them.
Stunning construction. What a shame the Spanish didn't recognize the genius of these engineers. They used this site as a quarry.
Not to be missed in Cusco. We really liked our visit here. We went in the morning and it was not crowded. We took great photographs. Do wear sunscreen!

Wow!!. I am amazed by these Inca engineers. They were amazing - the size of the stone here are huge. It is well worth the time. I recommend taking a taxi up and walking back. Stop by the church San Christobel along the way back.

Great site to see. Go with a guide, it takes about 2 hours and you get a great explanation of what went on there during inca times. As all inca sites, here you can see some great thinking that was done to build this site, very interesting!!!

How did they do it?. This site was astounding! How the Incas were able to construct with such precision walls made of stones weighing many tons boggles the mind. Went with a guide which I would recommend.

Amazing. This a rare example of MASSIVE Inca "monumentalism". The installation technique of huge block of stone or granite was employed by the Incas at all major sites but not to the magnitude of Saqsayhuaman. And as usual the precision of stone work is unbelievable. It must be seen to be appreciated
Awesome!!. Amazing stonework by the Incas which would rival anything we have seen in Europe or Egypt. Beautiful llamas grazing around the sight added to the surreal feeling.
Awesome Incan Ruins. Having a tour guide to help us understand the significance of the site, it's construction and use in 1300/1400's made a big difference in our appreciation.
