Incredible site. The site is incredible but it could do with a bit more historical knowledge and information so you can understand the history better. There are guides who you can hire to take you round but if you want to visit it solo there's nothing available in any language.

Hmm, definitely not a must see. First off, it is pricy. The ticket is 70 soles and they do not even provide a flier or map about the place. It is also not very interesting, I had a hard time figuring out what is what. It does have nice views over the city and it is not too far, so if you don't mind the money, go for it!

Amazing evidence of Incan architecture and construction. This is an expansive site with many structures still intact despite being raided by the Spanish to facilitate construction of their christian churches and cathedrals. Interestingly many of the Incan walls outlived spanish buildings in this land of relatively frequent earthquakes!After your guided tour, allow an hour or so just to walk around this site - lovely.

Wow. The ruins are on a plateau high above Cusco. There is interesting information near the entrance. Massive stones are set together in formations. It's awesome. Paths are available to climb up to the top of the walls. The views across from one ruin to the other is stunning.
so and so. Nice trip to this location, nice views of the city. here you could find some locals with the alpacas and llamas to take some pictures

Cusco ruins amazing. Really loved our time at Sacsayhuaman with our guide Percy Salas from Cusco. it was stunning. Wish I could see the Sun ceremony June 24th for solstice. the site is huge and open, giving you a sense of the building prowess of the Inca and the size and vastness of this empire. You can see the wall of the inca trail up on the hills. Really a great experience...got chills walking here. and a great view of Cusco, a really charming city.

Impressive Inca Remains. A very large site with quite impressive remains. The foundations are made up of very large shaped dry stone walls and terraces. The large size one of the main reasons why the stone was not stolen by the Spanish for use in Cusco (very close to the site) and by Peruvians until early last century. The smaller stones used higher up terraces have largely been taken away reducing the height of this site. Another part of the site was used as a quarry and further construction was halted when the Spanish arrived so there are some other unfinished terraces. Allegedly the sight is in the shape of a puma but I find this hard to visualise. Makes a good picnic spot in fine weather.

Unbelievable!. What is left is impressive. Huge stones fit tightly together to form three levels of walls. An engineering marvel. The Spanish demolished much of the site to take stones for their buildings. Even through the 1940's people were allowed to come and take stones. Oh to imagine what this must have been like before all that.
Nice opportunity to see Incan ruins. Nice opportunity to see Incan ruins, great view of Cusco is just a short hike while here. Easily acceesible

Amazing ruins. We had a private tour guide through Kuoda Travel take us here on our Cuzco tour. It was incredible to think how it was built. This was one of the couple main important places in the Inca capital of Cusco. It only takes about 30-45 mins to go through and it is definitely worth it.

Great ruins, beautiful view of the city. It was great to get up to Sacsayhuaman. Really cool to see the remainder of this important fortress after reading about it's history. A couple of notes for future travellers:-Definitely taxi up. Our travel book said you could walk, but it would have taken us half the day to walk from center of the city and it only cost us ~10 sole to get there by taxi. -It's expensive so bring plenty of crisp cash. I forget how much it was, but definitely look it up before you get there. -You may want to hire a tour guide at the sight, there's basically no information up there about what you're looking at. As I mentioned, I had read about it so I could explain a little to my wife since we didn't have enough money to afford a guide. Otherwise, it might have been less interesting.-It has beautiful views of the city. I can imagine that if you make the timing work, it would be really cool to be up there at sunset.
Inca ruins. Like most Inca ruins, it's incredible how they were able to build walls and buildings without mortar with amazing precision. Walk to the top for overall view of Cusco.
wow. Incredible stone work, views from the top were amazing ! Guide was very informative. Don't miss this !

Worth the walk both up and down from Cusco. I would recommend getting a guide as I would have missed a lot of interesting features. Shame the Spanish conquistadors did so much damage to the monuments, even using the place as a quarry for them to build their colonial buildings. The views over Cusco and the grazing alpacas are an added bonus!

A must see on your visit to Cuzco. Sacsayhuaman has amazing views and even more incredible architectural construction. We were so luck, as we where there on Thursday, May September 18 were young men training, performing ceremony and speaking in the old language. We came with guided tour, which I highly recommend.

Anniversary Trip. Definitely worth seeing. This site was included on our city tour of Cusco. They are still uncovering parts of this site which was part of Cusco before the Spanish conquest, more examples of the incredible Inca masonry

Not to be missed. Easy walk from Cusco and a only a short walk up the road for several other sites. Buy the tourist pass in Cusco save some cash and see allot.I spent hours at this site checking out the Inca stonework. Awesome!

Massive. Impressive dimensions you can spend a long time here due its size. Great views of the city as well. Better to go early to avoid the crowds, do not really need a tour guide; much better to do at your own pace.
Don't miss Sacsayhuaman. The ruins are a must when visiting Cusco. The giant rocks are even more impressive than those at Machu Picchu although the scenery is average.

Ancient construction high above Cusco. Part of the ancient Inca network of sites leading to the main temples of Cusco. Intricate construction with huge stones, with wonderful views of Cusco and the surrounding mountains.

City Bus Tour. This was a great tour as you could sit back and relax while the tour bus transported you from one place to another. Sacsayhuaman was a place where Inca kings and queens came to worship and where the high priests lived.

"Sexy Woman" as it is commonly pronounced lol. Amazing architectural construction of a defensive fort. Rivals anything I have seen in the middle east. Guided tours are the only way to see this attraction, otherwise you really do not have a proper perspective of what you ar looking at and the history behind it.
interesting ruins. interesting story surrounding these ruins. great photo opportunity! Bring a warm coat as it gets cold up there!
Amazing ruins. Very close to the beautiful city of Cuzco. Very large area of Inca construction. So interesting , beautiful views.

SPECTACULAR MAJESTIC RUINS,PEACE INSPIRING. The ruins exude peace. The overwhelming size of the stones is humbling and a silent reminder of the magnificent Inca civilization. The view is stunning, don't miss it!

Amazing, how did those stones get there?. This place will make you really ponder just how strong and determined the Incas were. The size of these stones, where they came from, how they were transferred and how they fit together like a perfect puzzle piece is just astounding. The views of the city are breath-taking and there are several opportunities to get up close and personal with the alpacas. There are 3 other temples you can view if you purchase the group ticket. Most require extra walking. There is also an option to visit all on horseback. You can do this on site very easily, so no need to plan transportation in advance.

A bit of a hike from Cusco town center but definitely worth it!. Definitely take the time to hike up here when staying in Cusco. The ruins and views are amazing. Our tour company recommended this to us - glad we checked it out!

Buy the touristic ticket! That place is included and you can do many more. Sacsayhuaman is very close to Cusco, you can walk since Plaza de Armas. Buy the touristic ticket on your first day of Cusco, that way you can see a lot of places, spending less. Me and my friends didn't, and we regreat! Sacsayhuaman is a big place, a complex of ruins! Very nice

Spend as long as you can at Sacsayhuaman. I initially visited Sacsayhuaman whilst on the Cusco City Tour and only had half an hour here which is nowhere near long enough to explore this amazing site. I'd recommend spending at least half a day here as the site is enormous. On my second visit here, I was the first visitor to arrive at 6.45 am and fortunate to be given a private guided tour by a shaman who happened to be there early. He showed me all the energetic hot spots around the site, the dark passageway in the rocks that you can walk through, various places which I wouldn't have found without his help ... then he showed me his ceremonial centre nearby. I felt very blessed to have had such a fantastic guide. You can go walking in the mountains after your tour. I found some stables close by and went to the Temple of the Moon on horseback which was brilliant. Tip: if you are only able to visit for a short time on a tour, keep your ticket and you may be let in again to have a longer look around if you have more time to spare.
Not to be missed. Gorgeous ruins! A short walk to an incredible site. Not Machu Picchu but very interesting. Glad we were taken there on our tour of Peru.

Amazing arhitecture. This is a must see if you are in Cusco. But don't do as a lady from our tour group, that went to the trip right after she get off the plane, because, of course you wont be well. Lay a bit in the bed, for 2-3 hours before doing any kind of effort. Now, the site is amazing. The perfect cut stones are breathtaking. It makes you realize that the ancient civilizations weren't that ancient as you may think. They were more evolved than we are now. They could be evolved even without smartphones. You also get a really nice view from the top.
Not to be missed. This is the South American rendition of Stonehenge. Be sure to get a tour with a good guide. Otherwise you won't understand what you are seeing. It's quite impressive.

Amazing architecture and history. This is one of the most easily accessible Inca ruins as it's within just a few kilometers from the center of Cusco. If you're really fit, you can hike up there from Plaza the Armas. The guidebooks optimistically estimate 30+ minutes - but that's if you're truly athletic and in prime shape. Another reason for NOT hiking up, even if you're physically able, is the fact that it's not safe to be walking on the shoulders of narrow, twisty and hilly roads where drivers are not in the habit of yielding to pedestrians. You can get a taxi up, or to 'kill two birds with one stone', you can get a city-tour (on a double decker) for 20 soles, get off at Sacsayhuama - and spend as much time there as you want, then catch another double decker bus (from the same company) back to town. Once you're at the site, do try to spend at least one hour to waslk around and appreciate the wonderful craftsmanship of the long-gone Inca stone masons. It's a real shame that some tourists just stay on the bus, which stops for maybe 5 minutes, for photos from afar. I believe that one can only appreciate the intricacy, the precision, the workmanship of the Incas by walking up and down the structures (staying on the marked paths, of course), eyeing the individual stones as well as viewing the entire complex from every possible angle. It's amazing how these large blocks of stones, some 11 feet tall, weighing up to 300 tons, could have been precisely fitted to their neighboring blocks by workers who had no use of the wheel and no access to power equipment. On the historic side: this was the site where one of the last Incas dared to challenge the power of the Spanish conquistadores - and where thousands of his followers were killed by the Spaniards. Due to its close proximity to Cusco, its grand architecture and its historical significance, Sacsayhuaman should not be missed by anyone visiting Cusco.

Took an afternoon tour!. This place is right outside the city limits of Cisco on the hilltop, so you can either take a tour or there is a sightseeing bus that will do drop off/pick up for this sight. It is amazing to look at the walls & how perfect they all are. You can walk a few miles to look at all the sites. There is a good view of the city of Cusco as well as Cristobal Blanco. Well worth taking in!

Mesmerizing place. Seriously they are all rocks. two hills of rocks on either side and you will think what are these? This was my favorite place in Cusco. The best thing to do is go in sunset. Take a seat in one place, perhaps on the grass, on any of the rocks, or anywhere. Don't just take a picture and walk through. Once you sit down, you will start to see it is actually very nice place. After hearing some commentaries from the tourist, I could start imagining what people would have done here. Take a moment, strangely this is a place I want to go back again.

Impressionable. If you are a person that feels a place and the ancient structures therein can weave a story all on its own, this is a site worth seeing. At only 20% of the original structure remaining (the Spanish gutted the rest for the construction of the cathedral) your mind will be left to ponder what impressions this ancient fortress might have held in its heyday.

How did the Quechua people do it?. The monumental stones, the detail of the stone work, the spectacular locations....see it with a guide who can bring the history of the culture to life (as ours did). Recommended.
Must see.. Amazing Inca temple complex with unbelievably large stones and great views. Went here with a local guide as part of our BackRoads tour. Fee paid by the tour.

Stunning examples of Inca buildings. This is the site of a major battle between the Spanish and Inca's and even in its current state you can see what a major Inca site it is (obviously not up to Machu or Ollantaytambo), but the size of some of the stones are unbelievable. You probably need about an hour to visit. Also on the main plain is a small tunnel for you to walk through, but it is very dark so take care one hand out in front and walk sideways!!This is worth a visit if you are staying in Cusco.
Amazing views of Cusco.. We took a taxi up (altitude) and walked down. It is definitely worth going to see. Amazing ruins in great condition. Definitely worth taking the time.
wonderful area. liked wide open spaces and spectacular views. children loved wild alpacas and small market areas. a short drive out of town.
Huge stones!. What a site! The fortifications were amazing rivaling Stonehendge and the pyramids. That they broke our group of 40 into groups of 10 was perfect to listen to the guide.

How could they have done it!!!. A sense of wonder invaded our group as to how things could be been put in place! It goes far and beyond the imagination!!! I believe that the best way to enjoy is to hire a guide! We all used Harmony travel and found that our guide was fully emerged in his history and knowledge of his culture!!!! Great experience!!!

More Powerful Than Macchu Picchu. Sacsayhuaman (pronounced 'sexy-woman'), is only a short walk from Cusco town center (make sure it's daylight hours) and almost always overlooked by tourists in favour of the more internationally know Macchu Picchu... but that's their loss and your gain.Sacsayhuaman is massive! 40 ton rocks litter the place... the stone work is near perfect and the condition of the Inca ruin is excellent. Having seen many many ruins across all of Peru and South America, I have to say that Sacsayhuaman sticks in my mind for no other reason than it's big, it's powerful and it's a clear statement of strength.Yes, go to Macchu Picchu but when you are next sitting in central Cusco and wasting away an afternoon drinking beer... consider a short stroll to Sacsayhuaman... you won't be disappointed.

Horserides recommended. There is actually lots more to see around the ruins of Sacsayhuaman, ruins which can easily be accessed by horse. Horserides aren't very expensive and much fun. You also get to see beautiful sceneries and a unique look onto Sacsayhuaman.
Wonderful. On this site you feel like you travel in time. Quiet place for meditation and the view is just stunning.
beautiful place. interesting place is so big the stones really charming, a hope returng to Cusco i visitd it first than machupicchu

wonderful way to acclimatise before trekking. Our trekking group had a day to acclimatise before trekking the Lares Valley to Machu Picchu. Our local tour guides took us on a walk around Cusco and then up to Sacsayhuaman where we learnt all about the ruins here. fantastic and absolutely worth a visit. The views across Cusco are also amazing.

Jaguars head. One of the best examples of Inca stonework outside of Machu Pichu. Outerwall is set at angles, one guide said it was to give it stability to resist earthquakes, another said it was to resemble Jaguars teeth as Cusco was designed in the shape of a Jaguar and Sacsayhuaman was its head.
Nice big ruins. These ruins are pretty big and overlook the town. Definitely worth checking out. Make sure you visit the other 3 ruins nearby too.

A truly magnificent site!. If you choose, you could walk from Cuzco to this site, but at 12000 ft above sea level, take a tuk tuk or a taxi.
This site has some of the most awesome architectural constructions of the pre-Columbian culture of Peru. If it is just one site you get to see while in Cuzco, away from the city, DO IT!

Very important tips about seeing Sacsayhuaman, Cusco Peru. Do not bother paying 70 soles or USD$70 to visit Sacsayhuaman, walk up to Cristo Blanco from Cusco city and you will have a good view of Sacsayhuaman from there. Trust me, I have done that and it is worth it, free for all to access Cristo Blanco. If you think my reviews have been helpful to you, please click 'Yes' for 'Was this review helpful?'

A Must See!. The was one of the power points of the Incan Empire. The stone work is spellbinding. It is a great place to stroll around, especially on a Sunday afternoon when local families are out and about, flying kites nearby. Nearby are three other Incan sights-they can all easily be done in an afternoon, taking a local bus for 1 Sole from Q'enko to PukaPukara and back.

Good view. Getting here is a little difficult, but we got a tour bus of the city and it took us up here. The view of Cusco is good, the statue of Jesus is not that impressive. There are the usual entourage of women selling handicrafts.

Amazing. It was cold & rained- later there was snow. It is an amazing site- be prepared before you go. We were amazed at the architecture & history of the site. The view from above cannot express the actual size of the location & proximity to Q'enqo & Christo Blanco.

A must see!. It is amazing what ancient cultures managed to accomplish and the Incans were no different. I can not imagine how them moved such large stones into such perfect formation. It is well worth it to visit this site and see what they managed to accomplish. No pictures do it justice.

Didnt pay to go in. It was 70 soles to get a ticket in, but we paid 20 soles for an uncovered bus tour of the whole town of Cuzco that went right through here. So we got to see great sights of the rocks and walls - just not able to walk around them or touch them. Not sure it is worth the extra money to get in, especially if you just came from the awesomeness of Machu Picchu - but it was really cool to see this site and learn of its history. It is worth a visit - maybe if we had the Bolleta de Tourista that would include other sites, it would have been more worth it.

HORSEBACK RIDING IN CUSCO only the best way to visit Sacsayhuaman.. horseback riding in the archaeological park of Sacsayhuaman the best way to enjoy this wonderful place in Cusco, the ruins can be visited with a guide, to know and understand everything, and most importantly understand the positive energy of this wonderful place. Informs them what they need to enjoy the most of this most mystical and beautiful place. Rent horses and visit the whole park is So good!, For the X Zone, Moon Temple, Sun Temple, the face of Inka, and many more beautiful places. I can recommend them to the correct and honest person to take them riding through all these beautiful places.
Ruins above the city. It was a short hike up from the Plaza to Sacsayhuaman and a couple of hours were spent wandering around this amazing area of ruins.

Lovely spot. My sister & I hiked up to Sacsayhuaman while we were staying in Cusco for a few days pre Inca Trek. It's only a 20 minute walk from the Plaza des Armas in Cusco city centre so if you have some free time its definitely worth the wander up. It does cost 70 sol to enter but there are great views of the city and you can wander around the ruins. It could do with some actual tourist information on site telling you about the ruins and giving you some perspective on the history etc which is why I only gave it 4 stars. Try and find the stone slide that you can slide down as it isn't mentioned in the Lonely Planet and we only heard about it from other travellers who had found it but we missed it ourselves as the site is huge and you could spend ages there. Indeed some families brought picnics and made a day out of it!! Worth a visit if you are in the locale :)

something for everyone. This large national park area has something for everyone: a smaller Christ the Reedemer, two Inca remain sites, local craft shops, huge park area for BBQ/kite flying and family days out.

Beautiful ruins near Cusco.. I visited Sacsayhuaman on a day tour of sites just outside of Cusco. We took a taxi around to these ruins and sites and this was one of our favorites. It was easily accessible and wonderful to walk around in. We took a lot of pictures.

A must visit in cuzco. Located up on the hills above the city, it is a quick 5-8 minute taxi from the plaza de armas. Taxi should be around 8 soles. It opens at 8 so get up there at 8 to beat the tour groups. Its a great sight with many picture opportunities. Get there at opening and start at the ground level where the big stones are to get the best pictures before people start to arrive. Later on work your way up to see the city from the top. Also good to do is walk to the other hill to visit the statue of christ and a better view of the city.

Awe inspiring. Sacsayhuaman, a stone fortress strategically built on a hill overlooking Cusco, Its walls were made of huge rocks, piled neatly one on top of another, and some of the walls standing over 30 ft high and the rocks weighing over 350 tons. Theories abound on how the stones were transported and set into position. Very impressive Incan engineering. Great place for group pictures.

This place rocks. Sacsayhuaman is incredible. It is huge, built of stones that looked immovable. Used as an Inca administrative center it must have covered acres and acres of land. From the top you look down on the city of Cusco. I loved this spot.
So worth the time. Giant teeth walls - amazing. Friendly dogs roaming the park - amazing. Even slightly drunk guide - amazing.

Hike up from the historic center! Well worth it!. One sunny Sunday I wanted a change of pace from the bustling historical center where my hotel was. So I started early and wound my way up the skinny streets, ascending steep stairs where dogs slept and worked my way up, up, up along the stream, until I was way above Cusco. Sacsayhuaman was the fortress where there were two towers and a formidable wall that is impressive to see because of its zig zag formation. You can enjoy a fabulous view of Cusco from where the towers were as well as vistas of the surrounding mountains and trees. Llamas graze freely along the hills. I really enjoyed my hike up! Bring plenty of water and sunscreen, because there are very few places to shop up there. The city tour bus will take you up there, but they stop briefly at a remote tourist trap and there is no time to buy a ticket and walk the grounds. You could always taxi it up, but why not hike, after you recover from elevation exasperation. I say go!
amazing. who build these amazing architectural complex that is breathtaking at all? dont to be missed in a sunny afternoon!

Not worth the price. The ruins are certainly interesting but 70 Soles is way too much for this place. You can see the best parts of the ruins, which are the walls, without entering it. Just go on the hill across it. There is not much more to see when you enter so basically there is no point in paying that much money.
An amazing Inca outpost. Excellent views and incredible engineering feat. It is being overwhelmed by the increasing number of visitors.

Interesting and well preserved. This is a great ruin. And worth 90 minutes or so. Can walk around it. A guide is very helpful to fully appreciate the context and importance. Perhaps the most important part of historical Cusco to see.

Fascinating. A large and interesting site. The zig-zag walls and enormous stones were worth seeing. Good information boards although we were lucky enough to have a guide with us. Very close to the White christ.

Can't Pronounce it, But I Loved it!. This is a large site and encompasses spectacular views of Cusco.You have the opportunity to climb the ruins and it is a much easier climb than at Ollantaytambo and Machu Picchu. The site is also included in the multi ticket if you have one.It's definitely worth seeing.

Fascinating History Perched above Cusco. My mom and I loved this site. It is large and beautiful, and you can see all of Cusco from here. Don't walk up from the plaza del Arma unless you want a bit of a trek. You can easily take a taxi.

Andean Architecture at it's finest.. Expensive to get in (70 soles each) if you only want to see one place, but very worthwhile especially if you have a guide. Good views of amazing Inca block-work with Massive granite stones and excellent views of Cusco.

Great history. I happened to see this on History Channel a few weeks before my Machu Piccu hike. So I was intrigued and came to the site. It was very impressive and I really enjoyed it and thought it was worth the entrance fee. Huge rock structures that fit perfectly into one another- one of the world's "how the heck was that built?" items. Believe it was $30 to enter.

Impressive !. This site is awesome ! We spend a day there and felt the magic of the place. The mystery of how these structures were built is still unresolved. We were looking for answers but never find one which is good because keep us dreaming about how the Inca world were in realty...
Interesting Site. Amazing structures with huge stones. Can be confusing without a guide to explain the history. Worth spending a half day there.

Don't buy the hype - strictly average. It's close to Cusco, and is a genuine historic structure, so there is a lot of hype. Try not to be swayed, because it isn't that big of a deal actually. Plus, there are almost no explanatory signboards in English, so you won't be able to understand anything without a good guide.If you have a good camera, you would be able to get some excellent pictures of the views and the area in general.
amazing. The whole place is just magical... The sun, the landscape.. if your breath is ok, you can go up the ruins and see the whole city of Cuzco from a great angle!
So interesting. One of several spots around Cusco that are definitely worth a visit. If you are interested in the Incan history you will enjoy getting a sense of this culture

Don't miss this. Titled Sexy woman by locals and travellers alike - Make sure that you don't miss this. Hire a local guide at the site and take in the wonders of a magnificent and huge old city.This will set the tone for your Machu Pichhu visit.

An amazing place I'd never heard of. This is a very large Incan fortress with huge blocks of granite fitted together seamlessly. I can't even imagine how the Incans managed to construct this in ancient times. It's truly impressive.

Good view of Cusco from above. You can easily purchase a "boleto touristico" at the office near the Plaza. I walked to Sacsayhuaman from the Plaza de Armas. It was definitely all uphill, steep and draining in the hot sun. We were unsure if we were going the right direction because there is no clear signage or view of Sacsayhuaman from below. We used directions given by locals along the way and as we got higher, we used the Cristo Blanco as reference. I want to add that hiking up to Sacsayhuaman will be quiet along the way and if you are a woman or with other females, you will most likely get some catcalling along the way. However, I recommend hiking up to Sacsayhuaman if you want to challenge yourself physically. I don't recommend it if you are thinking about doing this the first day you want to arrive in Cusco. One of my friends just arrived on the day we were going to Sacsayhuaman and ended up getting altitude sickness that night. I really enjoyed the view of Cusco while we were up in the mountain. The huge boulders of this old fortress was absolutely impressive to me. However, if you want to compare it to Machu Picchu, it is no comparison. If you are not interested in gazing at huge rocks that are remnants of an old fortress, you may not find that your trip up here or the money spent will be worth it. I was excited to look for the "slides" that I've seen pictures of but could not find it when I was there. If you are going to be in Cusco for a few days and have a few hours to spare, Sacsayhuaman may be a great thing to put on your itinerary. If you have limited time in Cusco, Sacsayhuaman can easily be skipped. By the way, we took a taxi back down to the Plaza and it was only about 5 minutes! I think our walk up was about 45 minutes with plenty of moments where we needed to stop and take a break!

A Close Inca Site To Cusco...Something To Do. After a couple of days in Cusco getting acclimated to the high altitude, we decided we needed to do something without over exerting ourselves. So we took one of the tourist buses. They drive around to a few of the local spots but one of them that they stop at is Sacsayhuaman. You get a good view of the large stones that are used throughout the city. You can also see where they cut them. The area is well kept and there are a few alpacas wondering around the site. I don't think you need more than a few minutes for good photos and be on your up to the next site. I think if you don't have time for this, you won't miss anything since you will see what you need at MP. (To Travel Is To Live)

Impressive place!. We had a wonderful guide (Christian) in Spanish who debunked all the myths about Sacsayhuaman, very entertaining. The site itself is impressive, very different from Machu Picchu obviously, but not to be missed when in Cusco!

Don't miss in Cusco. Amazing architecture and history. One of 4 nearby Inca sites, all worth seeing. Can walk here from town-up hill, but just take your time and you'll be there! Buy a boleto touristico for cheapest entry to all the sites.

"just ok". We saw the Sacsayhuaman ruins during our trip to Machu Picchu-----and I must say that although the ruins are interesting, they pale in comparison to Machu Picchu. I am not sure that these ruins are worth visiting----but I guess it is on the itinerary of every tourist who visits Machu Picchu. The only reason that all of us can remember this site is the "sexy woman" pronounciation of the the name told to every tourist by every guide.

A great architectural achievement. Saw many ruins and this was probably the better one. Was interested by Robert D below talking about safety as we have not felt threatened. We chose to do a self-tour with a driver so that we could control the time - eventually, the more you see, the more boring it becomes. Obviously all the locals call it the "sexy woman" as our hotel concierge did the same.Enjoyed this sight as a highlight and marvelled at the architectural, engineering and building skills and feats.

Boring, but nice views. I did not like this place other than our tour guide telling us the pronunciation is close to "sexy woman". I was able to take some really stunning pictures of Cusco's city center, but this place is not worth the price of admission. I don't know if I disliked it because we headed straight here from the airport, or if it truly is super super boring.

Fascinating. great views. It is (relatively) easy to walk from town to this ruined Inca hill fort. A lot of the original stone has been used elsewhere for house building, but enough remains to see the extent of the structure. you need a pass to get in - either 70S to see just the fort, or 140S to see all things Inca in Cusco and the sacred valley.The views from up here of the city are excellent.There are plenty of Peruvians wanting to give you a guided tour or (as we did) you can just wander round at your own speed.

Great place to acclamate. We used this historical landmark to get our climbing skills warmed up and to get used to the altitude. It was amazing seeing and walking around the engineering and architecture that has survived for 600+ years. What a view of the city. Use a guide to get the most out of the experience!

Impressive Historic Site. To me, every ancient site we visited in Peru was special in its own way and while maybe not as visually stunning as other Peruvian ruins, Sacsaywaman was still an important Incan site and the history here is something you can almost feel as you walk around. The remaining stonework is very impressive and there are lovely views of Cusco from the top of the site. It hosts Inti Raymi celebrations every June 24th. Entry to Sacsaywaman is included with the Boleto Turistico S/130 (along with 16 other sites around Cusco and the Sacred Valley) which is valid for 10 days. You can also buy a partial boleto S/70 (with limited inclusions) at the site which is valid for the day. You can walk here in about 40 mins from Cusco, but it’s all uphill so, taking the altitude into account, we got a taxi and then walked back down into Cusco instead. The site lacks any informative signage, so we negotiated a price with a guide at the entrance. We definitely found that the historical information provided by our guide added to our appreciation and overall enjoyment of the site. I would recommend 1.5-2 hours here to enjoy it at a leisurely pace. Although only about 20% of its original size, the area is still quite large.
Trip to Cusco and the Sacred Valley. Fabulous site that really needs at least half a day to explore. Take a slow pace though because of the high altitude - it really does affect your breathing.

You can walk here from Cusco. This is a very interesting ruin overlooking Cusco, and you can walk there from the city. You don't need to book a tour to get there, and you can pick up a guide when you arrive if you so desire. It does have an admission fee, so be forewarned, especially if you aren't doing the Sacred Valley circuit. It was totally worth it from our perspective as we had limited time and were on to Machu Picchu after this. This ruin is different from many others - totally military - and it looks and feels different from what you'll see elsewhere. Be sure to be prepared for sun (I got sunburned) and also to be bowled over by the llamas and alpacas.

Amazing structures.. I'll be honest I wasn't as excited about this place as I had been for some of the other ruins around Cusco. Maybe because it'd been talked up so much and because everyone that goes to cusco can get here as it's so close. Had just finished the Inca trail and Machu Pichuu the day before, so maybe was expecting too much! Still a great spot though.
incredible...... This is the spot where the stone were molded into place and kit like a jig saw puzzle. The stone were the sizes of houses.
How did they do that?. The rock walls here are stunning. It is a wonder how the Inca made such perfect walls with such amazingly huge stones!

Monoliths you must see. We visited Sacsayhuaman four years ago, and were able to go up to all the walls and building... not so anymore, which is disappointing.. not only can you not go up to these monoliths, now every picture you take has some rope or other barrier marring the beauty of the stones and carving.However... this is a site well worth seeing, but please make sure to allow yourself enough time to view it. Often the tour companies will take you to several sites in a day, but won't allow enough time at any one of them to really get a feel. We spent maybe an hour or so here, at sunset, and it wasn't enough to do more than walk from one end of the site to the other, where you will be bombarded with souvenirs to purchase and children trying to get you to hold their lambs (for a fee, of course)). There are walls opposite the main site, that wrap all the way around the back of the hill... obviously we didn't get to see these. I would recommend a minimum of 3 hours to roam around and take in the various walls, buildings and vistas.This site is very easy to get to from Cusco. Buy your "tourist ticket" at the tourist office in Cusco, which will allow you access here (and a bunch of other places you'll want to see too.) There is also horse back riding nearby that I assume goes into the ruins, although within the ruins we saw no evidence of either horses, or what horses generally leave behind.

Much better than Machu Picchu!. I am telling you.....the ruins of the Sacred Valley are INFINITELY better than Machu Picchu. They are SO MUCH less crowded, SOOOO much easier to get to and you can easily find a friendly fairly priced official guide to walk you around and tell you about the history of the ruins. I really enjoyed my time in the Sacred Valley and I think that the country of Peru does a MAJOR DISSERVICE to the ruins other than Machu Picchu. Seems like that is all Peru cares about. I disagree completely. There are at least 2 days worth of ruins to see, all within an EASY 1 1/2- 2 hour car ride from Cusco! Do your research and check these gems out. Trust me! You will not be disappointed!
Fascinating structures. Constructions to rival Chichen Itza. Beautiful setting just outside Cusco. Go with a guide, you will get much more out of the experience.

Super interesting. This place is yet another gem in and around Cuzco. It has a stunning location looking down on Cuzco and is full of enormous rocks. We went with a guide from Alpaca Expeditions who did a wonderful job of explaining the site. If you have children, make sure you go away from the city, on the other side of the rocks as there are natural slides formed in the rock. Definitely don't miss this place!

interesting visit of an inca fortress. Even if you visit it on a "normal day, rather than during the Inti Raymi of Festival of the Sun, you will find this visit very interesting to understand the Incas' special building skills.

Impressive, but not my favorite Inca ruins by any means. This is generally included on Cusco tours or tours of the Sacred Valley, and it's certainly worth going to as part of that. But it doesn't come close to Machu Picchu, of course, nor is it anywhere near as impressive as Quoricancha in downtown Cusco. If it's not included in what you're booked for, I wouldn't go out of my way to add it.
so cool. cool arquiological place. in the afternoon is windy, so keep a jacket and at the end of the visit, the local people sell corn and cheese to eat. so yummy.

I'll never forget this place. This is the place I think I'll never forget, cause My guide called "Sexy woman". It's very easy to remember it's local name. Apart from it's nick name. I like piles of stones and it's very calm place. I felt very peaceful.

Give it a few hours. If you want to do this ancient site justice, you need to dedicate some time to it. The site is HUGE, but most tour companies and day tours will only have you there for 1-2 hours. If you want to fully enjoy it, take some extra time to explore it more fully

it's a pile of stones. To be honest I was bored, this was the last visit of a city tour thst came at the end of a very long day. Nothin more than stones not a lot to see. Pleasant walk. I was more interedted in the grazing alpaccas
Impressive. Close to city example of Inca construction. Well worth a visit. Just don't believe any hotel concierge who says it's an easy walk.

Sacsayhuaman. Incredible stone architecture. A great place to spend a few hours. We arrived after hiking a long day, so we were exhausted. It would've been nice to arrive here fresh so we had mor energy to explore the place.

Stonebuilding at it's best. This is a great ruin to see the way the Inka built incredible stone formations. Thousands of pounds stones are pieces together like they were cut in modern times and fit beautifully together. Plenty of grass to spread out on, sit and rest if you want. Trails to climb among the stones and a hut or two. Well worth the visit.
My favorite place in Cusco. The Inca gods can really speak to you up at Sacsayhuaman. It's different than the other Inca sites - not to miss.

Great place to explore. Easily reachable on foot from the center of Cuzco for the beginning trekker, these impressive ruins overlook the city. fun to explore on your own, you can also hire a guide at either of the entrances for a minimal fee. Don't forget to explore the hill and religious center opposite the fortress. A couple of tunnels to explore. Catch the sunset over the fortress from the hill opposite.

Great views of the city.. These ruins are a great example of the Inca architecture. The importance of the puma is evident. The Spanish dismantled much of the structure using the stones for other building projects. The construction used concave stones below and convex on top, hence no mortar. Not as magnificent as Machu Picchu or Ollantaytambo, but still worthwhile.

The scale of Inca building !. The sheer scale of this set of ruins blows one's mind. The INCAS did things in grand style. With no steel, iron or wheel technologies. 150 years before the Spanish showed up. Sad that the Spanish so dismantled it. Views breathtaking. Scale of stonework makes one think. Make sure you have a good guide. We had Maribel, from Magical Cusco Tours - whom we strongly recommend. Without the right guide, the experience is less awesome.
Great views of Cusco. Well worth a visit just for the lovely views of Cusco. We got a taxi up to Sacsayhuaman but walked back down into town. Great views all the way.

A very sexy lady indeed!. I originally planned to walk to the site from town (some guide books recommend it), but I'm glad we took a tour as there was very little area to walk on the busy road. I was still a little disappointed with the tour as it did not allow for enough time to explore the site. I would recommend going there by taxi and taking your time.

Amazing views. We walked here from cusco and with a view breaks on the way it was fine - definitely walk instead of a taxi. The view was incredible and the site was beautiful, read up about it before you go. There were loads of llamas to see and even got a photo holding a baby one! Would recommend to anyone. We got a student package which gives entry to loads of ruins around cusco and ollantaytambo - bought in town for s/70.
Simply Spectacular. Amazing place, is a most see in Cusco. Take your time and enjoy the design and the nature around, you will keep thinking about it throughout your lifetime.
Great Site. Great place to visit and spend some time walking around...close to the Cusco city Centrum and easy to get to byy Tazi or bus.
Worth the hike. We hiked up to Sacsayhuaman. It was a lot of steps and of course all up. The view of Cusco from the top was awesome. Go on a clear day. You can also take a bus or taxi up.

Amazing. This was the first of the Incan ruins I went to see, so was blown away by the size of the rocks moved such long distances, and the neat and ordered patterns. Having gone on to see the Sacred valley and Macchu Picchu, this is a young cousin in comparison
Nice bit of history. Went as part of a package. It was a pretty place and it was impressive. I couldn't spend more than an hour here

Definite Must See. English speaking guide was great and answered all our questions. This is the place where the Inti Rami celebrations end on 24 July! Truly impressive, and great view of Cusco down below.
Niceish. Not bad...but compared to the other sites on Cusco it is a bit bland...I wanted to check it out..but could would have missed it if I knew what it is...

Been 3 times, and will go again.. My first time was in 1992 when Peru wasn't such a tourist destination. Then again in 1999 and my last time was August 2013... What a change! Granted it is great that you can now find restroom facilities. I was mostly impressed how the villagers have been taught how to speak English so they can communicate with all the tourists. Sacsayhuaman is a mystical place. Many people lived and died there. It is incredible how these ruins were built with no technology or equipment. Find a since stone, sit and relax. Enjoy the place for what it is with a book on hand. You can easily find a guide by the entrance so you don't overpay. And always offer about 50% less than what they ask for. In Peru, everything is negotiable! Take that from a Peruvian.
Wonderful ruins. A long climb up to watch the spectacular Inca Winter Solstice celebrations. The Inca ruins were extensive but systematically plundered by the Spanish.

Walk from here to Cusco. Instead of writing about how impressive this is, I just want to say that I walked from Sacsayhuaman to Cusco's Plaza de Armas. The walk is downhill and very relaxing. Don't take the bus, just walk and breathe in all that refreshing cold air of Cusco's sundown!

Amazing View. The Inca people prove again their knowledge of building without mortar, fitting stones of all shapes and sizes expertly together. This site is in a beautiful setting with an amazing view of the city and one of the easier sites to walk around.

Cool place, go with guide. We first trekked up to "sexy woman" to see the festivities of Inti Raymi. If you go to this, the atmosphere is very cool to be around, but be prepared to get there very early if you want an actual view of the main event on the ruin parade grounds. There are giant rock slides and epic ruins here. I suggest to go with a guide from a city tour as our second time up there was much more fruitful due to the great information and connections that our guide provided.

Impressive Fortress. Easy to visit from Cusco, this fortress may have been built to celebrate an Inca military victory around 1460. Built over three levels, the ground rampart is impressive built in a zig-zag fashion with enormous blocks that fit perfectly into each other, without using any mortar. We wondered how the poor workers transported these huge rocks to the site on the hill top.Locals call the site 'Sexy Woman'.

Ok - but as most ruins around Cuzco not mandatory. Nice to hear the story from the guide and try to travel back to the good old Inca days but the actual ruins are only so-so. Not absolutely required. Spend more time downtown, in Pisac or in the small vilages in the Sacred Valley.

Impressive Inca fortress ruins. The ruins at Sacsayhuaman are beautiful, as are the views of Cusco spread out below. What a shame the Conquistadors destroyed so much of the fortress; it must have been truly formidable at the time of the battle.

Fascinating. Make sure you do a little reading before you go about the ruins, it really adds a lot to your experience.It's nice how there hasn't been a lot of interference with the ruins with signage, they're pretty much untouched.To get to the ruins 4km away, flag down a taxi for one sol each unless you have time to walk up there.A little pricey at 70sol for entry to the ruins but enjoyable.

SexyWoman. That is how it will sound when the locals or tour guide will pronounce this attraction. This is definitely an attractive site for anyone visiting the Cusco area. There are many explanations as to what the structure was. But to see the large stones placed so intricately with all the different shapes, angles and rounds. It is amazing for the craftsmanship alone. But there is more... a feeling that you are in a very special place.. you come away with a great sense of Ahhhh.
Don't miss!. This site is very interesting--a must see! We also had a guide which added greatly to our experience.
blast from the past. I was in awe when I saw it for the first time. You get a feel on what the Incans accomplished across their empire

Beautiful!. A beautiful sight to behold! The terraced agriculture is demonstrated so well here. There were workers mixing mud/cement for the rock walls by walking in circles IN the gunk. The tombs in the rock walls are fascinating and another example of the class system that was in place years ago. My sons walked to the top and said the view was well worth it (I was dealing with a bit of altitude sickness and did not join them). Add this to your Cusco itinerary!

Archeological Awe. This site gave me an appreciation of the seemingly impossible logistics required to build ancient stone walls. And it helped me understand the impact of the Spanish/Catholic culture upon the original agrarian society. And it was beautiful.

Better in Real life.. An interesting bus ride through Cusco up to the site and a great guide to tell us all about it. We had of course seen documentaries about these massive, strangely cut stones but to actually stand beside them and see the exact fit was awesome. Hearing the stories of the area and the ancient people that lived there and built the fortress There were alpacas wandering around the site as well and a great view of the whole city plus the white 'Christ the Redeemer' statue on a nearby hill. Our group walked down the back streets to the main square in Cusco which gave us a chance to see the local houses close up.

High energy place!. I will rate this 5 not because of what you can see there but what you can feel!High energy place, Reload. (I felt this in only two places the other one is in Scotland "Fairie Glen")... Very nice place, choose evening for the visiting time, the less people the better! :)Uphill walk from Cusco 15mins. Forth it!

INTI RAYMI 2014. We got the tkts for INTI RAYMI 2014! We paid 140usd per person but it was worth it! It took 2hrs of continuous ceremonies of coca leave, chicha & sacrifice of live llama (which they did in very theatrical way & extremely caferul not to scare little ones)! Lots of colors & traditions! Tickets have assigned seats and it all started at 1:30pm! Do not be late like many tourists who paid so much and missed most of show!!

I liked it. It was a bright sunny day during my visit. The sprawling fields and stone monuments were magical in a way and looking out at Cusco from here was quite a sight.A bit like Stonehenge in many ways but different in many as well. You can actually walk up into the monument site and explore the ruins. I think it's a visit not to be missed. Added advantage is to have a knowledgeable guide with you.

Amazing experience. Saqsayhuaman was awesome. There is so much to see and at the top, there is an amazing photo op and a panoramic view of Cuzco. Plan to spend at least 2 hours here. There is so much history and it is amazing to see. The ruins are beautifully preserved and it is a very interesting place. One of my favorite spots in Cuzco. Highly recommend, but there is lots of walking as it is a big place. When you go over to where they mined the stone further from the ruins itself, there are natural slides carved in to the rock that are really fun.
Great place to visit. the ruins were well preserved and provided an interesting view of the Indians of Peru. The entire area provided nice things to see

Impressive!. Beautiful fortress, impressive huge stone walls! lots of greenery like a park high up youcan see the whole city of Cuzco! We used a guide and it was extremely informative and interesting!

Insight into the Inca Civilization. While visiting Cusco in May our guide took us to Sacsayhuaman, an Inca temple that consisted of ruins remaining from the Inca Dynasty. The site is not far from central Cusco, so it can easily be visited in a few hours. It is an excellent example of Incan architecture, and gives you insight into how intuitive the Inca culture was. When you learn the boulders used to build the stone walls came from 15 kilometers away, you appreciate the ingenuity of the Inca people. You can spend as much time as you like at the site, but it can easily be visited in one to two hours. I would highly recommend going with a guide knowledgeable in the Inca culture.

Huge! Lots to see. Very large area of land covered by these ruins. Definitely plan a few hours to spend here. 25-30 minute uphill walk from most hotels/hostels. The most impressive aspect of Sacsayhuaman are the GIANT stones and flawless architecture. I visited by myself but would join a tour or hire a guide if I did it again. Just so much interesting history behind these ruins!
Renamed "sexy woman". We enjoyed our tour of this interesting place.....our guide renamed it "sexy woman", recommend you experience it.

Amazing Views. A great place to get up and close to some inca ruins. Go before 0730 and the ticket offices aren't open and along with incredible views over Cusco you will find half of its residents exercising in the morning cool. Well worth the early wake up
Impressive stonework. Sacsayhuaman is a must-see for archaeology: especially its stonework is really impressive, there are stones of up to 300 tonnes!!! Incredible how the Incas did this.
interesting site very close to the city. very interesting. HUGE stones used in construction. Worth a trip up if you are in town for a few days.

Well worth the hike from Cusco!. We walked up the stair to this Inca ruin and we were sure glad we made the effort. Great ruins that we could climb on and explore without feeling like we were in a museum. Our kids loved the various caves and carvings. The hike was quite strenuous but you can take a taxi. Great view of Cusco and surrounding mountains!

Saksaywaman, Saqsaywaman, Sasawaman, Saksawaman, Sasaywaman or Saksaq Waman. This is also a MUST when visiting Cusco, since is really close to downtown AKA Historic Center. It is fortress and it´s made of large polished dry stone walls. They are exquisitely cut to fit together, and is so close without spaces that you just wonder... HOW?
Amazing view of Cusco and the Mountains. Interesting Incan temple but the best part is the view of Cusco and the surrounding mountains. Plus we saw llamas!

first visit to Inca ruins. Our first day in Cusco we were taken to this amazing site. The festival of the sun was happening in a couple of days and there was lots of activity. A great first view of the ancient Inca's ruins
Nice archeological site. Nice archeological site but I have seen much more impressive ones in other countries such as Mexico.
huge rocks!. Impressive. We watched the practices for the Inti Raymi celebrations. The place gives you a real feel for the expertise in Incan construction. how did they get those rocks there??

The Stonework of the Incas. The stones at Sacsayhuaman are an enigma, when considering when they were constructed (between 900 and 1400 AD) and the massive size (some weighing up to 200 tons). But their alignment, perfectly smooth surfaces, and amazing mortarless construction exemplify the advanced civilization of the ancient Incas.

Well worth seeing and so close to Cusco so easy to see. This was out introduction to the Inca building and it was certainly impressive - the stones here are HUGE and it certainly gives you some feeling of the detail involved in what the Incas did when building.

Sexy woman easy Tour. After having climbed through Inca ruins in the Sacred Valley and Machu Picchu it was a pleasant change to take a short drive out of Cusco and visit the impressive stonework at Sacsayhuaman. The size of the stones hewn by the Incas is absolutely incredible. The panoramic views are not to be missed and as long as you have acclimated to the altitude at Cusco this is an easy visit and should not be missed.

Impressive site. Best with a guide that you can generally find on site ( 1 hr for 30 soles). Incredible Incan Stonework with MASSIVE stones. Be sure not to miss the "slides" and 30 second tunnel at the back of the site.

always a pleasure -- early in the morning. Avoid the crowds in the afternoon and head to Saqsayhuaman around 8am. You will definitely enjoy this stunning place. Walk around the ruins to enjoy a great view of Cusco, as well as the stone toboggans.
Great views!. This is a great site to visit and explore. The views of the city from the walls are fantastic. Get there early to avoid the haze and the crowds. And don't forget the statue of Christ.

Sacsayhuaman Walls. Saqsaywaman was once the capital of the inca empire, it is a huge wall structure located at nothern of Cusco, about 20 minutes from Cusco downtown at an altitude of 3.701 m. It played an important role during the the spanish invasion as it was used as a fortress by the incas against the spanish conquerors.When our tour van set off to Saqsaywaman it was raining, our tour guide said that the rain was not good, and if it doesn't stop or lessen it wouldn't be possible to visit Saqsaywaman, but besides that that was our luck day, right after we arrived in Saqsaywaman the rain started to lessen and it almost stopped completely, but we bought a peruvian hat just in case and to keep our hair dry. We had no umbrellas, but the weather during the day was really nice so we didn't need one.The Saqsaywaman walls are really massive, the view is amazing and mesmerizing, most of the stones used to build it are really huge, that makes you think how the incas were capable of cutting, polishing and stacking up these heavy stones. You can hear a lot of people conjuring conspiration and aliens theories to explain it. At a first glance, the place seems something fake, but once you get closer, have a better look and touch it, you realize how real it is and makes you admire even more what people are capable of achieving once they have a purpose and the right "motivation".The are a total of three line of walls that spreads through a long part of the site, at the middle you can find a huge open area that is if often used in modern days to celebrate the annual winter solstice Inti Raymi inca festival.The place is usually crowded with tourists with a lot of tour groups visiting the place at the same time, but will find lots of space to roam around, to have a better view of the walls you can go up the stairs of a steep hill oposite to the walls, and from the top amuse yourself with the stunning view of the entire site.So, be sure to have Saqsaywaman in your trip plan.Check out my travel videos on Youtube:https://www.youtube.com/user/ricfsCheck out my travel blog:http://www.tripcall.net/Check out my travel pictures:https://www.flickr.com/photos/ricardofs/

Take your time to enjoy this very beautiful site. I took a tour that included this site. I wish I had gone without the tour so that I would not have felt rushed. The site and views of Cuzco and surrounding mountains are amazing.

Amazing. This place is amazing. It's unbelievable how smart the incas were. Its incredible how good at engineering the incas were, even though they did not have the right tools back then. Our tour guide made us walk through a small underground tunnel, and mentioned that there is a big tunnel that connects Sacsayhuaman with the city. Many interesting myths exist from this place. Very peaceful place with so much to see.

Impressive Incan Ruins, but others are more impressive. UNESCO World Heritage SiteA guide will make the visit more worthwhile. Plan 1-2 hours to tour this site.This is a Incan Fortress. The walls are made of large polished stones. The boulders fit together tightly without mortar. As with other Incan ruins the engineering is amazing.There is a good view down at Cusco from this site.

Impressive!. Like everyone else, we came to see Machu Picchu. The many other nearby ruins like this were a bonus! Large property, lots of opportunities to climb and explore. The local guide offered the very latest ideas on it's purpose, not something written in a guide book from 20 years ago. We were there with a TOUR GROUP and had about an hour and a half to explore. That was enough for me to see all I wanted to see........ As with other ruins handicap access is limited to ground level viewing.

Huge expert stone construction is awesome. This site had the largest Inca-worked stones we saw in Peru. The work and expertise required to shape and polish and move all the stones is mind-boggling. If you're touring is focused on Inca-style culture and architecture, this place is a must-see.
Inca ruins. You have to visit Sacsayhuaman, awesome inca ruins over Cusco, also you have a nice view of this city
Fascinating. Our Cusco Native guide provided a compelling private tour. We hung on every word and enjoyed this place tremedously.

Amazing Workmanship!. Intricate stone walls that the Incas constructed for their village soar several feet high above the grass. The stone areas that are still seen and not destroyed vary from a few feet to well over 20 feet high. A large common area separates the two major restored stone areas. No mortar was used in the construction of these walls and buildings. Just amazing to stand in the wonder of these masterful craftsmen of long ago!

One of Best Sites to See in Cusco Area. Took a taxi up, hired a local elderly guide on site, and had an amazing tour! He was one of of the best quids we had in Peru (I am sorry that I cannot remember his name). Absolutely beautiful setting and structures! We walked back to town through neighborhoods.
Very cool historic site. Make sure to go at sunset. Short ride from the heart of Cusco. Nice trip to do at the end of the day and provides a lovely photo op.
really cool. Like: so cool. Get a guide- the history makes it worth the visit. was thinking it was just a bunch of rocks- but the story gives it life. Dislike: warm- be sure to hydrate

OK Ruins; but the View is Great. I assume that if you've come to Cusco, your going to Machu Picchu. That being said, the ruins here are quite mediocre to be honest. It's interesting but by no means spectacular. However, the view of Cusco from these heights is fantastic and is definitely worth the trip!

Fine example of Inca stonework. This is a must in Cusco. It takes about an hour. The easiest of the ruins as far as moving around is concerned. Its pretty level without much climbing which you encounter at the other sites. We hired a guide and learned a lot about the site. The largest rock in the Inca empire is pretty impressive.
Must see!. Amazing Inca site right outside of Cusco. We walked there and took a few hours to explore the whole site. It's only 20% of the original size but still huge. Very impressive Inca ruins.

A learning experience. Our guide gave us a look into the ways of the Incas and their building methods. We had the opportunity to climb the steps placed by the Incas and appreciate the intricacies of the construction.
Outstanding Inca ruins. A delightful spot to visit with a great view of Cusco below. Very impressive stone work. Understated with a lot of open space. Somehow memorable, nevertheless.

Great Scenic Walk. If you like photography environmental shots, this is the place. Quite a scenic walk amongst the greens and a mix of interesting folks - local and tourists to meet and greet. The rock formations are definitely a great watch!
Llamas. It is great to vist and see the llamas and the ruins. Good views from the top of the city. Will get out of breath quick thou. Alot of history and a good place to start.

Part of our bus tour. This was a stop on our bus tour. We had a great guide that explained the architecture and how it was built. You get a great view of the city of Cusco from above. We weren't there very long - and there are people selling their wares on the way out.

Big stones I had never seen.. I never imagine that the incas noved the big stones and built their temple it is extremely amazing.
It Was beautiful also the temple of water Tambomachay The Inkas though that the water was sacred because no body lived without drinking water.

Surprisingly good. This was so much better than I was expecting! I walked there from Plaza de Armas, up Plateros St and then Saphi, up lots of steps. Just keep heading uphill and go right when you reach the proper road, passing some little shops and cafe on the right on a bend. Coming back down I went down the cobbled lane immediately by the cafe, and about halfway down on the right there is a fab organic place where you can buy a variety of things from delicious coffee (to buy or drink there), chocolates and herbs to alpaca jumpers.I visited Sacsayhuaman in the morning, when it was quiet, and spent around three hours there wandering around and just being so impressed by everything. Before going to Sacsayhuaman, I had already visited several Inca sites including Machu Picchu, and part of me thought that I shouldn't bother going as it would just be more of the same. But it wasn't.As most reviewers have said before, get a guide to be sure of getting the best out of your visit. And go down the tunnel!

Oh the stonework!. This site was a good stop while in Cuzco. The stone work was brilliant. It's amazing how they could've brought these giant stones and carved each piece to completely match and build this site. Walk up the hill to see the view of Cuzco. There were a flock of Alpacas when we went. We had a wonderful guide who told us the history of the site. It wasn't a long stop, maybe 30 to 45 minutes.

Don't miss this fantastic historical sight. This was one of the most interesting tours we took so you need to have a really good guide to show you everything. Go dressed with a bit of a hill climb in mind so that you can walk up to what they think was the Inka throne.

Must see. Sacsayhuaman is a must see in Cusco. My husband and I were able to walk from our hotel in San Blas to Sacsayhuaman, so that was a bonus. We hired a guide at the ticket office which was great and recommended. He was able to explain more about the architecture of the place, how it was built, what areas were used for, etc. The tunnel is also a fun little adventure - very dark so don't go if you're claustrophobic :-)

Just ok. Compared to the ruins at Ollantaytambo and Machu Picchu (which most travelers will undoubtedly see), these are just ok. I didn't purchase a tourist ticket so the cost was .70 soles to get in, which was expensive for me. My husband chose to not pay to get in and instead climbed the hill next to the ruins. He not only saw the Cristo Blanco statue, but also got a pretty amazing view of the ruins. Save your money and pay to get into Ollantaytambo ruins instead.

"sexy woman". Went with a tour group in May 2014. This was our first day at altitude, Sacsayhuaman is a little higher than Cusco, so I did feel dizzy here. Inspite of this I really enjoyed it and our tour guide Edwin was awesome!
Great scenery. Incredible stone work that seems almost impossible to build with todays tools. Just a short trip from Cusco

The best Inca rock work of all the Inca sites. We´ve been to many of the Inca sites, and the rock work at Saqsaywaman stands out. The rocks are huge and the manner in which they are fit together is complex because there are lots of inside and outside corners.The place needs bathroom facilities.

Inka Beauty. While traveling to Machu Picchu we had the opportunity to stop at some other Inka sites. This one really stands out. The shear beauty of it is incredible. We enjoyed walking around the grounds and learning about the Inka's ability to create huge structures. Not as grand at Machu Picchu, but definitely worth a visit.

Impressive. We walked up to Sacsayhuaman from the Plaza des Armas, about a 30 minute walk. This is an impressive site - massive granite rocks weighing tons put together in Inca style without mortar. The overall layout of the site is beautiful, curving walls, an open plain, great view of the city. If you want you can also visit the Cristo Blanco from here. We had visited several other ruins so didn't hire a guide, but there are many guides available on site if you want to pay for one. This site is another testament to the ingenuity and engineering ability of the Incas. We were very glad we took the time to visit.

Recommend to visit the amazing and craziest stone work!. My review with many photos: http://shrimp2.pixnet.net/blog/post/105279122Wow! Even two of my friends were having slight altitude sickness, we still came here for visiting!Wonderful views of new and old Cusco. Sacsayhuaman is one of the most incredible Inca structure using giant giant rocks.Recommend to visit the amazing and craziest stone work! Just bring up your food with friends here for a picnic : )

Inca ruins close to Cusco. These Inca ruins are very close Cusco; some even hike uphill to see them. They also offer an amazing view of the city. I would recommend a guide to ensure you get a good understanding of what you are seeing.

Just incredible!. The fortress built near Cusco is incredible ! Not just by having three (!) walls around it in a zig- zag pattern (like a hair on the back of the leopard) , but by sheer volume of work. Some stones are about 150 tons! how on Earth did they build this citadel? Although we were told 20000 slaves were called by Inca to build it! Unforgettable experience!

A Must See.... We recommend at least a half-day visiting Scasayhuaman. We had an intelligent and informative guide from Condor Travel, and an unusually large and collegial tour group. There is much to see, many questions to ask, and a lot to learn. You get a distinct feel for the strategic location, history, and relevance of this site when you walk through it. This visit is not so much about the photo ops, it is the sense you gain of what Scasayhuaman meant to the Inca, and this is a very real and important part of any time spent in resplendent Peru. We had sun, rain, clouds and cold wind during this afternoon so dress with care.
enormous stones. By visiting this spectacular fortress one can examine closely some extremely huge stones used by Incas to build this structure.
Individual Stones size of a bus. The Incas were extremely smart about how to move these extremely large stones. Not only were the stones large but the parade area was massive over looking Cusco.

Amazing stone work, wish more survived. This is the remains of the temple in Cusco believed devoted to lightening, which is believed to link this world to the upper world. Look for the aerial photograph at the entrance, to see how the walls zig zag like lightening. Wonderful views of old and new Cusco. Believed to have had a towers, the large round one must have been visible from the city and was said to have been covered in gold and silver sheets. I imagine it gleamed up on it's hill. Very interesting.

Wow! What a fortress!. This fortress overlooking Cusco is right past the Incan man-made lake, and is another example of how incredible the Inca structures are. On the top are the remains of three massive towers, one of them for getting water. Just an amazing, beautiful structure - well worth seeing!

Wow!. Even though I was having effects of altitude sickness, this was one amazing place. If you think about the stone work alone which will be very hard to duplicate with modern technology, that alone is amazing. Include the history and this place is a must see and experience.

Awesome afternoon exploration. One of the most incredible Inca structures using large, large rocks! The site is quite spread out and takes about 2-2.5 hours to explore leisurely. We drove up to the main entrance and once inside, the site did require some uphill climbing by stairs but we paced ourselves. We chose not to use a guide as our guide book contained a significant amount of detailed information. The site is a great example of Inca work featuring incredibly large stones carved and set so perfectly that it leaves you dazed!
Gigantic Rocks. This place has some of the craziest rocks structures I have seen in my life.There is grand cash prize if you can spot two different rocks of the same size ;)
great ruins to visit...not as crowded as Machu Picchu. Definitely get a guide. Otherwise, you'll have no idea of the significance of what you're looking at.

Go. You will not regret it.. I walked up from the historic center of Cusco in about 40 minutes. Steep walk and with the altitude quite tiring but absolutely worth it. Great ruins that are extremely impressive and nice view of Cusco as a bonus. One of the best examples of Inca ingenuity.

How did they do it?. This was our first encounter of really big rocks locked together perfectly. It was amazing, helped by a very jolly guide who used a radio mike and earphones. The walk up the hill and the view over Cusco is a fantastic added bonus.

Without a guide you may miss the clue of the place. We have been there with our guide from the agency, so we heard lots of stories about original usage of the place by the Incas and the technologies they used. Basically, all these huge stones were transported from the quarries located in 15km distance. Impressive.

Interesting, better get a tour guide.. I think it is better to get a tour guide for this site, because it has lots of interesting history and hidden designs, without a tour guide we would never had found some of them, and those little hidden things are so interesting and made this place very special.We didn't spend too long here but we really enjoyed this place, especially the view to cuzco.

Start point on Sacred Valley tours. Sacsayhuaman overlooks Cusco and is often the start point for day tours to the sacred valley. Get a Boleto Turisitco for 130 soles. Valid for ten days it gives you access to 16 archaeological sites around Cusco and the Sacred Valley. The ticket gets stamped as you enter each one. It will save you a lot of money. Cusco from above is meant to look like a puma, and Sacsayhuaman is the head. The view across the town from the ruins is stunning. Besides the obvious massive stone walls there are lots of other interesting parts which only a tour guide can point out to you. There is the Qocha Chincanas, a huge circular amphitheatre, said to be an Inca graveyard. There are some stone slides you can slide down and a scary pitch black tunnel which they don't prepare you for. Before you know it you are in an initiation tunnel, it is only one minute long but not for those with claustrophobia.

An interesting stop. These are not the best Incan ruins, but it is a nice place to visit and we are sure that on a clear day the view are very nice. We were there on a drizzly day. The stonework is of course amazing. Again, there are better examples around the Sacred Valley, but if you are only in Cuzco definitely go see this. If you are on your way to the Sacred Valley, take the route that brings you by here and spend an hour, especially if it is a clear day.

A Must Visit. This is a must visit site. I found this site very interesting and it gives you an idea how good the Incas were at building. The size of some of the rocks and how they all fit together is fascinating. I would have liked a lot more time here, the tour we did was a bit to rushed for me.

Not to be missed. This is an incredible site and deserves plenty of time to wander among the many levels of the ruins. The size of the stones are astounding - beautiful spot right outside of Cusco. We returned twice - once on our own.
Very interesting. Huge rocks --how did they do it??? Nice view of the town from the top. Take the time to walk down to town via the cobblestone shortcut.

Interesting and beautiful views. Sacsayhuaman is an Incan archeological site located on a steep hill just north of town. The large site overlooks the city and contains an impressive view of the valley and offers a nice backdrop for pictures.It is the construction of the stone blocks that make visiting this site a must. These ruins have endured some devastating earthquakes, but the engineering techniques the Incans utilized in construction (rounded stone edges, interlocking shapes and leaning some stones slightly inward for structural integrity) helped many sections survive. Much of the destruction was due to the Spanish dismantling of the structures to utilize the stone for their own purposes.

Interesting site, hire a guide. This site is about a 30 - 45 minute walk straight uphill from the Plaza de Armas or a short taxi ride. We found it to be very interesting and the views were great. Be sure to hire a guide. We hired a man who was sitting at the taxi parking lot and tipped him 20 soles at the end. There are no signs with explanations, so a guide is a must.
Fab views over Cusco. Another must-see place in Cusco. I wish we'd had more time here. The views over Cusco are awesome. It was quite crowded so maybe it'd be better to go early in the day.

Amazing place. The most impressive place I saw in Peru. The size and architectural marvels make this place a must see attraction in the Cuzco area. It is large in scope but relatively easy to navigate if your bus parks at the top and allows you to walk down. The size and fit of the enormous stones defy belief. All in all, this site merits all the accolades it receives.

The remaining stonework is Amazing; Largest cut & fitted singular piece is over 120 TONNES. All that remains here of the stonework are some of the three tiered fortification walls and a portion of the ground level foundations that used to be the base for the stronghold & towers, as the rest was used by the Spanish as a quarry to construct Colonial Cusco's buildings. However, what does remain is a tremendously impressive testament of the Incan's stonework skill, unmatched in all of the Americas.The blocks are gigantic, and were fitted so tightly together using rudimentary bronze tools and sand to polish and final fit that a singular piece of paper cannot fit between any two. This is truly amazing, esp in light of the fact that what remains does so after withstanding numerous earthquakes that flattened buildings and cities thru ought the years.The siege of this fortification by the Spanish ( which will also give you first hand Spanish accounts of what the original towers and building looked like ) is well worth the historical read. Also interesting is that Cusco was designed in the shape of a Puma, and this was the Puma's head. The views from the highest walking point over Cusco and the bowl ( which was entirely underwater, a lake many years ago ) are spectacular.
Cool place.. The walk was easy for high altitude and the history is fascinating. We had a great guide who helped us understand and was born in Cusco.

Nothing great.. A expensive entry price with nothing impressive structures. Just an Incan ruin and there are much better places in Peru where there are better Incan ruins.
