It's a huge archaeological site but if you go in the evening you can view a beautiful sunset from here over the surrounding mountains.

Very Interesting Site!. Don't miss this archaeological site just outside of Cuzco. It's amazing that the Incas built this site with massive stones weighing tons and carved so precisely that a piece of paper can't fit between them.

Great visit 5 minutes from Cusco. Interesting Incan ruins 5 minute cab ride from Cusco. Easy to walk around by yourself, and you can even take a picture with the llamas or baby lambs that the local women have there!

giant's castle. The most amazing view from cuzco you can only have here! On the top of a mountain it is such a big site that your legs almost can't make it! The huge stone blocks from a past time in history, the huge doorsteps make you feel like either you are a dwarf or they were giants! A feeling like no other. It' s very cold up there. The weather changes rapidly, so take your lhama wool blouses with you!
Beautiful Setting rich in history. Peaceful moving beautiful location so rich in history you could feel it. Locals so proud of the history. Allow time to explore
How did they do it!!!. This historic site was amazing. This temple was built to represent the temple of lightening, and it sure was. One of the best sites I thought.
Unbelievable. The ruins were unbelievable. Being able to look down at the city of Cusco was awesome. The view of the Andes was breathtaking.

Must visit if in Cusco (morning better). I found that other travellers often overlooked this site. It gave me a real sense of perspective about the achievement of the Incas and the stonework is stunning, some of the blocks are huge. There's even a place with a llama built into the stonework. You can see why it was such an important location, as the views over Cusco are impressive.I travelled with a group in the morning, before all the tour groups arrived in the afternoon. There were very few people there apart from a local school group using the open space as a rehearsal for a re-enactment. I saw it as part of a tour including the other ruins in the area, on the hill above Cusco.

very busy between 3 and 4 pm. The site itself is worth 5 stars, it's absolutely magnificent. Be warned, though, that the afternoon tours all converge on it after around 3pm and leave in an hour. When I arrived a bit after 2, it was almost empty, and a herd of alpacas was peacefully grazing in the center of the field. As soon as the tours arrived, the alpacas moved off. I suggest exploring the rocky areas on the other side of the archeological park, when the groups rush in, and sticking around until sunset (usually 5 or 6 pm).

Beautiful, not as impressive as other ruins. The site is very nice, but it wasn't as impressive as a lot of the ruins we saw. It was very pretty, and the structures were amazing. The views were beautiful. We didn't have time to climb to the top.
Sacred place. Beautiful. We decided to walk up to the hills. The high altitude pressure was hard. But, it was worth.

Best Sacred Valley site. This is the site to go to if you only have one day in the Sacred Valley or if you want just a taste. For me, the sites all started to look a little alike and I got the idea the first time. But then I am not such an archaeology fan. However, this site with the history and the view of the valley and town is worth the effort. You can learn all about the Incas building techniques and a lot of culture here plus you have one of the cutest towns in the Sacred Valley at the base. If you love archaeology then go to all the Sacred Valley sites. If you want archaeology lite then go here prior to Machu Picchu.

Fantastic archaeological site. It's vast and took me many hours of wandering to see most of it. I know there were more labyrinths to explore. Information about the site was scant, even on the web. So unless I want to do a major study I have to guess what some of the features were about. There is controversy about the circular ruins on top of the high reaches of Sacsayhuaman but they were amazing to see. This site is interesting because it is build on a plateau so there is a large circular field on flat ground (different to the circular structures on the hill). Take your time here it is worth it. Those huge rocks were carved and brought to their resting places yet we don't know how this was done. The Incas were pretty amazing with their construction abilities. This was my second visit to Sacsayhuaman and I'll probably go again. The steep walk up from Avenida Arcopata or Plaza de Nazarenas are well worth the walk as you get better and better views of Cusco on the way. Yes you'll have to stop a lot as you puff and pant your way up, but it's worth it for a good work out. I loved this site.

Great views of Cusco. Loved the hike to the top and around the grounds. Wonderful examples of Incan walls. A bit further is the White Christ and from there is your best view of Cusco and the Plaza de Armas.

Great Panoramic View over the city. How to get there: Walking uphill for 25 min will get you to the gate of Sacsayhuaman, from there its another steep 15 min climb to the top of the mountain (the ruins sits on top and is relatively flat). You should also be able to negotiate with a taxi driver to take you up for about 10 sol.$$$: If you plan to visit secret valley, the entrance fee is covered under the billett touristico (130 Sol), otherwise i believe entrance fee is 74 sol for a more limited ticket.Spectacular panoramic view from the top of the ruins. Well worth the climb! Its also a short walk over to Chriso Blanco (The Christ Statue) but the view over the city is similar so I wouldn't say its a "must see".

An 'appetizer' before Machu Picchu. In Cusco you'll be saturated with Incan ruins, and this is one is right at the city's doorstep. The massive stone walls support terraces on top of which stood other structures long gone. Be sure to bring a hat, sunglasses, mineral water and put on sunblock.

Sexy Woman???. We visited Sacsayhuaman as part of a day tour arranged by GoToPeru and thoroughly enjoyed visiting this amazing place. It's an Incan village that is truly spectacular, lovely terraces and views.

Perfect Spot For Inca History and Construction. He hired a guide to take us around and explain the Inca history and architecture. It was a perfect place to start as we then understood what we were looking at and for and when as we toured other sites.

good place to visit when looking for ruins around Cusco. Did this tour as part of our overall tour of Cusco - it was very nice - good view of the city as well - need a guide to assist you understand the significance of the location
Sexy woman. As our guide was prone to say. It was a great tour of a beautiful place with lots of interesting history. Great view of the city below.

A Must See!. The former Incan capital - this is a must-see just outside of Cusco. Climb up to the top for breathtaking views of the Andean mountains and Cusco. I really enjoyed learning about the Incan architecture, and the process of building Sacsayhuaman. The drive up there from Cusco is stunningly beautiful as well. Nearby there's a great little market that sells genuine baby alpaca scarves, blankets, hats, etc. But the journey alone is worth the visit to Sacsayhuaman. Get a guide though, it would be far less interesting without someone explaining some of the history.

extraordinary. The construction of three parallel zigzag walls in unbelievable. Great to just wander around and admire. It would be wonderful it interpretive signs could be added giving some ideas on what the theories are re use of spaces.

A Must-See while in Cusco. Expansive grounds, incredible Inca stonework, and located on a site perched high on the hilside overlooking Cusco, make this a very memorable place to visit. We spent roughly two hours getting a guided tour. One warning...if you can find it, there is a small cave-like tunnel which is pitch-black dark and very claustrophobic. If you don't like either darkness (essentially walking blindly) or smal enclosed spaces, then skip the tunnel walk. In any case this is a stunning site, highly recommend visiting.

The Fort....Head of the Puma that was Cusco. Sacsayhuaman....Tour Guide on our bus helped us pronounce the name (Sexy Woman). Easy to remember. We did a drive by and chose not to march through. This is the remains of a giant fort that sits on the top of the mountain in Cusco. During Incan times the entire population could find refuge inside. The city of Cusco was designed in the shape of a Puma. Sacsayhuaman was the head of the Puma. Over time the Spaniards and locals striped the fort of many stones. What is left is still cool but not as complete as other sites.

Unfathomable fortress. Sacsayhuaman has a variety of spellings (eg. Saqsaywaman or Saksaywaman).The Temple of Sacsayhuaman is perched on a hillside overlooking Cusco. It is a fortress built of gigantic stone blocks - some weighing more than 350 tonnes. It was raining while we were there in January 2014 and with a cool temp (14C), we didn't spend long in the ruins.However nearby (behind the Cristo Blanco "white Christ" statue) we watched a Mother Earth Ceremony performed by a local shaman (at an indoor store named La Vicunita Factory). These ceremonies were practiced in Peru before the arrival of the Incas. They thank Mother Earth and ask for good health and safe travels.

Very interesting place to visit. The Cusco region of Peru is full of Incan ruins. And what with doing the Inca Trail and Macchu Picchu, I was a bit afraid that they were all just going to start to run together in my head. And I'll be honest, some of them did. But if I had to pick a few (other than the Inca Trail and Macchu Picchu) to recommend, this would be one of them. Full disclosure: I never made it to Coricancha and I hear that one is really awesome too, maybe better than this one. We hired a taxi driver to take us to several of the ruins and then bought a day pass to half of the sites (your options are a day pass to all of the sites (120 soles) or to half of the sites (60 or 70 soles), there is no a la carte menu). The upside of this was we saved a lot of money. Our driver was 60 soles and he was with us for about 3 hours. The downside is he was just a driver and we didn't have a guide to explain what we were looking at. And there were no guides or books at the sites. So we googled it all when we got back to our hotel that evening, but it's not the same as knowing the significance of everything while you are at the site. What I would do differently next time is print some materials about the sites or buy a book in advance.

Sexy Woman. We walked up from Plaza de Armis, Cusco. The trail was good and people along the way pointed us in the right direction. You have to pay for four attractions to get in to this one. Possibly second best to Machu Picchu.

The horse, the star and the glow all in one. Some people travel for pleasure, some simply because it is something that has to be done. As much as this travel felt like work there was no better confirmation that what was experienced at Sacsayhuaman. From beginning to end the entire site was spectacular. The first confirmation came in form of a horse from the gorgeous clouds above us as we stood in the middle of the park. The second confirmation formed itself with the same cloud and into a star. Our tour guide looked at both formations and smiled as she knew what was going on. Sacsayhuaman for those who don’t know is the head part of a puma, specifically the teeth. Visit Sacsayhuaman on your trip to Cusco, you will enjoy it.

Major highlight. We visited Sacsayhuaman as part of the half day Cusco city tour we did through Lama Path tours (great company). I have to say that this site was probably one of our favorite places during our time in Cusco, the Inca Trail, and Machu Picchu. It is truly an amazing architectural feat that the Incas brought these massive blocks down from the mountains and put them into place without mortar. Lots to explore here; would highly recommend doing it with a guide.
Interesting History. Great example of how the Spanish had to build around Incan temples or adjacent to. Great place for history buffs

Amazing view. Once at the top of this fortress you can see an amazing view of the city. Are tour guide was very knowledgeable and gave us a lot of info on this fortress. Gives you a little insight on to what Machu Picchu is like.

Amazing Inca site. Considering the resources available to the Incas, the construction of this site is overwhelming. Huge stone blocks on one side of the field face a hillside of striated rocks, which we were told had reigious significance.

Sounds like Sexy-Woman (not the name however). Lots of history as you can imagine get a local guide they can give you lots of interesting information. Take a cab here, you can then get a cab to Tambomachay and Puka Pukara (right next to each other). Get the day pass for ~70 soles each, is good for 24 hrs and covers all these and more. Also great view of Cusco City,
If you did Machu Pichu then. Do this on an open topped bus from the square for 20 sols. Bus trip was good. View of the city worthwhile.

Spectacular Inca ruin. I don't know what this site was built and used for, but it was amazing. Large juts of rock into an open field, from above looked like jaguars head. Modern day dancers practicing a performance when we were there added ambience

Amazing!. The Inca capital.Set on a hill overlooking modern Cusco the construction remains a mystery with very large stones carved into interlocking complex curves.The temples away from the main structure are being examined with new discoveries.The Temple of the Moon has 2 caves.One cave is an echo chamber where 3 people can resonate a low frequency hum that when in tune at a certain pitch produces a very high frequency at much higher octaves - we achieved that twice with one of the archaeologists.The other cave has the face of a Jaguar that was found only in December 2013. When viewed in moonlight the Jaguar's body looks to be running.A most amazing place to experience.Worth taking the horse riding tour to see the outlying grounds.
sacsayhuaman tour. tour guide $30 told us a lot of information, its very close to cuzco 30 mins centre and possible to see many sites on the way
Staggering. It's hard to imagine how people could build with stone a thousand years ago, using only crude stone hammers, bronze tools, llama skins and hand labor. Must be seen to be believed.

How they do that?. Cannot imagine how they were able to cut, move, and place such huge stones. It is a testament to what we can do. Hired a guide, like all of the ruins, the local population earn a few bucks touring you around. Really accurate their narration is but they do point out items of interest you might otherwise miss. The tour busses come in the north gate so use the west gate to avoid the crowds. Part of the Turista Boleta.

A TESTAMENT TO INCA ARCHITECTURE. I took a taxi, from my hotel in Cuzco, to these Inca ruins. Guides, fluent in English, were available on site for a fee, but I opted to explore the ruins on my own with a guidebook in hand. The construction of Sacsayhuamán was begun in the fifteenth century by Inca leader Pachacuti. It took decades to build. Thousands of men used thick ropes to haul the massive blocks of stones from quarries many miles distant. Such a labor force was readily available since Inca lords imposed a labor tax on their subjects. Apparently built as a fortress, Sacsayhuamán must have been awe inspiring to set eyes on during its glory years. It's now just a shell of its former majesty. The Spaniards, after subduing the Incas and occupying Cuzco, turned this fortress into their own quarry. The superstructure of the fortress was disassembled block by block. Those finely hewed stone blocks were then used by the Spaniards for walls and buildings in Cuzco. What remains today of Sacsayhuamán are the massive foundation stones, many weighing more than 100 tons, with some reaching 300 tons. This foundation is arranged in three tiers. I strolled along the rows of blocks, set in a zigzag pattern. I was struck by their sheer size. Some seemed to reach twenty feet in height. And I was awed by how tightly the blocks were still fitted together after centuries. And without the use of mortar! I noticed that in places on these walls some of the blocks interlocked at their corners. Apparently this architectural feature was to prevent the massive stones from slipping away from one another in what is an area beset with earthquakes. So successful has been this construction that even today a knife blade cannot be inserted between the blocks! The ruins provide a commanding view down onto the city of Cuzco. After taking in these magnificent ruins, I hoofed it back to my hotel, an easy hike down a steep gradient.A site not to be missed.

Beautiful. This site is just outside of Cusco city. There are huge boulders that were brought by the Incas to the site from a nearby mountain. It is beautiful and included in the boleto turistico. I would not miss this site if going to Cusco.

Most importent place of CUSCO. This is the most importent place of CUSCO. I participated in the half day city tour of the tour around ruins. (It is about 10 dollars surely.) My guide said ,it is most important ruin of ancient cusco. becouse, it is made of more huge rocks than other ruins and, cusco is placed in higher altitude than other king's palace ob INKA.If could visit, you will certainly be surprised.

Amazing. I had not even heard of this set of ruins before seeing them from the open-topped bus.After our trip to Machu Picchu, we had a free day - so headed up there to explore. We took a taxi from the hotel (40 soles return) and the driver waited 1.50 h for us.The ruins themselves are every bit as impressive as Machu Picchu - but do not have quite the same spectacular setting. There are no information boards - so we were glad we had invested in a guide to explain the complex to us. There is no way we would ever have known what most of the ruins were originally. Well worth the 30 soles! There are huge rocks cut and fitted together in true Inca style. What an amazing race of people! There is an excellent view of Cusco from the ruins.

stonehenge on steroids. we had a great guide, who had published a photo book on this and many other local attractions, so had great insights into the location. impressive and massive stone structures and great that it is so large that crowds do not feel intimidating or always in the way

stonehenge on steroids. we had a great guide, who had published a photo book on this and many other local attractions, so had great insights into the location. impressive and massive stone structures and great that it is so large that crowds do not feel intimidating or always in the way
Imponente. Imponent and beautifull view of the City of Cusco. Our guide was quite an expert and the visit was really educational. Learned a lot. You can feel the history in the air.

Make the effort and GO - its fantastic!. Tip - Pronounced "Sexy Woman"We walked up from Cusco (and it was a great uphill hike) we took it slow because it was high up, but its safe to walk up on your own and you also get to turn around and take in the town from the top of the hill and take some amazing photos! the best is that you get to see the tiny side streets with the local shops that you wouldnt see if you took the bus up - we rested along the way and had a lot of photo stops but we got to the site and were just amazed, its so worth every penny and every step we took to get there! - start from Plaza de Armas up Plateros Street which then changes to Saphi, look for the long staircase on the right, follow the paved curvy road up to the next cobblestone pedestrian path and follow this pst the first closed control point to the 2nd control (might sound difficult to follow but we got this from a guide book and it was very eay and straight forward and there are signs!)Make sure you wear runners or closed shoesYou can take amazing photos in front of the huge boulders and its just amazing how they made these walls!

Interesting, Spectacular. This is a fantastic archeological site. Highly recommend using a private guide, as they are not too expensive. Be careful with who you hire, as we ended up with a guide who was not official and maybe not as good as the others. The official guides had notebooks with photos and pictures depicting how the site could have looked before the Spaniards sacked it.

Incredible structure, beautiful location, great views of Cusco. Its worth getting a a guide for the explanation of how the site was constructed and all the symbolism built in. Admission is included on the tourist ticket. It's 40 soles for one hour with the guide. Then you can wander around on your own as long as you want. Bring a picnic. I took a taxi up for 10 soles and then walked down in about 20 minutes.
Lovely views. Our first Inca experience. Nice to see the llamas and alpacas keeping the grass down. Wonderful Inca walls. Tremendous views of Cusco

Probably better with a guide. This place is huge. Like really huge. You don’t need a guide for the other three ruins outside of Cusco but there is so much ground to cover here that you really should make sure someone is there who can explain it to you. My wife and I did without and wandered on our own with only what we could glean from the Peru Lonely Planet. I feel like we missed out on some of the history of the space, would have likely been worthwhile to have someone point out the various points of interest.

Don't miss these ruins. On the outskirts of Cusco, these ruins are a must see. We hired a taxi driver who charged 30 soles to take us to the ruins, stay there while we visited the ruins and take us back to our hotel. Make sure to stop at the church at the top of the curving street to appreciate the view of Cusco. Martin the llama may be there. He makes for fabulous photos although you do have to pay his owner to take his picture (3 soles seemed fine)We paid to get into the ruins when we arrived. ONLY SOLES ARE ACCEPTED / NO DOLLARS OR CREDIT CARDS.Guides are available for hire on the property. We hired a lovely guide, Carmen, who spoke perfect english and gave us a fabulous tour. She only charged us 40 soles…negotiate the price ahead of time. She was fabulous!!! The kids loved walking up to the second tier of the ruins and walking around. The highlight of the tour had to be be the 12 resident alpacas and llamas. Don't miss these ruins. They truly are fabulous!!!

Time Travel on Foot. Sacsayhuaman provides a glimpse into the world of the Incas and leaves you both amazed and wondering "How did they do that?" This is an easily accessible site by car, taxi, bus, and even on foot. We did a half-day hike from the heart of Cusco and visited this site along with several other smaller sites in the area. On the back side of this site there are natural channels in the rocks that you can slide down on your bum and have a bit of fun. Be sure to get a map to the area so that you can see what else is easy to get to from here. There is generally no charge to access the site and it is easy to explore on your own with a guidebook. There is a small gift shop and place to buy drinks and snacks as well as washrooms as well as craft vendors along the roadways. It does take some physical effort to explore the full site but there are steps and fairly easy climbs for those who are moderately fit.

Gigantic rocks!!. The Temple of Sacsayhuaman, which sort of sounds like sexy human, is an expansive fortress of gigantic stones, with some huge blocks weighing over 350 tons! How did they built this..?? You enter at one end of the property and leave at another..it's in the middle of nowhere..kind of like Stonehenge in England..only this is much larger and covers more area. It also overlooks the city of Cusco and you can see a huge Christ statue in the distance..a mini version to the one in Rio...Of course, at the end, on your way out, are vendors selling there goods and also photo ops with llamas for a few coins....a must see if you are in Cusco
Good way to start Inka journey. This is a good warm up prior to Machu Picchu. I enjoyed the sites but do recommend a guide so that you can learn about what you are looking at.
they call it sexy woman. Awesome sight. About a 15 minute walk from plaza de armas. Beautiful an impressive for its massive perfectly cut rocks!

Impressive site. This site is just outside of Cusco; you can hike up to it from the city quite easily. It is a good starter hike to get you used to the altitude if you plan to do some trekking. It provides a great backdrop of Inca building for your initial photos on your trip.

Great views of cusco, quick 15-20 min drive through town. Loved the view from up top. Hired a tour guide from the checkin point where we paid for entrance (didn't know we had to pay- I think it was 70 soles per person for ALL 4 of the archeaological sites- sacsayhuaman, and 3 others). The tour guide kept saying, "como se dise?" So we fired her, nicely, after the tour of one site. She was nice though. just couldn't speak english well enough. We just grabbed a random taxi from cusco city to drive us up- we ended up scoring with emilio who was so fun and happy and smiley- he took us to all 4 sites for 80soles ($40)- we tipped him and all our taxi drivers, even after finding out that they don't tip taxis! it was a total of about 3.5 hours he drove us around and walked with us through some sites... even though he didn't speak english!this site had alpacas in the main grassy plains area... had LOVELY views of city- if we had a better tour guide I bet it woulda been more interesting... I would have done that differently! Mayuc is a tour company in plaza de armas and Jeremy spoke excellent english (he took us on a tour of sacred valley). I would recommend them! And I would recommend taking a fast tour of this site... or just get up there to drive through town and see the city from above:)

A MUST SEE in Cusco.. This place is worth the hike or take a cab. Everyone really needs to see this before going to Machu Picchu. The stone work and the grounds are fantastic. Walk up the stairs from Cusco for a better experience - along the stream.

steep walk. I didn't have a guide, so I didn't know much about what was going on. It was also a little bit expensive. It is a steep walk from down - it's a great idea to take a bus up to the highest of the 4 ruins and then walk down.

Open air site "writ large". Site close to the city of Cusco, one can easily view how construction was done. Part of the "boleto" which allows you to visit many sites around Cusco and the Sacred Valley.

Take a little extra time for the gorgeous views and impressive rocks!. Very tranquil and gorgeous view. I recommend seing it on your own time and not with a bus tour. It takes a few more minutes than they give to walk around and appreciate all that it has to offer.

one of most interesting visit. astonishing, the megalithic construction of wall astonished first Spanish soldiers, that continue to astonish every visitor - take a time to walk all around even climb the oposite hill to see it better - the best view is from sky, but that is only possible to ghosts of Inka......Do not miss it it's hard to ptonounce = Sacsayhuaman = think to pronounce it like "Sexy Woman" and you'll remember it for always........

Nice Local Ruins. If you have the time, this place is an easy walk from the city center and you have a great view of the entire city. I think if you just do this one ruin, the price is about 45 soles - 70 soles if you want to do all four of the ruins. Sacsayhuaman is definitely the most interesting of the four so check it out if you have time!

Do the horseback tour!. These ruins are an amazing feat of engineering and it offers great views of Cusco. We went for one of the horseback tours offered on the way up. It sounds a bit suspect but we paid S/.45 each (we paid a tip at the end as well) for entrance to Sacsayhuaman (usually S/.90 each) and a three hour horseback tour of various other sites, like the Temple of the Moon and Zona X. I've never ridden on a horse before, the pace was gentle and our horses looked well fed and cared for. An amazing afternoon out!

amazing. My second visit and maybe there will be a third one! the road is very good, I was lucky since the weather was very good. A tip, in my opinion, would be to visit the ruins after lunch, colors at the Sacred Valley are amazing at that time.

Wonderful history. Stopped at this location on a tour in Cusco. Was able to learn more about the Incan history and the ruins. Overlooked the city. Very beautiful and would definitely recommend as a special place to visit.
Rich cultural experience. High above the city, this parque let's you experience why the Incas chose to build their cities in the clouds - you truly do feel closer to the deities.

Wow to the Incas. The amazing ingenuity of the incas was visible here, which was the first of the inca ruins we visited. The climb is a bit difficult but once on top, the view takes u by surprise. The preciseness with which thein as built the stone walls is an architectural marvel
My favorite ruins. Definitely my favorite ruins within Cusco itself. I love the view and the open space, and most importantly the natural rock slides towards the back!

A lovely historical site close to Cusco. This site is only about 15 minutes drive from Cusco and it is well worth seeing. You can see Cusco from the lookout and it is a great photo opportunity. The massive stones interlocked in the typical Incan manner are the star of this attraction though.
See it. Beautiful views of the countryside and ruins very interesting. The city tour a great way to see the sites around Cusco.

Amazing Place. Sacsayhuaman was amazing. The size of some of the stone sthey used to build it is incredible. The top of the hill, above the temple, offers a perfect view of the whole of Cusco. It is also right next to Cristo Blanco so you can do 2 trips in one.There are Llamas jus walking loose around Sacsayhuaman (meaning you don't have to pay to have a photo) :)

Early bird got the worm. My wife and I hiked the curving road up to Sacsayhuaman at about 6:30 a.m. on a Sunday morning and found the first gated entrance to the complex (abeam the creek that runs down a valley between Sacsayhuaman hillside and the "Christ the Redeemer" hillside) to be open and the adjoining ranger booth to be unmanned....at this hour there were only local Peruvians enjoying sunrise in the complex up there (jogging, kids playing soccer, hiking, etc). We hiked up through the open gate and enjoyed both Sacsahaman and the large white J.C. statue hill adjoining with the expectation we'd be asked to pay when we left. However, the gate was still open and the payment-looking both unmanned as we exited the complex at about 8 a.m. on Sunday morning. It was nice to enjoy this beautiful ruin (with massive rocks bigger than Machu Picchu) without other tourists and without paying 70 Soles ($25) each to visit!

So impressive!. Sacsayhuaman is one of the best sets of ruins in the region. From the giant walls to the tunnels you can walk through, there is a huge variety to see. You need a good amount of time to see it all. The first time I went, we had a guide. I liked learning about the site, so I would recommend getting one. If not, most travel books have at least some information, so you can educate yourself while you walk around.Don't miss the stone slides- so fun!

Visit, but earlier in the day. I was in an organized day tour of the city and only wished it was down down in the opposite way. We started at the cathedrals and ended by Sascayhuaman. I wish we started here while the sun was rising and with more time to explore this landmark, which wasn't a fort, but a religious center. Also Cuzco is laid out in the pattern of a Puma, and this is the head.

Great primer for Machu Picchu!. For some reason I thought this site was a "15 min walk around" kind of thing, and was pleasantly surprised to find its a full attraction worth even a half day visit! The views of Cusco are amazing and the stone work is fascinating. Worth getting a tour guide a the front so you don't miss some of the interesting formations (like the representations of cougar paws, snakes, guinea pigs in the stones). There's also a flock of alpacas running around that we got to take pictures with, an interesting ritual sacrifice location within walking distance (admission included in the day ticket).
A glimpse into Incan history. A must see while in Cusco. It's even better with a local guide who can explain the history of the ruins.
interesting and inspiring. go with a guide, they can really make the area feel alive. The alpacas wandering across the site were adorable.

A must visit in Cusco. This is an impressive Incan site which represented the "head" of the Incan empire originating in Cusco. It's a large area to walk around in, some of the blocks are gigantic; we were informed that the original site was likely a hundred feet higher and what we were seeing was the 10% that was not destroyed. You should walk to the Christ the Redeemer statue, the large and white statue, which overlooks Sacsayhuaman as well as Koricancha, to get a better appreciation of the proximity of the two sites and their relationship to one another.
Wonderful!. You have to see it to understand the awesomeness of this place and learn about Inca ways of building cities

Plenty sexy. We arrived at Sacsayhuaman as part of the City Tour from Cusco, and it was the highlight of our tour.Maybe not as impressive as Machu Pichu due to the relative flatness of the terrain, but impressive nonetheless. The area of the temple is huge, and there are some great examples of the magical stonework, with many of the stones weighing several ton (see my photos). It remains a mystery to me how these stones were cut and lifted into place. Despite all the theories expounded by the guides, no one has managed to duplicate the building process, despite all the modern equipment we have at our disposal.

Plenty of walls. This large holy inca site has the most famous walls of all. There are walls on three levels with stones of wildly differing sizes. All are put together without mortar, an inca specialty. It is beautiful and fascinating.

A great introduction to Cusco. You must go to Sacsayhuaman and see the ruins of the pyramid. It was fascinating. We were breathless from the altitude so I didn't do much higher climbing but what I did see was amazing.

What a impressive place!!!!!!!. Just go there and try to imagine how the incas built such giant structure.
Once you get the place You won't believe what You see, the size and shape of the stone blocks are incredible, take your time for climbing the hill in from of the structure, because the best panoramic view is from there.

Walk or Ride - But Don't Miss It!. Sacsayhuaman is the closest Inca ruin to Cuzco. Ask for directions or get a map. Most people can hike (not difficult) to the entrance within an hour of leaving Plaza de Armas. If you don't care to take the hike, it is a inexpensive taxi ride up. There are always 'guides' hanging around to offer their services. Many of these 'guides' are not professionally trained, but with a 'proper interview' you should be able to determine if you like what they can offer.You can easily spend several hours at the site, once you get an idea of the layout and follow some of the available brochures.Enjoy
Stunning. Enjoy your hike. If you are game, wall from town. I highly recommend a guide who can tell you some history. As impressive as Machu Pichu.
Beautiful site in the Sacred Valley. The size of the stones and remaining ruins are impressive and it is an easy walk through the site. Beautiful site lines from various spots on the tour.
Giant Stones joined together to make a magnificent architecture. It is a must see ! Giant stones joined to build the Sacsayhuamán..another Incas building,a military fortress.

Great place to visit to get used to the altitude. This was a perfect ruin for me to go to on my first day in Cuzco. I was still getting used to the altitude and this was an easy place to walk around with minimal ups and downs that helped me get used to hiking around ruins at altitude. I found the scenery to be breathtaking and serene...and I even found a guide to give me a little interesting history about the place, especially the tombs. Make sure you do this BEFORE Machu Picchu though, because you will be spoiled by MP and Sacsayhuaman won't hold a candle to it.

A good Inca site. Sacsayhuaman is a wonderful place to take in the construction process of an Inca site. A herd of Alpacas were grazing and hawks were hunting among the terraced landscape. Great photo opportunity.

Large site of Inca Walls. A large site that can be easily accessed by a short walk from Cusco.Whilst at this site it is worth visiting, again a short walk, the White Christ statue which is on a hill overlooking the Sacsayhuaman site.
Interesting Inca Site. Overlooking the town of Cusco, this is a small Inca site that is well worth a visit. We'd recommend a taxi up and then walking back down to the town.
Amazing!. What an amazing place! The greatness, the mystic environment, the giant stones...The Cusco sight is wonderful. Even though the place is worn, it is still very impressive.

They tell you that its easy to remember the name Sexy Woman. A variety of names but listed on the tourist ticket as Saqsayhuaman. We took a tour after reading some of the revues, but felt it was not long enough. The views overlooking Cusco were great. The climbing up and then down and then up again were necessary in order to see parts of the site. It is a very large site and without a guide or some advance reading it would probably be just a bunch of large rocks .There are little or no signs on the site explaining anything. You can walk up to the site but given the elevation of 3,701 m or 12,142 ft its a little exhausting. You can get a taxi to drop you at the highest point on the site and then walk down but there are no hand out pamphlets or guides on site. These Inca men must have been very strong to have moved all these rocks and arranged them into the fortress that it is. The only bathrooms are at the entry and the site is large and on a hillside.

Subdued but interesting. Quarry/religious Inca site above Cusco. Great examples of Inca rock building skills, but not nearly as varied as Machu Piccu. Not very crowded and you can walk (good luck - uphill) or cab up to it.

Sacsayhuaman. How fun was this tour of the ruins. Amazing how these stones/rocks were brought in one by one to make this walled complex. It's considered northern outskirts of Cusco. When the Spanish conquerors arrived first to these lands; they could not explain themselves how Peruvian "Indians" (ignorant, wild, without any ability of logical reasoning, one more animal species according to conquerors) could have built such a greatness.

Worth seeing but please, provide some information for visitors!!. This site provides some of the most impressive stonework of the Inca empire and this is after visiting Machu Picchu. It was a good walk uphill to the site from Cusco and we enjoyed our morning there but continue to be frustrated by the lack of any good curation at these sites. They are so amazing and even small amounts of archaelogical information would be welcome. We did eventually find a few boards with some spanish info but even those were not very evident to those walking in from either of the two main entry points. Much of the best parts of the site were off limits to visitors...not sure why.

Ruins being preserved-Good Job. This was the main site where once a year on Winter solstice, government officials from all over the Incan empire would journey for months to see the 'high priest' explain how they were going to control the weather and to start to make the days grow longer for crops. It is still amazing to see how these places could be built today with modern engineering and mechanization. How did they do it 1/2 millenium ago? Glad that they are charging to help keep these areas preserved and protected. You can do this in 15 minutes or spend 1/2 a day there. Very close to downtown Cusco.

Impressive Inca Ruins. You will see more impressive ruins as you go along the Sacred Valley and visit Machu Pichu but these ruins overlooking Cusco are definitely a good place to start early in your trip (or at the end). Good view of Cusco and surrounding mountains from here.

A must see. This place is incredible! No one can figure even now how the stones got there. The size of the place and architecture is so advanced - you need to experience it Again we had such an informative tour guide. That's so essential and we had it arranged through Hernan at Pachamama expeditations
If you are in Cusco, go. Very nice area to walk and view the ruins. There is an especially good view of the city at one end. A nice prep if you are going to Machu Picchu.

So close to town, so ancient, so impressive.. Take a "city tour" here in Cuzco and you will also be treated to Sacsayhuaman ("sexy woman" to those of us who can´t pronounce the Quechau name properly). Incan ruins that stretch over an area larger than Machu Picchu, though looted by the Spanish to build the cathedral and other holy buildings.

$$$$$. I had read about the ruins and took a taxi up from Cusco to see them, but when I got there they were asking a lot of money for a tourist pass to several sites in order to get in the park. I said I just wanted to see this site, then they offered me a lower amount that was around $25. I told them, no thank you. When I started to walk up the street to take a picture from the distance, a guard would not let me pass. Lucky my taxi driver was waiting for me and he drove up the road, dropped me off some areas he knew of and I got a few good shots of the ruins. It is a nice historical site, but it is not fair to ask the tourist to pay prices that are unrealistic.

Amazing Site. Pronounced "sexy woman" as per our guide. Another amazing site of early engineering feats. Just hard to imagine how the walls were built with such precision. Just the history wants you to learn more.
sexy woman indeed. lovely location and fantastic ruins very interesting geology and great views overlooking Cusco. Also a great walk up to the site and around

Very Impressive. Amazing how the Incas built this place as the stones are huge and cut perfectly. It would have been nice to see the centre of the temple, but that was not an option. Great views of the city from the cross.

Use you imagination to appreciate this amazing structure on a huge scale. Well worth a visit, the scale of the ruins is immense. The size of the stones dwarf a human being and will leave you wondering how on earth did the Incas achieve such a feat .

How Did They Do It?. With crude tools but lots of manpower and incredible engineering. The walls are built out of enormous stones or boulders that have been polished and shaped to fit together perfectly. Beyond the engineering is the history. What stories these stones could tell. Well worth a visit.

Awesome. It is amazing to know that only 20% of this temple is left. It is huge, in the shape of a lightening bolt, symbolizing production. It is no wonder the Catholics thought it was not done by the Inca. The stones are massive and placed in perfect alignment. It is a marvel of Incan architecture, I only wish I could have seen it whole.

A must see in Cusco. Have your hotel find a driver that will take you to the ruins and explain the fascinating background of the ruins. Many guides are available in different languages. Plan on having trouble breathing at 14,000 feet.

Beautiful! But know this before you go!!!. Amazing to visit, but they charge tourists a lot to go, s/ 70 if you're international. There is a horseback riding excursion, s/30 per person (roughly $11 US) That takes you through Saqsayhuaman, and 3 other locations- for us Templo de la Luna and Templo del mono as well as the caves in the mountains behind saqsayhuamanIt is a much better experience, and well worth the money, since the horses also bring you through and above saqsayhuaman, the views are stunning

It does not change. I visited here 27 years ago and nothing changes other than the number of people as well as my growing fascination with the place. Back then, it was just another place to see, now I can see how it fits in with the Inca Empire and the importance to Cusco. As I have travelled through the sacred valley of the Incas towards Machu Picchu it all starts to come together.

Excellent site on Incan History. Sacsayhuaman is a excellent place to learn and observe the Incan culture, and building skills, dating back to the1400's. The fortress wall was uncovered and you can see the huge boulders that were used in the construction. It is very long and in the shape of a snake, when observed from above. The area where the stones are from is across the small opening from the wall. Construction techniques are still unknown, but there are few exhibits on how the stones were cut and grooved for fitting and placing in the wall. However they did it, they really knew how to fit and place stones, especially to withstand all the earthquakes that have occurred in the past. Climbing to the top of the wall you get a great view Cusco with its blanket of red tile roofs. While we were there we experience a flock of Alpacas with their shepherd on the valley floor. Be sure to go with an experience local guide, they will make the visit more interesting and you will get a better understanding of the culture. Our guide was great.

if time, must see. If you have a day, or a day and a half, in Cuzco, this is worth seeing. We were about to do the Inca Trail walk, so used the climb up through the houses/restaurants up to the site to acclimitize. It was oddly difficult to find the way, but perhaps that was just us with the new altitude! Be careful NOT to walk up the big main road very much - there is no need, with paths off the side which are much more enjoyable. We found the ruins a bit crowded, and bland, but the big stones are certainly impressive, the views of Cusco good, and the llamas engaging.

!!!Energy is fantastic. We've been there before sunset. We were practically the last one who left this site. We felt so positive energy of this place, it's impossible to describe, you should feel it. After visiting of Sacsayhuaman amazing things happened to us.

Inca Terraces. Apart from some amazing Inca Terraces there is not much to see -but the setting like so many Inca ruins is spectacular.Get there early or late to avoid the place being swamped by large groups from tourist buses
Amazing. Hoe they got these blocks to fit on top of each other and fit as perfectly as they do is amazing. Maybe ancient aliens is right

Amazing Ruins. This was a religious place, despite some people incorrectly believing it was a fortress, dating back to Inca times. Their are giant boulders some over 100 tons that were moved and placed by the Inca's. If you go to the top their are some good views of Cuzco.
Amazing intro to Incan ingenuity. The story of how it was built is incredible and mysterious. Do not attempt walking up to Sacsayhuaman from Cusco unless you are a mountain climber.

Don't miss it in your visit to Cusco. Tours in all the Cusco area are very well planned but usually they are rushing you for the next stop, I wish we had more time in Sacsayhuaman, it might be better if you just take a taxi or a bus and enjoy your stay there. The place is stunning, rocks from all sizes but the ones that will catch your eye are the big ones, you can picture the battle between incas and spaniards. Walk around the big platform, climb up, the Cusco view is awesome!!!!

Do Not Miss. A short and fun walk to the upper edges of Cusco and you're in one of the most amazing ruins in all of Peru. The layout and the sheer size of the stone blocks is jaw-dropping. Keep walking around the entire compound and you'll find other treasures - like dark long tunnels, rock faces to slide down ... and it goes on. Wonderful place.
Massive stones. This was one of the many stops during our afternoon tour. It was cold and raining at that time. The stones were massive. A lot of walking and climbing.
in the rain. Its just a short walk from plaza armas. Pretty typical if youve been traveling around peru but its nice for its proximity to the city

Those Incas knew a thing or two about building. My wife and I walked up from downtown Cusco all the way to the ruins. It was a long steep climb, but well worth the effort. The ruins are spectacular, as is the view over the whole valley. The only negative was the many closed areas at the very top of the site.
Sacsayhuaman. A beautiful place located in Cusco. The structure of the place are made by rocks , the guides count that this place were construed by the famous Inkas

A must see in Cusco. We took a tour to Sacsayhuaman which included the cathedral etc downtown. In retrospect, it would be much better to just take the tour of this area and in the morning, if possible. I think you really need a guide to get full value from this wonderful place. It is full of stories to be told and very big- a lot to take in on your own.

Pretty Cool!. Easy to get to and worth visiting! We found it very interesting to check out the different architectural techniques used at each ruin site. You'll find massive rocks used to construct the walls here. Really incredible.
Beautiful. A beautiful place where you can experience the mysticism of the entire city of Cusco. The architecture is beautiful and amazing

Unbelievable place.... Our travel Agency Peru path offer us to do a tour in the city before our trek to the inca trail and definitely they were right, our guide fredy was the person that explain all about the place and I am still thinking about it. it was really beautiful, we really recommend to go.

Wonderful Into to Inca Civilization and Architecture. We visited this site although the name was different on the entrance sign (see attached photo). But as an introduction to Inca Architecture, we were still amazed at how this culture mastered building buildings that withstood earthquakes, Spanish conquests, and time. We had an excellent guide explaining details in the techniques used by the Inca's which are amazing they had none of the digital measuring and computerized manufacturing techniques available today.The location is a short drive outside to hill above Cusco but it's well worth the time and cost to this adventure.

Colossal Inca Fortress. Incredulous zig-zag walls built with immense granite stones. Be sure to climb Inca's reviewing hill facing the fortress to get an overall view of the structure as well as the large amphitheater behind. A do not miss! A fairly hard slog uphill from Plaza de Armas if you like to trek.

Inca Masterpiece. Of all the Incan sites, this one stands out based upon its location, rock formations and history. For many reasons this is a star among Incan ruins. The historical significance, engineering feet and pure beauty makes this a required stop. Plus, the view of Cusco is amazing.

High Andes Inca experience. A good guide is invaluable to decipher the history and stories behind the huge stones and impressive constructions at this special site. The views over Cusco were also lovely. It is at a high altitude and we became rather tired and suffered from a bit of altitude sickness. Worth pacing it but worth going.

Magnificent stones and stunning views. You get some of the best views of Cusco from this fortress on the hill above the city. Fantastic examples of Inca stonework with hidden passageways and temples nearby.

Amazing What People Have Achieved. It was amazing to see the ruins and I was blown away by seeing it all in person. Unfortunately, this was quite a bit of walking and we were taking a tour in the rain. Our guide was knowledgeable and spoke good english but a full day of seeing the archelogical ruins is a lot of trekking.

Another Andean Wonder. We climbed all of the steps even though this was our first day in Cusco.to catch the beautiful sunset.
I was amazed at these boulders, the history and the tenacity the Incas must have had to place them in such order

Just outside of Cusco. It's pronounced "sexy woman". We took a guided bus tour. It is a short ride up into the hills above Cusco. The views are amazing of the surrounding mountains and of all the red clay roofs of Cusco. Inside the park you will see enormous rocks that the Incas carved to form Sacsayhuaman. There are a couple of places with steep stairs and loose gravel. The only bathroom is located just outside the park. At the end, there are about 5-10 native women with their alpacas and lamas that will pose for pictures. They expect a tip of about 2-5 sols for taking there pictures. This places is very interesting.

Mystical and mysterious place. This was our introduction to ancient structures. The place has a special energy and ora surrounding it. It is quite a hike between the tiny streets of the old city of Cusco before reaching the stone structure on the hills. The view there is absolutely mind boggling. Try to go there during the Inti Raymi like we did (the Inca's festival of the sun) on June 24th, during which the Cusco people reenact the Inca's celebration in an all day event that is carried out in the ancient fortress of Sacsayhuaman.

Very interesting Place. This was the first of our ancient structure visits. It is very impressive. You must have a guide who will also take you to the corpse preparation site. 120 ton stone blocks - how did they get there??The craftsmanship is mind boggling. A great place to visit before going to Machu Pichu. Purchase a general attractions ticket for soles 128 which allows you to see many local attractions - instead of paying per attraction which could be as high as soles 70. A must see while in Cusco.

An incredible site within easy walking distance from Cusco. This is a fantastic site to visit pre-Machu Picchu. The stonework is incredible, and the whole site has a mystical feel a bit like Stonehenge. Highly recommended.

Amazing. It is the best choice to start explore a Cusco region and Sacred Valley there.You can reach this place just for 10 minutes by taxi from Downtown. This is a huge complex of Inca's ruins, very impressive and amazing. You need around 2-3 hours for enjoying the whole place - ruins, park, lamas and view.

impressive. what can I say it is an impressive site to see. I suggest that when you visit this you do so with a guide that that can informed you more about the history of the site and answer all question you may have about it. For all you woundering it was not the work of aliens....

Amazing fortress. We arrived through the back entrance after visiting other sites higher up on the hill. After each part we were surprised to find a new, even more stunning sight. The Inka did a great work by incorporating natural rock formations into their buildings, but one you get down to the 3 zigzag walls made from huge stone blocks you just say "WOW!"You then get a stunning view of the city center and you can clearly recognize Plaza de Armas and the churches. If you still have enough energy continue to the White Christ statue and the walk down the narrow streets and stair cases of San Blas to the city

How Did These Structures Get Here?. This structure leaves more questions than answers about the Inca building techniques. There are some very large stones put together to form tight fits in unbelievable configurations. There is also a nice view of Cusco from this ruins. Not a waste of time to visit this old structure.

Impressive. The walls of Sacsayhuaman resemble the teeth of the Puma's Head when the Inca designed the city. The view is impressive but the story of the design is more fascinating. You should learn about the story before visit or hire a guide.

Warm up before Macchu Picchu. If you just arrived in the city and haven´t see Macchu Picchu yet, you can start your stay in Cuzco very weel visiting this place.Ruines from the time of the Incas decorate this enormous space. Stay prepared to be caught for a unexpected rain. The place is usually cold too, Be prepared with rain covers.At least, reserve 2 hours to around and enjoy the place.

Some changes after 35 years. This was the first time we've been back after 35 years. There are some changes - you can no longer get up close and personal with the large stones, but that also protects them. Great scenic overlook of Cusco has been added. During this time of the year there aren't very many tourists, but at the same time it can be rainy so go early.

Simply beautiful. With so many places to see in Cusco, I'm glad I got to take a side trip here. Once again the grounds are so amazing and beautiful. The Stones and steps and how did they build these places???? So fascinating to hear all about it from the so informed guides. Just make sure your acclimated to the altitude before you go to any attraction. Otherwise you will feel awful.
Interesting. The rock walls here were quite something to see. Huge stones so carefully carved to fit together. Well worth seeing.

Inca Empire former capital architectural marvel. This place unravels some of the greatest architecture and monumental stonework. Huge boulders were cut together carefully that they could be joined together without a mortar. Because of the high walls, it is also called the fortress. There are also llamas around
amazing walls !. even under the rain it was still of a great interest...perfect architecture of huges stones tightly fitted and still there after all those centuries..

Nice vista to Cusco. We made the trek from the town up here and really there is not a lot to see. The location is stunning but there are only a few walls left and restoration work is going on so that there will be more to see in the future.
This is a fabulous, fascinating array of stonework.... Not throngs of people to get around...you can wander at your own pace and not be crowded...it was a hot day, so bring sunscreen or hats.

Impressive site. An uphill walk from the plaza brings you to this religious/military compound which was the site of a significant clash between the Spaniards and the Incas. The architecture is amazing for it's time as military citadels used the same years later. Finally, it's hard to walk this site, notice the structure, and not wonder time and again "how did they do this?"

"SexyWoman" is nice place. We went there with a local guide which makes that experience much more enjoyable, I highly recommend that once there, just pay for that to give more then feel tired @ night.

130 Tons!. That's the size of the largest stone at this site. It is believed to be a religious amphitheater of some description - no one really seems to know. Regardless, the sheer magnitude of this location gives one pause to consider how construction of this type might have been possible so long ago. The giant Jesus with the outstretched arms, visible all over Cusco is adjacent. Put Sacsayhuaman on your list if you're visiting the Sacred Valley.

Amazing. This is a spot all visitors to the Sacred Valley should include in their schedule. It is amazing what Inca culture achieved. The skill of builders was totally amazing. The morning I visited it was not crowded but the guide that is fairly unusual so plan to view this location early to avoid the crowds.

Cool, but no need to pay the price. We went to visit these ruins and found out that you can't just pay admissions for the site only, you have to buy the complete Boleto Partial which was 70 sols. So we just walk on the other side of the road and viewed the stone walls from afar. Again we had been to Machu Picchu so didn't feel the need to see these close up. If it was the only ruin I was going to see then yes I would pay the price. Walking across the road took us up to San Cristobal which was neat which the most amazing view of the city. Then the walk back down on the old cobblestone road was great, putting you right into one of the main squares. Definitely worth the trip.

the closest Inca ruin site, walkable from downtown Cuzco. There are various spellings you'll see to this name. One I've seen often is "Saqsayhuaman". It's on the hilltop just behind the Plaza de Armas. You can get a Boleto Turistico to this site as part of the 4 sites that is all clustered together on the hilltop behind Cuzco valley. Tambomachay, Puca Pucara, Q'enko, and Saqsayhuaman, can all be seen together for 70 Soles in 1 day. I'm sure you can get a ticket to enter just Saqsayhuaman by itself, but not sure how much it is. The day we went up we had planned to go do all 4 sites, but the weather turned really bad as soon as we got to Tambomachay (the furthest one away). Thunder clouds rolled in and it started to hail and it got very windy, cold, and there was lightning. We managed to also see Puca Pucara, but had to skip Q'enko. We got a taxi to take us up to Tambomachay and had planned to walk down to the other sites. On a nice day this would not have been any trouble at all. By the time we left Puca Pucara we decided that we probably needed to get a ride back down somehow. Luckily, a very nice Peruvian couple spotted us 3 tourists walking along the side of the road and offered to take us back down to Cuzco. We went passed Q'enko, but decided to at least try to get in Saqsayhuaman since we had already forked out 70 Soles to see these 4 sites. I wish we got to spend more time at Saqsayhuaman as it seemed like a very impressive site. Those HUGE stones along those walls will just blow your mind. How in the world did they even move these stones into place?? All the information about the place says its a fort given it's layout and strategic location above the city. But that's mainly from the perspective of the Spaniards coming in. I do wonder though if there is another explanation for what this place was really meant to be .... You can get a fantastic view of the Plaza de Armas from Saqsay. And after you're done you can just work your way back down to the city with not much trouble at all. Definitely worth it to visit this site and so close to the city.One major piece of advice .... we came here the 2nd day of being in Cuzco and so we were not yet savvy taxi negotiators. Besides I didn't have a clear idea of how far Tambomachay really was from Plaza de Armas and so didn't know what would be a fair and reasonable rate to negotiate. As it turned out it really was not very far at all. We paid 30 Soles for the 3 of us to get up there (just 1 way). But in hindsight it should have been no more than 15 Soles. It only costs 15 Soles to get to the airport from downtown, and later on we did a day trip out to Moray & Maras in a shared taxi (combi) that was only between 5-7 Soles per person each way and that was 30km from Cuzco. Tambomachay must have been less than 10km for sure. If you do a shared taxi it should not cost more that 5 Soles per person one way for sure. Stand your ground and don't back down.

sacsayhuaman. Very interesting visit, My tour guide are excelent, walking,and walking ,no waters To drink or bathroom in the ruins, but the bus stop in other site To go. I recommended tennis, rain coat, and alpaca sweater.

Impressive architecture - well worth a visit. Most people couldn't name anything left behind by the Inca's other than the deservedly famous Machu Picchu site. There are a number of equally amazing sites in the greater Cusco area, especially in the Urubamba River Valley. Sacsayhuaman is actually much larger than the Machu Picchu site and involved the use of much larger stones, some weighing over 100 tons. Unfortunately, this site was sacked by the Spanish when they defeated the Inca's so that all is left are the massive foundations. We had a guide which was useful as there was limited information presented at the site.

Worth a visit. We took a taxi from our hotel (20 soles) and enjoyed exploring the ruins. There is no information posted on site, so best to read ahead, or get a guide if you're really interested in the historical details. We walked back to town afterwards, which was nice. Probably took about 15 minutes.

Put on your walking shoes!. It's a nice hike up a pretty steep hill and there's an interesting statue of Jesus at the top. Given the altitude and the steep climb, I'm just grateful we were able to do it! (We're 58 & 65 respectively).

Definitely worth the visit. This ruin is just a short ride from Cusco and definitely worth the visit. Without our tour guide we likely would not have known quite as much about what we were looking at, so make sure you understand what the site has to offer. This ruin is another remarkable example of Incan engineering!

Inti Rami!. We went here for Inti Rami (The Sun Festival) and it was incredible. Being Archaeologists and having no money, we sat with thousands of other Cuzco residents on the hillside, eating potatoes and chicken whilst we waited for the guy to come round and sell ice-creams. The festival itself probably looked great from the expensive Gringo seats but the Peruvians went mental whenever the music started, you just had to join in. The best part of all of this is the fact that Sacsayhuaman is free to entry for one day only, meaning you can have a good nose around without paying for the tourist ticket (although this ticket is worth it for all the amazing sites it gets you into). The Inka stonework is truly stunning, some of the best in the Andes (trust me, I know my Inka stonework). Do not miss this site!

Fortress above Cusco where Incan's had their last stand for Cusco. Fortress above Cusco where the Incan's had their last stand for Cusco against the Spanish Conquerors. While many stones were removed and used in Cusco it is still an engineering marvel, and impressive site. Strongly suggest background reading before traveling to make the sites come alive. The first half of the book, "Fall of the Inca's" was very relevant.

"Monumental!". This type of place, just like "Macchupichu", leaves you in awe!We had a great personal guide, Angel, who showed us around and told us many stories while gaving us a lot of information about this particular monument, also called "la Fortaleza" (the Fortress). Originally built as a sacred place, according to the historians, the Incas made their last stand here against the Pissaro brothers.The feeling you get walking among those huge stones, perfectly chiseled to fit with each other without mortar, just makes you wonder how they did accomplish such amazing big building-miracles!

Don't miss it but come early to enjoy. This is a great place to visit but only with a private guide that can explain everything otherwise you won't understand or appreciate its history and wonder. Place is not accommodating to people in wheelchair which is a shame. If you go, go early in the morning not in the afternoon. This is part of the tourist ticket which gains you access to other sites. Wear tennis shoes. One of the most beautiful pictures can be taken on your way to the site so don't miss it.

So impressive. We taxied to all the ruins in the area and then did this one last so we didn't walk up from the city. So impressive. Walked among the ruins and saw some llamas. Great spot for a picnic. We walked down when we were done....maybe 10 minutes but downhill.

Fascinating site. Beautiful Inca site located in the hills of Cusco where not only the site itself is impressive but the beautiful views of the city too. Probably the second most important ruins after Machupicchu and only 15 minutes away from downtown Cusco. I would recommend hiring a guide (approx. 30 soles) which you can do when you get to the site. Keep in mind you have to buy the "Boleto Turistico" to enter.
History brought to life. A fascinating place to visit but ally need to have a guide to explain what it is all about, otherwise just seems like list of rocks!

Great site. Not a must, but very interesting--Keep in mind that it is 70Soles to get in, or 130 soles to visit 4 sites together (40soles for students). About 15 soles cab ride from the city center. Bring a compass, it goes crazy on the top of the rocks.

One of the most impressive Inca creations.. A large site that truly reflects the scale of their work. Stone pieces up to 170 tonnes moved without the use of any wheels. We had a great guide and that is essential for all these visits.
Another Good Example of Inca Craftsmanship. This Inca fortress is in quite good shape. I was particularly impressed with the size of the stones and how carefully they had been fitted.

Well worth the walk up. I was going to get a taxi up and walk back then decided to brave, and it wasn't nearly as bad as I feared - it took under half an hour even with frequent stops for breathI decided against a guide, having had one in Pisac, and I was quite happy just to wander round being amazed by the achievements of those who had built it. Whatever the buildings were for (and remember the guides are only guessing anyway as the Incas didn't write) they are great to look at and think "how did they manage that".Good views of all of CuscoMake the short detour to the Cristo Blanco whilst you're up thereIf you want to go on to the other ruins be warned the signage is not at all clear - I gave up!

Ancient ruins not to miss. This is located above the city of Cusco and the huge stones that the Incas used to construct this area are mind boggling. Our guide led us around most of the area in little over an hour, and that helped us understand and appreciate it. All week he kept telling us we would see "Sexy Woman" on our last day, now I know he was talking about Sacsayhuaman. Like many places in Peru with ruins, this also has a few steps to climb, that plus the altitude had me breathing hard, There were several alpacas on the grounds, made for some interesting pictures for our group,

Peaceful and spiritual. Included in the City tour were these ruins. It was situated above Cusco. It was great to visit it the day before heading to Machu Pichu. The stone walls were unbelievable. It was a wonderful view. It felt so peaceful to be in this place. I highly recommend visiting this place.
amazing cut stones. weara jacket here.. it gets breezy..I can't get enough of the Inca stone.. good examples here.and a nice view of the statue of jesus

How did they do that?. This site makes you ask more questions than it answers. Just has to be seen to be believed. Get used to altitude before going up to site as it is several hundred meters above Cusco.

Pronounced Sexy-woman !. An Inca settlement high above Cusco, amazing structures and brilliant building techniques have made this a must visit site. Excellent views over Cusco add to the interest. Then on to the traditional local craft village ! If you like woollen garments fine, but for 5 blokes on holiday it was a quick in and out !

Must See In Cusco. Great place to visit while in Cusco.. I recommend doing the City Tour where you will get to see these ruins and other sites. Having a guide is definitely a help. Awesome ruins to see.
Over-rated as a site. There is not much to see and without a guide the site makes little sense. It was packed with school groups the day in August when we went

How'd they do that?. This is a sprawling labyrinthine complex of enormous multi shaped stones wedged and held together without mortar. You are left wondering how supposedly primitive pre-Columbian man was able to do this, and have a sense that this structure is unlike the pyramids or Stonehenge.
Magical Ruins. I have visited the ruins of Sacsayhuaman 4 times. I find the atmosphere and the stories associated with this place more spiritual than even Machu Picchu. I always feel good here.
Very impressive. Great ruins and again a must see if you are in Cusco. We took a tour that covered the entire Scared valley that took the whole day. A great prelude to Machu Picchu.

Amazing Megalithic Structures. WOW...what can I say? WOW! This archaeological site has some of the largest stones I have ever seen. How did they construct this??? The site is very close to Cusco and there are other archaeological sites nearby. Take the day to visit them, it is definitely worth it. Your appreciation and awe will grow with every site you visit.

Epic Inca Ruins, and yet so close to Cusco City. Don't miss out on Saqsayhuman, it is one of Cusco City's best attractions. You can do it as part of a guided tour of the city, or you can do it on your own. From Cusco's main plaza it is just a 30 minute walk (up-hill), but well-worth the effort. Remember that you will need to BTG Cusco tourist ticket to get in, which you can buy at the wardens hut. Don't forget to see the rear section of the ruins, often overlooked (or unknown) by visitors.

Impressive and fun. This was part of our tour. It was very impressive and interesting; thank goodness our guide gave us some background and history on this spot. If you have the time, definitely climb around and don't miss sliding on the rocks.
Interesting place. Its an interesting place, and a big terrain. We payed 20 or 30 soles for the guide, it has a nice view over Cusco

Waste of money. I'm amazed at how high this is on the list. The site is interesting, and the views over Cusco are great, but the price was outrageous. We took a cab up and he was sure to drop us at the ticket office, so maybe we got taken, but I think we paid the standard admission price, about $25 per person. There was absolutely no information available unless you wanted to pay a guide. No plaques, no map from the ticket office, nothing. Our guidebook had some limited information so we got the point, but I really felt like we overpaid to see some rocks. I'm not sure what they use the money for. From what I can tell there was one employee and very little upkeep necessary. What's worse, I'm fairly certain that you don't need to pay to get in. There seemed to be about 20 different ways to get in and out, and there was nobody checking tickets or anything. I would say that if you're going, go in the back way - there is a large field to the left just before the ticket office (if you come by car). Walking through that field will take you right into the ruins. If it cost under $5 I might call it 3 stars for the view.

Ancient wonder of the New World. Yes, you will love this place. It's full of energy and wonder, and there are llamas and alpacas wandering about freely. The stones are cut so perfectly that you wonder how they did it. There are huge stones that must weigh tons !!! We spent over an hour here and there is a great view of the city of Cusco below. Right near by is the statue of "Christ of Cusco" which is lit up with blue flood lights at night-so exotic and awe inspiring !!! If you go in July take a good alpaca sweater cuz it will be chilly !!!

Impressive Stones!. HUGE stones and amazing engineering feats by the Inkas! Our guide (a history major) wanted us to know how special and more sophisticated this place was than Machupicchu. It was impressive but MP to me is hard to beat.

How did they build that?. I am still amazed all these months later at how the Inca's were able to build these massive structures without our modern knowledge. The placement of the stones are an architectural perfection!

Definitely interesting. This was part of my Cusco day tour.This ancient archeological site is located on the top of the hill, so its a pretty steep climb.But as you get there, the grounds are massive and you get beautiful views of the the surrounding area and Cusco city.It definitely had a military fortress like significance back in the day.The grounds are well maintained and you can spend a few hours just wondering around the site.Lucky we had a guide so the importance was explained in full.Worth a visit since it took 70yrs to build using around 20000 men.

Big Rocks. We took a taxi to Tambo Machay and then hiked back to Town past Puca Pucara, Salapunco, Quenko and Sacsayhuaman. The hike was easy and very peaceful -we saw no other people. Sacsayhuaman is the best of the 5 sites and very amazing. We didn't have a guide, just a guidebook, I'm sure a guide would have added more meaning. But in any case, the size of the rocks and the way they fit together is unbelievable.

great site. This is a fascinating historic site easily accessible from Cusco. More excavation to be done but already well worth a visit. Nice views. Worth hiring a guide as you can learn so much more.

Wonderful at sunset. My wife and I traveled to Sacsayhuaman at sunset. What an experience. First off, the size of the rocks, or perhaps I should say boulders that are perfectly laid on top of other boulders is amazing. It is impossible to grasp how the Inca could have accomplished such a feat. What is more amazing is looking at the site and imagining what it once was. I am not a big fan of guides at archaeological sites. Typically, with a guide you get a lot of false information, or guesses presented as truth. However, when you go to a place like Sacsayhuaman, it is necessary that you either read about the site in advance or get a guide to tell you about the history of the site and what once stood at the site. Keep in mind that the majority of the stores were taken into Cusco to build Spanish buildings. This is a MUST SEE if you are in Cusco! You will not find Incan architecture of this scale anywhere. GO!

If the Incas only had horses and steel.... ...we would all be speaking Quechua now. Maybe a bit exaggerated, but you get the point. One of the coolest things I learned was that the Incas did not use any kind of mortar to fit their structures - they cut the blocks to the exact specifications, and they did all of this without the help of iron or steel (they were still in the stone and bronze age when the Spaniards arrived).This fortress held back the attacking Spaniards on several occasions and is where one of the five conquering Pizarro brothers was killed. The stones are immense. It is really amazing. If you can read The Last Days of the Incas before you go it will help you visualize the purpose. It would get five stars from me except that in the end it is a field with giant rocks, so, come on.:)

Another World Wonder!. While we stopped here with a guide, who provided the background history of this amazing site, one could read about it in a book as well.(We think the guides make the trip much more interesting). The sheer size of the stonework so perfectly fit together into mammoth stone walls is unbelievable, it is well worth the trip. Make sure to check out the aerial photos by the entrance (or exit depending on where you begin the hike) to see how the walls are configured.

Another Must See. The Sacred Valley is an important part of any trip to Cusco, even if you are there primarily for the Inca Trail. The countryside is beautiful, and Sacsayhuaman is such a wonderful representation of Quechua architecture that you will not be disappointed.

A GOOD CLIMB. the climb up has both stone steps and a trail so you can pick what you feel like doing.it is pretty much straight up and if you're not in great shape you will be huffing and puffing,lol (i did) once you get to the top the veiws are amazing! so make sure to take your camara!

Please don't say sexy woman again.. One of the more interesting archeological sites (don't say ruins). It was interest touring this place with the Quechuan guide. I would recommend this as a place to visit.
