Interesting site. This was a very interesting area. However, you need a guide to help explain the history. The elevation is quite high above Cusco, so it is difficult to get enough oxygen.
Impressive!. Did my own research - and wish the guides shared more with visitors about it's mystical origins, including the legends, the mysteries surrounding the way it was built, etc.

Very cool place.. This is a really cool attraction that is very close to the center of Cuzco. The history here is amazing and this is a great thing to check out while you are hanging out in Cuzco waiting to adjust for the altitude!
Sacsayhuaman. It is a very short ride away from Cusco and worth seeing this unique historic site. A true marvel of engineering!
Another Inca Marvel. We were not disappointed in any of the Inca sites. This one is definitely worth seeing and so close to Cusco. Wonderful views of the surrounding areas as well.

Worth a taxi ride out from Cusco. We hired a taxi to take us to several areas of Incan interest. A great day out cost us US$50.
Sacsayhuaman, is huge fortress created by the planners of Cuzco. It's impressive and worth a visit. We probably did not do it justice in the hour visit, but we had other places to squeeze into our mini trip.

Beautiful and accessible. This was one of the most accessible Inca sites. Beautiful. Easy walk around the site. We tried to see the cave but the smell of urine was overwhelming. I hear it's interesting though. Outside of the cave smell, not a lot of downsides to the visit. Beautiful views of the city and mountains from the site. Save plenty of space on your memory card for the visit.
Not a bad day trip from Cuzco. I took the Cuzco city bus ride to the site - but did not actually "enter" the ruin. It's interesting and worth the two hours too see it.

Breathtaking experience. Sacsayhuaman certainly takes your breath away on first view. I had seen pictures in the holiday brochure, but seeing it for real was just amazing! The size of this structure has to be seen to be believed,& its state of preservation is impressive, despite the intervention of the Conquistadors...We had an excellent guide who brought the whole thing to life, with his knowledge of the complex. The size of some of the stones used in the building of the walls has to be seen to be believed. All in all, Sacsayhuaman is a place not to be missed. You will be blown away. I would certainly love to have another chance to explore it further.

Fantastic. This is one of the most interesting, most accessible (you can walk up from Cuzco) and least crowded Inca sites in Peru - don't miss it if you are around Cuzco. The 'jaguar's teeth' are an amazing construction - huge blocks fitted very closely together - how did they do it??? It is a large site with plenty of interesting corners to explore, and in varying states of ruin, from almost perfect to hardly visible any more. Apparently 80% of the stones have been plundered. The vision behind the plan of the site is staggering - we did not have a guide (other than Lonely Planet), which was fine, but would have learned much more I think if we had. Views over Cuzco and the surrounding hills are beautiful too.
Nice. To see if you are in Cusco. Very short trip out of Cusco. Impressive Incan ruins. Was not crowded. A must do if you are in Cusco.

Amazing architectural feat. Definitely worth touring this site. Lots of space to enjoy the rock formations. Easy access on foot if you walk up street from hotel Monastery. Cheap day pass about $30. Not worth ten day pass you can see everything in a couple hours.

Pretty, spectacular. One of the most accessible ruin sites. You can walk from town, which is a bit of a hike, or take a tour bus in. We hired one of the on-site tour guides, and that turned out really well. Edwin took us through tunnels that we wouldn't have found on our own. He played his flute in the caves, which was a great experience. He was also selling music CDs, videos and flutes, but wasn't pushy about it (To book him, call 974270100.) Bonus: One of the cleanest bathrooms in all the ruin sites we visited.
Wonderfull. A fascinating familiar experience. I wish we could visit Sacsayhuaman at night.My daughters, parents, sister and me for sure will return some day.

An amazing architectural structure!. Sacsayhuaman is commonly known now as a military complex due to the references giving by the Spaniards whom associated it's construction to the military fortresses of Spain. When they arrived and saw this amazing buildings they thought that because of it's construction, it had to be one to protect the VERY AMAZINGLY RICH Sacred City of Cusco. They Spaniards had no idea of what they were looking at, at all. Based on the chronicles of Pedro de Cieza de Leon whom is titled self appointed (later by the crown of Spain) the FIRST CHRONICLER OF THE INKAS. Sacsayhuaman isn't really a military fortress, (And yet here is where the last rebelion of the INKAS lead by TUPAC AMARU II was fought against Spain and lost) That in fact Sacsayhuaman was in part a warehouse but mostly was a RELIGOUS COMPLEX. Cieza whom had being a witness to the invasion of the Empire of Tawantinsuyo, arrived at 13 - 14 years as an square, comeback as a soldier at 16-17 and lived 17 years in PERU (Died at the age of 35 a year later after coming back to Spain) He took as his life's duty traveling across the entire Empire to record not only of what he was seeing but everything he could taking his time investigating, talking to the survivors of the massacres specially to the nobles to let the generations to come INKA and European known the crimes committed against humanity and the World instead of acquiring the knowledge of how the INKAS had accomplish such incredible organization and productivity in all possible aspects on a such bast and hardship land. He describes in detail the purpose of this complex. "THE INKAS OF PEDRO DE CIEZA" it's a wonderful book to read. Very clear, concise, impressive, and almost sad - fun :(.Translated into English it contains two of Cieza's books. Pedro Cieza's chronicles were banded by the "holly inquisition" since PEDRO brought to light not only the amazing history of the INKA culture and race but the unjustly abuses inflicted on the "Noble people of PERU" as he calls them and savages, ignorant nitwits and cruel to his fellow man the 'Spaniards'... Sacsayhuaman is in did an architectural WONDER... (In all extent of the word). I was born in Cusco - Sacsayhuaman was my playground! WHAT A LUCK!! I LOVE THIS LAND!!
Super cool. I was amazed by the size of the stones. I felt very small next to them. It wasn't as crowded as Machu Picchu so it was really nice just to walk around and take pictures.

Don't miss this. We walked here from the centre if Cusco - a bit tiring but quite do-able. When you arrive at the site, the fortifications are quite jaw dropping. An amazing example of Incan building. Do not miss this site if you are in Cusco.

Must see while in Cusco. Inca ruins are all around Cusco and the Sacred Valley. This is a very short trip out of Cusco. You can even walk there. It is an amazing ruin. Enormous and awe inspiring with a great view of the city. Don't miss this when in Cusco!

Sacsayhuaman. i was overwhelmed at these ruins. i had no idea what i was going to see and was shocked at the vastness and good condition of this terrific structure. Clearly, the highlight of a visit to Cusco! We had a guide that helped significantly.
Awesome. This plae reminded me of the temples in Egypt - same enormous stones put in place with masterful precision. Beautiful spot with peaceful atmosphere.
Exciting Ruins. Very interesting look at how the Incas approached building and some insights into their cosmic vision

How did they do it?. With the wisdom of hindsight, sexywoman as the guides called it, was not as sensational as other sites we visited. However, the size of the stones which make up this site literally take your breath away. They are fitted together without mortar and need to be seen to be believed. It is worth walking all over the area despite the altitude which may affect some more than others. The remains of the central tower give an idea of what it was like before the Spanish trashed it. It must be seen, but in our opinion was not the best Inca site we saw.

Awe inspiring settlement with massive walls. Sacsayhuaman does not get the publicity that Machu Picchu gets but it deserves to get more. It is a deeply moving location which served many purposes in the past, but now serves the purpose of showing what amazing skills the builders had.
worth the climbing. great place, very easy to get to by foot. Impressive walls, great atmosphere. Walk slowly, it's worth it !
Don't miss this..... This site was included in Cusco/Sacred Valley tour package and I am glad we did not miss it. Almost as amazing to see as Machu Picchu....

And so close to Cusco. An extraordinary structure built by the Inca. It gives you a sense of their culture and engineering skills. Carving and fitting such huge rocks together in 3 dimensions is amazing.
Great ruins near Cusco. These ruins are not so big but they are in a very good shape. They have a significant historical value. From the hill, you can see a great view of the city.

A must visit whilst in Cusco. This is an epic archaeological site located on the outskirts of Cusco. You can visit as part of a tour or on your own. You can walk there from the main Plaza de Armas, leaving by Calle Suecia. The walk takes about 40 minutes, and is up hill all the way, but well worth the effort. You will need a partial BTG ticket to get in S/. 70

A place to visit.. This year was my second visit to Sacsayhuaman, last year we could approach the walls and touch them and stand against them. This year there are ropes to keep the people at a distance. All these power places are being more and more protected because of all the visitors.
The Inca craftsmanship has to be seen. must visit, close to Cusco, to see the craftmanship in this area shows us the Incas had an ability to cut hard granite we do not have today.
Interesting. This site is amazing because of the size of the boulders used, and of course, the ability of the Quechuan people to cut stone with only stone.
A worth while side trip to see Machu Picchu. Visited here as part of a tour group on our way to Machu Picchu. The ruins were a good starter for what was to be seen the next day.
Saccsayhuaman. A beautiful place where you can experience the mysticism of the entire city of Cusco. The architecture is beautiful and amazing

Very Interesting. Interesting ruins - under some restoration work but a beautiful place. Avoid the souvenir peddlers at the end (lots of rip offs to be had). Annoyingly the cord placed at the foot of some of the rock walls to prevent people from touching it detracts from the photos somewhat - however near to the exit and very close to the entrance you can find walls without the cord for picture opportunities.
Great view of the city. and nice set of ruins. We were a bit tired from the previous days treks so we took a taxi to the ruins (10 PEN) and chose to walk back to the city.

Very interesting. Was a great place to get the back ground on the Incas and is needed as a precursor to going to machu picchu. The tours do take you to a few markets but this so you can use the bathrooms.

Amazing History. To read about the history of the Incas is one thing, but to see, first hand, the scale of what they constructed is utterly amazing. Don't miss a visit to this important piece of Inca history just above the city of Cusco.
Get a guide. Well worth a visit but ensure you have a guide as they are excellent at pointing out things you would miss like the pumas paw built into the wall.
Very interesting. Enjoyed visiting here, was a long day though, try and have a day "off" before getting into the tours, alot of walking. Really enjoyed it though
Gorgeous. Peru is blessed with many ruins sites. This site is very well maintained. It comes with it's share of engineering mysteries to contemplate. There is less climbing than other sites.

Atmospheric. Very atmospheric visit at a time when the local school boys were practising for a re-enactment of an Inka ceremony in which 14 year old boys marked their manhood. Fabulous setting and spectacle.

Amazing. We found this a little by accident after a morning spent horse riding. It’s very much worth a visit. Some amazing views of Cusco and great photo opportunity. Make sure you bring a warm coat if you are staying out for the day. When the sun started to go down we nearly froze!

An Interesting Site. Great views of Cusco A must see to tie all of the history together of the Incas and Pachacutec. It is located just above the city of Cusco. My family and I visited Sacsayhuaman on our last day in Peru, the tour was interesting and the kids enjoyed running with the alpacas.
Read the name again and it sound like sexy woman!. That was how I remember how to pronounce the name Lamas wandering around fantastic history and views over Cusco well worth a visit

small but impressive. Of all the ruins we saw during our 2 week stay in Peru, Sacsayhuaman has the largest and most impressive stones. It's very close to Cusco and doesn't take much time to walk through the site, so go if you're in Cusco. Get a tour guide. They have a lot of great information to share and are worth the small fee.

Hard to believe this place exists. Not knowing what to expect, I was stunned by this site. The open field leading to the fortification is impressive in itself, but when we got to the stone structure I was in total awe of their ability to build a structure of stone so perfectly. You have to see it to believe it!

Cool ruins. Wow - we actually walked all around the ruins. Fascinating experience. Seeing the wall the incas built sure made me wonder how they did all that without the modern machinery we have these days. There were families there having picnics and flying kites right in the middle of these amazing ruins
Very good if you like archaeology. Nice site to visit with a guide ( many guides wait at the entrance). Up there you will also meet alpacas on the incas ruins and the view of cusco is beautiful.

One of Peru's Best. An absolutely breathtaking site containing a fortress of enormous proportions whose building must have called forth the maximum in human energy, endurance and skill. The height and thickness of the stones used in its construction are massive. They were obviously pulled over long distances by large teams of lower workers, using ropes and ramps to aid their formidable task. The most dramatic component is a large Plaza sued for ceremonial and sacrificial purposes that is buttressed by three levels of terraced walls, and for which dramatic views of Cusco can be enjoyed. Many storehouses, suitable for military equipment as well as food, can be seen, as sieges of the Fortress taking place during external assaults on Cusco have been authenticated by scholarly research. Ultimately, many of the smaller stones were removed to Cusco to expand the city, but the larger ones that remain provide the finest examples of Inca stonework: adjacent blocks are cut and polished to interlock without the use of mortar, and the joints are so perfect that the thinnest piece of paper cannot pass between them. The mountain scenery visible from this site is among the best you will see in all Peru.

Amazing Place. First, this place is immense so you can't see it all. Next, take a good look at the stunning stonework. Don't know how the Inca managed. Seeing the earthen ramps from the quarry area is also interesting. Go.

Wonderment at 11,348 Feet!. Sacsayhuaman embodies the Inca Imperial style of workmanship in stone. What remains of this site are the fortifications and bases built by the Inca during their short but important Pre-Conquest dominance. The workmanship and scale of this site are impressive. I highly recommend touring Sacsayhuaman an hour before sunset to capture the brilliance and beauty of this site as the sun rests upon her age old bones.

*sigh*. it is a good hike up the mountain from cusco. it doesnt take too long and there is plenty to see along the way.
the veiw from the top is breathtaking!
Incredible. an incredible historic site, and one of the best we encountered in Peru. The enormous stones have to be seen to be believed.
Good site. The ruins were great to see. In the afternoon it gets cold. Very windy. Be sure to ask for a map. It is helpful with the sites on the tourist ticket.
awesome ruin site. I've wanted to come here since watching TV programs about it. I found it very interesting. it has super views of Cusco looking below

Bonus view of the city. In addition all say about the site, you also walk to top and find a beautiful view of the city of Cusco!
Not very far from city either-easy to get to.
Make sure you go even if you feel you've seen enough rocks!

Fascinating Architecture. After reading about all the history at this site, I absolutely HAD to visit. The construction is amazing and interesting. Highly worth the visit, much more worth it than many other smaller ruins in the area.
Historic Beauty. Don't miss this! Amazing and so rich in history. Take a tour round (there are plenty of English speaking tours) to really appreciate this place.

good place. we loved the huge stones sacsayhuaman is said that this place was for him only lightning god I can not imagine how moved huge stones can even believe that this was not manmade visit this beautiful place

Must Go. We had a great time learning and exploring with our guide Harvey. A big shout out to Harvey who we had the pleasure of having as our guide thru international expeditions. The massive structure and its fine workmanship is not to be missed. Plus the history surrounding this site makes it a must see
Tour of Sacsayhuaman. Very impressive Inca stone work, incredibly large stones finished and placed so accurately. Also saw some native rock with what appeared to be glacial grooves.

An engineering wonder. We saw many sites around Cuzco while spending several days in the city adjusting to altitude prior to a trek. For me, the most significant aspect of this site was to observe the sheer size of the stones making up the walls and to marvel at the precision fit the Incas achieved. It boggles the mind. Sacsayhuaman is an expansive site and while it is not as busy as Machu Picchu there are a lot of tourists there. Some complained of cost. Please, please: if you are visiting Cuzco for more than a day or two buy the Touristico Boleto (or however it is spelled). Huge money saver and is good for 10 days. This was not my favorite archeological site in Peru, but definitely worth the time and money.

Very interesting place. Sacsayhuaman is a short drive out of Cuzco and definitely worthwhile seeing. I enjoyed the fact that we had an English speaking guide that explained all the history and details to us.
Guided Tour. Beautiful day, loved spending time walking freely and enjoying the openness of the area and visiting the ruins. A must.

Interesting place, a must. Imponent ruins in the outskirts of Cusco. The ceremony of the Inti Raymi (to the God Sun) took place here and every year they continue to do it.Huge rocks, gives you an overview of what the Inca´s Empire was.Takes aprox 45 minutes to get around and take pictures.
Get your walking shoes on!!!. This is a very expansive ruin site... so be ready to walk lots and climb up ruins to get the best ever views. And the resident pack of alpacas and llamas is adorable!!!
great!. this inca site is really wirth visiting it!!we loved the surrounding and the view over cusco.the site is amazing, the history really interesting! we just loed it!

A must-see in Cusco. Sacsayhuaman is only a couple of kilometres from the centre of Cusco -- hey, we walked there, but it is uphill all the way. It's a fabulous set of ruins with some aspects you don't see everywhere else. We spent hours there -- much longer than we intended. You need a special ticket (turistico boleto) to visit Sacsayhuaman. One or three day options can be purchased at the gate. Ask for details at the gate or in town at the tourist office.

We lucked out. We visited these ruins on the outskirts of Cuzco while it was lightly raining. So glad we did because for about an hour, we were the only visitors there. What a lovely advantage!You can hike up to explore these incredible ruins although it probably takes a good hour from Plaza de Armas. Uphill all the way, baby! We chose a taxi. Once there, we explored the entire area, took a nice long path to find the overlook of Cuzco (beautiful panorama) and climbed the hill to Cristo Blanco to snap some closeup photos.The grounds here are kept very clean and are marked well. Walk up to the ruins walls and note the intricacy of how they are carved to perfectly fit against each other. Unbelievable.I suggest you use a guide as these ruins would make more sense.These ruins and the others close by are a definite must-see when in Cuzco.

Huge rocks and impressive formations. If in Cusco, this is a must see "ruin" although without a guide, it won't makE a lot of sense. The rocks are huge that formed Sacsayhuaman. Big open fields. Interesting grounds. Not much more than rocks, formations and wide open fields. You can explore the entire place in an hour. You do get nice views of the city. Make sure you go through the caves that Are off to the side. Very interesting.

Good Introduction to the Region. We visited Sacsayhuaman twice while in the Cusco area. It was part of our intro city tour. Then, we returned for the Inti Raymi festival. It is an interesting site and a good introduction to the region. I would definitely recommend going on a tour with a knowledgable guide to explain the significance of the ruins and the architecture.
Amazing. Good introduction to what a hike would feel like. Amazing views, huge site and a great place for a picnic

Interesting. The Sacsayhuaman is, in reality, an archaeological complex with different sites. The one they call Sacsayhuaman is the largest one and they say it used to be a fortress, other say it was a religious site. The place is well preserved and is interesting to know more about inca architecture and building skills. But, besides that, there's no information regarding the areas - you need to hire a private guide and, although they're not expensive on site, some of them just made up information, especially because there wasn't an incan written language registering its history. Anyway, it's near Cusco and a nice place, with beautiful views from the city.
Great views. As well as the marvellous Inca ruins where you can see the typical angled Inca stonework, the views over Cusco were fantastic.

Sunset view. Try to get here so you can explore in it the daylight and still enjoy the sun setting over the ruins. Also, do not get rushed. These ruins are incredible and deserve walking, not running, through. Pay close attention to the incredible stones making up the massive walls and foundations.

Expensive - make sure you have nuevo soles!. Didn't realize how expensive admission would be, especially since they tie the admission to either 5 or 3 other sites in a bundle package. We did not have enough soles for entrance but we also didn't want to go back down to Plaza de Armas to exchange money from USD to soles. We then asked our cab driver to drive around the site so we could get a glimpse of Sacsayhuaman from the street - just as good for WAYYYY less!Also note that there were no taxis in the area so you're lucky if you can find someone to drive you back down the mountain.

Review to Sacsaywaman Historic Site. Guide services were excellent, as well as bus service. No negative remarks. This place is for wonderful contemplation of human endeavor in transporting, cutting and placing extra heavy stones on top of each other.

Slide Rock was a highlight. this site is enormous and I could have stayed there for hours. I was amazed by the size of the rocks used to build the walls The guide stated the largest of corner stone rocks we saw was over 60 tons???? The engineering in the days of the Inca civilization to move rocks of that size and reshape them to fit adjoining rocks is mind boggling. every stone had been reshaped to fit perfectly against the adjoining stones. some of the rocks in their natural setting had been reshaped into a slide for recreation....watch out for the sudden stop at the bottom.
Wonderful place to visit. Loved this - a great introduction to the Inca heritage. A huge, open site with great walks and open spaces. Definitely worth a visit while in Cusco.

Wonderful Inca Fortress. This is a fascinating site to see a rather different kind of Inca stonework.The fortified walls are made of blocks of very different sizes and shapes. Some of the larger blocks were said to be over 50 tons in weight. The quarry was only a few hundred metres away, but even so it must have been a considerable challenge to move the blocks to their final place and get them at the right height in the wall. I couldn't even begin to imagine how the complex shapes of the stone blocks were finished so that the blocks connected so tightly together.Sacsayhumuan is very easy to visit if you are staying in Cusco and well worth going with a qualified guide.

Incredible. I was expecting a nice place with big rocks, but the size of the stones the Inkas used to build this fortress is amazing! Do not miss the sacred rock that is slight off the beaten path in the monumental area, next to the big circular structure (a possible water reservoir)
Amazing place. When you look at all those huge stones on top of the mountain, you would think this is incredible. you also get a bird view of the entire cuzco, which is beautiful

must visit!!!. this is one of those places that don't impress you in pictures, but when you visit it personally you end amazed!! it's so impressive what the incas built there, even though today it is just a fraction of what it used to be before the spanish. lot of history in this place. amazing view of the mountains around Cusco

Quite interesting. If you have extra time in Cusco I would recommend going here, if not it's okay to skip it, too. I hiked up to it from Cusco, there were a lot of stairs, but it was an okay walk. Use your pass from the other sites in peru or get one here to use at other sites (~140 soles for adults). Afterword, visit the White Jesus statue nearby.

Impressive ruins reflecting the ancient glory of the Inka realm. Impressive ruins reflecting the ancient glory of the Inka realm. Unfortunately a lot of stones have been used to construct houses and churches but with a bit of imagination you get a good idea about the achievements of the Inka. Furthermore you are rewarded with a beautiful view over Cuzco.

Make sure your guide is not making it up.. I came here with a National Geographic expert, Peter Frost. He told us things about the site in scientific and archaeologically legit manners while some of the Sacsayhuaman guides told weird stories about the site. I heard one of the guides claiming the stones in the fort as 'fossils' as Cusco used to be an 'ocean', while the stones are actually quarried and built by the Incas (obviously!).

Magycal Place. i really like the History of the incas on thata time and i was wondering how amagazine they build a big place like sacsayhuaman ,was so perfectly to see the rocks in perfect together .... i hope to return and see the inti Raymi

too expensive. At a price of USD40 to enter it, it was a little steep, so we walked around the hill via the street and got to the top and could see a little bit of it before being asked to stop walking on the public road. But we hear it is a good event, just pricey.

Easy to get to from Cuzco. Worth a visit. How did the Incas move those stones in position?Great place. Evocative. Apparently the condors ate the carrion of the Spaniards after their first defeat. Rotten the Spaniards, what they did to wonderful PeruWe went as part of a tour and didn't spend long there. couple of sites nearby. You really need to be well informed or get a good guide to take you.

must see. So close to the city. I recommend the hike to the 5 ruins just outside of Cuzco. Take a combi or taxi to the farthest site and walk back into town. Sacsayhuaman is the last stop. But if there's not time for all, this one is impressive and has a great view of the city below.

Must see. We went here after walking from the other ruins near Cusco (Puka Pukara, Q'enko) and this was an amazing finale to our walk. I'd read about this site so it was exciting to see where the Spanish were able to finally topple the nearly year long Inca rebellion; a significant turning point in the efforts to conquer the Incas. The stones are impressive and this fortress would have surely been intimidating to the small number of Spaniards who overtook it. Great view of Cusco as well!

A Must See in Cusco. A friend recommended visiting here, saying it was almost as amazing as Machu Pichu. That's a stretch but I would highly recommend visiting Saksayhuayman. It is mind boggling to imagine how the rocks were placed here. We went with a guide and learned about the grounds having been used for rituals, such as bravery tests for boys transitioning into manhood. Courting ceremonies, etc. Definitely worth a visit.

Stunning. the sheer scale and breath of this building, its site and its history make it a must visit - just marvel at the thought of moving some of the towering blocks of stone with no wheels or large draught animals.
if you are in cusco go to the ruins. you need to visit them to understand the porportions of the rocks used in the ruins.. is amazin... its overcrowded so go early

Loved this place!. I thought this place was amazing. The stones are huge and quite heavy. Our guide told us how they were pulled and pushed up ramps with wooden logs under them then placed on top of the existing layer. Once there they were tilted back using long wooden logs in notches made in the bottom of the rock so it could be shaped to specifically fit that spot then slowly lowered into place. You cannot even fit a piece of paper between these mammoth stones. They are shaped in points jutting out from the central area. My only regret is that I did not have more time to spend here as there was an area across from the stones area to visit as well as above the ground level where we spent a few minutes.

Fabulous - a must see. We enjoyed this site for two reasons. The first is the stunning acheology, and the story about the battle in this area between the Spaniards and the Incas. The way that the Incas were able to move the large tablets, weighing around 200 - 250 tonnes, is amazing. We saw the ramp where they rolled the large stones down from the quarry on the adjacent hill, and then brought them up again. Similarly, the stonework where they fitted these huge stones to closely together and then finished them beautifully. It would have been nice to have also seen a reconstruction of the site in a larger scale. Secondly, our children loved the Llamas that were playing around the site (and some were tethered there), which made it much more appealing to them than simply being ruins. Strongly recommended if you are in Cusco

Amazing. We went here as part of a city tour and our guide said he would take us on a different route to the normal tours. We arrived via a large round reservoir which may have been used as an observatory, then passing this we were met with a fantastic view of Sacsayhuaman. It is huge and as you get closer and realise just how big the stones are and how perfectly the fit together it is so hard to comprehend how it was done. An excellent place to visit, not to be missed.

Worth a trip north of Cusco to see these Inca ruins. This site was part of a Cusco city tour and we enjoyed it. The ruins show the incredible skill of the Inca Empire when it came to stonework. We spent about 45 minutes walking through it with our guide and also visited some of the smaller nearby sites that are part of the archaeological park.
Must see when in Cuzco. Very interesting place to visit. It is amazing how large it is and one can only imagine what it looked like when it was complete. It provides a wonderful view of Cuzco.

Great place to visit. Aka "sexy woman" this is a great place to visit. When you are here lookout for the heaviest limestone rock piece that weights 125 metric tonnes. Try to imagine how the inca's moved this piece here. You also get a great scenic view of Cusco city. The zig zag foundation is also amazing. It's a must visit.
Impressive. It worth the visit! Misterious place... how those rocks were cut? Amazing... You can go walking from the city it is not far away but you must climb the hill...

sacsayhuaman. Fantastic views. We had a great tour guide that told us so much about this place.
If you ever come to cusco just ask for sexy woman and you will be pointed in the right direction.

Great site and close. Had a great time viewing the ruins and amazing stonework. It's nice to be able to walk from the city and not have to take yet bother bus. If you are any kind of athlete you can make it up in 20 min in flip flops. Definitely a must see - would be beautiful at sunset!
Must see. A great representation of the ruins, and if you climb to the top there are wonderful views of the city below.

Awesome. One cannot miss this attraction.
Its the best in Cusco city by far.
One cannot believe how these huge rocks were moved into position.

Closer than MP. These ruins are right in Cusco, up a lengthy staircase. They are really impressive because of the size of the stones that were used to create the structures, and you also get an awesome view of the city from the top. Highly recommended, and if you're not up for a walk, you can also take a collectivo or taxi.

Sacasayhuaman. I did a city tour where the archeological site sacsayhuaman it's included. For this city tour you need to buy the ticket in the ministery of tourism. With this ticket you can visit the sacred Valley also, so it's a good idea to buy.

Kids learned about Inca culture. Phenomenal archaelogical site, went with the family. We loved walking around this site. The size of the stones is impresive. It is a good place to visit with Children as well, an easy walk and easy to understand, a great intro to Inca culture and understanding the magnitude of this civilization.
Impressive ruins only dwarfed by Macchu Pichu. Very impressive local ruins a short taxi ride or walk away. The tour guides are excellent and the views of cusco amazing.

Stone slides were big attraction for the group. Close to Cusco, certainly worth visiting this site. The younger people of the group had lots of fun trying the natural slides. Amazing how those huge stones were used to build this site.

Pleasant but not dramatic. Pleasant walk and unnecessary to have a guide. Give yourself at least an hour but not a lot more. Be sure to add the 3 smaller Inca ruins at the edge of town and you can either walk there from Sacsayhuaman or take a cab there and walk back.
Love the name the best.. It wasa very interesting Inca ruin and loved the llamas. We thought our guide was saying, "sexy woman" so we had a chuckle upon arrival.

Definitely worth the time.... We almost missed this site (1 of 4 sites that are within close range of each other)... So glad we didn't!! It's situated very close to Cusco's main plaza. You can walk/hike there, take a 15 min taxi, or hire a guide at your hotel. Either way, it's definitely worth checking out!!
We loved it here!. My husband and I visited here while in Cusco. Amazing views of the city, and the ruins are just breath taking. A must see!

Walk up from cusco - take the road "choquechaca" to the entrance. We decided to visit the site as it looked really interesting but couldn't find info on the best way to walk from cusco. We asked our hotel concierge who told us to walk straight up choquechaca. It took about 15 mins to walk as it's uphill. The site was really interesting but the highlight for us was taking photos of the llamas and alpacas that we're grazing the area. They were really tame so we got great photos of the llamas with the ruins in the distance. There was also a really friendly sheep that walked straight up to us wanting to be stroked!
A great place to get to know Inca culture. This is a great acheological site where you can see inca's walls and temples. It certainly has to be in your trip schedule.

Inca Magic. This site is an engineering feat. How did they do it? One can only marvel. We had a guide how took us round the site explaining the history and pointing out the various points of interest.

Great ruin to visit. We really enjoyed this site. Our orient express guide, Darwing, took us here. It is really very interesting. You also get the most amazing view of the city of Cusco. I highly recommend a visit to this unique historic site.

So much history!. Don't miss the rock slides - kids had a blast sliding down them. Sacsayhuaman is an impressive ruin as we'd been reading about the demise of the Incas this site had great significance.

Fascinating Place. We visited Sacsayhauman after seeing Machu Picchu, so anything after that does not resonate as well. Nonetheless, the masonry workmanship and precision of the joints between the rocks is spectacular. It's hard to appreciate what this place looked like in the time before Pizarro. There are also great photo opportunities with local color.

Incredible. This place is a great example of the magnificence of the Inka culture. The huge stones and the perfect walls resonate with a spiritual energy that help you understand the philosophy of these people. It also offers a great view of the city of Cusco. Don't miss it while in Cusco.
Breathtaking!. This is one of the best examples of the magnificence of the Inka culture. The huge stones and walls resonate with spiritual energy and mysticism . Don't miss it when you visit Cusco.

get the city tour. my wife and I, get cheaper price, when I ask around in the airport, many people of the tour companies, will tried to get to U to purshed tours, so when I start to ask prices, they start to lower their price or get me more thing to the tour, so I get the city tour that start in the afternoon, por about 4-5 hr, and take to te ruins out of cusco like sacsayhuaman, and other include the localguide for about 20 dol each, extra is the tourist tiket to get to all the ruins (save U money), be careful of the peruvian indians, the tried to sell U sweters saying that is alpaca and is acrilic, for the same price of course,

Feel like I am going back in history. Arrived early in the morning. The site is really very well preserved considering the number of visitors that come here. If you are a photographer, you will love all the possibilities of creating the perfect shot. You get great views of Cusco as well.

Really Impressive Ruins. This place was pretty amazing - not only are there Incan ruins, but pre-Incan ruins right next to it if you know to look. If you go on your own, make sure to arrange to have the cab come back for you at some point - or you can walk down the cobblestone Incan path back to town if you know how to find it - or have some random "tour guide" offer to show you it like I did. Kind of an interesting experience!

Really big stones. The revolving joke in Cusco is that Saqsayhuaman should be pronounced more or less as sexywoman. It still sounded a bit different to my ears.It is easy to reach by taxi from the Plaza de Armas, the going rate is 10 soles for a single ride. You need to have a Boleto Turistico which can be bought at Saqsayhuaman itself for 130 soles (we did). Or pay the entrance fee which was about half of the price of the Boleto. Definitely worth a visit for the views over Cusco and the really big stones.

Fascinating. My husband and I chose to take a taxi to Tambomachay and then walk the ruins circuit and back to Cusco, so this was our last stop on the way. It turned out to be a great finish to the circuit. The largest of the four, the masonry is really impressive. There are 15-20 foot high stones that fit precisely and perfectly into each other. Loved it.

Shoulda spent more time :(. We visited Sacsayhuaman as part of a 1/2 day p.m. organized tour and wish we'd spent more time here--not sure about greater than 3-4 hours, I'd plan at least two for waltzing around. Although the tour was helpful both from an informational and logistical (transportation) perspective, we only spent about 1hr here and a straight-thru line, not getting the chance to diverge from the main open areas into nooks and crannies. Not as impressive at MP for sure but the size of the stones still makes you scratch your head as to how the ruins were built, proximity to town is an asset, and it's not nearly as crowded as it may appear in pics given its large size. Buy 'multiple entry' tickets for the local ruins rather than at each site--save Soles for eats. For those who are gonna hike walk there, do acclimate at least a day first--ain't NO easy climbs in this town for us sea-levelers but it's just a lungs/heart thing, not other physical danger. Watch out for llama crossings :)
Amazing construction feat. Very interesting to see how the Incas made each stone fit so perfectly. Some were huge, and makes one wonder how they moved these huge rocks from the quarries to this site.
Inca ruins. Sacsayhuaman are huge inca ruins on the outskirts of Cusco, go on a city tour bus or taxi, need boleto turistico to enter. Amazing place, Inti raymi festival is held here in June

Excellent views. Excellent views, interesting history. We walked up to the ruins from Plaza de Armas (note: we are from colorado and live at 7000 feet, and are in pretty good shape). Ignore people trying to sell you a tour on horseback. Take a cab inbetween ruins, shouldn't cost more than a few Soles.

Game center!. Do not forget to slide from the rocks, investigate deep tunnels and play with llamas which were plenty there. Best to climb from Cusco downtown using the stone stair. Overall it takes about 30mins same as if you go by taxi as it has to navigate many side roads before getting into there.
Fortress. This was an excellent experience. With the benefit of a guide, we wandered around this site learning about it's history. The stonework is incredible. Definitely worth a visit.

Sexy Woman!. This site is full of rich culture and history. The largest stone used in the structure is 128 tons! Be sure to bring your camera, sunscreen, and hat. Definitely hike up the terraces to take in the phenomenal view!

Close to Cusco. Great afternoon, impressive ruins. I walked back to Cusco in about 1/2 hr, I would not recommend walking up to it if you are not acclimatized, it's rough going. I got half way up and decided to take up a couple of locals on an offer or a horseback tour of the plateau.

Just Incredible. Many people look at Saqsayhuaman as a place of many rocks, and don't get it! This place has a lot of rocks, sure, but has some of the most ingenious architecture (all rock!) that I ave ever seen. Some of these foundation rocks are over 90 tons, and have been strategically placed to hold up these ruins for centuries. The entire site is amazing. Get a guide so as not to miss anything in this marvelous area.

Amazing sights over Cusco. In my last day in Cusco I was so tired to go anywhere else so I took a hostel mate and went up the hill to this amazing place that I cannot remember and say the name :)) The ticket I must say was little expensive but the views were absolutely gorgeous.First you have an areal over the city of Cusco (see pictures) which blows your mind away O.oBesides there are ruins to visit and huge stones where the Pre-Inca civilization used to hide when the Incas came to conquer the lands. I suggest go want on the stones, hide around and make it an adventure, the feeling is amazing.The Temple of the Sun hides a little bit further and can be reached either walking either horse riding (what we did for one hour) When you enter the stony cave a sacrifice rock is placed in the middle of the place, the stone where animals were sacrificed as offering to God.One of the most lovely things to see up there are the cute fluffy llamas and alpacas. I just could not get my hands of them. Consequence? I want one home now :)))Ride the horse on the hills, visit the local shop that lives there since ages and go more up with a bus to have even a higher view over Cusco (which we did not have anymore energy to do it)Drink coca leave tea before and have some coca candies with you in case of high altitude sickness. I did not have any problems but my companion did :)A perfect day out in the heart of Cusco!

Impressive. It is awesome to think of how ancient people could have moved these huge boulders into place here to form these ruins. They were setting up for the festival that happens on June 21 so the only downfall was that there were chairs in some of the pictures but not much could be done about that.

Impressive fortress. The construction of the successive walls are amazing! Very impressive, and more so, the closer you walk up to them. Large open green area next to the ruins where alpaca and llama graze. It is mind boggling to ponder how these huge stones were moved many centuries ago!

Sacsayhuaman Day Trip from Cusco. We spent the day here. It costs a bit per person to visit but you can use the same ticket for 10 days at places like Pisac and Ollantaytambo ruins also. We took a taxi from near plaza de armas and it was 10 soles to get 3 people to the ruins. There is a path that you can walk back to the plaza de armas (I think it took about 20 mins but all downhill, so not very strenuous)The ruins are interesting and there are several areas to look around here. You could spend a good part of a day here easily. We all enjoyed this as it was part of our "taking it easy while we aclimate" plan. Its a good leadup for the other ruins which get more spectacular, in my opinion.Take water (and any food you want) with you.
Great learning experience about the Inca Empire. Walk up to Sacsayhuaman from Cusco - it gets you ready for your trek or walk up to Machu Picchu & the views/experience are incredible.

Interesting. We took the sighting seeing bus from the square and arrived at what we thought was The Sexy Women. A small version of Christ Redeemer stands at the top of the hill over looking the town of Cusco. terracotta roof tops and green hills in the background. awesome views and great photo opportunities. take a little walk down the hill to see the amazingly built stone walls of the fortress. Don't forget to take small change for photos with an alpaca and locally dressed men.

If you can't get to Machu Picchu, this is it.. If you can't get to Machu Picchu, you need to come to this place. The zigzag that's supposed to be the puma's teeth is pretty cool. You will be amazed again by all those gigantic rock construction.
Amazing. Don't go on a tour take a hike from your hotel and explore it yourself. The views at night are astounding!

great site, and not far from cuzco. use the bathroom before entering.some sort of guide or guidebook is useful.very interesting and different from other ruins....just a couple hours is good here; save MUCH more time for machu picchu.climb the ruins on the left after walking about halfway - nice views.there is a 'rock slide' around the back of that.... can sit and slide down the rock.
Good ruins near Cusco. These ruins are interesting, but after Machu Picchu we probably could have skipped these. Good views of Cusco from the top, though.
Also spelled Sagsaywaman so don't be fooled. A great site to visit on a fine day as there s no shelter if it rains (which it does quite often here!) Another impressive example of inca engineering.
Nice Ruins ... But Not The Best in Peru. We enjoyed our visit to Sacsayhuaman, but the ruins didn't compare to the ruins in Ollantaytambo or Machu Picchu.

Group travel. Computer images do not do this justice. A real "must see" when visiting Peru. Unfortunately, our tour got us there late in the day so hiking was dicey and short. This was just after the Inti Raymi celebrations. The good point was the panoramic views and amazing stone work..
Inti Raymi. We where there during Inti Raymi so it was really crowded, however the place is worth while walking to from Cusco (much closer than expected)

Great Views of Cusco. I was on a day long tour that included a visit to Sacsayhuaman. It was nice. There was a ton of climbing and I was still adjusting to altitude sickness. One bad thing did happen. We were led through a completely dark cave, you are in there a total of 3 minutes. While in there my camera bag spilled open. I was able to retrieve my camera in the complete darkness. However, when I got out of the cave I realized that my $50 camera battery had fallen out. There were dozens of people behind me so I couldn't go back and retrieve it, very frustrating.I don't know how much I paid for this attraction because my tickets were lumped into a package. It was ok, just the week before the festival of the sun had taken place at this exact site.

A view from Cristo Blanco. Saqsaywaman is pretty expensive at 70 soles a person. However, it is possible to get a pretty good view from the statue of Christ - Cristo Blanco - just to the right of the ruins. We got to Cristo Blanco by taking the flight of stairs on the right at the end of Tandapata. At the top of the stairs there are steps cut into the soil. Head up to the white taupalin, cross that and continue up the path. The hedges get pretty close to the path and it´s pretty steep but only takes about 5 minutes. When we got to the top we arrived at a road and there were lots of vehicles parked at the top - so if you can find the road it might be an easier walk up - or it would be possible to get a taxi... Cristo Blanco is fairly impressive, although there is wire 6ft up from the floor. The views of Cusco are spectuacular and you can see Saqsaywaman clearly too. So you miss the history of Saqsaywaman this way, but if you´re happy to read about it before or afterwards, this way will save you 70 soles...

Roaming Llamas. My children were very excited about all the timing llamas. My husband and I were more impressed with the architecture. Unfortunately, there was a taxi strike the day we decided to visit. So we walked up hill with our 7 &9 year old. It was definitely a challenging climb, but we were rewarded with an amazing view of Cusco and amazing ruins. Watch out for the salesman trying to sell you horse rides, they were very persistent. Other than that the ladies with the llamas accepted our s/.6 for a picture, without asking for more.
How did they do it?. The size of this Inca site and the size or the rocks that are fitted together is amazing. What went into building this site and how the Inca's used it is something to ponder.

Stunning Incan ruins.. Loved this archeological site. I was only sorry that it was the last stop of a long day so we didn't spend as much time wandering around as we should have. The views to Cusco are amazing.

Perfect precursor to Machu Picchu. Sacsayhuaman is the perfect way to get started in Cusco and the Sacred Valley before you trek to MP. It gives you a first glimpse into how amazing the Incans really are. The ruins are just outside of town. It's an easy climb as you get acclimated to the higher altitudes in Cusco region. Rest up in the morning before you go. Drink lots of coca tea. Lots of guides are available and you will make the most of your time there with a small group tour of the area. June 24 is Cusco Anniversary and there are huge performances there that day. Beautiful view of Cusco city from the top.

Interesting place, great view!. I did all four inca ruins around cusco, and of course Sacsayhuaman (or Sacsaywaman) is by far the most impressive. If you only have to time to see the 1 when you're in Cusco then make sure to see it. If you can spend the say then see all four. They are all pretty interesting!

Wonderful contrast. The massive boulders that make up this archaeological site are worth viewing, but be sure to have a guidebook or guide to put them in context for you. Have your photo taken in the giant stone doorway and look for llamas. Then hike up the hill (in March there were flowers everywhere) for awesome views of Cusco
Awesome place. Really cold in June but a must for any traveller. To get to it you book a 'city tour' through the thousands of travel agencies there are available. Long long day.

Not just another Incan ruin. You must have a very good guide, or a very good guidebook to truly appreciate the magnitude of history and archeological military ruins of this place. We visited several other Incan ruins, including the fabulous Machu Picchu, before we came here, and I thought this was an interesting choice for the last place to visit when it comes to Incan history. Both the magnificent and the tragic can be viewed in these enormous granite stones.

A challenge on our first day in the Andes. Having a difficult time with the altitude of the Andes we were quite intimidated by the climb we saw ahead of us. The arduous climb to the top afforded us a great view of the village and valley spread out below us. The craftsmanship of the Inka civilization continued to amaze us. Well worth the climb.
Sacsayhuaman. All of these ruins are quite amazing. It is hard to fathom how anyone could build such perfect structures.

Read about it. Another spectacular site built with gigantic granite stones shaped and fit together perfectly. It is also the head of the Puma and look for the eye of the puma on top of one hill. It almost stopped the Spanish cavalry; it was a store house for many products including food and weaponry, none of which could match the Spanish cavalry nor the swords made of Toledo steel which cut through the thin inca cloth armor like butter. Read "last days of the Incas" by Kim MacQuarrie before you go.

A must in Cusco. Very interesting site. The size of the stones is amazing, and the structure is incledible. It is also a very fun site for childrens, which looks like a natural attraction park. I think it is a must to visit in Cusco, in single, family or group.

Worth a Visit. We visited this site as part of a day tour from Cusco. Of all the sites, this one is one fo the best around the Cusco area. The walls are enormous and the work that went into creating them must have been incredible. Definitely worth a visit when in Cusco. Just ask to tour "sexy woman" and they will know what you mean.

Fascinating. I visited the site a few weeks ago and found it fascinating. It was not crowded at all when we were there and we were able to take pictures of everyone by the gigantic key stone. Consider a guide to learn the most! Walk fast from the parking lot unless you want to buy someting (-:

Impressive. We saw this without a guide, having bought a 1day ticket for Tambomachay, pukapukara, Quenco and Sacsayhuaman. They're all easily accessible by bus from Cusco (2 sol) or if you're feeling more adventurous, squeeze yourself onto a "Huerto" minibus for 1 sol.The site is simply impressive. Give yourselves at least an hour (preferably two) to explore the different parts of site. If you don't have a guide, take a guide book with you because there's a lot of interesting background info to learn.Once you're done make sure you take 10mins to do the short walk to Christo Blanco to take a few more photos and enjoy the view back down to Cisco.

Rainy but still astounding. We got a little unlucky on the day in which we toured these ruins, and the vendors selling rain ponchos were making a killing! However, our tour guide brought us back later that day when it had stopped raining, and the ruins looked very spectacular at dusk, with a rainbow in the distance. I would definitely say to go here before Machupicchu, because everything else pales in comparison to that unbelievable sight.

Fabulous, but very crowded. We loved our trip up to see Sacsayhuaman. I didn't know what to expect, but my husband told me all he knew about it. There were loads of people there, and the weather was great, so everyone was enjoying it. I was disappointed that so many of the trails were closed for rehab, but I am sure that is necessary with so many people coming there all the time. We went up the other side from the main "field" and had some beautiful views with no other people there.

Dark, Dark Cave. I was taken to "sexy woman," as it is called, by a man from the Cusco based South American Explorer´s Club. Sexy woman is a Peruvian archeological site, which we should have paid money to enter, but being so late in the day we just skated on in. We spent most of the time negotiating tight passages through rocks. Our guide Scott led us through this cave, which was totally dark (by this time it was almost 6pm). The surrounding hills were burning a bright orange in the dying light of yet another day. It was a magical experience.

Cooler than you thought. You should go to this place. We went in the morning. We took a cab there and walked back to the plaza de las armas. You could walk ther and back, but only if you love walking up steep hills. Walking back was painless and enjoyable. The site itself is beautiful and impressive. The stones are much bigger than macchu pichu. There are also other ruins nearby. Don't be afraid to walk back to town. It's not that far, and the scenery is nice. I will go back next time I'm in Cusco.

Huge and Beuatiful. The size of that perfect stones is just unbelievable. Place with lots of history, where you can see the inteligence of Inka people and how everything was just perfect, even in that time. As usual, amazing and beautiful landscapes!
great. great place to see history.... im typing more because trip advisor wont let me post with out 50 characters
Amazing. Such an amazing beauty and so underrated. We spent just over and hour here with fantastic views of cusco. We went here as part of our half day tour. Really recommended it,

Fascinating Building!!!!!!!!!!. The Sacsayhuaman the real Temple of the inkas it shows the building used with the bigest stones that I never seen.
I can not understand how the Inkas built this place.
Theresita.
Monaco

An amazing Inca site!. Just outside of Cusco lies this incredible jewel of the past, Sacsauhuaman! Gigantic boulders cut perfectly to fit together to form a zigzag wall reminding us of a massive lightning bolt. A beautiful lookout to Cusco beacons. Don't miss the head of the Puma, Sacsayhuaman!!
Amazing huge stones.. It is a site one should not miss if visits Cusco. The stone mason of Inca is stunning. Inca has too many wonderful things got buried or lost.

Impressive. Definitely worth a visit. We caught a taxi up and then walked back. I agree with other reviews that without a map of the sit or guide you could miss parts of the site. The large stones were very impressive and I also liked the view of Cusco from the lookout.

City Tour. We visited Sacsayhuaman as part of the city tour. It was a nice way to spend some time as we weere getting acclimated to the altitude. It is a very large fortress, and you are not given sufficient time on the city tours to truly explore it.

Definitely worth it!. This ranks second to Machu Picchu but still should not be missed. A very tranquil and peaceful spot with delightful breezes.....you find yourself wondering how on earth they moved those huge stones without modern machinery.....
Worth the hike. We hiked up here from Cuzco and it was totally worth it. Very peaceful and spectacular views of the entire city and valley.

Amazing place. What an amazing place - just blows your mind that the Incas could move giant stones, cut and polish them and then create a temple/fortress out of them. We almost missed it due to time pressure but were glad to have made it. We were two families with 4 kids and they really enjoyed going through the ancient tunnels and sliding down the smooth rock slides.
I expected a little more. The place is fine, the ruins are really well preserved but having seen Machu Picchu and Ollaytantambo, the place is not as much impressive. You should start with it.

The big stones are the best part of this site.. We saw Sacasyhuaman AFTER seeing Ollantaytambo, Pisac, and Machu Picchu. The standout feature of Sacasyhuaman is the large stones. We took a cab up (10 soles) and walked down as we were burnt out from all the hiking we did the day before at MP. I was disappointed that they didn't provide a map of the site when you checked in. We felt they wanted you to hire a guide. Without a map, we almost missed two areas that are on either side of the main area. Remember to ALWAYS take some toilet paper with you as almost every bano that we used outside of a hotel or restaurant did not have any!

If just 1 ruin outside of Machu Picchu...this is it!. If you could just visit ONE ruin besides Machu Picchu, this is the one. Walking around and climbing around - you see the massive stones that fit so perfectly - there was no need for mortar and had the Spaniards not conquered Cusco, these massive amazing temples will still remain - snake at the bottom, puma in the middle and condor at the top.There is a wonderful vista from the top of the city and you can spy the Santa Domingo Cathedral below as well as various other landmarks.Beautiful and breathtaking - amazing when you think of how they were able to build it. Oh, cute llamas roam around too.Worth a visit for sure!

rivals Machu Picchu. I was lucky to visit this site before other visitors...quiet, beyond impressive rock arrangement, grand design. Too bad the Spaniards destroyed 60 per cent of the site but still beyond impressive.
Awesome ruins. Huge rocks that fit together like legos. An awesome story to go with the fall of the fortress as well. A must see in Cusco.
unexpected. The boleto touristico is worth it. A difficult hike if you're from sea level but not un-doable. Amazing ruins to see and walk around.

Fantastic. Go here before Machu Picchu.I went as a part of an organised tour, although we only saw the outside rather than climb to the top, I was left feeling suitably impressed. How did they move the stones there?!We all have our ideas but even the guides are stuck for a real conclusion.Beautiful vistas to be had, get there early as it for pretty busy, pretty quick.

Worth a visit - prepare to walk.. Sacsayhuaman (pronounced sort-of like SACK-say-WU-man) is a very extensive set of ruins up above the city of Cusco. It was the first place we visited when we got to the city.Tip: wear sunscreen. We were there at the end of the rainy season during the South American summer. Even though we were wearing long sleeves, pants, and hats, I managed to get sunburned badly ON MY HANDS. It didn't even occur to me that they were the only part of my body not protected and, due to the altitude, I got burned. Ouch.The ruins here have some amazing examples of Incan stonework. Huge boulders fit together as if with mortar, but with no mortar! Also, you get a great view of Cusco from the site, perfect for a "look where we are" photo.The best way to explore Sacsayhuaman is, in my opinion, with a guide. If you have the money, there are always guides available for hire there. The one we hired was quite a good English speaker and well worth the money; he was able to explain a lot of the features and history of the site and we learned much more than if we were just reading a brochure.Tip: There is a pass/ticket that you can buy here that is a combo-type ticket for a number of sites within Cusco (several of the museums included) and in the Sacred Valley. If you are going to be doing a lot of sightseeing in these areas, you should check it out as it is a time- and money-saver.

Go fo Inti Raymi!. We were fortunate enough to be here for the annual Festival of the Sun. A very spectacular and colorful festival with thousands of spectators. It is a reenactment of the ancient festival and we loved it. If you can go in June, go for Inti Raymi.

Ruins just outside of Cusco. Nice ruin just outside of the city of Cusco. If you can manage the climb up to the top of the ruins and bluff, there are great views of the city - including the Plaza de Armas. Very impressive but go with a guide since there are no signs around the ruins. Great example of Incan construction.

Zig zags and motifs. I like the big field, the remnants of the zig zags of the ruins and the fact one can see many motifs surrounding these ruins!!! It is a pity that one can't see more due to the destruction of this site many many many years ago
interesting place. Great example of Incan construction. Great photo opportunities from this location. Lots of other tourists on the city tours.

Extraordinary Archaeological Site. I visited this site on my first day in Cusco, which can be exhausting when you are still in the process to get used to the altitude. To enjoy it at its fullest, I would recommend to leave this visit for the second day or even after coming back from Machu Picchu. Nevertheless, I had a wonderful time and learned enough to understand much better what happened in Cusco during the colonial times.
Cusco Highlights. The ruins are very impressive. It was helpful having a guide to provide details to what we were seeing. It is fascinating to see and hear of the Inca's engineering prowess.

Get there late. Just as so many others have stated, each and every Incan site that we visited in Peru, was fantastic. We had the great fortune of visiting while overcast with thunder rumbling through the valley.

Inca ruins and terraces. Enjoyed seeing the surviving history of the Inca's in the Sacred Valley. Not far from Cusco and can be seen as part of a tour including other nearby sites. Liked the lama lawn mowers too!
Awe inspiring. Made me realize what a high civilization the Incas had before the Spanish destroyed it. Incredible achievement of architectural precision and ingenuity.
Big stones!. It is interesting to see the layout of the site and there are great views over Cusco from the viewing point. Just how did they move the very largest stones? Toilets rather smelly.

Breathtaking. These ruins were more incredible that I expected. My husband and I went with a City Tour via Llama Path while we were staying in Cusco. It is a must see in this area. Absolutely breathtaking! The size of this ancient ruin and the individual stones is incredible. Our guide did an amazing job with educating us in the architecture and history behind the ruin, Incas, and Quechuas.

Peaceful spot. This is a beautiful place high above the city of Cusco and well worth a visit. Here you can get a feel for Incan architecture and learn more about the history of this amazing people. It is great to have a guide with you who can explain all that you are seeing and how the building was done. But it is also good to have some time to roam on your own, since there is a lot to see, and tour guide lectures seem to keep you in one place. We took a bus up with a tour but there is also a trail you can take from the city, if you feel like a hike. Don't miss this site if you are in Cusco.

Peru's answer to Stonehenge. Remarkable!!! Massive and dramatic. Should not be missed. This is a very large space and you can walk all over and climb paths for better views. It takes your breath away.

Could have stayed longer. A very interesting inca site. Felt a little rushed by our tour guide and would have liked to stay longer. The inca construction is amazing. Well worth a visit if you are interested in inca history.

Amazing stonework. Such large stones at this Inca fortress. So difficult to imagine them being pulled from miles away, and the way they fit so precisely together is almost inconceivable. Definitely worth seeing. We went with the City Tour, and it was combined with Qoricancha and the cathedral.

How did they move those stones. The stone work at Sacsayhuaman is amazing. Some of the larger stones are cut very precisely. It must have been amazing to see these huge stones, some weighing more than 100 tons, being moved. This is a must see during any trip to Cusco
Trip to Cusco and Machu Picchu - Beautiful Hotel and Tours. This was the first ruins that we visited when we got to Cusco. The guide was really helpful and the view impresive.
Very Cool!. We had a great tour guide so it was great to learn all the history. Still perplexed at how the Inca's got all the rocks to fit together so perfectly!

Amazing Site. This is an amazing sight to behold. The largest stone is 128 tons! We didn't have as much time to explore since we were with a group tour, so I actually recommend doing this on your own. Also bring a coat/rain jacket. It was a beautiful, hot, sunny day but we didn't realize how much colder it would be up above the city. It also started to rain and hail on us which had us returning quickly to the tour bus.
One of the best places to visit. It is along with MachuPichu, one of the best places to visit in El Cusco, it is just beside the Cristo Blanco, the hieghest point to see El Cusco

very close to Cusco, worth a stop. This is an important Incan site, and definitely worth reading about before you stop to see it. We saw it as our last stop when being driven from Urubamba to Cusco. There is a large grassy area and I think that some groups picnic near the ruins. There are also horseback tours. It was very busy when we were there. The entry fee is part of the boleto turistico that you will need for quite a few sites. Seeing the large boulders that had been worked over by the stone-cutters to fit so securely was amazing.

' sexay woman'. Our first view on arriving in Cusco was to see 'sexy woman' as they pronounce it here. That gets a laugh from everyone who is still breathing normally after the hike upwards to see the way the Incas built walls with nothing in-between the large boulders. Beware the altitude when you first arrive. If you have a guide that sprints off walk slowly after them or else you may pay the price.A fascinating site. One of a vast amount in this incredible area.

Impressive. Ticket is part of the Tourist Ticket and well worth seeing. You can take your timing walking around the area. If you feel like it you can do some climbing, With the altitude we stayed on the level. The view of the city is lovely

Stroll through history. Up at the top of the hill overlooking Cuzco, we were treated to a lesson in history. The ancient people who built Sacsayhuaman built it to celebrate their religious beliefs and to dazzle any who saw it. A short time after it was built the Spanish came and conquered them. And then forced them to dismantle it, blow up its walls and rocks, and send them down to build other things in Cuzco. How bitter this must have been. The remnants that are there hint at past glories.

nice afternoon trip. go it alone not with a tour as you will prbably only spend like 30 mins there, we spent 2 hours had a picnic surrounded by some llamas with the sun shining. the ruins are the best in cusco some of the stones are huge. also gives great views of cusco.

A great place with a great view. We spent about an hour at Sacsayhuamen as part of our half day tour of Cuzco. It was our first taste of Inca architecture and we were impressed by the scale. Access was easy and the climb up to the highest point was well worth it in order to enjoy the beautiful view over the city of Cuzco.

Serenity. After seeing a host of other Inka wonders one might think some rocks, big deal, if so you would be wrong. This place is serene.As we walked the site there was a sense of peace. May sound kookie, but multiple people commented on it.The amazing feat of what was done, when, and with such precision had us awestruck.

Sacsayhuaman!. The general description in this site of what Sacsayhuaman is as a MILITARY FROTRESS. But, it isn't so. It was called a military fortress by the Spaniards whom had no idea of what they're looking at much less of what the building was all about. Sacsayhuaman was and still is an archeological wonder, the summit of architectural skills of the Inkas. They knew how to maneuver nature to their advantage. Sacsayhuaman was a very important complex that housed storage compartments where they kept provisions for the people in times of extreme necessities as it was also a religious ceremonial center. In the chronicles of one the first writers honoring the Inkas who's writings were forbidding by the "Holy Inquisition" - Pedro Cieza de Leon... with sadness and regret explains the beauty of what he had seen and the destruction he was being a witness too.. Sacsayhuaman as he tells it was the most grandiose sacred religious site where most of the year around great Inka ceremonies were performed and where the Inkas kept the most important momies and deities represented by them in gold, silver and precious stones. These treasures were ransacked by the Catholic Church titled them as demonic along with the greediest of Human kind back in those days the SPANIARDS.. When you visit the site you can still see the foundation of the round tower in the center of one of the sides of the fortresses stand. Here was where they kept the momies this tower was tall - high and stand over the entire complex... After it's destruction the stones were used to build the Catholic Churchs that now stand still around the entire city of Cusco. Since the last battle of rebelion fought by Tupac Amaru ll the last Inka whom almost won back the Inka Empire from the Spaniards but lost it to a treason, keptured, tortured and killed dismembered in the Plaza Mayor of Cusco - Wacaypata... Spain ruled free abolishing the citizenship of the Tawantinsuyo Inka people took away not only the land, it's riches but dehumanized them as well. The Catholic Church proclaim that these people weren't worth going to the kingdom of God because they were evil. Tupac Amaru ll was the last breath of freedom of the INKA EMPIRE... The TAWANTINSUYO it's RELIGIOUS CAPITAL CUSCO - Q'OSQO. (It means the center).

Sexy woman as the locals call it - and very attractive it is too.. The quality of the stonework and scale of the complex makes it a must see. Very sad to see that the conquistadors, as usual, destroyed what must have been a great temple to force their own religion on the people. What remains is still impressive. The story of this structure as a symbol of (unsuccessful) revolt against the Spanish is also very interesting if sad.

Don't miss it. Visit all 4 sites.. Take a cab from Cusco to the top of the 4 or 5 Inca sites above Cusco (15 soles) - I can't remember the name of the top one but they'll tell you. Walk between the top two. Eat a picnic at the second. Catch a local bus by the side of the road (2 soles) to Sacsayhuaman. It's really cool. Walk all around. If you leave early enough in the day, you can walk a giant stairway back to Cusco. If it's late, take a taxi down (8 to 10 soles). Great place for kids to run around, play hide and seek.

Lots of steps, but worth it!. We were traveling with G Adventures and had the most incredible guide for this attraction, a professor at the University named Adelke Palomino. He is an Incan expert, having studied the culture for 40 years. Sacsayhuaman (sexy woman) is a fine example of Incan stonework, a fortress city above modern day Cusco. Fantastic views from the top. A huge grassy area with patient llamas to welcome you. Really a beautiful day!

Sexywoman.... Must see in Cuzco, high altitude and preparing one for Machu Picchu. Informative tour guide explained the full history of the park and gave relevance to Pachamama. Great day at the park. I recommend.
You have to see it. A very popular spot due to proximity to Cusco. The stones are amazing and the path will take you to a bird's eye view of Cusco.

Awe inspiring. We visited this archeological site today and thoroughly enjoyed our visit. It used to be the site of an Inca temple although much of it was destroyed after the Conquistadores dismantled much of it by using the large (and very heavy) stones to build their churches after the Incan conquest. We were there on a beautiful day with blue skies and puffy white clouds which added to it's charm. We marveled at how these boulders were cut with such incredible precision, carted from quarries over many miles and then reassempled without any mortar and put into perfect position. They truly must have been a very advanced civilization - perhaps more than our own!

Magnificent view of Cusco. I walked to the top on my first day, which was a bit of a challenge due to the altitude. However the view of Cusco was stunning. I also got to see some Llamas roaming the hills.I did not pay to go see the temple portion of the area. I thought the price was too steep and got a better view from across the way.

Wonderfull place. We arrived and we loved the city view from this place. You can see a good part of Cusco... it is simply beautiful. The ground is so green and there were some alpacas to take great pictures. The stone structure was awesome... the guide gave us the explanation but was hard to pay attention with all those big stones in front of you. The place is to high so I recomend take some coca te or coca candies. Excelent place that have to be in your itinerary.
beautiful!. While in Cusco, do not miss this. Views are gorgeous We were with our private guide, so we had our own tour. Areas are well-marked for tourists on their own.

The is more to Peru than Machu Picchu!. Reading some of the reports on here about this place was so disappointing, you can marvel at the massive boulders and how they were moves, and placed in such symetrical and straight lines, some of the nicest terraces we saw in Peru, and the stunning scenery, if all you go to Peru for is to see Machu Picchu, you are going to be pleasantly surprised, there is equally great attractions, and this is one of them.
not worth the money. paying 26usd entrance fee is way too expensive. it's just another place where they ripp-off tourists and benefit from the "Machu Picchu"-hype

more old stones. Not worth the price if you are visiting Maccu Pichu anyway, its more of the same and the entry fees are crazy - but the walk up is nice, even if we didn't see any other walkers, just dozens of tourist buses. Overpricing is ruining the 'Sacred Valley' experience....the only thing sacred here now seems to be the God of Mammon.
fascinating Inca site. You can walk up to this site along a beautiful stream to see stunning examples of Inca building techniques and get great views over the whole of the Cusco valley

Unexpected treasure. I'd been on a previous trip and it was nothing special.This time I took a friend to the Blanco Christo as he didn't have time for all of the tourist things. We ended up getting the ticket for Sacsayhuaman (which for s/70 can be pricey but worth it)the ruins are neat but a lot like others. However most people really miss out by not exploring the entire park. We walked around, hiked over walks, saw the Inka slides, and spent a good five hours there.Take some wine and a snack and enjoy your day in a far more quiet and peaceful setting. You'll likely be alone!
A place to visit allways!!!. The most energetic place in Cusco.....It is a must to visit....Even though the "solar clock" is closed for public visits......it is a must to go!!!

Must see of Cusco. Give yourself half a day for this if at all possible. The architecture is stunning and the area to explore is quite large.
