I recommend a guided tour and if I had a chance to do it again, would have taken the offer from a guide to do it on horseback (make sure your guide can speak your language, or make sure you understand enough Spanish). There is a wealth of history, beauty, wonder, and amazing views.

Largest stones of all the ruins. This site is perched above Cuzco and provides some fantastic panoramic views of the city. Although you can technically walk to it from downtown, I suggest taking a taxi for 5-10 soles, as it is a very long walk. This site was the only one where we did not have a guide, as I was hoping there would be one at the entrance for hire- but there was not. While there we saw a small heard of alpaca, which was a fun to see. The stones used in the site are the largest we had seen amongst all of our ruins visits. While there, we took the short walk over to the Jesus Christ statue that looks over the city. Overall, I think I would have enjoyed the site a little more with a guide.

Amazing Inca site. One of the first Inca sites that I visit was Sacsayhuaman.You need a Boleto Turistico for admission.It's a big site and to fully see and enjoy it, at least three hours. I was on a big tour so my time was limited.The site was impressive and shows the large scope that the Inca use.
a lovely old Inca site. Interesting Inca stonework structures, uncrowded, excellent views of Cusco, a great place for a leisurely wander.

Walk up from Cusco !!. We walked up to Sacsayhuaman from Cusco one one of the days we were acclimatising before we trekked the Inca trail. It is really worth a visit to the site, due to large size and carving of the rocks to build the main walls, and to see the vertical 'slipper dip' limestones. It was a steep walk up via San Cristobal but good to get away from the tourists and hawkers for a while! Note that it was cash only to get in ...

Part of the Cusco day tour. Highly recommended to do the day tour which includes Sacsayhuaman, Coricancha etc. You reach an altitude of 4000 metres above sea level on this tour. Interesting and well worth the visit.

Interesting if you are in Cusco.. We had a fairly short visit with our tour group on our return to Cusco from the Sacred Valley. Our tour guide made the visit interesting. It's such a mystery of how this was built! As we did, it's a good stop along the way, just to see it and marvel at how the enormous stones are placed and to speculate on the meaning if this site. There are also great views of Cusco from this height.

How they did it???. Rock weighing thousands of tons that fit perfectly one on top of the other. No cranes, no machines, no grinders, no tools, .... How did they build this temple? You have to see it. You have to feel it. You have to visit it.

You will not believe what you see. Some people may think this is made by extraterrestrial beings. I do not know but I am sure that with all the technology we have today we would not be able to build it yet.

"Sexy Women" as they call it. Sacsayhuaman is a beautiful place to visit. From its pinnacle, you have a great panoramic view of the Cusco valley.
Tour guides jokingly refer to it a sexy woman" although it is a truly meditative and religous Inca site.
Great Ruins to visit in Cuzco. We loved this set of Ruins, the walls were massive and teh views of Cuzco were great. It helped inform us on the significance of Cusco in the Inca Empire
Amazing. Is an awesome place we loved to walk thru those ancient contructions and listened about its history. Surely i will return there again.

Worth a visit. This site may not be as amazing as some of the others throughout Peru, but worth visiting if you have time in Cusco. We walked from the historic part of Cusco which took some time, but was an adventure in itself. If you are in good physical condition and won't mind the climb, there are plenty of things to stop and see/do on the way. Otherwise it would just be a short cab ride. The ruins are interesting because of how extremely large the stones are. Moving and carving these ginormous objects seems unimaginable. There are also excellent birds eye views of Cusco from the top. We actually planned the rest of our route for the day from the resting point at the peak. There were also many llamas/alpacas in and around the site, which is fun for everyone!We didn't find the (more expensive) tourist ticket necessary, we purchased the tickets for $15 a piece, which also includes 2 other nearby ruins. It didn't seem like many people knew about this option. There are guides for hire on site. We chose to go it alone, but I'm sure they are willing to strike deals for their services. There are restroom facilities available, but bring some tissues or your own toilet paper! (Do this for all of Peru!)

Saqsayhuaman..... when you visit Sacasayhuaman, please go and ride a horse up to the Zone X, Moon Temple, Sun Temple,Qenqo...and many other incredible ruins arround the area...the best time to visit , is from May to November...that way you dont have rain..because when is the rain season is not as nice .

Don't miss saqsaywaman. We took an English tour arranged by our guesthouse. Make sure you have your ticket before you get there, it's s70 per person for a ticket tgat includes many city and local sights arount cuzco. They don't take credit cards or foreign currency so have your tickets or enough Peruvian Sols with you. A guide is a must and really helps explain how amazing it is and it's role in the Cuzco area. Climb to the top for an amazing view of Cuzco below. We saw this in addition to a few other nearby sites we stopped at outside Cuzco on our tour. Highly recommend on a visit to Cuzco.

Ridiculous pricing for foreigners. I understand this is a place of historical significance, but this is no Machu Pichu. Ridiculous prices for foreign tourists is unreasonable and this convinced me that it was not worth the trip- Exploring the surrounding area by foot might be a better idea. Compared with other worldly places of historical significance, this one doesn't stand out and could be safely eliminated from your plan, unless you really want to kill some time in Cusco.Machu Pichu on the other hand, and going down to the south via Andean explorer was still not cheap, but totally worth it.

Should be number 2 or 3. Best thing to do is ask in the tourist information place at the historic centre where to get the local bus. This will cost you about 2.50 to get to the top of the hill where you can walk back to town and visit 4 inca sites (names escape me but its on the map). Sacsayhuaman will be the last before you pop back into town for a break. Dont miss the inca slide - if you go on the weekend all the kids will be sliding down it.

This was sad for me, but worth the visit. The ruins at Sacsayhuaman were beautiful, but the highlight is the view from the top. The sad part is that only 25% of the original ruins remain because upon their conquest, the Spanish used this site as their quarry for stone to build the city of Cusco.

Historically Important But Not That Scenic. This is included in every city tour of Cusco as it's historically important. But I thought there were more scenic sights although I didi see this in the rain which probably inlfuenced my judgement.
Not to impressive if Seen on A Rainy Day. It was pouring when I saw this so it no doubt affected my judgement. Large grounds but ruins while historically important weren't that scenic.

Huge, what a great temple. The jewel in the crown of the temples around cusco. Huge temple with huge rocks, they estimate the biggest ones at over 100 ton. Get a guide to explain how they did everything, the way they cut the rocks is fascinating.

Hire a Guide. Our group of 12 hired a taxi ride up and then hired a guide at the gate to tell us the history of the site. We hiked back down a 25 minute easy walk back into town down a trail. A must see while you are in Cusco.
Sacsayhuaman. Another brilliant day. The size of the stones are enormous - how did they move them without wheels. Tried to put a credit card between them, no way would it go in.

Amazing experience. I was a bit worried I may be 'inca'd out' because I'd visited Machu Picchu the previous day, but need not have feared as this site was awesome. The local guide who accompanied us to the four sites that make up Sacsayhuaman was knowledgeable and allowed us to maximise our experience.
Great views over Cusco. The ruins are awesome, take a taxi to there from Plaza de Armas (about 10 soles), and if you have breath return to city center on foot.

One word: WOW!!. This is an amazing historical site. There is so much history in just one place.The stones are huge and breathtaking. This is a MUST place to visit!!!!!There are agencies that give tours of the place. They pick up the tourists at their different hotels and then the tour starts. I have never done this type of tour but have heard it is a generic tour and does not last as long as people would want.I have done it privately and you go at your own pace. You decide how long you want the tour to be.We decided for a whole day. We walked up to the site from the Plaza de Armas and leisurely visited everything. We walked from one site to the next and rested as needed. At the end of the afternoon, we stopped to eat at a restaurant outside the site and had a good meal. It was nice ending the day outside of Cusco.We took a combi (mini-bus) back down to Cusco.I suggest that you mini-interview your guide before hiring him or her. I interview to get a feel of their level of English (or whatever language). Peruvians are not offended by this. Of course, the guide could speak perfect English and not know a thing about the place! If I am going to pay more money for a private guide, I want to be able to understand what is being said!!! You could ask at your hotel if they can suggest someone. Or go to a travel agency and ask there for a private guide.You could opt to go alone but it can be unsafe. Robbers really like the lone tourist. So extra precautions are needed.

I wanted more time :(. I really wanted more time here. I found the history of the ruins fascinated. Some of the architecture is actually predating the Incans! This was one of the two places that I went on the tour where I felt that the amount of time that I was provided was entirely insufficient. I suggest possibly doing this solo and doing some research on it before showing up to avoid the extra expense of the guide, but so that you can fully understand what you are seeing and take your time doing so!
Great ruins overlooking Cusco. The walk up to Sacsayhuaman is exhausting but the views and the massive Incan stone work make it worthwhile. Consider taking a taxi to the top and walking back down.

Great views. Similar to my experience in Moray, it was more the views and the surrounding landscape that impressed me than the man-made structures that I thought I was going to visit. There are massive stones that are impressive and everything, but there are a lot of stones in the Sacred Valley area. The ones at Sacsayhuaman seemed to be the largest of them all, but that is not the point. This place was special due to the natural setting and scenery that it provided. I highly recommend you experience the natural beauty here.

Serene sense of history. An absolute "Must See." This was our favorite after Machu Picchu. The massiveness of the stones create a majesty and serenity that is very evocative. A guide might help you understand the history, which is fascinating. But, walking among the massive stones by yourself is also awe inspiring. Some doorways are breathtaking. Brilliant stonecrafting using nothing but wooden wedges to increase the cracks in the stone. By expanding the wedges with water, the gigantic stones would break along fissure lines, giving the unique "puzzle piece" appearance of the terraces and walls. Bring extra wraps, as the winds sweep across there with a vengeance, adding to the feeling of being with the ancients.

A good introduction. The views over Cusco are great from here and as in introduction to the ruins in the area it was fantastic. We had a great guide who helped us understand what we were seeing, without this though I may well have struggled.

Lived up to expectations. Busy with lots of tourists - although quiet compared to Machu Picchu - as it's on all the Cusco and Sacred Valley tours. But it is fascinating and the views over Cusco are amazing.
Great Day trip form Cusco. Not from out of Cusco at all and a great view of Cusco from up there ... Great introduction to Inca ruins and really worth the trip !

Disappointing. We were not impressed. This site was recommended by the Lonely Planet guide as a must-see, but I must say it was definitely not worth our trouble. We bought tourist tickets just to enter the site which was not worth our money. We got there 1 hour before the site closed. Apart from a few people hanging about the place seemed rather deserted. No tours around the site were offered either. Also, we did not get to see much at all as most of it seemed closed to visitors. If you decide to walk there from the city centre, I must warn you that it is a very steep and long walk up the hill. Also if you can, visit the place earlier in the day. I would recommend instead of paying to enter this site you can go and see the statue of Jesus on the right hand side of Sacsayhuaman where you will be able to get a great view of Cusco. You do not need a tourist ticket to enter.
Incredible. This is a beautiful ruin worth a visit. The massive stones are incredible. The name itself is great. Worth a visit.

Just Okay. Due to a thundershower (and hail) our tour was cut short and we were left to wander around the site on our own after 15 minues of touring with our guide. Bummer. I see other pictures on-line and we didn't get to see anything quite that detailed. Just a walk by the terraces, a quick hike up and away we went.
Great history. Get a guide that will tell you about the history of the site - incredible to see how the Incas moves such large rocks.

Mysterious. Its mind-boggling to me how the Incas built this "fortress". Huge stones lined up & formed the walls. The area itself is huge and high up on a hill. Too bad most of the structure was destroyed over time & during the Spanish conquest. Still one can imagine how magnificent Sacsayhuaman must have been on its heyday.

So close to Cusco, do not miss it!. I'd recommend hiring a guide to walk you through and explain things to you as well as taking a ride on the Incan slide. Great place to start your Incan exploration..

Beautiful ruins!. These ruins are very beautiful and magnificent! The size of the stones is surprising and the surrounding landscape helps giving this place its magic. We went there with a tour and the guide told us the stones used to be much much much bigger before the Spanish went to Peru! Amazing

A must do. This is an important Inka Ruin, a temple dedicated to thunder and lightening. The construction is a marvel. The Inkas used no mortar to hold the stones together. They used wood, doused it with water, and hit it into cracks in the rocks. The water would make it expand and split the rock. The site is also surrounded by fields of lovely wildflowers and has great views of Cusco.
Simply stunning!. The Inti Raymi festival took place in Sacsayhuaman, which already has an air of mysticism. the dancing, costumes, crowds, reenactments of Inca traditions... wow. I was blown away!

Strongly recommend this location. We went there while in Cusco and wished we had had more time to spend there, we were with a group and only had a limited time there. We found Sacsayhuaman to be a very calming place, you just felt like you were in a special place there, something very spiritual about it. We hope to return someday and spend the day and soak the place in.

Worth a trip. We visited this as part of our half day city tour and it was worth the visit. The site is supposed to be the head of the puma as Cuzco is the body. It does get quite busy here during the afternoon but you get a wonderful view over Cuzco and of course, it's another excellent example of Inca construction.

Impressive ruins, good hike. Good hike to test how well you are adapting to the altitude. The ruins are just outside the city off a main street, so no need to take a tour bus to get here. Spent a little under two hours exploring - you can bring a flashlight and go through some small caves under the amphitheater. Not much signage, so it helps to bring some information on the history so you know what you are looking at.

Another beautiful Inca ruin.. Our tour stopped at Sacsayhuaman and it was a relief just to get out of the bus and be off the winding mountain roads. What a beautiful site. The view and the ruins were stunning. I wished we had been able to stay longer and just enjoy the area but as tours go, there is a schedule.

Extraterrestials.... If you want to see a proof of ancient astronauts visiting Earth in the past, Sacsayhuaman is what you are looking for. Good energy there and it is insane how precisely the stones are cut and put together. A walking distance from the center of Cusco, must see!
Wow. How did the Incas create such a place...lining windows up with sunrise and se on summer and winter solstice . Saw puma teeth, earthquake proof walls, llamas.

Good to walk up and see, don't pay to go in.. Place is poorly maintained with expensive options for entry. You get the sense of the size and complexity, just by walking around the outisde. A short walk up the hill from the Nazarenas. Be careful where you walk. Dog poop is everywhere.

Great hike and photo op.. I enjoy hiking so it was quite fine, but basically you go up look around, take some pics and head back down. I'd do it again, but the limited rating is because it's really just that. I wouldn't have paid for it as a tour.

Head of the Puma. Surprisingly peaceful and calming place. Beautiful stone structures and layout. Seeing the alpacas up close was a treat as well. Make sure you go around the corner past the ruins to see the view of the city of Cusco unfold at your feet.

Magnificent stonework and views over Cusco. Sacsayhuaman is a huge stone fortress that overlooks the Cusco city-we walked up from the town centre as a bit of acclimatisation for our Salkantay Trail walk a few days later. It took us an hour up through some interesting and historic parts of the town, although you can take a taxi if walking at altitude is too taxing.We were amazed at the scale of the fortress, the massive stones and the stonemasonary in the accurate jointing

when in Cusco visit the sexy human.... you would love to stay a few more moments and soak in the air and the energies...all in a day's time...vast expanse of land...take a deep breath and do the walk...

Magnificent Inca fortress. The site was initially started by the Killka people Jo preceded and were then overrun by the Inka in the 14th century. The Inka sections are characterised by their mind-blowing geometric stone cutting, on a truly epic scale. The Spanish trashed the site looking for gold, then knocked most if it down to build their own buildings in the city centre. The area was also used as a quarry in the 18th century. Getting there is easy enough. Get the Christo Blanco combi from the Avenida del Sol for 80 centimos. Alternately you can walk. I was told to watch out for muggers both at and around the ruins so go in a couple or more if you can. The views over Cusco are stunning, as are the wildflowers that grow everywhere. You can get a guide at the entrance but going quizzed a few I wouldn't say they know a massive amount beyond the usual historical dogma. It's rather expensive for what it is, but a good way to spend a morning.

"What the @#$?!?! How did..." GIANT STONES!!!!. How the hell did anyone make this site?!?! Three-hundred ton stones, quarried, moved, and hewn to fit together with laser-like precision. Truly an amazing site that poses more questions than proofs for answers. TIP 1: It's pronounced "Sahk-sahee-wah-mahn" (I've heard so many butchered versions, thought I'd help out)OTHER TIPS: It's at 12,000 ft altitude so be prepared for that; You'll take lots of pics; Put a person in front of/next to some of the bigger stones to provide a sense of scale; learn about it before you go, it'll be more impressive for you that way. (p.s. indulge yourself in all the "conspiracies" of how they are built). Although you may have paid for a tour, you will have to pay approximately 70 Soles ($28 US) for a 5 park/site pass that gives you access to this and others in this area, although it wouldn't surprise me if you don't pay until the 2nd or 3rd site. As you leave the site, there are groups of little bitty locals (Cholitas) dressed in traditional Quechua clothing along with llamas and/or alpacas. They know enough to say, "voluntary donation" for a photo op - so be prepared for a tip, BUT also be prepared for them to say, "No, not enough!" and I was generous - so they will try and milk you for more, just stick to your guns and say, "Eso es todo", meaning "That is all".All pics I've posted here are from Sacsayhuaman

Cut rocks that dwarf you.. There are huge cut rocks that are enormous. Some have many cuts to fit the rock that adjoins it. Interesting to see the contrast of Glacial rock in the same area. Alpacas we're roaming around the area. Natures own lawn service at work.

Interesting Place but VERY expensive. Extremely overpriced. Several years back was a great place and free to visit. In recent years the Peruvian government has invoked extremely high admission prices to most all of the tourist attractions in the Cusco area.

huge stones. The size of these ruins made them impressive. Easy to get to just outside Cusco. Part of it was under renovation when we were there, otherwise I may have gotten to see more and given it a higher rating. Some nice photo spots here. Also, the llamas wondering about were kind of interesting. Also neat to see the map and how it was puma shaped with the city. In case you want o know how to pronounce it, it's pronoucned, basically like "sexy woman". Again, I marvelled at just how they did this with those heavy huge stones back then. Worth a short trip.

A very good experience - Care re climbing the Stairs. An outstanding display of the ruins and its reconstructed format to demonstrate how life was within the town / city and its living and agricultural plateaus.We had an excellent tour guide , but we found the walking and climbing a particular challenge because many of the steps were not only steep but were also quite high. For anyone with recent leg issues or replacement knees this is a challenge.But an unforgettable experience with wonderful historical perspective of life in this civilisation

Well worth seeing. A large open site with lots of Inca walls plus reconstructions of buildings. We went in the late afternoon and the evening sun helped give it a mysterious atmosphere. Nearby views over Cuzco are great too, especially at night/sunset.

Impressive ruins. Popular historic attraction overlooking the city of Cusco. The fortress is impressive, with huge stone walls and impeccable Incan masonry. Llamas roam all around the site. Try to visit Sacsayhuaman BEFORE Machu Picchu. It's totally worthwhile, but probably won't "wow" you as much if you've already seen the Sacred Valley's crème de la crème. Its location high above Cusco makes for some spectacular views, but also a rather steep, headache-inducing uphill jaunt. The hike isn’t terribly difficult, but you NEED to acclimate yourself to the altitude before setting out. This can be tricky; you might feel perfectly OK in the city, but things can change almost immediately when you begin walking uphill. The ruins themselves are quite cool, but after our uncomfortable ascent, we had trouble fully enjoying them. I wouldn’t bother with the tour guides; bring your guidebook and read about the background/history at the top.

Marvel at Inca Architecture. Went with a local tour guide who filled in all the history with regards to this attraction. Other than enjoying pronouncing the name of the place (sounds like sexy woman). Was impressed by the size and scale of the stones making up the structure, of what once was an immense inca temple. It was truly a marvel and wonder of what the incas could accomplish. It was nice seeing the locals with a few llamas walking about. The view of cusco is awesome from up there.

A marvel of Inca engineering. Having a good guide who knows what the latest archaeological research says makes all the difference in visiting Sacsayhuaman. Otherwise, you just see some very long walls made of giant stones that have been carefully pieced together. Impressive but the story behind it, what it means, is even more so. Plan at least 2 hours here.

One of the best Inca ruins -- with a good guide. Magnificent site, with great history and wonderful view of Cuzco. Easy access. Be certain to find a guide that really knows Incan history and archaeology in order to appreciate what it was and means.

You can feel the mysticism. Beautiful place where you can only start to imagine how beautiful and important it was to the Inca culture and feel their pain when you find out how most of the materials that once made their temples and palaces are now part of churches and local houses in Cuzco. There are so many stories untold where we can only make guesses on how they lived and what they did.

Great day trip from Cusco. A great place to appreciate the immensity of Incan ingenuity. The large stones make you appreciate their accomplishments, and the llamas are a nice touch. The view of Cusco is superb from the overlook here. Definitely a must-do if you have time in Cusco.

stunning but bring a good guide. this is an amazing site to see but allow at least 2 hours to walk around (elevation is 12000 feet) and bring a good guide; most are pretty bad. Try to get a recommendation for a private guide from your hotel or research one in advance.

Do not miss visiting this amazing historical site. This site, near Cusco, should not be missed. It rivals Macchu Picchu but is much easier to access. We have been to Stone Henge and the Pyramids; this site we found to be equally impressive. If you have difficulty with climbing and stairs you would still enjoy this site.
Awesome. I loved these ruins. Probably my favourite that I saw during my whole trip. We also had a really funny tour guide which helped. Visited Sascayhuaman twice during my trip.
make sure you slide down the stone slide. Great place to walk up to. Large stones and llamas walking around. Dont forget to slide down the inca stone slide at the back of one of the stone edifices.
Sexy woman. Great ruins up on a hill looking down on Cusco and my guide kept calling it Sexy Woman to help people on the tour group who couldn't pronouce it.
Fascinating. Definitely include a tour of this historic site while you are in the Cusco area. Fascinating to learn how the Inka people lived and to understand their culture.

Ok but Probably Better if not on a Tour. While interesting with great views of Cusco, we felt extremely rushed because we were there on a tour. The tour also made stops at the other Incan ruins surrounding Cusco. It was basically a mad rush to get from site to site, all because the tour operator wanted to squeeze in a visit to the alpaca factory after the sites, which everyone was forced to visit. In fact, we skipped one site just to make it to the factory before it closed for the day. My suggestion is to try to find a way to visit the Incan sites on your own, whether it's by car or bicycle.
Pronounced "Sexy Woman"... :-). One of Cusco's greatest spots to see the surrounding hills - and the absolute immensity of what the Incans were able to build.

Peace and quiet near Cusco. Great place to visit to get an impression of the ancient Inca sites. Huge stone ruins with impressive stonework. Good view over Cusco and a nice place to escape to if you are tiring of the hustle and bustle of the city.

Richard in the Inca Fortress. Great ruin overlooking Cuzco. Some of the inigmatic stone work remains; enough to give the visitor a sense of the size and complex stone work the Inca are noted for. Much of the fortress was destroyed by the Spanish as were many other structures in Cuzco.

Simply Amazing. Also locally referred to as "sexy woman" it is well worth the visit. The ruins are beautifully presented and you just marvel how so many centuries ago man was able to undertake such amazingly precise engineering feats.
at the top of the world. surrounded by the feats of the ancient Incas was magical.....the local woman who came down from her farm for photo ops was cool

A must!. Great introduction to Inca architecture, knowledge, history, believes...
We loved it and kids loved climbing on old structures/buildings - great view on Cusco.
If you can afford it, please go for a guided tour as you learn so much otherwise, it may just look like a pile of old stone!
Highly recommeded.

Just walk up the hill...... This is a fun thing to do if you are in Cusco for a few days prior to heading to Machu Picchu. It can also ack as a goo warm up to acclimatize yourself if you are hiking up to the Machu Picchu gates. The cement path has steps, when you reach the top there is a gate and you have to pay around $20.00 each to enter the Sacsayhuaman park. I recommend just walking up to the gate, then back down again if you are not interested in seeing rocks....
Get a Good Guide!. Make sure you get a knowledgeable guide when touring these ruins, as the history of the building is quite a story!
overrated pricey. 70 soles to enter not worth itclimb from town is good getting ready for machu picchuor two months daily of stair climber
Sacsayhuaman. A very special place for the Inca and even today, especially during the Inti Raymi when there are thousands of people there. To bad the Spanish destroyed so much of it.

Amazing place. we went to this site by using the service of Free Walking Tour those guys are good fun they expained us every detail about Sacsayhuaman and without charging us any extra money I highly recommend to go with them they are very knowledgeable guides
Amazing ruins!. One of the better places we went to hike around and see some really big ROCK! Very beautiful. Llama herd also!

How did they do that?. Sacsayhuman is unbelievable. How did these ancient peoples move bolders that weighed many tons with no animals or machinery? The skills needed to accomplish what they did is hard to fathom. The fact that there is no written accounts of what they did is unbelievable, but true.

The scope of this site is breath taking.. It is such a crime that so much of this site was scavenged for stone during the building of colonial Cuzco. But one can still get the feel for what the site was like in it's Inca heyday.... a must see for Cuzco visitors.

Really nice introduction to ruins in Peru. We saw this site as part of the half day Cusco city tour. The bus takes you around to these sites and gives you some time to walk around and explore. It's interesting to see the craftsmanship of the giant stones at these sites. Just a nice easy day to get acclimated in Cusco and start learning about the Incas. Get the Cusco City Pass.
Hiker's Delight. When you get off the tour bus you will be lead down a path to ruins that will delight even the seasoned traveler. There are many places to walk or just sit and enjoy the scenery.

Gives perspective to the Inca history. Sacsayhuaman, even on a rainy, cloudy day, is a key component of getting the flavor of the Inca empire outside Cusco. We had a wonderful guide from Condor Peruvian Travel who made the visit wonderful and memorable. Awesome construction effort which has withstood earthquakes, weather and the ill conceived attempts of the Spanish to destroy this culture.
Big Rocks and Expanse. It was a nice place to visit for an hour or so, maybe have a picnic if the weather's nice. It was very windy when we went, so bring a jacket just in case.

Go before Machu Picchu otherwise you will have been spoiled!. Part of the 130 soles 10 day pass. You can actually walk out of San Blas up to Sexy Woman (the guides say this a lot, especially on the open top tour bus). Or just take a taxi for a few soles. Unfortunately the Spanish knocked down most of the temple complex to build their houses so only base stones left. Nice workmanship though! When we visited we couldn't go onto the top but maybe this was because of the poor weather?

Outside Cusco, but great place to visit. Great place to visit.Entrance fee 70 Soles/pp but with tour, all entrance fees (incl Cathedral) were included.If possible, stop and visit the nearby shop LA VICUNITA FACTORY, for Alpaca and Baby Alpaca clothes, at much cheaper prices, than in shops in Cusco.Great service. We did not have enough cash to pay. THe shops offered us to take clother with us and we could leave the USD at our hotel, later in the evening,

Large Incan ruins, with great view of the city. This is a very large set of Incan ruins, so it takes awhile to wale around. Often on grass, so in rainy season it can get muddy. Affords a beautiful overlook view of the city of Cusco.
pillars of the earth. we got here late in the day which was not the plan but actually a great time to see "sexy women" with the sunset casting a subdued hue over the massive stones. No crowds either
ruins and history. thats why you travel to see what you have read or seen on pictures. take your camera it is just fabulous
easy to get to wonderful view. great view, lamas to take pics with, stone slides was fun, can walk there from city or cab. make sure to bring a camera!
A surreal set up. there are a lof of ruins around Cusco but Sacsayhuaman is a few minutes up the city, it has a great view of Cusco and the ruins are quite beautiful and looked after.
Not so interesting. After Machu Picchu, this place pales in comparison and somewhat looks like a bunch of rocks. The best thing is the view of Cusco city available from the site.

Not so interesting. Unfortunately, we saw this after Machu Picchu, and we didn't find it too interesting. We just didn't find it to be that unique. We had also been at other ruins and maybe we were just tired of seeing Inca ruins at that point.

Interesting site, great views of Cuzco. This site is covered by most tours but if you can get there yourself it's much better. Get there early too and you'll have the place to yourself. You need the boleto turstico to get in which is a bit of a scam but unavoidable. You can buy it here or in Cuzco's tourist office.

stunning with a guide. When the guide explained what I was looking at and walking around, I was most impressed.
This is an extraordinary place.

one of the most AMAZING experiences ever!!!. Such a beautiful archaeological park.. Simply breathtaking this was probably one of the biggest highlights of my trip. Just sincerely memorable, the views are just extraordinary! Must see!!
An amazing historical site. Located just above Cuzco it is an historical Inca site not to be missed!! The stone walls are incredible, but go with a guide so as not to miss anything.

Fascinating site. This was our introduction to the local building styles, and fascinating it was. So many questions about how and why these sites originated, and fab views down towards the city. Also, strange how what are clearly former laval flows have remained bare rock.

Worth hiking if you are getting acclimatized.. Nice place to check out in Cuzco if you have just arrived. It's not really a hike, more of a walk. You have to pay to get in but I would recommend hiking around. There is lots to see within a short hike of the surrounding area (30 or so) that you don't have to pay for and have almost no people. Have fun.

Amazing!. This is like an Incan Stonehenge. Actually, I think it was partially pre-Incan. No matter, it is an awe-inspiring monument. How did it get there? What was it used for? What did it look like? Unfortunately, we don't really know. The Spanish started destroying it. Using the stones to build their settlement in Cusco. We went here as part of a tour but I wished we hadn't. You don't need a guide. In fact, I wish I had a few hours to explore, rather than the 1 hour the tour gave us. Don't forget to go behind the ruins for a good view of Cristo Blanco

Got soaked. It was sunny in Cusco but by the time we got up the hillside on our bus tour it was pouring at Christo Blanco near Sacsayhuaman. So we did not enjoy it too much. If your going in December purchase a good quality rain poncho.

Hudge stones. The size of the cut stones is really unusual. We went with part of a city tour and did not get to spend as much time wandering around as I would have liked to. Better to get a cab and spend time wandering around, although you don't need a lot of time. Just a slower pace than with tour groups. Interesting to see the workmanship that went into cutting the stones so perfect, but not a lot of other interesting things to see, but worth seeing.

Amazing, Impressive a must see. Do not miss it. You can do it on your own if adventorous. You will be amazed to see Sacsayhuaman. How did they do it? This fortress is amazing and makes you wonder how did the Incas build this fortress. how did they bring the rocks, how did they pile them up? How did they make them fit perfectly. It is only 3 kilometers outside Cusco. If you take a tour (Maybe $100-150 dollars per person)they rush through this ruins and you will not appreciate this wonderful ruins. Actually Parque arquelogico Sacsayhuaman includes 4 ruins: Sacsayhuaman, Quenqo, Pukapucara and Tambomachay. Also on the way the white Christ can be seen) Hours 7:30am to 6:00pm Ticket for Foreign visitors is 70 soles (US28) and cash, soles only.If you hire a Taxi, they might charge you around 60-80 soles ($24-32 US) hire them to take you to the Sacsayhuaman entrance, go the the other end of Sacsayhuaman, and wait for you while you walk through Sacsayhuaman,then take you to the other 3 ruins (Quiet a distance between the ruins. You need a Taxi unless you really want to walk a few kilometers.) There are also free lance tour guides on site that maybe for $10-$20 dollars will guide you through all the ruins. (need room on your TaxiIf your party is more than 3, you can get a Van they may charge 100 soles to do the same route for you. (Up tp 7-9)If you are adventorous and do the tour on your own. You will really enjoy it. You can do it in 4 hours. It is worth it
Panoramic .. The visit to the underground cave and temple of Kenko was amazing. above ground was a great place to have a panoramic view of the city of Cusco.

These Ruins Had Amazing Patterns and Architectural Design.. This was one of the last stops in our tour and we would have wanted to stay longer. We were told to be back on the tour bus in 20 minutes which did not do justice to the significance and history of this place. The sizes and shapes of the stones were enormous. This was referred to as a fortress. The stones were laid down precisely and not a piece of a paper could be inserted between the rocks or boulders. These ruins were very impressive- design wise and precision wise.Every visitor to the Cusco should see this.

wow what a climb:). Sacsayhuaman is 300m up the hill over Cuzco. it is just 300m up, but in total it would make 3701m above sea level, so it is peculiar walk and struggle. once you are there the views and the site make up for the struggle. this site can be well visited as the last site when coming from the north seeing 3 other Incan sites earlier. this way it would mean probably avoiding going up...make sure to visit San Blas on your way/up down. very close to that site there is Christ monument - also worth visiting.
How Did They Do It?. Just amazing rock formations which left us open mouthed at how it could have possibly been done. Go on a guided tour as the information provided was very informative.

Huge Ruins overlooking Cusco. Sacsayhuaman is different from the other ruins in the Sacred Valley because the size of the rocks are massive compared to Ollantaytambo and Pisac. Once you have seen 5 ruins, you have seen them all, but Sacsayhuaman is a little different because the size of it and because it has a nice view of Cusco city.

Stunning...Incas were an incredible people. Sacsahuaman is definitely worth the trek up from the Plaza de Armas (don't cheat). The walls seem a physical impossibility but are a wonder to gaze upon. You have to pay for a joint ticket for the Inca ruins which is a bit pricey, but it's up to you to decide how much you wish to make of it. Once we'd visited nearly all the sites it works out at a pretty good price. There is no information at any of the Archaeological sites so it's probably worth investing in a private guide (at the entrance), or having a smart phone or tablet with wikipedia saved! The view is stunning from the top, but don't miss out on the sites from Tambomachay to Sacayhuaman. The hike is less than 7 km and is really easy. It's worth seeing the collection of Incan ruins that constitute the whole site.

Another large Site. Another large site that the tours tend to lightly hit, if you are on a group tour and have some free time, go up to the back side (opposite the main ruins) there is a cool slide and an interesting area of cut stone.

Good site from the outside. Refused to pay for an 'all sites' ticket as I had done most in previous years, and there wasn't a single entry ticket. However, having walked up here (much to the cost of my lungs) you can see quite a bit from outside the perimeter, (mostly intricate shaped stone walls) and you can easily walk across to Christo Blanco and the views of the city (and to the temple of the moon up the road a bit).

The Inca Crown of Cusco. Sacsayhuaman is a spectacular example of Inca architecture as well as stone work. The huge stones in this fortress weigh up to 300 tons, and yet the fit and finish is so much finer than anything at Machu Picchu. It is an easy taxi ride to the fort (10 Soles, about $4), and a pleasant, down-hill walk back to our B and B in Cusco. In addition to the magnificent fort, one can view almost all of Cusco on top of the ruins.

A good warmup for Machu Picchu. Not as well known as Machu Picchu or remote, but just as well built and interesting history. If you are up for a hike, start and the bottom and work up through the 4 sites separated by several miles of countryside at high altitude. A more relaxed walk would be to take a bus or taxi to the farthest site and walk downhill through the 4 sites, ending closest to Cusco and a steep walk or ride back to the city center.

Beautiful Ruins!. We came to Peru expecting to see some interesting places prior to being amazed by Machu Picchu, but boy were we surprised by this place! These ruins are amazing and our guide - from Condor Travel - gave us an excellent overview of the history. The construction is fantastic, we definitely were not expecting such amazing ruins, and it is a wonder these aren't more well known. We are very glad we visited and would recommend this to anyone.

Most amazing place!. A nice walk from the center of Cuzco brings you to these Incan ruins that are just amazing to see! We kept asking ourselves how they built the complex as the stones are immense and weigh tons. A must see in the area and a nice intro before Macchu Pichu.
Amazing. The skill of the Incas that built this place blew me away. it's huge. It's fascinating. Its easy to get to outside of Cusco. Go! I think seen best with a guide.

Don't miss it!. Really amazing example of Inca construction - the scale of it is astonishing Although the setting isn't as stunning as Machu Picchu the ruins are just as impressive and it's easy to get to. Glad we made the effort to go.
Timeless Monument. If you are in Cusco, you MUST visit this site. The scope of the old fortress ruins is HUGE, and the stonework second to none for sheer size and majesty. Amazing place.

Pricey but interesting and a good view point. Taxi 8 soles from Cusco is money well spent. Only take soles at the entrance and will only sell you a 70 sole two day ticket that also includes 3 other sites. Luckily there was a money changer around at a worse rate than town (2.5 compared to 2.7) plus another $1 to accept a slightly torn $20...which was interesting. Worth walking back down to the bottom entrance for what is probably a better view of town from the chuch square where you can sit for free and take in the view. The ruins themselves are what they are but worth a visit seeing that they are so close (albeit expensive). From the church it is a down hill stroll back to the main square.

Large ruins, with great views. The Sacsayhuaman ruins are nice to visit because they are a little closer into Cuscu and easier to reach than Machu Picchu, making them much more accessible to the locals. It was enjoyable to visit the site along side groups of school children, a bride and groom, and countless other Cuscans (is that a word? is that the correct word?).We visited as part of a tour which took us just down the road a ways to allow us to "look back" onto Sacsayhuaman. It is amazing standing there, but even more amazing to view it from afar.

A great place to gain perspective!. I love Sacsayhuaman! It is humbling to be surrounded by such grand architecture that is yet to be replicated by modern society. Best of all is that the ruins are only a few minutes from the city center and it is relatively easy to walk back town if you are the 'explorative' type.
Neat ruins. Great place to explore--need more time than the typical 30min that the tours give you, but it is a neat place to check out.

Large Impressive Ruins. Amazing to see the huge rocks the Spaniards couldn't move but the Incans had placed to form a Puma above the city of Cusco. Impressive and overwhelming, great views of the city, very worth it and close to the city.

Unique Approach. OK, when we arrived at the ruins, we met a young man who offered us a horseback tour that would include visits to numerous ruins in addition to a grand view of "Sexy Woman" from above. Simply amazing! Then we hiked down and stopped at a church overlooking Cusco and shared a bottle of wine as the sun set and the city came alive with lights, AMAZING!

Tour of Ancient Incan Sites. Our only tour on our trip to Peru was of the ancient Incan sites around Cusco. It was very interesting and beautiful. It was nice to have a guide to explain the Incan building techniques.

Amazing. This is called "sexy woman". Amazing fortress. The boulders were huge and fit exactly. Llamas roamed the grassy area. Great guide to explain the findings including the tight fitting rocks and the trapezoid doorways. thanks to Ideal South America

Highly overpriced - avoid if you can. The site is magical and great, you might ask Why the 'avoid'? Because most of the area has been cordoned out so you can only really see/touch the first level. Granted the first level is perhaps the most impressive, but there are many details to be seen in the other levels. For example, we wanted to go where the towers used to be erected, the towers have been gone since the colonial times but it happens to be one special magnetic place (if you don't want to believe that, that is fine). I have been there several times over the past 15 years and this would be my last visit. Not only that but I recommend to avoid and even boycott. The regional or city government that sets up the price are only interested in the money. Little or no maintenance has occurred, other that getting some contention barriers so some of the walls don't completely fall apart. For US$28.00 I expect full access: price is been about same for several years but tourists see less and less and that is just NOT acceptable. Either post a sign a the office where one buys the ticket, so an informed decision can be made, or reduce the price. I estimated well over 60% of the entire site is not accessible now. Very upset!

Sacsayhuaman. We got a taxi to the furthest of the 4 sites, easily arranged by the hotel, then caught a collectivo - you just hail it - back to the main site from outside a weaving cooperative, visiting a local llama show on the way, and walked back down to Cusco. A good trip for the first day while adapting to altitude.

THE INCAS DID IT. When you face this amazing place, you try to explain, but many doubts come. Our guide gave a poor explanation for this and was not satisfied and took a second chance following another group and notice that was very similar. Do not miss the place and after visit go down to Cusco city in a loving walk.
Go on your own. You do not need a guide to take you here. Its very close to Cusco & a taxi is fine. A good guide book will help understand the impressive ruins.

Archeological delight!. Loved walking thru the Inca/Quetchua ruins. The history is amazing! Loved seeing the huge rocks used in the walls, including the keystone, which stabilize the massive walls. We were amazed they mined the stone away from the site, must have had thousands of slaves! We also went into a cave with an alter for sacrifices. Great place to soak in history!

Amazing Incan site not to be missed. This is just outside of Cusco. We saw it on an afternoon "city" tour. The ruins around Cusco are far superior to Machu Picchu in terms or their engineering. Do not miss this our you will have missed much of what the Inca were about.

Close to Cusco. I think most visitors to Cusco visit Sacsayhuaman; it is on the city tour and easily reached as it sits on a hill, overlooking the city of Cusco. While not on as grand a scale of construction as Machu Picchu, it does have some of the largest worked stones you will find through the region.

Walk there if you can or take a taxi. It's definitely worth visiting the site of some incredible Inca architecture. Even though we had a really terrific guide, I would avoid the group tour and find your way up there on your own, especially if you're staying in San Blas. Otherwise, you're at the mercy of group dynamics and what others may or may not be interested in doing.
inteesting.. take a private taxi and hire a guide there. It's quieter in the morning. It's a good introduction to Inca stonework and culture. We also did the other sites nearby

Sexy Woman?. When in Cusco do as the Inca did, This is a fantastic walking experience. Explore the caves and tombs first. Then do the zig zag walls from beginning to end. The walls really are different. Then walk the walls from uptop. The views are stunning. Check out what appears to be an astronomical observatory. No one knows if it is or it isn't but this area is a gem to those who can spend time here. No trip to Cuzco is complete without a trip to Sacsayhuaman.
Not much to see. The best part of this site is that it is on the top of a mountain overlooking the city of Cusco with terrific views.

Walking tour withing a stroll of Cusco.. You don't have to go to Machu Picchu to see Incan stonework. In fact this place is better stonework than it, and within a 30 min uphill walk of Cusco - on the hill with the cross. Entrance is part of the S130/70 Bolleto Touristico package you can buy at the entrance.

good intro to inka architecture. we landed in Cusco, spent 2 days there, then 4 in the Sacred Valley before starting the 4 day Inka trail. we saw a progression of Inkan sites leading up to Machu Picchu, and our appreciation just grew as we went along. Our first taste was Saqsayhuaman above the city of Cusco. We were totally impressed with the vision, design, and technical prowess of the stone work there. As for the reviewer that complained about the price: it would be worth it just by itself, but it is part of the Boleto Touristico, which will get you into 15-16 different sites in the area, so truly a bargain. BUY ONE AND GO SEE THE PLACES ON IT!

Huge Inca structure.. Thunder in the skies and heavy clouds did not stop our enjoyment of this location.Massive stones, huge zigzag shapes, masterful engineering and steep climbs - impressive. Views over Cusco from the third level.

The "Great Wall" of Cuzco, Peru. It is amazing to read up about the history of this site in Incan culture. It is a HUGE wall made of a zig-zagging formation which was created to expose enemy flanks in battle. The zig zags represented puma's teeth (sacred animal to Incas). Unfortunately, they were conquered here and the Spaniards disassembled the wall in places to build the buildings you see in Cuzco today. Incredible how the Inca built this wall! A must see in Cuzco!

Overrated and expensive. the cost to enter was $25USD per person because you must buy a package to see Sacsayhuaman and two other ruins whether you go see them or not. It is a HUGE hassle to make it to all three locations in the same day before your ticket expires. Their refusal to sell individual tickets is a blatant way to get more money out of western tourists. As for the ruins itself, it was just ok. most of the ruins is closed and not accessible. the large stone walls were different but not worth $50 USD for my wife and I to attend. You also need to pay for a $10 cab ride (each way) and bring lots of water with you. there is a HUGE drop off from this site and Machu Picchu. We were dissapointed

Awesome!. Pre-Visit here before you head up to Machu Piccu. Neat place to see how they constructed walls, moved massive boulders. You can learn quite a bit here if you have the right guide with you or have an excellent guide book! Have fun!Cliff- Ottawa ON Canada
Interesting but there are much more impressive ruins. Sacsayhuaman is close to Cusco, walking distance, and an interesting site, but there are much more spectacular sites in the Sacred Valley.

Walk there from the city. Amazing place. Expect the walk to take a loooong time unless you are acclimatised to the air. But the views on the way up, looking back at the city, are worth it. The stones and teh 'feel' of the place are remarkable. We loved it there, a really good half day out.

Amazing!. A great place to visit! You still must go to Machu Pichu, but this is another must see. The massive boulders fused together without mortar are even more amazing when you consider they were quarried miles away and somehow delivered to the site. Amazing!

An amazing precursor to Macchu Pichu. Two days before we embarked on our four-day Inka Trail Trek, we walked from Tambo Machay to Sacsayhuaman. Walking through the hillsides surrounding Cusco,there are 4 ruins to visit which are quite interesting and picturesque. At one point along the trek, we found ourselves in a pasture of sheep, with several newborn lambs. When you arrive at Sacsayhuaman, it is only a 20-30 min. walk back to the Plaza de Armas in Cusco.

Maccu Pichu lite. A must see and very easy to get to. We saw most of the Sacred Valley and this was only behind Maccu Pichu as the most amazing ruin. Make sure you try and find the secret rock slides!!

Incredible. Beautiful views of Cusco and the ruins are spectacular. You cannot miss this if you go to Cusco. There are llamas and alpacas all over the place (at least when we were there). Be sure to get a professional guide to explain it to you.

Impressive, if in town should definitely see.. Very easy to take a cab to (negotiate before getting in - shouldn't be more than 10 soles). Our guidebook was extremely outdated - learned that admission was much higher than we were expecting (can't remember the exact amount) b/c it gets you in to all 4 ruins around Cusco - problem being this was the only ticket they were selling.Very nice ruins site - great view of Cusco from one of the vantage points. Would suggest against hiking up to the Cristo statue..

the best one to see. Probably the best inca ruin to see.I love the inca ruins and this is another one to tick off the list.They are well maintained and offer you an insight into the amazing strength that the culture has at creating great structures.

Close to Cusco and very interesting. I took a cab up and hiked back down. I did it on my first day in Cusco while still adapting to the altitude and found myself a bit out of breath just walking around, but the stone walls there were unlike anything else i saw...even in Macchu Picchu. Read about the history if you don't plan to get a guide...but do it!
Incredible view!. Our tour guide was terrible, but the views and size of these ruins are impressive. Sunset from those hills was incredible.

Very interesting site. The weather was beautiful and we had an excellent guide - very informative. In spite of the fact the schools were having their annual field trip day, it is not crowded, plus they were fun to watch.

Amazing!. This place was truly amazing! It is so hard to imagine the amount of work that went into building this structure it is just mind boggling! Don't miss this!!!!! It is a must if you are in Cuzco.
This site is enormous!. We saw what the Incans were capable of building with this impressive site! We have watched several shows on TV that talk about it, but being there is so much better.

Interesting. We were there as part of the Cusco City Tour and did not expect to be outside the city, but were glad to be able to see these ruins. Be sure to check to see if your city tour takes you outside the city because it can become very cold at this high elevation.

An amazing place!. This is NOT a military fortress! It is a sacred temple site guarded by the most astonishing network of hand carved limestone butresses - it has no equal anywhere on the planet. To miss this site is to miss the most important place in Peru.
Interesting history. We walked from the top down this very open site. We had a guide who explained the very interesting history of the site. Without him we wouldn't have known the history.
huge site. Such a big site its hard to get perspective. Close to Cuzco so include it while staying there. Take a guide to fully appreciate.

One of the top ruins, but get the guide!. We walked up from Cusco, it took about 30 minutes. We hired a guide at the site (would not recommend site without guide), who offered us a shorter or longer option; we chose the longer option and were very glad of it. The first half of the tour (the shorter option) was your "standard" Inca ruin stuff - fabulous walls, huge stones, awesome doors/windows, Puma paw in the wall, etc. But the second half (across the "field" from the "main" part of the ruins) was wonderful, and totally had not come on my radar even after having done research in advance. It was like an Inca playground, with slides, caves, tunnels, grottoes; really wonderful. Nice views of Cusco from here. We walked to Q'Engo from here, but it is not marked, not obvious, not clear on the tourist map. If memory serves, there are two roads out, we took the one on the right (the guide can point you in the right direction); at the split in the road, stay to the left and Q'Engo will appear shortly on the right.

GO SEE Sexy Woman...as they call it!. Fantastic ruins, beautiful vistas and with a guide you learn all about this beautiful Inka place....worth hiking up higher than the crowds and looking at the gigantic blocks that were carved and placed. Amazing culture and great opportunity to see the past.
Very Interesting. A beautiful site full of interest and intrigue. I enjoyed visiting it. I recommend anyone to go there.

IF you've already been to Machu Picchu this is a little disappointing.. We did this towards the end of our trip and were a little disappointed as we'd already seen Machu Picchu. However if this is the first place you visit it's a nice warm up for what's in store. We did appreciated the history behind it.

Great for Pictures!. I've visited Sacsayhuaman 3 times and really enjoyed it. The first two times, my husband and I went with a tour and learned a lot about the history and culture behind it. Although that is quite interesting, i have to say that my favorite part about it are the giant rocks that you see there! They make for amazing pictures! The third time we went, we walked there early in the morning and watched the sunrise! It was an amazing experience!

A day or an hour, you can tailor this site to your schedule. If you are going to drive up to this site, just up the hill from downtown Cusco and near the giant Jesus statue you can see from all of town, then make sure you invest in the Boleto Turistico. The cost of entry to this site alone is 70 soles. Not sure of the Boleto cost, but you can use it at Moray and the salt mines too I believe. This site is one that clearly attracts many locals on Sunday in particular as families are seen picnicing, hiking and playing soccer. The giant boulders are amazing and the position of this Inkan fortress was a great choice given it's position above Cusco. You can just drive by this enormous site, but if you have time, use your ticket and spend some energy strolling and climbing the ruins.

Ruins and more ruins. Sacsayhuaman is a must to see- an amazing example of incanm architecture. Walk through narrow alleyways with walls created out those incredibly carved rocks. The highlight was the incan temple of the sun and moon, destroyed by the spanish but what is left creates a wonderful atmosphere. If you get a choice for a guide take Julio- he kept us enthralled for hours and is passionate about his town. He works for agency apus peru- adventure specialists..
Beautiful!. If you are in Cuzco you should visit this place where the inti Raymi takes place, it is beautiful and very well preserved!

Dont go if you went to Machu Picchu. what a let down after ollantaytambo and machu picchu. really nothing to see that you cant see from the road that goes around it and it is pricey for admission. if you feel like you have to see it, just have the cabbie drive you around it and look out the window.
good builders. About 30 minutes from the city, an amazing complex of stone walls and buildings showing the genius of the Inca culture

Great views of Cusco, Amazing Ruins. Definitely worth exploring when enjoying Cusco, we saw Sacsayhuaman as part of a day tour of Cusco and the ruins. The ruins themselves were amazing with fantastic views of Cusco!

Great inca site in Cusco. A great site right in Cusco, it is offered by many tour companies but you are in and out in no time, we were staying in San Blas so it was just ashort 10/15 walk. we arrived and had the place nearly to ourselves, so quiet you could really imagine it in it's prime , full of activity, movement and ceremony. it was great to spend a morning there at our leisure so if you have time do it yourself.A short walk brings you to another site name escapes me but if you have Cusco ticket its on this. Quiet ,peaceful and calm.On the way back you pass textile weavers working outdoors in traditional methods. Very interesting and slightly upsetting to discover how long they spend weaving them and the price they accept for such quality work. It's all relative I suppose and prices reflect relative cost of living. but it was great to deal directly with labour and craftsmen rather than shops in cusco.
Puma's head. great ruins - take the time to explore, get personal guide. City views are good. Puts Cusco in perspective.
If you have time, see it. Impressive complex, but I would get a guide. Otherwise , you are just walking around looking at big walls and rocks
An Inca ruin. This visit was OK, we all got a little tired. The ruins were worth seeing, but I could have missed it and kept myself for the Inca Trail!

Want a good walk?. Then start at Plaza de Armas, and head up. Make sure you have your ticket to get in. We took "pollo a la brasa" from Los Toldos, and had a nice little "picnic" up there. Oh, it was beautiful!! You can always take a taxi up, and walk down. The experience has no words...

Close enough to walk...or at least walk back to Cusco. Very cool giant stonework and very close to Cusco. I didn't get a tour and the 70S. seemed a bit steep just to walk around, but it was still worth the trip. And pronouncing it "Sexy Woman" is just fun.

Hail storm. I am sure my memory of this site is colored by the hail storm that crept up on us while standing in the expanse of the ruins. It was memorable to stand in the protection of those slightly leaning immense walls while the hail pounded down on us amid ruins that were censuries old. It was a bit different from the other ruins we saw at Ollantatambo or Machu Picchu, but just as interesting.
Impressive Place. Place the unique battle between the Incas and Spanish. Sacred place and you can feel the force of it until today. Very well maintained and signposted.
See it by horseback. We had a private tour, guided by the great Alain - superb docent. Half the trip was on foot, the other half on horseback. It was absolutely perfect.

Easy walk from the center of Cuzco. We read various accounts of the safety or otherwise of walking here from the center of Cuzco. It was difficult for us to understand why anyone would not walk. It is a short distance, an easy walk, and there were plenty of tourists and locals around. A large site with lots to see. Easy to spend several enjoyable hours here.

A good introduction to Inca ruins. If you're like most of travellers, you'll fly into Cuzco. A quick 1-2km walk up the hill (good for acclimatization before the Inca Trail) is Sacsayhuaman, overlooking the city.The views from on top are great, and this is a good introduction to Inca ruins.Particularly, it has the largest stones of any ruins I saw. It's amazing how they were able to make them fit so closely together, particularly as the region has had several earthquakes in the intervening years.

Allow plenty of time. Sacsayhuaman is a national park consisting of a number of Inca sites so allow a good half a day to see them all. Bring plenty of water as there are no shops, only street vendors. The biggest site is an Inca palace which is very interesting and also local mountain tribes visit.

How did they do it.. Once a religious center of lncas, Sacsayhuaman (pronounced "sexy woman") was finally the last Inca stronghold when the Spanish invaded. Possibly the most important historic archaeolog discovery of the Inca demise at the hands of the Spanish invaders. Ironically, the Spanish destroyed the structure only to use the stone to build Catholic churches.

Close to Cusco. We took a taxi up to the site. It cost 10 soles. They wanted 25 soles for them to wait for us. We gambled and fortunately were able to find a taxi to take us back down to the Plaza de Armas for 7 soles. The stones were definitely impressive as was the view of Cusco. I wish they had had a map to guide our tour around the site. We chose not to hire a guide, but that might have made the experience better. If you use the bathroom, be sure to have your own toilet paper on hand.

First inca view. This was our first day tour planned of our trip and it didn't disappoint. Quiet season beautiful sunny day and very few tourists. The ruins themselves are interesting but the views of the valley and the comprehension of what it must have been like at the time were wonderful.

Interesting. A quick stop, worth the look. This was a part of the trip to Pisaq. This was at the end of the trip and the least spectacular site, but worth the look. The area is very close to Cusco and is a part of a day trip, not a special trip.
Part of the City Tour. Be prepared for rain and crowds - all teh City Tours seem to start at 2pmBut great Inca site and more impressive stones than mach Piccu

See it at dawn... We were staying at a hotel above San Blas, so it was only about a 15 minute hike to the site. We decided to do this at first light before the complex opened. We were able to walk throughout the site without paying admission. I'm sure we missed some of the nuances without a guide, but the ruins were impressive and we enjoyed wandering around on our own (in the company of Cusquenos out jogging or walking their dogs). It is an easy hike from here to the white Jesus statue for a great overview of Cusco.

teeth of Cuzco puma. Really impressive ruins made of extra huge megalithic stones. Absolutely worthwhile to visit from Cuzco. You can walk there from Plaza de Armas, thou it is steep walk. There is also a fun attraction - a sliding hill that has been polished to perfection; do take care, however, you get up to some speed sliding down and then inevitably have to stop at the bottom, on you own precious legs. Besides the ruins, you also get an excellent view on Cuzco from above. Within fifteen minute walk there is another attraction - Q'enquo, and others if you are willing to walk more. There is also the statue of Christ. All in all, you could spend at least half a day or all of it visiting these places. I had the Boleto turistico, which includes both these attractions. Do take care to stay within the limits of the site, I stepped outside and had to explain myself to a guard coming back in, even show my passport.

"Sexy Woman". This is a great site to see in Cusco, it's even worth the long steep climb from the city centre. It's a good hike to help prepare trekkers for the Inca trail, and the site itself is worth seeing. The stones are absolutely massive, and it is so expansive, it's difficult to see it all in one day.
Awesome. Hike up the 700 steps from Cusco and visit the Sacsayhuaman ruins..the site where the Quechua rebelled against the Spanish control. Great ruins atop the hill.
Magnificent. Should be more famous! The size of the stones used to build is amazing. I suggest going with a guide.
Sexy woman ruins. Wow, these were incredible . Visitings here was for me part of an inca tour visiting four sites but this was without a doubt the best. Amazing to think how it was all done.

Cool ruins, even better view. If we did it all again, my girlfriend and I would have probably hiked up here. Instead, on account of it being late in the day already, we took a taxi up and paid the entrance fee ($30 US each or something like that). Being our first ruins, we were intrigued for about an hour, climbing them and exploring.Then we came upon the view of Cusco. Wow. Jaw dropping. We were lucky enough to be up there during a beautiful sunset. If you're into photography, then this is a must! Also, make the walk up to the statue of Jesus, as it's a neat little area to explore. When you're ready to head back down to the city, the walk is only 15 minutes or so.Overall, it was one of the highlights of Cusco for me.

Views are worth the walk..!. Walked up here from the Plaza de Armas, it is so worth the walk for the views. Here I bought the tourist ticket for 130 soles which lasts for 10 days and gets you into various sites and museums, definitely worth getting this. Also walked across to Cristo Blanco from here.
Not our favorite site but worth seeing. I guess it is supposed to be impressive but after a while, it just looks like a lot of rocks. Enjoyed the llamas there.

Touristy but not that interesting. My husband and I hiked up from Cusco to Sacsayhuaman because we heard from various people that it was a must-see attraction close to Cusco. It was a steep hike up but not that far outside of the main city. This site is included in the Cusco tourist ticket that gets you into a number of museums and other attractions throughout the area. Also right in the area is the Cristo Blanco overlooking the city, as well as a giant cross. The trails around the site are in good shape and relatively easy to walk, not too many stairs. However, a lot of the ruins were blocked off for maintenance of some kind. Given this, there just wasn't as much to see as I had hoped, and perhaps coming here after seeing numerous ruins along the Inca Trail and Machu Picchu was what made it less interesting to me.

Great to site to visit in Cusco. We toured Sacsayhuaman on our 2nd day in Cusco. It's a short walk up some stairs. No need to take a cab. The ruins are amazing. If you're willing to pay for a tour, I recommend it as you'll not know what you're looking at. We had to pay for admission into the site and then pay for a guide. The only option for admission was a multi-ticket pass. It was good for other sites - however we didn't have time to go. The guide was about 40 soles for the both of us. It was a 2 hour walking tour.
Worth the trip. Even after seeing various different sites along the Inca Trail, including Macchu Picchu--this place was still impressive. Definitely worth the trip.

How the heck did they lift those giant stones??. This site will blow your mind, when you see some stones almost 2-3 stories high. How did the Incas lift these monster rocks? Either they had some forgotten power of levitation or their physics were so advanced that civilization has forgotten it! Dont miss it. The llamas and alpacas wandering the site are very friendly and. Dd a nice touch.

Unbelievable.... you need tourist ticket to get in but if you keep walking around pass the barb wire, you can sneak and climb up and get in. A little European bird shared this info. The place is huge and beautiful. is definitely worth to check out...

amazing engineering feat. take a while and investigate the whole site, much of which is only a shadow of what it used to be. The main cathedral was built using this site as a stone material supply depot by the Spaniards.

beautiful walk. I'm Italian.Go with a taxi to tambomachay, visit the site and walk to puka pukare, visit the site and take a taxi to Q'enqo.Take (remember to contract the price, 25 soles for both Q'enqo e saqsaywaman are very good for the guide) a guide also for Saq, and then visit first qenqo then alk and visit Saqsaywaman, then walk back to cusco: 6 hours tour included eating, shopping and filming.

Climbing day one. We arrived in Cusco and immediately started climbing to get to Sacsayhuaman. Locals were flying kits and there were lots of places to walk around and get great views of Cusco. There is a fee of 70 Soles per person to get into the ruins though.

Close to town, make it a last stop.. This is one of five ruins that are close to Cuzco. Head to the farthest one first by taxi ($5 ride) and walk back towards town to Sacsayhuaman. Not only will you be able to take in the sites at your own pace, but you can see the scenery and locals in the fields. It took us about 3 hours to walk the whole course and enjoy the site and people. You can then pick up a taxi at Sacsayhuaman to travel back to town if you don't wish to walk back.
Great half day hike from town. This is a quick 20 minute walk (uphill) from town and the ruins are interesting and the area makes for a great half day of hiking around with amazing views of the city.

Nicely preserved ruins. and a lot of open spaces to climb or just stay below to get pictures from there. We had open time here and it was very nice. We had blue skies, no rain, and a perfect day for capturing the site in pictures

Inca stonework at its best. We took a taxi up to the sight, and hiked back down to the plaza via the small Inca Trail. We were able to hire a private guide, Jaime, who spoke perfect English. The signt is amazing - the stones are huge and perfectly carved. We spend about 2 hours. It is high above Cuzco so you can see everything. Bring a jacket - it was cold and windy while we were there!

Surreal. It's amazing and troubling as you try to figure out how the hell anyone, any hundreds or thousands could have moved any of the rocks that formed this structure not to mention how they managed to make them fit together so intricately. Even spending a few minutes here has a magical feeling, like you've visited a different time and when you touch the stones . . . to know that it was carried by the Incas makes you feel almost like a part of history.

Awesome site, magnificent!. We spent a few hours wandering aroung Sacsayhuaman and loved it. It is an amazing place, and there is lots to see and learn. It is well worth having a guide. Don't miss sliding down the rock slides or walking through the pitch black caves, especially if you have children in tow.

The head of a Puma. Cuzco was built by the incas in a shape of a puma and Sacsayhuaman is the head, all that more than 500 years ago.This place is walking distance from Cuzco but it´s better to go on a City Tour ofered by many hotels and travel agents in the city, it´s cheap and you will have a guide and tranportations to Sacsayhuaman and other places.Impressive how incas put huge and heavy rocks together like a puzzle.

Fantastic. This place is more full of questions than answers, however when you arrive you will know this place was very important for many people at one point, fascinating, always ask you guides for extra info!

Worth a guide. Brought to life by guide hired at the gate. Really only thought we needed the flimsy plastic rain coat she was selling. Nothing like taking your chances standing on an iron stone mountain in the middle of a thunderstorm looking over Cusco.
Energetic place. You'll feel the energy that this place has, no doubt !!!!! Remember when the Incas were there and imagine their life and how they built this place. Awesome view fo the Cusco's Valley

One word... How!?. Like all the things you see on TV where you're asking yourself "how?". How did they do this? How can rocks so large be stacked so perfectly? Sacsayhuaman is one of those places. A true spectacle.
Sacsayhuaman. This site was included in our half day tour of Cusco, it was very interesting, quite a bit of climbing at the beginnings to get to the top but was fascinating.

The best Inca site. You cannot miss this site which is in the outskirts of Cusco city. It has the most fabulous stone construction of them all and also has the Inti Raymi celebrations on June 23rd each year.
Great!. Wonderful site, great energy. We thoroughly enjoyed the ruins throughout Peru, and Sacsayhuaman was no exception.

Beautiful Spot. This is a little bit of a hike up from Cusco, but worth it. The view at the top is beautiful, and the ruins are fascinating. I recommend bringing a lunch with you and enjoying it with a view of either the city or the ruins - it's quite nice!

Glad we saw it!. Our tour guide told us when they were voting on the wonders of the world, people who knew what they were looking at wanted this place instead machu picchu. Why? Because the workmanship was more fascinatin-- how they could fit these many thousand ton boulders on top of each other and in place without mortar was amazing! I'm glad we saw this and felt like we spent enoug time here. The structure is amazing.
Sacsayhuaman. Without a tour guide we would never have known about this site. He made it come alive with his detailed information about the site, the architecture and Incan history.

You can't miss this!. Sacsayhuaman is located on a hill and it's so green and it feels so peaceful now that it is almost like being on a sacred place, more than at a fortress. While we were walking around, there was this group of alpacas grazing, they were so cute and chunky letting everybody snap pix of them, it was lovely!Walking around the fortress itself is a very pleasant experience, and you can appreciate the architectural prowess of the Incas who built that huge structure out of humonguous rocks. The area around the bulding is green and I almost wanted to just sit there and have a picnic, it was so picturesque! Of course you cannot eat on site, but ooh would it have been lovely
Lots of rocks. It was scenic, but very, very touristy. Try to get to one of the outer sites (like Moray/Maras) if you want to get off the beaten path.
