Classic Inca ruins. The size of the stones used in construction and the magnificent detail of the rock joinery is really remarkable. Plus, the view over Cusco is not to be missed.
same as above. beautiful as with all the places we went. Takes some getting used to and you have to close your eyes to the driving..
Great View. This is quite a hike but worth it! The view of the city from the ruins is amazing. It is also a bit cold late in the day so dress warmly.
Don't miss it. Close to Cusco city. Tremendously impressive and informative Incan site. Don't miss it. A great build-up to other Incan sites in the area.
Interesting. Interesting, but not fascinating. I would not rush to go their again, but it depends how interested in the Inca sites you are.

Prepare to be amazed. The site is massive and only when you get there will you understand why the locals see it as "more important that Machu Picchu".strongly recommend visiting as part of a "city tour" with a guide or at lest with a driver. It is very touching to see the desolation of the Peruvian when they explain the amount of destruction that the site had to undergo at the hands of the Spanish and, later on, the lcoals.Things to note: the site is vast and gets taken by hordes rather quickly so it pays to go there early. Also there is no infrastructure so do take water with you !
Fascinating Spot!. Incan ruins are interesting and engaging. Our family of four visited and learned a lot! It's always best to be with a guide so you can get the most our of your touring experience.

You Must Go Here. This is such an amazing site. I would have loved to see it in its full glory before the Spanish Conquistadors took it apart to use the rock in their building-up of Cusco. Unfortunately, I came here on a guided tour and we only spent about 30 minutes. The site is large and deserves a proper walk-around and an opportunity to enjoy the view of Cusco. Instead, what I got with the guided tour is a 20 minute run down which included what the site may have been used as, about the quarry process, and how the Inca moved the enormous rocks once cut. We then were permitted ten minutes to walk up to the top where there is a nice view of Cusco city. We then had to be back on the bus so that we could spend another thirty minutes at the Alpaca Wool Cooperative shop five minutes away. While I agree that buying from the Cooperative is a good benefit for the locals, I don't believe it should be at the cost of missing out on one of the most magnificant sites in the SV. A couple whom I had befriended on the tour sent me an email once they returned home and said they went back and spent four hours there! I would recommend getting some proper literature about the site and simply paying for a cab to take you there (you can also walk!) and guiding yourself around this amazing place.
Expansive archaelogical site. lots to see and explore - you need time and acclimation under your belt before you take this one on but it is definitely worth a stop during the sacred valley tour

Must see. This was our first stop after the Cathedral when we arrived in Cuzco. I would consider it must see. We booked a city tour of Cuzco via the travel company Llama Path and it was perfect logistically. They picked us up from the airport, took us to the Plaza de Armas and the Cathedral and then took us to Sacsayhuaman and then a few other ruin sites before dropping us off at our hotel. Very much worth the tour as we didn't do much walking and were able to relax, see tons of site and take it easy while acclimatizing before our Inca Trail hike.

Majestic and breathtaking. This site sits on an open field and it's got lots of GIANT stones. We went near sunset time and the colors were perfect. According to our guide only 40% of the site had been unearthed. Make sure you climb to the top to see the incredible view.

Huge Stones. Sacsayhuaman has amazing HUGE stones. The ruins are sparse as much was torn down in history. But the fact that the Inca built a city with them is incredible. Climb to the top for a rewarding view of Cusco and the Plaza de Armas.
Lots of big rocks. Lots of big rocks, but the ruins don't really form anything recognizable. The grounds are beautiful and you have a commanding view of Cusco.

The views alone are worth the trip. We hiked up from Plaza de Armas which takes about 20-30 minutes (although we had to keep stopping because the altitude made us a little short of breath). The views along the way and especially the view from the top of the ruins are truly incredible. You can see why the Incans chose this site for their fortress -- you can see (what seems like) forever. Well worth the trip!

Saxy Woooman. This was large and mind boggling as to how big it would have been before it fell to ruins. The view of Cusco from this site is worth the walking around. We were there just before the winter solstice so there were preparations for lots of festivities at the time.

"Sexy Woman". We went on a tour group and this was one of our surprise stops -- we didn't pick it out specifically but enjoyed it all the same. Our guide, to get the English speakers to understand the word kept saying "its like Sexy Woooman" and intend, you can buy shirts that say this down in Cusco. The rocks are huge! And you are able to walk around quite a bit. It was raining when we arrived (which is fairly common) and there were several industrious vendors selling plastic ponchos. Not a site that you could spend a whole lot of time in (its bigger than some but not as big as Machu Picchu) so best to do as a stop if you are looking at several of the easily accessible sites near Cusco. You can buy a ticket that covers several different stops in and around Cusco where at every stop they punch a hole in it. We did this as part of group so I'm not sure how much it was specifically to get in but you do get several attractions on your ticket. There is ample parking if you're driving and there are other sites nearby but not necessarily walkable (unless you're a hiker and into walking). The view is tremendous.

Worth a trip if you do not intend to visit other Incan Sites. The history of the site is far more interesting than the site itself. Covering a vast area little reamains although there are a few walls with the iconic Incan (no mortar) construction. We spent 1/2 hour there and that was enough

Interesting ruins just on outskirts of city.. I took the city tour and we did this amazing place. It is magnificent and a large area. I had a guide which was great but I felt rushed and would have loved to have stayed longer and wandered by myself and walked to the Christ statue. If i had time I would hike or walk up there from San blas and spend more time wandering. But definitely worth seeing.

Awesome ruins--huge rocks. What is cool about these ruins is that they are so completely different than Macchupichu and other ruins in the area. They are dark black rocks--huge ones! We took a taxi ride to them about 3-4 soles--and then took the walk back to town. I'd recommend the walk to the white Christ figure just because you can. If you don't, you can still get a great view of Cusco from the ruins themselves.
Fantastic!. We were lucky to be here for Inti Raymi - the festival of the sun, it's a don't miss when in Cusco, some of the biggest Inca stones we saw. Again we marvelled at the Might Inca!
Nice. Enjoyable taxi ride out to these ruins and great aerial views of the whole city from here. We were able to take some very nice pictures.

Must visit site in Cusco. We hiked up to Sacsayhuaman from our Hostal in the San Blas area, that is a great way to see it. Later that day we took a half day city tour and went there also, but the hike was our favorite way of getting there. HUGE site that is a great way of practicing an easy hike up at that altitude.
Beautiful views!. An incredible thing to see! Nothing like this is made in todays world. A great taste of history and an amazing view of Cuzco city.

Great trip for the family. Went here with kids ages 6-15. All enjoyed, and we had a lot of fun going down the slides. One of my favourite parts was going through the tunnel. All in all it was great fun and highly recommended for families with kids.
Saxy Woman. Beautiful and historic. Great view of the city. Our tour guided was very kind and informative.

Nice visit with right guide. This Inca ruin is not nearly as well preserved as Machu Picchu, but if you read up on it before hand and get a decent guide it is worth seeing. It has an interesting history and nice overviews of Cusco. Don't expect Machu Picchu, but it is worth the trip up from Cusco.
Very cool!. It is an amazing place to see. It is unbelievable how they were able to move and carve such gigantic stones so perfectly. It is certainly worth taking a trip to see.
Amazing view of Cusco!. Not only is Sacsayhuaman an amazing feat of Inca architecture to view - it is located above Cusco and affords expansive views of the city nestled among the mountaintops.

Was a bit underwhelmed. We started to take a tour that included this site. Instead, we took an open-top, double-deck bus tour around Cusco, which completely circled Sacsayhuaman. We felt like we saw pretty much everything they have to offer, and save ourselves the $25.00 p.p. entry fee. Our friends who did the tour wished they had done the same thing we did.

Get a good guide. Our tour guide was bad, and he kept joking about this place as "sexy-women" i never learned what this place was all about.... So i suggest that you get a good guide. Nearby were llama, that make a great photo. It is also near the Jesus on the Mountain (huge white statue).
Wonderful Inca Ruin. A great introduction to the Inca Ruins. A lovely open, grassy area to explore at your own pace. Climb the hills and take in the views.
Awe-inspiring ancient ruins. Most impressive site with mammoth stones fit together without mortar.

Worth it if you have a free half day. The ticket for this is not cheap, but gets you into a set of 4 ruins - only two of which are really accessible by foot. The ruins are pretty spread out, and although they lack the intricate carvings or fine objects of other ruins, they are impressive and worth a visit for a half day.Like many sites in Peru there is virtually no signage, leaving you to a guide or your own interpretations.
Great place to explore, great view of Cusco.. If you're up for the exercise, walk up from Cusco proper. Amazing views.

Your Cuzco Adventure Won't Be Complete. Sacsayhuaman is the most breathtaking site in or around Cuzco. It cannot be missed and is second only to Machu Picchu as an Incan gem. You'll marvel at the size and scope of this "jaw biting" historical location.

Look for animal shapes formed by the blocks. We went with a private guide (Eddie) who had a decent sense of humour.Of course his first bit of humour was helping us to pronounce the name. He said just drawl on sexy woman. Actually works.Then he showed us the stone work. Compared with temples in the town it was interesting to see the very large boulders fitting so snug with each other. Here was his next bit of trivia. He showed us how to make out shapes of animals in the rock combinations. Another cool mystery to contemplate.Walk up through the setting sun door was a bit challenging more with other tourists crowding around or trying to get you to move away for pictures than with the altitude. Great view of Cusco from the top.But Eddie also told us the sad lost of a fantastic monument when the stones were pillaged to put up some of the churches in town.Useful notes: there are bathrooms on either end of this ruin. So don't worry. Watch out for the protective curators, stay on the designated paths no matter how tempting the photo opp. You can get some great choclo (boiled corn) at the exit.

Very different from other Inca ruins. There's no reason not to visit Sacsayhuaman if you're staying in the Cusco area. It'll cost you about s/10 to get there by taxi, or you can walk up the steep streets/steps for free. We opted to taxi to the ruins and walk back to the city.The ruins themselves are very different from other ruins in the region, like Pisac, Ollantaytambo and Machupicchu. Other sites are highlighted by the remnants of temples or living quarters; Sacsayhuaman's structures are long gone, and what's left is the massive foundation of an important site. The focus today is on the stonework. The Inca carved massive stones into tightly constructed walls, all without mortar. These walls are a wonder.Another highlight is the view of Cusco from the site. From this vantage point, you can see all of Cusco, from the central historic district to the shantytowns that ring the city.

Large Interesting Site. Covers a large area this Inca site should only be visited with a guide if you want to experience it properly. We did it on a combined tour of city cathedral and churches and 3 other adjacent Inca sites and it can easily be done in an afternoon. Go here before visiting Machu Picchu though

Sexy Women. Our tour guide called this place Sexy Women which will probably stay in my mind forever. Nice historical place. Does not compare with MP but still I would recomment going there and seeing it.

Within walking distance to Cusco. We walked here from our hotel in Cusco during the Inti Raymi festival. It's very steep. It was really amazing to see the colorful crowds all along the way. We went back later by bus to see the ruins themselves, but they were just okay. It wasn't the same without the context of the festival.
Awesome..... The way the stones were placed, the whole location was fascinating...the history engaging!

Seems Different. My first visit was 34 years ago. Seemed more or better or more awe inspiring then this time. Amazing stone work and it does seem there is more control for entering and maintaining the site.
amazing architecture. Massive stones put in place without the wheel. Fort represents the head of a puma.
A lifetime experience!!. Lie on the ground and feel the energy of the inca ancestors stream over you and feel the happiness of the here and the now!

Overlooking Cusco. We came in through the back way, having ridden horses to the 4 sites.....we had to crawl through a cave to get into the seldom seen internal, circular area used for irrigation...and we had to climb out of it before going to the main area....HUGE. Great spot, great views over Cusco.

Very cool historical Incan site. Large archaeology site; plenty of room-- grassy fields; interesting use of huge stones (over 5 meters high!?) to build this Incan monument. Great vistas of the city/ Plaza De Armas. Within walking distance of downtown Cuzco. Be sure to go down the ancient stone slide & check out the caves.
A must see.. It is amasing how these old Inca buildings were constructed and to hold up over years of earthquakes.

Interesting ruins, be wary of the guides. This was a nice site. It was fairly large and in good condition. The crowds weren't bad. It was a fairly easy walk from the Plaza. We were also pleased to discover that the notorious Cusco tourist ticket could be purchased as a one-day ticket rather than the full ten-day, which saved us money given our limited time.We hired a guy named George to show us around the site. He did a good job and seemed fairly knowledgeable. There was of course an "artist" who George knew waiting along the route, selling little hand-made statues. We bought one knowing full well that the artist's hands had just removed said statue from a shipping crate, but no hard feelings. Amusingly, they screwed up the choreography and another of George's 'artist' friends tried to sell us an identical handmade statue a few minutes later, and George tried to warn him off in rapid Spanish.We ended up renting a couple of horses from George to see three small, related sites. (Tambochay and two others, all discussed with Sacsayhuaman in the guide book, don't recall the names.) George sent us out with his ten year old daughter, who was very nice but spoke no English (contrary to his assurances.) It was getting dark by the end of the tour, and she ended it rather abruptly on a dirt road in the middle of the hills, instructing us pleasantly to "walk straight, then take a right, then hail a bus." (it actually took two combis to get back to the plaza, we had to transfer.) My wife and I are fairly adventurous types, but it was a little odd being abandoned on an unlit country road well outside the city after dark. I would recommend reaching a clearer arrangement with George or his ilk before accepting tour services.

Less crowd between 4:00-6:00. We rented a Taxi and had him take us there and wait. Cheap. We paid less than the double decker red bus (Cusco City tour) that did not even stop there. We went before the sunset so the crowd thinned out. Perfect time. The tickets allow you to visit a few other sites/museums.

Up on the hills. Sacsayhuaman is a very interesting Inca site, where you will see the biggest smooth rocks the Incas were famous for using. It also boasts very nice views. I strongly suggest taking a guide who can explain what everything is (and take your picture!)There are two ways to get up there: by taxi and by foot. The second option is only for the fit, as it's one long steep hill up.Entry to the site is quite expensive, at 70 soles. However, the ticket includes entry to a few other sites around the city.
it´s a amazing place. if you are pretty fit. i recommend you to walk all the way up there, might take 1 to 2 hours. we went doing Inti Raymi festival. it was magical.

10,000 may have lived here. Although only huge blocks of stone remain from this cite and only about 20% of its original size, this is still a must to see when in Cusco. It was built in the mid-15th century by the Incas but dismantled by the Spanish a century later. However the huge stone blocks are still there and one can see how the Incas fitted each stone together with not much space between. This may have been a form on fortification to protect Cusco below, a 30-45 minute walk.

My first meeting with an Alpaca. Got up close and personal with an alpaca here, changed my life. The hike from the Plaza is a good warm up before heading to machu pichu, and especially if you are there to acclimate before doing the Inca Trail.

Amazing architecture. The huge stones set to avoid being destroyed by earthquakes showed just how advances the Inca were 500+ years ago.The area for preparing mummies was amazing, especially considering the builders cut the solid stone walls to perfectly match the Milky Way and path of the moon!!

worth the hike. We stayed near the path to walk there. It was steep but worth it. The walls are amazing, and reminds you how sad it is the spanish destroyed so much. plus, how many tourist sites are pronounced sexy woman?

Great place to see the wonders of the Incas. Sacsayhuaman is out of town so you will either need to see it on a tour or take a taxi. You really need a guide so that you understand the importance of this sacred area.

Very impressive. This place did not disappoint, it was every bit as majestic and imposing as we expected. The views of Cusco below are breathtaking, and there was a llama family wandering around providing a perfect backdrop for our photos!

Incan fortress ruin above Cuzco. Taking a tour of the ruins above Cuzco is a "must do" as part of a visit to this area. Sacsayhuaman is by far the largest and most interesting of the 4-5 ruins that are within 3-4 miles of each other in the mountains above Cuzco. It is worthy of planning a couple hours to tour it fully and enjoy the amazing stonework and scale of this fortress. 2 of us from our party of 10 decided to start at the highest ruin above this and then walk 4 of the ruins going downhill, with Sacsayhuaman being the last and lowest, over about a 3 mile stretch. The hike after Sacsayhuaman down into Cuzo is easy, downhill, and picturesque. It takes you down into San Blas, an interesting destination of its own, and then down to the Plaza de Armas. It is included in the aggregate sites ticket you should acquire in the plaza.
views and history is awe inspiring. be prepared to walk and look - the ruins are fantastic, and the story behind the ruins is even more amazing.
Not pronounced "Sexy Woman". If your guide is not in a hurry, you will enjoy the tour. Very interesting. Just wished we could have seen the annual celebration- Temple of the Sun Festival

A lot of history. It helped us to understand the history of the sacred valley. Lots of ruins and a burial preparation area which was fabulous! Our guide told us the best way to remember the name is "sexy woman"!
sacsayhuaman. great site to visit...slight downside is that there are very few information signs at the site.

Interesting Inca site. This site is very worthwhile. A guide is worth it to tell you all the interesting historic details! Allow yourself a couple hours. I felt that my guide moved us on to the next thing too quickly and I didn't explore as much as I should have. Besides the site itself, it offers a fantastic view & classic photo-op of the city of Cusco.
Big,. If you miss this you would not get the grandeur of the Inca! The carved stones here dwarf the stones in Machu Pichu!
Very impressive ruins. Huge stones carved into what looks like the teeth of a puma. You can see stones shaped like a guinea pig, and excellent view-point to Cusco.
Satified Falcon. Hit the sit too late in the day to really spend the time needed. Need at least a couple of hours and spend the 20 Sols on a guide. Question them first

Love the huge rocks. Hire a local guide at the entrance, they are very well prepared and are able to tell you lots of stories that makes your time in there more enjoyable... The guide was able to get 100% attention span of my 9 yrd old with cool stories
Can be missed. Is great if your really into visiting incan sites, however could be missed. Lots of Americans.
Too little time!. We visited here as part of a tour with Condor Travel. The guide was very informative but we could have spent a lot longer here....too much to see in such a short time!

overwhelming !. found the size and grandeur nearly impossible to absorb.....how was such amazing construction achieved ?.......the large amount of tourists slightly marred the experience but i was still thrilled to have been there

Best view of the city.... A must if you are visiting Cusco - a lovely walk to get there, the view is spectacular and the stone chutes are worth a go on, no matter how old you are!! Very good fun and with all Inca sites - most impressive. Give yourself a good few hours to explore properly.

Sprawling and Wonderful. Next to Machu Picchu, this is one of the most impressive area of Inca ruins. To fully appreciate what is here, you need probably need to make at least a couple of visits to different parts of the area.
Nothing to really dislike, even the hawkers are not intrusive.

A great find. We didn't plan on visiting this, or even know it existed. The hotel suggested that we see it. We were really glad we did. Interesting ruins, great view of the city, and while you are inside the boundary of the park the street vendors are not allowed in. A taxi up from the city center was 10 soles. When we went down the taxi driver wanted 15 -20 soles. Only a few taxis at the exit of the park- supply and demand. I think you can take the series of stairs to walk down to the city but since we visited the site late in the day (it gets dark very early in June) we didn't want to be in an unfamiliar area at night.
inca ruins in cusco. amazing ruins just on outskirts of cusco. 2km hike from centre. christs statue at same spot. dont take a taxi just walk 40-50 mins

must see whilst in Cusco. Impressive ruins close to Cusco. We took a taxi up to the ruins and walked back to the town which provided great views on the way down (allow 1 hour if you take it slowly with breaks).
Fascinating site. The rock walls were built in a zig zag line reminding you of lightening. From the top you can look over Cusco.
Amazing. Historically important and unique. Plus the difficulty of building with boulders of this size is simply amazing.

Amazing architecture...incredible history. We visited Sacsayhuaman as part of the city tour offered through our hostal. It was 1 of 5 ruins we visited in a half day period. It was breathtaking...you must read The Last Days of the Inca to get a feel for the history of this place. I only wish we had more time, I could've spent a couple of hours here walking around.

A pile of rocks. But what big rectangular cut rocks. Simply amazed at how they were put in place by the Incas. Try and avoid the crowds. I walked up here first (not as bad as other reviewers claim) then later while on a 1/2 day city tour was driven up and got the explanation. Understanding the history a bit certainly helps puts this place in perspective. Great views back down over the city.
sleet. didn't get to see all of it, got sleet/hail during the tour! but the little that we did see, it looked well kept and full of history

Great place to visit. We did a half day city tour for 20 soles (great value) that took in the cathedral, sacsayhuaman and some other archeological sites up on the mountain outside Cusco. This place was great to walk around and explore and start a little light climbing to get adjusted to the altitude before going to Macchu Picchu! Unless you have been in Cusco a while, I would recommend getting a tour or taxi here - walking up from Cusco looks painful!
Beautiful ancient site. It was quite a climb to get on top of the huge rocks. Amazing how the ancient incas were able to form this. Makes one admire these ancient people and their abilities then,

A 'stone' throw away from Plaza Mayor, Cusco. Fabulous site. If you just landed in Cusco and would like to do an 'orientation' hike in altitude then walk up from Plaza Mayor to Sacsayhuaman (= 'Sexy Woman'). If you don't want to pay to enter site then walk up to Cristo Blanco on the opposite hill instead. You can still see a bit of Sacsayhuaman but I would recommend you pay and enter the site. Buy 'turistic' ticket for entries to tourist sites within Cusco and surrounding areas, it's worth it.
Immense stones. Very impressive. These stones are immense - some over 20 feet tall. Great views over Cusco.

Each ruins are so different.. Sacsayhuaman is 500 feet above Cusco. The Inca stones are HUGE--probably 18-20 feet tall. They were quarried about 5 km away, and then, somehow, dragged here. The stones are in the shape of a jagged lightning streak. There is also a view of all of Cuzco. We took a taxi here from our hotel in Cuzco, had the driver wait, and then he took us back to the city. This was 25 soles, about $9.00 and so well worth it. There are alpacas grazing on the flat field at Sacsayhuaman, and this is where crowds come to informally play soccer, or to gather for the Inti Raymi celebration on June 21. We didn't spend a lot of time here, but I certainly think it is worth seeing to complete your idea of some of the major ruins.

One of four Inca sites near Cusco. We did what a travel book recommended, and took a taxi to the farthest of the four nearby Incan sites on the road to Pisaq (about 8 km along), and walked back to Cusco visiting each one until we reached the most magnificent of them all, the ruins at Sacsayhuaman. The size of the stones used to build the zig-zag walls is unbelievable. We know they harnessed lots of human power, but still, the engineering knowledge was remarkable. Sad to know that the conquistadors were so fearful and hateful they had to tear down anything and everything they did not understand, and that it was not until sometime in the 1930s that the Peruvian government finally put an end to allowing builders to help themselves to what was left of what was obviously once a massive fortification/temple.

Go to say you saw "Sexy Woman". By the time i saw this i had been through Machu Picchu and the Sacred Valley, so i was pretty caught up on the histories and piles of rocks, but still, it's a cool site to see.

Impressive stonework. Expect to see some huge stone blocks set up in a zig-zag design. Take a walk to the top terrace, where you will find an awesome view of Cusco. You can pick out all the major sites from this hilltop - even the airport off to the far left. There are a few ladies dotted about selling their craft work and some colourfully dressed women who will gladly pose for photos with you with their Llamas or Alpacas for a few Sol.

Hire a car and go on your own. Sacsayhuaman is amazing... I would have liked to have seen more of it if only our organized tour guide had let us. The site is right outside of Cusco. An adventurous traveler could even walk there from the outskirts of Cusco. I would hire a cab to take you there and wait. Then you have the ability to walk all over the site and really check it out from the top.
Amazing. Words cannot describe... visit Sacsayhuman, you wont regret it.
Alzheimers charity trek. Amazing ruins and wondering how the Incas moved these giant stones in to place. Apparently the centre of the Earth
Spectacular and HUGE!. ENORMOUS stones fitted together to make serpentine walls and other structures (Inka). Beautiful setting on hilltop with views of Cusco.
Sacsayhuaman Inca site. Fascinating in all respects: the engineering behing that construction is awesome.

Pronounced (Sexy Woman). Was a delight to witness some of the most amazing ruins in Cusco during the Inca civilization. The site is still used today for the annual Inca festival in June. This site is part of your tourist ticket. A must see!
The Biggest Rocks. Sacsayhuaman is big enough to handle the crowds and has something for everyone--stone slides for the young at heart and awesome Inca stonework for those interested in archaeology.

A great place to visit when in Cuzco.... A large fortress used by the Incas that was mostly destroyed by the Spanish....alot still remains and you can see the entire city of Cuzco from the top. Recommended !

Great place to start. The stones in this place are amazing, as is the view over the city of Cusco! Highly recommend seeing this place and understanding the history. All roads led to Cusco in the Inca Empire. Not something I knew before this trip.

so close and interesting. This is right above the city of Cusco. A taxi ride up makes it an easy site to see. There are guides who will show you around (about $10 American) and then it is a nice walk back down to the heart of Cusco. Great display of Incan ingenuity with amazing walls. Llamas and alpacas grazing on the large grassy area and local families enjoying the area, playing soccer or picnicing.
get a guide. I would suggest strongly that you use Natalie with Travel Peru company...passionate about the history, well informed, and totally a fabulous guide!!

Try to go before you do Machu Picchu. That's what we were going to do, but since we were trapped in La Paz for 4 days we had to do it after going to MP and I can asure you, nothing is spectacular once you've been to MP
amazing inca architecture. interesting, and so near to the city. nice half day tour to see the amazing inca architecture and how they build the city years ago.

How did they move those stones?. More impressive Inca ruins. Just fantastic walking up and down the paths and marveling about how they fit all those stones together. Don't forget your soles for your picture with the lady with the llama.

Massive. Up on the mountain just outside of Cuzco, this place was another example of just how different all of the ruins are. Peru is just an amazing place to visit with the sites are awe inspiring, Sacsayhuaman was a lovely place to have a walk around and unlike some of the other places didnt seem to be as crowded when I went (mid morning). Would have also been a great place to go for a picnic (just to sound typically english lol).

Extremely impressive. In the 15th C thousands of workers moved, cut and built with massive stones a village. It is estimated that at its' height; it may have housed 10,000 pepole. The spaniards dismantled much of the site however they could not move the massive bases. These form 3 tiers of a zig zag wall of @1,000 ft. The zig zags are thought to be something they used in defense but this area seemed much more than just a fortress. Today this area is a terrific park area which is lit at night. People bring picnics or cook potatoes, llamas and horses are about...it is just below the Statue of christ and is a great spot to visit and marvel at the sheer size of the rocks that were placed there

amzing stone structures. We had a very enthusiastic and knowledgeable guide named Carlos on our city tour. Only two other couples were with us.The site is built with massive, highly finished Inca stones. This was a religious pilgrimage site of great importance to the Incas.Extremely interesting and makes you wonder how they were able to do such fine and extensive work with primarily stone tools, no written language

"Sexy Woman". If you can't pronounce in the Native language, this is as close as you'll get. Don't walk up from Cuzco should you be over 40 years of age, or an Olympic Athlete. Down is a lot better.. maybe 40 min.. Up could be hours, or require a MediVac.More of a magnificent testament to Inca technology than Ollantaytambo or Machu Picchu... stones up to 350 tons...and none existed on the mountain ( as opposed to Machu Picchu ). Not to be missed if in the area.

do not miss!!. amazing views of cusco and the mountains surrounding the city. We paid a guide 20 soles (£5) and she showed us round the site for approx 30 minutes. She offered to take pictures. Don't go for the first guide when you go in, walk in and around for a few minutes and don't be afraid to ask different guides for their prices.

Go if you are a student. It was a fun cool place, you get to walk in and around the area, and if you are a student you can buy a discount pass that lets you go there and many other cool places. It is a very easy, fun hike to get there, and you can hike to Cristo Blanco from there in 10 minutes. It has great views of the city.

Quite a site. I wanted to go here after hearing about it on Ancient Aliens. It was very cool to see the site in person. I was there as the sun was setting and it gets cold fast when the sun goes down in May. It is set up on the mountain side from Cuzco so you can get a nice view. We were dropped off on one side and walked to the other side where our bus picked us up. At the exit you will find ladies selling crafts for very good prices. You will also see more wild life like Llamas.

A surprising must see right there in Cusco. It would be easy to go to Cusco and never even know that this extraordinary Inca site exists, but don't miss it. The base stone walls are incredibly impressive but we loved the very heavily glaciated hill opposite the walls and the ruins beyond. Suggest getting a taxi up to the site then walking back into Cusco.

Interesting archeological site with a great view.. An intriguing Inca ruin located high on a mountainside on the edge of the city of Cusco. Great views of the city and an interesting drive through the Andean countryside
important historical ruins. great views, massive stones carved into walls. How did they get there? place to just hang out for day and walking distance to the white christ.

Sexy woman. Our guide told us the only way to remember the name of this place is to pronounce it Sexy woman! The Incas were incredible, how they built what they did is difficult to comprehend. The site is superb giving an insight into the Inca culture and technical know-how. The guide was extremely informative about the site so if you do go make sure you book a proper visit with guide otherwise you will just wander around the place with no real comprehension of what it is all about.
The view is amazing. The site is very interesting and gives you a great view over Cusco, you have to visit this site if you are around Cusco.
worth driving by. and taking a quick photo but not much to do there. the size of the rocks are definitely worth seeing though as they very unique

more than I expected. fascinating site. We took a taxi to Tambomachay and walked back down to Sacsayhuaman. It's fun to walk around and discover all of its different sections - much bigger than I thought it would be and well-preserved.
Impressive. I was still getting over altitude acclimitization, but was still impressed by this large site. Interesting building techniques. Great views of Cuzco.

Dont miss this place. me and my family did a Biking tour to city our cusco and this was the highlight of our biking tour, I could not believe that incas built all this structures without having any current tools. visit this fantastic fortress to be appreciated

Beauty of nature. The beauty of this place is simply out of this world. When you step out of the rat race into a place like Cusco, you are rewarded with a plethora of options and each of them are simply beautiful
Take a guide. Great site(s) to visit. Guide provided history to each site visited. Well worth visit. Main site also offers high viewing point over Cusco and surrounding valleys.
First tour of trip. Good introduction to building methods. Huge stones; amazed at how they moved them

If you had to visit one Incan site. This would be the one to visit. The views are stunning and the stonework is unbelievable. Make sure you hire one of the licensed private guides waiting by the entrance. Ask for Adrian if he is around...it is totally worth the 30-40 soles for the tour. Those guys are full of information about everything and University educated.
Sacsayhuaman - not to be missed. Great ruins. Worth getting a guide as you enter to bring it alive for you.
Unik. Master work of stones, very unik...Just visited quickly, but amazing.

Make sure you have a guide. This site is not to be missed. Wear something you can slide in so you can join the locals in the natural slide. There are guides available at the gate where you pay to get in they are well worth it and add a lot to the experince. You might as well see the other 3 smaller sites that are nearby when you see Sacsayhuaman, if you like your guide they will go to the other sites with you, but those sites have guides there as well.

Our first taste of the Inca/Andean culture.. Our guide (Americo from Wildnerness Travel) gave us a thorough and interesting tour through Sacsayhuaman. It set us up for all the other ruins up to and including Machu Picchu

Boletto turistico rip off. To get in here you have to first purchase a Boletto Turistico. It is very expensive and it allows you access to 4 historic sites. Might seem like a good idea except that it is only valid for 1 day. Rushing around to 4 sites to get your moneys worth is blackmail. If you would like to see Sacsayhuaman then get out of bed at day break and just walk in. The ticket office staff do not start work until at least 8am so since there are no gates or fences you can walk around for free early morning.
Very pretty. Its a 20 min walk from Plaza de Armas. Great views of the city below..and stunning ruins. Its a must if visiting Cusco.
A great walk.. We walked up here twice. A great walk and very beautiful.
Stunning. Referred to by the guide as "Sexy woman", this site is well worth the visit
Close to city. 2nd best Inca ruins in Peru. Close to city, with lots of easy walking areas to explore.
fantastic. go before 3pm no bus and almost alone to visit. cheap for guides at the door and very professionnal. do not miss
History. This beautiful area is worthseeing. We were guided and that is important.

Amazing. We travelled to Peru and had a guide with us during our stay. We drove to this site and walked the site. To fully understand this remarkable place a guide is wonderful to have such as ours was, or at least take a travel book that will explain what took place here. Worth the visit. Beautiful day we had as well...check out the Llamas on site too.

Large site, nice green grounds. We had a private tour of the sites on a lovely sunny morning. Some areas closed for reconstruction, then toured the other 3 sites - Q’enko, Puca Pukara and Tambo Machay. We walked to two of the sites then back to Cusco - about 5 hours in total. A guide can explain so much more about the sites than just walking through them.

Very interesting step in the history of the Incas. It is an impressive example of Inca ruins and was a good stop on our travel through Inca history. This site was the only site that is fairly flat and open but still showed the great building ability of the Incas.

Most peoples first view of Inca ruins.... While making the journey, most will spend a day or two in Cusco. This would be a must see site and probably the first Inca ruins most people will be exposed too. While the Inca military fortress is quite impressive in itself and worth seeing, the Inca archaeology sites get much better down the road.

Unbelievable Site!. We hiked up from the neighborhood of San Blas where we were staying to see Sacsayhuaman. The ruins are fantastic. Make sure you climb to a high view point to see that the shape of the entire complex is the head/teeth of a puma! I recommend getting a local to show you around for a nominal fee. For the most part, they are very proud of their heritage and know many cool details that I would have never found out on my own!

A great introduction to incan architechture. You're sure to see lots more on your trip, but Sacsayhuaman (pretty easy to pronounce once you say it a few times) was the first Incan treasure we got to see and we were so impressed by the Incan builder's skills and determination. A beautiful site.

Awesome!. I personally found the temple structure of Sacsayhuaman more inspiring than at Machu Picchu -- it's mind blowing to imagine rocks that are twenty times the size of the average human being moved and stacked manually to form this amazing and sacred temple. That is, Machu Picchu is awesome in itself, but I found this area to be doubly so. There are assumptions as to how the temple was built, but I don't think anyone really knows how it was done. Each tour guide will give you a different impression. Rocks that weigh thousands stacked upon rocks that weigh thousands???? Go figure! In any case, this is a DEF MUST visit on your travels through Peru. One of my favorite parts of the trip!

Brilliant Inca Ruins. On this occasion I didnt use a guide, so probably didnt get all out of this trip I could have done, however that said, the archaeology here was amazing and spoke for itself, well worth a trip, to appreciate the skill of the Inca builders. 70 Sols to get in approx £17
"sexy Woman". Another sight that just makes you contiue to wonder "how did they do this". very interesting how this city got it's name.

Walking adventure. We walked from Casa-Cartagena until Sacsayhuaman, it was a nice experience, the park is located only 15 minutes from Cusco, hike was easy, we did a short walk around the park by ourself and enjoyed this green and sunny area

Great ruins $4 cab from Cusco. I was very impressed with these ruins. I had been studying up on the Incan rebellion and these ruins were verything they were supposed to be. Perfectly placed and cut, these massive/gigantic stones are something that need to be appreciated.
The Incas were incredible!. Every site, including this one, just leaves you with the feeling of "WOW" - how did the Incas do that?
Dramatic site. Imposing zigzag fortress of huge stones; last holdout of the Incas. The walk down to town is lovely and you get a great view of the Plaza de Armas.

Large Inca site. Located very close to Cusco, can actually be visisted by foot. I would recommend to get there by taxi and return walking as the road is very steep. It is worth a visit if you do not have better plans for the day and the weather is pleasant.

it didn't do much for me. I hired a guide so had quite a detailed visit. Most of the site has been stolen over the centuries for building materials for other buildings. Some of the stonework is very impressive but overall it didn't do much for me.

Another Incan ruin. Walked to Sacsayhuaman from Plaza de Armas. Go to San Cristobal and you'll find your way up to this site. It's just another Incan ruin. If you do it yourself like we did, you can pay an entrance fee to walk within the ruins. You need a passport (if you do it yourself) to tour inside. Since we didn't bring ours, we walked to the White Christ nearby where you can take top view pictures of the site. Thought this was better since we didn't pay. So you have a couple of choices - go with a tour group, hire a cab to take you there, walk if you want/need exercise (about 20-30 min. hike from Plaza de Armas) then pay the entrance fee or hike up the White Christ for a free look. The Cusco view from the White Christ site is amazing. Lots of locals offering us horseback riding option which got annoying. At least 4 different horseback riding offers on our walk to the site.Wear sunscreen, comfy walking shoes, bring water and your camera. Lots of llamas grazing, there's a creek and nice view of the city.

Large and mysterious!. Our guide said that Sacsayhuaman most likely was from the pre-Inka time, as it wouldn't have been possible to build all this in the Inka period. Also, the doors and steps of Sacsayhuaman were very high, - indicating that people at that time were tall, which the Inka's were not. You should visit it if you're in Cusco!
Walk right in the center of the ruin. I liked being able to walk among the ruins, though there were parts closed off that I would have liked to see. Parts were so accessible, and others not so much.
On the way to the Sacred Valley. You'll be impressed by the Inca stonework. The views are nice from this location.

Head of the Puma. This hilltop ruin overlooks the beauty and expanse of Cusco. The trails are well maintained, and the street vendors are kept to a minimum. This is a perfect place for a half day hike or a nice picnic - the strolling alpacas add to the ambience.

Disappointing after Ollantaytambo and Machu Picchu. We had already seen the stunning ruins at Ollantaytambo and Machu Picchu before we arrived in Cuzco. Unfortunately the Spanish had managed to plunber and destroy most of the ruins and used the rocks to build their cathedrals. We did the ruins on our own by hiring a cab who turned out to be a guide as well and spoke excellent English. We were also restricted from visiting certain parts of the ruins due to the extensive archaelogical work being done. From the ruins there are great views of Cuzco and it is definitely worth the trip just for the views.It is possible to walk to Sacsayhuaman, Quenko, Puca Pucara and Tambo Machay however it is a long hile and if you are affected by altitude sickness as we were you will find it very difficult and the walking times quoted are grossly understated.

Impressive!. Go with a taxi to all 4 ruins close to Cusco, for about 40-50 soles. Sacsayhuaman (Sexywoman) is really mindblowing. Get a guide at the site (for 10 soles) and hear the extraordinary stories of the Incas who built this place. An absolute MUST SEE!

SEXY WOMAN - sacsayhuaman. If you do not have enough time to see Machu Picchu, this site is well worth seeing. Here you will find the biggest/heaviest rocks that the inkas modeled and moved to this site. Several inka symbols can be seen. Taking a guide is worth while as he/she will show you every detail possible.Don't miss to use the sliding rock... :-)
Great Tour. Highly recommend doing this tour and hiring a guide at the location. Very interesting.
A huge impressive Inca stone structure. Very clever early use of interlocking stone to withstand earthquakes.
Buy BTG and visit. You can walk or take a taxi from Cusco. Not too special on a regular day.

Trip to Sacsayhuaman. Took a pre-arranged guided bus tour to see Sacsyhuaman and several other nearby sites. The sites are stunning, but it is a shame that the time allowed to enjoy them is minimal. Something like 15 minutes to take photographs and then rushed back into bus which is on a tight schedule to allow room for other buses. If you want to spend more time here, it may be worth contracting a private tour but not sure how much more time this would allow you. Rushing and altitude sickness is not a good combination!

Take a hike up the hill!. we walked up to Sacsayhuaman on our own time! It was worth it the view is beautiful and it is about a 1 hour hike with lots of scenery to enjoy. I would recommend getting a guide for this tour because the place is large with many hidden treasures!

Unique stone walls and great views. This site overlooks the city of Cusco and it's possible to walk there from the Plaza de Armas (though it's all up a steep hill). The site is pretty large and the huge walled plaza with three terraces is spectacular. Stones that weigh tons fit together perfectly - an amazing feat. Lots to explore. After seeing some other small nearby sites, it's certainly the most interesting and impressive. If you are planning on going to any other ruins or museums in town, you should get the tourist ticket (either in town or at the entrance). You'll pay for it by visiting two sites.If you're feeling up to it, you can take a local bus to the ruins of Tambomachay (11 km outside Cuzco) see them, and then walk back to town via the highway visiting Puca Pucara and Qenqo on the way and arriving at Sacsayhuaman (all on the tourist ticket). It's a pretty easy downhill walk most of the way, and the scenery is nice. Go in the morning to avoid rain. It will take a few hours.
What amazing rock walls!. On of the best Inca ruins we saw. the HUGE boulders used for the lower part of the walls boggle the imagination at how they built the wall.
A site to behold. A testament to man's ingenuity and perseverance to build things in a Grand Scale.
impresive. i was there during the night and seeing this was wonderfull, seen the ilumination of the stones, the amazing sky with the full moon just priceless

Helped me understand much better the Inca culture. I like history and to understand the origin of the places I am seeing. I visited Sacsayhuaman without a tour, but hired a guide there, that was great! Before this I did the Sacred valley tour so I was done with buses and organised tours, and had already some knowledge about the inca constructions. For me, to visit the whole "city tour" was very interesting, this is the group of 4 ruins, each one with a specific purpose in the life of the incas. And doing it with out a guide, doesn´t have any sense because there are so many not obvious things that must be explained by somebody that knows about it. Days after this I was in Machu Picchu, and of course it is overwhelming. I still think visiting Sacsayhuaman and the other ruins was good, in Machu Picchu the constructions made sense to me inmediately ,mainly because of all what I learnt before, even when the guide in MP was great. Cut it out of your itinerary only if you are really short in time. I was lucky to have time to visit all the ruins around Cusco. Tip: If you can, hire a guide recommended previously. In Sacsayhuaman the first one we hired was terrible and because we knew a little already we realised that, then we hired another person, called Lucho (an antropologist) that not only knew a lot, but was passionate to share his knowledge. Don´t have any other information besides his name, but I leave a photo in case you see him there and recognise himTip2: Take in consideration that if you are visiting several ruins and sights in or around Cusco, is better to buy the whole Boleto Turistico that allows the entrance to this and other main sights.

Great views of Cusco / Able to wonder the ruins alone. We chose to walk from the city city to Sacsayhuaman. (Be prepared to breathe hard and take a few breaks along the way) It was worth the walk in my opinion as you get to pass a lot of schools w/open courtyards and see some village life. Also the largest Incan stone in Cusco is located at this site.

Skip this if you are going to see other Peruvian ruins. We were planning on visiting Sacsayhuaman, but saw it on a local tour bus and was glad we had not paid to go there. It is out of town, and it pales when compared with ruins in Pisaic, Ollantaytambo, Maras/Moray, etc.
S/P. Amazing place to do wachuma and chill all day.. dont forget your camera

Utterly fascinating. With a knowlegeable guide like ours,half Inca,you have a direct link to the culture-wow-were they industrious,complete masters of stone,artistic,musical-they put us Europeans to shame.

Unbelievable. You will not be able to beleive the size of the stones thast were used to build this structure....they are huge. Even pictures do not accurately tell the tale. An awesome view over Cusco as well.
Art of the Incas. Sacsaywaman is skillfully crafted and to a rock lover like myself it is exquisite.

How did they construct the site. What can one say. You have to see it to believe. It is a real wonder of the world. The construction of the site. How did they transport such enormous stone to the mountain top.

Fascinating archeological site. The historic site of Sacsayhuaman is a fascinating composition of inca buildings a natural formations atop of the city of Cusco. When visiting you should either make sure to have some knowledge prepared or book a guided tour. Apart from the travel agencies are some local guides on site who offer their services for a small tip. We did this a got a very good two hour tour of the site with many interesting insights about history, culture and special location of the site.

Definitely make the effort to come here.. Our guide said that this was not a military fortress....does not seem to have the layout and design or even the location that one would associate with a military stronghold. Never mind, the size of the stones used to build this are impressive, the views of the city below are very good, if you have come all this way to Cusco, then visit these ruins too. You don't have to be in such good shape, there is less climbing involved here and you can just walk around the large grassy area at the foot of the ruins if you wish and avoid climbing altogether. If you do climb, remember that you are almost two miles above sea level, so unless you are an athlete in great shape, climbing around here requires more effort than you might think.
Size and construction quality was very impressive. Very impressive Inca architecture. Take it easy as the altitude is over 12,000 feet. Great views.

FASCINATING INCA RUINS - GREAT VIEWS OF CUSCO. These Inca ruins are well worth the visit. There are great views of the city of Cusco and the huge stones used in the construction make you marvel at the engineering skills of the Inca. The ruins are easily accessible from Cusco.
no. what is there is very impressive, what is missing is sad.
Another don, miss sight. There,s so much to see, and area to cover that you could walk tell you drop it,s just great
Great example of Incan Architecture.. This site really showed/introduced you to Incan Architecture and was a great prelude to the Sacred Valley.
lots of good energy and peace. I been in Sacsayhuaman so many times and still going back ,
Amazing ruins from another world.... Excellent place, here you find giant Incan rocks which look from another world because of the size. Definetely is worth to visit it.
ruin exploring. nice start before u see MP!! This will be a taste of whats to come in Aguas Caliente.

Worth the walk. I encourage anyone to walk up from Cusco Plaza, as it is about a 30 minute walk, but the walk is easy, and the views are great. Hire a guide once there (Guido was great) and it is so worth exploring. Also, walk over to the Christo Blanco, as it is worth seeing and is only a 10 minute walk away.
Good side trip from Cusco. Be careful on those sacred rocks. They get pretty slick in the rain.

Worth the trip up the hill.. The enormity of the stones are amazing - the largest is 27 ft. high! The actual workmanship is comperable to Machu Picchu. Recommend going in the afternoon - Llamas grazing, and safer too.
wordless. is all wonderful, I would like to live here, has everything one would wish and even more

Impressive fortress, so-so tourist site. You enter Sacsayhuman with your tourist boleto, that 16-attraction item omni-ticket you get for 135 soles (Feb 2012). Most of the items are missable but Sacsayhauman should be a "must see." Sadly, no. There is a single explanatory photo at the entrance and then you are free to wander -- but wait! Turns out most of the citadel is fenced off from visitors. You cannot see enough of the ruins to gain an understanding of the fortresses' arrangements. The bulwarks, arranged in slants, for example were an innovate design at the time, centuries before the star-fortresses of Europe discovered the virtues of enfilading fire when defending a castle. The guides I overheard had very little information and some of it was obviously wrong: you build form-fitted 30-ton stones with water freezing and cracking the stone. (I heard this explanation throughout Peru but a little Goggling will set you straight.) Sacsayhuaman (it's a Spanish rendition of the Inca/Indian word 'sashaywama' (my attempt at the phonics). is the "head of the Puma of Cusco" (cuscah in the Indian tongue) and the fort plus the area below it were the heart of center of the world. Sadly, none of that comes across at today's exhibit. Far better to visit Pisaq which is stunning visually and a lot more fun to climb around.

A Bit confusing. It was pouring down rain and our guide seemed to be a bit lost in himself, but the ruins were certainly exceptional. I did not understand everything he was mumbling. From what I saw, Sacsayhuman cannot compare with Pisac or Machu Picchu.
Mirador. Stone fortifications which rival the pyramids for the size of the rocks which were transported there and manhandled into place. And the view over Cusco and environs is unbeatable.
A neat site to visit. Elaborate spanning space for a relaxing walk to get to experience some amazing stone architecture as well.

Mind-boggling!. It is mind-boggling to fathom how they could build such a place. The boulders are huge and they fit together like gloves. Great views of Cusco. It is a must see if going to Cusco. Wow!

A tribute to human hands and skill.. This site is right outside Cusco and is easy to get to by bus or taxi. While not as awe inspiring as Machu Picchu it's well worth spending a couple hours marveling over the huge granite stones that make up the site. This history is a little muddy but it's beautiful to walk through the field with these huge monoliths. Go in the morning before the tour buses arrive so you have the site more or less to yourself.

Forget City Tour, hire a guide from Plaza de Armas. For just 81 soles ($30) we had a private car with a brilliant local english speaking guide called Gustavo. We covered everything of the City Tour except the church with the temple of the Sun - which you had to pay extra for anyway. Just the two of us and the guide - and out of the tour times, so no bus loads was just fantastic.

Sort of OK. Went to Sexywoman right after landing in Cusco. An impressive view of Cusco, but compared to MP and Pisac, kind of boring. Glad we went there first. It was nice, but glad we didn't plan a special trip there. Can easily be seen in an hour.

Fascinating history, but only 20% of the original structure remains. I agree with other reviewers that the views over Cusco are lovely, but you can get great views of Cusco from Colcampata. Additionally, the stone work that remains is impressive and you have the opportunity to view the largest stone used by the Incas; unfortunately, not much of the original structure remains. I recommend going with a guide if you're interested in hearing about the history, but it's visually unimpressive.
A Must See. Wonderful, enormous and truly interesting. I highly recommend this site and it takes about 2 hours to go through it.
What a treat!. We didn't know much about these ruins until we arrived in Cusco. The tour was quite informative and a great prelude to the tour of the Sacred Valley.
Amazing work. The Inka sites in Cusco are a work comparable maybe with the pyramids!

Fantastic!!!. Very interesting inka ruins close to Cusco city surraunding a very greena park. Tha stones are bigger than the Stone Heege in UK! Cusco city has pume shape, and this is the dead of the puma! Nice isn't?

Beautiful Inca site. Beautiful site!Gigantic stones, beautiful landscape and excellent views over Cusco.It is only 20 minutes’ walk from the main square in Cusco and it is very easy to find. Sacsayhuaman is an impressive Inca site and therefore it is a must-see when in Cusco. Your ticket allows you to visit two smaller sites nearby that are less significant but the route that leads you there is gorgeous. If you have time don’t miss it. You probably need around 2 hours to visit Sacsayhuaman and an additional 2 hours for the other sites.
amazing sights!!. book a private tour!!!!!! its beautiful!!!! we did it on horse back.
Impressive. Must go- ruins are spectacular. Get a better look at the stone work and just how amazing it took to build these temples
Huge stones!. This is a very interesting site and well worth visiting. It is walking distance from Cuzco and has some of the most impressive Inca stonework you will see.

Fascinating. Impressive site 250m above the city of Cuzco. These zigzagging walls are made of huge monolith stones, largest ones weight over 300 tons and are 8.5m (28ft) high. Thousands of humans or aliens? Leaves you speechless!

Interesting, just very large and not alot of access. I liked the site, but it was really large, and I couldn't get to the places I wanted to get to. If you go on a tour, you won't get enough time, so go up by yourself.

Great little walk just out of town. If you find yourself with a nice day and some energy, and are not totally over ruins, it's a great walk up the hill. I didn't hire a horse or a guide, as I prefer to wander by myself with a camera, but the horse ride looks fun too.One thing no one warned me of was that I had to pay, luckily I had enough cash in my pocket to cover it.

Stunning site on the hill above Cusco. A must do for any Cusco visit. Fabulous Inca fortress with massive boulders forming the outer walls. If you're in good health go further up the mountain to the Inca water temple of Tambo Machay and get a guide to do the walk back to Sacsayhuaman and Cusco. Views of the city from the fortress are spectacular.

Amazing. Theres not much to the ruins left.. but the architecture and the manpower it must have taken to cut and move the huge rocks just tell you how amazing the incas are. Be sure to check out the view of cusco. Slide down "nature's slide" which is a bunch of rock formations that are so smooth you are able to slide down them.... and walk through the earths belly... which is an underground tunnel where you enter on one side into pitch darkness and walk through the passage way (without sight) and birthed out the other end with your soul cleansed....
Introduction to Inca engineering. Amazing to see the large stones fitted together without mortar and the engineering which withstood the weather and earthquakes
Huge carved stones, a must see!. There weren't many tourists here and the carved stones are just enormous - a really special place to make a stop at.

Love it!. I have been in Sacsayhuaman by day by night, at the time they let you be by night......as far as I know they do not let go into the site by night.Very mysterious and magic. The carved stones are awesome and so intriguing. One of my favourites while in Cusco

Impressive ruins near Cusco. We really enjoyed our visit to these ruins: the stonework is beautiful and impressive and there is plenty to see and walk around at this site.I'd recommend visiting this site at your own leisure, take a cab up, it is not too far. We visited during a day-tour where we visited multiple other sites as well, and wished we would have had more time to explore Sacsayhuaman.
Location unbelievable. It was a very interesting ruin. The construction of the walled fortress was incredible.

Visit First. Visit this place before you go anywhere else. If you go after Machu Picchu you'll just be let down. Also if your spanish is decent you can get a horseback tour from people around the ruins.
magnificent. Go early and walk from the top all the way down. The size of the stones is unbelievable.

Nice but fast.... The Sacsayhuaman ruins are huge and has interesting history + beautiful landscape/surroundings. However, in 20 minutes you are able to see everything and the city tour we booked gave us 40 minutes inside the site. So, it was a little boring.It was March and rained a lot the night before we visited the site, so the grass was soooo green. It was amazing to scent fresh grass overlooking ancient Cuzco. If you don't have too much time in the city , avoid it or spend no more than 20 minutes in Sacsayhuaman.
Beautiful and interesting!. We arrived and were greeted by a large rainbow. Amazing ruins and lots to see, don't miss this large site!
wau. Impression that seems the work of giants, I have no words to describe it, just wau
excellent way so get to know the ruins. We did a tour of the ruins around Cusco which is an excellent introduction prior to doing the inca trail and visiting machupiccu

Beautiful, go without a tour group.. Tour groups show up here, en masse, around 17:00 (late afternoon, depending on the season) or so. I would avoid them if possible, and certainly not go in one, to allow yourself some time to really explore this magnificent site.

Pronounced "Sexy Woman". This was an incredible place. Make sure you get the history of this place. The huge water filtration system that was constructed here for the people is amazing especially considering when this was built.
Simply amazing!. We only did the sacsaywaman portion of the tour and it was sufficient. try to do this in the morning or early afternoon because the wind get very strong later in the day.
Amazing. Just seeing the immense size of the rocks and the intricacy of the design was amazing. We took a tour that included this stop and it was definitely worth it.
a fabulous experience. Go on a tour as there are no explanations on site.

Another incredible site.... Sacsayhuaman has been my favorite site in Cusco for 38 years. On a hill overlooking Cusco, you'll get lovely views and an introduction into Inca construction before you head to Machu Picchu. Worth the trip to the edge of town!
Great introduction to Incan history!. The site is located in the highlands above Peru and is very interesting. We saw alpacas grazing there.
A stop one must not miss. The tour guide provided us with information that provided insight to the extent of the Inca Empire. A site well worth the visit.
Impresive Incan and other civilizations construction.. A place that shows the grandness of the pre columbian civilizations in the andean zone.
Very educational. This was our first exposure to inca architecture. The site is awe inspiring. The flat meadow in front is very captivating. Take the time to climb and you will be rewarded.

You must visit. We hiked up from Cusco on a beautiful October day. We were not planning on hiring a guide but decided at the last minute to do so. It was definitely the right thing to do. Instead of a 1 hour visit, we spent 3 there because our guide was such a wealth of information and the site itself so magnificent. No guide book or photograph do this place justice, it must be seen first hand. Prepare to be wowed, we were.
We can't build like that today. Another vast mind blowing site, we only got to explore a small part of it but the technical ability of the people was awesome.
Read before you go. It's quite difficult to take all this in when you first get there. A huge site.

So close from Cusco.... And so full of history!Besides the temple itself and its history, the place offers a great view of the city of Cusco. It won't take you long, and it will introduce you to the magical world of the Incas.
Don't miss. This site is worth 4 hours to visit. It is different than other sites but well worth the time.

This is at the top of our "must see" in Peru. The stonework here is another wonder of the world in my book! The sheer size of the boulders that comprise these walls is absolutely amazing. The way the walls are built, in a zigzag pattern is stunning. I am a huge fan of the Inca people for their ability to build walls of these proportions and to make them so perfect and so beautiful. Don't miss this when you are in Cusco and environs!

So close to Cusco it would be a shame to miss this. nice place, great stonework, of the 4 sites very close to Cusco this is the most impressive, the other 3 are rather dull and crowded (fountain, hill side fort and temple, I forget the names), but not an unmissable place.

Awesome site. Even though there is not much left, what is stil there gives a small picture of its former grandeur. I was a pleasure to walk around the ruins on a sunny afternoon and imagine what must have happened there

Good place for a horseback tour. There are ruins to see, and llamas roaming freely to take photos with. I went horse back riding with a kid that offered me a two hour ride for 25 soles. It was a fun ride and very interesting to see the ruins if you have a guide to explain the history of them. You can walk all the way back to town in 5 minutes from here.
Enormous stones. Some incredible stone carving on such a large scale. Definitely worth the visit.

the history of this place is amazing. Be sure to spend the time to read of the spanish conquest of this city and how this site plays an amazing part both culturally in the Inca history and during the conquest of this wonderful city. It is too bad that through the years, blocks have been removed and its not the site it was 20 years...but, it is still amazing.
Interesting Inca Site with massive stones. Visit the market shop and learn how to tell real Alpac garments from fake ones.

Nice To See. Visited Sacsayhuaman on a city day tour but you could probably do this on your own. The massive scale of the stones are impressive and how the Incas engineered such a site is truly astonishing. Beautiful view of Cusco from the top.
Great ruins. Very interesting and worth visiting....amazing what the Inca;s could do!
Oh so interesting. Sexywoman as we called it, was part of our tour of Cusco. The ruins are amazing.

Sexy Woman. Yes... that's how you say it. This place is huge... and a must see. The stone work is too amazing to describe - especially when many of the rocks weigh in excess of 100 tons. There are roaming alpaca... and many archeological sites to explore.
Worth a visit. The views of Cusco from Sacsayhuaman are worth the visit alone. Navigating around tour groups is challenging here as at other sites.
Just Incredible. The rock-work is amazing. The architecture and design is amazing. The idea of the place is amazing. Those Incas must have been visionaries. And hard workers too.
The beginning of the trip.... This area showed us the beginnings of what the Inca empire could have been.
Battleground overlooking Cusco. Don't miss this battlefield overlooking the rooftops of Cusco. In addition to the historical significance of the site, it contains great views of the city.
amazing. excellent inca site, we visited as part of pur llama path city tour. was windy so take a jumper!

Impressive and incredible. you wander through the site and wonder how they moved such large stones into position and with such precision. Even more proof of the ingenuity and skill of these people. Be sure to visit the other nearby sites where you can see Inca fountains and small fortifications. Worth the extra time and, I believe, included in the original ticket price.
fascinating. A fortress/city with a long, three tiered zigzag wall. Some the carved stones seem as long as rail cars. Simply amazing.
Worth the Visit. Was a short but tiring walk uphill from our hotel. Views of Cusco are fantastic. Ruins very interesting

Inka ingenuity. The Inka were incredibly precise in their mathamatical calcuations and used them in piecing together their granate walls. This task must have been very difficult but the precision is on display here.
Awesome. The engineering and sheer human effort to construct Sacsayhuaman (pronounced "Sach-see-woh-man") is amazing - almost hard to take it in.

Amazing stones. This began our tour and although bit rushed it was cool to see such large stones in place without mortar. There were alpaca grazing around and as others mention the views below of Cusco are very nice. Because its easily accessable from Cusco, one could go on there own and be able to spend more time here.

Nice to see. Sacsayhuaman is a very nice ruin to see, I don't think you need too much time here and can do it on your own. We did it with the city day tour and could have also easily done it on our own. It's an very interesting place and you have some nice views from here.

great views. We took a taxi to the site and hired an english speaking guide. Her english was better than my spanish but not by much. She did show us the hidden animals in the stones and gave us the gist of what we were seeing. The views of the city from up here were great. We walked back to town.

Historic Site right in Cusco. I hiked up to the site right outside Cusco and met Fredi at the gate. He provide a guided tour that was very complete and well worth it. He was well prepared and the site has lots to see from the Pacha Mamma ceremonial caves to the architecture of the temples. I walked up to Qenko as well which was less worth it but also interesting.

Too little time. As with so many sites, I would have liked more time here to wander, at leisure, and to learn more about the site. Our guide's English was poor and I feel there was so much more to learn
Fascinating place!. I toured it as a part of my city tour with Ernesto, an outstanding guide. Great preparation for visiting Machu Picchu.
Impressive site. Very interesting site. Good introduction to Inca architecture. Great views down over Cusco.
Great Experience. This is the up point of the day tour which includes Sacsayhuaman, Kero and Pucapucara.
needs to be cleaned. it is nice but thaee you can see a lot of garish, it needs to be cleaned
Must see!. Absolutely amazing and breathtaking! Do not miss this site.

Hiked from Plaza de Armas. We liked hiking around these Inca Ruins to get acclimatized to the altitude our 1st day in Cuzco, and to see a bit of the town. There is a white statue on the next hill that we hiked to and then some more ruins up the hill.

Amazing Stonework and a Nice View of Cusco. Sacsayhuaman is the largest and most impressive ruins site within a few minutes of Cusco (Pisac is a good hour away, as is Ollantaytambo). It's easy to take a taxi here, or you can walk from Cusco (if you're a masochist), but the best way is to go here with a tour guide so he can explain to you about this site.The most impressive feature of this site is the stonework - it stretches the imagination to think how the fairly primitive Incas could have collected these massive stones, shaped them so perfectly, and fit them together absolutely seamlessly - you can't even slide a blade of grass between the stones! The site was built in about 1508, and purportedly took between 20,000 and 30,000 men over 60 years to build. Of course, like most Inca sites, when the Spanish came, they figured such mastery must be the work of evil spirits and destroyed it in the name of Catholicism, so there isn't a lot of it left now. People figure that the complex stood at least 10 feet higher than it does today.If you climb up the ruins, you can get a great view of Cusco, and a nice photo op with "Viva Peru" carved into the side of the mountain. The site is part of your "all-ruins" ticket for 130 PEN, or you can buy a ticket to this and two other nearby sites. There is a restroom here that is usable. Like all the Inca sites near Cusco, make sure to visit this site before Machu Picchu or it will seem quite unimpressive in comparison. It will only take a half hour or so to visit, it's not that big, but it is amazing to think that this city you're looking down on was once the capital of the Inca Empire.
interesting site + beautiful view of Cuzco. We turned down getting a guide at most places on our trip, but thought the guide for Sacsayhuaman was worth it. Ask for Veronika.

Interesting site after a 'breath' taking climb from cusco !!!. We decided to walk up to this attraction from Cusco. It was well worth hauling our unfit altitude distressed bodies up the slope / steps. There is the option of taxi or wooden bus ride - but wheres the satisfaction in that ?!!!The site itself is quite compact its very impressive to see the three tiers of stones, enourmous stones and wonder just how they managed to construct such an enourmous temple. There are also fantastic views across the valley cusco city below. We went on our own with no guide, only a guidebook - which we left behind !!! We managed to spend 3 hours looking at just the main temple !There are quite a lot of steps on the site so good practise for Machu Picchu ! We were a little annoyed that it wasn't possible to buy and entrance ticket to just this site we had to buy a ticket that included 3 other sites that we didn't have time / desire to see, so it cost us about £35pp. The alternative was to buy the cusco pass which was about $100. We noticed that most attractions on this pass were extremely expensive to visit independantly so this may be worth purchasing.Must say however that the bathroom facilities were very clean.

Great, interesting. this is a great way to introduce yourself to the Inca life before heading to Machu picchu..nice gentle walk around the stone walls ( gets you used to taking your time with the altitude adjustment ). I went as part of a tour groupl so we had a great english speaking guide, very infomative.

Massive stone walls. Impressive Inca stone walls. The site looks like a fortress, built of massive boulders cut to fit precisely. On the other side are an Inca cemetery, tunnels, and a natural stone slide. You can walk up, or take a taxi. Most people that walk take the path between the Cristo Blanco and Sacsayhuaman. Don't try to walk up if you are recently arrived to Cusco, it's all uphill and you will be sucking wind! There is no shade, so if it's sunny bring a hat or umbrella. There are bathroom facilities at each entrance. The cheapest ticket is 70 soles, which lets you into Sacsayhuaman and 2 or 3 other sites, but it's only good for one day. The other sites are up the road a bit, by bus or taxi. You can buy the combined ticket for 130 soles, which gives you admission to other archaeological sites and museums. There are craft vendors at the exit (where aren't there craft vendors in Cusco?).

slides, tunnels and llamas. Took a walk to Saqsaywaman as my first site on my tourism ticket and really enjoyed it.
