The walk is great practice for getting used to the altitude and for any further trips, and at the top provides an excellent view of cusco and the surrounding mountains.The ruin itself is quite large compared to others on the ticket, after the initial jagged formation make sure to cross the flat grass area and head on up the curved rocks (while we were in this grass area some llamas were being farmed providing entertainment as they chased each around us), on the far side of these are large smooth curved rocks which are good fun to slide down! At the bottom there is a circular patch of grass, on the far side of this is a hole which leads to a tunnel, this does become completely black as you walk through but just keep going and you will come out the other side of the rocks eventually! A nice way to spend a few hours on a quiet day.While here you can also walk across to the Cristo Blanco, i wasn't particularly impressed with the monument itself but there is a very nice view from it and you can continue walking up the road from here to Qenko and a little further to temple de la luna.

practice climb for machu picchu. I was sedentary prior to going to peru and didn't fully realize that there would be climbing involved. This was the first ruin our tourgroup went to and I was the last person to reach the top having to stop several times while carrying my heavy camera and lenses. I was not able to hear the tour guide's description but the view was breathtaking(well maybe it was the climb that took my breath away) After this initial shock to my body, I was able to circle machupicchu with ease.

Great view -part of boleto touristica. It may be better to see this before other sites, it's a great way to acclimatise to the altitude. A steep walk, but slippy if it's rained. You get a great view of Cusco and it's included on your ticket.

Nothing Special. Nothing special. Here you will see the largest rock (in Inka empire) ever moved to a site from a quarry, and that is about it. Oh yes on top of the Sacsayhuaman there is a great vista point to see the entire city of Cusco. If you have nothing better to do in the city then come here. Word of caution, if you do decide to spend the time here come here before you go to Macchu Picchu. This way you will at least not be completely disappointed.

I must have missed the point.... All the guide books and reviews build this up so I was somewhat looking forward to seeing this. However, by the time I´d visited Nasca, Arequipa, Puno, and Colca this just seemed like another Inca Wall formation to me.It was okay, my guide tried to make it interesting, but you´ll either love it or hate it. It´s marmite. By the time your tour is here you will either be totally clued in to all the Inca empire and fascinated by it all, or you´ll be looking for somewhere to get another Pisco Sour.Whether you like this place will depened which of the above camps you fall into.

Great Inca Ruin. Beautifull observatory on Cusco. Incredible Inca Ruin. The stone are amazing. Try the Inca slide ;-)
The view on Cusco and on the white Jesus is amazing. Great pics for sure!!

Must see if in Cusco. Nice place to spend the afternoon if its not too hot. Amazing inca walls and the size is amazing. If you have no idea what you are looking at get a guide to walk you around. Great view of Cusco on the top. It is hallowed ground considering the slaughter that went on here. Take a cab up to the ruins for 8 soles and walk back down to Cusco its a fun walk all downhill.

Astonishing. The stones are huge but, unfortunately, the Spanish destroyed lots of it so all that you can see are the foundations. It is still very cool, and almost next door is Q'enqo, which is very cool also.

Different than other Inca ruins, worth a trip. Given the proximity to Cusco, Sacsayhuaman is definitely worth the trip. It is different than what you will see at Ollantaytambo and Machu Picchu. Read up ahead of time and bring a map, since very little is marked at the site.

Fly over Ruins to see the Best Views. If you're walking the ruins, you won't see much because the best views are apparently from the sky--so fly over the ruins or skip this attraction and read about it.

Historically Important; Others in Peru are more impressive. We were looking forward to visiting the ruins of Sacsayhuaman for their tremendous historical importance. We found the ruins to not be as impressive as we had imagined. They are challenged by decay and very sad attempts at reconstruction from the Government. During the course of our trip, we found other ruins (Pisac, Ollantaytambo and Machu Picchu) to be much more impressive.However, the views of Cusco are absolutely stunning!More on our trip to Peru:http://justanothertravelblog.blogspot.com/2010/05/altitude-changes.html

Massive!. This place is best visited with a guide, so get on a organized tour and enjoy. The site itself is basically just rocks, but the way they are cut to a perfect match is stunning! If you want to see "inca" stonework this is the place to go before Machu Picchu. The view over Cusco is also nice. Set aside 1 hour plus time for getting there and back.

Sacsayhuaman carved rocks, together with absolute precision. This would be a spectacular fortress built with enormous carved rocks, together with absolute precision. Along with Machu Picchu and Choquequirao

These ruins are best visited by taking a tour. At almost any hotel, you can book a tour which takes you to a couple of sites in Cusco as well as the four sets of ruins outside the city. Sacsayhuaman is one of them. The entire tour takes about 4 or 5 hours and doesn't cost much so it's advisable to take the tour. It's the easiest way that I know of to see these ruins. We toured these after walking over the ruins at Machu Picchu, Ollantaytambo, and Pisac. They didn't seem so impressive after all of that but there is some history here.

great place to visit. We came by later in the afternoon (near 5:30). The ruins were almost deserted. A local guide came over and -- noticing that we were feeling the altitude, picked some wild mint and had us smell it, making us feel better. He gave us a tour (there is no set fee -- just a voluntary contribution). We spent about an hour there, but could have spent much longer. Our tour was informative and very affordable. The ruins are majestic and the views of Cusco did not disappoint. We did not walk over to the mini-Christ the Redeemer statue nearby, but if you have time and energy, don't miss that one.

Bigger is not always better. We weren't crazy about Sacsayhuman. There just isn't much left there to give you a soild feel for what the structure must have been like. If you do go, I would suggest a guide (we didn't use one). But we were more impressed by Q'uenqo. Though it's much much smaller it was simply more interesting to explore.

Interesting but Tiring. My husband and I eventually made it to Sacsayhuaman after a horseback tour gone wrong. By the time we got there we were exhausted so we possibly weren't as impressed as we should have been. We probably should have gotten a guide since much of the sprawling site seems rather unplanned without someone to guide you through what it once looked like. Still, guide or no it's certainly not the kind of experience that you just can't miss so if you don't have time for it on your visit don't despair. If you do go hire a guide and be careful when you pick a horseback tour.

Must see/do, impressive. The last review is way off. Sure it seems like an incomplete set of rocks because it is 75% destroyed by the Spaniards and Cusco government. For hundreds of years they stole rocks from this fortress to build Cusco. Although it is the top Sun Temple where Inti Raymi is performed, it is really built like a heavy fortress. It was so strong the Incas were able to hold off the Conquistidors from taking it over for 2 months and the only way they took it over was by cutting off the water to it. The remaining foundation and lower walls is utterly impressive in size and design. The rocks used are the largest I've seen in any of the ruins, including Macchu Pichu, at over 500-700 tons. The design is powerful with two dry moats and only 3 enterences. I felt impressive military power from this ruin that Macchu Pichu does not have, as it is much more a city dwelling with light military defences. Our guide said he lives down the hill from it and when he was a kid while playing in the filed next to the ruin a massive earthquake occured and he said he say the massive rocks slip and slide appart and go back and forth during the quake and the all settled back into their original possition after the quake as if nothing happened. He says the Japanese since visited and studied this site to learn how to design buildings to survive big quakes. With all the crazy cuts and angles of the rocks, there was a genius to it that will likely take many more years to even more appreciate.You have to see this one with a guide if possible. We did it as part of a horseback city tour. The landscape was nice but not impressive since we are from the SF bay area and are used to the similar type of mountainscapes of that area, but if you are from flatlands, then horseback might be your most interesting way to go. There is a beautiful natual vulcano rock formation in front of the ruin. Of course, pictures don't do any of these things justice.

I can't see the puma!. Compared to Machu Picchu, Sacsayhuaman (pronounced unusually like sexy woman) seems like a pile of rocks and much more of a tourist trap. It's definitely worth seeing because it is huge, but I couldn't really see that it was supposed to be a puma. Although the one geographically interesting point is the stones carved by glaciers that came through millions of years ago. Other than that, once you leave you are subjected to a borage of locals looking to make a sole. Make sure to purchase the sites pass as it will save you money if you are going on a day tour.
